name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Anderson has asked for the floor on a point of order.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, many apologies, and I know it was a difficult decision, but I did want to make the point that the decision to decide to delay the vote is, to our delegation anyway, a big problem in terms of how it is perceived by the citizens of Europe, who are very concerned about this. So I wanted to stand up and make that point. (Applause) (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I will give you the floor after the announcement I make.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, I have another point about Amendment 27, and the ordering of Amendment 27 on the agenda, because again, this is designed to confuse citizens. It should have been taken as a whole, and then the other parts should have been falling. I agree that this is a procedural point, but there was a lot of support for Amendment 27, and I urge the President to think again about that issue in future.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Anderson, listen for a moment to the Presidency's communication, then you can have your say. Some group leaders, who represent the majority in the Conference of Presidents, have informed the President of Parliament that they wish to postpone Mr Lange's report on the negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership. At this point the amendment can only be made on a proposal from the President to amend the agenda in accordance with Rule 152. In order to enable Parliament to vote on the proposed amendment, the President agreed to table this proposal. I therefore put to the vote the proposal to postpone the Lange report by roll call. If there is a representative who wishes to speak in favour of postponement and a representative against referral back. Anyone who wants to speak in favour of postponement, given that the proposal has been tabled. I believe that parliament's will must be respected, since Parliament will vote, the sovereign House will decide what to do, and the House will decide what needs to be done.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report We have all been preparing for today's plenary debate and the planned vote, and we learned yesterday of the President of Parliament's decision that we cannot vote today. Because there have been various rumours, I would like to make it clear that our group would have been prepared to vote today. However, since the vote does not take place today and the committee now has to vote again on the amendments, it makes sense that the vote and the debate should also take place together and that we then debate TTIP and the report when we know what will actually be put to the vote. I therefore ask that we hold the vote together with the plenary debate when the committee has met again, and that we therefore do not hold the debate today, but postpone it until the right time. (Applause)

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report and for the It has just been said in the explanatory statement that the group chairmen, who have the majority of the votes in the group chairmen's committee, have turned to the President to put the debate on hold today. I would like to say that I consider this to be very problematic, because you are also suspending institutions within this Parliament. They are doing all this without at least asking the representatives of the various groups here without being consulted. That's an aberration! You can always hide behind paragraphs. One can always claim a right – such as the fact that too many amendments have been tabled. What I think is necessary, however, is that there should be consultation before hand and with each other. That is unacceptable! And we, as a group, are protesting against this way, in which Parliament is slowing itself down, that we are putting our own rights aside. (Applause) Millions of people are waiting for what we are doing today. And you just push it aside. If we want to represent the people we have been elected by here, then at least they have the right to hear Parliament's voice, whether or not you like it from the majority side. We are not responsible for the grand coalition ... (Applause) ... cannot agree here in Parliament. This is a move, an unworthy move, in which we will no longer participate! (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: This is service information, so that we know that 116 amendments, 87 requests for roll-call votes and 10 requests for split votes had been tabled for the vote in plenary on the Lange report. In accordance with Rule 175 of the Rules of Procedure, President Schultz, after consulting the chairman of the Committee on International Trade, asked this committee to meet to examine these amendments and requests. The vote has therefore been postponed. We are now debating the debate, whether or not to hold the debate, not the vote, because the vote has been postponed on the basis of Rule 175 of the Rules of Procedure by decision of the President.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Mr President, you anticipated me, because in the first stage of this debate it was not clear whether the vote or the debate should be postponed. You have rightly made it clear that the vote is not under discussion. The vote was suspended by a decision by the President of Parliament which postponed the resolution in committee because of the large number of amendments. We appreciated Mr Schulz's wisdom, because Parliament's problem is not – I beg your pardon – to show itself, but to deliberate. We would betray the confidence of the citizens if we do not take a decision and, faced with the real risk of not having a resolution, President Schulz has done well and this is not the first time in the history of this Parliament. Point! Secondly, we are not for or against the debate. For us, the debate can be there or can also be done together with the vote when there is a vote. For us this is not a straight issue, but the central issue is that in the face of the lack of agreement between groups, not just majority groups, groups on the resolution, President Schulz wisely decided to refer the vote back to the committee responsible.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what is this European Parliament where the President decides to manipulate the regulation because he is afraid that he will not have a majority for the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership and because he is afraid that he will not have a majority for the ISDS system? What is this Parliament where the Liberal right believes that debate on a subject of interest to citizens should be spolised? What is this European Parliament that is afraid of the vote, afraid of debate and afraid of European citizens?  Frankly, let's debate and vote!

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The fact that it is only 8 o'clock in the morning is a relatively exciting debate in the European Parliament. First of all, I would like to make it clear once again that the question of whether or not we are discussing today is decided by Parliament's plenary. That is why it is not decided behind closed doors, but we Members decide whether or not to discuss. This is an absolutely fair procedure, and rightly so. Secondly, Martin Schulz has decided on the basis of the Rules of Procedure. The rules in the Rules of Procedure are clear: if too many amendments have been tabled and the House is overburdened with them, it has the right to refer the matter back. He also deserves our support for this in order to properly discuss the work of Parliament. Thirdly, in terms of party politics, I am afraid to see the two extremes in the House, namely the left-wing radicals and the right-wing radicals, talking to each other in rage and, on the other hand, the Greens standing alongside these people. I am very concerned about this. (Applause)

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Weber, I think that you really should think again about this last accusation. If anyone who is critical of private arbitration under TTIP is now being pilloried as radical left-wing or right-wing, then I wonder what kind of cooperation we have in this House. (Applause) There are many Colleagues sitting here, especially on this page, but also on the side that promised their constituents during the election campaign that these private arbitration tribunals will not exist! I can read these promises everywhere. This vote and the debate are being postponed today. Martin Schulz is doing this, based on the Rules of Procedure. Martin Schulz is in favour of postponing this vote because it is no longer clear how his group, the Socialist Group, stands by its campaign promise. (Applause and cries) Mr Pittella, we have already taken votes with far more than 200 amendments. The fact that this is not possible now is because Mrs Malmström's proposal ... (The President cut off the speaker) (Tumult in the Hall)

name: Syed KAMALL
text: – Mr President, let us be quite clear about this: we were willing to vote. It is because of the dishonourable behaviour of the Left in this House that we are not voting today. Is that right? (Applause) We thought we had an agreement, but that agreement was turned upon. So what we are now discussing is whether (we are not having the vote) we have the debate. Now let us be quite clear: you are absolutely right, the citizens out there – those who care – do want to hear us discuss this issue. But it is absolutely right that we have the debate at the same time as the vote. You can get as excited as you like and have your debate now, but let us have the debate so that it is fresh in our minds when we have the vote. And when I see the Greens and the Socialists talk to each other in that friendly way, can I suggest that not only do we need a dispute mechanism at international level, but probably here in Parliament for the Left. (Considerable applause)

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, this is what the citizens expect. The citizens of Europe expect us to hold this debate now. We have had over 2 million citizens petitioning us to deal with this Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership issue. We have had phone calls, we have had emails to every single one of us in this House. We have been deluged. People care about this issue. What are we doing this morning exactly? This morning is scheduled for us to debate TTIP. It is on the agenda for today So what do we do? Do we go back to our offices? Or do we actually do what people expect us to do, and hold a debate? The choice here is a choice between democracy – listening to the people – or going back and doing things behind closed doors in the European Union way. We have to hold this debate today, because that is what is expected of us by the people of the United Kingdom, of Italy, of the whole of Europe. (Applause)

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I share the indignation of those who, this morning, expressed exactly what the citizens think. We are a Parliament of bureaucrats when it suits us and a Blah Parliament when it is not comfortable for the majority. We are truly shameful. Rules are only used when it suits them and I would like to remind people in the middle that they are anchored to an old idea. You are within an old ideological idea of the right and the left, the good of the citizens and the decisions of common sense are neither right-wing nor left-wing, and I am really sorry to say this to you, Mr Weber. Today, common sense is demonstrated by the parties on the opposite side of this Parliament. Certainly not you in the middle.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The positions are clear, everyone has expressed their position. (By roll-call vote Parliament approved the request for postponement of the debate) The agenda is thus amended. The sitting shall be suspended until voting time at 12.00 p.m.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, that is the second time today that you have ignored me when I was expressing good manners, standing up and doing the appropriate call for a motion. I wish to call attention to Title VII, Chapter 6 of the Rules of Procedure, ‘Interruptive and Procedural Motions’, Rule 191: ‘Suspension or closure of the sitting’. This morning I raised this point before you. You stood up and walked away. You left me without answering my question. If 40 Members of this Chamber decide to stand up at this moment, we are entitled to have a vote on whether we suspend the motions and sitting today in response to the disgraceful treatment we have had over the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership issue. This will send out a strong message to our constituents that we are supporting them. So I am asking that 40 Members of this Chamber stand up, and we are entitled to a vote to suspend this sitting under Rule 191. Will 40 Members please stand up, if they support that opportunity? (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Your request this morning was made when the sitting had already been suspended. Now, under Rule 191, since 40 Members can request that the sitting be suspended, I must put the request for suspension to the vote. We do so by roll call, those who want to suspend the sitting and those who do not want to suspend the sitting. Voting yes means suspending the sitting, voting no means continuing the sitting. (Parliament rejected the request)

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, according to the Rules of Procedure, Rule 152, and I would also remind you of Rule 190 with the interpretation given, the date, time and time it will be taken must also be indicated, inso far as it is decided to adjourn a debate to a later part-session – it has not been done in this case. I therefore request that he be brought back to Mr Sleyn. Schulz that we need to know when there will be.  It is necessary, according to the Rules of Procedure, to give even now, place and time when the sitting will be postponed. This has not been done. I would therefore ask you to know when the vote on TTIP will take place and when the debate has been postponed. I propose, because it is possible to refer it back to INTA and do what we have to do to the Committee on International Trade at the next sittings to fix it in July.  We can also ask for a vote.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: This morning there was no debate on the updating of the debate or the vote. It was only discussed and it was decided to postpone the debate because the decision to postpone the vote had already been taken by the President. We shall proceed to the vote.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: Mr President, I will not hold you back for long, don't worry. I have a humanitarian concern. Humanitarian in the sense that I saw President Schulz in perfect health yesterday, while this morning, for a very important discussion, here in the European Parliament, I have not seen him. Can you therefore reassure us that President Schulz is in good health? (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: That does not seem to me to be a matter for the agenda.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: – Mr President, paragraph 12 should read, ‘Renews its call for the development of strengthened analytical and monitoring capabilities of Russian propaganda, especially in the Russian language in order to be able to identify, and respond swiftly and appropriately to, deliberately biased information spread in various EU languages; calls on the Commission to earmark without delay adequate funding for concrete projects aimed at countering Russian propaganda and misinformation within the EU and abroadʼ – and here comes the insertion – ʽwith professional reporting in line with journalistic ethics, standards and good practice’. The only aim is that we do not make counter-propaganda but just counter Russian propaganda.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Mr President, knowing that the Front National got a loan of EUR 49 million from a Russian bank, I consider there is a clear conflict of interest here, and the Members in question should be prevented from voting. (Applause)

name: Marine LE PEN
text: Mr President, I think you are probably using your impunity in this body to defame your colleagues. This is absolutely outrageous, sir. You know for a fact that the National Front borrowed from a Russian bank. We have never hidden it from anyone. But we, unlike you, we can't buy. So maybe it's a mirrored accusation?

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, I propose to add a new short paragraph after paragraph 19, as follows: ‘Stresses, in this respect, that the recently-adopted bill on undesirable foreign organisations that allows authorities to bar international NGOs seen as threatening Russia’s defence capabilities or constitutional foundations is a further worrying sign of the ongoing crackdown on civil society.’

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, it is even more worrying if colleagues from the extreme right are against this one. I propose that in paragraph 21 certain modifications be added: ‘The European Parliament calls on the Commission to propose legislation ensuring the full transparency of political funding and financing of political parties in the European Union, in line with the recommendation of the Council of Europe with regard in particular to political or economic stakeholders outside the EU. We call for transparency.’ (Applause)

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, I just wanted to ask Mrs Hautala if her amendment also concerned the financing of American, Qatari, Saudi, Middle East or Middle East banks and a few other places. In which case, we are happy to join.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, I can guarantee that this is a call for the full transparency of all foreign funding for political parties. (Applause)

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr. Speaker, my motion of order is based on section 175 of our regulation.  As you know, it allows the President of our Assembly to send a text back to committee when he presents more than fifty amendments or votes per division. I note that this is the case with the report that we are about to vote on. However, the President did not use this prerogative in this case. I therefore wonder, as do many of my colleagues, whether, when he had this prerogative used to vote on the Lange report, which was due to take place this morning, he would not have obeyed concerns that were slightly more political and partisan than purely technical. I give this reflection to your judgment.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: It is too late to raise the issue, however the issue is the president's discretionary power. So the president decided based on his discretion. - After the vote.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I wanted to educate the next-door colleagues. If he had followed the vote closely, there would have been only a few amendments, but only votes on the original text. These were not amendments. Perhaps he should look at his voting list better.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I propose correcting an error and replacing the words 'in the next five years' with 'in this legislative term'. This has been agreed with the rapporteur, and I would ask you to agree to that.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: That concludes voting time.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: We now come to the explanations of vote.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, it is essential that we in Europe, as well as national governments, continue to face up to the problem of climate change. In 2012 the Kyoto Protocol, as the only existing and binding agreement under which developed countries undertake quantitative commitments to cut greenhouse gases, was amended so that it could seamlessly continue. The Doha Amendment creates a second commitment period from January 2013 to December 2020. For the EU and its Member States, ratification of the Doha Amendment does not entail any new commitments beyond those set out in the 2009 climate and energy package: a 20% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions compared to 1990 levels. EU legislation concerning the technical implementation of the Doha Amendment was adopted last year in May 2014. We all know that, in the long run, emissions will have a negative impact on many sectors, such as the environment, health and our well-being, as well as our economies. That is why I strongly support the objectives of the Doha Amendment, which ensure that, over the period until 2020, we continue to have a tactical and coordinated response to climate change.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, let us take it as read that all of us care about the survival of the species and of the planet. There is no one in this Chamber who wants our children to fry. That should not need saying but, given the tone of the debate, it evidently does. The argument is about what is the best approach in order to steward our resources: does it necessarily have to involve more bureaucracy, more wealth redistribution, higher taxes and more decline of state sovereignty? Now, obviously, if you happen to like all of those things anyway, it is easy to persuade yourself that there is no other method to control climate change. But I would suggest that the facts about the environment suggest something different. The countries which have done the most to improve environmental and ecological standards are the ones which have become wealthy and have therefore been in a position to do it. In fact, the best thing to have happened for the environment was the collapse of the Berlin Wall and with it, the smokestack industries, which was exactly what those in the left of this House supported at the time. Cheer up, things are getting better.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I too was pleased to support these proposals and delighted to see them adopted by a large majority: 584 out of 651 voting in favour. This extension to the Kyoto Protocol by the Doha Amendment is very important in sending a strong signal that we are serious about tackling climate change, as most people now agree that climate change is occurring and that it is a challenge to us. It is, therefore, very important – ahead of the Paris Conference in December – that we do everything to ensure that we keep to the 2° Celsius objective. Therefore, motivating businesses, motivating individuals and, above all, motivating other countries to come on board is going to be vital. If we do that, then we can make good progress.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – I, too, was happy to support this proposal, because I believe that awareness of the problem of climate change is very high, which is why it is important that this has also been adopted today in the European Parliament by such a large majority. Europe is a driving force in this area, but at the same time we have shown and demonstrated that there are a whole range of opportunities for European jobs in the area of green jobs. I am also pleased that, in recent times, other large emitters have followed these aspirations, and what has been impossible to expect for a few years to come is that China, for example, would invest heavily in renewable sourcing, in reducing greenhouse gas emissions, is a reality today.  I believe that at the Paris meeting at the end of the year, all sorts of other world-sized economies will follow these directions of Europe.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. U2012 Voting positively to the Decision to ratify, on the part of the EU and Iceland, the commitments of the Doha amendment mean sending a very positive signal. Ahead of the Paris Summit, the European Union tells the world that it wants to continue to lead the fight against climate change, setting an example while inviting the most reluctant and most polluting to continue investing in the future.  Doha is a good dressing to keep the Kyoto Protocol alive, but Paris must be the event that sees a new binding agreement born. It's about adding up wills, but also involving all parties alike in the search for a model that stops harming the planet and engaging our future generations. The G-7 has already sat down to talk about it and emerging people are seen with good predisposition. That is why the ratification of Doha by the EU and Iceland makes us proud that, despite the unrecorated criticisms of some 'climate-sceptic' sectors, we are on the right track.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change was signed in 1997 with the aim of setting an internationally binding emission reduction target. The EU ratified this Protocol in 2015. In 2012, the Doha Climate Change Conference approved an amendment to The Kyoto Protocol 1 establishing a second period (2013 to 2020) with legally binding emission reduction commitments for the parties. By this amendment, EU Member States and Iceland undertook to reduce their annual average greenhouse gas emission.  I supported this report which consents to the Doha amendment as a positive step, although I believe that the amended Kyoto Protocol is still a long way from effectively combating climate change on its own, as it lacks complementary measures, such as provisions on climate justice, as well as serious commitments to work by more industrialized countries.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. The Kyoto Protocol, signed in 1997, set an internationally binding emission reduction target: to meet the 8% commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions below 1990 levels in 2008-2012. The EU ratified this Protocol in 2002. At the Doha Climate Change Conference in December 2012, the Parties agreed on a further quantified emission reduction of 20% below 1990 levels for the period 2013-2020. For the European Union, its Member States and Iceland, this means limiting their average annual greenhouse gas emissions to 80% of their emissions in the base year (1990). The Doha amendment requires the adoption of the Kyoto Protocol by the Parties and will not enter into force until the instruments of adoption of at least three-quarters of the Parties to the Kyoto Protocol have been received. In its ratification decision 10400/2014, the Council adopted the Doha amendments to the Kyoto Protocol, which require the assent of the European Parliament in accordance with Article 192(1) and Article 218(6) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. I welcome this resolution because it provides a clear signal of the efforts and leadership of the EU and its Member States in combating climate change at international level.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The Kyoto Protocol set targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions under a binding legal framework. The Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol aims to open a second period of commitments of the Protocol, from January 2013 to December 2020. These Kyoto agreements now appear to be ineffective, as only European countries respect them when they are already among the least polluting countries. In addition, binding legal provisions have contributed to the deindustrialization of EU Member States. European states should not be used to promote the cosmopolitan ideology that uses ecology to increase the profits of the super-world class. They are also the only ones to apply these rules since all the other states in the world practice protectionism, which the Union refuses in principle. These multilateral commitments are ineffective but above all harmful to the peoples of Europe, so it must be stopped. For these reasons I therefore voted against this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ It appears that most global economies are likely to abstain on Annex B to the Kyoto Protocol. This will not come into force worldwide and therefore I believe that the UK should be able to make its own decision on this matter.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because the Doha amendment establishes a second commitment period for the Kyoto Protocol, until 31 December 2020. It thus reiterates the legally binding emission reduction commitments, under which the European Union, its Member States and Iceland commit to limiting their average annual GHG emissions to 80% of their emissions for the reference year (1990 in most cases) over the period 2013-2020.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: in writing. ‒ The EU should not commit to a second phase of the Kyoto project. There has been no climate change for 15 years and most global economies will abstain when called to ratify the new agreement.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: In writing. I supported Elisabetta Gardini's report on the Council's draft decision on the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the joint implementation of the resulting commitments. Indeed, the Doha amendment establishes a second commitment period for the Kyoto Protocol, which began on 1 January 2013 and will end on 31 December 2020. The amendment also provides for legally binding emission reduction commitments for the EU, its Member States and Iceland: limiting their average annual greenhouse gas emissions to 80% of those emitted for the reference year, i.e. 1990. I voted for this draft decision because we need to send a strong signal ahead of the Paris conference on COP 21 to fight climate change at the international level.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to approve the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. The Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change was signed in 1997 and sets an internationally binding emission reduction target. The European Union has taken responsibility for its commitment to reduce total greenhouse gas emissions by 8% between 2008 and 2012. In 2012, the Council agreed to propose a common eu commitment to reduce emissions by 20% compared to 1990 levels. This, known as the Doha Amendment, sets out a second commitment period for the Kyoto Protocol. I agree that the ratification of this amendment will send a clear signal that the EU and its Member States are working to address climate change at international level and are leading this process.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. In line with the Kyoto agreements signed in 1997, the Doha Amendment aims to open a second period of protocol commitments, from January 2013 to December 2020. These are targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions under a binding legal framework.  I voted against this text because the Member States of the Union are the only ones that really seek to respect the commitments made in Kyoto: once again, our States appear to be the turkeys of farce because the constraints we impose on ourselves are harming our industries, while our competitors have no such scruples.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The Doha Amendment establishes a second commitment period for the Kyoto Protocol, which began on 1 January 2013 and will end on 31 December 2020, and provides for legally binding emission reduction commitments, under which the European Union, its Member States and Iceland commit to limiting their annual average greenhouse gas emissions to 80% of their emissions for the reference year by 2013-2020. This commitment was determined on the basis of the total greenhouse gas emissions authorized during the 2013-2020 period under all climate and energy measures. It seems to me that it is essential at the moment to support an ambitious plan to combat climate change and greenhouse gas emissions. This amendment will extend the period of application of the Kyoto Protocol, so I can only welcome that.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. The ecological crisis facing the planet is a global challenge that requires a globally articulated response.  The Doha Amendment, which introduces a second binding commitment period to the Kyoto Protocol to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 20% compared to the 1990 base year, is a key step in the necessary transformation of our societies towards environmental sustainability and climate change mitigation.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it sets a new deadline until 31 December 2020 for emission reduction commitments, so that they are limited to 80% for the year referred to. This commitment was reflected in the climate and energy legislative package.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. Following the Kyoto Agreements signed in 1997, the Doha Amendment is to open a second commitment period, from January 2013 to December 2020. These are targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions under a binding legal framework.  However, these agreements are ineffective for a number of reasons, such as the fact that major polluting countries such as China or the United States are being sidelined, or that the good results in terms of reduction in Europe are mainly due to the slowdown in the economy and the loss of our industries. The Kyoto Protocol could go in the right direction if the effort were truly collective, but at present this agreement will only place constraints on the EU Member States. I have therefore decided to vote against this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Kyoto II package incorporates a reduction in CO2 emissions that the EU has already imposed on itself and has already achieved since the introduction of the 2009 climate and energy package. The ratification of Kyoto II until 2020 is nothing more than symbolic adherence to a protocol from which the major CO2-producing countries have already pulled out precisely because of its ineffectiveness, for these reasons I did not intend to support the report with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. U2012 Voting positively to the Decision to ratify, on the part of the EU and Iceland, the commitments of the Doha amendment mean sending a very positive signal. Ahead of the Paris Summit, the European Union tells the world that it wants to continue to lead the fight against climate change, setting an example while inviting the most reluctant and most polluting to continue investing in the future.  Doha is a good dressing to keep the Kyoto Protocol alive, but Paris must be the event that sees a new binding agreement born. It's about adding up wills, but also involving all parties alike in the search for a model that stops harming the planet and engaging our future generations. The G-7 has already sat down to talk about it and emerging people are seen with good predisposition. That is why the ratification of Doha by the EU and Iceland makes us proud that, despite the unrecorated criticisms of some 'climate-sceptic' sectors, we are on the right track.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the EU, of the Kyoto Protocol to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change and the joint fulfilment of its commitments. The Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change was signed in 1997 and sets an internationally binding emission reduction target. In 2002, the EU ratified this Protocol and committed itself to the implementation of the protocol in stages. In the first period (2008-2012) The EU has committed itself to reducing total greenhouse gas emissions by 8% compared to 1990 levels and by 20% in the second period (2013-2020) compared to 1990 levels. The Doha Amendment sets out the second commitment period for the Kyoto Protocol, which started on 1 January 2013 and ends on 31 December 2020, and the legally binding emission reduction targets.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported the adoption of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol, which is an important signal given by the EU in the fight against climate change. This comes less than 7 months after the start of COP 21 in Paris and follows a few days of the commitment made by G7 members to implement actions aimed at limiting the increase in the earth's temperature to two degrees in 2050. The extension of the Kyoto targets until 2020, as well as the global commitment to reduce CO2 emissions by between 40-70% in 2050 compared to 2010, appear to be achievable targets and are the key prerequisites for establishing a binding climate agreement for post-2020. However, we should not underestimate the importance of incisive diplomatic activity that aims to involve the greatest number of stakeholders, and in particular to commit emerging countries to binding emission reduction targets.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ The Kyoto Protocol and the Agreement agreed in Doha in 2012 are among the most important global agreements and therefore the European Parliament must give its clear and undivided support to this report.  The Doha amendment obliges signatory countries to reduce the average annual greenhouse gas emissions to 80% from 1990 between 2013 and 2020. I support this report because its adoption will send a strong signal that the EU still has a leading role in the world in terms of environmental protection and the fight against climate change.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the EU's commitment, within the framework of the Kyoto Protocol, to significantly reduce its CO2 emissions is one of the flagships of the Union's action and that, therefore, it is necessary to continue along this path.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Reducing polluting emissions is essential to safeguard the future of our planet and to combat the damage caused by climate change (climate tropicalization, extreme marine weather phenomena, alternating droughts and floods). The Union and the Member States have committed themselves to achieving the objectives set out in the Kyoto Protocol: today we must ratify the Doha Amendment, which starts our efforts together with the regulation that will enable us to technically pursue the objectives set out in the second period by reducing emissions by 21% compared to 2005 levels by 2020. The Regulation provides the necessary basis for technical legislative acts for the implementation by the EU and the Member States of the second commitment period. There is no denying the importance that the decision to ratify the Doha Amendment and the fulfilment of commitments by the Eu ropean Union will be: a strong signal in the fight against global climate change that certifies the Role of the Union as the leader of the issue. Because of the political, economic and environmental importance of the Kyoto Protocol, it is important that ratifications in the Member States take place by the third quarter of this year, so as to participate in a definite, unified and consolidated position at the UNFCCC conference in Paris.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. I voted against the report. The world's main polluters are China and the United States. However, these two states are not signatories. So how can greenhouse gases be effectively combated if those who are largely responsible for them are not part of the effort? With the Union, citizens of the Member States are used to sharing the punishments to which they are foreigners: it would now like to make them bear the actions of other continents. This is a counterproductive relentlessness of the Union.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Climate change is one of the most important challenges facing and requiring a responsible approach, as well as taking concrete action at global, national and regional level. Rising temperatures, droughts, floods and melting glaciers are increasingly rapid phenomena, confirming the existence of climate change. For several years, the European Union has been committed to the fight against climate change, both domestically and internationally, making this one of the EU's priorities. In this context, the Kyoto Protocol concluded in 1997, whereby the European Union and its Member States had a joint responsibility to fulfil their commitment to reduce their collective greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by 8 % from 1990 levels in 2008-2012. It was an effective tool used by the EU. In view of the problems involved in climate change and the steps to be taken to protect the environment, I welcome the fact that a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol is to be established as this helps to eliminate risks to the present and future population of the planet.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the measure. Kyoto II incorporates the -20% CO2 that the EU imposed on itself in the 2009 energy climate package. It barely covers 15% of global CO2 emissions.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. U2012 Voting positively to the Decision to ratify, on the part of the EU and Iceland, the commitments of the Doha amendment mean sending a very positive signal. Ahead of the Paris Summit, the European Union tells the world that it wants to continue to lead the fight against climate change, setting an example while inviting the most reluctant and most polluting to continue investing in the future.  Doha is a good dressing to keep the Kyoto Protocol alive, but Paris must be the event that sees a new binding agreement born. It's about adding up wills, but also involving all parties alike in the search for a model that stops harming the planet and engaging our future generations. The G-7 has already sat down to talk about it and emerging people are seen with good predisposition. That is why the ratification of Doha by the EU and Iceland makes us proud that, despite the unrecorated criticisms of some 'climate-sceptic' sectors, we are on the right track.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The Paris Climate Conference is scheduled for December. Despite the 1997 Kyoto Protocol arrangements, the lack of compromise at the Copenhagen conference in 2009 shows the difficulties of establishing a common agreement. It is more necessary than ever to take responsibility for global warming. The report calls on Member States to ratify the Doha amendment. It legally requires developed countries to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions by at least 18% by 2020. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the joint fulfilment of its commitments. The 1992 United Nations Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) sought to limit the rise in global temperature, but as early as 1995 it was clear that the agreement would be insufficient. The countries of the world have therefore opened negotiations to improve the global response to climate change and, in 1997, adopted the Kyoto Protocol, which sets an internationally binding emission reduction target. The EU and its Member States have therefore committed themselves to achieving their commitment to reduce their overall greenhouse gas emissions in the first period (2008-2012) by 8% compared to 1990 levels. The Doha Amendment establishes a second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol (KP CP2), which begins on 1 January 2013 and ends on 31 December 2020, and provides for legally binding commitments to reduce emissions under which the European Union. I am therefore delighted that the European Parliament has voted in favour of it.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This report gives consent to conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. The Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change was signed in 1997 setting an internationally binding emission reduction target. The European Union and its Member States were thus jointly responsible under the Kyoto Protocol’s compliance mechanism for fulfilling the commitment to reduce their collective greenhouse gas emissions in the first period, 2008-2012, to 8% below 1990 levels.  In December 2012, at the Doha Climate Change Conference, the 192 Parties to the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change adopted an amendment to the Kyoto Protocol, version one. This ‘Doha Amendment’ establishes a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol, starting on 1 January 2013 and ending on 31 December 2020, with legally binding emission reduction commitments for the Parties listed in its Annex B. Under the Doha Amendment, the European Union, its Member States and Iceland commit to limit their average annual greenhouse gas emissions in the years 2013 to 2020 to 80% of their base year emissions (mostly 1990). It was for these reasons that I voted in favour.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the ratification decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and the joint fulfilment of the commitments by the European Union will send a strong signal about the efforts and the leadership of the EU and its Member States to address climate change at international level. The Kyoto Protocol has made a crucial contribution in global efforts to tackle climate change. I believe that it is now important that all the Member States conclude their ratification processes in time for the Paris UNFCCC Conference in 2015.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, signed in 1997, sets an internationally binding emission reduction target. The EU ratified the same protocol in 2002. The so-called 'Doha Amendment' establishes a second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol with a deadline of 31 December 2020. In the light of the above, I voted in favour.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted against this text, which enshrines the huge equality that exists between the efforts of Member States to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions, and the most polluting countries that have strayed or are exempt from the Doha amendment. If this objective of reducing greenhouse gas emissions is indeed laudable, the amendment will prove to be, like the Kyoto Protocol, perfectly ineffective, for several reasons. First, while it is clear that countries such as the United States and Canada are the primary polluters, they have chosen to depart from the Doha framework, while emerging countries in the industrialization phase, which are themselves at risk of emitting more greenhouse gases, are not included in the amendment's annexes. Translation, only those states that have already made the greatest efforts will once again be penalized by an increasingly restrictive system. While the recent U.S. reversal in this area is to be welcomed, it is clear whether this recent change in attitude is primarily a matter of opportunism of convenience in this pre-election period.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 The recommendation voted on today on the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol is an important signal from the European Parliament to the governments of the Member States and also to the countries party to the Kyoto Protocol. It is a sign of the EU's renewed commitment to combating climate change. The amendments provided for in the amendment introduce, among other things, the possibility for countries that deem it appropriate to go beyond the emission targets set.  Formal ratification of the Doha Amendment is necessary because it contributes crucially to the pursuit of ambitious global efforts to keep the planet's temperature rise below 2°C.  With its policies and legislation, the European Union has in recent years waged an intense battle to combat climate change, but we need a global commitment and the involvement of those countries, still many, that have so far been reluctant to take on emission reduction constraints.  The adoption of this amendment is an important step before the International Climate Conference scheduled for the end of the year in Paris, where it will be essential to reach a global agreement. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We welcome the proposal for a Council decision providing the basis for the conclusion of the Doha Amendment by the European Union and laying down the conditions for the joint fulfilment of obligations by the EU.  The case for reducing greenhouse gas emissions concerns us all, because it touches on the health and quality of life of all the citizens of the planet. EU member countries are committed to reducing and limiting average annual greenhouse gas emissions in 2013-2020 to 80% of emissions.This commitment was established on the basis of the total greenhouse gas emissions allowed in 2013-2020 under the EU climate and energy package. I believe that we all have a responsibility in the face of worsening climatic conditions and we must respond to the call and commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in every way.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure concerning the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. The Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), signed in 1997, sets an internationally binding emission reduction target. The European Union and its Member States committed themselves to reducing their overall greenhouse gas emissions in the first period (2008-2012) by 8% compared to 1990 levels. In the Council conclusions of 9 March 2012, a 20% target was proposed for the second commitment period (2013-2020) of the Kyoto Protocol, which was then accepted by EU Member States at the Doha Climate Change Conference in December 2012, attended by 192 states.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of concluding the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol because I am convinced of the importance of reducing the impact of pollution on the atmosphere and I am also convinced that the individual Member State individually would not be able to set itself and achieve such an ambitious objective.  This amendment provides for a reduction in average annual greenhouse gas emissions by 80% for the period 2013-2020 by the Member States and Iceland compared to the reference year, which is usually 1990. I hope that in the not too distant future we will also be able to convince those countries that have the greatest impact on world air pollution to join, while now the whole weight or almost all of climate policies are on Europe's shoulders. However, only by adopting common climate and environmental policies will it be possible to pursue the objective of keeping the rise in the planet's temperature below two degrees. Congratulations to the rapporteur.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Kyoto Protocol, signed in 1997, has set a binding international emission reduction target. The Protocol was ratified by the EU in 2002.  In March 2012, the Council decided to propose a joint quantified commitment to reduce Union emissions by 20% below 1990 levels for the second period of the Kyoto Protocol commitment. This Council position was followed by the Member States during the Doa conference where the amendment to the Protocol was adopted. The Doa amendment establishes a second commitment period under the Protocol, which includes legally binding emission reduction commitments under which the EU and its Member States are jointly and severally committed to limiting their average annual greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in the years 2013 to 2020 to 80% of their annual reference emissions. I supported this recommendation, as with this ratification decision on the Doa amendment, the EU sends a clear signal to the efforts and leadership of the EU and its Member States in addressing climate change at international level.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Climate Protocol to establish a new commitment period (2013-2020) to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. We have a shared responsibility to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The Doha amendment to the Climate Protocol is an important step in the forthcoming negotiations on a new global climate pact.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Doha Amendment of the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the joint fulfilment of its commitments establishes the second commitment period of that Protocol. Amendments to the text of the protocol made by the Doha Amendment include the inclusion of a new gas (nitrogen trifluoride), the simplification of the procedure to allow a party to adjust its commitment by increasing the level of ambition during the commitment period, and a provision that makes it possible to prevent one party's emissions for the period 2013 to 2020 from exceeding its average emissions recorded in the period 2008 to 2010. This amendment does not change the environmental objectives and obligations of the Member States enshrined in the 2009 climate and energy package legislation, but will send a strong signal about the EU's leadership in this area. Therefore, in the light of these facts, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 In December 2012, at the Doha Climate Change Conference, the 192 parts of the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change adopted an amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. This Doha amendment establishes a second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol, from 10 January 2013 until 31 December 2020, with legally binding emission reduction commitments. Under the Doha Amendment, the EU, its Member States and Iceland undertake to limit their gases (GHGs) in the years 2013-2020 to 80% of their emissions in the reference year. For these reasons, I am voting in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change was signed in 1997 with the aim of setting an internationally binding emission reduction target. The EU ratified this Protocol in 2015. In 2012, the Doha Climate Change Conference approved an amendment to The Kyoto Protocol 1 establishing a second period (2013 to 2020) with legally binding emission reduction commitments for the parties. By this amendment, EU Member States and Iceland undertook to reduce their annual average greenhouse gas emission.  I supported this report which consents to the Doha amendment as a positive step, although I believe that the amended Kyoto Protocol is still a long way from effectively combating climate change on its own, as it lacks complementary measures, such as provisions on climate justice, as well as serious commitments to work by more industrialized countries.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the ratification decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol because I believe that this is the European Parliament’s chance to send a powerful signal in favour of stronger leadership for the EU and its Member States in order to address climate change at international level.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the adoption of the Doha Amendment establishing a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol from 1 January 2013 to 31 December 2020, providing for legally binding emission reduction commitments, thus proving that both the European Union and the Member States are committed to limiting their annual average of greenhouse gas emissions (GHGs) in the period 2013-2020.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes to give the European Parliament the agreement of the so-called "Doha" amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. The Kyoto Protocol, which came into force in 2005, contains binding reduction targets between 2008 and 2012. In December 2012, the Doha conference adopted an amendment establishing a second commitment period between January 2013 and December 2020. Under this amendment, the European Union, its Member States and Iceland commit to limiting their average greenhouse gas emissions to 80% from 1990 emissions, the baseline year. Considering that it is necessary for the Union's agreement to the Doha amendment to be given before the end of 2015 and ratified as soon as possible by the Member States and Iceland for the Paris Conference, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. By this vote, MEPs approve the Council's draft decision on the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. It establishes a second commitment period (2013-2020) from the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, with legally binding targets. We call on Member States to do their uedsing to ratify this amendment before the third quarter of 2015. The European Union will thus be able, at the Paris conference in December, to defend enhanced ambitions for the fight against climate change.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. Parliament has approved the conclusion of the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol, which establishes a second commitment period for the Kyoto Protocol. It began on 1 January 2013 and will end on 31 December 2020, and emissions reduction commitments are legally binding. The European Union, its Member States and Iceland are thus committed to limiting their average annual greenhouse gas emissions to 80% for the reference year (1990 in most cases) over the period 2013-2020. This amendment to the protocol is a strong signal from the European Union for the Cop21 in Paris which will take place next December. Given the stakes, the Union must be the driving force behind European ambitions to prepare for the post-Kyoto period.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted against the recommendation on the Council's proposed decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the joint implementation of the commitments that flow from it. The world's main polluters are China and the United States. However, these two states are not signatories. So how can greenhouse gases be effectively combated if those who are largely responsible for them are not part of the effort? With the Union, citizens of the Member States are used to sharing the punishments to which they are foreigners: it would now like to make them bear the actions of other continents. This is an insolent relentlessness of the Union which, in addition to stopping the inequalities it reinforces, should see the failure of its system.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the conclusion of the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol because I am convinced that only with the common efforts of all parties will we be able not only to make progress in the fight against climate change, but also to send a signal to the international community, and in particular to the US, Canada, Russia and Japan, which have not ratified climate change. By voting in favour, the European Parliament has re-reduced the obligations of member states and Iceland to reduce greenhouse emissions by 20% compared to 1990 levels by 2020. For our children to have a future, we must act now!

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation as the Doha Amendment establishes a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol, which includes legally binding obligations to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. I recognise the urgency of Member States ratifying by the end of 2015 the Doa amendment to the Kyoto Protocol, and the second commitment period is mainly supported by EU countries. Member States are already implementing a 20% reduction in emissions by 2020. A new agreement is in the foresee with experts and MPs joining forces to negotiate the text that will succeed the Kyoto Protocol, which is expected to be adopted in December 2015 and implemented from 2020.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation, because only the Member States of the European Union have to bear the constraints of the Kyoto Protocol. At present, the United States, for example, is not bound by any of its provisions.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Doha Amendment establishes a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol (2013–2020). In 2012, in the absence of a comprehensive and effective agreement capable of replacing it, it was decided to extend the Kyoto Protocol, extending with it all its weaknesses, including the perverse flexibility mechanisms. It is still the only legally binding emission reduction commitment. The EU, its Member States and Iceland undertake to limit their average annual greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in the period 2013-2020 to 80% of their emissions in the reference year (in general, 1990). This commitment was determined on the basis of the total level of GHG emissions authorised during the period 2013-2020 under the EU Climate and Energy Package, and falls short of that recommended by the UN Climate Change Panel, despite all the propaganda on the EU's "leadership" role in combating climate change.  We have supported this resolution, even though we know that much is part of the majority of Parliament in relation to the approach followed on the issue of climate change. The omission of the effects of liberalisation and deregulation of international trade and the absence of criticism of the carbon market should be stressed.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the Kyoto Protocol to the 1997 UN Framework Convention on Climate Change has set itself the objective of reducing emissions. The EU ratified the Protocol in 2002 and under the Protocol its Member States were responsible for reducing common greenhouse gas emissions by 8 % from 1990 levels in the first period 2008-2012. Subsequently, in 2012, the Council agreed and proposed to reduce emissions for the EU by 20% ( from 1990 levels). The Doha Amendment set a second commitment period for the Kyoto Protocol, which ends on 31 December 2020, where the EU and Iceland have committed to limiting their average annual emissions by 2020 to 80 % of the volume from the base year 1990.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 We reiterate our vote against. To be in favour of a greener world is not just to impose limits and disadvantages on Europe and its businesses.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Under the Doha agreement we committed to limiting our average annual greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in the years 2013 to 2020 to 80% of our 1990 emissions. I am in favour of ratifying the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol as it will send a strong international signal about the efforts and the leadership of the EU and its Member States in addressing climate change. I believe we need to increase political momentum towards a strong Paris agreement and this is why I believe all the other Parties to the Kyoto Protocol should rapidly advance their ratification process. This ratification is of tremendous importance to ensure the necessary global response to climate change. Signing the agreement will keep us united, on the right track, sharing a vision of a climate-safe world with sustainable growth for all.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. The fight against climate change, in which the EU must play a key role, is essential to continue decisively. That is why I think the Doha amendment is very positive, which establishes a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol, which began on 1 January 2013 and ends on 31 December 2020, with legally binding emission reduction commitments, under which the EU and Iceland undertake to ensure that the annual average of their greenhouse gas emissions from 2013 to 2020 is limited to 80% of its base year emissions. The EU should use all the tools at its disposal to add up to other international actors in the fight against climate change. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. U2012 Voting positively to the Decision to ratify, on the part of the EU and Iceland, the commitments of the Doha amendment mean sending a very positive signal. Ahead of the Paris Summit, the European Union tells the world that it wants to continue to lead the fight against climate change, setting an example while inviting the most reluctant and most polluting to continue investing in the future.  Doha is a good dressing to keep the Kyoto Protocol alive, but Paris must be the event that sees a new binding agreement born. It's about adding up wills, but also involving all parties alike in the search for a model that stops harming the planet and engaging our future generations. The G-7 has already sat down to talk about it and emerging people are seen with good predisposition. That is why the ratification of Doha by the EU and Iceland makes us proud that, despite the unrecorated criticisms of some 'climate-sceptic' sectors, we are on the right track.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. U2012 Voting positively to the Decision to ratify, on the part of the EU and Iceland, the commitments of the Doha amendment mean sending a very positive signal. Ahead of the Paris Summit, the European Union tells the world that it wants to continue to lead the fight against climate change, setting an example while inviting the most reluctant and most polluting to continue investing in the future.  Doha is a good dressing to keep the Kyoto Protocol alive, but Paris must be the event that sees a new binding agreement born. It's about adding up wills, but also involving all parties alike in the search for a model that stops harming the planet and engaging our future generations. The G-7 has already sat down to talk about it and emerging people are seen with good predisposition. That is why the ratification of Doha by the EU and Iceland makes us proud that, despite the unrecorated criticisms of some 'climate-sceptic' sectors, we are on the right track.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The text, for which I was rapporteur, provides the legal basis for the EU to conclude the Doha Amendment, as well as a necessary measure also to allow rapid ratification of the agreements by the Member States. It is right and proper that the EU should continue to play the leading role in the field of climate change, but it cannot remain alone in making binding commitments, as has all too often been the case in the past. These are very important commitments which are unfortunately only made to a large extent by European countries, while some of the most polluting countries do not participate. In this respect, the EU must use all possible political, diplomatic and economic instruments to ensure that cop21 reaches an international agreement that is as comprehensive as possible.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the Council decision on the conclusion, under the EU, of the Doha Amendment of the Kyoto Protocol to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change because I believe that the fight against climate change and the protection of our planet are fundamental challenges for world policy, as confirmed by the recent G7 discussions.  The EU is and must remain at the forefront of international negotiations, with the ambition of a bold agreement that will protection the environment and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The Doha amendment, by imposing a reduction in average annual greenhouse gas emissions for the period 2013-20 by 80% compared to 1990 levels, is a step in the right direction.  It is therefore essential for the EU to ratify it and for all Member States to implement it by the third quarter of 2015, so that it can present itself with a strong position at the Paris negotiations.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Gardini report on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto protocol, in which the EU commits itself to limiting the average annual greenhouse gas emissions between 2013 and 2020 to 80% of base year emissions, because we need to send a strong signal about the efforts and the leadership of the EU and its Member States to address climate change. Global warming is costing the world more than USD 1.2 trillion a year and EU citizens are telling us we should act. In the UK, nearly 70% of people say we are not doing enough to tackle climate change. Climate change is posing a threat to the security and well-being of all, but the EU can be instrumental in turning this around. The plan to have 90 000 diplomats in over 3 000 missions lobbying to win pledges on carbon cuts from countries ahead of the Paris summit on climate change shows the huge added value coordination on climate change on EU level can have.  The Paris summit will be crucial in tackling one of the greatest threats of our time. We cannot afford to fail.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. With the Doha amendment, the EU demonstrates its commitment to combating climate change by supporting the extension of the temporary scope of implementation of the Kyoto Protocol. In fact, the EU had already set its own target by 2020 to reduce greenhouse emissions by 20% compared to 1990 levels. What is worrying is the attitude of most other countries, which have not made binding commitments. We need an international agreement in which the major issuers step forward. Otherwise, the EU's efforts, responsible for only 11% of global emissions, will have a very limited impact.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. ‒ The EU needs to ratify the Doha Amendment if the EU or the Conference of Presidents are to carry any weight when it comes to tackling climate change. If the EU does not ratify the amendment, it will be seen as backing away from its responsibility to the environment and will lose any opportunity it has to take a lead on climate change negotiations globally. Having played an active role on many climate change related files in the ENVI Committee, I understand the technical challenges that lie ahead, but I am also confident that this Parliament will be overwhelmingly unified in its support of the Doha Amendment and I look forward to Europe proactively setting the agenda in Paris later this year.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted IN FAVOUR since the draft Council Decision forms the basis for the conclusion of the Doha amendment by the European Union, its Member States and Iceland. The text requires Member States to take the necessary measures to complete their national ratification processes by the third quarter of 2015. The Doha amendment establishes a second commitment period for the Kyoto Protocol, which begins on 1 January 2013 and ends on 31 December 2020, setting new limits on greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I along, with my Labour Party colleagues, voted in favour of this report as the ratification decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and the joint fulfilment of the commitments by the European Union will send a strong signal about the efforts and the leadership of the EU and its Member States to address climate change at international level.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for a Council decision on the adoption, on behalf of the European Union, of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the joint implementation of its commitments. Under this amendment, EU countries, together with Iceland, commit to a second period of emission reductions, during which countries will have to reduce their average annual greenhouse gas emissions by as much as 80% by 2020. In addition, the amendment also included a number of procedural clauses to ensure that this objective was achieved. I believe that the adoption of this recommendation shows that the European Union is determined to deliver on its promises and to combat climate change internationally, thereby encouraging the whole world to join this fight.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the proposal on the ratification by the EU of the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol to the UNFCCC. The EU has already committed to a 20% reduction target under its 2020 climate and energy package and so this does not in any way affect Member States’ individual obligations under the 2020 framework. By continuing its participation in the Kyoto Protocol, the EU is confirming its commitment to lead international efforts to stop climate change. This ratification simply means the international recognition of efforts already being undertaken by the EU. Even if only a few countries outside the EU have taken on legally binding targets for the second commitment period from 2013 to 2020, it is an important bridge between the current international climate regime and the new international agreement to be adopted at the Paris Conference in December.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ The Kyoto Protocol is a vital tool in the fight against climate change and today’s vote underlines the EU’s commitment to fulfilling its international obligations. The EU’s work is complemented by the efforts of individual nations and in this context it should be noted that my own country, Scotland, is now more than three-quarters of the way towards achieving its world-leading target of a 42 per cent reduction in greenhouse gases by 2020, with emissions falling 14 per cent between 2012 and 2013.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted IN FAVOUR since the draft Council Decision forms the basis for the conclusion of the Doha amendment by the European Union, its Member States and Iceland. The text requires Member States to take the necessary measures to complete their national ratification processes by the third quarter of 2015. The Doha amendment establishes a second commitment period for the Kyoto Protocol, which begins on 1 January 2013 and ends on 31 December 2020, setting new limits on greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. \u2012 It is important that the ratification decision on the adoption of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and the joint fulfilment of commitments by the European Union send an important message at international level. The EU must be a positive example of this.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft decision to amend the Doha Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the joint fulfilment of the resulting obligations, as it further strengthens the European Union's global role in international environmental commitments.  However, it also requires a strong alliance and a strong partnership that will involve other countries and powers that record high levels of pollution, as it is obvious that the European Union does not bear the whole responsibility, but is the same common. I support the fact that the amendment further strengthens the commitment under climate change and establishes a binding international agreement that is comprehensive and sustainable.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I have decided to vote against this text on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the joint implementation of the commitments that flow from it.  The Kyoto Protocol set targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions under a binding legal framework. The Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol aims to open a second period of commitments of the Protocol, from January 2013 to December 2020. However, it is now clear that these Kyoto agreements are ineffective, because only European countries respect them, even though they are already among the least polluting countries. On the other hand, binding legal provisions have contributed to the deindustrialization of our countries. European states must not be useful idiots of ecology and liberalism, which they are, and the only ones to apply, since all the other states of the world practice protectionism, which the Union refuses in principle. These multilateral commitments are ineffective but above all harmful to Europeans, so they must be stopped.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Elisabetta Gardini's report on the conclusion of the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. This essentially technical text allows Member States to join the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol, more commonly known as the "Doha Amendment" which was signed in December 2012. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This report has been, so to speak, nodded off by consensus, and I am abstaining from voting. The Council has agreed to set the emission reduction commitment below 1990 levels for the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol. A noble objective, but it is mainly EU Member States that join this commitment period, while the largest issuers do not. Although I am in favour of climate protection and halting climate change, I abstain because of this non-commitment of other states.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg. It is clear that climate change is happening and countries must agree on measures to prevent their negative consequences. The main challenge is to reduce greenhouse CO2 emissions. Countries that have committed themselves to achieving a certain emission reduction target have ratified the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. Unfortunately, all countries, such as the US, which are one of the biggest emitters, have not done so. The European Union emits only about 10% of global CO2 emissions. EU countries will not prevent negative climate change on their own, so the European Union must put pressure on other countries in the world to set the same targets as we do, because the fight against climate change must be carried out by everyone.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support the recommendation that the European Parliament give its consent to the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. It is important that the amendment be formally entered into force, as the Kyoto agreement, and extension thereof through the Doha Amendment, plays a central role in the global approach to tackling climate change. Furthermore, I strongly support the calls for Member States and Iceland to ratify the amendment domestically by the third quarter of 2015 to send a strong united message from Europe ahead of the Paris COP21 Conference in December.
