While the ratification should be seen as Europe taking a leading role in tackling climate change, it should also be seen as encouragement for other countries to act similarly to pursue a global solution to climate change.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly supported the recommendation to ensure that the Doha climate agreement, setting targets for emissions reductions up to 2020, is still ratified by the end of the year.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. – The Doha Amendment establishes a second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol (KP CP2), which starts on 1 January 2013 and ends on 31 December 2020, and provides for legally binding commitments to reduce emissions under which the European Union undertakes to limit average annual greenhouse gas emissions over the period 2013-2020 to 80% of their emissions in the reference year (typically 1990). The Lima appeal, adopted at the 20th Conference of the Parties in December 2014, encourages all 192 parts of the Kyoto Protocol to ratify the amendment. As of 14 May 2015, the amendment had been ratified by 31 countries but, for it to enter into force, it needs to be ratified by 144 parties. I voted in favour of this proposal because it represents a step towards full ratification and once again underlines the leadership of the EU and its Member States on climate change.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. Following the Kyoto Agreements signed in 1997, the Doha Amendment aims to open a second period of commitments of the Protocol, from January 2013 to December 2020. These are targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions under a binding legal framework.  These agreements prove ineffective for several reasons: - the main polluters (United States, China, Canada ...) have deviated from them; - Emerging countries are not included in Appendix 1, which sets out the list of countries subject to the reduction targets, while emerging economies are on the verge of emitting more greenhouse gases in the medium term than OECD countries. The fight against greenhouse gas emissions and energy transition requires above all monetary sovereignty and intelligent economic protectionism. Without it, the country that makes the most effort is ruined by imports of foreign material without being able to protect itself. So he's underprivileged. The private banking system does not have the means to finance the necessary investments that amount to tens of billions of euros a year for a country like France.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted against it. The Doha amendment aims to make reducing greenhouse gas emissions a binding target. But this will have no concrete results since the main polluters (United States, China, Canada, etc.) do not participate in the Kyoto commitments. European countries have performed well in the fight against greenhouse gas emissions thanks to a number of factors combined: technological advances, economic slowdown and deindustrialization. But some countries are not playing the game in the fight against these emissions, which has the effect of making Member States bear the costs.  It is time to put an end to this injustice. In addition, the UNITED States' commitment under COP 21 to reduce its emissions risks putting additional pressure on EU member states.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The report involves the mere process of allowing the Doha amendment to enter into formal force when the EU, and subsequently Member States, complete their planned ratification processes by the third quarter of this year, so that the instruments of acceptance are on the table for the decisive appointment of the Paris Climate Summit in December. This amendment to the Kyoto Protocol (decided at the 2012 Doha Summit) establishes a second commitment period, which began in January 2013 and should go until December 2020. These commitments mean that the EU and Member States are obliged to ensure that the average of their emissions in that period has a ceiling of 80% compared to emissions for the reference year (1990) and always taking as a whole the total emissions authorised under the Emissions Trading Scheme (STD). Agreeing with the objectives of this amendment, I voted in favour.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change was signed in 1997 with the aim of setting an internationally binding emission reduction target. The EU ratified this Protocol in 2015. In 2012, the Doha Climate Change Conference approved an amendment to The Kyoto Protocol 1 establishing a second period (2013 to 2020) with legally binding emission reduction commitments for the parties. By this amendment, EU Member States and Iceland undertook to reduce their annual average greenhouse gas emission.  I supported this report which consents to the Doha amendment as a positive step, although I believe that the amended Kyoto Protocol is still a long way from effectively combating climate change on its own, as it lacks complementary measures, such as provisions on climate justice, as well as serious commitments to work by more industrialized countries.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I am in love with it to protect the environment. However, I do not agree with the dogmatic approach of ignoring the possibilities of states, businesses and citizens. Green policies also create a lot of unnecessary regulations, the significant benefits of which are not substantiation and which represent a great cost to the economies of the Member States.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the ratification decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol because the EU has to promptly address the issue of climate change at an international level. A multilateral response to climate change, together with a smart, strategic framework for an Energy Union are two complementary EU policies. We cannot coherently tackle the issue of energy security and efficiency without taking into account climate change. In addition, the EU and its Member States are already implementing a 20% emissions reduction target by 2020, which in fact allows them to agree to implement their commitments for the Kyoto Protocol. We are witnessing extreme weather events: very high temperatures on the hand, and on the other hand the Western Antarctic and Greenland ice-sheets melting at unprecedented rates.While the oceans are warming and industrial pollution is booming we must not forget that nature takes care of us, so we need to take care of nature as well! Protecting our planet and the future of our grandchildren has to be our primary goal.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Advocate Elisabetta Gardini recommended on behalf of the ENVI Committee that amendments to the Kyoto Protocol signed in 1997 be adopted with a view to reducing greenhouse gas emissions. I support the recommendation to ratify the Doha amendment protocol as soon as possible in order to send a strong message in the fight against climate change towards the 21st century. The UN Climate Change Conference in Paris at the end of this year.  The Doha amendments propose a common commitment to reduce emissions in the second binding protocol period by 2020 of 20 percent from 1990 levels, which is also one of the five objectives under the Europe 2020 Strategy. After 2020, the protocol to be agreed at the UN conference in Paris will enter into force.  Achieving the greenhouse gas emission reduction target is a major challenge for all economic sectors that must contribute to their achievement and Member States need to make their proposals for the period up to 2020.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. The Kyoto Protocol, which regulates greenhouse gas emissions, is among the most important documents in the world. Together with my colleagues (584 Members in total), today I voted in favour of the amendment to the Protocol which will improve the situation of global warming on our planet.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ the Doha Amendment commits the European Union, its Member States and Iceland to reducing their average annual greenhouse gas emissions by 20% between 2013 and 2020 compared to the base year 1990. This commitment builds on the European legal framework for climate and energy policy by 2020. The proposal does not change member states' objectives or commitments under the legislation of the 2009 climate and energy package, thus respecting the principle that individual Member States' commitments to reduce their emissions in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol do not exceed their obligations contained in the EU legislation constituting this package.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the joint fulfilment of the relevant obligations, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 9/6/2015, but also because this recommendation sets out an ambitious target for reducing climate change, that of limiting average annual greenhouse gas emissions in the years 2013 to 2020 to 80%, both for the European Union and its Member States as well as for Iceland.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report. The Doha amendment provides for the opening of a second commitment period for the Kyoto Protocol, until December 2020, with targets to reduce greenhouse gas emissions under a binding scheme. We objected to this report because the Kyoto agreements prove ineffective: the main polluters (United States, China, Canada...) have deviated from it, the emerging countries are not among the countries subject to the reduction targets whereas in the medium term they will be very polluting and the efforts, when there are, are not collective. We therefore do not think it is necessary to continue with a second period of commitment.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. This protocol, signed in 1997, aims to reduce internationally binding emissions, thus making a fundamental contribution to global efforts to tackle climate change. I believe it is of the utmost importance to make legally binding commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, so that we can make all the climate commitments and ensure that Europe can help to make its commitments effective at international level.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Kyoto Protocol, signed by the EU in 2002, aims to reduce internationally binding emissions. The Doha Amendment inaugurates a second phase of compliance with the Doha Amendment, which will end on 31 December 2020. It includes legally binding commitments under which the EU, its Member States and Iceland undertake to limit average annual greenhouse gas emissions between 2013 and 2020 by 80%. I voted in favour of mrs Gardini's report, because I believe that we need an increase in efforts to tackle climate change.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. In 2002, the EU ratified the Kyoto Protocol with a view to reducing emissions. The so-called Doha Amendment establishes a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol, which began on 1 January 2013 and ends on 31 December 2020, with legally binding emission reduction commitments. My support, therefore, for the European Parliament's proposal for the conclusion of this Amendment and for the joint fulfilment of the commitments made under the Kyoto Protocol. We must continue in the EU our efforts to meet the targets we have set ourselves to reduce emissions by 20% by 20% and lead global efforts to combat climate change from Europe.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. In its conclusions of 9 March 2012, the Council agreed to propose a common quantified emission reduction commitment for the Union for the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol for the Union, below 1990 levels. I abstained because of the apparent non-commitment of other states outside the EU and the scientifically controversial view that climate change can be stopped by humans by reducing CO2 emissions.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as the Doha Amendment establishes a second commitment period (2013-2020) under the Kyoto Protocol. The Doha Amendment is a commitment by Member States to limit their average annual greenhouse gas emissions to 80% of their base year emissions during this period.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report validates the Council's proposal on the EU's commitments to the Kyoto Protocol for its second period, 2013-2020, validated at the Doha Summit in 2012. Meanwhile, states including the United States of America have not wanted to validate these binding targets to combat global warming. Moreover, according to the work of the IPCC, these efforts are far from sufficient. The EU would need to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by at least 30% by 2020, while it remains at the 20% target. The 'carbon market', the main measure to reduce European emissions, is ineffective. It allows polluting companies to resell their quota of right to pollute. But it also increases the debt of states badly by allocating public money to them to compensate for the excess emissions. It therefore prevents the development of other policies in favour of energy transition. I abstain. We cannot send a "strong signal" for the next meeting in Paris, COP21, without changing these methods and objectives. As the NGOs are asking, let's change the system, not the climate!

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The Kyoto Protocol set targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions under a binding legal framework. The Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol aims to open a second period of commitments of the Protocol, from January 2013 to December 2020. However, it is now clear that these Kyoto agreements are ineffective, because only European countries respect them, even though they are already among the least polluting countries. On the other hand, binding legal provisions have contributed to the deindustrialization of our countries. European states must not be useful idiots of ecology and liberalism, which they are, and the only ones to apply, since all the other states of the world practice protectionism, which the Union refuses in principle. These multilateral commitments are ineffective but above all harmful to Europeans, so they must be stopped. I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Doa Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the joint fulfilment of its commitments. A significant reduction in collective greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions is a clear sign of the EU's efforts and leadership in meeting the Kyoto targets to combat climate change internationally.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ The Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol establishes a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol lasting from January 2013 to the end of 2020. Signatories will commit to legally binding emission reductions and the European Union, its Member States and Iceland are committed to limiting their average annual greenhouse gas emissions in the years 2013 to 2020 to 80% of their base year emissions (mostly 1990). I therefore chose to support this recommendation as it will send a strong message at the international level that the European Union, its Members and its partners are committed to their efforts to address climate change.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – With the adoption of the Council's draft decision, Parliament confirms the EU's leading role in the fight against climate change. Doha's amendment to the Kyoto Protocol set out more ambitious and legally binding emission reduction commitments for the second commitment period, which expires at the end of 2020. In that second period, a reduction of 20% of greenhouse gases is pursued. The EU and its Member States have endorsed the shared ambition to limit harmful greenhouse gas emissions to 80% of the 1990 reference year's emissions. While the EU is making its commitment to the fight against climate change, it is regrettable that the major polluting countries are still lagging behind. The EU must use all its political and diplomatic means to convince these countries to join the fight against climate change. A new international agreement to follow up the Kyoto Protocol will be negotiated in Paris at the end of this year. It is already encouraging that, at their meeting in Berlin this week, the G7 Heads of Government agreed to further reduce greenhouse gas emissions by eliminating the use of fossil fuels by the end of the century.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing ‒ the Kyoto Protocol signed in 1997, the EU and the Member States committed themselves to reducing common greenhouse gas emissions in the first period (2008-2012) by 8% compared to 1990 levels. In 2012, in the Doha Supplement, the Council introduced a second commitment period (2013-2020) of the Kyoto Protocol, proposing a common qualified commitment for the EU, Member States and Iceland to reduce by 20% compared to 1990, thus the parties committed to reducing emissions to 80% compared to 1990. Furthermore, the Doha Addendum introduced three changes to the wording of the Kyoto Protocol concerning the inclusion of new gas (nitric fluoride), an ambition mechanism that allows a Party to adjust the commitment by increasing its ambitions, and provisions that prevent emissions from increasing above the volume of the first period in the second commitment period. I agree that, in order to achieve the effective adoption and implementation of the Doha Amendment before the start of the UNFCCC conference in Paris at the end of 2015, member states need to ratify the Amendment by the third quarter of 2015 at the latest.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. Under the Doha Amendment, the European Union, its Member States and Iceland commit to limiting their average annual greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in the years 2013 to 2020 to 80% of their base year emissions (mostly 1990). The ratification decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and the joint fulfilment of the commitments by the European Union will send a strong signal about the efforts and the leadership of the EU and its Member States in addressing climate change at international level. The timely consent of Parliament is necessary.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The amendment to the Kyoto Protocol was adopted by the 192 Member States at the Doha Climate Change Conference in December 2012. This created the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol, from 1 January 2013 to 31 December 2020. For this period, the European Union and its Member States and Iceland have committed to a joint emission reduction of 20% compared to 1990 levels. The second commitment period is therefore a very important stage in the fight against climate change. However, the amendment will not enter into force until it has been adopted by at least three quarters of the Parties to the Kyoto Protocol. The adoption of the Council draft decision is therefore a significant step in efforts to prevent climate change. The Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, of which I am a member, therefore supported the conclusion of the amendment, and that is why I supported it myself.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. Following the Kyoto Agreements signed in 1997, the Doha Amendment aims to open a second period of commitments, from January 2013 to December 2020, to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. These agreements are proving ineffective because the main polluters (United States, China, Canada ...) have deviated from them, and emerging countries are not included in the annex that defines the list of countries subject to the reduction targets, while their economies are on the verge of emitting more greenhouse gases than developed countries. The Kyoto Protocol could go in the right direction if the effort was truly collective.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of this proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Doa Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, as the formal entry into force of the Doa Amendment is among the priorities of the European Union, considering that the Kyoto Protocol is a key contribution to global efforts to combat climate change. The ratification decision on the conclusion of the Doa Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and the joint fulfilment of the commitments made by the European Union will send a clear signal to the efforts and leadership of the European Union and its Member States in addressing climate change at international level.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The Doha Amendment aims to extend the Kyoto agreements signed in 1997 through a new commitment period from January 2013 to December 2020. Its objective is to reduce greenhouse gas emissions through legally binding regulations. However, several elements will lead to the ineffectiveness of these commitments. First, the main countries responsible for these emissions are not affected. The list of countries to meet these reduction targets (Annex 1) does not include emerging countries that are destined to become the world's leading polluters. Finally, if the countries of Europe have had satisfactory results, it is primarily due to their technological advance, but also to the economic crisis and deindustrialization. In reality, this agreement imposes obligations only on the Member States of the European Union, once again confined to their idiots of the global village. Nothing is said about the necessary implementation of ecological protectionism, the only weapon capable of actually reducing greenhouse gas emissions. So I voted against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as the ratification decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and the joint fulfilment of the commitments by the European Union will send a strong signal about the efforts and the leadership of the EU and its Member States to address climate change at international level, and the timely consent of the European Parliament is necessary.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the conclusion of the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. Purely technical, it authorizes member states to join the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol. This commitment is important to continue our efforts to reduce carbon emissions and preserve the future of our planet.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Doha Amendment establishes a second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol (between 1 January 2013 and 31 December 2020) and provides for legally binding commitments to reduce emissions under which the European Union, Its Member States and Iceland undertake to limit average annual greenhouse gas emissions to 80% of their emissions in the reference year (usually 1990). We therefore welcome the draft Council decision on its conclusion. We regret, however, the non-participation of some of the most polluting countries. We believe, in fact, that the European Union cannot continue to be the only one to make all its climate commitments, any new international agreement will have to be ambitious, but at the same time more realistic if the objective of keeping the planet's temperature rise below 2°C is to be met. Our ratification decision today will certainly send a strong signal about the efforts and leadership of the EU and its Member States in tackling climate change internationally. We therefore call on the Council to ensure that national ratification processes in the Member States can take place by the third quarter of 2015.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour, in view of the amendment to the Kyoto Protocol adopted at the eighth session of the parties to the Kyoto Protocol, in view of the Council's request for approval and in view of the recommendation of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Gardini's report because I believe that the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol to the UNITED Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the joint fulfilment of commitments by the European Union is the right way to address these problems at international level. This document finally marks a new phase in which the European Union, its Member States and Iceland undertake, through binding targets, to jointly reduce annual greenhouse gas emissions. I therefore hope that the national ratification processes in the Member States can take place as soon as possible and that the Member States and the Union will be able to deposit their instruments of acceptance well before the UNFCCC conference, scheduled in Paris.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 As we all know, in 2012, as a result of the Doha Climate Conference, the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol came into force, covering the period from 1 January 2013 to 31 December 2020. For this stage, we have set a target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 20% compared to the reference year (which is the base year 1990 for most States that ratified the Kyoto Protocol). I am convinced that this will only work if we somehow get both the US and China to take the commitment seriously. We need to use our strength in the economic and diplomatic field so that we can truly treat climate change as a global issue. I believe that this is the only way to achieve the target – that is, to regulate global warming to 2 degrees Celsius. At Member State level, we must not delay but urgently ratify the Doha Amendment before the UNFCCC conference in Paris in November 2015.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: în scris. ‒ The Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change was signed in 1997 setting an internationally binding emission reduction target. I have voted for this report because it will commit the States Parties to reducing greenhouse gases and also because it is a valuable part of the momentum for global climate action.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The Kyoto Protocol should make a decisive contribution to global efforts to combat climate change. This includes the official entry into force of the Doha amendment as one of the EU's main objectives. It is important that the national ratification procedures in the Member States can be carried out no later than the third quarter of 2015 and together with the EU, so that they can deposit their instrument of acceptance in time for the UNFCCC conference to be held in Paris in 2015. I abstained from voting because of the scientifically controversial view that human climate change can be stopped by reducing CO2 emissions, and the apparent non-commitment of other states outside the EU.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This report aims at the European Parliament's agreement to conclude the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol on the commitment of the signatory parties to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The new agreement, signed in 2012, extends the first commitment period on binding emissions reduction until 2020. With this new agreement, the EU, its Member States and Iceland are committed to limiting their greenhouse gas emissions by 80% from 1990 levels. In order to limit as much as possible the harmful consequences of the air pollution of the major economies on global warming, I have, of course, voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the bill. The decision to conclude the Doha Amendment, which introduces a second commitment period up to 2020 on greenhouse gas emissions, sends a clear message that the EU is making efforts to tackle climate change. Iceland, which participates in the EU ETS, will also join the amendment. The EU must call on other major polluting countries to sign a binding international agreement establishing a level playing field so that the EU is not alone in meeting its climate commitments.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. The Kyoto Protocol is the palpable example of selfishness that reigns in the interests of many countries, and how the present is always more important than the future. It is also a test for industrialized countries. Unfortunately, it is above all the EU Member States that are involved in the second period of commitment to meet the objectives, while the most polluting countries refrain from participating. But we can't give up now. The EU must use all the political, diplomatic and economic instruments available to it to convince these countries to sign a binding international agreement establishing a level playing field, so that all signatories are responsible for and comply with the Protocol. Because the EU has to stop being the only one that makes all the climate commitments.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – This ratification decision reaffirms the EU and its Member States' efforts to address climate change at international level and are leading this process. It should be noted that the formal entry into force of the Doha Amendment must be one of the main objectives of the European Union. It is to be welcomed that the EU is a leader in all climate commitments. However, this is not enough. Other countries must follow the EU's example. The most polluting countries need to do much more to combat climate change. Effective results on climate change can only be achieved at global level. It is therefore essential to persuade these countries to sign a binding international agreement through all possible political, diplomatic and economic means.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. The Doha Amendment establishes a second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol, it started on 1 January 2013 and will end on 31 December 2020, and includes legally binding commitments to reduce emissions under which the European Union, its Member States and Iceland undertake to reduce average annual greenhouse gas emissions by 20% compared to 1990 in the period 2013-2020. I therefore believe that the ratification decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and the joint fulfilment of commitments by the European Union will send a strong signal on the efforts and leadership of the EU and its Member States in addressing climate change at international level. That is why I believe that the entry into force of the Doha Amendment is one of the European Union's priority objectives, as the Kyoto Protocol makes a crucial contribution to global efforts to tackle climate change.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 As a member of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, I have followed the discussions on the Kyoto Protocol and in particular the Doha Amendment, which establishes a second period of commitment for states to limit emissions to 80% of 1990 levels. I voted in favour because I believe that the EU Member States ratifying it before the end of the year, when the TWENTY-FIRST Conference of the Parties (COP 21) of the UNITED Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change takes place, will set a good example at international level. I would like to thank Mrs Gardini for her excellent report.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ I support the consent to the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. The European Union needs to send a strong signal to the rest of the world in its commitment to address climate change. Not only is this a signal that the fight against climate change is of key importance for the EU, but also that the development of renewables, with their impact on fighting climate change, remains at the core of the energy strategy.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported this recommendation, which demonstrates the Responsibility of the European Parliament in front of its citizens and the international community based on its powers and expresses its firm desire for Europe to continue to remain a leader in the fight against climate change.  The EU and its Member States have agreed to adopt by the end of 2015 a protocol, another legal instrument that has legal force and applies to all parties under the convention, which is due to enter into force and apply from 2020. The Council agreed to propose a common quantified commitment to reduce emissions by 20 % for the second binding period of the Kyoto Protocol for the Union and its Member States.  At the Doha Climate Change Conference, the Union and its Member States reached an agreement on their commitment to quantified emissions reductions limiting their average annual greenhouse gas emissions in the second binding period of up to 80 % of the sum of base year emissions. The Union and its Member States also offered to achieve reductions of 30% by 2020 compared to 1990 levels as part of a global and comprehensive agreement for the period beyond 2012, provided that other developed countries make a total reduction in emissions and that developing countries contribute adequately, in line with their responsibilities and appropriate capabilities.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. Following the Kyoto Agreements signed in 1997, the Doha Amendment aims to open a second commitment period from January 2013 to December 2020. These are targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions under a binding legal framework.  These agreements prove ineffective for several reasons: - the main polluters (United States, China, Canada, etc.) have strayed from them; - Appendix 1 provides a list of countries subject to reduction targets where emerging countries do not appear, while they are on the verge of emitting more greenhouse gases in the medium term than OECD countries; - the good results of European countries are largely due to technological advances, but also, alas, to the economic slowdown and deindustrialization. This agreement only places constraints on the Member States of the European Union. The commitments of the United States, which are entering the pre-election period, are subject to caution and are above all likely to be used as a pretext to further increase the constraints on the Member States of the European Union. For all these reasons, I am voting against this text.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ In December 2012, at the Doha Climate Change Conference, 192 parties to the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change adopted an amendment to the Kyoto Protocol, establishing the second target period of the agreement, which begins on 1 January 2013 and ends on 31 December 2020. Signatories have committed to reducing emissions. According to the Doha amendment, Croatia, together with other Members of the European Union, has committed to limiting its average annual greenhouse gas emissions between 2013 and 2020 to 80% of its emissions. I therefore support the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the EU, of amending the Doha Protocol of Kyoto to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the joint fulfilment of the resulting commitments, as I believe that this will send a strong message internationally that the European Union, its Member States and partners are making every effort to address global climate change.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I gave my approval to the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol because it is of the utmost importance that a second period of commitments by the EU be established that is legally binding for the reduction of average annual greenhouse gas emissions. Given the priority of this issue, I hope that the EU will take all possible measures to persuade some of the most polluting countries, which are not part of it, to sign a binding international agreement, so that climate commitments are shared and the objective of keeping the planet's temperature rise below 2°C is achieved.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. MEPs approved the conclusion on behalf of the EU of the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change and the joint implementation of the resulting commitments. I have spoken in favour of this proposal. It is essentially a technical text aimed at authorising the accession of Member States and Iceland to the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol, and defining the technical modalities of implementation.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The Doa Amendment establishes a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol, beginning on 1 January 2013 and ending on 31 December 2020, with commitments to reduce legally binding emissions according to which the European Union, its Member States and Iceland undertake to limit their average annual greenhouse gas emissions , in the period 2013 to 2020, at 80 % of its emissions in the reference year (in general, 1990). This commitment was determined on the basis of the total level of greenhouse gas emissions authorised during the period 2013-2020 under the EU Climate and Energy Package. In view of the importance of ambitious commitments to combat climate change, in particular in order to achieve the objective of keeping the planet's temperature rise below 2°C, I voted in favour of this decision to approve the conclusion of the Doa Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. I voted this afternoon in favour of the Gardini report on the Council's proposal for a decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. The Union has always been at the forefront of the fight against global warming. This is still true with the emission reduction target, up to 20% below 1990 levels, for the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol (2013-2020). In any case, the duale approach between rich and developing countries resulting from the Kyoto Protocol in 1997 will have to be overcome, since major regions of the world's major polluters, China, India and Brazil, are not currently subject to greenhouse gas emission reduction obligations. A common and binding commitment of the main economic blocs for the planet and the environment is a prerequisite for the success of the Paris International Climate Summit (COP21), which begins on 30 November. It should be added that this agreement is one of the last chances for the world's leading decision-makers to preserve the goal of limiting global warming to 2 degrees Celsius.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which validates the conclusion of the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol by the European Union. This amendment extends EU countries' commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions for the period 2013-2020, and makes several changes to the original agreement, such as the addition of a new greenhouse gas. We thereby encourage our Member States to take the necessary steps to achieve their emission reduction targets, and place the European Union as a leader in the fight against climate change at the global level ahead of the major climate conference in Paris in December. Let us hope that this great conference will live up to the challenge. Hopes are allowed.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Doha Amendment establishes a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol, beginning on 1 January 2013 and ending on 31 December 2020, with commitments to reduce average annual greenhouse gas emissions from 2013 to 2020. Like the rapporteur, I believe that this decision on the joint fulfilment of the commitments made by the European Union will send a clear signal to the efforts and leadership of the EU and its Member States in addressing climate change at international level. It is too bad that countries with the highest pollution rates systematically refrain from participating.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. U2012 Voting positively to the Decision to ratify, on the part of the EU and Iceland, the commitments of the Doha amendment mean sending a very positive signal. Ahead of the Paris Summit, the European Union tells the world that it wants to continue to lead the fight against climate change, setting an example while inviting the most reluctant and most polluting to continue investing in the future.  Doha is a good dressing to keep the Kyoto Protocol alive, but Paris must be the event that sees a new binding agreement born. It's about adding up wills, but also involving all parties alike in the search for a model that stops harming the planet and engaging our future generations. The G-7 has already sat down to talk about it and emerging people are seen with good predisposition. That is why the ratification of Doha by the EU and Iceland makes us proud that, despite the unrecorated criticisms of some 'climate-sceptic' sectors, we are on the right track.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The Kyoto Protocol on climate change was signed in 1997. It sets a binding international emissions reduction target. By ratifying the protocol, the European Union pledged to reduce its greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by 8% compared to 1990 levels in the first period (2008-2012). In 2012, the Doha conference adopted an amendment to the protocol that established a second commitment period (from 2013 to 2020) with legally binding GHG reduction commitments, under which the EU commits to limiting its annual GHG emissions to 80% of its annual emissions over the period 2013-2020 compared to 1990. The Doha amendment also makes three changes to the Kyoto text that must be implemented during this second commitment period: the inclusion of a new gas; an ambition-related mechanism that provides for a simplified procedure allowing a party to adjust its commitment by raising its level of ambition during a commitment period. The report voted today gives its approval to the conclusion of the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The Kyoto Protocol on the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change entered into force on 16 February 2005, establishing a set of legally binding emission reduction commitments between 2008 and 2012. In 2012, at the Doa Climate Change Conference, it was decided to approve an amendment to the Kyoto Protocol, where a second commitment period, 2013-2020, was established, with equally binding commitments to reduce emissions. The European Union, its Member States and Iceland undertake to limit their average annual greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in the period 2013-2020 to 80% of their emissions in the reference year (in general, 1990). This commitment was determined on the basis of the total level of greenhouse gas emissions allowed during the period 2013-2020 under the EU Climate and Energy Package. In view of the above commitments, I endorse this legislative resolution to continue with the rapid entry into force of the Doa Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. The Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol was adopted at the climate change conference in December 2012. It establishes a second commitment period for the Kyoto Protocol, which began on 1 January 2013 and will end on 31 December 2020, and provides for legally binding commitments to reduce emissions. For the European Union and its Member States, the aim is to limit average annual greenhouse gas emissions to 80% of emissions recorded in 1990 (the reference year) for the period 2013-2020.  I voted in favour of this text, which stems in particular from the measures of the "Climate and Energy" package of 2009.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol sets out a new phase, which opened in 2013 and will end in 2020, when the European Union, its Member States and Iceland commit themselves through binding targets to jointly reduce annual greenhouse gas emissions. The text before us can only receive a favourable vote from me, in line with the majority of Members of this Parliament.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote against because the extension of the Kyoto Protocol, to which many of the countries responsible for most of the world's CO2 production have not acceded, will have a marginal and overall negligible effect on the overall amount of CO2 released into the atmosphere.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted IN FAVOUR since the draft Council Decision forms the basis for the conclusion of the Doha amendment by the European Union, its Member States and Iceland. The text requires Member States to take the necessary measures to complete their national ratification processes by the third quarter of 2015. The Doha amendment establishes a second commitment period for the Kyoto Protocol, which begins on 1 January 2013 and ends on 31 December 2020, setting new limits on greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, the European Parliament gave its approval to the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. The European Union therefore undertakes to meet the binding targets for reducing annual greenhouse gas emissions in the period from 1 January 2013 to 31 December 2020. I voted in favour of Parliament's recommendation. This decision will help to confirm the EU's key contribution and leadership role in the fight against climate change. I would like to point out, however, that the second commitment period covers only 14% of global emissions, since the United States, Russia, Canada, Japan and developing countries are not involved. I therefore hope that the next UNFCCC conference in Paris at the end of 2015 will mark a turning point in this regard, through the conclusion of a new climate agreement that is legally binding and enforceable fairly by all parties. The fight against climate change requires a global political response; It is therefore time for each country to assume its responsibilities.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 All efforts will be few to achieve ambitious targets that can mitigate the effects of climate change and one day reverse its effects. This amendment, proposed in Doa, is a good step, but an insufficient step. We have to be even more ambitious. We owe it to future generations, that is, to our children and our grandchildren. In addition to what is expressed on paper, member states must be ensured to be adoption and implementing quickly. Furthermore, it is absolutely necessary to captivate the other polluting countries in order to meet ambitious targets. The United States of America, China and Japan are, along side the European Union, the most responsible for the unfortunate environmental condition of the planet. Just as Commissioner Vella presented a call for Global Ocean Governance during the Blue Week in Lisbon last week, as was presented during the Blue Week in Lisbon last week, the mechanisms for Global Environmental Governance should be strengthened. The timing is exceptional. For exceptional moments, exceptional people and exceptional mobilization and action capabilities are required. We roll up our sleeves!

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ As the ratification decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and the joint fulfilment of the commitments by the European Union will send a strong signal about the efforts and the leadership of the EU and its Member States to address climate change at international level, the timely consent of the European Parliament is necessary.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ the European Union agreed in 2002, when ratifying the Kyoto Protocol, to jointly fulfil the emissions commitment that applies to all Member States, including the Slovak Republic. When voting on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol, which provides for a reduction in emissions below 20% from the 1990 level, I voted in favour of this resolution, as, on the basis of the Council's position, the Member States themselves adopted an amendment to the Kyoto Protocol as early as 2012 at the Doha Conference.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. \u2012 I support the conclusion of amendments to the Doha Protocol of Kyoto that lay down mitigation obligations for the second target period of the Kyoto Protocol for the States set out in the protocol. Most of these amendments only allow for the implementation of new mitigation obligations, but some provisions also make changes to material obligations. These relate to the inclusion of new gas, nitrogen trifluoride (NF3), whose emissions are low but on the rise.  The Republic of Croatia has expressed its position expressing its intention to fulfil its obligations in the second binding period of the Kyoto Protocol. Croatia, together with other Member States of the Union, has committed to limit its average annual greenhouse gas emissions between 2013 and 2020 to 80% of its emissions.  I believe that the amendments to the Kyoto Protocol on joint fulfilment of commitments by the European Union will send a strong signal of the efforts and leadership of the European Union and its Member States on climate change at international level.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the EP resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change and the joint fulfilment of the obligations arising therefro on behalf of the European Union. The Kyoto Protocol represents a key contribution to tackling climate change in the world. The ratification decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol is a good strong signal of the role of the EU and its Member States in tackling climate change. The Doha Amendment was adopted at the Doha Conference in December 2012, where 192 Parties to the Kyoto Protocol adopted an addendum to the Protocol and provides for a second binding period where the EU, its Member States and Iceland undertake to limit their average annual greenhouse gas emissions in 2013-2020 to 80 % of their base year /1990/ The Doha Amendment also introduces further changes to the wording of the Kyoto Protocol – the inclusion of new nitric fluoride gas, a simplified procedure allowing adjustments to the greenhouse gas reduction commitment and avoiding an increase in emissions above the average emission volume of previous years.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol on climate change and the joint fulfilment of commitments focuses primarily on climate change. The Doha Conference adopted a 20% reduction in polluting emissions gases. In the Kyoto Protocol, EU Member States committed to limit greenhouse gas emissions to 80% of the current amount. At this junier, it is important to mention in particular the concrete measures to further reduce global emissions before 2020, which are currently being implemented by member states. Among them is the most important objective, which requires a 20% reduction in emissions. I find it disappointing that the second target period of the Kyoto Protocol is mainly joined by EU Member States, but not by the largest emitters. The EU should use all the political, diplomatic and economic tools at its disposal to persuade these countries to sign a binding international agreement. In this way, we would create a level playing field and, above all, the EU will not have to meet all its own climate obligations. As enhanced measures to combat climate change are of great importance, I voted in favour of adopting the European Parliament recommendation for the Doha Amendments to the Kyoto Protocol and the joint fulfilment of the commitments under this amendment.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment of the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, signed in 1997 to set a binding target for reducing greenhouse gas emissions at international level. The Doha Amendment is crucial to achieving the global emission reduction targets, as it establishes a second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol (2013-2020) and provides for legally binding commitments under which the EU undertakes to severely limit average annual greenhouse gas emissions compared to the reference year, usually 1990. The draft Council decision therefore forms the basis for the conclusion of the Doha Amendment by the Union and lays down the conditions for the joint fulfilment of these commitments. With the conclusion of the Doha Amendment and the commitments that come with it, the Union will send a strong signal about the efforts and leadership it intends to have in addressing climate change globally ahead of the UNFCCC conference in Paris in 2015. At this point, it is therefore crucial that the Member States quickly conclude the national ratification processes, before the important meeting in Paris at the end of this year.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing \ u2012 I welcome this Commission proposal. I regret that most EU countries subscribe to the Kyoto Protocol commitments, not the ones that pollute our land the most. The EU should use all possible political, diplomatic and economic instruments to get these countries to sign a binding international agreement. The ratification decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and the Joint Implementation of commitments by the European Union can thus contribute to tackling climate change at international level.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒I support this recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Amendment to the Doha Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the joint fulfilment of the resulting commitments, as I believe that by 2020 the reduction of Member States' gas emissions should continue and that the European Union should lead the way and set a good example for other countries.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒I support the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of amending the Kyoto Protocol of Doha, with the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the joint fulfilment of the resulting obligations.  The Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change was signed in 1997. The European Union and its Member States are jointly responsible under the Kyoto Protocol, in compliance with the mechanism for meeting the commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the first (2008-2012) period by 8% below 1990 levels. Since March 9, 2012. The Council proposed a common quantified emissions reduction commitment of 20% below 1990 levels.  The decision on the draft Council provides the basis for the conclusion of the Doha amendments by the European Union and lays down the conditions for the joint fulfilment of obligations by the EU, its Member States and Iceland. This requires Member States to take the necessary steps to complete their domestic ratification processes by the third quarter of 2015 at the latest.  The rapporteur believes that the ratification of the decision to conclude amendments to the Kyoto Protocol of Doha and the joint fulfilment of commitments by the European Union can send a strong signal on the efforts and leadership of the European Union and its Member States on climate change at international level.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the recommendation on a draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and the joint fulfilment of the commitments under this amendment. The second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol, 2013-2020, contains legally binding greenhouse gas emission reduction commitments under which the European Union and Iceland undertake to limit their average annual greenhouse gas emissions to 80% of their emissions in the base year between 2013 and 2020. I support the rapporteur's position, which regrets that the second target period of the Kyoto Protocol is mainly joined by EU Member States, but not by the largest emitters. The formal implementation of the Doha Amendment must be one of the European Union's priority objectives.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Environmental protection needs to be strengthened. In this light, the legislative proposal for formal ratification by the European Union of the second commitment period (2013-2020) provided for in the Kyoto Protocol on climate change is auxiliary in this direction.  In particular, reducing combined greenhouse gas emissions will improve the lives of citizens in many countries. It is also good that the commitments are based on the differentiated responsibility of the States, depending on their capabilities. The decisive step towards improving environmental conditions will take place when neoliberal policies are terminated and barriers are put in the way of unregulated development and over-exploitation of the environment on the altar of profit by large multinational corporations. Until then, we will support any proper efforts to improve environmental conditions. That is why we voted in favour.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The Doha Amendment establishes a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol, which includes legally binding obligations to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and the joint fulfilment of the obligations arising there from it. As a long process, I think it is important that we constantly make adjustments to reduce emissions. The Kyoto Protocol establishing a binding international emission reduction target was signed in 1997. In 2012, the Council undertook to propose a joint reduction commitment of 20% on the part of the Union for the second commitment period, 20% compared to 1990 levels. I believe it sends a strong message that the Union and its Member States are making efforts and that they are leading the way in the international fight against climate change. Together with the rapporteur who has noted the draft, I welcome the relevant Draft Council Decision. I share the regrettable view that the EU also has a duty to convince the main polluting countries that are excluded from such conventions, and that it must use all political, diplomatic and economic means to do so. I am sure that all these processes and further commitments will also be an important point of negotiation in the new international agreement to be final in Paris in the second half of this year.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The ratification decision on the conclusion of the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and the joint implementation of commitments by the European Union is supposed to send a strong signal about the efforts and leadership of the European Union and its Member States in the fight against climate change at the international level. It is regrettable, however, that the main polluters are not more concerned!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ By voting in favour of this recommendation, the European Parliament gave its full support to the ratification on behalf of the EU of the Doha Amendment to the second Kyoto Protocol commitment period (from 1 January 2013 to 31 December 2020) and the joint implementation of the commitments this entails. The ratification of the Doha Amendment removes any danger of a legal vacuum arising between the end of the Kyoto Protocol and the new, legally binding, world climate deal, to be negotiated at the COP21 summit in Paris in December 2015, that is due to come into force in 2020. If Europe is the leading force in climate policy, then it needs to be followed by the rest of the world.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Doha Amendment establishes a second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol, from 1 January 2013 to 31 December 2020, and provides for legally binding obligations to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The second phase of the Kyoto Protocol serves as a bridge to a post-2020 global climate change agreement. In this context, the European Union and its Member States, together - and together with Iceland - have committed themselves to reducing their emissions in the period 2013-2020 by 20% compared to 1990 levels. We are on the right track, although we within the Union itself could do much more, but we know that this is the result of sound policies aimed at achieving defined objectives and we will not tire of reaffirming our commitments also taking into account the needs of our businesses. The formal entry into force of the amendment is an essential step towards achieving the EU's priority objectives, as the Kyoto Protocol makes a crucial contribution to global efforts to tackle climate change. The entry into force of the Doha Amendment is an important step before the Paris Conference.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report on the conclusion of an amendment to the Kyoto Protocol of Doha signed with the aim of reducing greenhouse gas emissions. In March 2013, the Council proposed a commitment to reduce gas emissions by 20 % for the second period of the Kyoto Protocol commitments, from 1 January 2013 to the end of 2020, compared to the previous period from 2008-2010. I support a provision of the Protocol requiring the parties to set and report on the level of emissions of gases by joint agreement in order to ensure the transparency and efficiency of the parties to their obligations, with each Country being able to individually account for its emissions and the amount allocated. Accordingly, I believe that the Commission should continue to work with Member States and third countries so that they can adopt and apply the Kyoto Protocol rules as effectively as possible, thus contributing to global efforts to address climate change.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \ i supported the recommendation to conclude the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. The Council of the EU should ensure that ratification procedures in the Member States and in the EU are implemented no later than the third quarter of 2015 so that they can deposit their instruments of acceptance in due time before the 2015 Paris Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. This would send a strong signal of the efforts and leadership of the EU and its Member States in taking action against climate change at international level. In addition, we would set a mirror to the biggest emitters and encourage them to take the same action. At the same time, the EU should use all the political, diplomatic and economic tools at its disposal to persuade these countries to sign a binding international agreement. It is important to take into account the EU's climate change policy and the promotion of the use of renewable energy sources. Last but not least, in the Commission's programme, its President Juncker also supports the EU's leadership in the area of the application and promotion of renewable energy sources. In order to meet the obligations arising from the Doha Amendment, and if we want to maintain the trajectory in order to keep the temperature growth on the planet below the 2 °C target, it is necessary to find, in the light of sustainable development, the true relationship between the economy and environmental challenges.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted IN FAVOUR since the draft Council Decision forms the basis for the conclusion of the Doha amendment by the European Union, its Member States and Iceland. The text requires Member States to take the necessary measures to complete their national ratification processes by the third quarter of 2015. The Doha amendment establishes a second commitment period for the Kyoto Protocol, which begins on 1 January 2013 and ends on 31 December 2020, setting new limits on greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Following the Kyoto Agreements signed in 1997, the Doha Amendment aims to open a second period of commitments of the Protocol, from January 2013 to December 2020. These are targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions under a binding legal framework. The great disparity in global efforts in the fight against so-called climate change is counterproductive and it is not acceptable to extend the application of such a mechanism, especially since the rapporteur rightly notes that European states bear these constraints while other States abstain from them. The stubbornness to continue in this logic is therefore paradoxical. I am voting against this text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted IN FAVOUR since the draft Council Decision forms the basis for the conclusion of the Doha amendment by the European Union, its Member States and Iceland. The text requires Member States to take the necessary measures to complete their national ratification processes by the third quarter of 2015. The Doha amendment establishes a second commitment period for the Kyoto Protocol, which begins on 1 January 2013 and ends on 31 December 2020, setting new limits on greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of ratification on the conclusion of the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and the joint fulfilment of commitments as this will strengthen the work of the EU and Member States in the fight against climate change.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This Recommendation is intended to highlight that, in order to bring the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol into force, Member States must ratify the Doha amendment and the agreement itself. That is why I believe that it must be voted in favour.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change was signed in 1997 with the aim of setting an internationally binding emission reduction target. The EU ratified this Protocol in 2015. In 2012, the Doha Climate Change Conference approved an amendment to The Kyoto Protocol 1 establishing a second period (2013 to 2020) with legally binding emission reduction commitments for the parties. By this amendment, EU Member States and Iceland undertook to reduce their annual average greenhouse gas emission.  I supported this report which consents to the Doha amendment as a positive step, although I believe that the amended Kyoto Protocol is still a long way from effectively combating climate change on its own, as it lacks complementary measures, such as provisions on climate justice, as well as serious commitments to work by more industrialized countries.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. In its conclusions of 9 March 2012, the Council agreed to propose a common quantified emission reduction commitment for the Union for the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol for the Union, below 1990 levels. I abstained because of the apparent non-commitment of other states outside the EU and the scientifically controversial view that climate change can be stopped by humans by reducing CO2 emissions.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I refused to agree to the conclusion of the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. The Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, signed in 1997, set an internationally binding emission reduction target. The Doha amendment establishes a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol, which began on 1 January 2013 and ends on 31 December 2020 and includes legally binding emission reduction commitments requiring the European Union, its Member States and Iceland to limit their average annual greenhouse gas emissions to 80% of their emissions in the base year (in most cases 1990) in 2013-2020. I do not share the ideology of man-made climate change that underlies this agreement. Accordingly, I rejected the amendment to the Treaty.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today for Parliament to give its consent to the ratification of the agreements reached at Doha in December 2012. I think it is important for the European Union to send a strong signal to the other world powers, pointing out its leadership in the fight against climate change in the international context. With these agreements, the Eu ropean Union is committed to reducing its greenhouse gas emissions by twenty% by 2020. I believe that, although the European Union is already implementing similar reduction targets under the Climate and Energy package, European ratification is an important step towards the entry into force of the agreements.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: in writing. I welcome today's vote because I believe that the ratification of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol by the European Union is a step in the right direction, also in view of COP21 in November. In view of this important meeting, it is essential that we ensure that a legally binding agreement is reached in Paris, thanks to the full involvement and commitment of both the United States and the emerging countries, from which most greenhouse gas emissions come. The European Union must send out a strong signal in the fight against climate change and present itself as its leader by adopting a global strategy. Finally, I would like to stress the importance of the G7 conclusions in Bavaria in which leaders stated the need to take urgent and concrete action as soon as possible to tackle climate change and the need to keep the increase in global temperature within the two-degree limit and a reduction from 40 to 70 % of emissions compared to 2010 by 2050.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, there is a tremendous argument now going on in advance of the UK referendum about whether we should keep our places at the top table. We are told that, if Britain withdraws from the European Union, we will lose our voice where the rules are made. But, as we see, and as we in this House know because we are always legislating on it, the real top tables are global rather than European. Whether it is food standards, banking rules or internet domain names, the real top tables apply much more widely than just to the 28 Member States of the European Union. What we find is that all of our Member States have effectively contracted out their voice at those real top tables to EU institutions – whereas, say, Switzerland, as an independent country, is separately represented and sits there. So the United Kingdom has given up its voting rights and its speaking rights at the World Trade Organisation – unlike, say, Switzerland. That seems to me – in a world where the European Union is shrinking as a share of the global economy and losing its pre-eminence in terms of GDP – a real loss of influence, which we will recover only when we re-establish our independence.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, again I am very pleased to support this report, and again it is great to see the vast majority voting in favour. Obviously the conclusion of the agreement with Iceland is a good move and sends out a proper signal. One thing I would like to highlight though is that we have to be very careful at European level to balance our needs for food security with climate change, and there is a grave danger that we could bring in measures that would be counter-productive in terms of the development of our agriculture but also in actually creating greater emissions through displacement. Already we have made good progress, particularly in the CAP, where greening was an essential element and, indeed, a lot of measures now at Member States level are being put in place to reduce emissions through agriculture. But we must not at the same time finish up in a situation where we are over-strict on agriculture, which actually leads to greater emissions worldwide, as we have seen with some of the measures we have taken in the past.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, the United Kingdom will soon have a referendum on whether we leave the European Union. Regarding that, I support wholeheartedly that we should do so. But, during that debate, there will be many occasions when arguments will be put forward that, by leaving the European Union, the United Kingdom will not have a voice within the European Union or indeed across the world. Here today, in this motion, we see Iceland, a smaller nation than the United Kingdom – Iceland with less GDP and less influence in the globe than the United Kingdom – entering into an agreement with the European Union on a matter that is crucial for the people of the world: how we deal with our environment and how our international partners in Kyoto agree on what we should do with the environment. This proves today that the United Kingdom, outside of the European Union, would be able to negotiate and have trade deals with the European Union. We do not need to be a member of it to succeed in the future.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change was signed in 1997 with the aim of setting an internationally binding target for emissions reduction. The EU ratified this protocol in 2015. In 2012, the Doha Climate Change Conference approved an amendment to The Kyoto Protocol 1 establishing a second period (2013 to 2020) with legally binding emission reduction commitments for the parties. By this amendment, EU Member States and Iceland undertook to reduce their annual average greenhouse gas emission. Since Iceland is not part of the EU, it has been necessary to sign this separate agreement for participation. I supported this report which consents to Iceland's participation in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol as a positive step, although I believe that this agreement is still quite far from effectively combating climate change on its own, as it lacks additional measures, such as climate justice provisions, as well as serious commitments by the most industrialized countries.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. As one of the parties to the Kyoto Protocol, Iceland committed itself to limiting the increase in emissions to below 10% between 2008 and 2012. For the second period 2013-2020, Iceland announced its intention to work with the EU and its Member States to comply with the emission reductions quantified at the Doha Climate Conference. Iceland is involved in the EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS) and in the EU Regulation on a Greenhouse Gas Emissions Monitoring System (Monitoring Regulation). The rights and obligations that apply to Member States in joint compliance must be extended to Iceland by EU legislation. I voted in favour of this resolution because it sends a strong signal to the EU's coordinated efforts to combat climate change at international level.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Iceland is already taking part in the EU's carbon market and greenhouse gas declaration. The European Union, which is seeking to become a leader in reducing these gases, wants to bring other states with it. Iceland has the advantage of being a particularly low-polluting state. The Kyoto Protocol and its provisions are ineffective, so will the second commitment period. The main polluters, the United States, China or Canada, have not ratified it, demonstrating a political pragmatism that is sorely lacking in Brussels. Emerging countries, which were not necessarily so in 1994 when the protocol was signed, are not mentioned in Appendix 1 of the agreement, which defines countries subject to reduction targets. I therefore advocate the repeal of this mechanism in order to make way for bilateral agreements, and I have therefore voted against this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ It appears that most global economies are likely to abstain on Annex B to the Kyoto Protocol. This will not come into force worldwide, and therefore I believe that the UK should be able to make its own decision on this matter.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it reiterates Iceland's commitment, like all EU states, to limit its GHG emissions over the period 2013-2020.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a Council Decision providing the basis for the adoption of the Doha Amendment to the Agreement between the EU and its Member States, of the one part, and Iceland, of the other part, on the participation of Iceland in the joint implementation of the commitments to the Kyoto Protocol. I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to approve the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. The Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change was signed in 1997 and sets an internationally binding emission reduction target. The European Union has taken responsibility for its commitment to reduce total greenhouse gas emissions by 8% between 2008 and 2012. In 2012, the Council agreed to propose a common eu commitment to reduce emissions by 20% compared to 1990 levels. This, known as the Doha Amendment, sets out a second commitment period for the Kyoto Protocol. I agree that the ratification of this amendment will send a clear signal that the EU and its Member States are working to address climate change at international level and are leading this process.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Iceland has expressed its intention to fulfil its commitments jointly with the European Union and its Member States during the second commitment period. I can only rejoice that a country is following in the footsteps of the European Union in order to combat climate change in the world.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. U2012 Climate change, caused primarily by the emission of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere, does not understand political boundaries or geographical boundaries. The will of both the Government of Iceland and the European Union and its Member States reflects the full awareness of this fact.  Thus, the country's participation in the second period of commitment of the Kyoto Protocol, together with the European Union and all its Member States, only reinforces the firm commitment to meet this challenge from a common, coherent and deeply cohesive position to which I strongly subscribe.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
