text: in writing. I voted in favour of this because this is the basis for an agreement between the European Union and the Member States with Iceland. The latter has an interest in complying with Union legislation and participates in the Community Emissions Trading Scheme as well as the GHG Emissions Monitoring and Reporting Mechanism; therefore, the agreement needs to be verified to achieve climate change objectives more urgently.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report on an EU-Iceland agreement on the Kyoto Protocol suggests adopting the Council's position on Iceland's integration into the Kyoto commitments for the second period. Iceland is a low-polluting state, exploiting geothermal energy, for example. Unfortunately, as in the text voted above, these agreements are imperfect and insufficient for the same reasons. The largest producers and emerging countries are not participating in the protocol. This agreement with Iceland should enable the EU to position itself as a leader and this may lead to additional constraints for member states. Iceland would not, in fact, even need such an agreement. As with the previous vote, I therefore decide to vote against this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Kyoto II package incorporates a reduction in CO2 emissions that the EU has already imposed on itself and has already achieved since the introduction of the 2009 climate and energy package. The ratification of Kyoto II until 2020 is nothing more than symbolic adherence to a protocol from which the major CO2-producing countries have already pulled out precisely because of its ineffectiveness, for these reasons I did not intend to support the report with my vote.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supports the decision on iceland's participation in the joint implementation of the EU-Iceland commitments to the Kyoto Protocol to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change for the second commitment period. Iceland is a country listed in Annex I to the Kyoto Protocol, having achieved its individual objective in the first commitment period. Iceland was able to increase its emissions by an average of no more than 10% on average during the first commitment period. Finally, iceland's emissions decreased by an average of 2% during this period. Iceland has stated its intention to fulfil its obligations in the second commitment period together with the EU and its Member States. Iceland is part of the EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS) and complies with the REGULATION on the EU's greenhouse gas monitoring mechanism. Eu legislation requires iceland to be granted rights and obligations such as those attributed to Member States that fulfil their obligations in general. Iceland has an interest in jointly fulfilling its obligations with the EU and its Member States, whether it joins the EU or not.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 Like the Recommendation on the draft Decision amending the Doha to the Kyoto Protocol, I was also pleased to support this proposal for a decision on the conclusion of an AGREEMENT between the EU and Iceland on iceland's participation in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol. The European Union is a driving force in the fight against climate change, and I am pleased that Iceland, which is not yet a member of the EU, is joining the EU's single fight to achieve the Kyoto Protocol commitments. Iceland is already participating in the EU Emissions Trading Scheme and the Greenhouse Gas Emissions Monitoring Mechanism, and cooperation under the second Kyoto target period represents an upgrade of the single fight against climate change. I am pleased that, more recently, there have been more concrete shifts in the area of combating climate change, which, I hope, will reach a long-term agreement at the climate conference at the end of this year in Paris. The EU is at the forefront of the fight against climate change and it can be seen that other world economies, which are among the biggest emitters of the atmosphere, can follow. This is the only way to achieve the objective set out in the Doha Agreement of reducing greenhouse gas emissions to 80% of emissions by 2020 compared to 1990 levels.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the EU-Iceland agreement on iceland's participation in the second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol is a demonstration of the importance of the Eu ropean Union's role in the fight against global warming at international level.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The participation of Iceland, a virtuous country that has significantly reduced its polluting emissions over the past five years and which is a positive model for most technologically advanced states, in the agreement to start the second phase of the Kyoto Protocol is certainly to be welcomed and supported politically. The participation of the Republic of Iceland in the common achievement of the objectives set out in the Doha Amendment must encourage us to be ambitious and not to be satisfied with the results achieved: there is still much to be done to build a technologically advanced and environmentally sustainable civilisation. We must create a binding legal structure for all countries, pushing them to achieve their objectives in a clear and fair manner, adapted to the economic and environmental conditions of their territory. We can do this together, sharing good practices and developing new development models. The fight against climate change is not a struggle between countries or peoples: it is a struggle of human civilisation against the polluting factors that threaten its prosperity and development. It's a fight we only win if we work together, united for the sake of that great common home that is our planet.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. I voted against the recommendation on the EU-Iceland agreement on Iceland's participation in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol. Why is the Union trying to integrate new states into an inefficient system? Like the recommendation on the conclusion of the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol, the purpose of this text is to legitimise the strengthening of the objectives of the scheme. On the other hand, we need to think about a concrete and realistic programme, based on cooperation between the sovereign states of Europe.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Iceland, on the other, on Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of the commitments of the European Union, its Member States and Iceland for the second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol. This Agreement lays down the conditions governing Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of commitments by the Union, its Member States and Iceland. This country participates in the joint fulfilment of commitments on the same basis as that of the EU Member States. I believe that Iceland's participation in jointly fulfilling its commitments for the second period of the Kyoto Protocol will have a visible impact and will send a strong signal of coordinated European efforts, as well as involvement in addressing existing climate change problems.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against. Kyoto II is an inadequate and ineffective agreement, and the problem must be resolved differently.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The Kyoto Protocol was adopted in 2005. The countries that adhere to this agreement are committed to reducing their greenhouse gas emissions. The Doha amendment is an extension of the Kyoto Protocol. It seals Iceland's commitment, in conjunction with the European Union, to maintain the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions. It is essential that the various states that make up the European Union, as well as third countries, agree on the way forward in the fight against pollution and climate change. Any new emissions reduction agreement will make the commitments already in place more effective. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this recommendation today because I believe that the agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Iceland, on the other, with regard to Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of commitments for the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol will be a strong signal that will highlight coordinated European efforts to combat climate change at international level. Iceland is interested in joint compliance with the EU and its Member States regardless of whether or not it joins the EU. Therefore, the accession negotiations between Iceland and the EU must have no impact on the joint fulfilment of the commitment agreed between the EU, the Member States and Iceland for the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol. I therefore believe that the Council's decision on Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of the kyoto commitments must be ratified without unnecessary delay and certainly well before the Paris climate conference in November.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ The Doha Amendment establishes a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol, starting on 1 January 2013 and ending on 31 December 2020, with legally binding emission reduction commitments according to which the European Union, its Member States and Iceland are jointly committed to limit their average annual greenhouse gas emissions in the years 2013 to 2020 to 80% of their base year (mostly 1990) emissions. That commitment was determined on the basis of the total greenhouse gas emissions allowed during the period 2013-2020 under the EU Climate and Energy Package. Since Iceland is not an EU Member State, the terms of joint fulfilment concerning its participation had to be laid down in a separate international agreement. The proposed Council Decision provides the basis for the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Iceland, of the other part, concerning Iceland’s participation in the joint fulfilment of commitments for the Kyoto Protocol to the UNFCCC. The report gives consent to the conclusion of the Agreement, and it was for these reasons that I voted in favour.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I fully concur with the recommendation that the European Parliament give its consent to this agreement for Iceland to jointly fulfil its commitments, in a second commitment period, together with the EU and its Member States, of the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. Enabling the entry into force of Europe’s commitments as legally-binding commitments in international law sends a strong signal about the commitment of the EU and its Member States to a rules-based multilateral regime for addressing climate change at international level. Since Iceland is not an EU Member State, the terms of joint fulfilment concerning its participation had to be laid down in a separate international agreement.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Iceland will participate in the joint fulfilment of the Kyoto Protocol on the same basis as the Member States with this agreement. Environmental protection is essential and every state on the planet should contribute to it.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I objected to this report, which aims to force Iceland to the commitments made by the Union under the Kyoto Protocol. Indeed, even in terms of environmental policy, the Union seems to want to position itself as a moral authority, but the choice here seems particularly aberrant since Iceland is known to be one of the least polluting countries in the world, in particular because of its exploitation of geothermal energy. In addition, Iceland - a state that has recently withdrawn from the candidate countries for EU membership - is already participating in the EU's carbon market and greenhouse gas declaration. Finally, as I said about the Gardini report on the Doha amendment, the Kyoto Protocol has proved ineffective in reducing greenhouse gases, as the main polluting countries are not subject to the emission reduction constraint.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure concerning the EU-Iceland agreement on Iceland's participation in the Kyoto Protocol. The Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), signed in 1997, sets an internationally binding emission reduction target. The European Union and its Member States pledged to reduce their overall greenhouse gas emissions in the first period (2008-2012) by 8% compared to 1990 levels. In the Council conclusions of 9 March 2012, a 20% target was proposed for the second commitment period (2013-2020) of the Kyoto Protocol, which was then accepted by EU Member States at the Doha Climate Change Conference in December 2012, attended by 192 states. Since Iceland is not a Member State of the European Union, the terms of its participation have been set out in an international agreement between the EU and Iceland.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement that will allow Iceland to participate in the second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol established by the Doha Amendment. This means that the countries that make up the European Union and Iceland will jointly fulfil their emission commitments. I am in favour of Iceland's participation because it has already demonstrated by its participation in Annex One of the Kyoto Protocol that it is able to meet and fulfil its commitments by averaging 2%. The fact that Iceland is not part of the European Union further underlines coordinated European efforts in the fight against climate change at international level. Furthermore, the conclusion of this agreement with Iceland does not in any way affect the content of the accession negotiations between the two countries.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Iceland is a part of the Kyoto Protocol which has respected its individual objectives during the first period of the commitment. In 2009, Iceland expressed its intention to jointly fulfil its commitments to the European Union and its Member States in the second period of the commitment, regardless of whether or not it joins the EU. The Council welcomed this request and concluded that the combined length in the second period should include Iceland. The agreement between the European Union and the Member States on Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of commitments in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol is a clear signal to coordinated European efforts to combat climate change at international level.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the EU-Iceland agreement on Iceland's participation in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol, as we can only counteract climate change by jointly fulfilling the obligations under the Protocol. Cooperation with non-EU countries is an essential approach to tackling this major climatic challenge.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement between the EU and Iceland on iceland's participation in the second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol. Iceland is part of Annex I to the Kyoto Protocol and in 2009 expressed its intention to fulfil its commitments in a second period of implementation of that Protocol.  In my opinion, the EU-Iceland report on environmental policy represents a further opportunity to renew our joint efforts to tackle the problem of climate change at international level.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 Iceland will participate in the joint fulfilment of the Kyoto Protocol on the same basis as the Member States with this agreement. As parties to the Kyoto Protocol, the Eu ropean Union and its Member States are subject to a number of monitoring, reporting and verification obligations under the Kyoto Protocol. For contracting parties which have agreed to fulfil their commitments jointly, some of this information must be submitted jointly. The Commission will ask Iceland for information which will enable the Union to fulfil its reporting obligations. In addition, Iceland will have to participate in the system of registers of the Union and its Member States which are relevant for the fulfilment of its obligations under the Kyoto Protocol. This requires Iceland to apply Union rules not applicable to third countries, in particular with regard to the monitoring, reporting and verification of emissions, as well as with regard to the functioning of the register and the accounting treatment of transactions related to the implementation of the commitments of the Union, its Member States and Iceland under the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol in line with the terms of joint compliance and internationally agreed standards. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change was signed in 1997 with the aim of setting an internationally binding target for emissions reduction. The EU ratified this protocol in 2015. In 2012, the Doha Climate Change Conference approved an amendment to The Kyoto Protocol 1 establishing a second period (2013 to 2020) with legally binding emission reduction commitments for the parties. By this amendment, EU Member States and Iceland undertook to reduce their annual average greenhouse gas emission. Since Iceland is not part of the EU, it has been necessary to sign this separate agreement for participation. I supported this report which consents to Iceland's participation in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol as a positive step, although I believe that this agreement is still quite far from effectively combating climate change on its own, as it lacks additional measures, such as climate justice provisions, as well as serious commitments by the most industrialized countries.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-Iceland agreement on Iceland’s participation in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol as this provides legally binding emission reduction commitments according to which the EU, its Member States and Iceland are jointly committed to limiting their average annual greenhouse gas emissions in the years 2013-2020. This provides a strong signal about the efforts to seriously address climate change.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I appreciate the fact that Iceland, which is not a Member State, also supports the adoption of the Doha Amendment, thus proving that it is interested in jointly fulfilling this commitment established on the basis of the total greenhouse gas emissions allowed in the period 2013-2020 under the EU climate and energy package.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes to give the European Parliament the agreement to conclude an international agreement with Iceland for the implementation of the so-called "Doha" amendment and Iceland's participation in the common reductions on which the European Union has committed. This report is linked to the Gardini report also voted at this plenary and aims to facilitate Iceland's participation in limiting average greenhouse gas emissions to 80% compared to emissions emitted in 1990, the reference year. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The European Union has been instrumental in the fight against climate change at the global level, including the adoption of the Kyoto Protocol to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change. At the end of the first commitment period (2008-2012) of the Kyoto Protocol, EU Member States became more involved in setting legally binding targets for the second period (2013-2020). Also, by 2020, our annual greenhouse gas emissions should not exceed 80% of the 1990 emissions level. With this vote, we urge the Council to adopt a decision authorising Iceland to join in the joint implementation of these objectives. The widest possible coordination of efforts at European level will allow us to approach the Paris conference with a strong position.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. Parliament has approved the conclusion of the agreement that allows the joint implementation of the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol between the European Union and Iceland. The protocol includes legally binding emission reduction commitments, under which the European Union, its Member States and Iceland commit to limiting their average annual greenhouse gas emissions to 80% for the reference year (1990 in most cases) over the period 2013-2020. On the eve of the Paris climate change conference in December 2015, this cooperation is heading in the right direction.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted against the recommendation on the EU-Iceland agreement on Iceland's participation in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol. Why is the Union trying to integrate new states into an unsatisfactory system? Like the recommendation for the conclusion of the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol, this text is intended only to legitimise the strengthening of the objectives of the scheme. On the other hand, we need to think about a concrete and realistic agenda, based on cooperation between sovereign states.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of Member States' obligations in the Kyoto Protocol for the second period from 2013 to 2020 because although Iceland has formally withdrawn its application for EU membership, the country has expressed its desire to jointly implement our efforts to actively combat climate change. Together, we agree to limit greenhouse gases by 20% from 1990 levels over the next five years.  This will be a strong international signal for the other countries of the Kyoto Protocol and an example of how different countries can come together and jointly fulfil their obligations in the fight against climate change.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement as Iceland is part of Annex I to the Kyoto Protocol, which succeeded in meeting its individual objectives for the first commitment period. It expressed its intention to jointly honour its commitments in a second period of engagement with the EU.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. I support the conclusion of this agreement, signed by the Eu ropean Union and Iceland on 1 April 2015, as in 2012 the 192 parts of the Kyoto Protocol to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change adopted an amendment to the Protocol (the Doha Amendment). This amendment established a second commitment period, from 1 January 2013 to 31 December 2020, with a binding emission reduction target for the parties (including the European Union, the Member States and Iceland). There are 144 ratifications required for its entry into force, but to date there are only 32. This makes us realize how far we are still from the finish line. In any event, the EU and its Member States have chosen to fulfil jointly the commitments under the Kyoto Protocol. And in 2012, the Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Iceland, on the other, declared their intention to jointly respect the commitments of the second period in order to conclude, in 2014, the negotiations for an agreement on joint fulfilment. Once the joint effort has been fulfilled, those parties shall be deemed to have complied with their emission obligations under the Kyoto Protocol. Otherwise, each party becomes responsible for its individual level of emissions.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Council Decision provides the basis for the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Iceland, of the other part, on Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of the commitments for the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol to the UNFCCC. During this period, the country had to limit its emissions to below 10 % on average. In the end, emissions decreased by an average of 2 % during this period. The Agreement on Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of commitments in the second kyoto protocol commitment period to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change will be a clear signal to coordinated European efforts to combat climate change at international level.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation, because the Kyoto Protocol is exclusively binding on the Member States of the European Union. Moreover, it does not seem appropriate to vote on a deliberation on Iceland, which has just officially withdrawn its application for membership of the European Union.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Doha Amendment establishes a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol (2013–2020). In 2012, in the absence of a comprehensive and effective agreement capable of replacing it, it was decided to extend the Kyoto Protocol, extending with it all its weaknesses, including the perverse flexibility mechanisms. It is still the only legally binding emission reduction commitment. The EU, its Member States and Iceland are committed to reducing their average annual greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in the period 2013-2020 by 20%. This commitment was determined on the basis of the total level of GHG emissions authorised during the period 2013-2020 under the EU Climate and Energy Package, which falls short of that recommended by the United Nations Climate Change Panel.  Although Iceland is not an EU Member State, it intends to fulfil its commitment in this second period of the Kyoto Protocol, together with the EU and its Member States. Nothing against it. That is why we supported this report. As for its participation in the Emissions Trading Scheme, despite the appeal that this is a sovereign decision of Iceland, we reiterate our deep criticism and disagreement with it.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I agree with the conclusions.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the agreement between the EU and its Member States, on the one hand, and Iceland, on the other, on its participation in the implementation of the Kyoto Protocol in the second period will send a signal of a joint European effort to tackle climate change at international level. We welcome the EU's position, which has become particularly crucial in international negotiations on climate change. That is why we consider it important that the Council's decision on the Doha Amendment, as well as iceland's participation in the joint implementation of its commitments, should be ratified in parallel and without undue delays.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 We reiterate our vote against. To be in favour of a greener world is not just to impose limits and disadvantages on Europe and its businesses.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The Doha Amendment establishes a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol, starting on 1 January 2013 and ending on 31 December 2020, with legally binding emissions-reduction commitments according to which the European Union, its Member States and Iceland are jointly committed to limit their average annual greenhouse gas emissions in the years 2013-2020 to 80% of their base-year (in most cases 1990) emissions. Since Iceland is not an EU Member State, the terms of joint fulfilment concerning its participation had to be laid down in a separate international agreement. The ratification decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol, and the joint fulfilment of the commitments by the European Union, will send a strong signal about the efforts and the leadership of the EU and its Member States in addressing climate change at international level, and the consent of the European Parliament to this agreement is therefore necessary.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Iceland is a country that has taken part in the commitments of the first part of the Kyoto Protocol and has also expressed its interest in being part of the second commitment period of the kyoto protocol, within the framework of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. Iceland has so far largely fulfilled all its climate commitments and is already participating with us in the Ets programme and the MMR mechanism. In view of the entry into force of the Doha Amendment and also of COP21, it is necessary to proceed with the most inclusive perspective possible. That is why we welcome iceland's commitments and renew our confidence in fruitful and broader cooperation. For these reasons, I voted yes to the report.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. The further reduction of greenhouse gas emissions in the renewed commitment enshrined in the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol is an important testimony to the battle of the Eu ropean Union and its Member States, together with Iceland, to make further progress in the strategy to combat pollution and combat global climate change. I welcome the ratification of the conclusion of the amendment, because it means approaching the great meeting of the Paris 2015 Conference with greater responsibility, setting ambitious targets on the universal climate agreement that will not only affect the amount of emissions from our countries, but also on the levels of growth, development, investment and work, capable of contemplating new forms of energy production and consumption.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP's position on the Council decision on the conclusion of the agreement between the EU and Iceland and Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of the commitments of the EU, its Member States and Iceland for the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change. The negotiations on climate change are at a crucial stage as the Paris Conference approaches. The recent discussions at the G7, culminating in the agreement reached between the leaders of the 7 participating countries, are a key step towards reaching an ambitious, comprehensive and legally binding agreement for all. The difficulties in convincing emerging countries require unity and firmness on the part of the EU, which must take the lead in the negotiations and become a driving force behind them. It is therefore essential to have a unified and shared position. Iceland, part of the Kyoto Protocol, has adopted the Doha Amendment and is calling for a joint commitment with the EU to respect the limits imposed therein.  I therefore believe that we must support this process, given that Iceland, which is part of the European Economic Area, is already participating in the ETS and MMR systems and shares European climate policy and that this decision would be a further sign of unity before its international partners.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ As I explained in the context of the Gardini report, I believe the ratification decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and the joint fulfilment of the commitments by the EU will send a strong signal about the efforts and the leadership of the EU and its Member States in addressing climate change at international level. I therefore supported the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. I also voted in favour of the La Via report, given Iceland is not an EU Member State, which means the terms of joint fulfilment concerning its participation in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol had to be laid down in a separate international agreement.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. ‒ I am keen to see Iceland, as part of the European Economic Area, ratify the Doha Amendment along with the EU. This is a positive example of the EU using its scale to encourage other European countries to commit to their climate change targets, so I was happy to vote in favour of this agreement.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of Iceland's participation in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol. Since Iceland is not a member of the EU, the terms on which its participation is reflected must be reflected in a separate international agreement.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my Labour Party colleagues, voted in favour of this report. Since Iceland is not an EU Member State, the terms of joint fulfilment concerning its participation had to be laid down in a separate international agreement. The proposed Council Decision provides the basis for the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Iceland, of the other part, concerning Iceland’s participation in the joint fulfilment of commitments for the Kyoto Protocol to the UNFCCC.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for a Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Iceland, of the other part, on the joint implementation of the commitments of the European Union, its Member States and Iceland. I believe that the inclusion of Iceland in the EU's fight against climate change shows that we must fight for our planet not by EU member states, but internationally. The EU is one of the world leaders in the fight against climate change, because the objectives we set are ambitious, understandable and legally binding. We must therefore not hesitate to give an example to other countries and encourage them to contribute to a cleaner, safer world.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. U2012 Voting positively to the Decision to ratify, on the part of the EU and Iceland, the commitments of the Doha amendment mean sending a very positive signal. Ahead of the Paris Summit, the European Union tells the world that it wants to continue to lead the fight against climate change, setting an example while inviting the most reluctant and most polluting to continue investing in the future.  Doha is a good dressing to keep the Kyoto Protocol alive, but Paris must be the event that sees a new binding agreement born. It's about adding up wills, but also involving all parties alike in the search for a model that stops harming the planet and engaging our future generations. The G-7 has already sat down to talk about it and emerging people are seen with good predisposition. That is why the ratification of Doha by the EU and Iceland makes us proud that, despite the unrecorated criticisms of some 'climate-sceptic' sectors, we are on the right track.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report because I believe that such an agreement sends a strong signal about EU efforts to address climate change at an international level. Iceland expressed its intention to jointly fulfil its commitments under the second period with the EU and its Member States in 2009, and today we supported this. The EU has long been a driving force in international negotiations on climate change and was instrumental in developing the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change and the Kyoto Protocol. The Doha Amendment establishes a second commitment period from 2013 to 2020, with legally binding emission reduction targets which we already have under our 2020 framework. According to these, the EU, its Member States and Iceland are jointly committed to limiting their average annual greenhouse gas emissions to 80% of their 1990 emissions.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ Iceland is a near neighbour of my own country and I was delighted to vote in favour of its continued participation with the EU in implementing the Kyoto Protocol.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of Iceland's participation in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol. Since Iceland is not a member of the EU, the terms on which its participation is reflected must be reflected in a separate international agreement.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft decision to conclude an agreement between the EU and its Member States and Iceland on Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of the commitments of the European Union, its Member States and Iceland in the second binding period of the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, as a result of the fact that it sends a strong message on the European Union's coordinated efforts on climate change at international level.  It is extremely positive that Iceland has decided to meet the objectives of the second binding period regardless of membership of the European Union, as it is also a message to other countries about the importance of joint efforts on global problems and challenges. A multilateral approach to addressing climate change, based on clear regulations, can certainly contribute to effective and sustainable progress in protecting international interests.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I have decided to vote against this recommendation on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the agreement between the EU and its Member States, on the one hand, and Iceland, on the other, on Iceland's participation in the joint implementation of the commitments during the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol. Iceland is already taking part in the carbon market and the EU's declaration of greenhouse gases, and the European Union, which is seeking to become a leader in reducing these gases, wants to bring other states with it. Iceland has the advantage of being a particularly low-polluting state. The Kyoto Protocol and its provisions are ineffective, so will the second commitment period. Indeed, the main polluters, the United States, China or Canada, have not ratified it, thus demonstrating a political pragmatism that is sorely lacking in Brussels. Moreover, emerging countries, which were not necessarily so in 1994, when the protocol was signed, are not mentioned in Schedule 1 of the agreement, which defines countries subject to the reduction targets. Such a mechanism must be repealed to make way for bilateral agreements.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Giovanni La Via's report on the EU-Iceland agreement on Iceland's participation in the Kyoto Protocol. This essentially technical text allows Iceland to participate in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol, more commonly known as the Doha Amendment, which was signed in December 2012. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Iceland is joining the EU in joining the second commitment period to meet the Kyoto targets. This is a noble act, but because of the large number of issuers who do not want to be committed, I am abstaining.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I support the recommendation that the agreement in relation to the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol between the European Union and Iceland should be concluded as soon as possible. As Iceland already participates in the EU Emissions Trading System and the EU Monitoring Mechanism Regulation for greenhouse gases, the conclusion of the agreement with Iceland with regard to the second commitment period for the Kyoto agreement would send a strong signal that Europe is leading the way in pursuing a global solution to climate change. This should also act as encouragement for countries to take a similar approach in the lead—up to the Paris COP21 Conference in December.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly supported the recommendation to ensure that the Doha climate agreement, setting targets for emissions reductions up to 2020, is still ratified by the end of the year.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The EU Climate and Energy Package determines the total greenhouse emissions allowed for the period 2013-2020. The EU Member States and Iceland undertook the commitment to limit their average annual greenhouse emissions (2013 – 2020) to 80% of their base year emissions (Second Commitment period under Kyoto Protocol). I have voted in favour in order to facilitate the conclusion of the separate Agreement between the European Union and its Member States with Iceland, so that Iceland participates in the joint fulfilment of commitments under the Kyoto Protocol.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Parliament approved this proposal, for which I am rapporteur, by a very large majority. I believe that the agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Iceland, on the other, with regard to Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of the commitments for the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol, will be a strong signal that will highlight coordinated European efforts to combat climate change at international level, especially in view of the forthcoming COP 21 in Paris. The European Union has a position as a world leader in the fight against climate change and has always supported an ambitious climate policy. We will also do so with a view to Paris, stepping up efforts for an agreement that is ambitious, comprehensive and legally binding.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The report confirms the decision to continue to allow Iceland's cooperation in new EU efforts. Iceland, a Kyoto student who has managed to reduce emissions below the 10% awarded to it, stated in 2009 its intention to also opt for the fulfilment of Kyoto's second commitment period jointly with the EU. The Council welcomed this request and urged the Commission to implement the procedures for ratification by the other institutions and Member States.  Although accession negotiations are ongoing, Iceland is already actively involved in the Community Emissions Trading Scheme (STD) and the EU Mechanism for monitoring and reporting greenhouse gas emissions. In accordance with these considerations, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change was signed in 1997 with the aim of setting an internationally binding target for emissions reduction. The EU ratified this protocol in 2015. In 2012, the Doha Climate Change Conference approved an amendment to The Kyoto Protocol 1 establishing a second period (2013 to 2020) with legally binding emission reduction commitments for the parties. By this amendment, EU Member States and Iceland undertook to reduce their annual average greenhouse gas emission. Since Iceland is not part of the EU, it has been necessary to sign this separate agreement for participation. I supported this report which consents to Iceland's participation in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol as a positive step, although I believe that this agreement is still quite far from effectively combating climate change on its own, as it lacks additional measures, such as climate justice provisions, as well as serious commitments by the most industrialized countries.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I support The Recommendation of La Via, which welcomes the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and Iceland to jointly fulfil the obligations of the Kyoto Protocol for a second binding period. The targets for this period were agreed in 2012 and commit to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 2020 by 20 percent from 1990. The signing of this agreement sends a strong message of the European Union's commitment to achieving its international greenhouse gas emission reduction targets. The aim of the agreement is to lay down the conditions governing Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of the Obligations of the European Union and to enable effective participation. It calls for the swift signing of the agreement. At the end of the year, the Convention in Paris will decide on a strategy for the post-2020 period, but before that, the Doha amendments are to adopt and prepared plans for Member States and Iceland on how to meet the 2020 targets.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. \u2012 This week the European Parliament unconditionally committed to ambitious steps against climate change. With the adoption of the Kyoto Protocol Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol, the European Union and Iceland firmly declare their determination to reduce their emissions by an average of 20% from 1990 levels for the period 2013 to 2020. I therefore believe that the European Union's request to achieve further emission reductions by 2020, provided for such a commitment by other developed countries, makes a crucial call and guarantee for concrete action. I believe that with this decision, the European Parliament is once again showing not only the European Union's readiness to tackle global climate change, but also a demand for global leadership and partnership in this area. And most importantly: in doing so, the European Union sets a high bar for the negotiations at the UN Climate Change Conference in Paris in late 2015, where world leaders will discuss their commitments to keep global warming below 2 degrees.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. Iceland's participation in the second stage of the Kyoto Protocol implementations will benefit the global state of the atmosphere and the reduction of carbon monoxide emissions. I'm pleased to have voted for it. I am also pleased that 626 other Members of Parliament have approved the report. Such unanimity among Members is not common.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing \ u2012 Article 4 of the Kyoto Protocol allows the Parties to fulfil their obligations jointly. In a joint statement, the EU and its Member States expressed their intention to meet their emission reduction targets in the second commitment period, together with the extension of the parties to the joint implementation to Iceland, following its formal request of June 2009.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Iceland, of the other part, on Iceland's participation in the joint response to the obligations undertaken by the European Union, its Member States and Iceland in the second period of commitment of the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 9/6/2015, but also because an ambitious target for reducing climate change is being set, that of limiting average annual greenhouse gas emissions in the years 2013 to 2020 to 80% for both the European Union and its Member States and Iceland.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this recommendation. This Kyoto Protocol is proving ineffective and unnecessary since the main polluters and potential polluters are not, in any case, or more concerned. Iceland has the distinction of being low-polluting due, among other things, to its geothermal exploitation. For this reason, we do not think it is necessary to impose this protocol on Iceland, and we oppose this agreement.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the agreement on Iceland's participation in the second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol, in which the EU, its Member States and Iceland jointly commit to limiting their average annual greenhouse gas emissions to 80% of their emissions in the reference year. Iceland's participation is a strong signal that it underlines coordinated European efforts to combat climate change at international level and contributes to the fulfilment of the Union's communication obligations for the second period of commitment under the Kyoto Protocol.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement between the European Union, its Member States and Iceland on iceland's participation in the kyoto protocol commitments for the second commitment period, enshrined in the Doha Amendment, is a strong signal in the fight against climate change at international level. Given that the European Union plays a leading role in international negotiations on climate change, I felt it was right to support the report signed by My colleague Mr La Via.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. In the European Parliament, we support the proposal for a Council Decision for the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Iceland, on the other hand, on Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of commitments in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol. This agreement will also make visible the EU's coordinated work in the fight against climate change at international level, as the rapporteur of Parliament's report underlines, and to which I have added my vote.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. In its conclusions of 9 March 2012, the Council agreed to propose a common quantified emission reduction commitment for the Union for the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol for the Union, below 1990 levels. I abstained because of the apparent non-commitment of other states outside the EU and the scientifically controversial view that climate change can be stopped by humans by reducing CO2 emissions.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as Iceland is also committed to the Kyoto Protocol despite not being an EU Member State. Ratification of the Doha Amendment in a timely manner, before the Climate Change Conference in Paris at the end of 2015, is essential.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This report also concerns the so-called Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol.  The EU and Iceland have made commitments to combat climate change. Together, they define and report emissions levels and their ratification. These commitments are largely inadequate. They are not followed by the biggest polluters on the planet. They will not be able to reach the European level by relying on the current "carbon market". We cannot send a "strong signal" for the next meeting in Paris, COP21, without changing these methods and objectives. Let's change the system, not the climate!  I support the need for a binding model to combat climate warming, but not in these insufficient conditions. I abstain.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. Iceland is already taking part in the carbon market and the European Union's declaration of greenhouse gases, which seeks to become a leader in reducing these gases, wants to bring other states with it. Iceland has the advantage of being a particularly low-polluting state. The Kyoto Protocol and its provisions are ineffective, so will the second commitment period. Indeed, the main polluters, the United States, China or Canada, have not ratified it, thus demonstrating a political pragmatism that is sorely lacking in Brussels. Moreover, emerging countries, which were not necessarily so in 1994, when the protocol was signed, are not mentioned in Schedule 1 of the agreement, which defines countries subject to the reduction targets. Such a mechanism must be repealed to make way for bilateral agreements. I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and its Member States and Iceland on Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of commitments in the second period of the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). The EU is a strategic part of international climate change negotiations, and this agreement is further evidence of its serious involvement in meeting commitments jointly.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this recommendation as it is an extension of the vote on the approval of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. This recommendation concerns the agreement between the European Union and Iceland concerning Iceland’s participation in the joint fulfilment of their commitments for the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – With the adoption of the Council Decision on Iceland's participation in the joint European climate efforts during the second commitment period, the EU confirms its role as a driving and recruiting force in the fight against climate change. At Iceland's request, the negotiations with the EU were concluded in 2014 if the 'joint fulfilment' of the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol is to be achieved with different partners. By stepping into this partnership with the EU, Iceland is committed, together with the EU and its Member States, to meet the targets for a significant reduction in greenhouse gases and to take necessary steps to stop the adverse effects of climate change. The joint initiative of the EU and its Member States, on the one hand, and Iceland on the other, underlines the need and importance of a common, global and international approach to the climate challenge.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing \ u2012 The Kyoto Protocol entered into force in February 2005 and aims at binding emission reductions in the first period (2008-2012). The EU and the Member States have ratified this Convention and are committed to reducing emissions by 8% compared to the 1990 level of emissions. Iceland, which is not an EU Member State but has also ratified the Kyoto Protocol, has also committed itself to reducing emissions at the same level. In 2012, at the Doha Climate Change Conference, the Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol was adopted extending the emission reduction period until 2020 and where the parties agreed to gradually reduce emissions to 80% from 1990 levels. As Iceland is not an EU Member State, the Council Decision allows for an agreement between the EU and its Member States and between the EU and Iceland, for mediating Iceland's participation and creating a binding obligation towards the EU. For this agreement to be effective, I agree that the Council's decision on the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of its obligations under this Convention must be ratified in parallel well in advance of the start of the UNFCCC conference in Paris at the end of 2015.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU-Iceland agreement on participation in the second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol. The Doha Amendment establishes a second commitment period under the Protocol, starting on 1 January 2013 and ending on 31 December 2020, with legally binding emissions-reduction commitments according to which the European Union, its Member States and Iceland are jointly committed to limit their average annual greenhouse gas emissions in the years 2013-2020 to 80% of their base-year (in most cases 1990) emissions. Since Iceland is not an EU Member State, the terms of joint fulfilment concerning its participation had to be laid down in a separate international agreement. The ratification decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol, and the joint fulfilment of the commitments by the European Union, will send a strong signal about the efforts and the leadership of the EU and its Member States in addressing climate change at international level, and the consent of the European Parliament to this agreement is therefore necessary.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Iceland is not a member of the European Union, but for the second period of commitment of the Kyoto Protocol, they jointly underthrew a 20% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions compared to 1990. The agreement sets out the obligations of the EU Member States on the one hand and Iceland on the other, so its support logically follows from the support for the Doha Amendment.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. Iceland is a Party to the Kyoto Protocol, respecting the objectives set during the first commitment period. The Commission, on behalf of the European Union and its Member States, and Iceland concluded in 2014 the negotiations necessary for joint compliance in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol.  Iceland participates in the EU Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) and the monitoring and reporting mechanism on greenhouse gas emissions. The rights and obligations that apply to Member States in the framework of joint compliance should apply to Iceland through EU legislation. Iceland has shown an interest in participating in joint compliance with the EU and its Member States, regardless of whether or not it joins the EU.  I am voting in favour of this report as I endorse the rapporteur's position in considering that the Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Iceland, on the other hand, on Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of commitments in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change , will be a clear signal regarding coordinated European efforts to combat climate change at international level.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. As Iceland, part of the EU's carbon market and greenhouse gas declaration, the European Parliament must be consulted to incorporate it into the Kyoto commitments for the second period. The report therefore proposes to adopt the Council's position. But these agreements will place new constraints on the Member States of the European Union, while other countries, which are polluting more, have excluded themselves (United States, China, Canada...) or are not concerned (emerging countries). This new period of commitments will therefore prove ineffective. Finally, Iceland is a particularly low-polluting country thanks in particular to its important geothermal activity. I therefore see no reason to impose new constraints on it. So I voted against this report.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, since because Iceland is not an EU Member State, the terms of joint fulfilment concerning its participation had to be laid down in a separate international agreement. The proposed Council Decision provides the basis for the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Iceland, of the other part, concerning Iceland’s participation in the joint fulfilment of commitments for the Kyoto Protocol to the UNFCCC. Finally the ratification decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and the joint fulfilment of the commitments by the European Union will send a strong signal about the efforts and the leadership of the EU and its Member States to address climate change at international level, therefore rendering the consent of the European Parliament to this agreement necessary.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this purely technical text, relating to Iceland's accession to the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol, under the agreement between the European Union and Iceland. Our Icelandic partner, even if it is not part of the EU, will also continue its efforts to reduce carbon emissions, which are important for safeguarding the future of our planet.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Doha Amendment establishes a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol and provides for legally binding emission reduction obligations under which the European Union, its Member States and Iceland jointly undertake to limit their average annual greenhouse gas emissions. Iceland, although not a Member State, participates in the EU Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS) and the EU Monitoring Mechanism (MMR) Regulation for Greenhouse Gases. The rights and obligations which apply to Member States in the context of joint fulfilment must therefore be made applicable to Iceland by means of a legislative proposal. Our vote today in favour of this iceland participation agreement will be a strong signal, highlighting coordinated European efforts to combat climate change at international level. The European Union has long played a leading role in international negotiations on climate change and has made a key contribution to the creation of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and the Kyoto Protocol. We believe that we must continue to support the conclusion of a final agreement that is ambitious, comprehensive and legally binding.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour, in the light of the foreign affairs committee's letter, of the recommendation of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, the Council's request for approval and the agreement between the EU and its Member States (including Iceland) and iceland's participation in the joint implementation of the EU's commitments during the second commitment period.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The report signed by Mr La Via examines the proposal for a Council decision providing the basis for the signing of the agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Iceland, on the other, with regard to Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of unfccc's CP2 KP commitments. This document finally marks a new phase in which the European Union, its Member States and Iceland undertake, through binding targets, to jointly reduce annual greenhouse gas emissions. I therefore voted in favour of the recommendation because I believe that the two Council decisions on the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of the kyoto protocol commitments must be ratified in parallel without unnecessary delay and certainly well before the UNFCCC Paris Conference.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I support Iceland's participation in the second commitment phase of the Kyoto Protocol. I believe that it will be easier for us to achieve the objectives set for the stages ahead. On the other hand, I think it is important to work with other major powers, such as China, U.S. also cooperate, which are the largest gas emitting states.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report because the agreement with Iceland, in its Annex II, contains the same terms of joint fulfilment that are also laid down in an Annex to the Council Decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol to the UNFCCC and the joint fulfilment of commitments thereunder.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. As part of the Doha agreement on extending the commitment period of the signatory parties to the Kyoto Protocol, the European Union and Iceland have committed to enforcing the new commitments until 2020. As Iceland is a non-EU country, a separate international agreement had to be reached between the two parties to include Iceland in the joint commitments on the Kyoto Protocol. I obviously voted in favour of this recommendation, which commits a large number of countries to work together against climate change.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Iceland is a party listed in Annex I to the Kyoto Protocol that achieved the individual target for the first commitment period. The Doha amendments introduced a second commitment period for the Kyoto Protocol, on which Iceland has expressed its wish to jointly meet its commitments with the EU, regardless of its possible accession or non-accession to the EU.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I welcome the conclusion of the agreement. The conclusion of this agreement is proof that the EU is committed to a rules-based multilateral framework. At the same time, this is an excellent example of other countries taking joint action to address climate change at international level. In order to keep global average warming below 2°C to industrial level, it is necessary to immediately reduce the impact of human activity on climate change and to take immediate joint action. If urgent action is not taken, climate change will have dire, comprehensive and irreversible consequences for the entire world." Achieving the objectives set requires a global climate change agreement, which provides for greenhouse gas reduction commitments for the entire international community. It should be noted that the EU has long set an example and has been determined to mitigate global climate change. The EU is the driving force behind international climate negotiations, which consistently supports a broad policy to combat climate change.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that iceland's inclusion alongside the EU in the fulfilment of the Second Kyoto Protocol, the so-called Doha Amendment, can act as a stimulus for other states to follow the European example on a path of reducing greenhouse gas emissions. I would like to thank Mr La Via for his excellent work.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒I welcome the recommendation to take a decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Iceland, on the other hand, of Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of the obligations of the European Union, its Member States and Iceland in the second binding period of the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change.  Iceland's accession to this agreement in the framework of joint fulfilment of its obligations with the European Union indicates the correctness of the Union's climate policy and it is certainly necessary to welcome Iceland's position, when it comes to climate protection, which is similar to that of Croatia before its accession to the EU. Solving a common problem together is the right, responsible and good path.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The rapporteur suggests adopting the Council's position on Iceland's integration into the Kyoto commitments for the second period. Iceland participates in the carbon market and the european Union's declaration of greenhouse gases. It is a particularly low-polluting state, thanks in particular to its exploitation of geothermal energy. The Union wants to position itself as a leader in greenhouse gas reduction actions and therefore seeks to lead other states into its own commitments. This will mainly result in additional constraints for the Member States. I have already explained that the Kyoto agreements are ineffective anyway because of the non-involvement of the most polluting states and emerging countries. The good results in Europe are more the effect of deindustrialization and technological progress than of binding measures. I therefore vote against this report.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I support the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, the agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Iceland, on the other, on Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of the commitments of the European Union, its Member States and Iceland in the second binding period of the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, since I believe that this agreement sends a strong signal of concerted European action in the fight against climate change at international level.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the joint compliance mechanism, which is a specific feature of the Kyoto Protocol, is a good means for the parties to undertake to comply with their obligations to reduce emissions. If the joint commitment is not maintained, each participant is individually responsible for its level of emissions. In this way, I believe that there is a greater motivation for the participants to respect the commitments they have made. I welcome Iceland's interest and participation, and I voted in favour of the second period of Iceland's joint fulfilment with the EU and its Member States. I hope that all participants will respect the levels set out in the Kyoto Protocol for emissions.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's recommendation to allow Iceland to participate in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol. This technical text specifies how this commitment will be implemented between the EU and Iceland on the one hand, and between the European Union and the United Nations on the other.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The Doa Amendment establishes a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol, beginning on 1 January 2013 and ending on 31 December 2020, with commitments to reduce legally binding emissions according to which the European Union, its Member States and Iceland undertake to limit their average annual greenhouse gas emissions , in the period 2013 to 2020, at 80 % of its emissions in the reference year (in general, 1990).  This proposal for a Council Decision provides the basis for the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Iceland, on the other, on Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of the commitments for this second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol. Because I believe that this Agreement is another sign of the European Union's determination in the fight against climate change and in the definition of an ambitious policy in this area, I voted in favour of its conclusion.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which brings Iceland together with the other Member States of the European Union in setting binding targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions for the period 2013-2020 through the joint ratification of the Doha Amendment. Having already joined the European Union in 2009, we are pleased that it is renewing its participation in the quota trading system and the European Union's mechanism for monitoring and reporting greenhouse gas emissions. The climate stakes are immense and in these areas, the more collective the work, the better the results will be.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 Although Iceland is not an EU Member State, it intends to fulfil this second commitment of the Kyoto Protocol together with the EU and its Member States. The rights and obligations that apply to Member States in joint compliance must apply to Iceland through EU legislation. It is yet another clear signal from the EU about European efforts to combat climate change at international level.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. U2012 Voting positively to the Decision to ratify, on the part of the EU and Iceland, the commitments of the Doha amendment mean sending a very positive signal. Ahead of the Paris Summit, the European Union tells the world that it wants to continue to lead the fight against climate change, setting an example while inviting the most reluctant and most polluting to continue investing in the future.  Doha is a good dressing to keep the Kyoto Protocol alive, but Paris must be the event that sees a new binding agreement born. It's about adding up wills, but also involving all parties alike in the search for a model that stops harming the planet and engaging our future generations. The G-7 has already sat down to talk about it and emerging people are seen with good predisposition. That is why the ratification of Doha by the EU and Iceland makes us proud that, despite the unrecorated criticism of some 'climate-sceptic' sectors, we are on the right track.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The Kyoto Protocol on climate change was signed in 1997. It sets a binding international emissions reduction target. By ratifying the protocol, the European Union pledged to reduce its greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by 8% compared to 1990 levels in the first period (2008-2012). In 2012, the Doha conference adopted an amendment to the protocol that established a second commitment period (from 2013 to 2020) with legally binding GHG reduction commitments, under which the EU commits to limiting its annual GHG emissions to 80% of its annual emissions over the period 2013-2020 compared to 1990.  The Doha amendment also makes three changes to the Kyoto text that must be implemented during this second commitment period: the inclusion of a new gas; an ambition-related mechanism that provides for a simplified procedure allowing a party to adjust its commitment by raising its level of ambition during a commitment period. The report voted today gives its approval to the conclusion of the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The Doa Amendment establishes a second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol (for the period 2013-2020). Indeed, in 2012, in the absence of a comprehensive and effective agreement capable of replacing it, it was decided to extend the Kyoto Protocol, which remains the only legally binding emission reduction commitment. Although Iceland is not an EU Member State, it also wants to fulfil its commitment under the EU Climate and Energy Package with regard to the kyoto protocol's 'second period' targets, together with the EU and its Member States.  There is no reason to avoid this agreement, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. The Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol was adopted at the climate change conference in December 2012. It establishes a second commitment period for the Kyoto Protocol, which began on 1 January 2013 and will end on 31 December 2020, and provides for legally binding commitments to reduce emissions. Iceland has expressed its intention to meet its greenhouse gas reduction commitments jointly with the European Union during the second commitment period (2013-2020). I supported this text, which sends a signal about the Coordinated efforts of the European Union in the fight against climate change, in particular in view of the 2015 Paris climate change conference.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 By voting in favour of the text presented by Mr Beazley, i.e. by voting in favour of the text presented by Mr Beazley, i.e. by voting in favour of the text presented by Mr Be The Way, Parliament will start the conclusion of agreements between the European Union and its Member States on the one hand and Iceland on the other, with regard to Iceland's participation in the second commitment period under the Kyoto Protocol. We must, in fact, remember that Iceland is not a Member State of the Union, which is why the terms of its participation have been set out in a special international agreement.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote against because I consider the effects of the Kyoto Protocol on the amount of CO2 released into the atmosphere globally to be completely marginal.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of Iceland's participation in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol. Since Iceland is not a member of the EU, the terms on which its participation is reflected must be reflected in a separate international agreement.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the European Parliament's recommendation to allow rapid ratification of the agreement between the European Union, the Member States and Iceland, which expresses the intention of the parties to jointly achieve their greenhouse gas emission reduction targets, as part of the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol. This decision has the merit of reaffirming the importance of cooperating internationally in the fight against climate change. Iceland will be required to apply some of the Eu ropean Union's emission monitoring, reporting and verification regulations, and to provide all information enabling the EU to fulfil its reporting obligations. Joint fulfilment will therefore mean that the contracting parties will have the same rights, rules and, above all, the essential sharing of efforts to effectively reduce emissions. I hope that this approach will soon be part of the wider framework of a climate agreement, involving the entire international community.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 I share with the rapporteur the positive feeling regarding the joint participation of the European Union and Iceland in meeting the kyoto protocol's second commitment period targets. This is a particularly important but still insufficient moment. More countries need to be captivated for the full fulfilment of the kyoto targets and other relevant conventions for combating and mitigating climate change. As with the so-called ozone hole, swift and incisive measures must be taken that really make a difference. Do you have any costs? Yes, it has costs and these are very high. However, what is the price of looking at our children and grandchildren in a few years and saying that we have not done everything in our power? I'm not willing to pay that price. You have to do it and do it now. I congratulate the European Union on aligning itself with Iceland, a country that has managed to reduce emissions, with virtually residual use of fossil fuels.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ The ratification decision on the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and the joint fulfilment of the commitments by the European Union will send a strong signal about the efforts and the leadership of the EU and its Member States to address climate change at international level, therefore rendering the consent of the European Parliament to this agreement necessary.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ although Iceland is not a Member State of the European Union, participates in the European Union's emissions trading scheme and has therefore decided to fulfil its commitment to the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol and to participate in the joint implementation with the European Union, I therefore voted in favour of the motion for this resolution.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the EP resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of an agreement between the EU and its Member States, on the one hand, and Iceland, on the other, on Iceland's participation in the joint implementation of the commitments of the EU, its Member States and Iceland in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change on behalf of the EU. Iceland is a Contracting Party to Annex I to the Kyoto Protocol which has fulfilled its individual objective set for the first commitment period.
