During the first commitment period, Iceland was to limit the increase in emissions to an average of less than 10%. Iceland's emissions even decreased by an average of 2 % during this period.  The good news is that Iceland is interested in joint implementation of the Kyoto Protocol with the EU and its Member States, regardless of whether it accedes to the EU or not. The accession negotiations between Iceland and the EU therefore have no impact on the joint implementation of the commitment for the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft agreement proposed by the Council on Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of the commitments of the European Union and its Member States for the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. As a contracting party to the Kyoto Protocol, Iceland in 2009 expressed its intention to fulfil its commitments in the second commitment period jointly with the EU and its Member States. This decision is part of and continues the existing cooperation on the fulfilment of commitments to combat climate change. Despite the suspension of EU accession negotiations, Iceland participates in the ETS emissions trading scheme and the EU regulation on the greenhouse gas monitoring mechanism. This collaboration is significant in view of the UNFCCC conference in Paris because it highlights the coordinated European efforts to combat climate change at international level and the leading role taken by the European Union in this field.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: writing \ u2012 I appreciate Iceland's proactive approach to environmental issues and tackling climate change. Although Iceland is not an EU Member State, it nevertheless participates in the EU ETS and intends to fulfil its commitment in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol together with the EU and its Member States. It is therefore necessary that the rights and obligations applicable to Member States in the joint implementation also apply to Iceland, through EU law and a new agreement between the EU, all Member States and Iceland.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I support this recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Agreement between the European Union and Iceland on Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of the obligations of the European Union, Member States and Iceland in the second binding period of the Kyoto Protocol, with the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, as I consider that in order to reduce environmental pollution, which can have major impacts on life worldwide, it is necessary that as many countries as possible stick to the provisions of the Kyoto Protocol.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒I support the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Iceland, on the other, of Iceland's participation in the joint fulfilment of the obligations of the European Union, its Member States and Iceland in the second binding period of the Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change.  The rapporteur welcomes the proposal for a Council decision that is the basis for concluding an agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Iceland, on the other. This would like to highlight some aspects of the proposal for a Council decision. Iceland does not participate in emissions trading in the European Union's greenhouse gas emissions system.  The rights and obligations applicable to Member States in jointly fulfilling their obligations should apply to Iceland through EU law. Accession negotiations between Iceland and the EU therefore do not affect the joint fulfilment of commitments jointly agreed by the European Union and Iceland for the second binding period of the Kyoto Protocol.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on a draft Council decision on the signing of the Agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Iceland, of the other part, with regard to Iceland's participation in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol. Iceland was already a party to the first target period when it successfully met all the objectives set. The European Union is playing a leading role in the world in the fight against climate change, and I support the continuation of such a policy. I support iceland's annexation to the second target period of the Kyoto Protocol, as it will strengthen the fight against climate change, and the European Union will once again give a clear signal of coordinated European cooperation in the fight against climate change.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Reducing combined greenhouse gas emissions with the ultimate aim of reducing increasingly intense climate change is a positive step towards improving environmental conditions.  It is clear to us that environmental destruction is mainly caused by the unregulated activity of large companies, which in order to maximize their profits sacrifice the environment, transferring the burdens to the peoples (social, economic, etc.).  In order to take substantial steps towards improving environmental conditions, the EU must first and foremost change its course, stop promoting neoliberal policies and put barriers in the free market.  We also consider it important that the EU Member States, but also all States in general, take concrete action, depending on their particular circumstances and capabilities, in order to put an end to the violent exploitation of the environment. For these reasons we voted in favour.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Iceland is part of Annex I to the Kyoto Protocol, which has succeeded in meeting its individual objectives for the first commitment period. It expressed its intention to jointly honour its commitments in a second period of engagement with the EU.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft resolution on Iceland's commitment to the conclusion of the Doha Amendment to the Kyoto Protocol. As a member of the European Parliament delegation to Switzerland, Norway and Iceland, I believe it is important that environmental principles apply not only to EU countries but also to EEA countries. I believe that there is openness on both sides of the commitments, as evidenced by the experience of the last few months. I also welcome the commitment of not only the Member States of the European Union but also Iceland to the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol (2013-2020). As the draft points out, Iceland is a party to Annex I to the Kyoto Protocol; the country has met its individual objective for the first commitment period. Iceland had to keep emissions growth below 10% on average during the first commitment period. In 2009, Iceland indicated that it intends to meet its commitments jointly with the EU and its Member States during the second commitment period. I think it is important to note that Iceland participates in the EU Emissions Trading Scheme (EU ETS) and is covered by the Greenhouse Gas Monitoring Scheme Regulation. Therefore, the rights and obligations applicable under the common performance of the Member States should be extended to Iceland through EU legislation.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The agreement between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Iceland, on the other, on Iceland's participation in the joint implementation of the commitments of the European Union, its Member States and Iceland during the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol will send a strong signal about coordinated European efforts in the fight against climate change at the international level. The European Union has long played a leading role in international climate change negotiations and has been instrumental in the development of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and the Kyoto Protocol.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the EU-Iceland Agreement on Iceland’s participation in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol recommendation. The Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change was signed in 1997 setting an internationally binding emission reduction target. I welcome the intention of Iceland to join the EU’s commitments for the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol. The EU in general strongly supports commitments of individual states to reduce their collective greenhouse gas emissions, and this step could serve as an important example and signal on the international level.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 The International G7 Climate Summit finally led to an agreement setting a binding target for global temperature containment and the creation of a fund for initiatives in developing countries. We are on the right track, but at the Paris Conference we will have to ensure that the global agreement binds all countries, including the emerging countries, which are often among the most polluting. Much has been done from Kyoto to Paris, but we need a joint effort by all Member States and third countries to combat climate change. The European institutions play a decisive role in international negotiations and we can only welcome this agreement with Iceland, which reaffirms a commitment to ambitious, comprehensive and legally binding targets.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒This Amendment of Doha establishes a second period which allows contracting parties, the European Union and member states on the one hand and Iceland on the other, to achieve greenhouse gas emission reduction targets. States have pledged to reduce their average greenhouse gas emissions by up to 80% compared to their emissions on an annual basis.  Effective resolution of problems arising from climate change is only possible through a multilateral approach with provisions based on legal bases or international regulations. I believe that Iceland, as a non-Union country, is a good indicator that joint international action can contribute to global efforts to cope with increasingly frequent climate change, and in addition, a strong message on coordinated European efforts is being sent. As a representative from a country where the energy sector encounters challenges in terms of energy management, as well as the use of renewable energy sources, I believe that activities should primarily focus on increasing energy efficiency, developing the energy market and ultimately regulating energy prices that will be acceptable to all citizens. By implementing such measures, we will contribute to the achievement of long-term goals that include environmental protection, an invaluable Croatian resource, and therefore I supported this report.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the recommendation on an AGREEMENT between the EU and Iceland on iceland's participation in the second target period of the Kyoto Protocol. Iceland is a Party under Annex I to the Kyoto Protocol which has met its target for the first commitment period, when it has had to limit the increase in its emissions by an average of no more than 10 %. This country is also interested in jointly fulfilling its commitments for the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol. The agreement between the European Union and its Member States, of the one part, and Iceland, of the other part, is a strong signal of coordinated European action to tackle climate change at international level.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of Iceland's participation in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol. Since Iceland is not a member of the EU, the terms on which its participation is reflected must be reflected in a separate international agreement.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The rapporteur suggests adopting the Council's position on Iceland's integration into the Kyoto commitments for the second period. Iceland is already involved in the EU's carbon market and greenhouse gas declaration. This state has the distinction of being low polluting, exploiting geothermal energy for example. The Union wants to position itself as a leader in GHG reduction actions and therefore seeks to lead other states into its own commitments. But these acccords prove ineffective. The great disparity in global efforts in the fight against climate change is counterproductive and it is not acceptable to extend the application of such a mechanism, especially since European states bear these constraints while other states abstain from them. The stubbornness to continue in this logic is therefore paradoxical. I am voting against this text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of Iceland's participation in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol. Since Iceland is not an EU Member State, the terms on which its participation is reflected must be reflected in a separate international agreement.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the agreement between the European Union and Iceland because I welcome Iceland's intention to meet the joint commitments of the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol, the thus strengthening the EU's role in combating climate change.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. This Recommendation is intended to highlight that, in order to achieve the entry into force of the Doha amendment to the Kyoto Protocol, Iceland must ratify the Doha amendment and the agreement itself. That is why I believe that your vote should be positive.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. U2012 Voting positively to the Decision to ratify, on the part of the EU and Iceland, the commitments of the Doha amendment mean sending a very positive signal. Ahead of the Paris Summit, the European Union tells the world that it wants to continue to lead the fight against climate change, setting an example while inviting the most reluctant and most polluting to continue investing in the future.  Doha is a good dressing to keep the Kyoto Protocol alive, but Paris must be the event that sees a new binding agreement born. It's about adding up wills, but also involving all parties alike in the search for a model that stops harming the planet and engaging our future generations. The G-7 has already sat down to talk about it and emerging people are seen with good predisposition. That is why the ratification of Doha by the EU and Iceland makes us proud that, despite the unrecorated criticisms of some 'climate-sceptic' sectors, we are on the right track.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The Kyoto Protocol to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change was signed in 1997 with the aim of setting an internationally binding target for emissions reduction. The EU ratified this protocol in 2015. In 2012, the Doha Climate Change Conference approved an amendment to The Kyoto Protocol 1 establishing a second period (2013 to 2020) with legally binding emission reduction commitments for the parties. By this amendment, EU Member States and Iceland undertook to reduce their annual average greenhouse gas emission. Since Iceland is not part of the EU, it has been necessary to sign this separate agreement for participation. I supported this report which consents to Iceland's participation in the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol as a positive step, although I believe that this agreement is still quite far from effectively combating climate change on its own, as it lacks additional measures, such as climate justice provisions, as well as serious commitments by the most industrialized countries.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. In its conclusions of 9 March 2012, the Council agreed to propose a common quantified emission reduction commitment for the Union for the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol for the Union, below 1990 levels. I abstained because of the apparent non-commitment of other states outside the EU and the scientifically controversial view that climate change can be stopped by humans by reducing CO2 emissions.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today for Parliament to give its consent to the conclusion of the bilateral EU-Iceland agreement on compliance with the second period of compliance with the Kyoto Protocol. As a member of the European Economic Area, Iceland is already participating in the greenhouse gas emissions trading scheme. I think it is important that the commitments made in the field of climate change should be extended to European countries that are not members of the Union.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. Annex I to the Act of Accession contains a list of conventions and protocols to which Member States are to accede, including the Convention on Judicial Assistance in Criminal Matters. Since Croatia accedes to this Convention in the context of its accession to the European Union independently and as a sovereign state, I voted in favour of respecting its decisions in accordance with the principle of self-determination.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Following its accession to the EU in July 2013, Croatia is now the 28th Member State to accede to the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union and its Protocol. I welcome this accession to this agreement, which is part of the field of justice and home affairs, because it facilitates mutual legal assistance between the competent authorities and courts of the Member States in order to guarantee efficient and rapid cooperation.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This should be a matter for the sovereign government of Croatia. I oppose corruption, and therefore abstained rather than voting against.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because since Croatia is a full member of the European Union, it is no longer necessary, as in the past, to negotiate and conclude specific accession protocols. Article 3, paragraphs 4 and 5, of the accession act simply provides for Croatia to adhere to the conventions and protocols under that act.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters. This Commission Recommendation on the Council Decision aims at making the adjustments necessary for croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters and to the Convention on the Fight against Corruption involving officials of the European Communities or officials of EU Member States.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I did not object to this accession provided for by the very act of Croatia's accession to the European Union. An accession which I wonder if the Croats do not already regret it.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. As Croatia is a full member of the European Union, it is normal for Croatia to adhere to the Council's 29 May 2000 Convention in accordance with Article 34 of the Treaty on the European Union, on mutual legal assistance in criminal matters between EU Member States.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Recommendation because an error concerning the entry into force of the Convention between Croatia and the Member States creates confusion. Article 1 of the Recommendation provides for entry into force on the first day of the first month following the date of adoption of the Decision, and Article 3 of the Decision determines that it will do so within twenty days of its publication in the DOCE. The Parliament considers that publication is an essential requirement and the Decision must enter into force on the date set there.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report concerns Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters.  Croatia's 2012 Act on THE Conditions of Membership of the European Union simplified its adherence to the conventions (and protocols) concluded by Member States on the basis of Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union. It is no longer necessary, as in the past, to negotiate and conclude specific accession protocols (which were to be ratified by the 28 Member States). The commission's proposed decision recommendation, proposed by the Commission, is intended to make the adjustments made necessary by Croatia's accession to the Convention and Protocol.  Nevertheless, there is a requirement for publication since, without publication, an act is considered non-existent by the ECJ. Croatia's accession to the Union requires Croatia's quasi-automatic accession to the Eu.  I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report does not present any particular critical issues and is fully acceptable. Its aim is to update, following Croatia's accession to the Union, the EU Convention to facilitate assistance between judicial, police and customs authorities in criminal matters. For these reasons, I voted in favour of it.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which assumes the Commission's proposal to address a technical error affecting the provision of the Commission Recommendation on the date of entry into force of the Convention between Croatia and the Member States.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because It endorses the Commission's recommendation on Croatia's accession to 2000. convention on mutual assistance in criminal matters between EU Member States and its respective protocols. 2012 The Act on the conditions of accession of Croatia has simplified croatia's accession to the conventions and protocols which the Member States have concluded in accordance with Article 34 TEU. The Act of Accession notes that the Council will adopt a decision setting out the date of entry into force of these Conventions for Croatia and any harmonisation necessary for the accession of that new Member State to the said Conventions. The purpose of this Decision is therefore to make the adjustments necessary for Croatia to accede to the said Convention and protocol.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support this recommendation because it will pave the way for the completion of Croatia's accession to the 2000 Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union and its Protocols (MLA Convention). This Council decision will make the necessary adjustments to the MLA Convention, is technical in nature and no part is contentious and has the support of all political groups in the European Parliament.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted 'yes' to this resolution because I believe that Croatia, as a new Member State, must participate in all conventions concluded within the framework of the Union, including that relating to judicial assistance in criminal matters.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on the report on Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters. This vote is purely in form: Croatia's accession to the European Union also leads to that of the convention in question.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation of the Council's decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union, adopted by the Council on 29 May 2000 pursuant to Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union and the Protocol of 16 October 2001 thereto, since the 2012 Act on the Conditions of Accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union simplified the accession of that country to the conventions (and protocols) concluded by the Member States pursuant to Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union. The Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union aims to support and facilitate cooperation between judicial, police and customs authorities in criminal matters. It complements, in particular, the 1959 Council of Europe Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters and its 1978 Protocol. Such an act is welcome because a spontaneous exchange of information (without prior request) can take place at any time between Member States, concerning acts which may be punishable from a criminal point of view as well as administrative offences the sanctioning or treatment of which falls within the competence of the receiving authority.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. The aim of the convention to which Croatia will adhere is to facilitate assistance between the judicial, police and customs authorities in criminal matters.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Since joining the European Union in July 2013, Croatia has been able to accede to the various conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States. This recommendation, which is purely technical, is intended to enable the adaptations made necessary by the country's accession to the convention of 29 May 2000. This Convention aims to facilitate mutual legal assistance between the competent authorities of the Member States in order to make cooperation in criminal matters more effective and faster. I voted in favour of this report

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. It was a technical report which was concerned with the accession of a Member State to a single Convention signed and ratified between the EU Member States (instead of entering in 28 bilateral agreements).  I am of the belief that it is the decision of the sovereign nation to accede to international or European conventions.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this vote because accession to international agreements is a matter for the sovereign government of Croatia.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ The Act of 2012 concerning the conditions of accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union simplified its accession to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States on the basis of Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union (ex Article K 3 TEU). I voted in favour of this report as I agree with the procedural recommendations and timeline proposed in this report to make the adjustments required by reason of the accession of Croatia to the aforementioned Convention, in accordance with Article 3(4) and 3(5) of the Act of Accession.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of croatia's accession, the last Member State to join the Union, to the Convention, so that croatia is also a party to the Convention and subject to the same rules that already apply to the other Member States.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this report which provides for Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal and Judicial Matters. If, indeed, I oppose the logic of enlargement underpinned by such procedures, it is clear that Croatia's accession to the Convention is made logical by its very accession to the European Union. As recalled in the statement of reasons for the report, "[i]t is no longer necessary, as in the past, to negotiate and conclude specific accession protocols (which should be ratified by the 28 Member States): Article 3, paragraphs 4 and 5, of the accession act simply provides for Croatia to adhere to the conventions and protocols under that act." The legal simplification carried out by the treaties therefore made Croatia's accession to the Convention on Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters almost automatic.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Almost two years after Croatia's accession to the EU, it is important to ensure that the Convention of 29 May 2000 on mutual assistance in criminal matters between Member States and its Protocol of 16 October 2001 is fully operational for that country. These instruments are intended to facilitate assistance between judicial, police and customs authorities through a number of mechanisms concerning, for example, the temporary transfer or transit of detainees, the transmission of notifications, the direct exchange of information between the authorities concerned, the provision of stolen goods for the purpose of returning to the owner of the , the hearing of witnesses or experts also through videoconferences. The Convention also deals with measures of great importance in the fight against crime – in particular organised crime – such as the setting up of joint investigation teams, the use of infiltration operations and the interception of telecommunications. The recommendation, which is adopted in this legislative resolution, is a necessary measure to resolve certain technical issues related to Croatia's accession to the Convention and protocol referred to, and i therefore voted in favour on the basis of the foreays mentioned above.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure concerning Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters. The text is of a technical nature and aims to make the necessary adjustments following the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the Convention and protocol in accordance with Article 3(4) and (5) of the Act of Accession of Croatia to the European Union, as the 28th Member State, on 1 July 2013.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 Croatia's accession to the European Union implies its automatic adherence to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States. However, the Council adopts a decision setting the date on which these conventions enter into force for Croatia. Through the publication of this Convention there will be no doubt that it will enter into force from the twentieth day following its publication. In view of the absence of controversial political issues, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report, especially of a technical nature, is to give the Consent of the European Parliament for the European Commission to make the necessary amendments for croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union and its Protocol of 16 October 2001. It should be noted that there are still many instruments that need to be modernised in the context of police and judicial cooperation, especially in criminal matters. On the other hand, I am pleased to see Croatia as the latest Member State in 2012 to take another step towards its integration into the Union.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 On the basis of Article 3(4) and (5) of the Act of Accession, the Commission recommends that the necessary adjustments be made for Croatia's participation in the Convention of 29 May 2000 on mutual assistance in criminal matters between the Member States of the European Union, and its Protocol of 16 October 2001. I welcome the Commission's recommendation and hope that further progress can still be made, such as: reform of the judicial system and public administration, the fight against corruption and organised crime, as well as in the area of the protection of minorities.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ This vote reflects the accession of Croatia to the European Union. I have thus voted in favor of the report which is technical in nature and which makes the existing provision clear on the accession of Croatia to the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union, and its Protocol.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2012 Act on the Conditions of Croatia's Accession to the EU simplified its adherence to conventions and protocols concluded by Member States under Article 34 of the EU Treaty. It is no longer necessary to negotiate and conclude specific accession protocols, Article 3(4) and (5) of the Act of Accession simply states that Croatia accedes to the conventions and protocols under the Act of Accession. The Act of Accession provides for the Council to adopt a decision setting out the date on which these conventions enter into force for Croatia and making to the conventions all the adjustments which have become necessary as a result of the accession of the new Member State.  Annex I to the Act of Accession lists the six protocols and conventions in question in the field of justice and home affairs. The list includes the Council Convention of 29 May 2000, in accordance with Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union, on mutual assistance in criminal matters between EU Member States, and its Protocol of 16 October 2011. I voted in favour of this report because the aim of the recommendation is to make the necessary adjustments due to Croatia's accession to the convention and protocol referred to, in accordance with the Act of Accession.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. Annex I to the Act of Accession contains a list of conventions and protocols to which Member States are to accede, including the Convention on Judicial Assistance in Criminal Matters. Since Croatia accedes to this Convention in the context of its accession to the European Union independently and as a sovereign state, I voted in favour of respecting its decisions in accordance with the principle of self-determination.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 As the people's party responsible for the report, I consider it important for Croatia to join the 29 May 2000 Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Affairs between the Member States of the European Union, and I therefore voted in favour of the recommendation. Croatia's membership of the EU will be fulfilled by accession. The purpose of the Convention is to promote mutual criminal assistance between the competent authorities of the Member States, including police, customs or judicial services, in order to ensure more effective and faster criminal cooperation.  In a Union where there are no borders and persons, goods, services and capital can flow freely, there is no longer a national border for criminal offences. In this case, law enforcement cannot remain national. Only effective cooperation at European level can produce satisfactory results. This requires mutual trust, since law enforcement has so far been mainly a national competence and the competent authorities of each Member State are reluctant to share their information with the authorities of the other Member State. This is 100 points of the Convention, as it encourages and promotes mutual support and trust between Member States, which is one of the pillars of effective judicial cooperation. It also cover certain forms of mutual legal assistance, such as the establishment of joint investigation teams and covert investigations. I hope that the Croatian accession will make positive progress in the effectiveness of pan-European law enforcement.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this technical proposal which will pave the way for Croatia to complete its accession to the 2000 Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters (the MLA Convention), between the Member States of the EU, and the Protocol thereto.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes to allow Croatia to accede to the Council's 29 May 2000 Convention in accordance with Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union (EUT), on mutual legal assistance in criminal matters between EU Member States and its protocol of 16 October 2001. Considering that it is normal for Croatia, as a full member of the European Union, to become a party to this convention, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. Croatia's accession to the European Union leads to Croatia's accession to many of the conventions and protocols concluded between the Member States. In order to avoid too cumbersome procedures and too long delays, the Council can decide on Croatia's accession to such conventions and protocols, on the recommendation of the Commission and after consultation with Parliament. In this case, the European Parliament approved Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters. It, signed on 29 May 2000, facilitates cooperation between the judicial, police and customs authorities of the Member States in criminal matters.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The European Parliament approved the Council's decision recommendation to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU and improve judicial cooperation in criminal matters. This will improve the efficiency of investigations and the European penal system.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on the report on Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters. This vote is purely in form: Croatia's accession to the Union also leads to that of the convention in question.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters between EU Member States. I am deeply convinced that cooperation between EU Member States on criminal matters is of the utmost importance. The free movement of people into the EU is a fundamental right, but sometimes it allows criminals to flee to another Member State. It is therefore also important that Croatia as a new MEMBER of the EU is part of the Mutual Assistance Convention, so that in such situations there is rapid communication between law enforcement authorities in different countries and that the reaction is timely.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as Croatia has always pursued a stable Anti-Greek policy on all issues of interest to Greece at local, regional and international level, such as the name of Skopje, economic policy at Community level, etc.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2012 Act on the conditions for the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union simplified croatia's accession to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States, and it is no longer necessary to negotiate and conclude specific accession protocols. However, a technical error affects the provisions of the Commission's recommendation on the date of entry into force of the Convention between Croatia and the Member States, which is considered to be non-existent by the Court of Justice of the European Union. I agree with the need to correct the agreement.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I abstained on this deliberation because it contains a political dimension on enlargement and, therefore, on the intrinsic functioning of the European Union.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 It is essential to facilitate and improve assistance between judicial authorities in criminal matters, including against Croatia. My vote can only be in favour of any action that makes available as soon as possible all the instruments that European law provides for the exchange of information and cooperation between European states in this area. We must insist on this direction in order to prosecute crimes and offences more effectively and quickly, in compliance with the fundamental principles of the different laws of the Member States and with respect for individual rights. The fight against crime, in particular organised crime, money laundering and financial crime, cannot be limited to narrow national borders but must go further. All my actions in this fight will always be informed to ensure that it acquires a greater European and cross-border characterisation.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention on mutual legal assistance in criminal matters, of which Portugal is a party, was agreed upon, during its discussion in the National Parliament, for adequately addressing issues that are undoubtedly relevant in the field of judicial cooperation in criminal matters. This report stems from Croatia's accession to the European Union and from the fact that it is part of this Convention. We voted in favour. Unlike the vast majority of eu countries, Croatia's integration process has been subject to popular scrutiny, a claim of sovereignty, albeit in a contradictory act, but which we respect and accept. It should, however, be noted that the process to which the report reports, albeit simple, is part of croatia's broader process of integration into the EU, a process of integration resulting in serious attacks on the sovereignty of states and peoples, subjugating them to the logic of capitalist integration at the service of the great powers and large economic groups.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I believe this will assist in fighting crime.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ Croatia's accession to the EU has also facilitated the country's accession to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States within the meaning of Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union. However, an error occurred in the European Commission recommendation concerning the date of entry into force of the Convention between Croatia and the Member States, and such provisions could lead to unclear procedures.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the convection to which Croatia will now also join in order to facilitate assistance between the judicial, police and customs authorities in criminal matters.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ This Commission recommendation for a Council decision will pave the way for Croatia to complete its accession to the 2000 Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters (‘the MLA Convention’), between the Member States of the European Union, and its Protocol. It follows from the 2011 Treaty of Accession concerning Croatia, which lists six conventions and protocols in the area of Justice and Home Affairs to which Croatia would accede by way of Council decisions. This Council decision will make the adjustments to the MLA Convention which are required by reason of Croatia’s accession. I backed this proposal in the plenary.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. ‒ With today’s vote we gave our consent to the Commission recommendation to the Council to allow Croatia to adhere to the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union. The Act of 2011 concerning the conditions of accession of Croatia to the European Union simplified its accession to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States. It is no longer necessary to negotiate and conclude specific accession protocols: the Act of Accession simply states that Croatia accedes to the conventions and protocols by virtue of the Act. We voted therefore in favour and welcome this concrete step towards mutual assistance in criminal matters between the Member States.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Sippel report, which mainly concerns a number of purely technical adjustments to the 2000 Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union and its Protocol, which are required by reason of Croatia’s accession to the EU.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. Croatia is already an EU Member State with all the consequences. It is therefore logical that it adheres to the Convention of 29 May 2001 on judicial assistance in criminal matters between EU Member States. I am convinced that Croatia's participation in this Convention and the resulting cooperation between the police, customs and tribunal services will contribute to more effective justice.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted IN FAVOUR of Croatia's accession to the Convention; this only implies Croatia's inclusion in a convention concluded prior to Croatia's entry into the EU.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my Labour Party colleagues, voted in favour of this report as it will pave the way for Croatia to complete its accession to the 2000 Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union and its Protocol (‘the MLA Convention’).

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the recommendation for a Council decision on the accession of Croatia to the The Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union, approved by the Council in accordance with Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union, and the Protocol of 16 October 2001 annexed thereto. Parliament has adopted a resolution amending the legal details of this act relating to the publication and entry into force of the act. I believe that the proper establishment and implementation of legal procedures will help to make the EU more functional and transparent.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Mutual assistance in criminal matters provides EU countries with valuable tools in the fight against serious organised crime and cross-border offences. It is a matter of extreme concern that, at the very moment Croatia is acceding to this Convention, the UK is led by a government intent on ending EU cooperation and ripping up the European Convention on Human Rights.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted IN FAVOUR of Croatia's accession to the Convention; this only implies Croatia's inclusion in a convention concluded prior to Croatia's entry into the EU.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the recommendation for the Council Decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union and its protocol of 16 October 2001, as this Convention improves judicial cooperation between Member States in criminal matters and insists that mutual legal assistance be made available in as fast and efficient a way as possible. Therefore, it is important to join the Convention of Croatia for the purpose of commitments and to adapt to other conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States, but also to improve its internal system in that domain.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Birgit Sippel's report on Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters. This technical report aims to take into account Croatia's accession to the European Union and thus to make changes to the Treaty so that it is part of it. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This is a purely formal act for correcting a technical error. I am therefore voting in favour of this motion.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report’s approval of the Commission recommendation for a Council decision regarding the accession of Croatia to the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters. The accession will encourage and facilitate mutual assistance between judicial, police and customs authorities on criminal matters in Croatia and other Member States. This can only lead to improved safety and justice within EU Member States.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as the proposal is technical. It will pave the way for Croatia to complete its accession to the 2000 Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union, and its Protocol.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – Crime has become international and the conditions for law enforcement must be adapted to this challenge, within a reasonable framework, so that I could support this report. It is in our common interest for Croatia to be a party to the EU's criminal assistance system through its accession to the convention and protocol.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mrs Sippel's proposal on Croatia's accession to the Convention on Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters. The purpose of this Recommendation is to make the adjustments which have become necessary as a result of Croatia's accession to the Convention and Protocol referred to, in accordance with Article 3, in paragraphs 4 and 5 of the Act of Accession.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. This Commission Recommendation for a Council Decision will make it easier for Croatia to complete its accession to the 2000 Convention on Judicial Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union and its Protocol. This issue stems from Croatia's 2011 Act of Accession, which lists six conventions and protocols in the area of Justice and Home Office to which Croatia must accede by Council decision. The Council decision shall make the necessary adjustments to the Convention arising from Croatia's access. In accordance with these considerations, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. Annex I to the Act of Accession contains a list of conventions and protocols to which Member States are to accede, including the Convention on Judicial Assistance in Criminal Matters. Since Croatia accedes to this Convention in the context of its accession to the European Union independently and as a sovereign state, I voted in favour of respecting its decisions in accordance with the principle of self-determination.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒Report by Mep Brigit Sippel supports the Commission's recommendation that the Republic of Croatia accede to the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union and the implementation of the necessary adjustments for accession. The Convention was adopted by the Council of Ministers of the European Union on 29 May 2000.  The Convention aims to enhance judicial cooperation between Member States and foster cooperation between judicial, police and customs authorities within the Union while respecting human rights and the protection of personal freedoms. It is in the interest of all Member States to resolve as quickly as possible individual cases most commonly related to organised crime - human trafficking, fraud, arms smuggling and drug abuse.  I support the report, as joining the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters between Eu Member States will ensure that we work more effectively with other Member States and resolve criminal cases more quickly.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. With Croatia's entry into the EU, the issue of integrating Croatia into the international system of mutual assistance in criminal matters is imposed. I voted for it. Although it is a rather formal decision, it is necessary.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing \u2012 The Recommendation is based on the Act of Accession of Croatia. The aim is to make the necessary adjustments required by the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the recommendation for a Council Decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention of 29 May 2000, drawn up by the Council on the basis of Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union, on mutual legal assistance in criminal matters between the Member States of the European Union and in the Protocol of 16 October 2001 , because this report simplifies Croatia's accession to the Conventions (and Protocols) concluded by the Member States under Article 34 of the EES (formerly Article K. 3 of the EES).

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I abstained on this vote. Because of its accession to the European Union, Croatia's accession to this mutual legal aid convention in criminal matters is practically automatic. Any discussion on this subject therefore seems totally unnecessary.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union. The specific aim of the Convention, the final text of which was adopted on 29 May 2000, responds to the need to integrate and not replace existing conventional instruments from other legal areas, with a view to improving judicial cooperation in criminal matters through rapid, effective assistance compatible with the fundamental principles of the national law of the Member States and with the principles of the 1950 European Convention on Human Rights.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2012 Act on the conditions of accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union simplified the procedures for accession by the new Member State to the conventions, and protocols, concluded by the Member States in accordance with Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union. I voted in favour of the Sippel report, as I believe that it is desirable to facilitate relations with Croatia, including in the field of criminal legal assistance.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The report on the Council Decision Recommendation on Croatia's accession to the Convention on Judicial Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union and its protocol shows its support for complying with this procedure following Croatia's accession to the EU. My support for this resolution and its request for clarification of certain aspects of the Recommendation concerning the date of entry into force of the Convention.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Since this is only a mere formal act without any change in content or the correction of a technical error, I have given my assent to the report.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Cases aims to encourage and facilitate mutual assistance between judicial, police and customs authorities in criminal matters. Croatia also approved the convention in its act of accession to the European Union. It is now a matter of validating the date of publication and entry into force in the country. I am opposed to the enlargement of the Union, but I defend the sovereign choice of a State to participate in a European or international convention.  The similar convention of the Council of Europe is similar to this legislation and could have been sufficient. Under these conditions, I vote for.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's legislative resolution of 10 June 2015 on the recommendation for a Council decision on croatia's accession to the Convention of 29 May 2000 on mutual legal assistance in criminal matters between the Member States of the European Union. The entry into force of the instrument in Croatia depends on the Council's decision, which shall act unanimously. Croatia undertakes to adapt national law for accession and to facilitate practical cooperation between the institutions and organisations of the Member States.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it is largely a technical matter concerning the date when the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters enters into force with Croatia, following its accession to the Union.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union. In a globalised world, dominated by the internationalization of the lives of all of us, it is essential that optimal cooperation is in place in Europe in criminal matters, in order to ensure that the fight against crime, and in particular transnational organised crime, is carried out vigorously and effectively. Better judicial cooperation in criminal matters is the other side of the free movement of people and the simplification of red tape. Justice must respond to this international crime This accession goes in this direction and I fully support it.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on Croatia’s accession to the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Croatia, with its accession to the Union, undertook to accede to a series of conventions previously concluded by the Member States under Article 34 TSI. In this connection, the Council, on a recommendation from the Commission, shall adopt, after consulting the European Parliament, a decision setting out the date of entry into force of the Conventions with regard to Croatia and making the necessary adjustments for the accession of the new Member State. Support for this report therefore essentially means supporting croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Recommendation for a Council decision proposed by the Commission aims to introduce the necessary amendments as a result of Croatia's accession to the above-mentioned Convention in accordance with Article 3(4) and (5) of the Act of Accession. In order to clarify the possible doubts that exist with regard to the start of the entry into force of the Convention between Croatia and the Member States, and for reasons of legal certainty, I am voting in favour of the Commission's recommendation.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report concerns Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters. Croatia's 2012 Act on EU Membership Conditions simplified its adherence to the conventions (and protocols) concluded by Member States on the basis of Article 34 of the TREATY on the EU. It is no longer necessary, as in the past, to negotiate and conclude specific accession protocols (which should be ratified by the 28 Member States). The commission's proposed decision recommendation, proposed by the Commission, is intended to make the adjustments made necessary by Croatia's accession to the Convention and Protocol. Nevertheless, there is a requirement for publication since, without publication, an act is considered non-existent by the ECJ, but Croatia, as a result of Croatia's accession to the European Union, implies a quasi-automatic accession to this convention. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as this Commission Recommendation for a Council decision will pave the way for Croatia to complete its accession to the 2000 Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union and its Protocol (‘the MLA Convention’).

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this purely technical text, concerning Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters. This assistance is essential to be able to prosecute the perpetrators of crimes within the European Union. That is why I voted for this text in line with European law.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the recommendation adopted here today is simply to make the necessary adjustments following Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union, in accordance with Article 3(4) and (5) of the Act of Accession. This is a purely technical issue which does not raise any problems from a legal or political point of view.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour, in the light of the Commission's recommendation to the Council, in view of the report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, but also in view of Article 3 of Croatia's Accession Act, in accordance with which it was consulted by the Council.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of this Recommendation of the Commission for a Council Decision is to make any amendments which have been necessary as a result of Croatia's accession to the Convention and Protocol referred to, in accordance with Article 3(4) and (5) of the Act concerning the conditions of accession to the European Union of 2012. The act in question simplified its accession to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States under Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union (ex Article K.3 TEU). It is no longer necessary, as in the past, to negotiate and conclude specific accession protocols (with the consequent ratification of the 28 Member States). Article 3(4) and (5) simply stipulates that Croatia shall accede to conventions and protocols by virtue of that act. Therefore, for the above reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the report and croatia's accession to this very important convention.  It is good to see that, slowly and slowly, Croatia, as the newest Member State of the EU, is indeed closing all the procedures inherent in accession, acceding to the conventions already adopted and operated by the other Member States. This is the way forward, so croatian EU citizens can benefit the most from their country's EU membership and the EU acquis. I trust that citizens will soon feel the benefits of belonging and cooperation in everyday life.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ On 30 June, Croatia became the 28th Member State of the European Union. Today, I have voted for this report to continue its accession to the conventions and protocols concluded by the other Member States of the European Union.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. This report is a mere addition to existing agreements that have become necessary as a result of Croatia's accession to the EU. Since our previous criticisms have not been taken into account, but at the same time it is a purely technical process, I abstained from voting.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. This is an adaptation to the accession of Croatia to the said Convention and protocol.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This is a technical report aimed at the accession of Croatia, the new Member State of the European Union, to a convention signed and ratified by the Union and all its Member States, in this case the Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters, which intersects six conventions in the field of justice and home affairs. I saw no valid reason to oppose this report, so I voted in favour.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Sippel's report because I believe that there is a need for greater clarity regarding the entry into force of the Convention of 29 May on mutual assistance in criminal matters between Member States to which Croatia has automatically acceded following accession to the EU.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report by which the European Parliament, with the recommendation of the European Commission, gives the Council its consent to set a date for Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union and its protocol of 16 October 2001. This Convention is particularly important for Croatia, as it enables effective cooperation between the judicial authorities of the Member States of the European Union, which has proved very significant for Croatia.  Fighting corruption and enabling the prosecution of serious crimes requires cooperation across Member States' borders as well as a regulated and transparent system of judicial cooperation within the EU. I consider this to be the right path of cooperation within the European Union that guarantees the assurance of the rule of law. This kind of rule of law assurance must also exist in countries that join the European Union and align justice legislation.  That is why I once again point out the case of the Republic of Serbia, which grossly violates international law and the rule of law when applying the Law on the Organisation and Competence of Serbian State Authorities in War Crimes Proceedings, whose articles 2 and 3 must be removed if the Republic of Serbia wishes to continue on its European path.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report concerns Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters. Croatia's 2012 Act on THE Conditions of Membership of the European Union simplified its adherence to the conventions (and protocols) concluded by Member States on the basis of Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union. It is no longer necessary, as in the past, to negotiate and conclude specific accession protocols (which should be ratified by the 28 Member States). The commission's proposed decision recommendation, proposed by the Commission, is intended to make the adjustments made necessary by Croatia's accession to the Convention and Protocol. Nevertheless, there is a requirement for publication since, without publication, an act is considered non-existent by the ECJ, but Croatia's accession to the Union implies quasi-automatic accession to the Convention. I abstained on this text.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒I support colleague Sippel's recommendation for the Council's decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention of 29 May 2000, set out by the Council in accordance with Article 34 of the Regulation. treaty on mutual legal assistance in criminal matters between the Member States of the European Union and its Protocol of 16 October 2001.  This Convention aims to improve judicial cooperation in criminal matters between Member States of the Union, as the common interest of Member States is to ensure that mutual legal assistance is provided between Member States in a swift and effective manner in accordance with the fundamental principles of their national law and in line with the individual rights and principles of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms. The Act on Croatia's accession to the European Union meaningfully stipulates that it is not necessary to negotiate and conclude specific accession protocols, which should then be ratified by all 28 Member States, but stipulates that the Council will decide on the date on which the convention provisions begin to apply in relation to Croatia and will adapt them to the entry of the 28th Member State. Given the complexity of the Acquis of the European Union, coordination and cooperation between Member States, in particular as regards civil liberties, justice and home affairs, is a strategic issue of general interest to all its citizens.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 This is an obligatory step when a new Member State joins the EU and I naturally voted in favour. Croatia simply accedes to the EU Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters. It is then up to the Council to make the adjustments to the Convention that are necessary following Croatia's accession.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters. Personally, I have dealt several times in the past with representatives of the Croatian judiciary at a time when the country was preparing to join the Union, and I therefore assume that this accession to the Convention will further strengthen the rule of law in the eu's youngest Member State.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I supported this recommendation. This essentially technical text aims to authorise Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters, and specifies the terms of this accession. This accession is part of Croatia's process of adopting the various EU conventions following its accession in July 2013.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 In accordance with Article 3(4) and (5) of the Act on the conditions for accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, a simplified system has been defined for the accession of that country to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States on the basis of Article 34 of the ET, according to which Croatia adhers to such instruments under that Act , with the Council being required to adopt a decision, on a recommendation from the Commission and after consulting the European Parliament, determining the date on which the conventions enter into force for this new Member State and makes all necessary adjustments to that end.  This Recommendation for a Council Decision proposed by the Commission seeks to introduce the necessary amendments as a result of Croatia's accession to the Convention of 29 May 2000 on mutual legal assistance in criminal matters between the Member States of the European Union and its Protocol of 16 October 2001. I voted in favour.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. I supported this afternoon's report on the Council's recommendation on Croatia's accession to the Council's 29 May 2000 Convention in accordance with Article 34 of the Treaty on the European Union, on mutual legal assistance in criminal matters between EU Member States and its protocol of 16 October 2001.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 It is only a question of making the necessary adjustments by virtue of the membership of that new Member State to that convention.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution, which assumes the Commission's proposal to address a technical error affecting the provision of the Commission Recommendation on the date of entry into force of the Convention between Croatia and the Member States.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The 2012 Act on Croatia's accession to the European Union simplified Croatia's accession to the Eu-18 countries on the basis of Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union.  It is no longer necessary, as in the past, to negotiate and conclude specific accession protocols (which were to be ratified by the 28 Member States). Article 3, paragraphs 4 and 5, of the accession act simply provides for Croatia to adhere to the conventions and protocols under that act. To this end, these same paragraphs provide that the Council takes a decision setting the date on which these conventions come into force with regard to Croatia and makes all the adjustments made necessary by the accession of that new Member State to those conventions.  Appendix I of the Accession Act lists the six conventions and protocols concerned in the field of justice and home affairs. The convention of 29 May 2000 on mutual legal aid in criminal matters between the Member States of the European Union is on this list. The report voted today therefore aims to make the adjustments made necessary by Croatia's accession to the Convention.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention of 29 May 2000 on mutual legal assistance in criminal matters aims to supplement the provisions and facilitate the application between the Member States of the European Union of the European Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters. The adoption of this resolution is therefore the result of Croatia's accession to the European Union and, in its new status as a Member State, croatia must also become an integral part of this Convention.  There are no obstacles to Croatia's accession to this Convention, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. The Agreement on 29 May 2000 on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Cases aims to encourage and facilitate mutual assistance between judicial, police and customs authorities in criminal matters. Thus, the Member State to which assistance is requested must respect the formalities and procedures indicated by the Member State which requests it and carry it out as soon as possible, taking into account as best as possible the deadlines indicated. I supported this text which allows Croatia to accede to this convention.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report presented by Mr De Clercq. Sippel, which is purely technical in nature and which, in essence, allows Croatia, the last country in chronological order to have obtained accession to the European Union, to accede to the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I recognise the importance of facilitating assistance between member states' judicial, police and customs authorities in criminal matters.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We voted IN FAVOUR of Croatia's accession to the Convention; this only implies Croatia's inclusion in a convention concluded prior to Croatia's entry into the EU.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ This Commission Recommendation for a Council decision will pave the way for Croatia to complete its accession to the 2000 Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union and its Protocol (‘the MLA Convention’).  It follows from the 2011 Treaty of Accession concerning Croatia, which lists six conventions and protocols in the area of Justice and Home Affairs to which Croatia would accede by way of Council decisions.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing \ u2012 I voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution on the accession of Croatia to the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters, as the subject of the proposal was a clear and simple codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. I support the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters, as the EU borders have been abolished for individuals, but not for authorities such as police, prosecution authorities and courts. For these reasons, I agree that this accession will contribute to the direct sending of mutual assistance requests between member states' judicial authorities, allow for better exchange of information between Member States in compliance with the procedure of the requesting State.  The purpose of this Convention is to implement the principle of mutual recognition of judicial decisions on the insurance of property and evidence for the purposes of criminal proceedings between Member States. It also facilitated the enforcement of fines in a Member State other than the one in which the penalty was imposed. The formation of joint investigation teams between two or more investigating states will also help fight criminal activities.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing \ u2012 Croatia is a valid Member State of the European Union, which gives it rights and obligations. The implementation of legal standards is an essential part of a country's membership of the EU. It is essential that Croatia accepts all the obligations arising from accession to this Convention in order to contribute to the mutual assistance of the Member States in the field of criminal matters.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I support this recommendation report for the Decision of the Council on the Accession of Croatia to the Convention of 29 May 2000 established by the Council in accordance with Article 34. The Treaty on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union and its protocol of 16 October 2001, because I believe that the better functioning of the system related to criminal matters and all related activities in Croatia requires cooperation between Croatia and other members of the European Union.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ I support the draft of this report, as crime has become a very complex international phenomenon and a common European criminal justice area based on mutual trust and support between national police authorities needs to be developed. For Croatia, access to the convention is important because of the relatively high crime and corruption rate in this country, especially in the business world with an emphasis on the private sector. This report is technical in nature with the purpose of determining the date of accession of the Republic of Croatia to this Convention, for which the existing provision was not sufficiently clear. According to Article 1 of this Recommendation, the Convention will enter into force on the first day of the first month following the date of the decision. According to Article 3, the decision enters into force on the twentieth day from the date of publication in the Official Journal of the European Union. These provisions provide confusing timelines for the implementation of the Convention.  Official disclosure is an essential condition of the entire procedure, as without publication no act is recognised as valid by the Court. I therefore agree that the decision should first be taken and published and also contain the date on which the Convention should enter into force.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I supported the proposal in writing ‒ as it only takes into account Croatia's accession to the European Union.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on the recommendation of the Council Decision on the accession of Croatia to the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters between the Member States of the European Union. The accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union in 2013 simplified its accession to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States, as negotiations and conclusion of individual association protocols are no longer necessary. With the support of this report, we will accept all the adjustments necessary as a result of Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Croatia has always pursued a stable Anti-Greek policy on all issues of interest to Greece, at local, regional and international level, such as the name of Skopje, economic policy at Community level, etc.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. In its letter of referral, the General Secretariat of the Council informed the General Secretariat of Parliament of a technical error affecting the presentation of the Commission's recommendation, linked to the effective date of the convention between Croatia and the Member States.  In accordance with Article 1 of the recommendation, the Convention enters into force - between Croatia and the Member States for which the Convention is in force on that date - on the first day of the first month following the adoption date of the decision. According to Article 3, the decision "takes effect" on the twentieth day after it is published in the Official Journal of the European Union. These provisions could create uncertainty as to the actual date. The publication requirement is an essential procedural requirement. Without publication, an act is considered non-existent by the European Court of Justice. Therefore, the decision must first be adopted and published; it must then come into force on the date it provides. Finally, the convention should enter into force as a result of the formal publication and entry into force of the decision.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
