text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the accession of Croatia to the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters. The Act concerns the conditions of accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union and simplifies its accession to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States. It will no longer be necessary to negotiate and conclude specific accession protocols, which will simplify the procedures both for Croatia and for the EU.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The Commission's recommendation relates to the amendment of the Council Decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention of 29 May 2000 on mutual legal assistance in criminal matters between the Member States of the Union and its protocol of 16 October 2001.  The purpose of this recommendation is to make adjustments that include the adoption of the convention in Croatian in order to ensure as effective cooperation as possible in the international fight against crime as well as the provision of criminal justice assistance. In globalisation flows in which modern forms of serious crime enter the big door, it is important to react decisively even at the earliest stage of committing the criminal part.  I believe that this recommendation fully respects the principle of subsidiarity and justifiably adds value to the segment of international prosecution, which could not be sufficiently or remotely achieved by the Member States on their own. Serious crimes of an organised and transnational character require more effective responses in which Member States will not limit their legislation and prosecutions to ensuring only their national security, but will, through cooperation, successfully contribute to the security of other states and the world community. I therefore fully support this recommendation, which will allow for the necessary adjustments so that the Republic of Croatia will participate equally in judicial cooperation from 1 July 2015 together with other Members of the Union.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report. In today's globalised world, imbued with crime of all forms, cooperation between countries is all the more important. It is certainly in the common interest of the Member States to provide mutual legal assistance in a swift and effective manner compatible with fundamental principles and individual freedom.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We voted IN FAVOUR of Croatia's accession to the Convention; this only implies Croatia's inclusion in a convention concluded prior to Croatia's entry into the EU.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 We voted IN FAVOUR of Croatia's accession to the Convention; this only implies Croatia's inclusion in a convention concluded prior to Croatia's entry into the EU.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the two reports seeking to increase cooperation between Croatia and the EU in the fight against crime, and in particular against corruption.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a purely technical matter which must therefore be voted on positively in the House.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. Annex I to the Act of Accession contains a list of conventions and protocols to which Member States are to accede, including the Convention on Judicial Assistance in Criminal Matters. Since Croatia accedes to this Convention in the context of its accession to the European Union independently and as a sovereign state, I voted in favour of respecting its decisions in accordance with the principle of self-determination.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Since this is only a mere formal act without any change in content or the correction of a technical error, I have given my assent to the report.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. – I agreed with my group with my group on the recommendation for a Council decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention of 29 May 2000, drawn up by the Council in accordance with Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union, on mutual legal assistance in criminal matters between the Member States of the European Union and on its protocol of 16 October 2001. I am opposed to the enlargement of the EU to include further members. However, it makes sense to extend the rules on mutual legal assistance in criminal matters to other states, whether they are members of the EU or not.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. Croatia's accession to the Anti-Corruption Convention involving officials from the European Communities or Member States is involved. Annex I to the Act of Accession contains a list of conventions and protocols to which Member States are to accede, including the Convention on combating corruption. Since Croatia accedes to this Convention in the context of its accession to the European Union independently and as a sovereign state, I voted in favour of respecting its decisions in accordance with the principle of self-determination.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Following Croatia's accession to the EU in 2013, the country is now also acceding to the Anti-Bribery Agreement, which involves officials of the European Communities or the Member States of the European Union.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This should be a matter for the sovereign government of Croatia. I oppose corruption, and therefore abstained rather than voting against.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for croatia's accession to the Convention on the Fight against Corruption involving officials of the European Communities or officials of Member States of the European Union. This Commission Recommendation on the Council Decision aims at making the adjustments necessary for croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters and to the Convention on the Fight against Corruption involving officials of the European Communities or officials of EU Member States.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I did not object to this accession provided for by the very act of Croatia's accession to the European Union. Is the European Union really well placed to teach lessons in the fight against corruption?

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. As Croatia is a full member of the European Union, it is normal for Croatia to accede to the Convention of 26 May 1997, established on the basis of the Treaty on the European Union, on the fight against corruption involving officials of the European Communities or the Member States of the European Union.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This resolution relates to the Council's decision on Croatia's accession to the Anti-Corruption Convention of 26 May 1997 involving officials of the European Communities or the Member States of the European Union. Since Croatia's 2011 act of accession to the EU, Croatia must adhere to the conventions and protocols concluded by EU Member States through a simplified procedure.  The Commission's recommendation on the Convention between Croatia and the Member States contains a technical error on the date of entry into force, causing uncertainty as to the actual date and, therefore, threatens the very existence of the act.  However, as with the previous vote, Croatia's accession to this convention is de facto almost automatic through Croatia's act of accession to the Union. That is why I have also abstained on this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Hyusmenova report is fully acceptable and does not present any particular critical issues. Croatia also joins the EU States that have already acceded to the Convention on Combating Corruption, which involves officials from the European Communities or the Member States of the European Union. For all these reasons, I supported you with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which assumes the Commission's proposal to address a technical error affecting the provision of the Commission Recommendation on the date of entry into force of the Convention between Croatia and the Member States.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it expresses Parliament's support for Croatia's accession to the 1997 Convention on the fight against corruption involving EU officials or officials of member states. The Treaty of Accession of Croatia provides for a simplified framework for the accession of Croatia to the TEU conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States. Annex I to the Act of Accession contains a list of the relevant conventions and protocols. Included in the list in 1997 Convention on the fight against corruption involving EU officials or officials of Member States. By the time of the Commission recommendation on the Council decision, the purpose is precisely to carry out the adaptations necessary for Croatia to accede to that Convention.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. I support this recommendation, as it will pave the way for the completion of Croatia's accession to the 1997 Convention on Combating Corruption involving Officials of the European Communities or officials of the Member States of the European Union ("PIF Convention"). This decision will make the necessary adjustments to the PIF Convention, and it is a technical proposal that is not in dispute in any respect and has the support of all political groups in the European Parliament.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted 'yes' to this resolution because I believe that Croatia, as a new Member State, must participate in all conventions concluded within the framework of the Union, including the convention on combating corruption involving officials from the European Communities or the Member States.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on the report on Croatia's accession to the Anti-Corruption Convention involving officials from the European Communities or Member States. Like the report on Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters, this text is only about form and not substance.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The General Secretariat of the Council drew attention to a technical error in the Commission's recommendation affecting the provision on the date of entry into force of the Convention between Croatia and the Member States. Indeed, in accordance with Article 1 of the Recommendation, the Convention shall enter into force between Croatia and the Member States for which it is in force on the first day of the first month following the date of adoption of the decision. In accordance with Article 3, the Decision 'enters into force' on the 20th day following its publication in the Official Journal. Article 3(5) of the Act of Accession therefore provides that, to that end, the Council shall adopt a decision on the determination of the date on which those Conventions enter into force with regard to Croatia and the adaptations to be made to them as a result of the accession of the new Member State (which would in any event include the adoption of conventions in Croatian so that those versions are 'equally authentic'). I voted in favour of this council decision recommendation because I believe that the publication requirement is an essential procedural requirement and for the fact that the provisions laid down clearly regulate deadlines.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. Croatia's inclusion in the Convention is confirmed. Technical vote of mere taking note.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Croatia has been a new member state of the European Union since 1 July 2013. As such, it needs to deepen its integration and be able to follow the course of action and conventions established by the Member States. The convention of 26 May 1997 aims to combat any practice of corruption that could be used by officials of the European institutions or the Member States of the European Union. It is thus a fundamental pillar for the smooth running of institutions. This convention ensures a climate of trust for our citizens vis-à-vis national and European institutions. I voted in favour of Croatia's accession to this convention.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. It was a technical report which was concerned with the accession of a Member State to a single Convention signed and ratified between the EU Member States (instead of entering into 28 bilateral agreements) I am of the belief that it is the decision of the sovereign nation to accede to international or European conventions.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP abstained on this vote because we believe that accession to international agreements is a matter for the sovereign government of Croatia.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I fully agree with the procedural recommendations and timeline proposed in this report to make the adjustments required by reason of the accession of Croatia to the aforementioned Convention, in accordance with Article 3(4) and 3(5) of the Act of Accession. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 It is important that Croatia, the new Member State of the Union, is also subject to eu rules on the fight against corruption, and I have therefore voted in favour.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I have chosen to abstain on this report on Croatia's accession to the Anti-Corruption Convention involving officials from the European Communities or Member States. Indeed, if I object to the logic of enlargement underpinned by such procedures, it is clear that Croatia's accession to this Convention makes sense in view of its accession to the European Union. As recalled in the statement of reasons for the report, "[i]t is no longer necessary, as in the past, to negotiate and conclude specific accession protocols (which should be ratified by the 28 Member States): Article 3, paragraphs 4 and 5, of the accession act simply provides for Croatia to adhere to the conventions and protocols under that act." The legal simplification carried out by the treaties therefore made Croatia's accession to the Anti-Corruption Convention involving officials of the European Communities or the Member States almost automatic.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure concerning Croatia's accession to the Convention on combating corruption involving officials from the European Community or the Member States. The text is of a technical nature and aims to make the necessary adjustments following the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the Convention and protocol in accordance with Article 3(4) and (5) of the Act of Accession of Croatia to the European Union, as the 28th Member State, on 1 July 2013.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 As with the previous report, this is also a technical adjustment, which does not provide for political nodes. The European Parliament's vote is a formality, necessary to prevent rash decisions from being taken, but at the same time taken for granted in this particular case. I naturally voted in favour.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report, especially of a technical nature, is given the consent of the European Parliament to make the necessary amendments for croatia's accession to the Convention on combating corruption involving officials of the European Communities or the Member States of the European Union.  It should be noted that there are still many instruments that need to be modernised in the context of police and judicial cooperation, especially in criminal matters. On the other hand, I am pleased to see Croatia as the latest Member State in 2012 to take another step towards its integration into the Union.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report by Mr Hyusmenova, which essentially deals with a procedural issue relating to the lifting of technical error concerning the provision of the Commission recommendation concerning the date of entry into force of the Convention of 26 May 1997 between Croatia and the Member States.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ This vote reflects the accession of Croatia to the European Union. I have thus voted in favour of the report, which is technical in nature and which makes the existing provision clear on the accession of Croatia to the Convention on the fight against corruption involving officials of the European Communities or officials of Member States of the European Union and its Protocol.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 Croatia's 2011 Act of Accession introduced a simplified system of Croatia's accession to conventions concluded by Member States under Article 34 TEU. Article 3(4) and (5) of the Act provides that Croatia shall accede to conventions and protocols pursuant to the Act of Accession. The Act of Accession provides for the Council to adopt a decision setting out the date on which these conventions enter into force for Croatia and making to the conventions all the adjustments which have become necessary as a result of the accession of the new Member State. The Council shall act unanimously on a recommendation from the Commission and after consulting the European Parliament. Annex I to the Act of Accession contains a list of the conventions and protocols in question. The list includes the Convention of 26 May 1997 on combating corruption involving officials from the European Communities or EU Member States. I am voting in favour of this report because the Commission's recommendation for a Council decision is aimed at making the necessary adjustments due to Croatia's accession to the convention referred to, in accordance with the Act of Accession.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. Annex I to the Act of Accession contains a list of conventions and protocols to which Member States are to accede, including the Convention on combating corruption. Since Croatia accedes to this Convention in the context of its accession to the European Union independently and as a sovereign state, I voted in favour of respecting its decisions in accordance with the principle of self-determination.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on Croatia's accession to the 1997 Convention on the Fight against Corruption. Although Croatia's accession to the Convention can be regarded as a formality, it is of paramount importance as it completes its accession to the Union and ultimately contributes to a better functioning European Union. As the people's party responsible for this report, I consider croatia's accession to the convention to be of the utmost importance, as the Convention on combating corruption affecting EU officials and officials of the Member States of the European Union makes the Union accountable to its citizens. Under the Agreement, Member States shall take all necessary measures to ensure that passive and active corruption are criminal offences. Only this will ensure the effective elimination of abuses of power. It should be considered a criminal offence not only when a person promises or gives any advantage to an official, i.e. direct, active corruption, but also when an official, whether a national or European institutional officer, requests any advantage or accepts the advantage in order to take or not to take action in breach of his official duties, in the exercise of his or her powers. Moreover, since the crimes in the Schengen EU do not stop at the state border, the Convention calls on the Member States to cooperate where the anti-corruption procedure concerns at least two Member States, be it cooperation in investigations, prosecutions or the execution of the sentence imposed.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this technical proposal which paves the way for Croatia to complete its accession to the 1997 Convention on the fight against corruption involving officials of the European Communities or officials of the Member States of the EU (the PIF Convention).

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes to allow Croatia, following its accession to the European Union, to accede to the Anti-Corruption Convention involving officials of the European Communities or Member States of 26 May 1997, based on Article K.3, paragraph 2, paragraph c), of the Treaty on European Union (TUE). Considering that it is normal for Croatia, as a full member of the European Union, to become a party to this convention, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. Croatia's accession to the European Union, signed in 2011, provides for a simplified procedure allowing the 28th Member State to quickly accede to the six EU conventions and protocols relating to justice and home affairs. I have thereby supported the Council's decision to have Croatia accede to the Anti-Corruption Convention involving officials of the European Union or Member States.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The European Parliament has ruled favourably on this report, which aims to make the adjustments required by Croatia's accession to the Convention to Combat Corruption of European Officials. The fight against corruption must remain a priority in these newly arrived Member States in order to improve the effectiveness of the European policies put in place.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on the report on Croatia's accession to the Anti-Corruption Convention involving officials from the European Communities or member states. Like the report on Croatia's accession to the Convention on Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters, this text is only an appearance. The best way not to participate in these role-playing games is to abstain.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on Croatia's accession to the Anti-Corruption Convention, which includes officials of the European Communities or officials of the EU Member States. Although this report is largely technical, voting in yes, I would like to express my support for equality before the law to all subjects of all EU Member States. Croatia is 61th out of 174 countries according to the transparency without borders corruption perception index. Obviously, this is a big problem for the newest EU member state. In this regard, whether it is an official or another ordinary citizen, the law on corruption must apply to all. I hope that through the support for this report we will send a clear message to both Croatia and Bulgaria and the other EU members about the importance of fighting corruption not only at the highest levels of society, but also in general.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against as Croatia has always pursued a stable Anti-Greek policy on all issues of interest to Greece at local, regional and international level, such as the name of Skopje, economic policy at Community level, etc.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2011 Treaty of Accession of the Republic of Croatia introduced a simplified system for the accession of croatia to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States. The Council is also expected to take a decision determining the date on which these conventions enter into force for Croatia to make all necessary adaptations to those conventions by virtue of their accession as a Member State.  However, a technical error affects the provisions of the Commission's recommendation on the date of entry into force of the Convention between Croatia and the Member States, which is considered to be non-existent by the Court of Justice of the European Union. I agree with the need to correct the agreement.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I abstained on this deliberation because it essentially includes a deliberation on enlargement and therefore on the essential functioning of the European Union.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention on combating corruption involving officials of the European Communities or the Member States, of which Portugal is also a party, generally deserves our agreement. This report stems from Croatia's accession to the European Union and from the fact that it is part of this Convention. We had nothing to owe, we voted for it. Unlike the vast majority of eu countries, Croatia's integration process has been subject to popular scrutiny, a claim of sovereignty, albeit in a contradictory act, but which we respect and accept. It should, however, be noted that the process to which the report reports, albeit simple, is part of croatia's broader process of integration into the EU, a process of integration resulting in serious attacks on the sovereignty of states and peoples, subjugating them to the logic of capitalist integration at the service of the great powers and large economic groups.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 Following notification of a technical error in the Recommendation of the European Commission concerning the date of entry into force of the Convention between Croatia and the Member States, technical redress is being made, as the publication requirement is an essential procedural requirement and without its publication the CED the EU considers such an act to be non-existent.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 As in the previous vote in favour of the convection to which Croatia will now join in order to facilitate the fight against corruption.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ This Commission recommendation for a Council decision will pave the way for Croatia to complete its accession to the 1997 Convention on the fight against corruption involving officials of the European Communities or officials of the Member States of the European Union (‘the PIF Convention’). It follows from the 2011 Treaty of Accession concerning Croatia, which lists six conventions and protocols in the area of justice and home affairs to which Croatia would accede by way of Council decisions. This Council decision will make the adjustments to the PIF Convention which are required by reason of Croatia’s accession. I voted in favour of the proposal in plenary.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. ‒ With today’s vote we gave our consent to the Commission recommendation to the Council to allow Croatia to adhere to the Convention on the fight against corruption involving officials of the European Communities or officials of Member States. The Act of 2011 concerning the conditions of accession of Croatia to the European Union simplified its accession to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States. It is no longer necessary to negotiate and conclude specific accession protocols: the Act of Accession simply states that Croatia accedes to the conventions and protocols by virtue of the Act. The Council, in order to take a decision determining the date on which this convention will enter into force in relation to Croatia and making all the adjustments required by reason of the accession of this new Member State to this convention, will act on a recommendation by the Commission, after consulting Parliament. The Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommended that Parliament give its consent to the Commission recommendation. We voted therefore in favour and welcome Croatia’s contribution to the fight against corruption involving officials of the European Communities or officials of Member States of the European Union.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Hyusmenova report, which mainly concerns a number of purely technical adjustments to the Convention on the fight against corruption involving European Communities officials or officials of Member States, which are required by reason of Croatia’s accession to the EU.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. The fight against corruption in public life must be an EU priority. I therefore fully support the accession of Croatia, the last country to join the EU, to the Convention on combating corruption involving officials from the European Communities or the Member States, which aims to strengthen judicial cooperation between Member States in this area. Thus, each country must take the necessary measures to ensure that corruption is considered a crime and that its perpetrators are convicted. Being an official cannot serve as a shield to avoid condemnation. Conversely, being in charge of the public imposes a special responsibility for citizens.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted IN FAVOUR of Croatia's accession to the Convention; this only implies Croatia's inclusion in a convention concluded prior to Croatia's entry into the EU.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my Labour Party colleagues, voted in favour of this report as it will pave the way for Croatia to complete its accession to the 1997 Convention on the fight against corruption involving officials of the European Communities or officials of the Member States of the European Union (‘the PIF Convention’).

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the recommendation for a Council decision on the accession of Croatia to the The Convention against Corruption relating to officials of the European Communities or officials of Member States of the European Union, drawn up in accordance with Article K.3(2)(c) of the Treaty on European Union. I believe that we need to ensure that all legal procedures within the EU are carried out smoothly and effectively, without creating further disagreements.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: in writing. \u2012 Accession to the Convention on Combating Corruption, involving officials of the European Communities or officials of EU Member States, is important not only for Croatia, but also for the whole EU, as it concerns a matter of common interest – improving judicial cooperation in the fight against corruption.  Corruption is a problem that affects long-term economic growth, sustainable development and equality in the Union, and ultimately the interests of European taxpayers. Given the importance of the Convention as a common EU instrument for tackling the problem, I am pleased that croatia's accession report to the Convention was voted on by such a convincing majority.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted IN FAVOUR of Croatia's accession to the Convention; this only implies Croatia's inclusion in a convention concluded prior to Croatia's entry into the EU.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the recommendation for the Council's Decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention on Combating Corruption involving officials of the European Communities or officials of the EU Member States, on the basis that it is necessary to ensure the necessary adjustments in order for Croatia to accede to that convention in accordance with its membership in the European Union and following the legal acts that provide for it.  Furthermore, this Convention is of particular importance since it aims to improve judicial cooperation in the fight against corruption throughout the European Union, including in Croatia. With this convention, as well as other conventions and protocols and through a simplified system, Croatia continues to fulfil its obligations under the Accession Treaty of 2011.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Filiz Hyusmenova's report on Croatia's accession to the Convention on combating corruption of community officials. This technical report aims to take into account Croatia's accession to the European Union and therefore to make changes to the Treaty so that it is part of it. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This is a purely formal act for correcting a technical error. I am therefore voting in favour of this motion.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report’s approval of the Commission Recommendation for a Council decision regarding the accession of Croatia to the Convention on the fight against corruption involving EC officials or officials of Member States. This accession will underline the EU’s – and particularly Croatia’s – commitment to transparency, openness and accountability in governance. This can only serve to improve public confidence in their national and European representatives, and to improve the quality of governance within EU Member States

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as the proposal is technical. It will pave the way for Croatia to complete its accession to the 1997 Convention on the fight against corruption involving officials of the European Communities or officials of the Member States of the European Union.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – Corruption cases make the press loud every day, whether we think of cases of economic crime intertwined with sport or politics. Such processes, which cause very serious moral and social damage, must be prevented by all possible means, so I was happy to support the report so that Croatia could be part of the EU's anti-corruption system by joining the convention.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mrs Hyusmenova's proposal for Croatia's accession to the Convention against Corruption, in which officials from the European Communities or the Member States are involved. The recommendation is aimed at making the necessary adjustments due to Croatia's accession to the recalled Convention, in accordance with Article 3(4) and (5) of the Act of Accession.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. This Commission Recommendation for a Council Decision aims to facilitate Croatia's accession to the 1997 Convention on combating corruption involving officials from the European Communities or the Member States. This case arises from the 2011 Croatian Act of Accession, which lists six conventions and protocols in the area of Justice and Home Affairs which Croatia must access by council decision. The Council decision should make the necessary adjustments to the Convention required by Croatia's accession. In accordance with these considerations, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. Annex I to the Act of Accession contains a list of conventions and protocols to which Member States are to accede, including the Convention on combating corruption. Since Croatia accedes to this Convention in the context of its accession to the European Union independently and as a sovereign state, I voted in favour of respecting its decisions in accordance with the principle of self-determination.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The report of MEP Filiz Hyusmenova supports the Commission's proposal for the Accession of the Republic of Croatia to the Convention against Corruption involving officials of the European Communities or officials of the Member States of the European Union and the implementation of the necessary adjustments for accession. The Convention was adopted with a view to fostering a common fight against passive and active corruption involving national or Union officials causing financial damage. Cooperation rules are prescribed to equate Member States' criminal law with the Convention. Corruption is holding back economic and social progress. According to the Corruption Perceptions Index, Croatia was 61st out of 175 in 2014. Compared to 2013, it has regressed four places, suggesting a lack of fight against corruption. I support Croatia's accession to the Convention, because by correctly implementing the adjustment, we will strengthen the legislative framework and the fight against corruption. Croatia needs to foster the right values and create a corruption-free business environment to ensure economic development and investment.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. Croatia is the youngest member of the EU and must join the International Convention on combating corruption among senior officials. This is very important in preserving political culture and the public image of power in the EU. I voted for it.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing \u2012 The Recommendation is based on the Act of Accession of Croatia. The aim is to make the necessary adjustments required by the Convention on combating corruption of EC officials or officials of Member States.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the recommendation for a Council Decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention of 26 May 1997 drawn up pursuant to Article K.3(2)(c) of the Treaty on European Union on combating corruption involving officials of the European Communities or the Member States of the European Union, because this report lays down simplified arrangements for Croatia's accession to the Conventions (and Protocols) concluded by the Member States on the basis of Article 34 EES (formerly Article K. 3 of the EES).

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. Abstention on this vote. As with the previous vote, Croatia's accession to this convention is in any case automatic because of its accession to the European Union. Any debate on this subject seems unnecessary.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported Croatia's accession to the Convention of 26 May 1997 on combating corruption, involving officials from the European Communities or EU Member States on the basis of Article K.3(2)(c) of the Treaty on European Union. The Convention against Corruption is necessary for the improvement of judicial cooperation in criminal matters. Member States consider the improvement of judicial cooperation in the fight against corruption to be a matter of common interest.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2012 Act on the conditions of accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union simplified its accession to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States pursuant to Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union. With a view to supporting croatia's full participation in the activities of the European Union, I have chosen to vote in favour of this document, which enshrines the accession of the new Member State to the Convention on combating corruption in the event of the involvement of officials of the European Communities, or of the Member States.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report, as it is only a mere formal act without any substantive amendment.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. In its act of accession to the European Union, Croatia also approved a package of European conventions, including the anti-corruption convention. It is now a matter of validating the date of publication and entry into force in the country. I am opposed to the enlargement of the Union but I defend the sovereign choice of a State to participate in a European or international convention. Under these conditions, I vote for.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament of 10 June 2015 on the recommendation of a Council decision on croatia's accession to the Convention of 26 May 1997 on the fight against corruption involving officials of the European Communities or the Member States of the European Union. On the basis of this Convention, each Member State is obliged to take the necessary measures to ensure that the conduct constituting acts of passive or active corruption committed by officials is criminally penalised.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it is largely a technical matter concerning the date when the Convention on the fight against corruption involving EC officials or officials of Member States enters into force with Croatia, following its accession to the Union.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome Croatia's accession to the Anti-Corruption Convention involving officials from the European Communities or the Member States of the European Union. The fight against corruption and fraud in the European institutions is a top priority for the Union. All corruption, and especially that of civil servants, must be vigorously combated in order to ensure the good governance of our Union. Croatia's cooperation is a step in the right direction.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on Croatia’s accession to the Convention on the fight against corruption involving officials of the European Communities or officials of Member States.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Croatia, with its accession to the Union, undertook to accede to a series of conventions previously concluded by the Member States under Article 34 TSI. In this connection, the Council, on a recommendation from the Commission, shall adopt, after consulting the European Parliament, a decision setting out the date of entry into force of the Conventions with regard to Croatia and making the necessary adjustments for the accession of the new Member State. Support for this report therefore essentially means supporting croatia's accession to the EU.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The Recommendation for a Council decision proposed by the Commission aims to introduce the necessary amendments by virtue of Croatia's accession to the above-mentioned convention in accordance with Article 3(4) and (5) of the Act of Accession. In order to clarify the possible doubts that exist with regard to the beginning of the existing Convention between Croatia and the Member States, and for reasons of legal certainty, I am voting in favour of the Commission's recommendation.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This resolution relates to the Council's decision on Croatia's accession to the Anti-Corruption Convention of 26 May 1997 involving officials of the European Communities or the Member States of the European Union.  Indeed, under Article 3, paragraph 4, and Article 3, paragraph 5 of Croatia's 2011 accession to the European Union, Croatia must accede to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States through a simplified procedure. The Council must decide when these conventions will come into force with regard to Croatia, but also to adapt them (translation of conventions into the Croatian language, etc.). The Commission's recommendation on the Convention between Croatia and the Member States presents a technical error with regard to the effective date, which raises uncertainty as to the actual date and, therefore, threatens the very existence of the act.  However, we deny this desire for infinite enlargement of the European Union and Croatia's simplified procedure for accession to the conventions of which the EU Member States are parties. In these circumstances, I abstained in this vote.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as this Commission Recommendation for a Council decision will pave the way for Croatia to complete its accession to the 1997 Convention on the fight against corruption involving officials of the European Communities or officials of the Member States of the European Union (‘the PIF Convention’).

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this purely technical text concerning Croatia's accession date to the Convention of 26 May 1997 on the fight against corruption involving officials of the European Communities or the Member States of the European Union. The fight against corruption is a major challenge to maintain Europeans' confidence in their institutions. That is why I voted for this text in line with European law.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of the recommendation adopted here today is simply to make the necessary adjustments following Croatia's accession to the PIF Convention on combating corruption involving officials from the European Communities or the Member States of the European Union. This is a purely technical issue which does not raise any problems from a legal or political point of view.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour, in the light of the Commission's recommendation to the Council, of Article 3 of Croatia's accession, Article 59 of its regulation and in view of the report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The aim of this Commission recommendation for a Council Decision is to make the necessary changes following Croatia's accession to the Convention to Combat Corruption, in accordance with Article 3(4) and (5) of the 2012 Act on the Conditions of Accession to the European Union. The act in question simplified its accession to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States under Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union (ex Article K.3 TEU). It is no longer necessary, as in the past, to negotiate and conclude specific accession protocols (with the consequent ratification of the 28 Member States). Article 3(4) and (5) simply stipulates that Croatia shall accede to conventions and protocols by virtue of that act. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the report and croatia's accession to this very important convention.  It is good to see that, slowly and slowly, Croatia, as the newest Member State of the EU, is indeed closing all the procedures inherent in accession, acceding to the conventions already adopted and operated by the other Member States. This is the way forward, so croatian EU citizens can benefit the most from their country's EU membership and the EU acquis. I trust that citizens will soon feel the benefits of belonging and cooperation in everyday life.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: în scris. ‒ The 2011 Accession Treaty of the Republic of Croatia introduced a simplified system for the accession of Croatia to the European Union’s conventions and protocols. I have voted for this report, which recommended that the Council determine when these conventions enter into force for the 28th Member State of the European Union.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because the fight against corruption is crucial to the functioning of the European Union and, a foregone seof, new members must be supported in their fight against this phenomenon.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This is a technical report aimed at the accession of Croatia, the new Member State of the European Union, to a convention signed and ratified by the Union and all its Member States, in this case the Anti-Corruption Convention involving officials of the European Communities or the Member States. I saw no valid reason to oppose this report, so I voted in favour.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. This is an adaptation to croatia's accession to that Convention.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the requirement for publication in the Official Journal must be clear and does not give cause for doubt as to the entry into force of the Convention on combating corruption involving national and/or European officials.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report and welcome the Decision of the European Parliament giving its consent to the Council, as recommended by the European Commission, on the date of entry into force of Croatia's accession to the Convention aimed at combating corruption involving officials of the European Communities or officials of the Member States of the European Union.  Article 3(4) of the The Accession Act provides for Croatia's accession to the conventions and protocols concluded between Member States, set out in Annex I to the Accession Act, including the Convention against Corruption involving officials of the European Communities or officials of the Member States of the European Union.  Croatia has transposed into national law all legislative obligations to the European Union, including those provided for in the Convention, but I consider its application and consistent implementation extremely important. The fight against corruption must be a strong priority, both for the European Union and for Member States, in the performance of public service, at official level and in decision-making positions.  Given that, in the performance of duties in these cases, exceptional responsibility of management of european funds can also be addressed, legislative measures, transparency of work and allocation of funds must be defined and secured in all respects.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This resolution addresses the Council's decision recommendation on Croatia's accession to the Anti-Corruption Convention of 26 May 1997 involving officials of the European Communities or the Member States of the European Union. Indeed, under Article 3, paragraph 4, and Article 3, paragraph 5 of Croatia's 2011 accession to the European Union, Croatia must accede to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States through a simplified procedure. The Council must decide when these conventions will come into force with regard to Croatia but also to adapt them (translation of the conventions into the Croatian language, etc.). The Commission's recommendation on the Convention between Croatia and the Member States presents a technical error with regard to the effective date, which raises uncertainty as to the actual date and, therefore, threatens the very existence of the act. I reject this desire for the infinite enlargement of the European Union and the simplified procedure for Croatia's accession to the conventions of which the Member States of the Union are parties. In these circumstances, I abstained in this vote.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. \u2012 I support my colleague Hyusmenova's report on the recommendation for the Council's decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention of 26 May 1997 drawn up on the basis of Article K.3 (2) of the European Union Treaty on Combating Corruption involving officials of the European Communities or officials of the Member States of the European Union. The Croatian Parliament is currently in the process of adopting the Anti-Corruption Action Plan and the Anti-Corruption Strategy for the period 2015-2020. Croatian citizens were also invited to submit their comments on the aforementioned Action Plan by June 21st. These strategic documents are a continuation of national efforts since 2002 with the entry into force of the first in a series of National Anti-Corruption Programmes. According to a 2014 Transparency International report, the Republic of Croatia ranks 61st out of 175 surveyed countries, according to the corruption perception index. Given that Croatia has been a full member of the Union since July 2013 and its index (48) is below the Union average (66), accession to this Convention will contribute to Croatia's efforts to fight corruption.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Again this is an obligatory step following Croatia's accession to the EU, so I voted in favour. In the case of the specific Convention, it is for the Council to make the necessary adjustments to bring it into line with the accession of the new Member State.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Council's recommendation for a decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention of 26 May 1997, on the fight against corruption involving officials of the European Communities or the Member States of the Union. This text is part of Croatia's process of integrating the Union's regulatory values and legacies following its accession to the Union in July 2013.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 In accordance with Article 3(4) and (5) of the Act on the conditions for accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, a simplified system for the accession of that country to the conventions and protocols concluded by the Member States on the basis of Article 34 OF the ET has been defined, according to which Croatia accessions to such instruments under that Act , with the Council being required to adopt a decision, on a recommendation from the Commission and after consulting the European Parliament, determining the date on which the conventions enter into force for this new Member State and makes all necessary adjustments to that end. This Recommendation on a Council Decision proposed by the Commission seeks to introduce the necessary amendments as a result of Croatia's accession to the Convention of 26 May 1997 on the fight against corruption involving officials of the European Communities or the Member States of the European Union. I voted in favour.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. I supported this afternoon's report on the Council's recommendation for a decision on Croatia's accession to the 26 May 1997 Convention, established on the basis of Article K.3, paragraph 2, point c), of the Treaty on the European Union, on the fight against corruption involving officials of the European Communities or the Member States of the European Union.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. – This is the question of making the necessary adjustments as a result of the new Member State's membership of that convention.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution, which assumes the Commission's proposal to address a technical error affecting the provision of the Commission Recommendation on the date of entry into force of the Convention between Croatia and the Member States.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The 2012 Act on Croatia's EU accession conditions simplified its accession to the agreements concluded by Member States on the basis of Article 34 of the Treaty on European Union. It is no longer necessary, as in the past, to negotiate and conclude specific accession protocols (which were to be ratified by the 28 Member States): Article 3, paragraphs 4 and 5, of the accession act simply provides for Croatia to adhere to the conventions and protocols under that act. Paragraphs 4 and 5 of Article 3 of the Accession Act provide for the Council to take a decision setting out the date on which these conventions come into force with regard to Croatia and to make all the adjustments made necessary by the accession of this new Member State to these conventions. Appendix I of the Accession Act lists the six conventions and protocols concerned in the field of justice and home affairs, including the Anti-Corruption Convention involving officials of the European Communities or the Member States of the European Union. The report voted today therefore aims to make the adjustments made necessary by Croatia's accession to the Convention.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The Convention on combating corruption involving officials of the European Communities or EU Member States lays down the obligation for Member States to take the necessary measures to ensure that active and passive corruption, as defined by the Convention, is considered a criminal offence at national level. As with the Convention on Mutuo Legal Assistance, the adoption of this resolution stems from Croatia's accession to the European Union, and the country should therefore also be an integral part of that Convention.  Because there are no constraints that would affect their support, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. This Convention aims to combat corruption involving EU officials or national officials of EU Member States. Thus, each Member State is obliged to take the necessary measures to ensure that behaviours constituting acts of passive or active corruption of officials are criminally punished. The fight against corruption and fraud is a top priority of the European Union, which has always been defended.  I supported this text which allows Croatia to accede to this convention.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the text presented by Mr Beazley. Hyusmenova. It is a technical report which allows Croatia, the last country in chronological order to have obtained accession to the European Union, to accede to the Convention of 16 May 1997 on combating corruption involving officials of the European Communities or of the Member States.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because it is merely a note of Croatia's accession to this Convention.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We voted IN FAVOUR of Croatia's accession to the Convention; this only implies Croatia's inclusion in a convention concluded prior to Croatia's entry into the EU.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ This Commission Recommendation for a Council decision will pave the way for Croatia to complete its accession to the 1997 Convention on the fight against corruption involving officials of the European Communities or officials of the Member States of the European Union (‘the PIF Convention’).

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I supported the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the Anti-Corruption Convention, which was signed between EU Member States back in 1997 and entered into force in 2005. Article 3(4) of the The Accession Act provides for Croatia's accession to conventions and protocols concluded between Member States, including the Convention against Corruption involving officials of the European Communities or officials of the Member States of the European Union.  I believe that improving judicial co-operation in the fight against corruption is in the common interest of all Member States of the Union. Corruption is a socially unacceptable phenomenon that directly threatens human rights, destroys social capital and threatens the stability and economic progress of the state. The fight against corruption is a precondition for the development of a transparent and democratic society.  I support the strengthening of legal infrastructure in the fight against corruption and I believe that the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the Convention will contribute to a more effective implementation of anti-corruption measures.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: In writing ‒ Accession to the Convention is another positive step by the country in implementing its membership obligations and its efforts to combat corruption by EC officials or officials of Member States.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ By the Accession Act, the Republic of Croatia has introduced a simplified system for accession to conventions and protocols. Under Article 3 of the Accession Act, the Council shall decide on the date of entry into force of the Convention so that all necessary adjustments can be ensured.  A condition of publication is an essential process assumption without which a particular act is considered non-existent. The Commission's recommendation for the Council Decision on that Convention is to comply with the provisions concerning the date of entry into force of the Convention in accordance with Article 3. Accession Act. Based on the above, I underestimate this report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ I support the draft report on the proposal for a Council Decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention of 26 May 1997 drawn up on the basis of Article K.3 paragraph 2 (c) of the Treaty on Combating Corruption involving officials of the European Communities or officials of the Member States of the European Union. The Accession Treaty of the Republic of Croatia introduced a simplified system for croatia's accession to conventions and protocols concluded by member states. The Council shall take a decision, as determined by the date on which this Convention enters into force for the Republic of Croatia. Similarly, on the proposal of the Commission, the Council decides after consulting the European Parliament on the adoption of conventions in Croatian.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Report on the recommendation of the Council Decision on the accession of Croatia to the Convention on the Fight against Corruption of Officials of the European Communities or officials of Member States of the European Union. As with the report on the accession of Croatia to the Convention on Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters, we will accept all the adaptations necessary for the entry into force of that Convention by adopting the report on croatia's accession to the Convention on the Fight Against Corruption of Officials of the European Communities or officials of the Member States.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Croatia has always pursued a stable Anti-Greek policy on all issues of interest to Greece at local, regional and international level, such as the name of Skopje, economic policy at Community level, etc.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. The commission's proposed decision recommendation, proposed by the Commission, is intended to make the adjustments required by Croatia's accession to the Convention.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Accession of Croatia to the Convention on the fight against corruption involving EC officials or officials of Member States. It is a simple technical report aimed at allowing Croatia to be bound to this convention on the fight against corruption.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a report on Croatia's accession to the Anti-Corruption Convention involving officials of the Member States of the Union. Civil servants and public employees differ from employees in the private sector in terms of their duties, because through work they are obliged to respect constitutional values as well as the legal order of the state, but also the principles of impartiality, avoidance of conflicts of interest as well as equal treatment of all citizens.  I believe that in violation of these principles as well as the intentions to obtain their own benefits, and at the expense of the state, rigorous penalties should be carried out which clearly condemn the motives for the commission of corruption acts. As a new Member State, Croatia has demonstrated by its example that it is capable of using legal instruments to convict criminal offences and to show that it is ready for operational action in the field of security and justice.  I believe that Member States must insist even more on judicial cooperation in order to be able to respond to corrupt acts in a timely manner, with the aim of sending a clear message on the condemnation of corrupt and criminal activities. I therefore also call for further strengthening of precautionary measures as well as more rigorous regulations in sanctioning these procedures.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report. There's been a lot of ink on corruption. Despite the constant struggle against it, it is still very topical, more than ever. You could call it a 21st-century plague. It is a convention that forms the legal framework for member states' cooperation in the fight against corruption. And it is cooperation or collective revolt against such actions that can bring results.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We voted IN FAVOUR of Croatia's accession to the Convention; this only implies Croatia's inclusion in a convention concluded prior to Croatia's entry into the EU.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 We voted IN FAVOUR of Croatia's accession to the Convention; this only implies Croatia's inclusion in a convention concluded prior to Croatia's entry into the EU.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the two reports seeking to increase cooperation between Croatia and the EU in the fight against crime, and in particular against corruption.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a purely technical matter which must therefore be voted on positively in the House.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. Annex I to the Act of Accession contains a list of conventions and protocols to which Member States are to accede, including the Convention on combating corruption. Since Croatia accedes to this Convention in the context of its accession to the European Union independently and as a sovereign state, I voted in favour of respecting its decisions in accordance with the principle of self-determination.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report, as it is only a mere formal act without any substantive amendment.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation for a Council decision on Croatia's accession to the Convention of 26 May 1997 pursuant to Article K.3(2)(c) of the Treaty on European Union on Combating Bribery, which involves officials of the European Communities or the Member States of the European Union. I am opposed to the enlargement of the EU to include further members. However, it makes sense to extend the rules on bribery of EU officials to other states– whether they are members of the EU or not.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – Mr President, the balanced relationship between the European Union and Russia is crucial for the whole continent. Relations have hit rock bottom. The adopted report, going beyond legitimate expectations, is effectively an indictment of President Putin, who has been described as a dictator and aggressor. There will be no improvement in relations if the Union does not take into account Russia's legitimate interests. The Ukrainian crisis is also a conflict between the US and Russia, in which the Union has unilaterally become a representative of American interests. Maintaining and increasing sanctions is pointless and harmful. It is pointless because President Putin has not wavered in popularity, but it is also harmful because it causes very serious economic losses to certain Member States of the Union, including Hungary, and sanctions must therefore be lifted.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: – Russia and the European Union have been in a worrying bid for years now, in fact since NATO's enlargement to the east and the first military response by Russia in South Ossetia in 2008, a worrying bid, a dangerous bid, a spiral of mutual provocations, which is driving things to the fore and which we have known since 1914 that this could lead to a major war. No one has improved from these mutual provocations, not European farmers, not Russian farmers, not the Russian economy and not the economy in the EU Member States.  The harsh condemnation of Russian violations of the principle of consultation, as in Crimea, for example, is one matter. Tying the countries of the European Union to a geostrategic and economic de facto annexation of Ukraine, in which the people there are promised a promise of money and immigration on behalf of the EU peoples, is another pair of sleeves. Vlaams Belang advocates the restoration of diplomatic relations with Russia and questions the reciprocal economic sanctions and the trade boycott. We believe they are laying the seeds for a further escalation of the conflict.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, Russia is failing to protect the human rights of many of its people, such as the LGBTI communities. However, it is the conflict in Ukraine that has caused the crisis in relations. Unfortunately, this report is blatantly one-sided and fails to acknowledge that Russia, along with the EU and the US, has exacerbated this conflict. The report also reveals sickening double standards in EU external policy. International law and human rights are mentioned 26 times collectively in eight pages of text. The report says cooperation should adhere fully to international human rights standards. I agree. But while the EU imposes sanctions on Russia, it has allowed Israel to violate international and human rights law with impunity for more than two decades. When it comes to diplomacy, it certainly seems that the EU saves the carrot for Israel and the stick for Russia.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: – Mr President, I voted against this report. It says that the EU targeted measures are not directed against the Russian people but against certain individuals and enterprises, but the figures say the opposite. Sanctions against Russia have led to a dramatic split between the peoples of Europe and Russia. Public opinion polls show that as a result of the sanctions, 59% of the Russian population have a negative or very negative opinion of the EU, but the approval rating of Vladimir Putin has risen to 86%. This 86% is not certain individuals, they are the nation, and the authors and supporters of this resolution enforcing political and economic confrontation between the European Union and Russia must realise that their actions could lead to an apocalyptical clash of two closely-related civilisations on the European continent.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, the EU needs a new strategy for its relations with Russia. The Russian occupation of Crimea, the continuous military aggression in eastern Ukraine and the blunt violation of international agreements have all come together to put EU-Russia relations at a crossroads. This Parliament must condemn the most recently-announced blacklist banning EU politicians, including 19 MEPs, from entering Russia. It is a breach of international law, violating universal standards and impeding transparency by the Russian leadership. It disrespects Parliament, but it is also an insult to the EU as a whole. And the European Union adheres to the very principles of the rule of law, transparency and self-determination. We must send a clear message to Russia that there will be more, tougher sanctions if the international obligations and the Minsk Agreements are not respected by Moscow.

name: Jens ROHDE
text: Mr President! I would have said a lot about the need for Europe to now have a strong common foreign and security policy and also a strong defence policy. Because the softpower that we have in Europe, which is, of course, economic in nature, is limited by others when there are territorial battles in the foreign policy game. Much could be said about this, but I simply have to address the fact that, when we had the vote, some words emerged that I have not really thought about since the Cold War, namely 'useful idiots' and 'fifth column business'. These were concepts that we certainly had in the country I come from, Denmark. At the time, it was about the left, who were the useful idiots of the then Soviet Union. I have to say that what we have seen here today is an exhibition of the useful idiots on the European right, namely Putin's useful idiots. I think it's shameful.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – I was happy to vote in favour of this report. I am very glad that this report clearly and clearly identifies the situation in Russia, its presence on the international stage and also how democracy works within the state itself. I am from the Czech Republic, where a certain part of left-wing politicians relativizes the behavior of Russia and the behavior of Putin and his regime, especially, unfortunately, the Czech President. All the more valuable, I think, is that we have adopted here today a report that is not "politically super correct", which does not soften reality and which clearly states that Russia is now violating international law. That there is no democracy and a democratic rule of law in Russia, that there is no media freedom in Russia, and that in such a situation Russia can hardly be a strategic partner of Europe, and that sanctions must continue. I think that's the key message, and I'm glad we accepted it today.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the If a country violates international law, it cannot be without consequences, and then it does not matter whether it is a large country or a small country. For we cannot replace justice with strength or power. That is why it is very important that this report has been debated in the European Parliament. That is the first comment. The second is that anyone who reads the report very carefully will notice that this is not just about sanctions, about punishment. No, it is also a question of the willingness to engage in dialogue. The European Union is still ready to enter into dialogue with Russia in order to eliminate the existing problems. In other words, the report has not only been necessary, but it is also balanced. That is why I was able to give him my approval.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Russian resolution contains many important and valuable wordings, it is only a pity that it does not contain a clear condemnation of communism. Europe should not passively watch as in Russia there are still public cults surrounded by Bolshevik criminals such as Lenin, such as Dzierżyński, like Kalinin, and the Russians, in turn, should know that we are not fighting their state or their culture, but we are fighting against the continuation of the Soviet system, which has caused them so much evil and, above all, to them.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur The European Union and Russia could share common objectives, such as the fight against the Islamic State organisation in Iraq, Syria, Libya. Cooperation between the US, Russia and European countries in Afghanistan can serve as a model. It was a unique operation and a rare case, because all these countries had an interest in stability in Afghanistan, and all parties actively cooperated towards this goal. At that time, at that time, Russia allowed American cargo planes to fly over their territory and use a base in Ulyanovsk, and supported the us base in Kyrgyzstan. Both then and now, there is an active exchange of special services information, which allows for a more effective fight against terrorists and radical groups.  Dear colleagues, Fighting an enemy as dangerous as the 'Islamic State' cannot be successful without Russia's involvement. Yes, there are now contradictions between western countries and Russia that we need to talk about, but we also have more important tasks that we can only solve together through cooperation.  This time I voted against the Landsbergis report. Thank you!

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, I voted against this report. It is fairly obvious what sort of an individual Vladimir Putin is – not a very nice individual –but, unfortunately, the European Union at this stage has given up any right to lecture anyone on sovereignty. I say that as someone who comes from the Republic of Ireland, where we had a referendum on the Nice Treaty. You did not like the result, so you brought in the propaganda tanks and we then voted ‘yes’. We did not get the best of three, I noticed. Then, on the Lisbon Treaty – your glorified European Constitution – we voted against it. What happened? Did you – the people who are lecturing Russia, the EUSSR – listen to us? No, you did not. You brought in the EU Commission tanks with your money and you forced us again to change our vote. On TTIP you are undermining sovereignty. This Union should shut the hell up about sovereignty until it learns what it really means. You have not got a bloody clue.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Dear Mr President, I abstained on the report on the state of relations between the European Union and Russia because I believe that the report is incomplete and does not reflect all the themes and aspects of the matter. For example, we are witnessing russia's aggressive policy in the Balkans. An example of this is the relations with Serbia and Macedonia and their close relations with the Kremlin. Serbia systematically violates Union decisions, does not respect them in solidarity, as a country with the status of negotiating country should do. Regarding the Republic of Macedonia, there was no comment in this report regarding the remarks of the Russian Foreign Minister. The report also omitted the topic of energy and energy security and did not analyze the Project "Russian Stream". In my view, a clear assessment of this project should be given, as it should be taken into account, that the rapprochement between Ankara and Moscow seriously jeopardises the foreign policy interests of the Union, and in particular my country.  The positive thing about the report is that the themes of the conflict in Ukraine, the obstruction of opposition parties to participate in the upcoming elections, the persecution of political opponents and the restriction of media freedom are affected.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, Russia has been sliding into autocracy. It is a state where journalists are murdered, where opposition is harassed, where media are closed down, and every contiguous state feels the pressure of Russian revanchism, whether in the form of oil and gas diplomacy or, tragically, of direct military action. Saying these things does not mean that you support any particular foreign policy; it is simply acknowledging the truth about the unhappy developments in that country. I have to say I was surprised by the alignment of forces in this Chamber who are reluctant even to point out what is happening internally in Russia. There are some Eurosceptics who have got themselves, by a bizarre kind of ‘my enemy’s enemy is my friend’ logic, into lining up with one of the most repressive regimes in this part of the world. The reason I am against the Brussels racket is precisely because I believe in freedom, democracy and the rule of law, and when I extend that logic to what is happening in the Kremlin, I know whose side I am on.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Mr President, I voted against, for different reasons, but the main one is that it is self-contradictory. I am reading point 14: Parliament ‘is deeply concerned with Russia’s support for, and financing of, radical and extremist parties in the EU Member Statesʼ, while in point 20 we say: ‘calls on the Commission to programme more ambitious financial assistance to Russian civil society from the existing external financial instrumentsʼ. Exactly what Russia is forbidden to do, the European Union is called on to do. Point 19: ‘strongly condemns the governmentsʼ – certain governmentsʼ –‘continued crackdown on dissent by targeting independent NGOs through the so-called “foreign agents lawsˮ’. Point 21: ‘calls on the Commission to propose legislation forbidding financing of political parties in the EU by political and or economic stakeholders outside the EUʼ. So, what Russia is forbidden to do is allowed for us. The Russians would love it if they did it, of course.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, I would like to draw attention to the roll call vote on paragraph 21 of this report. I voted against this Orwellian-type incursion of EU power against Member States. It is all about giving the Commission power to oversee the funding of political parties within Member States. This is a gross incursion into the independence of the British democratic system. The unelected Commission should have no oversight in relation to the running of political parties, as it is a political and legislative body of the European Union. I also challenge the oral amendments after paragraphs 12 and 19 on the basis that they call for action to be taken by the Commission.
