I believe that a sovereign British Parliament, free from the European institutions, should be free to make such representations through the usual diplomatic channels rather than relying on this body.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, almost one year ago to the day, I entered this Chamber for the first time as a new MEP. Within the first few minutes of any debates I heard on Russia, there were those here seeking further sanctions. I then heard those who wanted to increase military action. During the course of my time here, I have seen debates and motions which are allowing an EU army to have funding for even things such as drones. In this debate today, I have actually heard people suggest that those who advise caution on how we deal with Russia are called idiots or indeed those who are funded by the Russian empire itself. I am neither one of those, but I do take heed of the fact that in this particular motion there is very careful phraseology that would actually decline and reduce our ability for free media. There is an ability to increase disinformation through different kinds of campaigns. There is an ability to control the funding of political parties by the Commission. There is an ability to build vehicles that would issue propaganda against the Russian countries. This is what I heard once before in the Soviet empire. This is about the European Union seeking to build its own empire. For that I believe that we have the language of dictatorship, not democracy, within this Chamber.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Mr President, it is about time that we talked about the 2 million people that are fleeing at the moment in Europe. It is an exodus of the magnitude of the Bosnian war. There are 1.2 million internally-displaced people in Ukraine: children, women, men – innocent people. There are 800 000 refugees leaving Ukraine. There are humanitarian convoys from the United Nations, from the European Union, that do not get through to the people in need. There are 3.2 million people in need of urgent help, according to the European Union Humanitarian Office. Why is no one talking about them? They are victims who are kidnapped and hijacked. But there is this fear of confronting Russia, which wants to subvert the order of peace and security in Europe by using force and, more and more, heavy weapons. I am glad that this Parliament, with a strong majority, has supported the resolution that simply tells a member of the Security Council to respect the rule of law and international law.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, Mr Rohde spoke earlier, no doubt by targeting us, of 'useful idiots'. I do not know if I am an idiot, but I will give him some useful information about this Parliament, where I have been sitting for twenty-nine years. Twenty-nine years ago, I never heard any criticism of the Soviet Union, which at the time ruled a regime of terror and subjected all the peoples of Central and Eastern Europe. Since the Soviet Union liberated these peoples of Central and Eastern Europe from its military occupation, since it dissolved the Warsaw Pact, since it gave freedom - and I am happy about it - to the Baltic States and many other Central Asian states and others, russia has been fired red balls, which is certainly not perfect.  But, ladies and gentlemen, what do you think? You are outraged by the blacklist established by the Russian government, but a year ago you went so far as to ban the coming of parliamentarians! The President of the Russian Parliament has no right to come and discuss with us! Ditto for diplomats! And you are surprised today that the Russian government decides to opt for a shepherd's answer to the shepherdess. You have declared economic war on Russia, but you would like to continue to export our products, agricultural or food, as if nothing had happened. The majority of this Parliament is in a world of Bisounours, which has no awareness of the realities of current geopolitics.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, Labour, Conservatives and Liberal Democrats have already criticised UKIP for standing up to an oral amendment and trying to prevent that amendment from being considered. Why did we stand against that? Firstly, we do not believe that the Commission should legislate over how political parties are funded, or anything along those lines – simply because that is a matter for individual nation states. So we stand on that point of principle, not necessarily against the evils which it tries to stop. Secondly, we believe that the oral amendments are a bad procedure in general. If you have got to try to decide within seconds, how are you going to vote on something? Are we going to vote in favour or against? That can very easily lead to some very bad decisions being taken. So we believe that these things should be sorted well in advance and Parliament should not be bounced into a response so quickly.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. Russia is the main neighbour of the European Union, one of its main trading partners – especially in terms of energy needs – and a country with which all the countries of the European Union have closely shared a part of history. That is why I believe that relations between the EU and Russia must be treated with the utmost care and great responsibility. In the text put to the vote, however, I have encountered a disproportionate vocabulary riddled with condemnation. But above all, there is a double standard that is difficult to digest by anyone who has briefly known the history of Europe in the last twenty-five years. I voted against this report because, according to the approved text, Russia should no longer be a strategic partner for the European Union, which is particularly worrying given the common interests that exist.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ Sinn Féin recognises and condemns Russia’s human rights abuses, including the discrimination against the LGBTI community and the imprisonment of political opponents and critics of the Putin regime as outlined in the report. However, the main focus of the report relates to the crisis in Ukraine, which is now to the core of current EU-Russia relations. Sinn Féin has been clear on our position regarding the conflict in the region. The conflict in Ukraine has stemmed from a zero-sum geopolitical game between Russia and the West that put Ukraine in the position of choosing to ally itself with one or the other. Russia and the EU should have been working together to create mutually beneficial and non-exclusive economic, political and social relationships with Ukraine. Instead Russian and EU strategic interests in the region have plunged Ukraine into crisis. While the report acknowledges the corrosive part played by Russia in the region it completely ignores any responsibility of the EU for its role in the development of this conflict. It is simply an unbalanced report. Furthermore, the report strikes the wrong note for future EU-Russia Relations. We believe that open dialogue, not confrontation, between the EU and Russia is what is needed to de-escalate tensions. That is why I abstained.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. I am convinced that a constructive, predictable relationship between the EU and Russia is possible and in the mutual interest in the long term, but regret that Russia can no longer be treated or seen as a strategic partner of the EU because of its aggressive and divisive policy in recent weeks and months. I therefore welcome the resolution adopted, as it calls for a critical reassessment of the EU's relations with Russia.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The main motivation for this report is primary Russophobia. The Russian Federation is accused of all evils: the outbreak of the war against Georgia, while Tbilisi's responsibility had been put forward by the independent international commission, "the illegal annexation of Crimea", while the people of Crimea seemed to be clearly in favour of this attachment to Russia.  Strangely, Brussels was far less severe when Russia was under Soviet rule, yet responsible for tens of millions of deaths. In addition, the rapporteur states that Russia "can no longer be treated or seen as a strategic partner". This is a serious political fault: to see the advent of a multipolar world, in which France and Europe would not be subject to any great foreign power, it is necessary, on the contrary, to make Russia one of our preferred partners. Finally, this report departs from its original objective and subject, which was to ask Member States to continue and intensify their efforts to eliminate the enduring decision-making deadlocks. So I voted against this report.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because following the events in Ukraine and the publication of the blacklist of "persona non grata" in Russia, the European Union must act and reassess its diplomatic position against the Kremlin. We must send a strong message to the Russian leadership that we are united with the victims of their aggression and with those who support the values on which the European Union is founded.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on the state of EU-Russia relations. As the report rightly points out, the EU has consistently sought for many years to develop a mutually beneficial strategic partnership with Russia. However, the illegal annexation of Crimea, the ongoing conflict in Ukraine and the apparent loss of democracy and human rights in Russia itself are a serious test for the European Union and a check on its solidarity and concentration. The Baltic states know better than others what russia's current neighbourhood means. They were the first to feel the brunt of russia's restrictions and sanctions on its economies, but withstood. We have been saying for years that Russia has used energy as a tool of political pressure, and the EU must draw the right conclusions and make every effort to build a strong European Energy Union, eliminating the energy vulnerability of individual Member States. Only a solidarity, not a single and fragmented Europe, will be able to withstand external pressures, and i would expect the EU to pass the solidarity test against Russia.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This is an exemplary report of the European Union's adversarial reversal with Russia. I regret that my Baltic colleagues cannot overcome their resentment towards their Russian neighbour: where is the spirit of reconciliation and peace that the Eurocrats pride themselves on? On the contrary, too many Members seek only to throw oil on the fire by multiplying bellicose statements, as unworthy as irresponsible. In the meantime, who benefits from this new Cold War in which we are being dragging? Certainly not to our farmers, nor to our industrialists.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. In the current context, I believe it is essential to reach an agreement that would ensure an end to the conflict in Ukraine. For some time now, Russia has been deliberately violating international law, the principles of democracy and the values of the rule of law. It seems to me inconceivable that the European Union and Russia should have a good relationship in this current climate of conflict. However, I am convinced that a constructive relationship between the Union and Russia would be possible and beneficial if it did not violate the values of the Union and implemented the Minsk agreements. So I voted in favour of the Landsbergis report.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. Russia's participation in Ukraine's conflict with the annexation of Crimea is a serious and deliberate violation of the most fundamental democratic and human principles.  Add to this the restrictions on media freedom, attacks on LGTBI people and the increase in pro-Russian propaganda in the Member States, the need for a strong and unified response is clear. This results in certain restrictive measures for certain individuals and companies linked to Russian leaders. However, these sanctions should be lifted when Russia has fully implemented the Minsk Agreements, including full control of the border by the Ukrainian authorities, the unconditional withdrawal of Russian troops and their weaponry, and the immediate end of aid to rebel groups. We need to critically assess relations with Russia and put all available means to end pro-Russian misinformation and propaganda within the EU. We must also be vigilant with increasingly frequent support and funding for radical parties in EU Member States by Russia. This report does.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because Russia's intervention in Crimea and Georgia violates the principles and values of the EU and international law and has created political instability in Europe. Russia cannot therefore be treated as a strategic partner, although in the long term it would be desirable for relations to be constructive and mutually trustworthy because of the benefits they bring to both sides. But to do so, I would have to respect the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine and, in my view, also crimea, and observe international law. We must also demand respect for human rights and, in particular, LGBTI people who suffer systematic harassment and violence.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The report on the state of affairs between the European Union and Russia is deeply scandalous. Indeed, this text is extremely belligerent and seeks only to accentuate the confrontation of the European Union with the Russian Federation when the only reasonable foreign policy to be pursued would be that of appeasement and a return to normality. For example, the report accuses the Russian Federation of being responsible for triggering the 2008 Georgian crisis, even though a report by the independent international commission headed by Swiss diplomat Heidi Tagliavini and funded by the Union established in 2009 that Georgia was responsible for the outbreak of the conflict. Russia is a partner of the European Union and must be treated as such, no more, no less. I regret to see that some seem to respond through the vote of this text to the injunctions of the United States. Moreover, surreptitiously, this report further and further promotes European integration and therefore less sovereignty for the Member States. For all these reasons, I am voting against this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the policy that Europe is pursuing against Russia. The only result of the decisions taken by the EU so far has been the creation of the sanctions system which is causing enormous economic damage to the European market, in particular the Veneto and Italian market. The persistence of Europe in its positions will make the disastrous economic situation we are experiencing even worse. For all these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I've abstained. The report's criticism of Russia is correct. I condemn the annexation of Crimea, as well as Russia's human rights violations such as the persecution of LGBTQ people and restrictions on freedom of expression and assembly. My criticism of Putin's authoritarian and corrupt rule is crystal clear. However, I deeply disagree with the report's conclusion that consolidation and deepening of the EU's common foreign and security policy is needed. On the contrary, I believe that non-aligned EU countries, such as Sweden, are needed, which retain their own independent ability to act for détente, peace and disarmament. I am also opposed to the ever closer cooperation between the EU and NATO. Militarization and great power building do not solve conflicts.   I would also have liked the report to highlight, and focus on, strategies for peaceful civil conflict resolution. That is why I choose to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The Socialists believe in constructive relations with Russia as one of the EU's most important neighbours, but we hope that Russia will do its part to make this possible, starting with the full implementation of the Minsk Agreements to stop the conflict in Ukraine. Russia is an important EU neighbour; there are interests in practical cooperation and in jointly addressing shared global challenges, such as jihadist terrorism, Iran's nuclear program, destabilization in the Middle East, or non-proliferation. Russia must change its behavior towards its neighbors. The report sets out clear conditions for the full resumption of cooperation with Russia, such as the implementation of the Minsk Agreements, respect for the security order based on OSCE indications and principles in Europe and full respect for Ukraine's territorial integrity, including Crimea. At socialist instances, the meeting of far-right European leaders in Russia is condemned and LGTBI rights are defended in Russia. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it has made Parliament express its position on the state of EU-Russia relations. In this report, Parliament reiterated that Russia's direct and indirect involvement in the armed conflict with Ukraine and the illegal annexation of Crimea, as well as its violation of Georgia's territorial integrity and economic coercion and political destabilisation of Europe's neighbours, deliberately disregard democratic principles, fundamental values and international law. Therefore, the EU cannot currently foresee a return to normal relations and has no choice but to re-assess its relations with Russia in order to counter Russian aggression and divisive policies. In its report, Parliament also stresses that the solution to the conflict in eastern Ukraine can only be political in nature. Among other things, in the report, Parliament also expresses its deep concern about Russia's support and funding for radical and extremist parties in EU Member States.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 Representative Gabrielius Landsbergis has done a thorough job and provides a broad summary of EU-Russia relations.  I agree with the wording of the report and of many European politicians that EU-Russia relations have reached a low point. No improvement is expected until the Minsk agreements are fully implemented. The illegal annexation of Crimea, the hybrid war against Ukraine, the deliberate destabilization of the country confirm that Russia has violated international law and norms. In resolving the situation in eastern Ukraine, I believe that we must insist that the method can only continue to be a political consensus through negotiations, since military acts have already claimed thousands of lives and caused great suffering to the population. It is therefore the responsibility and responsibility of the European Union to enhance and supervise the dialogue between the parties and to create the opportunities for a peaceful settlement as soon as possible. Against this background, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ The EU and Russia are connected through many sectors, from energy to tourism. However, currently existing ties threaten the weakening of democratic principles in Russia and non-compliance with international standards. That is why I regret to say that significant obstacles have been created to further develop the partnership and I hope that the European Parliament document will be an impulse on Russia for change.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I agree with its conclusions. I believe that Russia is acting in a hostile manner towards the international community and the EU. Nevertheless, I hope that relations between us and the Russian Federation will normalize so that we can create a strategic partnership in the future.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Russia is a natural partner of the European Union and the EU's policy of building a strategic partnership of mutual benefit, based on the shared values of democracy and the rule of law, as well as common economic interests, has been corrected.  However, the Russian leadership chose not to reciprocate the trust that the Union had granted by committing serious violations of human and political rights (imprisonment of political opponents, strong restriction of freedom of the press and opinion, discriminatory campaigns against religious, political or LGBT minorities) and violating the foundations of good neighbourliness by occupying the Georgian regions of Abkhazia and Ossetia, intervening militarily within Ukraine's territorial borders and illegally annexing Crimea , supporting serious political destabilisation initiatives in Ukraine, Moldova, Georgia and Armenia, repeatedly violating EU airspace and maritime space, also endangering the safety of civilian flights, and violating agreements on military non-proliferation and regulation of war equipment.   The situation has reached such a level of seriousness that it is intolerable: the solution is political and we must use the diplomatic and economic soft power that the Union and its allies have at their disposal to target the Russian leadership and contain the repercussions on the civilian population.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the state of affairs between the European Union and Russia. The French expect us to have a realistic position on Russia. Far from being objective, this report proposes to relay a pro-American and anti-Russian vision. Should we remember that Russia is nevertheless a privileged partner for Europe in many areas? This text paints an unbelievable picture of two states: one good, the other bad. However, I do not believe that improving relations with Russia requires political hard work. It is a victim of the double language of the members of the majority who constantly denounce the Russian choices while calling for appeasement. By reviving the fire they say they want to put out, they are merely serving the United States at the expense of the states it represents.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against, the report is pre-conceivable and full of anti-Russian prejudices. The anti-Russian policy imposed on the EU by the Americans must be reversed, Russia is an important partner for our businesses and Moscow is certainly not an enemy, but it should be more involved in European development policies.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the state of EU-Russia relations in order to emphasise that the European Union must review its relations with Russia, which currently appear to be compromised due to its destabilisation. With its aggression against Ukraine and the annexation of Crimea, the Russian leadership has put EU-Russia relations at a crossroads. It is now up to the Kremlin to decide the direction: cooperation or greater isolation. I am convinced that the Russian people, like all of us, want peace, not war, and, as Prime Minister Putin said in his recent meeting with Italian Prime Minister Renzi, they want to put an end to the reduction in trade with the EU because of sanctions. A change in Russia must come from within, it can be there and there will be.  In the meantime, we must send a strong message to the Russian leadership, stressing our closeness to the victims of its aggression and to those who defend the values on which the EU is founded.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained in the final vote on the EP report on EU-Russia relations. Sinn Féin recognises and condemns Russia’s human rights abuses, including the discrimination against the LGBTI community and the imprisonment of political opponents and critics of the Putin regime as outlined in the report. However, the main focus of the report relates to the crisis in Ukraine, which is now to the core of current EU-Russia relations. Sinn Féin has been clear on our position regarding the conflict in the region. The conflict in Ukraine has stemmed from a zero-sum geopolitical game between Russia and the West that put Ukraine in the position of choosing to ally itself with one or the other. Russia and the EU should have been working together to create mutually beneficial and non-exclusive economic, political and social relationships with Ukraine. Instead Russian and EU strategic interests in the region have plunged Ukraine into crisis. While the report acknowledges the corrosive part played by Russia in the region it completely ignores any responsibility of the EU for its role in the development of this conflict. It is simply an unbalanced report. Furthermore, the report strikes the wrong note for future EU-Russia Relations. We believe that open dialogue, not confrontation, between the EU and Russia is what is needed to de-escalate tensions.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I believe that the EU needs to conduct a critical reassessment of its relations with Russia. February 2014 marked the latest act of aggression by Russia against its neighbours. I have no doubt that if the international community does not react to this aggression in the right way, there will be more regions that one could add to this list. In light of this, if the situation does not improve quickly, through the full implementation of the Minsk Agreements and full respect for Ukraine’s territorial integrity and international law, then the EU will be left with no choice but to employ stronger measures against Russia. Less than a month since the Eastern Partnership Summit in Riga, the European Union owes this to its Eastern Partners.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Landsbergis report, while considering Russia, at the beginning, as a strategic partner, concludes that it must close the doors of the dialogue with Moscow. The report does not recall that, on the European side as well as on the Western side, relations have been gradually more established with Russia since the 1990s, but never open comparisons of their respective needs. Moscow has rightly called for respect for human rights, but it has not been pointed out that the same anti-Russian interlocutors, financed by the West, often do not comply with the requirements of the EU acquis. In general, I am opposed to the analysis approaches and the prospects for action supported by the report, so I voted against it. Russia's strategic capacity, not only from an economic point of view, makes it a subject with which the EU cannot fail to find a peaceful solution to disputes.  In my opinion, there is no other solution than a diplomatic solution based on soft power. Not to mention the fact that calling for a greater increase in budgetary expenditure within NATO and greater military commitment is not in the interests of our peoples.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which I fully support.  The Russian Government’s actions in Ukraine and internally against opposition voices are unacceptable and we should continue all our efforts to return Russia to a stable and democratic state that respects its neighbours and honours its international pledges and commitments.  As called for by European Council, I believe these actions should include a media campaign to counter the ever—increasing propaganda coming from the Kremlin. Russian citizens need independent and uncensored sources of Russian language news and information. We must endeavour to assist both existing Russian language services like Radio Free Europe and Euronews, but also to create new independent media sources on the internet and elsewhere.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I rejected the report on the state of affairs between the European Union and Russia as a whole. Once again, Russia is being singled out as the big bad wolf who intentionally seeks to cause chaos in Europe to satisfy an alleged fierce imperialism. A true model of subjectivity in reading geopolitical facts, the report thus attributes all responsibility for the 2008 Georgian crisis to Russia, thus ignoring the conclusions of the independent international commission's report on the subject, which established in 2009 that the Georgian authorities bore responsibility for the outbreak of the conflict. The last-minute amendments to the text by the rapporteur also endorse the decisions taken in a completely arbitrary manner by Martin Schultz on 3 June 2015 which, in total violation of the rules of the European Parliament, has denied access to the Russian ambassador without even informing the Conference of Presidents in advance. A denial of democracy found in Mr Landsbergis' report since he refuses to recognise the referendum approved by the people of Crimea. A typical model of dogmatism.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 Lately I have the impression that there are too many cold war nostalgia in the European Parliament. I do not agree with this approach. I believe that the EU must have a more effective and effective foreign policy, as far as possible, but that does not mean taking counterproductive action. So far, the EU has been characterised by the use of soft power, and I believe that we should continue along this path: more dialogue, less sanctions. More convenience, and less self-flagellation. We've always left the tug-of-war with others, and we should keep it that way.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The relationship of Russia is now affected by a set of actions perpetrated by the Russian State that had its exponent with the illegal annexation of Crimea, instigating an armed conflict at the gates of Europe, with harmful consequences for the social and economic development of the region and fears of war and imperial escalation. Added to these military actions are a set of internal legislative measures restricting freedom of expression and persecution of minorities which call into question the spirit of good neighbourly relations between the EU and Russia, which are not consistent with the values of the rule of law, democracy and respect for individual freedoms. I support the sanctions on Russia and believe that the EU should maintain pressure around the values of peace and the protection of human rights and essential freedoms.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The strategic partnership that the European Union has established with Russia is based on shared values and is characterised by a model of enhanced cooperation through which both sides benefit. The Ukrainian issue has destabilised some political and trade balances, but there is no doubt that it is in the interests of both sides to continue the dialogue with a view to the important common global challenges. Therefore, confident of the restoration of good neighbourly relations, I intend to vote for this resolution.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution points out that Russia’s direct and indirect involvement in the armed conflict in Ukraine and its illegal annexation of Crimea, together with its violation of the territorial integrity of Georgia, and economic coercion and political destabilisation of its European neighbours constitute a deliberate violation of democratic principles and fundamental values and of international law. Thus, because of its actions, Russia can no longer be treated as, or considered, a ‘strategic partner’. The resolution also calls on the Commission to do more to counter Russian propaganda and to put an end to Russia’s interference in EU democracies. The resolution condemns the ‘arbitrary’ Russian blacklist banning 89 EU politicians and officials from its territory as an infringement of international law, a violation of universal standards and an impediment to transparency. Meanwhile Parliament is also of the opinion that in the long run a constructive and predictable relationship between the EU and Russia is possible and desirable. I have thus voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Landsbergis report opens up by considering the EU's efforts in recent years to achieve peaceful and dispansive relations with Moscow. In the face of repeated violations of the Nagorno-Karabakh issue as far as South Ossetia and present-day Crimea, the report concludes that it must close the door to dialogue with Moscow. Moscow has rightly called for respect for human rights, but it has not been pointed out that the same anti-Russian interlocutors, financed by the West, often do not comply with the requirements of the EU acquis. Relations between the EU and the west as a whole with Russia have improved for years, including Moscow among the NATO, OECD, G-8 or G.20 partners. The conditionality that is being asserted with Moscow today is impeccable, but it should be the same for other international players, with whom the EU has stable relations. I believe that Russia's strategic capacity, not only from an economic point of view, makes it a subject with which the EU must find a peaceful solution to disputes.  I voted against the report because I am opposed to the analysis approaches and the prospects for action supported by it. I believe that any instrument of international comparison, going beyond the eu's typical instruments, risks distorting its function and being counterproductive.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. Russia is the main neighbour of the European Union, one of its main trading partners – especially in terms of energy needs – and a country with which all the countries of the European Union have closely shared a part of history. That is why I believe that relations between the EU and Russia must be treated with the utmost care and great responsibility. In the text put to the vote, however, I have encountered a disproportionate vocabulary riddled with condemnation. But above all, there is a double standard that is difficult to digest by anyone who has briefly known the history of Europe in the last twenty-five years. I voted against this report because, according to the approved text, Russia should no longer be a strategic partner for the European Union, which is particularly worrying given the common interests that exist.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report presents a critical overview of relations with Russia, the Union's strategic partner, which are marked by the Ukrainian armed conflict, the annexation of Crimea, the violation of Georgia's territorial integrity, the measures of economic coercion or political destabilization taken against certain European states, as well as in response to the EU's heavy economic sanctions against Russia. Distinguishing Russia, a great country that is destined to nurture strong economic and political relations with the Union, and the current action of its Government, I nevertheless believe that for the time being, the strategic partnership with Russia is being undermined in its founding principles, namely mutual trust as well as respect for international law, democracy and national sovereignty. Condemning the current attitude of the Russian Government but believing that the Member States, the European External Action Service and the European Commission must work constructively and relaunch the dialogue with the Russian Federation with a view to establishing constructive and predictable relations, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The European Parliament reaffirms its opposition to Russian military destabilization operations in its immediate vicinity, similar to what is happening in Ukraine. He also condemns the degradation of human rights regularly observed in Russia under the government of Vladimir Putin.  The European Parliament denounces an increasingly deleterious climate towards minorities such as Crimean Tatars whose freedoms and rights are violated. The freedoms of political opponents of Mr. Putin's government are also being undermined: travel bans, "blacklists", abusive detentions, unfair trials, etc. The state of affairs with Russia is therefore more than mixed. The European Union considers that the implementation of the Minsk agreements is necessary to continue its discussions.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I was led to vote in favour of this resolution because at present Vladimir Putin's Russia is treading the basic principles of international law by seeking to redraw Europe's borders by force. I believe that any further cooperation with Russia can only be envisaged if it respects Ukraine's territorial integrity and sovereignty and puts an end to its military and security activities for destabilization at the borders of the European Union. I encourage, however, the European Union to reach out to the Russian authorities and civil society organisations who are willing to develop political and diplomatic relations with the Union based on partnership and cooperation. Finally, I believe that the latest measure to ban political figures and UNION officials from accessing Russian territory is a pure provocation by V. Putin, who is clearly seeking to escalate tension. I would hope that Russia would reverse this decision.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. ‒ Given her ongoing encroachment into sovereign Ukraine and the illegal annexation of Crimea, it is ironic that Mr Putin at the weekend declared that his nation is no threat to the West.  We have seen reported violation after violation of international law, allegations of widespread corruption and the suppression of fundamental freedoms of speech, press and political opposition in Russia.  This is an affront to democracy and should be met with sanctions, whether they are in terms of trade or diplomatic ties. However this is not a line we take lightly.  The Russian import-ban has destabilised agriculture markets right across Europe. Unfortunately, Northern Ireland has been adversely affected, especially the dairy and pork sectors, with farm gate prices falling. Product in transit was also refused, costing dairy processors significantly, and with no support from the Commission.  Ultimately, amidst sending a message of zero tolerance to Russia, the Commission must focus on finding new markets and doing more to offset those affected through no fault of their own.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the state of affairs between the European Union and Russia. The French expect our words to be serious, relevant and realistic. Far from impartiality, this report proposes to relay a pro-American and anti-Russian vision. Should we remember that Russia is nevertheless a privileged partner for Europe in many respects? This text paints an unbelievable picture of two states: one good, the other bad. However, I do not believe that the improvement of relations with Russia requires the constant doggedness it undergoes. It is a victim of the double language of the members of the majority who constantly denounce the Russian choices while calling for appeasement. By reviving the fire they say they want to put out, they are merely serving the United States at the very expense of the states they represent.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as the geopolitical positions of the movement are with those of Russia. Europe serves the interests of the US-controlled system, especially in matters relating to EU-Russia cooperation.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 With this report, Europe comes to the conclusion that it wants to close the dialogue with Russia; It is claimed that all the efforts made by the EU to try to maintain relaxed relations with Moscow have fallen on the back of a vacuum in view of the multiple human rights violations that Russia has committed itself to and is taking centre stage in, starting with the Nagorno-Karabakh issue, passing through Crimea and ending up violating the freedoms of the press, expression and rights linked to sexual identity.  Finding most of moscow's behaviour reprehensible is entirely acceptable, but what is not at all is to consider the closure of the dialogue with Russia and the EU's renunciation of its soft power, the only viable alternative. What I also do not agree with is the fact that we use double standards according to economic convenience, if, on the one hand, we now want to be intransigent with Russia, on the other hand we are much more willing to accept behaviour that is completely out of the acquis communautaire on the part of other European partners.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The EU should monitor Russia's financial assistance to European political parties, allocate funds to projects aimed at addressing Russian propaganda and responding to security threats in the Black Sea following the illegal annexation of Crimea. This report calls on the European Commission to allocate appropriate funding without delay to concrete projects aimed at addressing Russian propaganda and disinformation inside and outside the EU. I agree with support for Russian citizens fighting for democracy and the rule of law in the country, such as human rights defenders, bloggers, independent media, academics and NGOs.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it is only intended to inflame relations between the Member States of the European Union and Russia. This is an exclusively dependent report, which I consider unacceptable as it stands.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. This report confirms the eu's position of confrontation, which is subservient to the geostrategic interests of NATO and the US, has been deepening with Russia. It enshrines the break-up of relations between the EU and Russia and a perfectly decontextualised approach to the Crimea situation of the conflict in Ukraine, where the far right has seized power in an EU-legitimised coup d'état. All framed in the siege policy and the warlike offensive that NATO and the US have been implementing.  This report makes it clear that, among other things, what is at the heart of the conflict with Russia is an economic war over dispute over areas of influence, which goes over the sovereign right of each people to decide their fate, free of interference. The issue of energy dependency of the EU deserves reference, seeking justifications for continuing the European energy security policy, which, among other things, provides for the transfer of energy dependency to the US. As well as the unacceptable instruments of interference, such as the support expressed to the so-called 'NGOs' that the EU funds and which, acting within Russia, are elements of mere political destabilisation.  We voted against it.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: in writing. In this report on relations between the European Union and Russia, I voted in favour because I believe that, at the moment, and following russia's role in the Ukraine conflict and the illegal annexation of Crimea, together with Georgia's territorial violation, the EU can only make a critical reading of its relations with Russia. This critical reading of our relations with Russia must be accompanied by a comprehensive contingency plan on future relations with Russia and Eastern European partners. EU-Russia relations must be based on respect for international law and dialogue. It is also important to resume cooperation in the future on the condition that Russia respects Ukraine's territorial integrity and sovereignty, including Crimea, fully implementing the Minsk Agreements and stopping destabilizing military security activities and at the borders of EU Member States.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ The interests of the European Union should be to maintain constructive relations in the long term aimed at facing common global challenges, for example in the fight against terrorism, organised crime, but also in the field of climate change or the development of new technologies. Unfortunately, in recent months, the Russian Federation has been actively exploiting hybrid warfare, thus blurring deliberately between military/paramilitary activities and political activity. Moreover, against the spirit of good neighbourly relations and in violation of international law, rules and standards, it has taken deliberate actions aimed at destabilising neighbouring countries. The EU is interested in improving relations with the Russian Federation, but it is obliged to use all means to prevent such actions on the part of the Russian Federation.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Report from myopic and crazy. The EU's attitude on this issue is simply suicidal for the majority of EU citizens. Chasing the United States in this new Cold War is crazy.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the inclusion in the report of the key policy lines of our group, such as the forecast for a long-term perspective with Russia. Russia must respect the Minsk agreements, the OSCE-based security order in Europe and the territorial sovereignty of neighbouring countries.  We should take a firm stand on Russia, although we must keep building a constructive relationship and cooperate on global challenges such as jihadist terrorism, Iran’s nuclear programme, destabilisation of the Middle East and non-proliferation.  I believe the report is balanced and sets out clear conditions for a full resumption of cooperation with Russia.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. The EU must ensure compliance with international law in Ukraine, with particular emphasis on fulfilling Russia's peacekeeping obligations in eastern Ukraine. We must also support Russian civil society from the EU to improve basic freedoms and rights, as well as respect for minorities. It is very important, for both Russia and the EU, that relations between the two sides improve in the future, but for this Russia must commit itself and work for the restoration of mutual trust. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the state of relations between the EU and Russia because I believe that Russia has in recent months taken deliberate actions aimed at destabilising its neighbours and, consequently, also the European Union.  Indeed, I am very concerned about the development of the situation in Ukraine and in particular in Crimea, whose illegal annexation has caused an ever-increasing climate of tension throughout the region, with strong repercussions on the smooth conduct of relations between Russia and the EU.  Media monitoring and intimidation of journalists are a source of tension, as is the gradual strengthening of pro-Russian propaganda and the suppression of dissent and free information. I therefore call for full light to be shed on all the murders of political opponents and activists.  On the human rights and LGBTI front, I agree with the need to commit to taking incisive measures to eradicate homophobia and discrimination in society.  I agree with the call for Russia, which is still a strategic partner for the EU, to cooperate in accordance with international law in order to relaunch international dialogue and cohesion, and I hope that Russia will be willing to restore and respect Ukraine's territorial integrity and sovereignty.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Landsbergis report because it is crucial we send out a strong, yet realistic, message to the Russian Government. The door must remain open for dialogue, but our red lines should be firm and clear: no return to business as usual unless the Minsk Agreements are implemented, the territorial integrity of Ukraine is restored and the OSCE-based security order in Europe is respected. I call upon the European Commission and High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini to work on these particular lines.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. The report put to the vote is a case of school in terms of bias and Manichaeism. It is a presentation of the situation solely dependent on Russia, which, far from improving relations between the European Union and the Russian Federation, leaves the latter with only two choices: submission to The Europeanist dogma, both legally and ideologically, or isolation. Far from the spirit of interference and moralization that dominates the text, attributing to Russia all the evils in respect of human rights, civil liberties, public morality, international trade and geopolitics, we reaffirm our opposition to a stigmatization of Russia. This text merely follows the direction of a move that Washington wants. European nations must not be held hostage to a potential cold war that people have not called for. Patriotic MPs will therefore vote against this peremptory, threatening, subservient and oriented text.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against this report on relations between the European Union and Russia, as it does not make any critical assessments of the current EU policy. It also represents a step forward in escalating the EU-Russia conflict, enabling the development of a policy of confrontation with Russia. The report as a whole is not seeking a peaceful resolution of the conflict, but rather delves into the tension between Russia and the EU. Those of us in favour of a Europe that advocates conflict resolution through dialogue and the constant search for peace cannot accept this report.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the state of EU-Russia relations because I believe that EU-Russia relations will not improve unless they are built on mutual trust and truth. For many years, the European Union called Russia a strategic partner. It is good that the European Parliament finally breaks with the illusion of a strategic partnership and acknowledges that it is impossible in a situation where Russia is violating Ukraine's independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity by violating the fundamental principles of the international order.  I also supported the Landsbergis report because it contained a provision calling for the surrender of black boxes and the wreckage of the TU154M aircraft, which was boarded by the Polish elite headed by President Lech Kaczynski. But I regret that once again the European Parliament resolution will not call for an international investigation, especially at the time when the German Public Prosecutor's Office opened a preliminary investigation into whether there was an attack in Smolensk.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with my Labour Party colleagues, voted in favour of this report to maintain a strong stance against Russia, but also to send a strong message to President Putin that active re-engagement and stepping back from isolation is the most constructive means to progress.  In the report, Labour MEPs helped secure important amendments on LGBTI rights – calling out the government for failing to address anti-LGBTI violence and anti-LGBTI legislation – and support for civil organisations in Russia.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the state of EU-Russia relations presented by Gabrielius Landsbergis, Member of the European Parliament. In adopting this report, Parliament recognised both direct and indirect russian hostilities in Ukraine. It has also been decided that these actions by Russia are a deliberate violation of the fundamental democratic principles and values that not only the European Union, but also the vast majority of the world, adhere to. For this reason, the European Union does not intend to return to its normal relations with Russia and will review them in the near future in order to combat the Kremlin's aggressive and divisive actions against EU countries and their partners.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. "We Swedish Social Democrats think it is good to analyse and respond appropriately to biased Russian information that is disseminated in different EU languages, but we do not believe that the Commission should earmark money to do so independently. Projects to monitor the spread of Russian propaganda inside and outside the EU are something we think the Commission should instead design in cooperation with the national authorities of the Member States. That is why we chose not to support all the wordings in paragraph 12 of the report.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the state of EU-Russia relations. This resolution does not shy away from hard statements. In particular, it renews the call for the development of strengthened analytical and monitoring capabilities of Russian propaganda – particularly in the Russian language. This means we will be in a position to respond swiftly and appropriately to any deliberately biased information that is being disseminated in different EU languages. We also call on the Commission and Member States to devise a coordinated mechanism for transparency in regard to financial, political or technical assistance provided by Russia to political parties and other organisations within the EU.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe it is important that the Parliament maintain a strong position on EU-Russia relations as the Ukraine crisis unfolds. The EU’s approach to Russia’s actions in Ukraine needs to be further developed in order to prevent further violation of democratic principles and to bring peace to Ukraine.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Landsbergis report because I believe that relations between the Union and Russia have not been as bad as in the last few months. Although they have not been formally broken, the actions taken by the Russian side make it difficult to talk about any cooperation or dialogue. As Mr Landsbergis rightly pointed out in his report, the resumption of cooperation should be considered, but certain conditions must be met at the outset. First of all, Russia must respect the inviolability of Ukraine's borders and implement the Minsk agreements. I consider this to be a prerequisite for starting the reconstruction of relations with each other. However, while the Union should set its expectations firmly, let us remember that the long-term objective should be to have a stable partner in Russia that respects democratic norms, law and international agreements. We share many common interests with Russia and good cooperation can have mutual benefits in the areas of economy, environment or global security.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ Russia will always be a hugely important country for the EU, and we must strive for a constructive relationship which will be beneficial to all our citizens. Nevertheless, we must not shy away from highlighting illegal and dangerous behaviour on the part of the Russian State. I was able to support this report.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted against this report on relations between the European Union and Russia, as it does not make any critical assessments of the current EU policy. It also represents a step forward in escalating the EU-Russia conflict, enabling the development of a policy of confrontation with Russia. The report as a whole is not seeking a peaceful resolution of the conflict, but rather delves into the tension between Russia and the EU. Those of us in favour of a Europe that advocates conflict resolution through dialogue and the constant search for peace cannot accept this report.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament resolution on the state of relations between the EU and Russia, as I agree with the fact that on many issues the situation in Russia deviates from the values that are important to us, that we represent and on which the European Union is based. Among other things, following the events in Ukraine and the annexation of Crimea that is contrary to international law, the EU and Russia definitely find themselves in opposing positions. It is in my opinion that the issue of developments in Ukraine is crucial for future possibly better EU-Russia relations, which I believe are necessary for both sides.  In this sense, it is important how the building of democratic institutions and respect for democratic values in Ukraine will develop further. What I have repeatedly talked about is that Ukraine has the opportunity precisely by decentralization and respect above all the rights of minorities to positively influence the unraveling of the whole situation.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I have decided to vote against this report, which provides an overview of relations between the European Union and Russia, in which the essential motivation is ideological in the service of a very worrying Russophobia. The Russian Federation is accused of all evils: of having started the war with Georgia, while Tbilisi's responsibility had been put forward by the independent international commission; or having "illegally annexed Crimea", while the democratically elected government of Crimea had requested its affiliation with the Russian Federation. In addition, the rapporteur states that Russia "can no longer be treated or seen as a strategic partner". This is a serious political fault: to see the advent of a multipolar world, in which France and Europe would not be subject to any great foreign power, it is necessary, on the contrary, to make Russia one of our preferred partners. Finally, this report departs from its original objective and subject by calling on Member States to continue and intensify their efforts to eliminate the decision-making deadlocks that still persist.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I abstained on the report by my colleague Gabrielus Landsbergis on the state of eu-Russia relations. This report notes the deterioration of relations between the European Union and Russia, but unfortunately does not propose viable solutions for a peaceful exit from the crisis. The text is indeed unnecessarily aggressive and proposes measures that would only increase the already very high tension between the Union and the Russian Federation. It would also close the door to any dialogue between the two sides by no longer considering Russia as a strategic ally of the Union, whose cooperation is vital for the peaceful settlement of the situation in Iran or the Middle East, for example.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Strained political relations with the Russian Federation are the result of the Kremlin's aggressive actions, completely ignoring the principles of law, trade and diplomacy. The involvement in the conflict in Ukraine and the annexation of Crimea, like an unjustified embargo on EU products, the ban on the entry into its territory of European politicians, including Members of the European Parliament, show how hostile Russia is to the West. In response, the European Union imposed economic sanctions on Russia, introduced individual visa restrictions and cancelled international meetings with Russia. All sanctions will be lifted if Russia keeps its promises made in the Minsk agreements in September 2014 and February 2015. The best path we can take now is constructive dialogue, countering propaganda and promoting democracy in both Ukraine and Russia. Supporting those who want change for the better. Russia must learn to respect the law – both international law and human rights. However, any action taken to improve the situation requires increased coordination at diplomatic level, unification of the common position and solidarity among the Member States. We cannot speak with many voices and make agreements behind the backs of others. Let us not let Russia destabilise Europe!

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This is an unbalanced, unjust and provocative resolution, which will certainly not help to calm the situation, which is unsatisfactory for all parties. It is time for the EU to seek dialogue and approach Russia with a healthy degree of willingness to compromise. Under no circumstances should the already tense situation escalate. I therefore reject the report.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I voted in favour of the report on EU-Russia relations. The current geopolitical situation in the world, and especially in our eastern neighbour, Ukraine, poses a security threat to the entire EU. Following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea, sanctions were introduced to stop and curb the aggressor activities in the EU's neighbour. Europe waited with tension and hoped that the Minsk agreement reached in February would be respected and that any hostilities in Ukraine would be stopped. It is clear that Russia does not respect this agreement and maintains tensions in EU-Russia relations. I voted in favour of this report because Russia must respect international law and fully implement the Minsk agreements so that the EU is ready to re-establish a dialogue of common interest with Moscow. This report also stresses that cooperation could be restored if Russia respected the sovereignty of Ukraine, including Crimea. The EU must be clearly aware of the current state of EU-Russia relations and make it clear to the Russian Government that it will not allow further attempts by Russia to change Europe's borders by force.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report. Despite recent worrying developments, we stress the importance of a long-term perspective for re-engagement and cooperation with Russia, on the condition that Russia fully implement the Minsk Agreement and respect the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine. Europe needs to stay firm and united, and we cannot compromise on our core values of respect for human rights and democracy.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – Normally, problems in international relations are settled by means of diplomacy and through negotiations. Those who, unlike those who touch sanctions differently, should not be surprised if the answer will be similar. I am convinced that it is not in the interests of European citizens to further escalate tensions, which have already caused enormous economic damage, and therefore the report cannot be accepted. Europe cannot be a server for the policies of the US or other countries, but must go its own way.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. \u2012 Supporting the report, I would like to recall that the restrictive measures imposed are not against the Russian people, but against the undemocratic model of government. In this regard, I believe it is necessary for the Commission and the Council to develop appropriate tools for strategic communication and to work towards promoting a genuine and independent civil society in Russia. We need to promote cooperation between students and researchers in order to improve mutual understanding. Last but not least, I call on the Commission and the Council to take immediate action against european populist, fascist and xenophobic parties funded from outside, aimed at undermining democratic values and the rule of law in the EU.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Thanks to this report, the European Parliament has reaffirmed Russia's direct and indirect involvement in the armed conflict in Ukraine, the violation of Georgia's territorial integrity and a policy of political destabilisation and economic coercion of neighbouring states. We must strongly condemn possible violations of human rights and the rule of law, while rewarding dialogue and cooperation between the European Union and Russia, so that the international democratic order can be fully restored.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Landsbergis report to provide an overview of relations between the European Union and Russia By adopting this report, we called on the European Union and Member States to critically reassess its relations with Russia, in view of the violent military action it is orchestrating in eastern Ukraine and its recent annexation of Crimea. , in total violation of international law.  The report also condemns The "black list" put in place by Russia, which arbitrarily denied 89 European politicians and officials access to its territory.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. The report on relations with Russia adopts a line of confrontation that only reinforces the mistrust between two groups obliged to agree. By taking the side of a confrontation, by re-entering into Russian provocations, we are playing the game of the harshest tendencies of the Russian power by legitimized its manufactured vision of power besieged by a hostile West. Getting out of these provocations requires an intelligent response, not an escalation. That is why, while I strongly condemn the bans on European Members and diplomats from accessing Russian territory, I do not support similar retaliatory measures that fuel the nationalist rhetoric of the Russian government. Nor do I support the rewriting of history observed in Russia during the Stalinist period, nor those put forward here to encompass Nazism and Communism in a totalitarian whole. On the contrary, I support the dialogue and the maintenance of existing cooperation, which is the means of maintaining channels of discussion at a time when political powers are fighting. Without naivety, especially with regard to attempts to influence Russian political parties in Europe, nor the spirit of confrontation.  That is why I voted against this text.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it is far too aggressive towards Russia. He says it is "no longer a strategic partner" of the European Union and accuses it of creating a climate of hatred in Europe. It also demands that it return Crimea to Ukraine in defiance of the right of peoples to self-determination. Finally, he wants to finance anti-Russian propaganda and raise the lead in European public opinion against Russia. This is an ignominious and irresponsible report which reveals that the majority of the European Parliament has become a party to the war. At the risk of being called once again a "sold" parliamentarian to the Russians, I hope that European leaders will regain their composure, to tear themselves away from the grip of the United States, and to find the way to a firm but fair negotiation with Russia.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted against it. Another report hostile to Russia, seen as a dangerous adversary and presented as responsible for political instability in Eastern Europe. In particular, the country is accused of being responsible for the conflict with Georgia, although a report by the independent international commission proved otherwise. The same is true of the annexation of Crimea, which is described in this report as annexation, despite public consultation. Thus, Russia is now described as a country that can no longer be treated as a "strategic partner". Always quick to deny Member States diplomatic autonomy, the European Union calls on them to preserve European unity. In fact, Member States are therefore prohibited from following the Union's position. This is what is clearly written in this text, in a federalist project since these states are asked to "definitely eliminate decision-making blockages and to work ... to strengthen common policies, particularly in the areas of trade, services and financial transactions, migration, energy, external border management, information and cyber security."

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The report sets out clear conditions for the full resumption of cooperation with Russia, such as the implementation of the Minsk Agreements, respect for the security order based on OSCE indications and principles in Europe and full respect for Ukraine's territorial integrity, including Crimea. Russia is an important EU neighbour; there are interests in practical cooperation and in jointly addressing shared global challenges, such as jihadist terrorism, Iran's nuclear program, destabilization in the Middle East and non-proliferation. A reference to the protection of lgbtI rights has also been included. In accordance with these considerations, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. Russia is the main neighbour of the European Union, one of its main trading partners – especially in terms of energy needs – and a country with which all the countries of the European Union have closely shared a part of history. That is why I believe that relations between the EU and Russia must be treated with the utmost care and great responsibility. In the text put to the vote, however, I have encountered a disproportionate vocabulary riddled with condemnation. But above all, there is a double standard that is difficult to digest by anyone who has briefly known the history of Europe in the last twenty-five years. I voted against this report because, according to the approved text, Russia should no longer be a strategic partner for the European Union, which is particularly worrying given the common interests that exist.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the European Parliament resolution on the state of EU-Russia relations. Eu-Russia political relations are currently strained due to Russia's disturbing actions, which are contrary to international law. Nevertheless, I believe that we must nevertheless focus on revitalise the EU-Russia dialogue, seek further peaceful, diplomatic and common solutions to the problems and rebuild our relations. We are all aware that the rulers are over and the nations remain. Our actions will now have an impact on people-to-people relationships in the future. Therefore, on the one hand, we must protect our values, demand respect for human rights and international law, but on the other hand, our message should leave no doubt that the Union wants to engage in dialogue and rebuild cooperation with Russia.  I fully agree with the rapporteur that people-to-people contacts should be strengthened m.in. through Erasmus+.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support this report. The geopolitical context in Ukraine should be the best incentive for Europe to unite and respond robustly to the Russian Federation’s illegal aggression. Let us show them what history has taught us! If we divide we will falter, but if we stand together we will thrive. The illegal annexation of Crimea and the destabilisation of Ukraine is firstly a huge threat to Romania’s security and secondly to the EU. That is why we have to be prepared to use all the legislative instruments laid down in the Lisbon Treaty, such as the solidarity clause and the mutual defence clause. I fully support the idea in the report that the current crisis should not be left entirely to NATO to deal with. The EU has the necessary tools to properly manage this crisis. We have postponed our common security defence plan for more than 50 years after the failure of the European Defence Community. It is now the time to step forward. The EU belongs to its citizens, and we have to be responsible and ensure them peace and security.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Russia is one of the leading powers in the world and it is understandable that the European Union strives for a strategic partnership with it in economic and energy terms, but also because of the struggle with global challenges. However, this cannot happen while Russia is violating international agreements.  In Ukraine, armed conflicts continue, the Minsk agreements have not been respected, the number of casualties has passed 6,200. President Vladimir Putin credited the illegal annexation of Crimea as his merit. Ukraine is not the only neighborhood state where Russia applies hybrid warfare. Although these countries are not members of the European Union, they are in our neighbourhood and we are concerned that conflicts destabilise them, block their development and undermine fundamental human freedoms. I support mp Landsbergis' report urging Russia to respect international rights and agreements, democratic principles and fundamental values. Since Russia systematically and continuously violates all of the above, including the sovereignty of other states and their borders, it cannot be considered a partner. The European Union must create a permanent foreign and security policy and show a strong attitude of condemnation towards Russia.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has always viewed the Russian Federation as a strategic partner and has sought constructive dialogue in its relations with it over the years. However, we cannot consider a partner state that violates democratic principles, international law, freedom of speech, which has called into question the fundamental principles of security in Europe and has reached out to a sovereign and independent state. The toughness of sanctions, as well as the EU's efforts to strengthen the independence of its gas supplies from Russia, are a clear sign that Europe is clearly changing the direction of its relations with the Russian Federation. As a representative of Bulgaria, where Russia's propaganda and attempts at political and economic influence are so strong, I strongly support the sharp tone and hardening of the EU's position towards the Kremlin. With its actions in recent months, with its refusal to comply with the Minsk agreements, with the use of jet fighters near the airspace of THE MEMBER STATES AND THE EU, Russia has closed its own doors to partnership with Europe. I supported the resolution on the state of EU-Russia relations because it provides strong evidence that we will not back down from our principles and values.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. U2012 The report, horrible; the rapporteur, horrible. Nothing to add. I voted against this report.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing \ u2012 Relations between the European Union and the Russian Federation are going through the most difficult period. They are influenced by a complex geopolitical situation, which ultimately affects and harms the economy and economic interests on both sides. This unfavourable situation affects not only the Russian Federation and its people, but also individual Member States and the EU.  We need to look for what unites us and work together to remove barriers. The current complicated state of eu-Russia relations requires intensifying diplomatic activity, increasing communication and strengthening mutual objective information. The mere use of economic sanctions without rational communication will hardly reverse the status quo.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the state of EU-Russia relations, because this report promotes the revival of a cold war climate in Europe that does not contribute to the consolidation of peace.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report. This state of affairs consists in fact of a long litany of criticism of Russia, accused of all evils. It is accused of creating a climate of tension and of having drawn up an arbitrary and reprehensible blacklist: what about the sanctions foreseen by the Union against Russia a year ago? The text, in turn, announces that Russia is no longer a strategic partner of the European Union, then acknowledges that sectoral cooperation is possible, and finally conditions our relations to the fact that Russia "returns" Crimea to Ukraine, ignoring the right of the peoples to decide for themselves (remember that the people of Crimea voted to join Russia). The EU defends democracy only when it goes its way and serves its interests. This resolution as a whole is a farce, a clever mixture of anti-Russian propaganda, bad faith and a call to arms, which we reject.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report to maintain a strong stance against Russia, but also to send a strong message to President Putin that active re-engagemnet and not isolation is the most constructive means to progress.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The progress report on EU-Russia relations covers a number of issues that are currently rather sensitive and complex. On the one hand, relations with a world power which are strained and restricted by embargoes and various sanctions with a number of situations to be resolved, and on the other, a long relationship and a closeness to certain trade issues that deserve to be dealt with. Putting these two realities together, I considered abstention to be the most balanced and appropriate choice.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report assessing the current relations between the EU and Russia. I could not support the report in any way because, in my opinion, it is completely biased and unbalanced. He blames Russia for all sorts of sins imaginable. Constant recriminations and recriminations are tactics that will do no good. As well as the unilateral decision by THE PRESIDENT OF THE EP, M. Schulz, to suspend the activities of the delegation for cooperation between the representatives of the European Parliament and the Russian State Duma. At the same time, who better to advocate dialogue than Parliament? The situation is unsustainable. As Europe continues to crush, the US benefits from trade with Russia, as not only the numbers prove. An absolute communication deficit is not the solution. Personally, I would like to agree with the statement of Jens Stoltenberg, who said: "Our aim is cooperation with Russia. It is in the interest of NATO, and in the interest of the Russian Federation."

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am of the opinion that relations between the European Union and Russia, compromised by recent events, would benefit from a proactive, forward-looking approach. That is why I have chosen to abstain from voting on this report which, in my opinion, proposes a nihilistic and closing strategy.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. I did not vote in favour of this Report, which considers 'that Russia, contrary to the spirit of good neighbourly relations and in violation of law, rules and international standards, has deliberately taken action to destabilise its neighbouring countries through illegal trade embargoes or the conclusion of treaties (...)', which may describe Russia's action, but also describes exactly what the European Union has been doing , through sanctions, political, economic or military pressures in various parts of the world, especially in the region in the vicinity of the EU and Russia. Between EU international politics and Russia's international politics there are many rivalries not because they are very different, but precisely because they are very similar and rival for the dominance of the same geographical space, where they use their influence in rival groups that fight politically and militarily on the ground, brandishing the Russian and EU flags, without any respect for the interests of the peoples development and peace in the region. My firm disregard for EU foreign policy does not imply any sympathy or support for its rivals who do not respect fundamental human rights.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing.
