THE EU's relations with Russia have been dotted with difficulties in the latter stage, which have become even more complicated by the unfortunate "blacklist" that Russia recently published to ban the entry into the country of 89 eu politicians and senior officials. I support the report we have adopted in the European Parliament, giving full support to the colleagues and people on the list, and showing our concern about Russia's attitude, which does not favour dialogue. In the European Parliament we are concerned about this situation and that is why we are calling for a critical re-evaluation of relations with Russia from the EU and a plan to counter the aggressive and divisive policies of the Russian Government.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I refused to support the motion for a resolution because I do not believe that the proposals in the report would improve the relationship between the EU and Russia.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The European Parliament is clearly taking part here to continue the escalation of tensions between Russia, Ukraine and the European Union. He called for new sanctions against Russia. The "restitution of Crimea" and compliance with the Minsk agreements is the precondition before we can consider cooperation with Moscow while acknowledging the many common international challenges that the two sides should pursue together. Ignoring the provocations of the far-right government in Ukraine, the report turns its back on the conciliatory role that the Union should play. Russia "acts in defiance of the international democratic community" which would require the "strengthening of cooperation between the Union and NATO" a well-known ally of peace, etc.  The rest is only double standards. He denounces "the illegitimate use of energy as a means of political and diplomatic pressure" when this is exactly what Parliament advocates against Russia in its report on energy strategy. It calls for strengthening the Eastern partnership with countries that are not 'liberal democracies', which is no longer a problem for the rapporteur.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. In this report, the Russian Federation is accused of all evils: of having started the war with Georgia, while Tbilisi's responsibility had been put forward by the independent international commission, or of having "illegally annexed Crimea", while the democratically elected government of Crimea had requested its affiliation with the Russian Federation. In addition, the rapporteur states that Russia "can no longer be treated or seen as a strategic partner". This is a serious political fault: to see the advent of a multipolar world, in which France and Europe would not be subject to any great foreign power, it is necessary, on the contrary, to make Russia one of our preferred partners. Finally, this report departs from its original objective and subject by calling on Member States to continue and intensify their efforts to eliminate the decision-making deadlocks that still persist. I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the state of relations between the European Union and Russia. Russia, with its action in Crimea and eastern Ukraine, can hardly be considered a 'strategic partner'. Strategic partnerships should be based on mutual trust and respect for international law, which recognises democracy, state sovereignty, territorial integrity, respect for the rule of law and human rights.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ This report takes note of the fact that it is of mutual benefit to the Union and Russia to work towards rebuilding a constructive relationship based on existing international agreements. It is crucial that both parties come together to tackle common concerns on the international stage. The report also highlights the importance of respecting the Minsk Agreement. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – In the report on EU-Russia relations, which no longer has the status of a privileged strategic partner due to its actions in Crimea, Parliament rightly expressed its outrage at the increasing extent to which political activists, opposition politicians and human rights defenders are systematically intimidated and persecuted by the Russian authorities. In the report, the EP also expressed its displeasure with the arbitrary measure by Russia to ban European politicians and civil servants from accessing Russia. Parliament has also instructed the Commission to examine the external financing of European political parties, for example from Russia, and to take appropriate action. It is worrying that Russia is increasingly acting as a challenger to the international democratic community and its rule of law. Nevertheless, the European Parliament continues to work for a constructive cooperation relationship with Russia, provided, however, that the Russian authorities guarantee international law, universal values and the right to freedom of expression and that they respect the territorial sovereignty of Ukraine, including Crimea.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing ‒ Since the beginning of the conflict in Ukraine, the positions of the Russian Federation and the European Union differ and even contradict each other, as Russia is suspected of being directly or indirectly involved in the unrest in eastern Ukraine, the annexation of the Crimean Peninsula and undermining the sovereignty of independent states that were formerly part of the Soviet Union. Such behaviour destabilises the EU's neighbouring countries and contradicts international law because it threatens peace between independent countries.  At present, therefore, the EU cannot treat the Russian side as a credible partner, as it is acting contrary to democratic principles. Russia has even recently been acting as a challenger against the democratic regime and the rule of law. It is therefore necessary to properly reassess relations with the Russian Federation, which is moving away from the values held by the EU. The rectifying and restoration of strategic relations is possible if the Russian side respects the Minsk agreements, stops tearing up Ukraine's internal infrastructure and accepts the autonomy and sovereignty of that state.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the state of EU-Russia relations. I believe in constructive relations with Russia as one of the EU’s most important neighbours, but I expect Russia to do its part to make this possible: first and foremost, by fully implementing the Minsk agreements to stop the conflict in Ukraine.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 As the report points out, the EU and Russia are interdependence in the long term in order to jointly face and respond to global challenges. At the same time, Russia today, as a result of President Putin's woefully changed policy, has not only deviated from the path of increasing freedom at home, strengthening democracy, respecting the principles of human rights and the rule of law, but also threatening these fundamental European values abroad by using its aggressive foreign policy, using the trade in raw materials and energy as a means of political pressure, and sometimes provoking armed conflicts. Moreover, Russia finds collaborators with this policy from certain governments and political forces in the Member States, and there are reasonable suspicions that it does not finance such a political force itself. I am convinced that the EU cannot stand by and do so, and in many respects the wording in the report seems to be an a good response to this policy.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. Over the past few decades, the European Union has been working to build a strategic partnership with Russia based on shared values and principles such as democracy and the rule of law. However, the recent positions adopted by Russia require the European Union to take a position. I am voting in favour of this report, which strongly condemns the illegal annexation of Crimea, Russia's support for Ukrainian separatists and the recent ban on several European politicians entering Russia. I therefore support the maintenance or strengthening of European sanctions on Russia at the next European Council in June. I believe that the normal relationship between the European Union and Russia can only happen when the Russian authorities leave Ukrainian territory and respect the rule of human rights and territorial freedom.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it sends a powerful message to Mr Putin to step back from isolation and re-engage. In the report, Labour MEPs helped secure important amendments on LGBTI rights – calling out the government for failing to address anti-LGBTI violence and anti— LGBTI legislation – and support for civil organisations in Russia.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. The report on relations between the European Union and Russia contains unnecessarily harsh and offensive language towards Russia, which contributes to the escalation of reciprocal sanctions. I believe that only respectful and peaceful dialogue will lead to political solutions to the Ukrainian crisis. This type of report only contributes to the inflaming of relations between the EU and Russia, which is why I abstained in the vote.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on relations between the European Union and Russia. With the annexation of Crimea and the aggression of Ukraine, Russia is violating the principles of democracy, the rule of law and international law. The European Union cannot therefore envisage the resumption of relations with Russia in its normal course. The European Parliament, through this report, expresses its concerns and reaffirms the necessary unity of the Member States. However, constructive and predictable relations between the EU and Russia are possible for the good of both sides, provided that Russia respects the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine, including Crimea, that it fully implements the Minsk agreements and that it puts an end to destabilizing military and security activities at the borders of the European Union.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report is yet another example of the prevailing Russophobia. In accordance with the Brzeziski doctrine, Russia is presented as the absolute evil that the European Union must fight with all its might. The report blames Russia for the full responsibility for the Georgian war, even though the international commission on the subject, led by H. Tagliavini, concluded in 2009 that the Georgian authorities bore responsibility for it. This report also criticises the enhanced cooperation between Russia and Georgia, but also the annexation of Crimea to Russia, described as an "illegal annexation", even though the Crimeans have decided to do so sovereignly, and that a recent poll organised by one of the most important German institutes showed that 93% of the inhabitants of Crimea supported this attachment. The rapporteur concludes that Russia can no longer be considered a strategic partner. the EU with Russia have put a drop in exports on our producers, and at the same time, US exports to Russia were increasing, the Union confirms, by its Atlanticist submission, that it is the idiot of the global village.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote expresses our deep concern at the recent tightening of relations with Russia, which has always been a strategic partner of the European Union. We hope that constructive relations will be possible and desirable in the long term for the benefit of both sides, bearing in mind that reciprocal sanctions are harmful to both economies, that common challenges and interests on the world stage must be tackled jointly and that the fragmented nature of the perception of security in Europe can only be overcome through enhanced dialogue. We therefore stress that the resumption of cooperation can be considered provided that Russia respects ukraine's territorial integrity and sovereignty and fully implements the Minsk agreements (which include full border control by the Ukrainian authorities, the unconditional withdrawal of Russian troops and armaments and the immediate suspension of the provision of assistance to rebel groups) , also putting an end to the destabilisation of military and security activities at the borders of EU Member States. We reiterate that unconditional respect for the rule of law, the protection of freedom of expression and of minorities are essential and founding principles of the European Union and we therefore call for their strict application.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour, although in many respects the Union's position is excessively harsh and is outside the diplomatic language that should be adopted in our relations with any country. Despite the tensions and fears, we must continue to engage with the Russian Federation because it can help us find the key to many conflicts around the world.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to abstain from voting on this report because I believe that the European Union cannot afford to interrupt the dialogue with Russia. Russia's isolation is bad for Europe as a whole and for the whole system of international relations. If we care about the prosperity and peace of the continent, we must step up our efforts to rebuild a relationship with that country.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The Russian Federation’s role in the Ukraine conflict has seriously affected EU-Russia relations. Consequently, some of the trading activities and agreements are at a halt and sanctions have been adopted. I have voted for this report in order to have a better view of EU—Russia activities and agreements.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I did not support the resolution on EU-Russia relations because I find calls for an extension of sanctions by 'further extending the retaliatory measures' to be unacceptable. This kind of "war of sanctions" only leads to a deepening of the crisis and an exacerbating of relations between the Union and the Russian Federation. The Europeans who suffer from these circumstances exceed hundreds of times those who are identified as victims of the crisis. These are not the units of European politicians, but the thousands of farmers from all over Europe, as well as the tourism industry in countries with traditions in this regard with Russia. Nearly a year has passed since the Russian Federation's retaliatory embargo, but there is still no clear commitment from the EU to European farmers. In a state of economic crisis in almost all of Europe, to expect these farmers to search for themselves and find alternatives to this traditional market is unacceptable. The illiberal politics of a self-regulatory market and bold measures continue to shake up the EU and make the situation worse, as well as creating difficulties for thousands of Europeans.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: i scríbhinn. ‒ Staon mé ón vóta deireanach den tuarascáil seo.  Aithníonn agus cáineann Sinn Féin na treascairtí ar chearta an duine atá a ndéanamh ag an Rúis, cosúil leis an leithcheal i gcoinne lucht LADT agus an phríosúnacht ar dhaoine atá i gcoinne réimeas Putin. Díríonn an tuarascáil seo áfach ar an ngéarchéim san Úcráin. Bhí, agus tá Sinn Féin soiléir ar ár dtuairimí maidir leis an gcoimhlint sa réigiún. Eascraíonn sé ó chluiche geopholaitiúil idir an Rúis agus an tIarthar. Chuir an choimhlint seo an Úcráin faoi bhrú seasamh a ghlacadh ar thaobh amháin nó ar an taobh eile. Ba chóir don Rúis agus AE a bheith ag obair le chéile chun caidreamh eacnamaíochta, polaitiúil agus sóisialta atá comhthairbheach a chruthú leis an Úcráin. An rud atá againn anois ná réigiún atá i ngéarchéim de bharr leasanna straitéiseacha na Rúise agus AE. Cé go n-aithníonn an tuarascáil seo an drochpháirt a d’imir an Rúis sa réigiún, déantar neamhaird iomlán den ról a d’imir AE i bhforbairt na coimhlinte. Ní dhéanann an tuarascáil maitheas don chaidreamh idir AE agus an Rúis don todhchaí. Tá gá ann do chomhphlé oscailte chun an teannas a laghdú – ní comhfhorrántacht.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, as I believe the subject is the most sensitive and important foreign affairs issue for the European Union. Relations with Russia certainly have to be preserved and enhanced, but only as long as the other side understands that all international treaties and norms, as well as the territorial integrity of Ukraine and other third countries, must be fully respected. Russia needs to re-evaluate its actions and to realise that cooperation, in this world of interdependence, is the only way forward towards mutual prosperity.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the situation in EU-Russia relations because, in my opinion, it is necessary to send a clear signal to Russia that the EU will not come to terms with its aggressive and expansionary policy and will not stop insisting on the demands of returning Crimea to Ukraine and respecting the Minsk agreements. The report also confirms the EU's strong position on sanctions. In the event of russia's unchanged behaviour, the EU should be prepared not only to extend existing sanctions, but also to tighten them up. The EU should also urgently agree on a communication strategy that will effectively counter Russian propaganda. A completely purposeful effort to distort history not only insociates me personally, but is also very dangerous. We must not let the shameless lying about the past and the distortion of historical facts that we witnessed on the Russian state-controlled television programme about the events of August 21, 1968, be liked. I appreciate that the report also addressed this issue and did not neglect the issue of financing certain political entities from sources linked to Russia.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted against this report because the state of play of EU-Russia relations is presented in a completely unbalanced and unobjective way. In my opinion, the resolution certainly does not serve to improve the relationship between the European Union and Russia.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This highly offensive report aims to take stock of The Russo-European relations, but contains many questionable elements. Thus the report accuses Russia of unilaterally damaging its relations with the Union, of fostering many frozen conflicts in its neighbourhood, of interfering in the affairs of sovereign countries with Russian minorities and of questioning the international order based on the rule of law. The report also proclaims that Russia is no longer a strategic partner for the Union, and calls for the freezing or reduction of cooperation programmes between the European Union and Russia. I voted against this report because I cannot endorse the positioning of the two major players on our continent as rivals and the resumption of a cold war climate, when we would have everything to gain as partners, on the basis of rules of law and good understanding.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. I supported the proposal. The aim of the document is to map the state of EU-Russia relations and to address current problems. EU-Russia relations would have great potential to return to normal if Russia were to accept the right of its neighbours to determine its own future and would in practice contribute to the resolution of frozen conflicts. The premise of this is that Russia will no longer see the West and Europe as an enemy and a security risk. Russia's behaviour involving deprivation of liberty from specific people, including the case of Estonian police officer Eston Kohveri, is very disturbing. As long as Russia does not value humanity, it is also very difficult to expect an intrinsic change in relations between the EU and Russia.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – Categorisation is not the strongest expression of diplomacy. In such a geopolitical situation, issues need to be dealt with through peaceful negotiations and diplomatic means. I think the escalation, the attempt to shove each other into a corner, does nothing good. You need to look for other options, different languages, different formats. The history of the world shows that there were also more complex situations and they were resolved. EU-Russia relations must be based on respect for international law and based on dialogue. A long-term, constructive relationship should be established with mutual benefit. It should be noted that cooperation cannot be developed by mentioning international principles, European values, norms and international obligations. For peace and democracy, the provisions of the Minsk Agreement, as well as other international agreements, must therefore be respected without reservation. First of all, the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine must be respected. Cooperation may only be resumed after the full implementation of the Minsk agreements.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. \u2012 While firmly reiterating that Russia's policy towards Ukraine cannot be separated from respect for Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity, I recognise that at the same time it is necessary to reassure Russia on an important point: Ukraine's accession to NATO is not a realistic hypothesis. I believe that a balanced policy by Ukraine towards the West and at the same time towards Russia is indispensable and beneficial to both sides. I have chosen to abstain from voting on this resolution because I believe that this document does not take adequate account of the delicate balance achieved within the framework of the Minsk II agreements. For the time being, showing the political will to start negotiations is the only right recipe for resolving the crisis. In order to avoid further tensions, official channels for an inclusive dialogue with Moscow must be kept open. EU and NATO enlargement eastwards is seen by Russia as a direct threat to its security and it is the duty of Western countries to understand and share Russian sensitivity on this point. Russia is a strategic partner and a relaxed and clear relationship is essential for the EU that allows the necessary cooperation in many areas with this great power.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. – The report calls for an escalation by all means, military, political, economic- of the EU's aggression towards capitalist Russia, focusing on their conflict following the imperialist EU-US-NATO intervention in Ukraine, but also on overall control of energy resources and their transport routes in greater Eurasia. It calls for a new extension of the time and scope of sanctions and greater pressure on Russia to consolidate the positions of the Euro-Atlantic axis in the region.  Despite calls by the representatives of the chapter for a unified EU attitude towards Russian capitalism, the report cannot hide the serious contradictions within the EU, between its Member States, due to the different interests of the business groups they represent, depending on the relations they maintain with Russian monopolies, but also the orientations of their international alliances. The EU-Russia conflict is solely about the interests of monopolies on both sides, and is expensively paid for by the people with their blood and the deterioration of their lives by economic measures and countermeasures.  The solution lies in the hands of the peoples, the popular struggle, to change the power relations, against monopolies, to disengage from imperialist associations and to form mutually beneficial relations between states and peoples.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Russia is a key partner for Europe without which it is not possible to build an area of security and prosperity. At the same time, recent events in Ukraine, not forgetting the 2008 military aggression against Georgia, together with recent laws restricting press freedom and LGBT rights, are putting a strain on EU-Russia relations. In recent years, Moscow has sought to create some political support within the Eu ropean Union by funding far-right parties such as the Front National in France and Jobbik in Hungary. I voted in favour because Mr Landsbergis' report expresses a balanced view of the actions that the EU and the Member States are invited to take in EU-Russia relations.

name: Vincent PEILLON
text: In writing. The text voted today provides a realistic picture of the current situation in relations between the European Union and Russia. The work of the group's rapporteur, Liisa Jaakonsaari, has helped to rebalance the text of the EPP rapporteur. In its initial drafting, it set unrealistic conditions for the resumption of cooperation between the EU and Russia, such as the return of Crimea to Ukraine. The resolution adopted takes a more open approach and better reflects the position of the Socialists and Democrats: if we need to be firm with the Russian government, to be intransigent on democratic principles and not to give in to intimidation, we must also give way to dialogue. Only a constructive approach will allow us to resolve the crisis in Ukraine. The European Union must be patient: the resumption of full cooperation with Russia will take time, and the settlement of the dispute in Crimea, perhaps even more so. During this period, we must maintain our unity and maintain dialogue.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. I am absolutely convinced of the following: that pursuing a strategic partnership based on common values and principles between the European Union and Russia was the right intention; that war is the worst possible way of regulating inter-state co-siding issues in Ukraine, as well as relations between Russia and Ukraine; that war violence on European soil is a tragic paradox that is at odds with political developments since the fall of the Berlin Wall and is a threat to peaceful development in the region; that no country wishing to share European values and principles voluntarily with the European Union is a threat to any other country and that, without respect for the rules of international law and agreement, no progress can be made in mutual trust without which there can be no partnership.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. The Russian invasion of Ukraine in 2014 constitutes a clear violation of international law such as the UN Charter, the Paris Charter, the Helsinki Final Document, the Budapest Memorandum in 1994. The practice of human rights violations with widespread corruption is the daily routine of this space.  The Russian leadership uses controlled state and other domestic media to drum up public support for its actions, as well as to undermine any opposition. Russia's actions are internationally unacceptable and the EU must respond to instability in the region. Ukraine needs to ensure its independence and peace for its citizens and it must be released from the firm embrace of the Russian government. Also, the EU and its member states must work to reduce energy dependency on Russian energy.  I also believe that at the moment it is necessary to seek to improve rather than destroy very poor relations between the EU and Russia. Dialogue and a clear expression of the EU's position that the other side needs to hear is needed. EU procedures should also be measured to show Russia the right path. This does not preclude the strengthening of sanctions or other necessary actions that need to be transparent, with a clear intention and a clear objective. As a result, I do not support the actions of European Parliament President Martin Schulz and his response to the Russian blacklist, which I consider unfair.  Returning in kind will not bring us closer or lead to a shift.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. In accordance with the Brzeziski doctrine, Russia is presented in this report as the absolute evil that the Union must fight with all its might. The text attributes full responsibility for the Georgian war to Russia, even though the international commission on the subject, led by H. Tagliavini, concluded in 2009 that the Georgian authorities bore this responsibility. The report also criticises the enhanced cooperation between Russia and Georgia, but also the annexation of Crimea to Russia, described as an "illegal annexation", while the Crimeans have decided sovereignly, and that a recent poll conducted by one of the most important German institutes showed that 93% of the inhabitants of Crimea supported this connection. It is incomprehensible that the European Union did not want to get involved so that the referendum would take place in the best possible conditions. The rapporteur then concludes that Russia can no longer be seen as a strategic partner. While EU sanctions against Russia have caused our producers to reduce exports, and at the same time US exports to Russia are increasing, the European Union confirms, through its Atlanticist submission, that it is the idiot of the global village. So I voted against this report.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I am glad that the European Parliament has adopted a strong resolution towards Russia, especially just days after Russia banned MEMBERS of the European Parliament who had criticised it in the past for its foreign policy and its non-respect for human rights. Russia has ceased to be a credible partner for the EU through the annexation of Crimea and subsequent non-compliance with the Minsk agreements, which of course does not mean that we are leaving the negotiating table. However, we must make it clear that the EU will not back down from its fundamental values, which undoubtedly include peace and democracy. Russia has shown that peace and democracy are concepts for it that it is always willing to relativize if it stands in the way of pursuing power interests. I believe that the European Union's intransigence on fundamental issues, the continuation of sanctions that are not very short-term, but all the more intense long-term impact and the fight against Russian propaganda will lead to a change in attitude on the part of Russia, which is a necessity for restoring peace in Europe and restoring confidence in the strategic partnership.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 In the last period, and I regret this, we have seen a growing tension in relations between the EU and Russia. I recognise that there have been actions taken by Russia which have not respected international law and created difficulties for the people and damaged the economy. Despite what has happened, I have chosen to abstain on the resolution because I believe that we must have a long-term vision and have as our objective a constructive relationship between the EU and Russia, in the interests of both of us and with a view to working together on global challenges such as climate change, the Middle East peace process, the fight against terrorism and organised crime and cooperation on new technological developments. Furthermore, the current sanctions are harmful to both economies, and existing relations, which are fragmented, both weaken on the world stage.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. In the face of Russia's occupation of Crimea and Russia's deliberate violations of international agreements, the European Union must seriously and quickly reassess its strategy towards Crimea. It is this message that we wished to convey to the European Commission by adopting the report on the state of affairs between the Union and Russia.  I voted for this report and believe that it is important to condemn Russia for its recent actions, including the publication of a blacklist of European politicians. Member States must unite to build a common and coherent response to Russia. However, it is also important to encourage a policy of openness with Russia so as not to sever any link with this power. In the short term, parliamentarians stress the need for an emergency plan to respond to Russia's attacks, but in the long run they advocate a constructive relationship.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. Russia's involvement in the armed conflict in Ukraine and the illegal annexation of Crimea, as well as the violation of Georgia's territorial integrity and the economic coertion and political destabilisation of its European neighbours, constitute a deliberate violation of democratic principles, fundamental values and international law. Equally worrying is the deterioration of the rule of law, human rights, political rights and civil liberties that has been seen in Russia in recent years, as well as the arbitrary measure adopted by the authorities to prohibit access for EU politicians and officials to Russian territory. In this context, the EU cannot, of course, fail to make a critical reassessment of its relations with Russia.  In the long run, it would naturally be important for the EU and Russia to be able to establish a constructive relationship, but the relaunch of this cooperation could only be considered in a context of dialogue and full respect for international law, implying Russia's respect for Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity, the full implementation of the Minsk agreements and the end of all destabilising activities at the borders of the Member States.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. At noon, Parliament reiterated its deep concern with Russia. And for good reason, The Russian leadership continues to violate international law and flout international norms: illegal annexation of Crimea, violation of Georgia's territorial integrity, measures of economic coercion or political destabilization against its neighbours, etc. When it comes to respecting democracy and fundamental freedoms, the bulletin is hardly brighter. Just yesterday, the eldest daughter of Russian opposition leader Boris Nemtsov, who was assassinated last February, denounced that "the Russian media, under the orders of the Kremlin, create a climate of violence and terror". And to top it all off, Russia has just published a blacklist banning 89 European politicians, civil servants and military leaders from entering Russian territory. Through its behaviour, Russia continues its international isolation. It is no longer one of the Union's strategic partners. Constructive relations between the European Union and Russia would, however, be beneficial for both sides. MEPs know this and do not close the door on the condition that this cooperation is based on dialogue, respect for international law and human rights.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. The adoption of a firm position towards the Russian authorities is necessary in response to their provocative behaviour. It is a question of the credibility of the European Union in defending its values and its security, and that is why I voted in favour of this resolution, which is going in the right direction in terms of the attitude to be adopted. As a result of its recurrent violations of international law, Russia can no longer be seen as a strategic partner. This should lead us in particular to review our defence cooperation and to develop measures to reduce our dependence on Russian gas.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I supported the report on the state of affairs between the European Union and Russia at a time when the international balance is very precarious. Russia has not respected Ukraine's territorial integrity or sovereignty during the armed conflict, illegally annexed Crimea and continues to exert an organized crackdown on political dissidents. We recall that Anna Politkovskaya, Natalia Estemirova, Boris Nemtsov, Sergei Magnitsky and Alexander Litvinenko were murdered because they were critics of the current regime. We strongly condemn all violations of international law, the rule of law and human rights. From now on, we must be clear. Russia must respect international law, fully implement the Minsk agreements and stop its military activities at the borders of member states. Our Assembly also wants to develop a comprehensive strategy for the future of our relations, both with Russia and with Eastern Europe.  A constructive resumption of relations is desirable for both sides, but this will only be done if Russia respects its commitments.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 It is important that the European Union and its Member States rethink the bilateral agreements concluded with Russia. The violation (in 2008) of Georgia's territorial integrity and the illegal annexation of Crimea were constantly denounced situations. Moreover, there are less denounced situations on Russian territory, but in which we cannot remain indifferent, such as the constant disregard for human rights and gender equality, and also for religious minorities. It is imperative that the European Union take an active stance in future strategic partnerships that can be celebrated with Russia, never forgetting the breaking of the principles, given the latest developments in Ukraine.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The Socialists believe in constructive relations with Russia as one of the EU's most important neighbours, but we hope that Russia will do its part to make this possible, starting with the full implementation of the Minsk Agreements to stop the conflict in Ukraine. Russia is an important EU neighbour; there are interests in practical cooperation and in jointly addressing shared global challenges, such as jihadist terrorism, Iran's nuclear program, destabilization in the Middle East, or non-proliferation. Russia must change its behavior towards its neighbors. The report sets out clear conditions for the full resumption of cooperation with Russia, such as the implementation of the Minsk Agreements, respect for the security order based on OSCE indications and principles in Europe and full respect for Ukraine's territorial integrity, including Crimea. At socialist instances, the meeting of far-right European leaders in Russia is condemned and LGTBI rights are defended in Russia. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted today in favour of this report, which calls on the European Union to critically reassess its relations with Russia. Relations that are deeply damaged as a result of Moscow's deliberate violation of democratic principles, fundamental values and international law through its violent action and the destabilization of neighbouring countries.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. This report draws attention to the deliberate and systematic violation of the democratic principles and fundamental values of international law, which is being perpetrated by Russia through its direct and indirect participation in the armed conflict in Ukraine, the illegal annexation of Crimea, the violation of Georgia's territorial integrity, as well as the economic coercement and political destabilisation of its European neighbours. The EU must therefore review its stance on relations with Russia, which should include a non-binding contingency plan and a detailed plan on future relations with russia and its Eastern European partners. Despite the growing concern and social alarm arising from the trampling of human rights and minorities, there is a belief that a constructive and predictable relationship between the EU and Russia will be possible in the long term, within a framework of mutual dialogue and cooperation, based on respect for international law. To do so, Russia will have to respect ukraine's territorial integrity and sovereignty, including Crimea, comply with the Minsk Agreements and cease military destabilisation activities at EU borders.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report presented by the Committee on Foreign Affairs on the state of relations between the European Union and Russia. This is because I believe that Europe's key mediating role in the difficult relations between the United States and the Russian Federation must not prevent it from adopting clear and clear positions on certain positions taken by its interlocutors. While it is good to keep the path of dialogue open, this cannot and must not prevent the EU from making a critical judgment of President Putin's policy, which, through strategic choices with which we are all familiar, has deliberately violated fundamental democratic rights and values. But a rightly critical assessment of Putin's policy must not turn into a total condemnation of Russia leading to a total closure of relations between that state and the European Union. If we care about the prosperity and peace of the continent, we must step up our efforts to rebuild a relationship with the Russian people.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because I consider Russia to be a strategic partner for the European Union and I do not agree with the current European foreign policy towards a country with which we should talk, rather than seek confrontation.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against this report on relations between the European Union and Russia, as it does not make any critical assessments of the current EU policy. It also represents a step forward in escalating the EU-Russia conflict, enabling the development of a policy of confrontation with Russia. The report as a whole is not seeking a peaceful resolution of the conflict, but rather delves into the tension between Russia and the EU. Those of us in favour of a Europe that advocates conflict resolution through dialogue and the constant search for peace cannot accept this report.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote because, as I stated in my written contribution to the debate, I ‘cannot have confidence in the version of one side or the other regarding the Ukrainian crisis, nor in the proposals that they are making regarding the future organisation of the European space’.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Russia continues to be an important partner of the European Union in a number of respects, including energy security, trade and the fight against terrorism and organised crime. I have therefore decided to vote against the report because I do not believe that it contributes to promoting a constructive debate in order to continue and, above all, strengthen long-term cooperation between the European Union and Russia. I hope that there will be greater efforts on both sides to try to put an end to the ongoing crisis in Ukraine as soon as possible, with mutual respect for the Minsk peace agreements, and thus to counter a possible further deterioration in relations. Both Russia's blacklist, which prevents 89 European politicians and officials from having access to Russian territory, and the report adopted today by the European Parliament are in danger of being counterproductive and have the sole effect of exacerbating the climate of growing tension.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ The rise of authoritarianism in Russia and clear breach of international law in relation to Ukraine clearly present an important challenge to Europe, but we cannot ignore the fact that Russia remains an important neighbour of the EU and that we have clear shared interests in practical cooperation and tackling global challenges, such as terrorism, the Syrian conflict, Iran’s nuclear programme and wider non-proliferation. This report is an important statement about EU-Russia relations following the recent events in Crimea and Ukraine.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ I consider it necessary to clearly define the EU's position on the aggression of the Russian Federation and to review the relations to date. However, I was unable to support the report, which is why I abstained. Stop treating Russia as a strategic partner (§ 2) or using overly harsh statements such as "strict, immediate and unconditional application (...) rules" (§ 18) is more damaging than it helps. The EU must strive for constant dialogue. Finally, I consider the call for the repeal of any law of an independent and sovereign state (§ 20) to be an overstep of competence that neither the EP nor the EU has.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ current EU-Russia relations are very weakened following the annexation of Crimea, and due to the ongoing conflict in eastern Ukraine, the resumption of cooperation is in sight. This is to the detriment of the whole EU, individual Member States and Russia. In the final vote, I supported the resolution, even though I opposed the part of the resolution where it was said that Russia is no longer a strategic partner for the EU. In my opinion, Russia has been, is and will always be, a strategic partner for its mineral wealth, for gas, for joint support in the field of the environment, in the development of new technologies, or, as was recently, in negotiations with Iran, where Russia has been very constructive. As in part of the resolution, I am of the opinion that, in the long term, a constructive and predictable relationship between the EU and Russia is possible and desirable for mutual benefit, in particular for existing relations in the areas of politics, trade, transport, energy, people-to-people contacts, cross-border cooperation, but also the Northern Dimension partnership, the nuclear talks with Iran, or the Middle East peace process.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: Writing. \u2012 Relations between the European Union and Russia are currently extremely strained and, unfortunately, increasingly characteristic of the Cold War period. I am convinced that maintaining this situation will not benefit anyone. I agree that the Russian leadership should seek to normalise relations and that it is of the utmost importance that the EU also tries to create a more favourable atmosphere for this. This is simply in the interest of European citizens, of the population living in increasingly difficult conditions in Ukraine, and even of Russian society. Of course, it is important for the Member States to act unitedly, but there is a better chance of this if we take into account the interests of all Member States in our common policies and show solidarity with each other.  In the changing circumstances of the coming years, we need to strengthen solidarity with each other in a number of areas, be it immigration, an economic crisis or the balancing of divergent interests with Russia. This could be the political guiding thread on which national leaders and the leaders of the European institutions can determine the direction of their action.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ the Russian leadership does not wish to improve relations with the European Union. The latest list of undesirable persons, including MEPs, and the new wave of propaganda campaigning are clear evidence of this. Europe can only respond to this by strengthening mutual solidarity and firm attitudes towards acts of aggression.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. \u2012 I support this report, because I believe that EU-Russia relations must be based on dialogue and respect for the provisions of international law, since the rule of law is one of the fundamental principles of the EU which implies not only respect for democracy and human rights, but also compliance with the provisions of international law and ensuring the implementation and application of the law, and judging by all events and statements, Russia does not meet these conditions as its authorities do not uphold the rule of law and do not respect fundamental rights.  Also the level of political rights, but also civil and media freedoms has been decreasing in recent years. Russia is now openly acting as a rival of the international democratic community, notably through its efforts to cross borders within Europe by force, and for openly highlighting the hatred directed against neighbouring nations and minorities, which is being achieved in ways that constitute a direct violation of the provisions of the international community.  EU-Russia cooperation is necessary and represents mutual benefit, but the EU will not deviate from its principles and values, in not all those relating to respect for human rights and freedoms, and it is imperative that Russia fulfils its commitments under the Agreement signed in Minsk for the potential continuation of cooperation and to stop destabilising military and security activities at the borders of EU Member States.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ With my S&D colleagues, I voted in favour of this resolution because it maintains its tough stance on Russia, and calls on Moscow to respect human rights and international values and step back from isolation and re-engage with the rest of the world. Russia is an important neighbour of the EU but, as the conflict continues, we back the continuing use of sanctions, though we are also clear that there must be engagement with our important neighbour.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒I support this report as the EU has pursued for years to build a mutually beneficial strategic partnership with Russia and remains open to such a relationship and dialogue with a purpose of restoring cooperation with Russia, provided that relations between the EU and Russia are based in the future on respect for international law and dialogue and that Russia respects the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine, including Crimea.  Russia must fully implement the Minsk agreements and stop destabilising military and security activities at the borders of EU Member States. The EU cannot plan a "return to the way it was" and is forced to thoroughly rethink its relations with Russia. In order for the EU to have more power in the negotiations, it is necessary to quickly create a strong European Energy Union in order to reduce the dependence of individual Member States on external energy suppliers, especially Russia.  Furthermore, deepening EU integration and coherence between its internal and external policies for a more coherent, efficient and successful EU foreign and security policy is essential. Political and financial support should be provided to independent civil society activists, human rights defenders, independent media, public figures and NGOs in order to promote democratic values, fundamental freedoms and human rights in Russia and occupied Crimea.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I supported the proposal in writing ‒ because I condemn Russia's annexation of Crimea. I believe that an agreement will be found between Russia and the European Union as soon as possible, because the current sanctions are detrimental to both parties involved.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ i voted in favour of the Report on the state of relations between the EU and Russia. Stability and peace in the European Union depends to a large extent on the quality of relations between the European Union and Russia. I support the establishment of a strategic partnership between the EU and Russia, but not at all costs. Russia must fulfil its international and legal obligations. In view of the numerous violations of the fundamental principles of Europe's security, the illegal annexation of Crimea, involvement in many frozen conflicts in my neighbourhood, I support the report, which stresses that Russia can no longer be considered a strategic partner at the moment.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the situation in the area of EU-Russia relations. I am very glad that the European Parliament has made its clear statement against violations of international law with this report, has clearly condemned Russian aggression against Ukraine, put the current situation in the context of relations between Russia and other states (Georgia, Moldova) and stated that it is currently not possible for Russia to continue to be regarded as a strategic partner of the European Union, because it is quite clear that it does not share the values professed by the Member States of the European Union. Until Russia fundamentally changes its policy, it is not possible to treat it as a partner, but above all, aggressive Soviet-style power politics must be strongly opposed.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The geopolitical positions of the movement are with those of Russia. Europe serves the interests of the US-controlled system, especially in matters relating to EU-Russia cooperation.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report because it provides an accurate and thorough picture of the current state of EU-Russia relations and provides a fair analysis of the reasons, in particular the facts of Russian aggression against Ukraine, the illegal annexation of Crimea and Moscow's continued expansionary policy. I agree that, at present, Russia poses a dangerous challenge and a near security risk for the Union, even though the EU continues to strive to be an important strategic partner once again. I consider it a virtue of the report to argue for the strengthening of the Common Foreign and Security Policy, in support of the efforts of High Representative Mogherini. I agree that, in all respects, but especially in enforcing the Minsk agreement and maintaining sanctions and tightening them as necessary, the EU must show demonstrative unity.  In this respect, I trust that with this report, the EP will give the High Representative and the European Council an incentive to take stronger action than ever before against the governments of the Member States, in particular the Hungarian Orban government, in the field of security policy, economy or energy policy. At the same time, I look forward to our recent resolution as a strong signal to the international community and to Moscow about the EU's unified and consistent stance on Ukraine's democratic development, territorial integrity and autonomy in Europe, and thus against Putin's further European expansion goals.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report takes a good view of the European Union's position. In the current situation, Russia, because of its actions in Crimea and eastern Ukraine, can no longer be regarded as a strategic partner, and it is therefore important that the Union as a whole take a firm and united stance. It is therefore good that a resolution in this form has been adopted, stressing not only disapproval of the military activities of Russian troops in Ukraine, but also negatively referring to the situation of respect for civil rights in Russia. This also applies to russia's threat to the EU's energy security.  I am also pleased that the final text of the resolution contains provisions on russia's call for the immediate return of the wreckage and any black boxes of the Polish plane that crashed near Smolensk and that this matter should be raised during all bilateral contacts with the Russian authorities. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Landsbergis report is a very serious attempt to sabotage the reality of the situation and peace. It deliberately mystifies the role of the US and the EU in triggering the crisis in Eastern Europe. I voted against. That is what really happened in Ukraine and triggered the crisis: Mr Yanukovich won democratic elections; the OECD, which is responsible for election monitoring, "promoted the Ukrainian vote as "transparent and honest", http://www.repubblica.it/esteri/2010/02/08/news/ucraina_8_febbraio-2224351/, after which "Western encouragement to anti-government activists in The Maidan was certainly neither discreet nor low-level, with the appearance on the square of the foreign ministers of France and Germany and Senator McCain", http://www.lastampa.it/2014/03/04/cultura/opinioni/editoriali/il-forcing-di-obama-e-il-bivio-italiano-dxAv9mXX3uw7w4VfibEtXP/pagina.html. The West should recite the mea culpa for helping to overthrow a democratically and regularly elected head of state. Furthermore, the report urges the EU to provide financial support to anti-government (or non-governmental) voices in Russia. This is called interference in the internal affairs of a sovereign country. The EU wants to behave with Russia in the same way as it has behaved with Yanukovich's Ukraine. The EU is now nato's eastern branch for good and wants to take Europe to the Third World War.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for it. I assume that relations between the European Union and Russia must now be based on respect for international law and on a dialogue in which the European Union would be ready to resume and relaunch cooperation with the Russian authorities in a number of specific areas of common interest.  It should be noted that a resumption of cooperation could be envisaged on the condition that Russia respects the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine, Crimea included, that it fully implement the Minsk agreements (which include full control of the border by the Ukrainian authorities, the unconditional withdrawal of Russian troops and weapons, and the immediate end of aid to rebel groups) and that it put an end to its military and security activities for destabilization purposes. at the borders of the Member States of the European Union. The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) has proven to be a structure capable of contributing to the resolution of the crisis in a neutral way.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Developments in Crimea and in Eastern Ukraine have considerably deteriorated the relations between the EU and Russia and it cannot be business as usual anymore. With the adoption of this report, the European Parliament points to the need to reassess its relations with Russia. The situation is serious and I decided to support this report to send a strong signal and call on the Russia authorities to respect international law.  If we look at the conflict in Ukraine, along with the annexation of Crimea and the political destabilisation of some countries in the area, the EU cannot consider resuming normal relations with the Russian Government. But this does not mean that the EU should cut off all relations with the Russians. On the contrary, the EU needs to develop a strong dialogue and cooperation with researchers, students, SMEs and Russian civil society in general.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report on the state of relations between the European Union and Russia, as it expresses a critical attitude towards dangerous and inadmissible current Russian actions on the international stage, as well as towards human rights violations and the rule of law in Russia itself.  In particular, I support that the report stressed that the European Union cannot continue its normal cooperation with Russia until it implements the Minsk peace agreement aimed at stopping the conflicts in Ukraine. If Russia meets these conditions, to which it has committed, a constructive relationship between the EU and Russia is desirable and possible, but until then Russia should no longer be considered a strategic partner of the EU. I am very pleased that the amendments of the European Conservatives and Reformists have been incorporated into the report, especially those concerning the call for the return of the wreckage and black box of the Polish government plane that crashed near Smolenska in 2010.  I also support the call on the Member States of the Union to maintain a unified attitude towards Russia.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on the state of relations between the EU and Russia. Direct and indirect participation in armed conflict, violations of territorial integrity, abuse of economic power and political destabilisation constitute a deliberate violation of democratic principles, fundamental values and international law. I am concerned about the fact, even in the light of recent events, the publication of the blacklist that Russia presents itself in public as a challenger to the international democratic community. I believe that we need to be careful in our relations with Russia and that, as an EU, we need to speak more unitedly against this country, which has been in a serious violation of international law in recent times.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against this report on relations between the European Union and Russia, as it does not make any critical assessments of the current EU policy. It also represents a step forward in escalating the EU-Russia conflict, enabling the development of a policy of confrontation with Russia. The report as a whole is not seeking a peaceful resolution of the conflict, but rather delves into the tension between Russia and the EU. Those of us in favour of a Europe that advocates conflict resolution through dialogue and the constant search for peace cannot accept this report.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour and I support this resolution. Russia’s direct and indirect involvement in the armed conflict in Ukraine and its illegal annexation of Crimea, together with its violation of the territorial integrity of Georgia and its economic coercion and political destabilisation of its European neighbours, constitute a deliberate violation of democratic principles, fundamental values and international law. In this context, the EU cannot envisage a return to ‘business as usual’. It had to act. On another note, the economic sanctions were one of the tools for use by the EU. They will damage Russia’s economy but not only Russia. In the medium and long term, sanctions will significantly harm some European SMEs as well. The EU must therefore make every effort to open up new markets for European SMEs.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This report reports EU-Russia relations and is consistent with all previous reports and resolutions on Russia, which is considered dangerous and carries global instability. This report is biased and partisan. Notably in the historical revision of Russia's involvement in the events that occurred in Georgia during the 2008 crisis and the annexation of Crimea. The rapporteur announces that Russia cannot be seen as a strategic and serious partner, and threatens it directly if it does not show more docility. I am obviously opposed to this surreal text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted against this report on relations between the European Union and Russia, as it does not make any critical assessments of the current EU policy. It also represents a step forward in escalating the EU-Russia conflict, enabling the development of a policy of confrontation with Russia. The report as a whole is not seeking a peaceful resolution of the conflict, but rather delves into the tension between Russia and the EU. Those of us in favour of a Europe that advocates conflict resolution through dialogue and the constant search for peace cannot accept this report.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The report confirms the current state of relations between the EU and Russia as a result of the conflict in Ukraine. It also incorporates the rejection of this house to the so-called blacklist drawn up by the Russian authorities. We are therefore talking about a report to be voted on positively.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. Russia is the main neighbour of the European Union, one of its main trading partners – especially in terms of energy needs – and a country with which all the countries of the European Union have closely shared a part of history. That is why I believe that relations between the EU and Russia must be treated with the utmost care and great responsibility. In the text put to the vote, however, I have encountered a disproportionate vocabulary riddled with condemnation. But above all, there is a double standard that is difficult to digest by anyone who has briefly known the history of Europe in the last twenty-five years. I voted against this report because, according to the approved text, Russia should no longer be a strategic partner for the European Union, which is particularly worrying given the common interests that exist.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ With my S&D colleagues, I voted in favour of this resolution because it maintains its tough stance on Russia, and calls on Moscow to respect human rights and international values and step back from isolation and re-engage with the rest of the world. Russia is an important neighbour of the EU but, as the conflict continues, we back the continuing use of sanctions, though we are also clear that there must be engagement with our important neighbour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'The state of play between the EU and Russia is frankly not very good. Although I have a difference of opinion with many of my colleagues on how to approach relations with Russia I voted in favour of this report because we, as the EU, need to make a clear voice. Personally, I'm not so set up with the scaffolding and trench warfare that we're organizing. I strongly call for more dialogue on the merits. What is happening now has root causes and we must dare to discuss it.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. The Landsbergis report supports the latest European Council decisions against Russia. This report is, in line with the other texts voted on the subject in recent months, a unilateral and bellicose report, which can only aggravate tensions between the European Union and Russia with hints of cold war and even surreal primary anticommunism on the part of the right of the Chamber. The report calls for speeding up funding for "independent civil society" in Russia and wants to set up a genuine anti-Russian propaganda programme in the European Union as well as in the Eastern Partnership countries. Whatever the primary anti-Russians think, Russia remains a strategic partner for the European Union, which we must treat without complacency or enmity. It is also time to open our eyes to what is happening in Ukraine, where corrupt oligarchs are far from paragons of virtue. I denounce this "double standard" policy, which is a bellicose one, which always fiercely denounces the same countries, but turns a blind eye when it comes to the Gulf countries or Israel. I therefore voted against this report without the slightest state of mind.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I refused to support the motion for a resolution because I do not believe that the proposals in the report would improve the relationship between the EU and Russia.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the EU Parliament's resolution on the state of EU-Russia relations. In particular, it perpetuates the difficult situation for Germany not to regard Russia as a strategic partner. Moreover, the resolution blames Russia solely for the cooling of relations. It deplores the state of the rule of law in Russia, but at the same time calls for the establishment of propaganda institutions in the EU to influence public opinion – thereby jeopardising the independence of the press and thus the freedom of the press, which is essential for a democratic constitutional state.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on EU-Russia relations. In view of Russia's aggressive policies and complete lack of respect for human rights and international standards and obligations arising from its membership of the UN, the Council of Europe and the OSCE, it is necessary for Europe to act in solidarity in the name of defending our common values and principles such as democracy and the rule of law. Any resumption of cooperation with Russia can only take place if clear conditions are met: respect for the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine (including Crimea), full implementation of the Miscan provisions of 5 and 19 September 2014 and 12 February 2015, and the cessation of destabilisation activities within the borders of EU Member States.  Furthermore, the situation requires us to take concrete preventive measures against Russian propaganda and disinformation campaigns, deliberately destabilising and antagonising the EU's cooperation with its eastern neighbours. In the current circumstances, I am also concerned about the fact that Russian nationalist forces have intensive contacts and cooperation with extremely radical European political parties – and I see a significant threat to our democratic order. For this reason, I support the proposal for a regulation prohibiting the financing of political parties by political and economic actors outside the EU.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ This report on the current state of EU-Russia relations comes at a tense moment unprecedented since the end of the Cold War. So there is caution on the ground not to pour oil into the fire on the one hand, but on the other hand, the position on Moscow's behaviour must be clear on the part of the EU. The consequences of recent events have caused the current situation to be impasse and the inability of the Russian authorities to engage in constructive dialogue with the EU. Russia is permanently violating the Minsk agreements, recently by blacklisting the names of MEPs. Russia has heightened tensions on the continent and violated international law. I appeal to the responsibility of the Russian authorities to accept the HAND of the EU and to start easing tensions in Ukraine. Respect for the Minsk agreements, meanwhile, is the only way to ease tensions between the EU and Russia and the best precondition for a solution to the impasse.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The report calls for an escalation by all means, military, political, economic, of the EU's aggression towards capitalist Russia, focusing on their conflict following the IMPERIALIST EU-US-NATO intervention in Ukraine, but also overall control of energy resources and their transport routes in greater Eurasia.  It calls for a new extension of the time and scope of sanctions and greater pressure on Russia to consolidate the positions of the Euro-Atlantic axis in the region. Despite calls by the representatives of the chapter for a unified EU attitude towards Russian capitalism, the report cannot hide the serious contradictions within the EU, between its Member States, due to the different interests of the business groups they represent, depending on the relations they maintain with Russian monopolies, but also the orientations of their international alliances.  The EU-Russia conflict is solely about the interests of monopolies on both sides, which people pay dearly for with their blood and the deterioration of their lives by economic measures and countermeasures. The solution lies in the hands of the peoples, the popular struggle, to change the power relations, against monopolies, to disengage from imperialist associations and to form mutually beneficial relations between states and peoples.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EU's tactics towards Russia, because I consider Russia's involvement in the occupation of Crimea to be a gross violation of the fundamental rights and values of developed countries. Russia poses a threat to the security and stability of the entire EU, especially Eastern Europe. As a result of the annexation of Crimea and the events in Ukraine, there has been a de facto departure from the concept of a strategic partnership. I still believe that, going forward, we should consider Russia to be an EU partner, but I think it is not being as a reliable partner at the moment.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted positively on the report drawn up by Gabrielius Landsbergis on relations between the European Union and Russia. In the light of the Minsk Agreement, the conclusions of the G7 countries, as well as the resolutions of the United Nations Assembly, I support the European Union's position that any restoration of cooperation with Russia is possible only when Russia fulfils its international and legal obligations, inter alia, ending direct and indirect military participation in the Ukrainian conflict, violations of Georgia's territorial integrity, and the anexacy of Crimea. I also support the position expressed in the resolution that, without Russia changing its course of action, the European Union must critically review existing cooperation, as it cannot at present be considered a strategic partner. It is essential that the restoration of cooperation with Russia can contribute not only to respect for the inviolability of national borders, but also to respect human rights, the rule of law, the principles of international diplomacy and trade.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ the report I voted for stresses that russia can no longer be treated as a strategic partner because of its actions in Crimea and eastern Ukraine. Strategic partnerships must be based on mutual trust and respect for international law. Russia is not complying with international law at the moment and has repeatedly lost the EU's trust.  In the long term, however, a constructive and predictable relationship between the EU and Russia is possible and desirable for both sides.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Defining at what stage EU-Russia relations are currently at is the key to developing the right policy towards our great eastern neighbour. We can no longer hide from ourselves that the policy of dialogue at all costs and of treating Russia as a strategic partner will lead to changes in Kremlin policy. Even those politicians and parties that wanted to talk to Russia when Russian troops occupied Crimea see this now. It is true that in many places the tone of this report could and should be sharper. Too often we have shown weakness to do so again, but it is difficult not to see that the EP's position is moving in the right direction. We cannot give up all the pressure on Russia that we have at our disposal. We must not forget that it was Russia that caused the war in eastern Ukraine. We must not forget that Russia has annexed part of the territory of Ukraine – our important partner. No one denies dialogue with Moscow once and for all, but now, under these political conditions, we cannot give up sanctions and diplomatic pressure. Russia needs to change its policy, and we must do everything we can to help it. The future depends not only on Ukraine, Georgia or Moldova, but also on the European Union itself.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the state of relations between the EU and Russia because Russia and the European Union need each other, in fact we should be partners. Putin's Russia, however, has betrayed this partnership in at least two ways in recent years: firstly, it has anecdote of a neighbouring country, challenged military maneuvers, undermined the stability of the region, caused conflicts in the neighbourhood, stepped up intelligence and propaganda activity in and against the European Union, and thus revived the Cold War. Secondly, it haunts the opposition at home and has never explained the murders of Ana Politkov, Natalia Estemiran, Boris Nemov, Sergei Magnickega, Alexander Litvinenko and others. There is no choice but to tighten economic and other sanctions against the country until Russia returns to respect for international law, returns Crimea and begins to respect basic human rights. European Union sanctions are already weakening Putin's position, but we must also continue to strengthen the unity of the European Union's policy towards Russia and, above all, strengthen our defence capabilities.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – We are now talking about a European energy security strategy. This material did not pass in the end, but I voted in favour. I consider it a mistake that this document was not adopted in the end, because I believe that it could have been the starting point for the future development of the Energy Union, which I, as a politician in the Czech Republic, a country that was previously under the influence of the Soviet Union, consider to be extremely important. The Energy Union is, in my opinion, part of the future energy security and independence from countries such as the European Union. Russia, which we are debating here.  On the other hand, I think that the EU should not dictate to individual Member States what energy resources they will use in the future, i.e. we should not say what the energy mix should look like in individual Member States. I am therefore glad that, in the end, the amendments did not pass, the whole report did not pass, but the amendments that, for example, very discriminated against and limited atomic energy, which I personally consider important, have not been tabled. I think it would be a mistake to try to discriminate against certain types of energy in the future when we return to this subject. We should leave that to the individual states. So I say, it is a pity that this material has not passed, we should return to the subject of Europe's energy security and adopt in the future an adjustment that preserves national sovereignty in the selection of energy sources, but, on the other hand, strengthens the entire energy security of the whole of Europe.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – It is a coincidence that there will be two Czech speeches in a row, but it is not a coincidence that we have a very similar position with my colleague Pospisil. Citizens in the Member States quite rightly expect that energy security will be our priority and that we will try to find a consensus and a common solution. The issue of energy security is a fundamental problem for us and it is an area in which the EU can have great added value and it is therefore our duty to come up with an appropriate solution.  I consider it necessary to work to make both the EU and the Member States less dependent on energy imports from outside the EU. I agree with many of the accents that the report has brought, such as the need to speed up work on the construction of the necessary infrastructure, including possible funding from the EU budget. As for other EU countries, nuclear power is essential for the Czech Republic, which has a great future of development. I therefore did not vote in favour of the amendments that limited it, and I am glad that these amendments have not been adopted. In the end, no resolution has been adopted, and this is proof that we still have a very difficult debate ahead of us, but we are obliged to have it.

name: Bendt BENDTSEN
text: Mr President! I voted in favour of the proposal today because I think it is extremely important for the European Union to find its feet in this area. It is regrettable that there was not a majority in favour of the EU's energy security strategy today. We are witnessing a world in which, over the last ten years, the European Union has become increasingly dependent on external energy, not least on Putin's gas and oil from the Middle East. That is why we need to use a number of elements in the coming years to ensure that we have a security strategy and security of supply. This is big politics. I find it regrettable that we cannot agree on this at the moment. We need to use all means to become more energy-independent of Russia in the future.
