This applies to shale gas, nuclear power, energy efficiency and renewable energy. I think we need to use the whole palette in order for us to become energy independent, not least of Russia.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, it is important that Europe would take a balanced approach to increase our energy security and to reduce our dependence, particularly on external supplies. Energy security is a key pillar of the Union, and the report highlights a number of areas in energy efficiency, renewables and the diversification of the sources of imported energy into Europe. Of course the energy mix of every country is a matter of national competence. In Ireland we are free to determine the energy sources used and the natural resources that will be exploited. There is a major emphasis on this, and I think that emphasis needs to be increased and that this point should be underlined when speaking to individual countries introducing energy efficiencies, particularly in commercial buildings. There is a focus on domestic dwellings, but there is a huge potential to introduce energy efficiencies in commercial businesses as well. It will be important for Ireland to develop interconnectors with the UK and, potentially, France as well. I am strongly in favour of the current moratorium on fracking in Ireland, and I support the government’s position that no decision will be taken on any proposal for the use of hydraulic fracturing until such time as the human health impacts of fracking are addressed. A report is currently being commissioned by the Environment Protection Agency in Ireland and we are waiting for the outcome of that report.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, I voted for Amendment 1. I come from an area that is potentially in danger from the production of shale gas. All our water courses are connected. I find it interesting that Ms Clune talks about a study that is coming forward from the EPA (Environmental Protection Agency). As far as I can understand, that study was presented at the Oireachtas Committee on the Environment today in the Republic of Ireland, and I think it is important to point out that the organisation that did that study and which was commissioned to do it – CDM Smith – are actually involved in the fracking and the shale gas industry. They led the move into Poland. They support shale gas. So really it is a bit like going and asking the ‘Lard Council’ whether it is a good idea to eat lard and is it good for your cardiovascular system? Well we know what the ‘lard council’ will say – yes of course, it is good for you – because they have an interest in selling it. We know damn well what CDM Smith will say. They will say it is fine, because that is what they do as a business. Hardly independent, is it, Ms Clune?

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – I voted against this report on the European Energy Security Strategy because, according to this report, the Commission must have the right to intervene as a negotiator in the conclusion of all energy contracts of national states.  Bulgaria has twice suffered economic consequences and losses from purely political decisions such as the important and strategic projects related to the Belene PP and the South Stream project. Furthermore, the report calls into question the security and use of nuclear energy. It has been proven that this energy is the cheapest ever invented and its price rise is nothing more than an artificially created phenomenon.  Here I must note that after the unclear closure of the first, second, third and fourth blocks of kozloduy nuclear power unit, Bulgaria has only two working reactors, which, if not refurbished, will be threatened as an energy center in the Balkans and we will go from exporter to importer of electricity from a non-European country – Turkey. I believe that this is contrary to the Union's energy security and I oppose this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – I voted in favour of this report because I am aware that, in the case of military and food security, energy security is very important, around which we also have a lot of business to run in the European Parliament.  Energy security is all the more at risk because most of the energy, which is imported more than half into Europe, comes from politically risky areas, there has been a lot of talk about Russia today, a lot of energy is coming from the Middle East, so it is right that we take decisive steps on the continent ourselves. Energy saving is the first, most important measure in energy policy, so I am pleased that this report is also dedicated to these energy saving measures, and on the other hand, it is also important that the measures we are preparing in Parliament, that is to say, in the actions of both the Juncker Plan and the Energy Union, provide an opportunity for a whole range of infrastructure facilities. which will allow for greater market stability.  What is also important is also the need for markets in Europe, particularly in the field of gas and electricity, to connect with each other, because otherwise these isolated markets will have major problems in the future.

name: Seán KELLY
text: –  A Uachtaráin, gan dabht ar bith tá sé thar a bheith tábhachtach go mbeadh straitéis éifeachtach againn maidir le slándáil fuinnimh a chothú san Aontas. Ní gá dúinn ach féachaint ar na figiúirí: iompórtálaimid 53% den fhuinneamh a úsáidimid; iompórtálaimid 66% den ghás agus 90% den ola. Mar a dúradh sa díospóireacht dheireanach, tagann a lán den fhuinneamh ó thíortha nach féidir brath orthu, cosúil leis an Rúis. Dá bhrí sin, caithfimid féachaint ar thíortha eile agus, go háirithe, úsáid a bhaint as rudaí cosúil le LNG (gás nádúrtha leachtaithe) chun gás a thabhairt isteach ó thíortha timpeall an domhain ar fad.  D’fhéadfaimis i bhfad níos mó a dhéanamh freisin maidir le fuinneamh a athnuachan, gaoth, grian, taoidí agus tonnta ach go háirithe. Tá taighde ar siúl, go háirithe i mo thír féin, a dhéanfaidh na cineálacha fuinnimh seo i bhfad níos éifeachtaí agus níos saoire amach anseo de bharr na teicneolaíochta nua a thiocfaidh as an taighde sin. Dá bhrí sin, feabhsóidh rudaí de réir a chéile.

name: Tim AKER
text: – Mr President, I voted against this report because, frankly, the EU energy policies have been a colossal disaster. The Large Combustion Plant Directive has closed the power stations in the United Kingdom that provide us with a third of our energy. In my own constituency, Tilbury power station was one of those victims, and hundreds of jobs were lost as a result. If you look at the wider effect on energy prices, we face the chilling prospect of 10 000 to 20 000 people – mostly older folk – dying every year. They are called excess winter deaths, and that is a horrifying euphemism if ever I heard one. They die because they have to choose between heating and eating. We are going to face this question at a referendum. In 1975 the British people thought they were voting for a common market. Now, with the EU controlling our energy policy, our laws and our borders, and us giving the EU GBP 55 million a day, the public will finally – and only because of UKIP – put this issue to rest so we can reject this Union and its failed policies.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE). Mr President, today we have not been able to agree on the necessary framework for strengthening energy security in the European Union, because of ideological amendments by the Left. It is these same ideologies that are driving the government and in my country, Greece, to increase dependence on a single provider, Russia, by undermining energy security. This is because of the extreme left-wing ideology and the minister responsible, Mr Lafazanis.  What will it really mean for European energy security, for the supply of gas from multiple suppliers, if the TAP pipeline does not go ahead and the Turkish Stream game continues, for which there are, by the way, no funds? What does the Greek government's refusal to proceed with the partial privatization of PPC mean for the single energy market and ultimately for energy security, the refusal to increase the participation of individuals through renewable energy sources, to pay the debts to private individuals anyway?  The resolution is necessary for energy security to move forward. It is, however, a prerequisite for governments of Member States, such as the Greek, that do not work to unify the energy market to comply in this direction.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, in the United Kingdom we need a basket of different energy types. I think that is pretty much universally accepted. Personally, I think that, as far as renewables are concerned, wind power is a bit of a dead end in the UK, certainly until the storage problem has been sorted. Sometimes the wind blows, sometimes the wind does not blow, and the times when we need the most power are generally the hottest and coldest days of the year when the wind is not blowing. Other types of renewables – tidal power, for example – are much closer to being sustainable and economical, and being ready to be introduced. Decisions should always be based on technology, not targets. The European Union is all about its targets, but the trouble with targets is that they distort and lead you down a blind alley. But none of this is really the point. The point is that we do not need an EU energy strategy. We need a UK energy strategy.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialists regret that the Saudargas report has not been adopted because, thanks to the intensive work in committee, the report was committed to a new energy model for Europe, a sustainable and equitable model. During the vote in plenary, the Socialists had managed to cover a majority on three essential points, two of them at the request of the Spanish Socialist delegation: (1) a majority in favour of asking the Commission to submit a Communication on energy poverty, accompanied by an action plan to combat it; (2) a majority in favour of asking Governments not to authorize any new fracking operations in the EU until such actions are shown to be safe for the environment, workers and the general population; and (3) a majority in favour of more ambitious targets in renewable energy, energy efficiency and climate change, and that these were also binding.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it bases European energy security on two pillars to which I oppose it. The first is to strengthen the EU's aggressive trade and foreign policy, with its pressures, impositions and attacks on our neighbours to access its energy resources. This is a voracious and short-sighted strategy that only contributes to destabilizing them and which we oppose, because only a project of development and mutual collaboration can be the basis of trade relations between sovereign states. The second is the impetus given to energy as dangerous as nuclear energy in the context of the energy transition. On the contrary, there are own resources, such as coal, that can be developed as a complement to renewable energy and environmental efficiency to reduce our energy dependence. For this reason, we defend the maintenance of production and generation aids with local coal, improvements in their combustion techniques (investing in thermal renewal) and a commitment to the technological development of new harvesting and capture techniques related to their combustion cycle.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. In May 2014, the European Commission published the Strategy for a Secure European Energy Supply in response to the worsening crisis in Ukraine. Important objectives of the energy security strategy include, inter alia, the attenuation of energy demand, in particular by increasing energy efficiency, linking energy networks between Member States and expanding domestic energy production. Priority is currently being given to the creation of a European Energy Union and the implementation of the EU's internal energy market. This own-initiative report by the ITRE Committee supports the objectives set out by the Commission. The urgency of a common energy supply strategy is mainly due to the EU's current delicate relationship with Russia and the high level of energy dependence on third countries – the EU meets 53% of its energy needs through imports from third countries. I therefore welcome the actions of the strategy and call on EU actors to work together to achieve the EU's internal energy market.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I voted against this text for two main reasons: ideological and principled hostility towards Russia, and interference in the policies of the Member States it supports. The rapporteur of this text was Lithuania's foreign minister during the 1990s, which partly explains his hostility in principle to Russia. He therefore advocates turning entirely to the United States in order to put an end to energy dependence on Russia. He argues that it would be an unreliable partner, without ever giving a concrete example of a broken contract. All the more so since, despite the tense geopolitical situation, Russia has further increased its natural gas exports to the EU countries. Rather than relying on Russian gas, this text wants Europe to depend on US or Qatari shale gas, which is geopolitically questionable and ecologically unacceptable, as hydraulic fracturing destroys ecosystems and pollutes water sources. Finally, the rapporteur wants to liberalise energy supply in Europe, by taking away the possibility of regulating tariffs or protectionist policies for their industries.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because, despite the progress made in strengthening its infrastructure and diversifying its suppliers, the European Union remains vulnerable to external energy shocks and geodiplomatic hazards. Europe has managed to ensure, thanks to the CAP, food independence, and it must now work to do the same for its energy needs. The European Energy Agency will be an essential tool for Europeans' purchasing power and a new stone of effective European diplomacy.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a European energy security strategy. I congratulate my colleague Algirdas Saudarg on the comprehensive and very important report that has been prepared. I have three observations. Firstly, the resulting and deepening tensions between the EU and Russia send a strong signal to the EU as a whole to create a fully connected, integrated and shock-resistant Energy Union as soon as possible. However, such a union can only be achieved when the political will to make difficult decisions has been found. The use of energy resources as a powerful political pressure against the EU is breaking it down, putting internal tensions at its disposal and depressing the economy. Secondly, I miss a regional approach in terms of energy security. The Commission should make concrete proposals taking into account the energy specificities of individual EU regions and assessing optimal energy mixes. One of the main works is the synchronisation of the baltic region's electricity networks with continental European networks. Thirdly, to date, the Commission has not come forward with a strategic approach to the development of nuclear energy in the European Union. While the Energy Action Plan presented by the Commission emphasises the role and importance of nuclear energy in the future production of clean electricity, no action has been taken so far to support politically those Member States that continue to want to use or develop nuclear energy.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Like almost all of the Baltic Members, the author of the report seems more driven by resentment against Russia than by the concern for the real interests of our peoples. The text repeatedly accuses Russia of being an "unreliable partner". However, during the debates taking place in the ITRE committee, no parliamentarian has been able to give a single example of a contract that has not been respected by the Russians. Despite SANCTIONS imposed by the European Union at the request of the United States, Russia has increased the amount of gas delivered directly to the EU by 10 Gm3 to compensate for the loss of gas caused by the crisis in Ukraine, while the exploitation of the Groningen deposit in the Netherlands and British production continue to decline. Instead of promoting north American shale gas imports and TNG from Qatar, to move from Russian dependence to US-Qatari dependency, this report should have sought to promote the future sectors of biomethane and its derivatives. France is lagging behind in this sector, but we could probably draw inspiration from what our neighbours are doing, especially Italy, which is at the forefront of the bioGNV sector.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I think the energy security model is linked to the energy transition. The priority must be to ensure energy efficiency, promote renewable energy and encourage financial investment in domestic energy production, rather than spending large sums of money to import energy. Developing the green technology industry is essential to creating jobs.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. It has been a pity that this report has not been adopted, as Europe needs to have a clear energy security strategy taking into account its current dependence. This requires a change in attitudes from the 28 countries of the Union to develop more connected networks and sustainable energies. These conditions will allow us to have cheaper energy, favoring the industrial sectors and making them more competitive. More efficient use of resources in households with a high energy bill will be encouraged and oil dependence should be reduced.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The author of this report, Mr Saudargas, who is fiercely hostile to Russia, gives us here a text clearly hostile to our Russian partner, in particular in defiance of the geographical constraints (ease of transit) and geological constraints (available stocks) related to energy supply.  The report accuses Russia of being "an unreliable partner" without citing concrete examples. The aim of this report is obvious: to minimize the European Union's dependence on Russia and to look to the United States for the conclusion of TTIP. Thus, this report proposes the proliferation of liquefied natural gas terminals allowing the delivery of Natural Gas from the United States (shale gas) or Qatar.  This text will only serve the interest of some. Wanting to "liberate" Europe from the Russian gas grip through liberalisation measures risks leading to an increase in tariffs for consumers (end of regulated tariffs) and breaking our industry solely in favour of short-term speculative markets. However, only states should be able to decide on their energy policy and cooperation in this area. So I decided to vote against this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report has controversial aspects that at least merited less partisan study, which is why I do not find it balanced and I do not agree with it. I have decided not to support you with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialists regret that the Saudargas report has not been adopted because, thanks to the intensive work in committee, the report was committed to a new energy model for Europe, a sustainable and equitable model. During the vote in plenary, the Socialists had managed to cover a majority on three essential points, two of them at the request of the Spanish Socialist delegation: (1) a majority in favour of asking the Commission to submit a Communication on energy poverty, accompanied by an action plan to combat it; (2) a majority in favour of asking Governments not to authorize any new fracking operations in the EU until such actions are shown to be safe for the environment, workers and the general population; and (3) a majority in favour of more ambitious targets in renewable energy, energy efficiency and climate change, and that these were also binding.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which the rapporteur highlights the crisis that has begun in Ukraine, which reminded the European Union of the importance of energy security and the decisive role in consolidating Europe's strong political and economic position. The vulnerability of the energy market to geopolitics has made energy policy one of the strategic priorities of foreign affairs. The European Union therefore needs to develop an energy policy based on coordination of positions and a unified position. Although significant progress has been made in improving the EU's energy security in recent years, the EU still faces various challenges, such as instability in energy-supplying regions, fragmentation of the internal market and climate change. The report identifies actions to reduce energy demand, increase local energy production and develop energy technologies, and follow-up to a fully integrated and well-functioning internal energy market, solidarity and coordination mechanisms.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 Security of energy security is one of the biggest challenges facing the European Union. The gas crises of 2006 and 2009 made it clear that Central and Eastern Europe is now the most vulnerable. We need to change this situation together, we have a duty to increase security of supply. In my opinion, the Saudargas report voted on by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy provided good guidance on the direction in which we should proceed. However, in the plenary vote, an amendment was voted on by some party groups condemning the technology used in research into unconventional energy sources and recommending member states not to allow non-conventional energy sources to be researched and extracted until it is found to be completely safe. In line with the people's party's position, as a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I abstained from voting on the report because, on the one hand, allowing mining activities is a competence of the Member States and, on the other hand, I consider it of the utmost importance that all possible domestic resources be sought in order to increase security of supply in Europe, while complying with mandatory standards.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 Recent geopolitical crises have shown the vulnerability of the European Union in terms of security and energy supply. In order to meet this challenge, it is necessary to overcome the idea that each Individual Member State should adopt its own national energy policy in an un coordinated and integrated way with respect to a general framework of priorities defined at Community level.  The draft report that we have voted on today clearly identifies these priorities: diversifying sources of supply, improving energy efficiency, developing modern transmission infrastructures and integrating renewable resources more efficiently. Efforts to achieve a fully integrated internal energy market combined with solidarity mechanisms between states will also need to be strengthened. This is a fundamental project which lays the foundations for a future Energy Union.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ This report, on Parliament's own initiative, is essentially a response to the European Commission's Communication on Energy Security in the EU, but also addresses broader energy issues.  The basic message the rapporteur wants to send is that it is better to spend in the "house" the money that EU Member States now give on imports of energy from abroad, which I fully support. The best way to achieve energy security in Europe is to invest in renewables, innovation and "domestic" energy production that will create new jobs.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report with my vote because I believe it is important for the EU to work to have its own energy security strategy that allows for a constant and regular supply of energy.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the European Energy Security Strategy. Once again, this report is written on the basis of ideological motivations. It aims at the energy independence of the Union from Russia, and turning to American imports. It is becoming urgent that the members of the majority seek the interests of the citizens of the Member States with the utmost coherence, taking into account the technical and geographical factors of imports. Unlike those Members who have chosen to demonstrate their friendship with the United States and their disagreement with Russia, I have chosen to focus on the States capable of providing energy to the French in the best possible conditions.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The energy challenge is one of the great challenges to which the European Union is subject. Bringing our energy system a new, more sustainable and more secure way is sustainable, but it is absolutely necessary to make ambitious decisions in this regard. Ensuring the supply of energy in sufficient quantities, at affordable prices, efficiently and sustainably are objectives that the European Union must achieve in order to ensure the energy security that Member States so badly need. I voted in favour of the European Energy Security Strategy because it is a key element that helps to define the main challenges that we must face by developing an energy policy based on close coordination of Member States' positions.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against. EU energy policy is wrong and uneconomic. It alienates the Russian supplier, which is currently the world's most expensive gas, and focuses on the expensive and insufficient development of renewables.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialists regret that the Saudargas report has not been adopted because, thanks to the intensive work in committee, the report was committed to a new energy model for Europe, a sustainable and equitable model. During the vote in plenary, the Socialists had managed to cover a majority on three essential points, two of them at the request of the Spanish Socialist delegation: (1) a majority in favour of asking the Commission to submit a Communication on energy poverty, accompanied by an action plan to combat it; (2) a majority in favour of asking Governments not to authorize any new fracking operations in the EU until such actions are shown to be safe for the environment, workers and the general population; and (3) a majority in favour of more ambitious targets in renewable energy, energy efficiency and climate change, and that these were also binding.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. We need to establish a European strategy for energy security. An energy union is essential for the proper functioning of the single market as well as for the security of the EU member states. We cannot be exclusively dependent on third countries. That is why we need to strengthen our energy production capacity, including with nuclear energy. Projects such as ITER must therefore be supported. There is also a need to improve research and innovation in the energy field. Since the text did not take these requirements into account, I voted against this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the European Energy Security Strategy. The well-known Russian events show that the security of the European Union and its prosperity require a rational and efficient use of energy, through a constant, accessible and sustainable energy supply. For the European Union, therefore, the establishment of a European Energy Union is absolutely essential. The EU energy strategy should also focus on crucial issues such as the creation of a fully integrated internal energy market, the moderation of energy demand, the decarbonisation of the energy mix and research and innovation, the development of renewable energies and their storage. The report touched on all these points and that is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as there were a number of concerning aspects contained within it, particularly in relation to fracking. I have always been very vocal in my opposition to fracking, which has the potential to cause serious environmental pollution and damage to fish stocks and livestock. It also poses a very real threat to the success of our farming industry, the tourism industry and the health and safety of rural communities. Moreover, in many places in the text, it calls for the completion of the internal energy market and ignores the rights of Member States to determine their own energy policy, which runs completely contrary to the principle of subsidiarity. It was for these reasons that I voted against this report.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ This draft report is the European Parliament’s response to the Commission proposal for a European Energy Security Strategy, which was drawn up following the crisis in Ukraine. The report outlines the framework for an improved energy security in the EU and identifies the main areas for European action in order to ensure comprehensive energy security in the EU.  During the voting I abstained on this report, as although I concur and applaud the majority of the elements in the report I could not fully support some aspects of the text especially concerning the use of hydraulic fracturing.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 We voted against Mr Saudargas' report. The negotiations conducted in the ITRE Committee led to substantial improvements in the first draft of the report, which made it possible to rebalance it, but not to change its nature; The text remains permeated with a strongly anti-Russian and profossile spirit. Instead, attention to energy efficiency and renewables and a moderate and cooperative attitude should dominate the Eu ropean Union's energy security strategy.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I strongly opposed this report, which uses energy security issues in a scandalous way to wage a new battle against Russia, which is outrageously stated in the explanatory statement of this report. Even though Russia is our largest partner in energy supply - the EU Member States that benefited from Russian gas to the tune of 167 Gm3 in 2013 - MPs claim that it is not a reliable partner, even if they are unable to cite even one example of a contract that has not been complied with so far by the Russian Federation. The European Union, through this report, therefore proclaims its preference for submission to American multinationals - in the logic of TTIP - Turkish and Qatari, which, it is true, have always shown unfailing reliability in respecting the interests of third countries. With this in mind, the report foresees the increase in the importation of shale gas from American soils, a most environmentally friendly prospect that must have pleased our friends the Greens. Finally, the report clearly sets out the will to achieve the single energy market, to the detriment of the energy independence of the Member States, but also of the consumers.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Energy security remains the great challenge that the European Union will face for the coming years. The instability in the regions that provide us with energy makes it necessary to achieve an energy union that can be achieved by defining a long-term strategy that will chart the path to increase domestic production. In this scenario it is essential not only to increase the production capacity and storage of renewable energies but also energy efficiency, where there are major critical issues considering that it is difficult to reach the target of 20% by 2020.  Efforts and commitment are needed at all levels, especially on the part of local authorities, which could provide a significant boost to invest in sustainable public transport and to make public buildings more efficient. The Structural and Investment Funds for 2014-2020 can be a very important financial source for achieving these actions and for triggering that energy mix that allows us to move towards a low-carbon economy and achieve European targets.  For these reasons, I voted in favour, but unfortunately the text did not achieve a majority in this House.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 "The European Union, which is currently at an energy impasse, has the opportunity and the opportunity to exploit Cyprus and its natural resources in the Eastern Mediterranean. In addition, it will be able to exploit the Cyprus-Greece-Israel energy axis which has enormous energy potential where Europe can truly gain energy and gain access to both the Eastern Mediterranean and the Middle East. It is very important and necessary to include Cyprus and the Eastern Mediterranean in the EU's Energy Planning. Energy costs will also be reduced "reducing energy dependency while increasing investment and creating new jobs".

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained on the European energy security strategy because, although I agree with the basic approach of rational and effective use of energy, so as to create an energy security situation that will enable the Union to emancipate itself politically from the yoke of its own needs, I felt that I could not speak in favour of certain points. I do not agree with the total demonisation of the use of shale gas, which could help to relieve us at least in part of our dependence on unsusable countries. To call it even an unpromising technology before its potential virtues and potential dangers have been scientifically explored seems to me to be frankly exaggerated. Nor do I agree with what has been said about nuclear energy because, although the subject does not directly concern Italy, I believe that the countries that have used this technology have had advantages and, aware of the risks inherent in this type of source, I am once again opposed to demonization outright.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Energy demand is increasing globally and is expected to increase by 27% by 2030. Currently, more than 50% of the EU's energy needs are covered by external suppliers, which makes the EU vulnerable to its energy policy.  I believe that a common, coordinated and strong strategy on the part of the EU is vital, so that, on the one hand, it moderates demand through energy efficiency and, on the other hand, to increase own energy production and to define measures towards an integrated, coordinated and effective internal energy market. The current geopolitics has demonstrated what the European Parliament has been announcing on several times. Partners in the East are unreliable when using energy supply as a political weapon. It is therefore necessary to diversify sources and supply routes, also increasing efforts in the implementation of strategic energy infrastructure projects for Europe. I regret that not all Member States are always committed to the objective of interconnectivity of networks and systems, in particular in connecting the Iberian Peninsula to the rest of the EU. There is an urgent need to put an end to the phenomenon of energy islands!

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 Energy security means political independence, independence of sovereign states, stabilisation of economic growth and democracy in Europe. Given that the EU still imports 53% of its energy needs, mainly from geopolitically unstable regions, and that some Member States depend on a single external source of energy supply, the use of oil and natural gas for foreign policy purposes undermines economic growth and EU stability. Therefore, the signing of an additional protocol would make it possible to establish a long-term strategy to promote the EU's energy independence, increase the bargaining power of Member States, develop energy technologies, diversify and consolidate supply options, increase consumption efficiency and develop interconnections in order to connect regional energy markets. In this context, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is in urgent need of a framework for improved energy security, especially in the current geopolitical context. Europe’s dependence on energy resources has an influence on pursuing an independent foreign policy, the competitiveness of the industry and the standard of citizens’ daily lives.  The report focuses on long-term strategic objectives and includes concrete actions to moderate energy demand, increase indigenous energy production, develop energy technologies, and ensure further action to build a fully integrated and well-functioning internal energy market as well as solidarity and coordination mechanisms. The report also emphasises the need for structures which provide consumers with access to electricity at the best price. I have thus voted in favour of this report.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it bases European energy security on two pillars to which I oppose it. The first is to strengthen the EU's aggressive trade and foreign policy, with its pressures, impositions and attacks on our neighbours to access its energy resources. This is a voracious and short-sighted strategy that only contributes to destabilizing them and which we oppose, because only a project of development and mutual collaboration can be the basis of trade relations between sovereign states. The second is the impetus given to energy as dangerous as nuclear energy in the context of the energy transition. On the contrary, there are own resources, such as coal, that can be developed as a complement to renewable energy and environmental efficiency to reduce our energy dependence. For this reason, we defend the maintenance of production and generation aids with local coal, improvements in their combustion techniques (investing in thermal renewal) and a commitment to the technological development of new harvesting and capture techniques related to their combustion cycle.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 Security of energy supply is one of the eu's biggest challenges and, without a doubt, Central and Eastern Europe is now the most vulnerable and vulnerable. We need to change this situation together. It is our duty to increase security of supply. The Saudargas report provided good guidance on the direction in which we should proceed. However, in the plenary vote, an amendment was voted on by some party groups condemning the technology used in research into non-conventional energy sources and recommending member states not to allow research and extraction of non-conventional energy sources until it is found to be completely safe.  In line with the People's Party position, I abstained from voting for this report because, on the one hand, licensing mining activities is a competence of the Member States and, on the other hand, I consider it of the utmost importance that all possible domestic resources be sought in order to increase security of supply in Europe, while complying with mandatory standards.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Energy Security Strategy as I believe that this is the first step towards a fully functioning Energy Union. The path to energy security lies in investing in energy efficiency, promoting renewables and developing green technology whilst creating more jobs.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 Energy efficiency is the world's first fuel, due to the lowest cost, is available and sustainable, and I therefore believe that Union policies must set clear targets for measures to increase energy efficiency and promote investment in energy efficiency because they bring important long-term gains for security of supply at European level.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This initiative report follows the adoption by the European Commission of a European energy security strategy in May 2014 following the crisis in Ukraine. The full dimension of the Energy Union project, energy security must be based on three main and complementary actions, namely limiting energy demand, increasing indigenous energy production, research and development in energy technologies. It is also necessary to complement the integration of the internal energy market and strengthen the diversification of internal sources of supply.  I fully support these objectives, however, the report proposed to the plenary seemed to me prescriptive, unrealistic and limiting. Indeed, this text largely limits the possibilities of strengthening European energy security through the exploitation of Europe's indigenous resources. In addition, it prescribes binding energy efficiency targets of 40% by 2030. As such, I am in favour of 30% targets, which I think are more realistic. For these reasons, I voted against this initiative report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. With this vote, I supported the European Commission's desire to put in place a clear energy security strategy. It is essential that the European institutions commit themselves to a European Energy Union with defined guidelines. This European energy security strategy must be in line with an ambitious climate policy. I regretted the European Parliament's inability to find a strong agreement which led to the rejection of this report and deprived us of our voice on this subject.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the European energy security strategy is an opportunity to consider the strong situation in Europe.  This is a sensitive debate, and we need to find a balanced approach between the need to develop a green vision of the economy and society, and on the other hand the demands of European industry. In this context, security is certainly one of the fundamental elements to be considered for future generations as well.  It is necessary to start from some considerations on the progress made in recent years on the differentiation of energy sources: in fact, thanks to the increase in renewable sources, dependence on less safe sources such as nuclear power is greatly decreasing. On the other hand, with regard to the issue of geopolitical security: then there is a second reasoning to be made, which concerns dependence on a trading partner: the Russian Federation. Today, the European Union is highly dependent on oil, gas, coal and uranium. It is therefore necessary to step up efforts towards greater diversification, which also entails a reduction in cost and risk. I therefore believe that we need to intensify a debate on this, both for reasons of economic opportunity and for the proper protection of consumer rights.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. It is regrettable that this report has been rejected.  Energy security is essential for the Union. Currently, Member States import 53% of the energy they consume. It is far too much dependence on foreigners. That is why we must make progress towards achieving a true energy union aimed at ensuring our independence. We also need to diversify our sources of supply, with a clear focus on the development of clean, renewable and innovative energy.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 Security of energy security is one of the biggest challenges facing the European Union. The gas crises of 2006 and 2009 made it clear that Central and Eastern Europe is now the most vulnerable. We need to change this situation together, we have a duty to increase security of supply. In my opinion, the Saudargas report voted on by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy provided good guidance on the direction in which we should proceed. However, in the plenary vote, an amendment was voted on by some party groups condemning the technology used in research into non-conventional energy sources and recommending member states not to allow non-conventional energy sources to be researched and extracted until they are found to be completely safe. In line with the people's party's position, as a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I abstained from voting on the report because, on the one hand, the authorisation of mining activities is a competence of the Member States and, on the other hand, I consider it of the utmost importance that all possible domestic resources be sought in order to increase security of supply in Europe, while complying with mandatory standards.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. The European Parliament unfortunately rejected this report, which aimed to increase security and reduce dependence on imported fossil fuels.  The text called for actions, including to moderate energy demand and increase local energy production while reducing carbon emissions. It is important to take further action in order to build a fully integrated and synchronized system, to set up mechanisms of solidarity and coordination and to ensure the proper functioning of the internal energy market.  Ensuring the EU's energy security must be at the heart of our long-term energy strategy. It is the cornerstone for a fully open and free common energy market, which ensures compliance with environmental standards while boosting economic competitiveness. Member States would now have access to cleaner and more cost-effective resources without relying on politically and economically unreliable third-country suppliers.  It is appalling that this report, which I personally supported, was rejected. This only increases doubt about Parliament's ability to move forward on issues of concern to European citizens.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – Ensuring security of energy supply is one of the biggest challenges facing the European Union. The gas crises of 2006 and 2009 made it clear that Central and Eastern Europe is now the most vulnerable. We need to change this situation together. It is our duty to increase security of supply. In my opinion, the Saudargas report voted on by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy provided good guidance on the direction in which we should proceed. However, in the plenary vote, an amendment was voted on by some party groups condemning the technology used in research into non-conventional energy sources and recommending member states not to allow research and extraction of non-conventional energy sources until it is found to be completely safe.  In line with the people's party's position, as a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I abstained from voting on the report because, on the one hand, the authorisation of mining activities is a competence of the Member States and, on the other hand, I consider it of the utmost importance that all possible domestic resources be sought in order to increase security of supply in Europe, while complying with mandatory standards.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this focus on efforts aimed at improving energy security across the Member States. The presence of an energy supply that is stable and affordable in EU regions is of vital importance to national economies, to consumers and to households, including those most vulnerable.  The recent drop in oil and fuel prices has come as welcome news to motorists and homeowners seeking to heat their homes. However, there are very real fears that the positive impacts of these reductions have not been felt nearly enough – and particularly by those working in agriculture and construction, who have not enjoyed subsequent cuts in their input costs. This is worrying and requires both national and EU attention. Of course, greater supply can aid this, and it is vital that T-ENE Projects of Common Interest (PCI) start to receive crucial funding to carry out projects that stand to ensure better regional, national and trans-national connectivity in terms of the energy market. At the core of this are many exciting projects, including a number in my own constituency, Northern Ireland, that stand to consolidate supply and storage in renewables, with potentially transformative impacts for consumers and businesses, including in rural areas.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the European Energy Security Strategy. Once again, this report is written on the basis of ideological motivations and stereotypes. It aims at the energy independence of the Union from Russia, and turning to American imports. It is becoming urgent that the members of the majority seek out the interests of the citizens of the Member States with the utmost coherence and logic, taking into account the technical and geographical factors of imports. Unlike those Members who have chosen to demonstrate their friendship with the United States and their disagreement with Russia, I have chosen to focus on the States capable of providing energy to the French in the best possible conditions.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as the EU must certainly on the one hand focus on new energy sources, such as wind and solar, giving more incentives to achieve this objective, while at the same time stopping the promotion of environmentally harmful sources such as hydraulic fracturing and not serving the interests of third parties. And all this for the benefit of Europe and its citizens. But Russia is also an important ally, which some Europeans do not count and which is both strategically and geopolitically in Europe.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 Security of energy security is one of the biggest challenges facing the European Union. The gas crises of 2006 and 2009 made it clear that Central and Eastern Europe is now the most vulnerable. We need to change this situation together, we have a duty to increase security of supply. In my opinion, the Saudargas report voted on by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy provided good guidance on the direction in which we should proceed. However, in the plenary vote, an amendment was voted on by some party groups condemning the technology used in research into unconventional energy sources and recommending member states not to allow non-conventional energy sources to be researched and extracted until it is found to be completely safe. In line with the people's party's position, as a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I abstained from voting on the report because, on the one hand, the authorisation of mining activities is a competence of the Member States and, on the other hand, I consider it of the utmost importance that all possible domestic resources be sought in order to increase security of supply in Europe, while complying with mandatory standards.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 The strategy was adopted by the Commission on 28 May 2014, following a request from the European Council to establish a short- and long-term action plan to reduce energy dependence on foreign countries. The initial text focused in particular on fossil fuels, relifiers, drilling, new pipelines and carbon storage. The Commission communication has a clear political orientation: to try to give up Russian gas as much as possible through other sources of supply and, at the same time, to increase domestic energy production, particularly through nuclear power and fossil fuel extraction. This goes hand in hand with the financing of new cross-border infrastructure works, which should improve the interconnection of the European energy network.  As M5S, we have managed to amend the text by adding key concepts such as appropriations for the energy redevelopment of buildings, emphasising the importance of renewables for European energy security, supporting the moratorium on fracking in the EU and the elimination of fossil and nuclear subsidies. Unfortunately, the final text, while approving the moratorium on fracking and the energy redevelopment of buildings, nonetheless has several negative elements, such as public subsidies for nuclear energy and the excessive demonisation of Russia. I voted against.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The EU's excessive dependence on Russian imports, demand moderation, prices, renewable energy, the completion of a fully integrated internal energy market, electricity and gas interconnection levels and investments are some of the issues covered in this report. It is resothing that the EU imports 53% of its total energy consumption. The main challenges in this sector are the creation of an Energy Union, the moderation of demand, the increase in own energy production, the development of energy technologies, the achievement of a fully integrated internal energy market, the diversification of external supply and the need for coordination and solidarity between all Member States.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this text because, under the false pretext of diversifying the energy supplies of the Member States of the European Union, it aims to distance Russia from our relations, when it should be a privileged partner.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The report contains some guidelines that deserve our agreement. Emphasis is placed on the exclusive competence of Member States in defining their energy ranges, the need to find solutions and commitments in terms of technologies (technologically neutral approach) and prices, which enable them to sustain reindustrialisation processes, or the key role of renewable energies. Other guidelines give us serious doubts and others still deserve our frontal disagreement and opposition. A vision that attributes to the market the decisive role in the management of energy issues, even if mitigated by possible mechanisms of solidarity; the transformation of consumers into energy asset investors; the absence of a clear and specific reference to the issue of the lack of energy resources (in the case of fossil fuels); the null and void consideration of strong State intervention, in particular in energy production and distribution and planning. In an overall assessment, however, it is the negative and even very negative aspects that prevail, eventually having a clearly greater weight than anything positive that the resolution can have.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: in writing. The European Commission has proposed to establish a European energy strategy in the wake of the Ukraine crisis. The EU relies on a stable and abundant energy supply to ensure its prosperity and security. Energy security problems are often directed only at national level without fully regard to Member States' interdependencies at the energy level. That is why the development of this strategy is fundamental for the EU. Although the report is generally positive after the adoption of the amendments, it is recommended that certain limits be set on energy sources and mechanisms which I believe may prejudice European interests; that is why I abstained in the vote on the report.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 The importance of energy security has been highlighted by the current crisis in Ukraine. Energy policy has thus become one of the strategic priorities of foreign affairs. It is therefore the EU's duty to develop energy policy on the basis of close coordination of opinions and uniform action. In addition to pursuing the energy security objective, the Energy Union should develop on the basis of a comprehensive approach and focus on completing a fully integrated internal energy market, reducing carbon emissions in the energy mix, reducing energy demand, but also research and innovation.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Another report that puts the EU out of the world games. Instead of wanting to build a global dialogue on this issue, we prefer to put the stakes on our businesses and companies.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report because I believe that we urgently need a European energy security strategy if we do not want to be vulnerable to supply disruptions, whether caused by political or commercial disputes or by infrastructure failures. The path to energy security lies in energy transition, in putting energy efficiency first, in promoting renewables and in investing the money we currently spend on expensive imports domestically to develop our green technologies industry and create more jobs. This is why I would like to state my support for the amendment that we tabled regarding the inopportunity of continuing with authorisation for new shale gas activities by Member States, clearly dangerous for the European environment.  It is indeed clear that we should focus more on investing in infrastructure if we want to increase energy security and reduce costly imports of energy from outside the EU.  I would like to welcome the inclusion in the report of higher 2030 targets for energy efficiency and renewable energy than those agreed upon by the European Council. This is an achievement by my Group that I consider to be of the utmost importance.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. – Ensuring security of energy supply is one of the biggest challenges facing the European Union. The gas crises of 2006 and 2009 made it clear that Central and Eastern Europe is now the most vulnerable. We need to change this situation together, we have a duty to increase security of supply. In my opinion, the Saudargas report voted on by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy provided good guidance on the direction in which we should proceed. However, in the plenary vote, an amendment was voted on by some party groups condemning the technology used in research into unconventional energy sources and recommending member states not to allow non-conventional energy sources to be researched and extracted until it is found to be completely safe. In line with the people's party's position, as a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I abstained from voting on the report because, on the one hand, the authorisation of mining activities is a competence of the Member States and, on the other hand, I consider it of the utmost importance that all possible domestic resources be sought in order to increase security of supply in Europe, while complying with mandatory standards.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 Security of energy security is one of the biggest challenges facing the European Union. The gas crises of 2006 and 2009 made it clear that Central and Eastern Europe is now the most vulnerable. We need to change this situation together, we have a duty to increase security of supply. In my opinion, the Saudargas report voted on by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy provided good guidance on the direction in which we should proceed. However, in the plenary vote, an amendment was voted on by some party groups condemning the technology used in research into unconventional energy sources and recommending member states not to allow non-conventional energy sources to be researched and extracted until it is found to be completely safe. In line with the people's party's position, as a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I abstained from voting on the report because, on the one hand, the authorisation of mining activities is a competence of the Member States and, on the other hand, I consider it of the utmost importance that all possible domestic resources be sought in order to increase security of supply in Europe, while complying with mandatory standards.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. With the situation of political instability in Ukraine, the European Union is now more aware than ever of the importance of energy security. The EU and its Member States are vulnerable in the geopolitical context, so energy policy has become one of the priorities of foreign affairs. Although considerable progress has been made in recent years, the EU still faces a number of challenges, including instability in energy-supplying regions and a fragmented internal market. Therefore, in order to face such significant challenges, the EU must develop a long-term strategy that will enable it to address present and future energy challenges, an east sector of significant importance for the well-being of citizens and economic growth. For these reasons I voted in favour.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialists regret that the Saudargas report has not been adopted because, thanks to the intensive work in committee, the report was committed to a new energy model for Europe, a sustainable and equitable model. During the vote in plenary, the Socialists had managed to cover a majority on three essential points, two of them at the request of the Spanish Socialist delegation: (1) a majority in favour of asking the Commission to submit a Communication on energy poverty, accompanied by an action plan to combat it; (2) a majority in favour of asking Governments not to authorize any new fracking operations in the EU until such actions are shown to be safe for the environment, workers and the general population; and (3) a majority in favour of more ambitious targets in renewable energy, energy efficiency and climate change, and that these were also binding.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialists regret that the Saudargas report has not been adopted because, thanks to the intensive work in committee, the report was committed to a new energy model for Europe, a sustainable and equitable model. During the vote in plenary, the Socialists had managed to cover a majority on three essential points, two of them at the request of the Spanish Socialist delegation: (1) a majority in favour of asking the Commission to submit a Communication on energy poverty, accompanied by an action plan to combat it; (2) a majority in favour of asking Governments not to authorize any new fracking operations in the EU until such actions are shown to be safe for the environment, workers and the general population; and (3) a majority in favour of more ambitious targets in renewable energy, energy efficiency and climate change, and that these were also binding.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. The Ukrainian crisis, as well as the recent reference to Gazprom, have undoubtedly been two important alarm bells that the Eu ropean Union cannot and must not underestimate.  In the light of all this, and with data on energy imports that stand at 53% in the EU (and which unfortunately see Italy, even more exposed, with energy imports for 80% of consumption needs) trying to act with the utmost urgency to implement a European energy security strategy can only be a plan not only acceptable, but today increasingly urgent , necessary and priority. I therefore wholeheartedly support Mr Saudargas' report, which highlights the main emergencies that we are committed to combating and, above all, the actions and measures that the EU and its Member States must take as soon as possible to reduce energy demand and create an internal market that protects us from any political speculation on energy supplies.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European energy security strategy in the EU, because the creation of a single energy market is a key issue, responding to economic, industrial, environmental and geopolitical challenges. The EU currently imports 53% of its total energy consumption, mainly oil, gas and solid fuels, from countries with complex geopolitical situations. The Russian crisis once again shows the dangers of dependence on a single source of supply.  This situation is untenable both politically and environmentally. The diversification of energy sources is, in fact, an essential condition for reducing dependence on fossil fuels. We need a new energy paradigm, a new vision for the future, which aims at European renewable energy production, energy efficiency and demand moderation, combining productive, economic and environmental objectives. I also agree with the reference to the role of local authorities in defining the energy policies of the territories.  It is precisely in this regard that I voted with conviction for the S&D Group's call for a moratorium on drilling and shale gas. The diversification of sources must not, in fact, put environmental protection at risk, and states have a duty to protect our seas, listening to the voice of those territories with a great tourist vocation.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The EU imports 53% of its total energy consumption, 85% of its oil, 67% of its natural gas, 41% of its solid fuels and about 95% of its uranium. The current dependence prevents a detached foreign policy and limits the competitiveness of industry. This dependency must be reduced. The aim is to ensure security of supply, affordable energy prices and the achievement of our climate targets at the same time. This requires a number of measures: energy efficiency must be increased and energy consumption must be reduced overall. In addition, domestic energy production is to be expanded. To this end, further investment will be made in research. We also need a fully integrated internal energy market. Energy supply has so far been decided at national level, without taking full account of the interdependence of the Member States. This will limit the EU's ability to respond as a whole to supply bottlenecks and threats to energy security. A united approach to external energy policy would give individual countries a better negotiating position. Another essential point is the diversification of energy suppliers. This must be implemented consistently, so that foreign policy is not influenced by energy policy dependencies and geopolitical developments such as those currently taking place in Russia and Ukraine do not jeopardise our energy supply. These guidelines should ensure energy supply both in the short and long term.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Saudargas report because it is clear to me that the path to energy security lies in energy transition, putting energy efficiency first, promoting renewables, and investing money domestically to develop our green technologies industry and create jobs rather than wasting scarce resources on expensive imports.  That is why I find it baffling that conservatives in Parliament, including Tories, voted down plans to guarantee European energy security. Given our current dependence on energy imports from unreliable partners like Russia, the enormous threat posed to our security by climate change, and the crucial importance of the renewables and green energy sector for the real economy, I find their decision to side with vested interests rather than standing behind the well-being of our citizens completely incomprehensible.  By establishing an ambitious energy security strategy, the EU can play a crucial role in protecting our citizens against the possibly devastating consequences of sudden disruptions of gas supplies, as already experienced by some Member States which were hit hard by disruptions in the winters of 2006 and 2009, and put us firmly on the path towards sustainable job creation.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. It is sad to see that the European Parliament has not been able to agree on what the European Energy Security Strategy should be. I voted in favour of a text containing many valuable elements to reduce our energy dependence abroad, such as improving energy efficiency, developing the infrastructures needed to achieve a true internal energy market that integrates so-called energy islands, diversification of supply or the development of indigenous sources. Energy is one of the many areas in which a European approach can generate added value, but this requires agreeing on a common policy. We must continue to work together to avoid results like today's, where discrepancies have prevailed over the ideas we all share.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I acknowledge that the EU’s environmental targets and energy security objectives are not entirely independent policy areas, I believe it is important that Member States decide their own energy mixes. Fully renewable energy sources are insufficient if the EU is to meet its carbon reduction targets and alternative energy sources can play an important, intermediately step in this process and at the same time reduce our dependence on external energy sources. This report should focus on reducing our foreign energy dependency in the context of an energy union whilst Member States should then be able to determine their energy mix whilst committing to the EU’s environmental targets. If this reports deviates away from its original function, we will end up with overlapping regulation whilst infringing on the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because energy policy must be tackled with an effective strategy. More than half of our energy needs are imported from third countries. In 2013, 39% of gas imports came from Russia, 33% from Norway and 22% from the countries of North Africa, Algeria and Libya. If we look today at the situation of our partners, we understand the urgent need to emancipate ourselves. Russia's black list is just the latest demonstration of the need to diversify external supply. Global geopolitics is changing, the effects on Europe are manifesting themselves at several levels. The energy sector is one of those that suffers the most, hence the need to reform it. For the security and well-being of our citizens, energy must exploit new technologies, not old diplomatic relations.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against the text on the basis that it advocates a supposed diversification of the energy matrix based on the continuity of the use of conventional hydrocarbons, the exploitation of unconventional hydrocarbons through techniques such as fracking, the achievement of gas megaprojects and the maintenance of renewable energies. The text clearly departs from the necessary commitment to an energy model change and seeks to operate a false transition based on low-carbon technologies whose use pernnizes the current dirty, dependent, unsustainable, asymmetrical, socially unfair and warrior model. Moreover, the text does not sufficiently defend measures to meet emission reduction, boost to renewable energy and energy efficiency targets.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the path to energy security lies in the energy transition, putting energy efficiency first, promoting renewables and investing domestically the money currently spent on expensive imports, to develop our green technologies industry and create more jobs.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I abstained on this report. I support the project to create a European Energy Union based in particular on close coordination of Member States, an integrated internal market, the development of low-carbon technologies, the search for energy efficiency and support for the competitiveness of our businesses. The crisis in Ukraine has reminded the European Union of the importance of energy security and the crucial role it plays in strengthening Europe's political and economic position. However, despite a difficult geopolitical situation between the European Union and Russia, I hope that we will remain open to dialogue with this major energy partner. Furthermore, in order to develop our energy independence, it is important that we do not close the door to indigenous energy production in Europe. Each country must remain free to decide whether to ban or authorize the exploitation of these indigenous sources under conditions that are always very strict and environmentally friendly.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. We have voted in favour of the Saudarga report on European energy security. Some of the wordings used are very broad and therefore include both positive and negative elements, which can make it difficult to draw the line between a technical finding and a valuable message. There is also a difference between national policies, where we ourselves decide our energy mix, and a European perspective, where it can be seen that, for example, nuclear power will be used for a long time to come.  We would therefore like to point out that our intention, with references to low-carbon, low-carbon, low-carbon, .m.  We are looking for a development, at both Swedish and European level, with energy efficiency and renewable energy sources in focus and where the highest environmental and safety requirements are to be set throughout the production chain and that emissions should cost.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. Although the report had positive elements and was in line with the socialist position thanks to the work of the S&D group in the ITRE Commission, the document still raised certain problems with regard to the coal sector which have led me not to support it decisively and to opt out of abstention. The call to phase out incentives for indigenous coal or vagueness in differentiation and the lack of more determined support for clean coal are some of the elements I find problematic.  Since the European Commission has accepted that, by 2050, fossil fuels will continue to be part of the energy mix, we should take into account the social impact and employment of the end of aid to indigenous coal, and take decisive conversion action before opting for an end to them. Moreover, we should not hesitate to support those forms of clean coal and carbon storage systems (CCAs) that, like Elcogas in Puertollano, offer clean uses of fossil fuels. In this regard, we will continue to work to ensure that future initiatives are more sensitive to this sector.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 Security of energy security is one of the biggest challenges facing the European Union. The gas crises of 2006 and 2009 made it clear that Central and Eastern Europe is now the most vulnerable. We need to change this situation together. It is our duty to increase security of supply. In my opinion, the Saudargas report voted on by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy provided good guidance on the direction in which we should proceed. However, in the plenary vote, an amendment was voted on by some party groups condemning the technology used in research into non-conventional energy sources and recommending member states not to allow research and extraction of non-conventional energy sources until it is found to be completely safe.  In line with the people's party's position, as a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I abstained from voting for the report because, on the one hand, allowing mining activities is a competence of the Member States and, on the other hand, I consider it of the utmost importance that all possible domestic resources be sought in order to increase european security of supply, while complying with mandatory requirements.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the European energy security strategy. In particular, I voted for Amendments 6 and 1. Amendment 6 asks Member States not to proceed with fracking. Unfortunately Amendment 6 was not carried, but Amendment 1 was, and this asks Member States not to authorise any new fracking operations, either exploration or extraction, until the technology is proven safe for the environment and for workers. Parliament also supported the statement that we consider fracking entails risks and negative consequences for the climate, environment and public health. Unexpectedly the whole report was rejected by the Parliament, and these really useful amendments on fracking now no longer stand.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. Yesterday, Parliament voted on the European energy security strategy. The report focuses only on energy efficiency and renewable energy. What is completely overlooked is the issue of technology neutrality. As far as possible, we should keep open all options for technological solutions to the energy challenges of our time, such as decarbonisation of the economy and the reduction of energy dependence. Of course, we are in favour of greater efficiency and clean energy. However, we in Europe must also clear the way for nuclear energy and shale gas, especially if we want reindustrialisation. 70 new nuclear power plants are being built worldwide – also in Europe! Moreover, fracking should not be banned in general. Scientists say the environmental impacts are hyped. It is not scientifically and technically justified and unacceptable to impose a general ban. That is why I voted against.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ My party has a long-standing policy of opposition to nuclear power, and the Fukushima disaster has underlined the dangers of nuclear technology. Too many people in this House remain supportive of nuclear energy. I cannot support the idea of nuclear power remaining a long-term answer to the EU’s energy needs.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against the text on the basis that it advocates a supposed diversification of the energy matrix based on the continuity of the use of conventional hydrocarbons, the exploitation of unconventional hydrocarbons through techniques such as fracking, the achievement of gas megaprojects and the maintenance of renewable energies. The text clearly departs from the necessary commitment to an energy model change and seeks to operate a false transition based on low-carbon technologies whose use pernnizes the current dirty, dependent, unsustainable, asymmetrical, socially unfair and warrior model. Moreover, the text does not sufficiently defend measures to meet emission reduction, boost to renewable energy and energy efficiency targets.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. \u2012 Considerable progress has been made in recent years in strengthening energy security, in particular by increasing the share of renewable energy. Firstly, we must stress the importance of energy efficiency, the promotion of renewable energies and investment in the internal market. We can develop our green technology industry and thus create more jobs. The report stresses that the potential of energy savings covers all sectors of the economy, including industry, construction, transport, agriculture and services.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on a European energy security strategy due to the importance of the Single Energy Policy and the Single European Market to make the European Union's energy system, globally, sustainable and competitive. In this context, it is necessary to reduce energy dependency, develop new energy technologies, strengthen the internal energy market and diversify external energy sources and routes.  It is necessary, however, to stress the importance of regional energy markets in the context of regional integration, which are the basis for energy security. I also agree with the need to implement strategic energy infrastructure projects for the sensitivity of the energy market, and I support greater coordination of different positions to contribute to a clearer and stronger EU energy stance.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I voted against this text for two main reasons: ideological and principled hostility towards Russia, and interference in the policies of the Member States it supports. The rapporteur of this text was Lithuania's foreign minister during the 1990s, which partly explains his characterized Russophobia.
