He therefore advocates turning entirely to the United States in order to put an end to energy dependence on Russia. He argues that it would be an unreliable partner, without ever giving a concrete example of a broken contract. All the more so since, despite the tense geopolitical situation, Russia has further increased its natural gas exports to the EU countries. Rather than relying on Russian gas, this text wants Europe to depend on US or Qatari shale gas, which is geopolitically questionable and ecologically unacceptable, as hydraulic fracturing destroys ecosystems and pollutes water sources. Finally, the rapporteur wants to liberalise energy supply in Europe, by taking away the possibility of regulating tariffs or protectionist policies for their industries.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The need to increase its energy security has been discussed for many years within the Union. Progress has undoubtedly been achieved, but much remains to be done. The mere fact that there is still insufficient transmission infrastructure between Member States and, consequently, the so-called energy islands, shows how much neglect we are facing. How can we talk about the Union's energy security if, in practice, there is no interconnected area in this dimension? It therefore seems that it is in this direction that our activity should go first. If we create a coherent energy area from the Union, it will be easier for us to deepen cooperation, whether by establishing an Energy Union or by creating real solidarity mechanisms.  Unfortunately, in the end, I was forced to vote against the report on the energy security strategy because of the very unfavourable provisions on coal mining, shale gas or the use of nuclear energy. On the other hand, I believe that it is only through the intelligent use of indigenous natural deposits that Europe will be able to ensure its energy security. It is therefore necessary to support sources such as coal and shale gas.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted against the report by my colleague Algirdas Saudargas on the European energy security strategy. This report promotes the escalation of tensions between Russia and the European Union by reminding that Russia cannot be a reliable partner, while Russia remains an indispensable partner in the energy field. The report also proposed the phasing out of nuclear power plants, an unrealistic proposal since alternative energy sources would be highly CO2-emitting and/or would compromise European energy independence. The report was rejected by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The current geopolitical situation is urging the EU to step up its efforts to create a self-sufficient energy market and ensure energy security for European citizens. More than half of the energy consumed in Europe today comes from imports, and many Member States source energy from a single source or from a single external supplier. Meanwhile, the crisis in Ukraine and Russia's behaviour have shown how unbelievable it is and how much it can flout our rules.  It is necessary to find new sources of energy and its new, stable suppliers and, perhaps above all, to develop the internal energy market. The Energy Security Strategy must be a long-term strategy that takes into account a wide variety of aspects, such as increasing local energy production and rational distribution, technological development and modernisation of existing production units, innovation in renewable energy and social campaigns to encourage sustainable, energy efficiency. We must also not forget the potential of the agricultural sector in this area – biofuel production must be an important element of the energy strategy. A proper energy policy of the European Union is a policy in which we remember solidarity and mutual trust; a policy in which we are united and in negotiations with third countries we present a common position.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am opposed to this report because it is very critical of Russia, which is still one of the most important energy suppliers to Europe and without whose cooperation it will not be possible to provide robust energy security. Furthermore, this report emphasises the positive aspects of nuclear energy, so that, as an Austrian, I must take a clear position against it.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Energy Security Strategy at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, which the Commission should take into account when drafting legislation in this area. The aim and main focus of the report was to put an end to the European Union's energydependency on Russia, which was defined as an unreliable trading partner. The report also stresses the need to use the energy resources available in the Member States and to invest in energy saving. Unfortunately, the Left of the European Parliament chose to act destructively and tabled a huge amount of amendments which lost the main meaning of the report: achieving energy security. As a result, there were not enough votes for the report to be adopted.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. One of the EU’s biggest problems is its energy dependence on third countries. This often affects EU decisions, making them milder than need be. Russia has in the past literally blackmailed the EU with energy and seems set to continue this practice. This report set out a range of policy lines and measures to increase EU independence from external energy. In light of growing instability in several of the countries that supply the EU with gas and oil, we cannot delay finding realistic alternatives. I regret that the outcome of the vote was negative. I do not believe that the EP is against diversifying energy sources or against calling for an EU energy security strategy, but unfortunately with this vote the EP got trapped along rigid lines. Nevertheless, I hope that the Commission will take the question of energy security very seriously and will come up with real policy solutions soon. And when they do so, I hope that the EP will engage in a more constructive debate than we have seen today.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report and am extremely disappointed it was voted down by UKIP and the Tories, as it would have helped thousands of people across the Europe out of energy poverty. The EU currently imports more than half of all the energy it consumes at a cost of more than EUR 1 billion per day – this cannot go on. Labour MEPs want to make sure the UK’s energy security is reinforced by reducing our dependency on fossil fuel imports and developing renewable technologies. We are pro—business and pro—environment and know it is crucial to boost investment in renewable energy across Europe.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 Security of energy security is one of the biggest challenges facing the European Union. The gas crises of 2006 and 2009 made it clear that Central and Eastern Europe is now the most vulnerable. We need to change this situation together, we have a duty to increase security of supply. In my opinion, the Saudargas report voted on by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy provided good guidance on the direction in which we should proceed. However, in the plenary vote, an amendment was voted on by some party groups condemning the technology used in research into unconventional energy sources and recommending member states not to allow non-conventional energy sources to be researched and extracted until it is found to be completely safe. In line with the people's party's position, as a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I abstained from voting on the report because, on the one hand, the authorisation of mining activities is a competence of the Member States and, on the other hand, I consider it of the utmost importance that all possible domestic resources be sought in order to increase security of supply in Europe, while complying with mandatory standards.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ Energy is a public social good and should therefore not be regarded within a profit—making framework. I voted against the Saudargas report as there are many points that undermine the commitment towards a sustainable energy model. The fact that the report makes reference to the use of nuclear energy is unacceptable, and such a reference should not be made anywhere in the EU. Additionally, the aim of an energy strategy should be to cover the needs of the people through necessary infrastructures and energy interconnections. It is to this extent that cooperation with Russia and other third countries should be promoted, while the report is completely against this line of cooperation; it seems it is only strong capital forces that could benefit from a single energy policy, and not Member States and their citizens.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: Writing. – Both professionally and from the point of view of the well-being and security of European citizens, the whole energy law so far is highly debatable and, in the opinion of independent experts, subordinate to economic and global political interests outside Europe. The report is also teeming with slips and does not provide real solutions, and it puts undue burdens on taxpayers, making it unacceptable, apart from some of its parts. Energy security requires a very complex technical, economic and political approach, which in a calmer political climate would have been much more likely than it is now.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: Written. \u2012 The report rightly highlighted important points in terms of energy security, such as the need to diversify gas imports. One way of diversifying import routes was highlighted in the report by increasing the terminal network for liquid natural gas (paragraph 31). Unfortunately, the point focused geographically on the Mediterranean and Black Sea region, while ignoring the potential of LNG terminals in the Baltic Sea region for the development of security of supply, industrial competitiveness and cleanliness of maritime transport. I voted in favour of this report and regret its fall. With a view to preparing the Energy Union, the Baltic Sea region must be borne in mind.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: in writing. ‒ The EU’s dependency on energy imports diminishes its energy security, as seen in 2009 Russian-Ukrainian gas crisis. This is apparent due to the persistently negative energy trade balance. Today, of Europe’s gas consumption, 60% is imported – nearly half of that from Russia. More than 30% of oil is also imported from Russia. Well-developed and interconnected gas infrastructure is one of prerequisites for reducing Member States’ vulnerability in relation to disruptions from a single or/and dominant energy supplier. We have to achieve an internal energy market, also through transparency, competition and synchronisation and by building closer links with the US liquefied natural gas (LNG) market. Early notification of bilateral agreements with Russian energy companies must be applied in every case and collective purchasing system for energy should be established. This would prevent Russian state-owned companies from abusing their favourable positions and imposing unfair, diversified prices for the Member States. Finally, have to apply without hesitation the principle of rule of law to a dominant supplier, and to any energy company having a role in the EU energy market. Russian companies who want to have their share and benefits in the EU energy market must comply with established EU norms and rules.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I have chosen to abstain on the Saudargas report on the European Energy Security Strategy. Indeed, while certain provisions of this report, such as the development of energy technologies or the diversification of sources of supply, were positively involved in the establishment of a European energy market, I considered that it also had inappropriate provisions, for example by recommending a moratorium in principle on the exploitation of shale gas or the outright rejection of nuclear power.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In order to ensure energy security, emphasis should be placed on renewable energy sources, promoting energy efficiency and investing money to buy expensive imported fuel for the development of our green technology industry and job creation.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which is part of a context of hostility towards Russia (opening of proceedings against Gazprom). It states that this country is an "unreliable partner" without any real evidence. The European Union has never had to suffer from a breach of the contract that binds it to Russia regarding the delivery of gas.  The aim is to end contracts with Russia and turn to the United States - an approach that is part of the Transatlantic Market Negotiations (TTIP). This Commission project, beyond the desire to sever all dependency with Russia, will have negative consequences for consumers and Member States. Indeed, the liberal policy on which this report is based will cause an increase in tariffs and could jeopardize our industries (increased free competition) which will be subjected to speculation.  Added to this is the unacceptable will of the European Union to dictate the energy policy of the Member States without leaving them the choice of their sources of supply. On the contrary, we call for the establishment of free interstate cooperation, by restoring their energy sovereignty to states.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The report makes two mentions of coal: it calls for a reform of the ETS to provide an investment signal for the gradual abolition of the most polluting forms of energy generation, such as coal-based ones; commission calls on the Commission to introduce co2 emission performance standards and energy performance standards for new and existing nuclear and coal-fired power plants. The positions of the Spanish Socialist Delegation prevailed in the case of more ambitious renewable energy and efficiency targets by 2030 and greater support for CCS. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it bases European energy security on two pillars which I do not share. The first is to strengthen the EU's aggressive trade and foreign policy, with its pressures, impositions and attacks on our neighbours to access its energy resources. This is a voracious and short-sighted strategy that only contributes to destabilizing them and which we oppose, because only a project of development and mutual collaboration can be the basis of trade relations between sovereign states. The second is the impetus given to energy as dangerous as nuclear energy in the context of the energy transition. On the contrary, there are own resources, such as coal, that can be developed as a complement to renewable energy and environmental efficiency to reduce our energy dependence.  For this reason, we defend the maintenance of production and generation aids with local coal, improvements in their combustion techniques (investing in thermal renewal) and a commitment to the technological development of new harvesting and capture techniques related to their combustion cycle.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 A key priority in the implementation of the European Energy Security Strategy must be to ensure that no EU country is left without excessive interruptions in energy supply from a single supplier. That is why m.in need to diversify our sources of supply, to create more connections between Member States and to modernise existing transmission networks. In Poland, a significant part of the power plant and transmission networks are outdated, decapitalised and inef-efficiency. Poor technical infrastructure poses a very high threat to energy security. I would also like to draw attention to the issue of energy prices. Ensuring an adequate level of energy security in the EU should take into account the guarantee of affordable energy prices for all EU residents. For example, at present, given the differences in purchasing power between EU countries, Poles pay some of the highest energy prices. In addition, one in four EU citizens was affected by energy poverty in 2012. Citizens must also be adequately informed about energy prices, opportunities to improve energy efficiency and reduce energy consumption.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the EU's efforts to centrally regulate energy production across the EU. Under the pretext of solidarity, Member States with a stable energy network should help those who have chosen to build windmills and close nuclear power plants instead of ensuring energy security.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because the EU’s energy security is highly important in the current geopolitical context. The EU imports 53% of the energy it consumes, including almost 90% of its crude oil, and Russia is responsible for a third of our oil imports. We need to send a strong message to our trading partners that we are striving for energy independence. Member States have to unite and cut back on energy consumption, boost energy production and invest in renewable energy sources. It is clear that energy security will be a highly important factor when we are seated at the table of international negotiations with other global powers. I strongly believe that a sustainable energy landscape is the only way we can achieve energy security and keep energy prices low for our citizens. I am confident that, slowly but surely, the Energy Union will achieve energy independence and this will hopefully change the foreign policy of some Member States.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒The prosperity and security of the European Union depend on a stable energy supply. Each Member State is known to be concerned about energy security. In the winters of 2006 and 2009, temporary interruptions in energy supplies highlighted the vulnerability but also the need for a common European energy policy.  The indicators point to growing energy demand worldwide, with expectations that it will increase by 27 percent by 2030. Strengthening mechanisms and building smart grids would improve energy efficiency, decentralise the energy system and strengthen energy security in the Member States. New technologies, alternative energy sources and unconventional fuels will play an important role in diversifying energy sources to reduce dependence on foreign suppliers and diversify energy supply.  This is one of the key proposals proposed by the European Commission in its Communication on the Energy Union. Given that an amendment was adopted calling on Member States to ban research or extraction of unconventional fuels, stressing that they have limited potential, I did not support this report, which prolongs dependence on fossil fuels and the achievement of targets.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. The basic idea was good: to ensure stability in the EU's energy operation under the conditions of steady growth in energy consumption. Many positive ingredients: green energy, supplies that will lower prices for EU consumers... But, as is often the case, they ended up adding anti-Russian policy expressions, such as defining Russia as an unstable supplier of energy resources to the EU (I voted against that amendment). It is logical that it has been rejected by the European Parliament by 315 votes against, 277 in favour and 11 abstentions.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: writing \ u2012 Efforts to increase economic growth and increase the standard of living of the population increase demand for raw materials and energy and their resources. The European Union's energy security is thus becoming the key to its economic growth, competitiveness and its strong political and economic position. This requires, especially in the current geopolitical problems, to ensure a common energy policy on the part of the EU and its Member States, as an integral part of the EU's internal and external policies. The energy security strategy emphasises the search for ways of reducing energy intensity and increasing the share of domestic energy produced and developing new energy technologies, with the requirement for the existence of a well-functioning energy market.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the European energy security strategy, because I disagree with the content of this report for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 9/6/2015.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report to ensure that our energy security is consolidated by a reduction on dependency on fossil fuels and by the exploration of new technology to support energy supplies in the future. I am disappointed that it was not passed, as it also highlighted the need to tackle energy poverty and energy efficiency.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against it. This strategy aims to remove the European Union from its dependence on Russian energy by offering it as a pasture to the United States and Qatar. This strategy hopes to achieve the famous "Energy Union" through a "fully integrated internal energy market". In fact, this strategy will lead to an increase in tariffs for consumers (end of regulated tariffs), the breakdown of our industry (end of long-term supply contracts, free competition obliges) and will deprive Member States of the choice of their energy sources, their suppliers and their supply routes. We're against it.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained on the report on the European Energy Security Strategy.  I consider this to be an issue of great importance, because of its crucial role in confirming Europe's strong political and economic position, which is so sensitive, because of its specific nature and because of the different demands required by the various Member States, not only because of the high costs involved.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report on energy security in Europe. I fully agree that energy security should be a key element of EU trade policy. However, I believe that the Energy Union project is too ambitious and I am not convinced that we will find agreement at EU level on the support and preferences of different energy sources. In the long term, I vote differently from my faction, which has, for example, problems with the core. I am also sceptical about setting binding targets. Moreover, I still believe that the energy mix should remain in the hands of every Member State, which is why I could not support the report in today's vote.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the crisis in Ukraine in May 2014, the European Commission promoted a European energy security strategy. The ITRE Committee then decided to draw up an own-initiative report on the subject, entrusting Mr Saudargas with the direction of its preparation. Although I believe that it is necessary for the European Union to be the coordinator of national approaches to energy security, I am of the opinion that the text voted on in this House does not fully meet initial expectations. That is why I have chosen to abstain from voting on it.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. \u2012 We cannot continue to treat energy as a source of profit and income for multinationals and monopolies. Energy is a common good and any European energy strategy cannot fail to take that into account. In addition, the strategy set out in this report involves the defence of nuclear energy or the use of shale gas exploration. It is a fact that the report mentions a change in the energy model, but everything is nothing more than a deliberate and misleading mistake, because the so-called 'new' model for which one intends to change is a model of dependency, unsustainable, asymmetric and socially unfair, that is, the total opposite of what should be. I couldn't help but vote against it.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The European Parliament's report on the European Energy Security Strategy shows its support for the Commission's efforts to work in this key area for the EU. From the EPP we agree that we must establish a long-term strategy aimed also at moderating energy demand, increasing energy production in the EU and developing energy technologies, in order to develop an effective and fully integrated internal market, as well as mechanisms of solidarity and coordination. However, I can only abstain from voting on the proposal put forward, as I do not agree with regard to the position it reflects on the use of hydraulic fracturing or fracking by the Member States.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. The Saudargas report is part of a comprehensive strategy and provides elements of response to the major energy challenges facing Europe today. So we start on the basis of the previous Parliament, with ambitious binding targets for 2030: a reduction of at least 40% in greenhouse gas emissions, an increase of at least 30% in renewable energy production, and at least 40% in efficiency gains.  The report highlights the European Union's poor performance in terms of energy efficiency in line with its three targets. He attributes this delay to the heating and gas crises in Europe. In line with the convictions of our group and the French Socialists, the report aims to guarantee energy security by developing renewable energies, which have the advantage of being indigenous and clean. The text calls for cross-cutting approaches, particularly in transport, to meet these ambitions. It is because it is ambitious that I voted in favour of this report. Quite the opposite of much of the European right, desperately pro-business and pastist.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The Freedom Party of Austria is clearly opposed to an Energy Union. That is why I rejected the resolution.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as the energy mix of a country is a matter of national competence. I fully support the current moratorium on fracking in Ireland and support the government’s position that no decision will be made on any proposal for the use of hydraulic fracturing in exploratory drilling as part of an unconventional gas exploration programme until there has been time to consider the outcome of the research programme directed at examining the potential environmental and human health impacts of hydraulic fracturing commissioned by the Environmental Protection Agency.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The text defends the creation of an energy union. Far from taking into account the environmental aspects of energy consumption, the text defends the emissions trading system as a panacea. However, this system has failed to engage Europe in a genuine energy transition to replace the bulk of carbon-based energy with renewables.  As for the issue of supply, far from promoting the diversity of suppliers as a guarantee of security, the text is concerned about the Union's dependence on Russia, which "endangers the security of the Union". I am voting against this abstruse text, which is absolutely not in the fight against ecological catastrophe.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The rapporteur of this text was Lithuania's foreign minister during the 1990s, which partly explains his marked Russophobia. He therefore advocates turning entirely to the United States in order to put an end to energy dependence on Russia. He argues that it would be an unreliable partner, without ever giving a concrete example of a broken contract. All the more so since, despite the tense geopolitical situation, Russia has further increased its natural gas exports to the EU countries.  Rather than relying on Russian gas, this text wants Europe to depend on US or Qatari shale gas, which is geopolitically questionable and ecologically unacceptable, as hydraulic fracturing destroys ecosystems and pollutes water sources. Finally, the rapporteur wants to liberalise energy supply in Europe, by taking away the possibility of regulating tariffs or protectionist policies for their industries. This report contains an ideological hostility towards Russia and interference in the policies of the Member States it supports. I voted against it.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ This report incorporates and tackles a wide variety of concerns, to ensure that a strong energy security strategy is achieved. As a representative from Malta, I support a comprehensive energy policy for Europe and recognise the importance of being connected to a well—supplied European energy grid.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing ‒ the European Union's energy security plays a key role in confirming Europe's strong political and economic position. As the European Commission has already outlined the main challenges in the energy security sector in May 2014, a political impetus from the European Parliament is now needed to outline a framework for improved energy security. Although the situation has improved compared to the past, so far the EU has been forced to import 53% of total energy consumption. It is therefore necessary to implement a long-term strategy that identifies strategic objectives with regard to Europe's energy security, built on key pillars for reducing energy demand. As the issue of energy security is often dealt with at Member State level, regardless of interdependence between Member States, I support the idea of a single European energy security for greater competitiveness of the European Union and a well-functioning internal energy market. On the issue of Russia's credibility as a trading partner, it can be seen that it uses energy for political purposes. I therefore support the idea that Member States should take a unified approach to foreign suppliers.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the European energy security strategy. The path to energy security lies in the energy transition: putting energy efficiency first, promoting renewables and investing domestically the money that is currently spent on expensive imports, in order to develop our green technologies industry and create more jobs. However, I voted against the amendments that ask Member States to refrain from shale gas activities, and on the binding EU energy efficiency target.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the European Energy Security Strategy, as I believe that it is essential for Europe to reduce its energy dependence on individual states in the future. I am disappointed that we have not been able to adopt this comprehensive and far-reaching strategy together. I am convinced that, if Europe is to achieve its self-imposed climate targets, it must diversify its energy sources in the long term, develop energy efficiency measures and switch to sustainable energy sources. That is precisely what this energy security strategy has called for, and it is a tragedy that the European Parliament has not spoken out today in favour of a secure energy future for Europe.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Given Europe’s current economic vulnerabilities, an excessive energy bill or having our energy supplies disrupted are risks that should be avoided. Nor can one accept the prospect of our citizens having to endure the cold of the winter because of the political machinations of some of our international energy providers. In this context, the aim of the present report was to complement what I consider to be an otherwise fairly balanced European Commission strategic guideline on how to deal with these challenges. I was largely in favour of an ambitious ITRE Committee position that emphasised energy efficiency, the completion of our internal energy market and a diversified energy supply and mix, as some of the key avenues to make the delivery of our energy more secure. Ultimately, Parliament did not reach the expected consensus. We have to realize that the stakes are high and that if an Energy Union is to be swiftly achieved for the equal benefit of all European citizens, less divisiveness in needed. Perhaps this vote should be regarded as a cautioning point for the oncoming Energy Union debates.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The report prepared in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy provides an excellent summarision of perhaps the most important issue of 21st-century European policy, the problems of energy policy, and takes a position on the appropriate response to them, closer European integration and, ultimately, the development of an Energy Union. It proposes measures to address the most important problems in this area: reducing demand for energy, increasing domestic energy production and developing energy technologies, building a fully integrated and well-functioning internal energy market and creating solidarity and coordination mechanisms. Overall, it is a strategy paper that reflects a genuinely long-term approach, which I was happy to support.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. Beyond geopolitical considerations, this report, like the forthwhile one on the Energy Union, purports to free Europe from The Russian gas grip through liberalisation measures that will lead to higher tariffs for consumers (end of regulated tariffs) and endanger our industry (end of long-term supply contracts, in the name of free competition). This system will benefit the financial markets of raw materials. While continuing to promote submission to market laws, the Union therefore intends to dictate to Member States their energy policy by depriving them of the choice of their energy sources, but also of their suppliers as their supply routes. This forced collaboration will lead to inextricable interdependence. Free interstate cooperation must be favoured and, in order to do so, restore their energy sovereignty to states.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. Despite the growing focus on renewable energy and diversification of energy sources, the European Union still imports 53 % of its total energy consumption, namely 85 % of oil, 67 % of gas, 41 % of solid fuels and about 95 % of uranium. It should also be added that the EU is heavily dependent on Russian energy sources. I am voting in favour of the fusion of atoms and I believe that further strategic studies are needed with regard to the prohibition of nuclear energy and the future use of shale gas. However, because I believe that energy issues need to be further deepened in key areas such as energy security and independence, I understood to abstain in the final global vote. I would also like to highlight the particular importance that should be given to the Outermost Regions, which have natural economic, social and territorial constraints and where energy supply becomes more difficult and with increased costs.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report seems to be tinged with a certain Russophobia, which it takes precedence over basic constraints on energy supply, such as geographical or geological factor (available stock). Thus, Russia, considered unreliable - without any other form of trial - must be set aside in order to reduce the Union's dependence on Moscow to the congruent portion. As the EU considers Qatar to be much more frequent, Brussels urges us to turn to the United States in order to conclude a major transatlantic trade agreement to multiply liquefied natural gas terminals to carry US or Qatari shale gas. The European Union, out of pure Russophobia, prefers to rely on a gas dictatorship, under the guise of liberalisation. All this will lead to higher tariffs for consumers with the end of regulated tariffs in favour of speculative markets alone. So I voted against this report.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the path to energy security lies in the energy transition, putting energy efficiency first, promoting renewables and investing domestically the money currently spent on expensive imports, to develop our green technologies industry and create more jobs.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I abstained on this text on the European Energy Security Strategy. The text, which is the result of compromises with the Green, ALDE, GUE, EFDD and ECR groups, is too exclusively geared towards renewable energy, to the detriment of nuclear energy and conventional and unconventional energy.  There is systematic opposition to shale gas and coal gas experimentation. Moreover, the drafting of certain paragraphs contributes to the tensions between the Union and Russia, which I deplore. On the other hand, I voted in favour of the amendment which asks the Commission to consider possible solutions for the establishment of a carbon adjustment mechanism at the borders. The aim is to create a level playing field between European and non-European producers, who are not subject to the same environmental requirements.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 The recent conflict in Ukraine has certainly reminded European states of the importance of security of energy supply and underlined the close link between the energy market and its geopolitical context. Despite some progress in recent years, the European Union still faces challenges such as instability in the regions providing it with energy, a fragmented internal market and the fight against climate change. The EU imports 53% of its total energy consumption and many Member States still depend on a single external source of supply, which hampers Europe's economic growth and endangers internal and EU security. The report adopted today points to a number of priority actions aimed at moderating energy demand, increasing domestic energy production and developing new energy technologies, with a view to building a fully integrated and efficient internal market. We must continue to promote new energy efficiency, focusing on alternative resources. New technologies could help reduce energy dependency by diversifying and consolidating supply options. As regional integration is a key element of energy security, the EU will need to step up its efforts to implement strategic energy infrastructure projects, promoting solidarity and coordination mechanisms.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission, following the crisis in Ukraine in May 2014, proposed a European energy security strategy. The ITRE Committee then decided to draw up an own-initiative report on the subject, instructing Mr Saudargas to draw it up. Although I believe it is necessary for the European Union to play a key role in European and international energy policy, I am of the opinion that the text, as drafted and presented in plenary, does not fully reflect the initial forecasts. That is why I have chosen to abstain.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Central and Eastern Europe is most at risk of a possible energy crisis. Our countries are the most dependent, I think, especially in today's geopolitical situation, increasing security is our first priority. In my opinion, the Saudargas report, voted on by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, provided good guidance. In accordance with the People's Party position, also referring to respect for the principle of subsidiarity, I abstained in the vote.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: în scris. ‒ The EU imports more than half of all the energy it consumes. The total import bill is more than EUR 1 billion per day. European energy security strategy has enabled so—called stress tests so that EU countries will work together so that no household will be affected in the event of a winter gas disruption. I have voted for this report because of its long-term energy measures such as energy efficiency, energy production, building missing infrastructure and strengthening emergency and solidarity mechanisms.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on energy security because it is very important to have a clear and future strategy to ensure the energy independence of all EU states, including Romania. The degree of dependence of many Member States on energy imports remains a security and safety issue for the economic and social stability of the whole EU, with direct and serious effects on European citizens. In this respect, the funds planned in the 2014-2020 budget year to increase the interconnection of the energy system at Member State level are of critical importance and can help to better distribute available resources. However, energy security and independence must and can only be achieved through sustainable development. It is sad that this report, which covered such a large number of energy security issues, was rejected because it was too critical of the shale gas extraction method, an extremely sensitive subject for Romania.  I regret that the EPP delegation thus intended to reject an entire document because of the blind support they give to hydraulic fracturing.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I regret that the draft energy security report was rejected. I consider the issue of shale gas extraction to be complicated and still being expertly debated, and it is still an open question for me rather than a reason for the fundamental political conflict that unfortunately occurred during the vote, and it was taken away by the report as a whole. I am equally sorry for the overly well-positioned position of a number of Members on the other side of the political spectrum. The report contained many positive elements, such as the promotion of new technologies, climate protection, energy efficiency measures and respect for the power of Member States to decide on their energy mix, including nuclear energy, which the report explicitly referred to as low-carbon. These elements contained in the report should certainly not fit in. And I thank the rapporteur for the work done.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Under the guise of energy efficiency, the European Union requires the citizen to build his house and how much energy he is allowed to use. This paternalism of the European Union must be firmly rejected! A reasonable agreement on the use of energy without regulations would be conceivable, but not in this form. As the report is moving towards the Energy Union and regulation, I have spoken out against it.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This report follows the commission's publication in May 2014 of its Energy Security Strategy, which was to offer the EU a plan to strengthen its sources of supply and security, thereby contributing to the achievement of an energy union. It outlines the internal and external development priorities of energy security, such as the development of technologies or the diversification of sources, but omits aspects such as energy poverty, or access to energy as a common good and not just a consumer good. Not wishing to place the future of European energy security in the hands of the dominant multinationals in this area, I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. I supported the proposal. The European Union should diversify its energy sources, create security of gas supply, establish energy links between EU countries, and speak and act in a coherent way in its policies.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that the EU must complete the single market by adding the energy union to it and this can only be done by diversifying energy sources and focusing on renewable resources. In the past, Russia, Europe's largest supplier of gas, oil, uranium and coal, has blocked ukraine's real gas supply due to disagreements with Ukraine. This has caused inconvenience in many Member States which are interconnected with the Russian Federation via the network through Ukraine.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ Energy supply, mainly from fossil fuels, has unfortunately become a matter of political influence. The EU is in fact an energy dependent block, which each year imports more than EUR 500 billion of energy. In the long run, security in energy supply can be achieved only by establishing the right partnerships and ensuring sustainable and environmentally viable exploitation of the resources we already have, including the hugh potential of renewables. The EU is in urgent need of a framework for improved energy security in order to pursue effective foreign policy and increase industry competitiveness through concrete actions to pool energy supplies among Member States and clean up inefficiencies in external supply. Therefore, in the current geopolitical context, it is of utmost importance that the EU works hard on a long-term strategy in support of the upcoming energy union.

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report on the European energy security strategy, because the issue of energy security is at the very heart of our energy policy in these uncertain times. In this report, we managed to ensure that Europe’s energy security is viewed not only as a short-term question of gas supply but also as a driver for local jobs and growth within the EU, through productive investment in innovation, the development of infrastructure such as district heating systems, and the renovation and construction of highly energy-efficient buildings. Energy efficiency measures and technologies, coupled with the integration of renewables, play a crucial role in reducing dependence on fossil fuels, and, in Denmark, they have created local jobs and a competitive economy, as well as a thriving export base. I believe that others in Europe will benefit from this kind of high-efficiency green energy transition, delivering both energy security and economic prosperity. I am therefore deeply disappointed that this report was rejected. I hope, at least, that, despite the result, the many positive examples we highlighted will still be taken into account in the ongoing work of building a European Energy Union.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒The strategy is an integral part of the 2030 climate and energy framework policy and largely follows the objectives of EU competitiveness and industrial policy. It shall specify areas where appropriate decisions need to be taken or concrete actions taken in a short, medium and long term in order to address energy security issues. It is based on eight key pillars supported by the principle of solidarity, which together must promote closer cooperation for the benefit of all Member States while respecting national energy choices. My view is that Europe should strive for energy independence, and that means it has to use its own resources in the best possible way. Dependence on energy imports, neglect of renewable energy sources and the retention of nuclear energy as an important source of energy is unacceptable to me.  Since an amendment calling on Member States and EU institutions to phase out subsidies and other public funding for the construction, operation and extension of the lifespan of new and existing nuclear installations has not been adopted, I voted against such a proposal for an Energy Security Strategy.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The author of this report, Mr Saudargas, who is very hostile to Russia, gives us here a text clearly oriented against a country, in particular in defiance of the geographical constraints (ease of transit) and geological (available stocks) related to energy supply. The text accuses Russia of being "an unreliable partner" without citing specific examples. The aim of this report is clear: to reduce the Union's dependence on Russia as much as possible and to look to the United States for the conclusion of TTIP. Thus, the text proposes the multiplication of LNG terminals (liquefied natural gas), allowing the delivery of Natural Gas from the United States (shale gas) or Qatar. It is therefore not a question of serving the public interest but of certain special interests. In order to "liberate" Europe from the Russian gas grip through liberalisation measures, we risk mainly leading to an increase in tariffs for consumers (end of regulated tariffs) and the break-up of our industry solely to short-term speculative markets, etc. However, only States should be able to decide on their energy policy and cooperation in this area, so I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I am very sorry that the European Parliament today rejected the ambitious report on the European energy security strategy that I was working on as shadow rapporteur. Some of the proposals seem to have clearly been too ambitious, in particular the promotion of binding energy efficiency targets, or too controversial as nuclear energy, which has divided Members for many years. The moratorium on shale gas extraction was another sensitive issue, and although the amendment in favour of imposing a moratorium was approved by the plenary session, it certainly left some colleagues with a bitter afterthis and led to their subsequent rejection of the entire report.  The votes against the report came across political groups, albeit for a completely different reason. Unfortunately, support did not come from the PPE faction, whose members abstained or voted against their own rapporteur's report. Today's vote showed the diversity of views across the EP on these sensitive issues. It is clear that we will have to have intense debates, especially in view of the forthcoming vote on the Energy Union report, where a similar conflict of opinion can logically be expected.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the rapporteur when he stresses the importance of energy security for the EU and how vulnerable the energy market can be if we refer to current geopolitics. It is important to stress that, despite the progress made in recent years, some energy security needs to be achieved in the EU, even now the EU itself imports 53% of its total energy consumption and some Member States still depend on only one external supplier, which suggests how fragile the balance can be and may jeopardise the EU's economic growth. I agree that we should create an efficient internal energy market by competing between various suppliers with the aim of having reliable services at lower prices, but that is precisely why, and i therefore abstained, I do not agree with the proposal to close trade relations with certain partners, because this would undermine the ultimate objective of having valid energy supplies at competitive prices.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Today, the European Union needs to ensure its energy security, especially in a geopolitical context that is currently unstable, especially with Russia. This urgent issue was addressed by MEPs last Wednesday. The report on the implementation of a European Energy Security Strategy proposed measures to address the EU's growing energy dependence.  MEPs rejected this report, and I also voted against it. This report was not balanced enough and proposed to use renewable energy too exclusively. There is a need to review this strategy and develop a more sustainable strategy based more on different energy sources in line with reality.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. I regret that MEPs have not been able to reach agreement on the fundamental issue of the European Union's energy security and have rejected the Saudargas report because of differences on the issue of hydraulic fracturing. Because the energy stakes go far beyond the problem of shale gas and impose a long-term strategy for a genuine European energy policy. The ALDE Group has a very ambitious strategy in this area, which I share: it is essential to go even further than the plan for the creation of the European Energy Union, presented on 25 February by the Commission. It is imperative to free ourselves from dependence on Russian gas. Clean and renewable energy is another objective for which Europe must invest to maintain its technological lead. Indeed, the present situation, with a Union importing 53% of all the energy it consumes, is not sustainable.  Energy efficiency is essential in this strategy. Upgrading residential and office buildings, modernising public transport, using smart technologies and innovation would boost growth and employment, while saving billions of euros.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. The implementation of a common energy security policy has become all the more essential in the wake of the tensions we are experiencing with some of our suppliers, particularly Russia.  That is why I supported this motion for a resolution which, although not legally binding, was part of an awareness of the measures to be put in place: the development of interconnection between Member States' networks, the promotion of indigenous renewable energies, and increased energy efficiency through innovative systems. However, I have not supported the amendments to bring nuclear power into disrepute, an element of competitiveness for industry, and low-carbon energy which still plays an important role in generating electricity in Europe, or shale gas, which is now known to have less harmful means of extracting it.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the European Energy Union. Energy is a key policy for the preservation of the environment, for the climate, but also to reduce our energy dependence. Dependence on a single supplier is dangerous. The 2014 crisis in Ukraine showed us that it was important for Europe to complete its own single energy market, in our interest and for the benefit of future generations. The Energy Union is a global project through which European citizens should be offered safe, sustainable and affordable energy sources. It is estimated that the potential economic benefits that can be deed from the energy market are between 16 and 40 billion euros per year. We also recall that in the field of energy security, solidarity is a fundamental principle. We therefore call for better communication and cooperation between Member States.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. The EU's external energy bill represents more than €1 billion per day – €400 billion in 2013 – and more than a fifth of total EU imports, depending on a large-scale single country, the Russian Federation, which is the largest source of oil import (35%), gas (26%), coal (30%) uranium (25%), often using its energy resources as a political weapon. The eu's prosperity and security require a rational use of energy and a stable, affordable and sustainable energy supply. Energy security is also political independence. It is therefore essential to develop an energy security strategy based on technology and the decarbonisation of energy resources. Energy efficiency, renewable energy and smart infrastructure are three pillars that do not compromise our future.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialists regret that the Saudargas report has not been adopted because, thanks to the intensive work in committee, the report was committed to a new energy model for Europe, a sustainable and equitable model. During the vote in plenary, the Socialists had managed to cover a majority on three essential points, two of them at the request of the Spanish Socialist delegation: (1) a majority in favour of asking the Commission to submit a Communication on energy poverty, accompanied by an action plan to combat it; (2) a majority in favour of asking Governments not to authorize any new fracking operations in the EU until such actions are shown to be safe for the environment, workers and the general population; and (3) a majority in favour of more ambitious targets in renewable energy, energy efficiency and climate change, and that these were also binding.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted this afternoon in favour of this report, which aims to define a European strategy for energy security. In this regard, the text provides, for example, that Russia can no longer be regarded as a reliable partner insofar as it explicitly challenges EU legislation, particularly in the WTO, and exploits energy supply for political purposes. The text of the report also recalls that Parliament has already twice called for binding climate, renewable energy and energy efficiency targets by 2030. For my part, I have also supported amendments such as the phasing out of all subsidies harmful to the environment; amendments that recall the risks and consequences for the environment, climate and health associated with the extraction of unconventional fossil fuels (i.e. shale gas) and call on the European Commission to study the feasibility of a carbon adjustment mechanism at borders.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the serious Ukrainian crisis, the European Commission proposed a European strategy for energy security in May 2014, and the European Parliament's Committee on Industry, Research and Energy decided to draw up an own-initiative report on this matter. This report has been structured in such a way as to try to address the Union's future challenges with regard to its Energy Policy, stressing the importance of achieving the objective of the 'European Energy Union', promoting energy saving and efficiency, increasing domestic energy production, betting on technological innovations/research and development, identifying constraints and creating European legislation enabling the development of a fully integrated European energy market, as well as externally, diversifying energy sources and the absolute need for a single discourse across the Union. Unfortunately, differences between the various political groups regarding the creation of binding energy efficiency targets, the use of nuclear energy or the legislative framework for the exploitation of shale gas have caused this report to be failed, and I abstained in the final vote.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because I believe that the text is overly optimistic in identifying the use of – important – renewable sources of energy sources as the solution to most energy supply problems at European level. I also believe that the text tends to encroach on areas that should mainly be the responsibility of the individual Member States.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against the text on the basis that it advocates a supposed diversification of the energy matrix based on the continuity of the use of conventional hydrocarbons, the exploitation of unconventional hydrocarbons through techniques such as fracking, the achievement of gas megaprojects and the maintenance of renewable energies. The text clearly departs from the necessary commitment to an energy model change and seeks to operate a false transition based on low-carbon technologies whose use pernnizes the current dirty, dependent, unsustainable, asymmetrical, socially unfair and warrior model. Moreover, the text does not sufficiently defend measures to meet emission reduction, boost to renewable energy and energy efficiency targets.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the path to energy security lies in the energy transition, putting energy efficiency first, promoting renewables and investing domestically the money currently spent on expensive imports, to develop our green technologies industry and create more jobs.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing \ u2012 I voted in accordance with the position of the EKR. Nuclear energy, which has low carbon dioxide emissions, continues to make a significant contribution to the EU's domestic energy production. I believe that the choice of the use of nuclear energy should remain within the competence of the Member States.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ In order for the European Union to achieve energy security, prudent and efficient use of energy and stable, affordable and sustainable energy supply is needed, as energy security primarily means political independence. Currently, the EU still imports 53% of its total energy for consumption, namely 85% of oil, 67% of gas, 41% of solid fuels and around 95% of uranium.  In order to achieve energy security, these figures need to be reduced and turned to renewables. Renewable energy should be a central supporter of EU energy and climate policy, but Community access and cooperation between Member States is necessary to achieve renewable energy targets more cost-effective. The LNG terminal project in Croatia is included on the list of the European Energy Security Strategy.  This Strategy represents a solid vision that promotes resilience to short-term disruptions of energy supply and reduces dependence on other energy sources, existing energy suppliers and existing energy routes in the long term. I think it is a demanding project, but one that needs to be run wisely.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the European Strategy for Energy Security because, in implementing it, I see great potential for the growth of the EU-wide economy, for environmental protection, but also for saving the population with lower and more efficient household consumption. I regret that the final vote did not support the strategy. At present, the EU imports up to 53% of its total energy consumption and a significant proportion of it comes from geopolitically unstable regions, which threatens the internal security of the Member States, but also the security of the whole EU. One solution to energy security and independence is also the Commission's priority for the EU to become the world leader in renewable energy. Renewable energy is often produced close to the point of consumption, creating locally sustainable jobs, not needing a costly distribution network, reducing emissions and also being the fastest way to reduce costs for households. As up to 40% of energy consumption in the EU is consumed by buildings – heating and/or air conditioning – it is essential to increase the scope and pace of modernisation of buildings and the use of renewable energy sources in heating and cooling. I also consider it a very excellent idea to have 2016 declared the European Year of Energy Savings, which we would also use to raise european citizens' awareness of how to reduce household energy consumption by simple and cost-effective methods.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the European Energy Security Strategy focuses on improving European energy security and efficiency in the light of recent crises in Russia and Ukraine. The importance of diversified energy sources and not just a single energy supplier must be aware. Although the moment is appropriate for the EU to focus on renewable energy sources, the report still focuses on gas and coal, the supply of which would be dispersed to different third world countries. As a representative of the Green Party, I cannot support this. Nature offers us many options and options for getting green energy, but unfortunately we are not making the most of it. The gas imported into the EU is mainly used to heat residential buildings, which is why any gas crisis is also a heat crisis. The use of renewable energy sources promotes decentralisation, better regulation frameworks and self-consumption, with a view to improving energy security. Nevertheless, the EU still does not deviate completely from nuclear power. It is true that nuclear power plants still contribute a large proportion of the total energy consumption, but a well-planned plan could change that. In view of this nuclear and infrastructure problem, I voted against the report on the European Energy Security Strategy.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the European Energy Security Strategy as I consider it of the utmost importance that the EU should provide itself with a regulatory framework that will enable it to ensure security of energy supply by progressively eliminating its dependence on fossil fuels. Unfortunately, I regret that the resolution was rejected, thus depriving the European Parliament of its voice on this issue. In fact, the document contained important proposals aimed at moving towards the decarbonisation of the economy (such as renewed support for binding targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, energy efficiency and the share of energy produced by renewable energies, within the framework of the 2030 climate package), environmental protection (moratorium on new shale gas explorations, recognition of responsibility for nuclear operators for environmental risks) and strong support for research for the development of new energy technologies. Parliament needs to continue the debate on this issue with an approach based on the combination and integration between energy policy and sustainable growth. I therefore hope that the future debate on the european Commission's recent proposal for the creation of the Energy Union will follow this path.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ the European Union should create legislative conditions that will not only reduce Member States' energy dependence on Russia in the future, but also allow for all-round support for the use of renewable energy sources. It is essential that transparency, consistency and continuity of regulatory frameworks in the field of renewable energy are guaranteed and that retroactive changes in the economic conditions governing investments are avoided. The main objective of these actions is to strengthen investor confidence and contribute to the cost-effective development of renewable energy sources.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I support this report, as I believe that, given possible unforeseen external influences such as the ukraine crisis, European energy security should be strengthened. A stable and efficient Energy Union is needed to reduce the external impacts on the energy security of the European Union.  It is also necessary to have a single energy market due to the reduction in energy prices and the development of better technology for energy production and consumption so as not to depend too much on outdated technologies. Also, new technologies increase the competitiveness of the European Union's energy market in relation to external markets.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the path to energy security lies in the energy transition, putting energy efficiency first, promoting renewables and investing domestically the money currently spent on expensive imports, to develop our green technologies industry and create more jobs.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒In 2012, the European Union today imports 53 percent of all energy consumption, while much of its energy is imported from geopolitically unstable areas. Moreover, several Member States still depend on one external source of supply, posing a major risk to economic objectives, economic growth and prosperity in the European Union. In addition, there is an outflow of some industries in the EU due to high energy costs, which reduces employment and harms the European Union economy.  The report focuses on long-term strategic objectives and includes concrete actions to moderate energy consumption, increasing indigenous energy production and developing energy technologies. The report is structured in such a way that it does not cover all important aspects of the European Energy Community in terms of energy security with a clear distinction between its internal and external dimensions, which is why I did not support this report.  The aim of this report is to set guidelines to ensure our energy security in the short and long term. As key votes proposed by the EPP Group were not adopted, I did not support this report.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ because I do not agree with the instruments to be used to achieve energy security. In fact, the proposal fundamentally focuses on various new obligations aimed at saving energy, which limits the decision-making of consumers and entrepreneurs. Moreover, the idea that energy security should be achieved to a large extent by mandatory energy saving is absurd.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the report on the European Energy Security Strategy. Today, the European Union faces major challenges in energy provision. Given the current geopolitical context, energy security is all the more important. The prosperity and security of the European Union and political independence depend to a large extent on a stable and affordable and sustainable energy supply. However, the report alone is not enough. The European Union must stand together and increase the use of its own resources: fossil fuels, renewable energy sources and economic technologies.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The proposed energy security strategy essentially serves private interests and exacerbates inequalities and exclusions. GUE/NGL chooses a different path of real development, where energy is a public social good, to which we must all have equal and cheap access. We also consider it important to ensure enhanced state control, to invest in public infrastructure and to promote international cooperation, carried out on the basis of mutual benefit, parity and solidarity. All this is absent from the report. Unfortunately, this report, apart from shortcomings, has also had many problematic references. For example, it proposed that the Commission should be involved in the negotiations on intergovernmental agreements and that the agreements under negotiation be evaluated in advance and ex post. These proposals limit the sovereignty of States and reduce national flexibility in the formulation of multidimensional and efficient international energy relations. The report also fails to address the problem of energy poverty in any way, while promoting the use of nuclear energy, which poses enormous risks to humans and the environment. For these reasons we have decided to vote against the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The EU must certainly, on the one hand, focus on new energy sources, such as wind and solar, giving more incentives to achieve this objective, while at the same time stopping the promotion of environmentally harmful sources as well as interventions such as hydraulic fracturing and not serving the interests of third parties. And all this for the benefit of Europe and its citizens. But Russia is also an important ally, which some Europeans do not count and which is both strategically and geopolitically in Europe.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the development of a European energy security strategy, a strategy that is complexly aimed at the development of the Energy Union. In my opinion, the development of an Energy Union is in the fundamental, fundamental interest of the European Union. It should take into account not only economic but also climate, environmental, trust and social aspects. I think it is important to point out, in the context of the crisis in Ukraine, that the issue of ensuring a reliable energy supply is more important than ever; as well as diversification of energy supply and over-dependence on energy production. I therefore agree that energy efficiency, new and renewable energy sources and R&D should be given priority, which will help to create not only energy security, but also jobs.  The report focuses on the role of carbon capture and storage and calls for significant research and innovation efforts in this regard and addresses the dangers of nuclear energy production. With regard to projects of common interest, I supported the initiative that the European Union should only support projects where all the necessary environmental permits have been obtained.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 As shadow rapporteur for the PPE Group, I have put a lot of effort into preparing this document in recent months so that the European Parliament can approve it. Unfortunately, the final version was unacceptable – that is why I voted against.  The document voted on, although it contains many beneficial solutions, such as strengthening the internal energy market, the call for greater coordination in the choice of energy suppliers between Member States or a reduction in the EU's dependence on a single supplier, as a comprehensive document does not fulfil its objective of ensuring the growth of energy security for the entire European Union and its Member States. It should be emphasised that the European Energy Security Strategy is a document of particular importance and as such should be formulated on the basis of well-defined priorities. However, its final version has become an ideological manifesto: 'if many of its provisions were to be implemented, they would, firstly, undermine the economic development and therefore the social development of the European Union, and secondly, it would not guarantee the energy security that Europe so badly needs.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted no by contributing to the rejection of Saudargas' report on energy security. It retained all the unpresentable elements contained in the European Commission's communication, more political than aimed at guaranteeing real and lasting energy security and still in the wake of the fossil paradigm. The plant started from the desire to no longer buy Russian gas and to replace it through the construction of infrastructure to import it from other areas; through the development of clean coal/CCS, nuclear and drilling to extract more fossil fuels and produce more indigenous energy in the EU. These negative aspects of the report were predominant over the good elements that the M5S, thanks to the work of the ITRE Committee, had brought: binding targets for renewables, energy saving and greenhouse gas reduction; commitment to financially support the energy redevelopment of buildings. They have lapsed together with the report, as has the moratorium on fracking in the EU, which was approved by plenary through an amendment. These parts are my only regret. However, the Amendments of the M5S adopted by the ITRE Committee and the vote in plenary against fracking are a sign of an existing majority in the European Parliament. I will work to ensure that this will can make its mark in the legislative process.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: in writing. ‒ Events in Ukraine have highlighted more than anything the need for EU Member States to become more energy self-sufficient and to diversify their energy supplies. As Russia becomes ever more belligerent in its war against Ukraine, we have become increasingly aware of the problems of relying so heavily on Russia for gas imports – some Member States rely on Russia for 100% of their gas imports. Energy imports cost EU Member States up to EUR 1 billion per day now, as over half of all energy consumption is met by imports. Completing the internal energy market is therefore of more importance than ever. My Group broadly welcomed the initial report published by the rapporteur, so I am sad to see that so much of that good work has been lost during the amendment process. This has resulted in a report that places too much emphasis on goals outside the perspective of this report and has allowed ideological principles to trump the much—needed aims and merits of the original report. With this in mind, I am forced in this case to vote against the report but this does not dent my enthusiasm for greater work to ensure energy security.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text with some specific positions via the amendments. By emphasizing the principle of solidarity, we must stress that energy security is a matter of collective action. Member States must ensure transparency in the negotiations and adopt a common position vis-à-vis foreign suppliers.  As the Commission's communication on the short-term resilience of the European gas system indicates, Member States' procurement strategies are currently one-sided and too uncoordinated. In this regard, we call on the Commission to analyse the possible mechanisms for joint gas purchases.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The report on energy security by Algirdas Saudargas was voted down. I voted in favour of the report because I see energy security and independence as one of the most pressing issues for the EU, and therefore I regret that the EP decided to refuse this document. A number of my amendments, especially in the areas of the competiveness of EU industry, finance for infrastructure projects and indigenous energy sources, were included in compromise amendments, and that is why I decided to vote in favour. However, I voted against couple of amendments, especially on those calling on the Commission to introduce binding targets for energy efficiency and new legislation in this field, which could potentially mean a new administrative burden. I also voted against amendments which could prejudice the sovereignty of states in terms of energy mix, for example by promoting only certain energy sources.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The majority of the text of this report focuses on renewables and improving energy efficiency.  While in principle I support increasing the availability of renewable energy and improving energy efficiency, I believe that this report highlights these issues too much and therefore misses out on the key provisions of the security challenges needed to complement the internal energy market and to end the European Union's dependence on unreliable energy suppliers from third countries.  Also, calls for the establishment of a common legal area based on criteria relating to the Union acquis and the principles of the internal energy market, as well as a requirement to impose legal obligations for the renovation of buildings and energy audits for larger companies, I consider unnecessary and inappropriate. So I voted abstention.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the energy security strategy because it contained certain arguments with which I cannot agree. On the other hand, there are also enough good, positive messages that I cannot refuse. Europe's prosperity and security rest on a stable and abundant energy supply. Today, the EU imports 53% of the energy it consumes from third countries. The real problem, however, is that the EU is strongly tied to only one supplier on these imports. The new strategy provides a framework for improving energy security. We must ensure a stable and predictable environment for private investors, while promoting European technological capacities, research and science.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against the text on the basis that it advocates a supposed diversification of the energy matrix based on the continuity of the use of conventional hydrocarbons, the exploitation of unconventional hydrocarbons through techniques such as fracking, the achievement of gas megaprojects and the maintenance of renewable energies.
