The text clearly departs from the necessary commitment to an energy model change and seeks to operate a false transition based on low-carbon technologies whose use pernnizes the current dirty, dependent, unsustainable, asymmetrical, socially unfair and warrior model. Moreover, the text does not sufficiently defend measures to meet emission reduction, boost to renewable energy and energy efficiency targets.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ Voting in favour of this resolution, I hope that we are able to set some guidelines for building the energy union. A low-carbon economy is fundamental for our future, as is keeping up investment in renewable energies, but other sources of energy that can be more cost-efficient in the short and medium term should not be dismissed.Moreover, I hope that the Commission listens to Parliament’s voice and publishes soon a communication on fighting energy poverty, as this is a grave situation that affects thousands of citizens around Europe and some Member States have not sufficiently fought it.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This report is very explicitly part of the European Union's new lukewarm war against our Russian partner, in particular in defiance of the geographical constraints (ease of transit) and geological (available stocks) related to energy supply. Russia is again presented as an unreliable partner when no examples can be provided on non-delivery of orders.  The main objective of the report is to minimise the Union's dependence on Russia, including a proposed look to the United States for the conclusion of the transatlantic treaty. More generally, it is a matter of supporting the achievement of the single energy market in order to ensure that the Commitments made by the Commission in recent years are met. Beyond geopolitical considerations, this report purports to free Europe from the Russian gas grip through liberalisation measures that will lead to higher tariffs for consumers (end of regulated tariffs) and the breakdown of our industry (end of long-term supply contracts, in the name of free competition), to the benefit of speculative markets in the short term. This system will benefit the commodity financial market. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of the latest geopolitical events, the importance of the European Union's energy security has become essential. Despite the fact that significant progress has been made to strengthen it, by increasing the share of renewable energies and by an overall reduction in demand, 53% of the European Union's total energy consumption is covered by imports. The main risks come from the fact that much of this energy comes from unstable geopolitical areas, such as the Middle East, Russia or the Caucasus, and from the fact that many European states continue to be dependent on a single external source of supply, which leads to high costs for citizens and endangers national and European security. I support the idea of creating an energy union, based on the principles of competitiveness and sustainability, in a fully integrated energy market. We need the full integration of energy systems, which allows the cross-border transport of surplus energy, in order to prevent shocks caused by external energy supply. Greater effective solidarity between European states would reduce risks to energy security and help to eliminate a serious vulnerability in the current international context, marked by tensions in Ukraine, the Middle East and the Maghreb.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against the text on the basis that it advocates a supposed diversification of the energy matrix based on the continuity of the use of conventional hydrocarbons, the exploitation of unconventional hydrocarbons through techniques such as fracking, the achievement of gas megaprojects and the maintenance of renewable energies. The text clearly departs from the necessary commitment to an energy model change and seeks to operate a false transition based on low-carbon technologies (too ambiguous term) whose use pernizes the current dirty, dependent, unsustainable, asymmetrical, socially unfair and warrior model. Moreover, the text does not sufficiently defend measures to meet emission reduction, boost to renewable energy and energy efficiency targets.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted against the report because it was too focused on nuclear power and fossil fuels, such as gas and coal. Moreover, a vital amendment tabled by the Greens against state subsidies for nuclear energy was also rejected.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. The Spanish Socialists regret that the Saudargas report has not been adopted because, thanks to the intensive work in committee, the report was committed to a new energy model for Europe, a sustainable and equitable model. During the vote in plenary, the Socialists had managed to cover a majority on three essential points, two of them at the request of the Spanish Socialist delegation: (1) a majority in favour of asking the Commission to submit a Communication on energy poverty, accompanied by an action plan to combat it; (2) a majority in favour of asking Governments not to authorize any new fracking operations in the EU until such actions are shown to be safe for the environment, workers and the general population; and (3) a majority in favour of more ambitious targets in renewable energy, energy efficiency and climate change, and that these were also binding.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted against this report because it bases European energy security on two pillars to which I oppose it. The first is to strengthen the EU's aggressive trade and foreign policy, with its pressures, impositions and attacks on our neighbours to access its energy resources. This is a voracious and short-sighted strategy that only contributes to destabilizing them and which we oppose, because only a project of development and mutual collaboration can be the basis of trade relations between sovereign states. The second is the impetus given to energy as dangerous as nuclear energy in the context of the energy transition. On the contrary, there are own resources, such as coal, that can be developed as a complement to renewable energy and environmental efficiency to reduce our energy dependence. For this reason, we defend the maintenance of production and generation aids with local coal, improvements in their combustion techniques (investing in thermal renewal) and a commitment to the technological development of new harvesting and capture techniques related to their combustion cycle.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Written. 'Unlike my ECR colleagues, I have supported the Saudargas report today. It contains strong paragraphs on the transition to a low-carbon energy mix. That is the direction we have to take and that is what we need to focus our innovation on. At the same time, there remains room for fossil fuels during the transitional period, so that energy security and stability are not compromised. At the moment, I do not consider the use of shale gas as a safe option because of the environmental risks. Let us rather devote our energy to the further development of truly sustainable energy sources.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the path to energy security lies in the energy transition, putting energy efficiency first, promoting renewables and investing domestically the money currently spent on expensive imports, to develop our green technologies industry and create more jobs.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. Energy is a key issue. The report presented to the European Parliament is not satisfactory. Indeed, it limits the sovereignty of Member States and tries to force a common energy policy into favour of a few huge companies that monopolize the exploitation and management of these resources. Energy is a public good and policies on this resource must be in line with people's needs, both in terms of prices, which must be affordable for all, but also in terms of infrastructure, to enable everyone to have access to energy. It is therefore also essential to become more involved in the issue of energy poverty and to take all necessary solidarity measures. Finally, environmental and health issues are not taken into account, especially with regard to shale gas by hydraulic fracturing. My group had tabled an amendment calling for a ban on this practice. That amendment was rejected. I have therefore voted against this report and am satisfied that it has been rejected and sent back to committee.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The Freedom Party of Austria is clearly opposed to an Energy Union. That is why I rejected the resolution.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I did not agree with the EU Parliament's resolution on the European energy security strategy. In the end, it did not get a majority in Parliament. My group has contributed many amendments which would have made the report better. However, even if these amendments were adopted, it would not have been acceptable to me. The report is an attack on Europe's industrial base and calls for a transformation into a greener energy economy. It is based on the ideological basis of man-made climate change, which I do not share. The central planning transformation of the energy generation industry in Germany and Europe due to questionable ideological dogmas is wrong. In addition, there are certainly tasks for coordinating matters in the field of energy security at EU level. However, this does not include requirements for the respective national energy mix. The proposal submitted to Parliament for a decision therefore also violates the idea of subsidiarity.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the path to energy security lies in the transition to a clean green energy supply that favours non-nuclear renewables, such as tidal lagoons. However I voted against or abstained from individual amendments promoting or justifying nuclear energy, including those using ambiguous language or terminology. My view is based on issues of long-term cost both to people and planet and the fact that it is impossible for us to accurately estimate the cost of nuclear decommissioning, or storage of radioactive and other toxic waste. Transport of raw, processed and spent nuclear fuel is also a financial and environmental burden. Nuclear installations are major targets for terrorist attacks which necessitates further spending on high-level security. Money currently spent on imports would be better used on creating more jobs, infrastructure and research, to support a move away from old carbon-based energy supplies and controversial nuclear power generation.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ I would particularly like to thank my colleague Algirdas Saudargas for his excellent work on such a complex problem. In addition to his expertise, he expressed a great sense of listening and compromise in order to strike a balance between a large number of positions. However, despite his efforts, new and new proposals were coming, which made this balance impossible. They were often conditional not professionally but partisanly, and this has politicised this report. So far, I have only encountered a similar procedure in the Committee on Women's Rights, and I have taken it as a bit like a normal trend. I am all the more sorry that this procedure is also beginning to appear on technical topics, and it will be difficult to find common positions in the future with inconsistencies in the political groups. It is all the more alarming that only now are we waiting for legislative documents to be fulfilled in the Junker package. Although the majority of my political group voted against this report, I wanted to express my delay in appeasing the efforts of my precious colleague Saudargas.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the current situation, the EU's dependence on Russia and its energy raw materials must be avoided by ensuring alternative supplies and better energy interconnections between Member States. However, this report contains points that I have voted against in the past, whether it is binding targets for renewable energy and energy efficiency by 2030 or calls for the decarbonisation of the mix and the prioritisation of renewables. This is in the hands of Member States that cannot be dictated by a single model.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 We today rejected the European Energy Security Strategy adopted by the Commission on 28 May 2014 following a request from the European Council to establish a short- and long-term action plan to reduce energy dependence on foreign countries.  Although considerable progress has been made during the negotiations, including in the text greater references to energy democracy, decentralisation of production, the role of local initiatives and citizens, energy efficiency, the essential role of renewables in the European mix, the need to eliminate fossil subsidies and the reduction of dependence through measures to moderate demand, the text remains highly questionable. This laborious rebalancing has not been enough, there are still some important concerns: the text covers all supply and mix options and does not close the door either to nuclear power or to shale gases; the improvements in the text have not made it possible to change its nature, which remains very focused on the anti-Russian and profossile attitude. The focus on energy efficiency, renewables and demand moderation should have been dominant in such a strategy.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that nuclear energy makes a significant contribution to the EU's domestic electricity production. This allows European states at least partial independence. Like renewable energy, nuclear energy has a positive impact on the environment and can contribute to better energy security for the EU and neighbouring countries.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I was confident in the report by Mr Algirdas Saudargas on the European Energy Security Strategy. This report shows how the European Union has gone in recent years to recognise energy security as one of the cornerstones of the EU's overall security. Europe's problem is that we are mostly committed to the supply of energy from outside the EU. This situation puts the Member State of the Union, which in practice today is doomed to a single supplier's monopoly, in a particularly difficult situation. I consider it particularly important in the report to announce an increase in investment funds that would allow gas and oil to be supplied from different countries. It is investments in gasports, in new industrial networks, in interconfectors. It is good that additional research funding is foreseen to reduce the consumption of energy carriers in Europe.  Poland has a vital interest in the EU's common energy security policy. I therefore support with conviction the content presented in this report.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: Writing. – I voted positively in favour of the European Parliament resolution on a European energy security strategy. Although there is progress in strengthening energy security in the European Union, most of the energy resources are still imported by Europe. In addition, exporting countries are often located in geopolitically fragile regions or are used for politically driven purposes. I believe that energy security also includes political independence. Consequently, I support a resolution that will promote this type of independence, both by optimising energy consumption in general and by emphasising the importance and usability of renewable energy sources, thus implementing sustainable energy policies and European economic development. At the same time, it is important to ensure that energy saving is actually linked to the legislation in place, not thanks to the economic slowdown – and thus the reduction in energy demand – in Europe. I would like to draw attention to the fact that, despite a supportive vote in solidarity with other Members of the ECR Group, I am cautious about the co2 release reservation.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ Although I considered the original proposal to be clear and acceptable, unfortunately the text that was finally tabled together with all the amendments focuses mainly on renewables and energy efficiency. Although these topics are of course important, the new wording of the proposal emphasises them all too much, which ultimately caused the key short- and long-term objectives relating to the current energy situation to back down. A particularly important topic is the creation of a single energy market and the need to end the European Union's energy dependence on third-country suppliers (the EU's dependence on oil imports is up to 90%, on natural gas imports 66%), on which the European Union cannot continue to rely.  It is precisely for these reasons, as well as because, in my opinion, the proposal tried to include legal obligations relating to energy audits and other burdensome obligations for entrepreneurs, that I voted against it. The imposition of such obligations, in addition to imposing a disproportionate financial burden on businesses and other unnecessary bureaucracy, is not in line with the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This report is an example of how confusing the title of a document can be and hide harmful content that is completely incomparable to real needs. Today, Europe's energy security is primarily about conventional energy sources – the stability of oil and gas supplies to and through conflict areas, the state and development of transmission infrastructure, diversification of suppliers and independence from energy raw materials purchased in Russia, the modernisation of the coal-based energy sector and investment in shale gas exploration and exploitation.  These are the real problems of our energy industry that respond to the needs of the European economy. These are the issues that require rapid responses and a coherent strategy for action. Instead, we are faced with another attempt to speed up the economically and socially harmful process of decarbonisation and to impose further restrictions on the formation of the energy mix. This definition of energy security is a misunderstanding of the sector's fundamental problems and another attempt to boost economies based on conventional energy sources, including the Polish. We cannot accept the climate dictatorship of rich EU countries at the expense of economically weaker countries.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: in writing. \u2012 I regret the result of today's vote because I believe that ensuring energy security is one of the European Union's main objectives and this own-initiative report would have been a step in the right direction. It is our task to significantly reduce the EU's dependence on fossil fuels and, in particular, on the dependence of those countries that rely on a single supplier. The EU must drive change towards diversifying sources of supply by investing in research and development in order to increase the potential of renewables and energy efficiency. Energy is the engine of sustainable growth in Europe and a potential source of high-quality new jobs and new export markets to support our SMEs. Finally, I would like to point out that growth and development in this area must go hand in hand with environmental protection legislation. It will be our task, in the coming months, to develop the ideas contained in the Commission communication on energy union, promoting coherent and effective legislation that can respond to the challenges of the future.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – I, as a former Minister of Justice in the Czech Republic, have come into contact with OLAF and I appreciate his work and consider it important. On the other hand, Today I supported the annual report of the Supervisory Committee of this Office, which is fundamentally critical. It concerns how OLAF's investigative office cooperates with the Supervisory Committee, which is to carry out some control over olaf's activities.  I believe that if the judicial authorities are to work well, they must be independent, but on the other hand, legal democratic control must be ensured so that they do not abuse their power. This report makes it clear that the Supervisory Committee puts recommendations, around 51, on the table and, unfortunately, OLAF does not follow them. It is therefore necessary for the Commission to rectify and address the problem of why the supervisory committee's activities in relation to OLAF are not being applied and the control is not working.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of the motion, but I was speaking against Mr Kessler, the Director-General of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF). Of course, he is a socialist, and every socialist is an enemy of mankind, but I voted against him not because he is a socialist. If he were a conservative libertarian I would also have voted against him. However, what I have observed in the discussion is that all the Social Democrats were defending Mr Kessler when trying to postpone the decision. This is very dangerous. I am happy that the motion by Petri Sarvamaa and Ingeborg Grässle was adopted.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, a while ago in committee, I asked the Director-General of OLAF, when he pointed out that there were now more fraud cases being opened: is it that you are getting better at detecting the fraud or is it that there is more fraud in the European Union? His answer was, in a moment of rare honesty in this place, quite telling. He said: I think it is a bit of both actually. But now we find that actually there are serious allegations that this Parliament has been misled over the figures and that the true figures could be completely wrong. We do not know what the true position is. The Scrutiny Committee has actually come up with a pretty damning report, it has to be said, of the way in which OLAF has conducted itself. So I think it is not just that there are big questions to answer within OLAF but wider questions actually about fraud and corruption within the whole European Union.

name: Michael THEURER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which For the third time, the Supervisory Committee of OLAF, the anti-fraud agency, has pointed out serious difficulties and obstacles to its work. For me and the ALDE Group, the fight against fraud is crucial, as is the independence and functioning of the Anti-Fraud Office. For reasons of the rule of law, however, it is crucial that control also has control. So who controls the inspectors, if not the members of the Supervisory Committee? We, as the ALDE Group, have put a question to the Commission. We have dispensed with our own resolution. However, the Commission's response in yesterday's plenary session was far from satisfactory. Questions were not answered, questions were only partially answered. That is why I and the ALDE groups have decided to vote in favour of the resolution by several political groups, which calls on the Commission to take action now, to present an action plan and to ensure the functioning of the Supervisory Committee.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution as it is a necessary exercise of control by the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) by the European Parliament. This Office is an institution that controls possible fraud contrary to the EU's financial interests. In its field of activity it conducts investigations into fraud, corruption or bad practices in cases affecting the EU budget. This Resolution points to different irregularities in the different disputes between the Surveillance Committee and OLAF itself. Seeking to adopt a political position aimed at improving its functioning, the Resolution also draws attention to the disproportionate allocation of resources and calls for a balanced allocation of resources. It is the commitment to improve the functioning of this very important institution that I have decided to vote in favour of this Resolution.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. The European Anti-Fraud Office, or OLAF for short, operates under the supervision of a Supervisory Committee consisting of five independent experts appointed by consensus by the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission. This Supervisory Committee regularly monitors OLAF's investigations in order to ensure its independence. The 2014 annual report, which has now been presented, casts some doubt on the Office's success reports. Among other things, due to tricks with statistics, the case numbers were artificially inflated. Against this background, I welcome the resolution, which urges OLAF, on the one hand, to comply with the legal requirements for launching an investigation and, on the other hand, calls on the Supervisory Committee to better verify compliance with these legal requirements.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. OLAF, which issued its annual report for 2014, is under fire from parliamentarians from several groups. The lack of transparency in the way OLAF conducts its investigations strongly calls into question its independence from the governing bodies of the European Union. OLAF tends to open too many investigations without the necessary information or motives. This draft resolution is, of all the proposals, the most critical of OLAF. In particular, it calls for the supervisory committee to monitor the duration of investigations and to improve the information provided by OLAF to the supervisory committee. It is also worth noting the close links between its Director General Mr Kessler and the President of the European Parliament Mr Schulz. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which raised serious questions over what confidence we can have in the work of OLAF. Had it failed, I would have supported the other resolutions including that of the EFDD.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because OLAF has three essential tasks in my view: protecting the financial interests of the European Union, detect serious facts related to the exercise of professional activities, committed by members and staff of THE institutions and bodies of the European Union and support the European institutions, and in particular the Commission, in the development and implementation of anti-fraud regulations and policies.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the ANNUAL Activity Report of the OLAF Supervisory Committee 2014. It identifies shortcomings in OLAF's activities. Limited access to information is the main reason why the Supervisory Committee cannot fully guarantee OLAF's independence, transparent investigations, the application of procedural safeguards and the appropriate duration of investigations. In this situation, monitoring and verification of olaf investigations cannot be properly carried out, which in principle seriously threatens the functioning and reputation of this institution of major importance for the EU as a whole. I agree with the positions putted by my colleagues on the need to improve the working procedures between these institutions, to define more precisely the role and rights of the Supervisory Committee and the nature of the exchange of information with OLAF. The Commission should mediate in these negotiations on a clearer definition of the institutions' area of activity. It is important to bear in mind that OLAF employs around 500 staff whose work should not be hampered by disagreements between OLAF and the Supervisory Committee.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is very critical of this institution, in particular the way OLAF opens and conducts its investigations.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. OLAF must, of course, comply with the legal requirements that govern the initiation of an investigation. The Oversight Committee must be able to fulfil its role and verify compliance with these legal requirements. It is regrettable that the Oversight Committee found that it was impossible to determine whether the priorities of OLAF's investigative policy had been properly identified and whether their application had had positive or negative consequences for the fight against fraud and corruption within the Union.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Written. \u2012 CU-SGP votes in favour of the joint resolution. The reason for this is that OLAF must operate independently and carry out its duties in accordance with the Regulation. Monitoring by the Supervisory Committee may not work properly at this time.  Since OLAF is affiliated with the European Commission, it is very important to ensure that OLAF can carry out its work with the right independence from the EU institutions. However, the Supervisory Committee cannot establish this by insufficient access to information. His findings, as read in its annual report, have all but reassured the Supervisory Committee.  There are even differences of opinion on the facts: is the duration of the duration of cases caused by the new calculation method or not? And has the opening of cases been assessed or not carried out in accordance with the regulation? Such differences of opinion on the facts signifies the working relationship between OLAF and the Supervisory Committee. The differences of opinion are also linked to the interpretation of the Regulation with regard to the role of the Supervisory Committee. That is why it is necessary to clarify this role so that OLAF's independence can be effectively guaranteed.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. A bad relationship between OLAF and the Monitoring Committee appears to be causing malfunctions in the functioning and fulfilment of the objectives to be achieved. That is why I think it is appropriate for the Commission to arbitrate the negotiations between the two so that they can draw up a work plan so that the Monitoring Committee can fulfil its mandate. I also welcome the collaboration of both to improve the contents of procedures and completion times. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution of the PPE Group, GUE/NGL and Verts/ALE.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This draft resolution on the 2014 annual report of the OLAF Supervisory Committee is in line with the 2014 report of the supervisory committee warning against OLAF's practices, particularly in the way it conducts investigations. OLAF, for example, would have a tendency to prolong investigations without real grounds. This resolution encourages OLAF to comply with the legal procedures provided in the event of an investigation. It also highlights the difficulty in determining whether the priorities of the investigation policy have been properly identified and whether their application has had positive or negative consequences for the fight against fraud and corruption, which is highly regrettable.  Finally, the resolution also proposes to allow the supervisory committee to monitor the duration of investigations and to improve the information that OLAF transmits to the supervisory committee. I have therefore decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution analysing the 2014 annual report of olaf's Supervisory Committee has controversial and unclear aspects, which is why I abstained.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution because it is based on the accusations made by the Monitoring Committee of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) without the Office itself being able to provide its explanations in the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control and without waiting to analyse the content of the annual report submitted by OLAF on 2 June. It is regrettable that, for the first time, the Committee on Budgetary Control did not send a formal invitation to the Director-General of OLAF, despite the importance of the 2014 Activity Report of the Monitoring Committee and despite the intense debate between the two bodies, and that it has not attached the same importance, or the necessary attention, to the presentation of OLAF's annual report. This approach has prevented Parliament from having the possibility of holding a full and substantive debate, with all the information on the table.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it presents Parliament with an evaluation of its 2014 annual report of olaf (European Anti-Fraud Office) Monitoring Committee. In its 2014 Annual Activity Report, olaf's Supervisory Committee noted that in 2012, following the reorganisation of OLAF in 2012, 423 cases were opened on the same day by the Director-General of OLAF, but OLAF did not properly assess the information received in relation to any of the cases examined, in most cases there were no indications of evaluation activities and the Director-General of OLAF had not determined in advance that there were sufficient suspicions that fraud, corruption or other illegal activities affecting the financial interests of the Union have been committed, which does not meet the legal requirements laid down by olaf in order to open an investigation at that time. For all these and other reasons listed above, Parliament urges the Commission in this resolution to assist in the negotiations between OLAF and the Supervisory Committee and to draw up an action plan by 31 December 2015 to amend the agreement on practical arrangements in order to facilitate the exercise of its powers under OLAF's supervision by the Supervisory Committee. This is very important because OLAF's objective is to investigate cases of fraud, corruption and serious irregularities affecting the EU budget within the EU institutions.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The adoption of the joint motion for a resolution was justified by the facts and problems identified in olaf's Supervisory Committee's 2014 Annual Report. Olaf SC has been heavily criticised for its management, management and case management of the European Anti-Fraud Office, which cannot be ignored. The report strongly criticises the procedure where, on 1 February 2012, 423 cases were opened at the same time on the basis of a decision of the Director-General, without any meaningful examination of olaf's competence in those cases on the basis of fraud, corruption or other illegal activity affecting the Union's financial interests. It is also a problem that the Director-General of OLAF ignores the recommendations of the Supervisory Board, having implemented only 8 of the 50 SC recommendations. Access to the information necessary for the performance of its duties is also not guaranteed, and the stable functioning of the SC Secretariat is also not guaranteed. The motion for a resolution calls on the European Anti-Fraud Office and its Director-General to address these problems. In order for the Supervisory Committee to function effectively and to carry out its tasks, all the necessary conditions must be met and the European Parliament has a duty to raise its word to that end. I supported the joint motion for a resolution in the plenary vote.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against corruption, fraud and illegal activities is of the utmost importance to the European Union. The 2014 Annual Activity Report of the OLAF Monitoring Committee highlighted critical issues over OLAF's work, without there being any contradiction on the part of OLAF, which has not yet had the opportunity to present its work to the relevant parliamentary committee over the past year. Without neglecting the importance of the role that each of the two bodies plays and in the absence of an in-depth analysis of the anomalous situation that has arisen, It seems appropriate to me to call for prudence and caution, first of all trying to shed light on the issue and on the possibility for both sides to clarify their positions. For these reasons, I voted in favour of my political group's resolution, which goes in this direction.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support this issue, as it is consistent with the principle that both institutions are heard in such cases and not take a unilateral approach. There are a number of very serious criticisms from sc's annual report to look out for, and the question arises as to why sc cannot fully implement its mandate and asks the Commission to take measures to improve SC's ability to monitor OLAF's independence and its function.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this resolution because I believe that OLAF has done a better job than the resolution would have us believe and that, on the contrary, OLAF's role is crucial to combating fraud against the Union.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the 2014 annual report of the OLAF Oversight Committee. Its investigations must be strictly consistent with the legislative framework on which they depend and must demonstrate specific, valid and justified reasons. In addition, in order for its results to be credible and legitimate, the greatest transparency should be applied to the way investigations are developed. The duration of these, in particular, must be clearly stated and any extensions justified. However, I will be very vigilant and oppose any creation of a European prosecutor's office that tramples on the judicial sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Recent actions by Belgian investigators have revealed that the EU Anti-Fraud Office, OLAF, is lacking in accountability and transparency, as well as the unnecessary opening of minor cases only to classify them as successfully resolved files. It appears that OLAF's actions were directed in a single day on 423 companies mainly from Romania and Bulgaria related to the attraction of European funds, with companies automatically blacklisted and payments suspended, even though investigations against them were abruptly halted. Furthermore, in view of the interruption of payments and the creation of gaps which subsequently involve new bureaucratic procedures, the Commission must communicate what remedial measures it will take so that Member States recover the damage caused by OLAF's actions. I voted in favour of OLAF's 2014 Annual Report on the Supervisory Committee because I believe it is the Commission's duty to clarify all these serious shortcomings of OLAF, precisely so that these errors cannot be repeated and that the effectiveness of the functioning of the European Anti-Fraud Office is to return to normal parameters.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained on the measure. OLAF is an important tool for clarity in the expenditure of the EU institutions and against abuses of EU funds and funding. Without prejudice to this principle, it seems to me that the political objective of certain groups in the text we are voting on is clear in order to target certain OLAF managers in the hope that their succession can be conditioned.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. It is essential that the supervisory committee of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) has all the necessary means at its disposal to combat any attempt at fraud that may affect the European budget. However, it appeared that some of the statistical data provided by OLAF to the supervisory committee was incorrect. The oversight committee must be able to act independently of OLAF. A more constructive dialogue between the supervisory committee and OLAF is thus necessary to prevent such a situation from happening again. The management of European agencies must be beyond reproach. The credibility of European governance is at stake. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ The proposed resolution focuses on the various observations of the Supervisory Committee of OLAF with regard to possible malpractices within OLAF. There are a number of worrying aspects in relation to how OLAF operates. They are reluctant to provide the Supervisory Committee (SC) and the European Parliament with the necessary information to fulfil their respective mandates. There are also very few safeguards against arbitrary decisions in individual cases or against violations of procedural rights of suspects. The Supervisory Committee tries to improve the quality of OLAF’s activities. This has not been welcomed by OLAF, but instead it has led to tensions between the SC and OLAF’s management, as the latter regarded the SC’s recommendations as interference. Moreover, there is an ongoing dispute about the question of individual cases: according to OLAF, information on individual cases cannot be shared with the SC, certainly not when investigations are still ongoing, but also when they have been closed, and it is difficult for the SC to obtain relevant information. This makes it very hard for the SC to do its supervisory work. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this resolution as it attempts to address these concerns.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted for this resolution because we support measures to tackle corruption and increase the transparency of how tax-payers’ money is used. In particular, the unclear practices of ‘clearing house’ meetings should be publicised.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I agree with the recommendations and analysis set out in this resolution following the consideration of OLAF’s responses to the Supervisory Committee’s reports and opinions that were delivered to Parliament.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against olaf's Supervisory Committee's 2014 annual report: the role of the CoV and its scope of action absolutely need to be clarified

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which validates the conclusions made by the supervisory committee in its 2014 report. The resolution rightly raises some legitimate questions about how OLAF conducts its investigations. It can be recalled that in 2012, OLAF, on the sole decision of its Director General, opened 423 cases on the same day, which casts doubt on the reliability of these investigations. Moreover, the latter often extend over time, without any explanation and in an absolute lack of transparency. It is these grey areas that are driving the parliamentarians of the Committee on Budgetary Control, in particular, to want to give authority to the supervisory committee to investigate the questionable practices of OLAF. This resolution is therefore, for once, in the direction of better control of organs to facilitate the fight against corruption and conflicts of interest.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because I believe that OLAF plays such an important role that shadows are not admissible on its work. While doubts have been raised about this, it is clear that some procedures have not been carried out with the necessary transparency. Therefore, although I take into account both the requests of the Director-General and those of the Supervisory Committee, I hope that this motion for a resolution will provide an additional incentive for these two bodies to work together and positively without obstruction. It is also because there are superior interests at stake in defending their respective prerogatives, which are to safeguard the Interests of the Union against fraud and corruption and from any illegal activity that might affect them. I therefore believe that we must be able to ensure that the body responsible for this function is also free from any constraint.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I note with regret that the Supervisory Committee has repeatedly reported that it has encountered multiple difficulties in carrying out its mandate as supervisor. The Supervisory Committee should protect the EU's financial interests in the fight against fraud and should constantly monitor OLAF's independence. I hope that OLAF will be able to fulfil its functions and that an action plan will be drawn up by 31 December this year with a view to creating a collaborative and transparent working environment.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution as it is a necessary exercise of control by the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) by the European Parliament. This Office is an institution that controls possible fraud contrary to the EU's financial interests. In its field of activity it conducts investigations into fraud, corruption or bad practices in cases affecting the EU budget. This Resolution points to different irregularities in the different disputes between the Surveillance Committee and OLAF itself. Seeking to adopt a political position aimed at improving its functioning, the Resolution also draws attention to the disproportionate allocation of resources and calls for a balanced allocation of resources. It is the commitment to improve the functioning of this very important institution that I have decided to vote in favour of this Resolution.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The adoption of the Parliamentary decision was justified by the facts and problems identified in olaf's Supervisory Committee's 2014 annual report. Olaf SC has been heavily criticised for its management, management and case management of the European Anti-Fraud Office, which cannot be ignored. The report strongly criticises the procedure where, on 1 February 2012, 423 cases were opened at the same time on the basis of a decision of the Director-General, without any meaningful examination of olaf's competence in those cases on the basis of fraud, corruption or other illegal activity affecting the Union's financial interests. Access to the information necessary for the performance of its duties is also not guaranteed by the Supervisory Committee and the stable functioning of the SC Secretariat is not ensured. The motion for a resolution calls on the European Anti-Fraud Office and its Director-General to resolve the problems. In order for the Supervisory Committee to function effectively and to carry out its tasks, all the necessary conditions must be met and the European Parliament has a duty to raise its word to that end. I supported the joint motion for a resolution.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this joint motion for a resolution because I believe that this motion represented a one-sided position regarding OLAF’s activities. I believe that both institutions should have been provided with the opportunity to present their positions before a clear stance was taken by Parliament. In this case the OLAF Director-General was not invited to respond and present its Annual Activity Report and the text voted upon represented only the opinion of the Supervisory Committee.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution follows the 2014 annual report of the European Anti-Fraud Board's (OLAF) supervisory committee, which has raised serious concerns in Parliament. According to the report, there are problems with the independence of the supervisory committee, OLAF's compliance with the regulations governing it, the working arrangements between OLAF and its supervisory committee, and the fulfilment of OLAF's primary mission of effectively protecting the Union's financial interests. Considering that the role of OLAF's supervisory committee, which aims to ensure compliance with the procedures and principles governing the mission of this independent body, needs to be clarified, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. A new action plan for changing the working arrangements of the European Anti-Fraud Office is a necessity. Better cooperation between OLAF and its oversight committee is needed to support the fight against fraud and corruption. There is a need to improve the evaluation of open files to enable the oversight committee to fully and in the best conditions. We call on the Commission to facilitate negotiations between OLAF and its supervisory committee, in order to strengthen the independence, control capacity and efficiency of this institution.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The adoption of the joint motion for a resolution was justified by the facts and problems identified in olaf's Supervisory Committee's 2014 Annual Report. Olaf SC has been heavily criticised for its management, management and case management of the European Anti-Fraud Office, which cannot be ignored. The report strongly criticises the procedure where, on 1 February 2012, 423 cases were opened at the same time on the basis of a decision of the Director-General, without any meaningful examination of olaf's competence in those cases on the basis of fraud, corruption or other illegal activity affecting the Union's financial interests. It is also a problem that the Director-General of OLAF ignores the recommendations of the Supervisory Board, having implemented only 8 of the 50 SC recommendations. Access to the information necessary for the performance of its duties is also not guaranteed, and the stable functioning of the SC Secretariat is also not guaranteed. The motion for a resolution calls on the European Anti-Fraud Office and its Director-General to address these problems. In order for the Supervisory Committee to function effectively and to carry out its tasks, all necessary conditions must be provided. And the European Parliament has a duty to raise its word to this end. I supported the joint motion for a resolution in the plenary vote.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. The 2014 annual report of the OLAF Supervisory Committee points to a number of shortcomings between the supervisory committee and the Director General of OLAF. These observations indicate a worrying lack of transparency.  For this reason, I strongly support the Commission's request to take the necessary measures to improve the ability of the OLAF Oversight Committee to monitor the Independence of the Agency, its investigative functions, the application of procedural safeguards and the duration of investigations. Although it is an independent body, OLAF must comply with the legal requirements that govern its operation and its responsibilities. In particular, the Agency must provide a timely justification for cases in which it has not implemented the recommendations of the oversight committee. For its part, the supervisory committee must have the opportunity to regularly monitor OLAF's compliance with the legal requirements that govern its operation. This mandate must be free to be carried out as it is essential to check whether the priorities of the investigation policy have been properly identified and whether their application has had positive or negative consequences for the fight against fraud and corruption.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – The adoption of the joint motion for a resolution was justified by the facts and problems identified in olaf's Supervisory Committee's 2014 Annual Report. Olaf SC has been heavily criticised for its management, management and case management of the European Anti-Fraud Office, which cannot be ignored. The report strongly criticises the procedure where, on 1 February 2012, 423 cases were opened at the same time on the basis of a decision of the Director-General, without any meaningful examination of olaf's competence in those cases on the basis of fraud, corruption or other illegal activity affecting the Union's financial interests. It is also a problem that the Director-General of OLAF ignores the recommendations of the Supervisory Board, having implemented only 8 of the 50 SC recommendations. Access to the information necessary for the performance of its duties is also not guaranteed, and the stable functioning of the SC Secretariat is also not guaranteed. The motion for a resolution calls on the European Anti-Fraud Office and its Director-General to address these problems. In order for the Supervisory Committee to function effectively and to carry out its tasks, all the necessary conditions must be met and the European Parliament has a duty to raise its word to that end. I supported the joint motion for a resolution in the plenary vote.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the 2014 annual report of the OLAF Oversight Committee. Its investigations must be strictly consistent with the legislative framework on which they depend and testify to specific, valid and justified reasons. In addition, in order for its results to be credible and legitimate, the greatest transparency should be applied to the method with which investigations are developed. The duration of these, in particular, must be clearly stated and any extensions justified.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained on the resolution on the 2014 annual report of the Supervisory Board of the European Anti-Fraud Office. OLAF has been substantially criticised for poor cooperation with its Supervisory Board, which has failed to control OLAF's independence and perform its functions qualitatively because of the refusal to access the necessary documents. I believe that, as the European Anti-Fraud Office, OLAF should be controlled but should also be given the freedom to carry out its duties.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report as OLAF must implement the EC regulations and resolutions. Its DG's compliance with the provision of information to the EU and the submission of annual activity reports enhances transparency and effort for sound management.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The adoption of the joint motion for a resolution was justified by the facts and problems identified in olaf's Supervisory Committee's 2014 Annual Report. Olaf SC has been heavily criticised for its management, management and case management of the European Anti-Fraud Office, which cannot be ignored. The report strongly criticises the procedure where, on 1 February 2012, 423 cases were opened at the same time on the basis of a decision of the Director-General, without any meaningful examination of olaf's competence in those cases on the basis of fraud, corruption or other illegal activity affecting the Union's financial interests. It is also a problem that the Director-General of OLAF ignores the recommendations of the Supervisory Board, having implemented only 8 of the 50 SC recommendations. Access to the information necessary for the performance of its duties is also not guaranteed, and the stable functioning of the SC Secretariat is also not guaranteed. The motion for a resolution calls on the European Anti-Fraud Office and its Director-General to address these problems. In order for the Supervisory Committee to function effectively and to carry out its tasks, all the necessary conditions must be met and the European Parliament has a duty to raise its word to this end. I supported the joint motion for a resolution in the plenary vote.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. I voted against this joint motion for a resolution because I find it regrettable that OLAF was not officially invited to present the OLAF Supervisory Committee Annual Activity Report 2014 in the CONT Committee. The debate was necessary in order to give the newly elected Members the opportunity to have clarification on this issue. In the absence of such a comparison, I do not have sufficient reason to hold OLAF responsible at this point for not complying with the legal requirements for launching an investigation.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it shows great legal and procedural rigour, and aims to establish a certain requirement for the work of OLAF.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 There has long been doubts as to the research activities of this body, in particular as to the dragging, sometimes for years, of investigations and of non-compliance with the rules of protection of respondents. Now, doubts arise about the failure to comply with the supervisory rules and the independence of this body.  This resolution is based on the 2014 annual report of the Olaf Supervisory Committee (CF) and its recommendations.  This report raises doubts as to the opening, in a single day, of 423 cases by a single decision of the Director-General of OLAF, without making adequate assessments of the information received on any of the cases examined by the CF. Most cases do not even show evidence of evaluation activity. The report also notes that the OLAF DG does not take into account the CF's recommendations, it notes the insufficient information provided to the CF in place to carry out its function and the lack of dialogue between the two bodies, with the CF unable to supervise olaf's independence, and there is a clear divergence as to the role and role of the CF on the part of the two bodies. Among others, these aspects are addressed in this resolution, which seems to us to be timely and relevant, and so we voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the OLAF Supervisory Committee considers the key issue in terms of the effectiveness of its supervisory role and fundamental differences in the views of the IP and the Director-General of OLAF on the role of the IP. As this is a very sensitive area of protection of the EU's financial interests and the fight against fraud, it is important that the European Commission take measures to improve the ip's ability to oversee OLAF's independence, its investigative function, the application of procedural safeguards and the duration of investigations, without jeopardising OLAF's independence.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is too critical of the agency's work, although we are also convinced of the need for surveillance in the EU, so I will abstain.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution, which criticises OLAF for poor cooperation with its Supervisory Committee. The Supervisory Committee has consistently pointed out its inability to supervise OLAF’s independence due to the lack of access to necessary information. OLAF did not take into account the three recommendations the Supervisory Committee made in Opinion No 1/2014 – namely that OLAF did not issue guidelines on the application of the selection principles (efficient use of resources, proportionality, subsidiarity/added value) and, instead of reviewing the financial indicators to adapt them to the reality of spending programs, OLAF has abolished them completely.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I agree that OLAF’s independence, transparency and respect for subsidiarity and proportionality need to be ensured and its actions clearly need to be clarified.  However I believe that before taking a stand on OLAF’s activities we should invite this institution to respond to the serious criticisms of the Supervisory Committee Annual Report.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The adoption of the joint motion for a resolution was justified by the facts and problems identified in olaf's Supervisory Committee's 2014 Annual Report. Olaf SC has been heavily criticised for its management, management and case management of the European Anti-Fraud Office, which cannot be ignored. The report strongly criticises the procedure where, on 1 February 2012, 423 cases were opened at the same time on the basis of a decision of the Director-General, without any meaningful examination of olaf's competence in those cases on the basis of fraud, corruption or other illegal activity affecting the Union's financial interests. It is also a problem that the Director-General of OLAF ignores the recommendations of the Supervisory Board, having implemented only 8 of the 50 SC recommendations. Access to the information necessary for the performance of its duties is also not guaranteed, and the stable functioning of the SC Secretariat is also not guaranteed. The motion for a resolution calls on the European Anti-Fraud Office and its Director-General to address these problems. In order for the Supervisory Committee to function effectively and to carry out its tasks, all the necessary conditions must be met and the European Parliament has a duty to raise its word to this end. I supported the joint motion for a resolution in the plenary vote.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The adoption of the joint motion for a resolution was justified by the facts and problems identified in olaf's Supervisory Committee's 2014 Annual Report. Olaf SC has been heavily criticised for its management, management and case management of the European Anti-Fraud Office, which cannot be ignored. The report strongly criticises the procedure where, on 1 February 2012, 423 cases were opened at the same time on the basis of a decision of the Director-General, without any meaningful examination of olaf's competence in those cases on the basis of fraud, corruption or other illegal activity affecting the Union's financial interests. It is also a problem that the Director-General of OLAF ignores the recommendations of the Supervisory Board, having implemented only 8 of the 50 SC recommendations. Access to the information necessary for the performance of its duties is also not guaranteed, and the stable functioning of the SC Secretariat is also not guaranteed. The motion for a resolution calls on the European Anti-Fraud Office and its Director-General to address these problems. In order for the Supervisory Committee to function effectively and to carry out its tasks, all the necessary conditions must be met and the European Parliament has a duty to raise its word to this end. I supported the joint motion for a resolution in the plenary vote.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. Olaf's work is indispensable and very useful, with the overall objective of achieving greater transparency and effectiveness of the Community mechanism. With the vote on the resolution that has just been adopted, I hope that the European institutions will do everything possible to support this institution, with the aim of closer cooperation in order to ensure adequate and complete information for the citizens and parliament.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution, given that the OLAF Director—General has not been invited to present the Annual Activity Report and respond to the opinion of the Supervisory Committee.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. This Resolution calls on the Commission to take immediate action and to submit an action plan to ensure the smooth functioning of the Monitoring Committee of the European Anti-Fraud Office. OLAF's mission is to protect the EU's financial interests; investigate fraud and other illegal activities related to the performance of professional activities by members and staff of EU institutions and bodies; as well as supporting the European institutions and, in particular, the Commission in the development and implementation of anti-fraud rules and policies. This role should be carried out with complete transparency and respect for the legal procedures established by the EU, especially with regard to the mandate entrusted to the Monitoring Committee. That is why I support this resolution.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against this Resolution on the report of OLAF's Monitoring Committee. We understand that there must be verifiable systems in place to ensure an improvement in the performance and tools available to OLAF, but we consider that any supervisory system that arises must be covered by transparent bodies chosen with the most democratic tools available to OLAF, and not by third parties that could be favoured by a supervisory body that was semi-elected and operated by institutions that may also require the research work of OLAF.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the resolution. This text represents only the opinion of the Supervisory Committee without inviting the OLAF Director—General to respond and present the Annual Activity Report. I regret that an incomplete debate was pushed forward without the plenary having the chance to deliver a proper and fully—informed opinion. We call for more efficient debates, with respect for transparency and full disclosure to Parliament and EU citizens.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the 2014 annual report of olaf's Supervisory Committee because I believe that certain actions taken by this Committee are ineffective and require revision. In 2014, the OLAF Committee resolved only 8.4% of the cases submitted to them, failed to comply with the recommendations of the SC Committee and misalted its resources. I believe that we need to ensure that EU committees and institutions work transparently, efficiently and quickly, even if this requires supervision. This will not only improve the work of the EU, but we will also promote the proper allocation of resources and resources.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The adoption of the joint motion for a resolution was justified by the facts and problems identified in the 2014 Annual Report of the Supervisory Committee of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF). Olaf SC has been heavily criticised for its management, management and case management of the European Anti-Fraud Office, which cannot be ignored. The report strongly criticises the procedure where, on 1 February 2012, 423 cases were opened at the same time on the basis of a decision of the Director-General, without any meaningful examination of olaf's competence in those cases on the basis of fraud, corruption or other illegal activity affecting the Union's financial interests. It is also a problem that the Director-General of OLAF ignores the recommendations of the Supervisory Board, having implemented only 8 of the 50 SC recommendations. Access to the information necessary for the performance of its duties is also not guaranteed, and the stable functioning of the SC Secretariat is also not guaranteed. The motion for a resolution calls on the European Anti-Fraud Office and its Director-General to resolve these problems for the effective functioning of the Supervisory Committee and for it to be able to carry out its tasks with all the necessary conditions, and the European Parliament has a duty to raise its word to that end. I supported the joint motion for a resolution in the plenary vote, in accordance with the position of the Hungarian delegation from the People's Party.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the OLAF Supervisory Committee’s annual report 2014. It is regrettable that the SC has had to continuously point out its inability to supervise OLAF’s independence and carry out its investigative function due to a lack of access to necessary information, which appears to stem from a fundamental difference of views between the SC and the OLAF D—G in their perceptions of the SC’s role. It is essential that the SC be able to fully implement its mandate, and I welcome the call on the Commission to take measures to improve the SC’s ability to supervise OLAF’s independence, its investigative function, the application of procedural guarantees and the duration of investigations without, however, putting OLAF’s independence at risk.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that this report demonstrates the need for the Parliament to have proper oversight of OLAF’s activities as well as the decisions taken by OLAF’s supervisory committee. There is concern that OLAF has not implemented the recommendations of the Supervisory Committee in a sufficient way and I believe Parliament needs answers to this. The Budgetary Control Committee should maintain its supervisory procedures over OLAF’s activities in this regard.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted against this Resolution on the report of OLAF's Monitoring Committee. We understand that there must be verifiable systems in place to ensure an improvement in the performance and tools available to OLAF, but we consider that any supervisory system that arises must be covered by transparent bodies chosen with the most democratic tools available to OLAF, and not by third parties that could be favoured by a supervisory body that was semi-elected and operated by institutions that may also require the research work of OLAF.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for an oral question on olaf's annual work report for 2014, as it is obvious that such an important EU institution has serious internal problems. It is inadmissible for such an important institution to have insufficiently defined procedures for its operations. It is also inadmissible that there are problems in the functioning of OLAF and the Supervisory Board and that there is a lack of transparency in action, which cannot guarantee the independence of the Supervisory Board.  Given OLAF's area of activity, which is primarily in charge of legality and fraud prevention, e.g. when using EU funds, this represents a serious debacle and destroys the reputation of the EU institutions in front of citizens, regional and local institutions and businessmen. In this regard, I would like to point out that I am in favour of the introduction of the European Prosecutor's post.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This draft resolution is of all the proposals, the one that is the most critical of OLAF. The latter, which issued its annual report for 2014, finds itself under fire from many parliamentarians (EPP, GUE/NGL and Greens/ALE). Many questions and a lack of transparency about the manner in which OLAF conducts its investigations strongly call into question OLAF's independence from the governing bodies of the European Union. Indeed, OLAF tends to open too many investigations, without having the necessary information or motives. It is also important to highlight the close links between its Director General Mr Kessler and the President of the European Parliament Mr Schulz.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the annual report of OLAF's supervisory committee. The report calls on the Commission to play an active role in facilitating a constructive dialogue between the supervisory committee and OLAF. Indeed, the 2014 report pointed out that OLAF manipulated its figures and statistics, thus distorting the reading of the supervisory committee, which is obviously not acceptable, especially given the vital mission of OLAF. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am in favour of this motion for a resolution. OLAF is doing a good job and is essential to maintaining the integrity of the European Parliament.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this joint motion for a resolution. As the report casts doubt on OLAF’s effectiveness in protecting the Union’s financial interests, it is imperative that Parliament deal urgently with the issue. The Supervisory Committee must be able to fulfil its role. Parliament has already called, in resolutions on the 2011 and 2013 annual reports on the protection of the EU’s financial interests, for an improvement in the committee’s ability to fulfil its mandate. The fight against fraud and corruption is of the utmost importance. It is regrettable that the Supervisory Committee is unable to carry out its duties due to a lack of access to information, and it is very worrying if the figures supplied by OLAF are in doubt. I welcome the proposals for the Commission to facilitate a better, more constructive dialogue between OLAF and its Supervisory Committee.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the resolution. This text represents only the opinion of the Supervisory Committee, without the OLAF Director General having been invited to respond and present the annual activity report. I find it regrettable that an incomplete debate was pushed forward without the plenary having the chance to deliver a proper, fully informed opinion. We call for more efficient debates, with respect for transparency and full disclosure to Parliament and EU citizens.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. The facts and problems identified in his report were justified by the facts and problems identified in his report. Olaf SC has been heavily criticised for its management, management and case management of the European Anti-Fraud Office, which cannot be ignored. The report strongly criticises the procedure where, on 1 February 2012, 423 cases were opened at the same time on the basis of a decision of the Director-General, without any meaningful examination of olaf's competence in those cases on the basis of fraud, corruption or other illegal activity affecting the Union's financial interests. It is also a problem that the Director-General of OLAF ignores the recommendations of the Supervisory Board, having implemented only 8 of the 50 SC recommendations. Access to the information necessary for the performance of its duties is also not guaranteed, and the stable functioning of the SC Secretariat is also not guaranteed. The motion for a resolution calls on the European Anti-Fraud Office and its Director-General to address these problems. In order for the Supervisory Committee to function effectively and to carry out its tasks, all the necessary conditions must be met and the European Parliament has a duty to raise its word to this end. I supported the joint motion for a resolution in the plenary vote.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Today's proposal concerns the 2014 annual report of OLAF's Supervisory Committee. OLAF, the European Anti-Fraud Office, was set up with the aim of combating fraud, corruption and any illegal activity that is of abuse of the Community's financial interests. This text contains the activity report in 2014 and underlines, among other points, the importance of a public comparison between OLAF and the Monitoring Committee on OLAF's responses to opinions and other documents included in the Supervisory Committee's 2014 Annual Activity Report.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution put forward by the EPP, Greens and GUE groups on the 2014 annual report of the OLAF Oversight Committee. This report raises serious problems with the functioning of this supervisory committee whose independence is not respected by OLAF, in violation of its own regulations, particularly with regard to the lack of an assessment of the opening of investigations.  That is why the resolution I voted on calls on the European Commission to play an active role on this issue by facilitating a constructive dialogue between the supervisory committee and OLAF, which protects the Union's financial interests.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it denounces the scandalous way in which OLAF (European Anti-Fraud Office) is used to carrying out its investigations. I am well placed to know that this is true, since I myself am persecuted by this organization.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: in writing. ‒ On 4 May 2015, the Supervisory Committee presented its annual report on the activities of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF). OLAF was not invited to respond. The Supervisory Committee makes a number of very critical points: it questions OLAF’s independence, transparency, respect for subsidiarity and proportionality. In such a situation, we should have had the opportunity to listen to the responses of OLAF’s Director-General.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted for it. This resolution echoes criticisms already made by the oversight committee in 2014. Indeed, the organization has already been criticized for its way of conducting its investigations. Together with my colleagues, I have decided to support this resolution because it reminds OLAF that it must also obey well-defined rules. It is a matter of making him understand that he does not have all the powers and that his investigations must be based on concrete data. It is therefore appropriate to allow better control of OLAF by the supervisory committee.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. Our group does not support this Resolution because it is based on the accusations made by the Monitoring Committee without OLAF itself being able to give explanations in the Committee on Budgetary Control and without waiting to analyse the annual report which was submitted only yesterday, 2 June, and which would have shed light on much of the criticisms made. Our group believes that both institutions — OLAF and the Surveillance Committee — should be heard, and not just based on the analysis of one of the two parties concerned, in order to have a proven view of reality. We also want to be fair and give the DIRECTOR of OLAF the same possibility of explaining in the Committee on Budgetary Control before raising the point to the plenary. I therefore voted against the Resolution.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution as it is a necessary exercise of control by the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) by the European Parliament. This Office is an institution that controls possible fraud contrary to the EU's financial interests. In its field of activity it conducts investigations into fraud, corruption or bad practices in cases affecting the EU budget. This Resolution points to different irregularities in the different disputes between the Surveillance Committee and OLAF itself. Seeking to adopt a political position aimed at improving its functioning, the Resolution also draws attention to the disproportionate allocation of resources and calls for a balanced allocation of resources. It is the commitment to improve the functioning of this very important institution that I have decided to vote in favour of this Resolution.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The Mission of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) is to detect, investigate and eliminate misuse of EU funds. The report submitted for the year 2014 shows the concrete results of fraud prevention with a view to ensuring the spending of EU taxpayers' money solely for the purposes for which it was originally intended.  OLAF received the highest number of fraud reports since its creation in 1999 in 2014. Precisely 1 417 cases represent increased trust by citizens, institutions and other partners. The report submitted suggests that there are problems with the supervisory board's independence, OLAF's compliance with the OLAF Regulation and the methods of conduct between OLAF and its supervisory board.  Accordingly, the report leaves doubts about how effectively OLAF protects the Financial Interests of the Union. It is important to remove these doubts as soon as possible, which is what this resolution points to, so I supported it.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
