text: in writing. The Resolution was initiated by the popular, green and communists. We Social Democrats don't participate. My group voted against it, and so did I. In the end, this resolution was adopted: 448 Deputies in favour, 197 against and 53 abstentions.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing \ u2012 Misuse of European Union funds and fraud significantly threatens and harms the economic and economic interests of the Union. This is one of the factors that is ultimately also influenced by the lack of growth in competitiveness and the increase in poverty among the population in the regions. Eliminating this problem requires efficient and systemic work by OLAF, while complying with the legal rules of this activity. The Supervisory Committee must have all the conditions in place to be able to monitor and control OLAF's investigative activities effectively and effectively, and the control rules must be set out in a clear and unquestionable manner. Any signs of transparency and non-communication on the part of OLAF cast doubt on the activities and legitimacy of the current position of olaf. The parties involved must therefore do their part to remove these doubts.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the OLAF Supervisory Committee's 2014 Annual Activity Report, because this report was well documented.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution in order to accentuate further the responsibility OLAF holds, especially in respect of complying with the legal requirements for opening an investigation and providing justification for the cases in which the Supervisory Committee’s recommendations were not implemented. It is worrisome that the Supervisory Committee feels incapacitated in fully implementing its mandate. I believe the Commission should take additional measures in that regard. Moreover, the Commission should further facilitate the negotiations between OLAF and the Supervisory Committee by speeding up the delivery of an action plan with a view to amending the working arrangements between the two entities so as to create a working environment in which, inter alia, there is no hindrance to the committee fulfilling its mandate.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this motion for a resolution. This text rightly criticises the way OLAF conducts its investigations, and highlights the dysfunctions of the system. We support this proposal because it asks OLAF to comply with the legal provisions governing the initiation of an investigation, which suggests that OLAF tends to open investigations without the necessary evidence or justifications. It also calls for increased cooperation with the supervisory committee so that it can monitor the duration of investigations (sometimes arbitrarily fixed), and that the information transmitted to it by OLAF is improved.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution on the 2014 report of olaf's Supervisory Committee underlines that the Supervisory Committee report raises problems relating to the statistics, timing and clarity of investigations supported by OLAF in 2014. I abstained because I regard Parliament's resolution as a hasty decision on the publication of OLAF's responses to the annual report of its Supervisory Committee. I also think it is important to work to create the conditions for a constructive dialogue that makes it clear between OLAF and the Supervisory Committee.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe it is essential that OLAF's work complies with the standards of legality, and responsibility. That is why I have chosen to support this resolution with a vote in favour, which calls on OLAF to act in full compliance with the legal requirements necessary for the initiation of an investigation.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The motion for a Resolution adopted in the European Parliament on the 2014 report of the OLAF Monitoring Committee — the European Anti-Fraud Office - calls for some actions to be corrected to improve the functioning of this body. My support, therefore, for the report, which seeks to establish mechanisms for this Office, so fundamental to the proper control of EU activity, can work appropriately and eliminate uns professional behaviour that has been detected in OLAF.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The joint motion for a resolution notes an insufficient position of the Supervisory Committee (SC) and cites unsatisfactory cooperation (OLAF very rarely implements the SC's recommendations) or the SC's lack or unexplained legal means of providing guidance to DG OLAF. In addition, this motion for a resolution recommends that DG OLAF should reconsider its allocation of funds, as around 86% of investigations had to be carried out in the field of agriculture and structural funds. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. It is necessary to fight fraud, it must be done in the service of European citizens and therefore, independently, effectively and with respect for the protection of the personal data of all citizens. As it stands, OLAF (European Anti-Fraud Office) is unable to meet these requirements. The text refers to the conflict between OLAF and its supervisory committee, which believes that it does not have the means to monitor OLAF's actions. The resolution denounces this situation and asks OLAF to comply with its legal obligations when it opens an investigation.  I'm voting for, which seems to me to be the minimum.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. OLAF, which issued its annual report for 2014, has been criticised by many parliamentarians. Many questions and a lack of transparency about the way OLAF conducts its investigations strongly call into question OLAF's independence from EU governing bodies.  Indeed, OLAF tends to open too many investigations without having the necessary information or motives. They also call for the supervisory committee to be able to monitor the duration of investigations and to improve the information provided by OLAF to the supervisory committee.    It is also important to highlight the close links between its Director General Mr Kessler and the President of the European Parliament, Mr Schulz. While we see every day that Mr Schulz is a President of the European Parliament who is a supporter of the FN, his links with the Director General of OLAF raise questions, but also a problem. For all these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 2014 Annual Report of the OLAF Supervisory Committee. It is a legal imperative to comply with the requirements laid down for the opening of an investigation, which OLAF must follow. I would like to highlight the need for OLAF and the Supervisory Committee to cooperate in order to improve the information provided, as well as the fulfilment of OLAF's commitment to report to the Supervisory Committee on the number of complaints received and the speed of its handling.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this cross-party resolution as it succinctly points out the many issues facing the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) Supervisory Committee. It is important that the Commission takes concrete steps to ensure that the Supervisory Committee can oversee OLAF’s independence and its ability to investigate in an effective and efficient manner.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the annual 2014 report of the OLAF Supervisory Committee.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 As a representative of a country that has given OLAF a particularly great much work and where a striking number of OLAF investigations have led to a regrettable positive result, I very much appreciate OLAF's activities. Of the three draft resolutions, S&D's proposal best reflects my opinion on OLAF's activities, which is why I voted for it.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) is the subject of a critical report, questioning its arbitrary practices in launching and managing procedures and its lack of transparency. For an organization charged with enforcing ethics within institutions, it is paradoxical to see that it is reluctant to impose such discipline on itself. Criticism of this should therefore be supported.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that measures need to be taken to ensure olaf's independence and that, at the same time, the OLAF Supervisory Committee has the necessary conditions and resources to fulfil its mandate.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This draft resolution on the 2014 annual report of the OLAF Supervisory Committee is in line with the 2014 report of the supervisory committee warning against OLAF's practices, particularly in the way it conducts investigations. It has many reservations about the opening and duration of investigations (which tend to be prolonged for no real reason). It strongly recommends that OLAF comply with the legal procedures provided in the event of an investigation. Indeed, the anti-fraud agency is sometimes won by a certain subjectivity or haste the opening of an investigation, without the necessary information or motives. The resolution also proposes to allow the supervisory committee to monitor the duration of investigations and to improve the information that OLAF transmits to the Oversight Committee. For these reasons, I have decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the 2014 annual report of the Supervisory Committee of the European Anti-Fraud Office. This report highlights the shortcomings of OLAF, which does not respect the independence of the supervisory committee, in violation of its own regulations. In particular, it points out the lack of an assessment of the opening of investigations and possible manipulation of statistics on the duration of these investigations, which does not allow a good assessment of the situation by the supervisory committee. It calls on the Commission to play an active role and facilitate a constructive dialogue between the supervisory committee and OLAF, whose role is to protect the Union's financial interests.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 With this resolution we wish to express our strong disappointment that for the first time the Committee on Budgetary Control has not sent any official invitation to the Director-General of OLAF, despite the importance of the 2014 Annual Activity Report of the planned Monitoring Committee and despite the intensive debate between the two bodies. We believe that a fair debate is needed on both annual activity reports for 2014 in order to ensure that Parliament can take into account all relevant information available in reported cases of corruption, injury to the Interests of the Union and fraud in the Community budget. We regret that the House does not thus have the opportunity to express an appropriate and fully informed opinion. We take this opportunity to reiterate our call for OLAF to be more independent, transparent in its activities and to respect the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I voted for it because there is a real problem within OLAF. It is necessary for the oversight committee and the director to find a harmonized relationship in order to put an end to the crisis affecting this organization.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2014 Annual Activity Report of olaf's Supervisory Committee raised concerns about the committee's independence and OLAF's compliance with the regulation governing it. I therefore decided to support the recommendation calling on the Commission to facilitate negotiations between OLAF and the Supervisory Committee by establishing an action plan by 31 December 2015 with a view to amending the working arrangements in order to create an operational environment in which the Supervisory Committee can fulfil its mandate, and urges OLAF to respect its legal obligations in order to enable the Supervisory Committee to fulfil its supervisory functions in accordance with the law and transparency.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Since its foundation in 1999, OLAF has completed 3 500 investigations, resulting in the recovery of more than EUR 1.1 billion to the EU budget. I have voted for this motion for a resolution in order to have a better view of the OLAF Supervisory Committee annual activity report and improved communication between OLAF’s Director-General and its Supervisory Committee.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report due to some serious concerns raised in the 2014 annual activity report of OLAF's Supervisory Committee. IT is true that OLAF's activities are a step in the right direction. However, it cannot be assumed beyond doubt that OLAF is capable of effectively protecting the financial interests of the European Union.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This annual report contains a number of criticisms of the functioning of OLAF, a body tasked with tracking down and preventing cases of fraud in the European Union. The oversight committee noted that there were questionable practices within the agency. Since these revelations, cooperation between OLAF and the Committee on Budgetary Control has deteriorated. Among the criticisms, it is mentioned that almost 90% of the cases opened by OLAF are not followed by any recommendation, or that too much attention is paid to "tobacco and counterfeiting", but too little for fraud at the CAP or structural funds level.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the 2014 report of the European Anti-Fraud Office Supervisory Committee. OLAF is part of the European Commission, which has a special independent status for conducting anti-fraud investigations. Unfortunately, however, the issue has not been dealt with until the end. More effective discussions are needed that respect the principle of transparency and make matters fully public to the European Parliament and EU citizens. The Commission should facilitate the talks between OLAF and the Supervisory Committee in this respect.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. The European Anti-Fraud Office must have as its fundamental and immovable axis independence from the work it does. However, we are concerned that, in some cases, there will be a malfunction of this Office. Its own Monitoring Committee has raised serious doubts as regards, precisely, the independence of OLAF's actions. Without safe, effective and demonstrable independence, we cannot rely on a mechanism, especially if fraud is fought, one of the greatest concerns of European citizens. It is a scourge affecting all Member States, and our duty to clean up and traceability must reach every corner. There are millions of Europeans who are having a hard time, and the institutions must extend their vigilance, control and certainty to all their areas of action.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – In particular, appropriate democratic control must be ensured. It can never go beyond the limits of legitimacy. The Supervisory Committee is responsible for overseeing OLAF's independence, its investigative function, the application of procedural safeguards and the duration of investigations. Close cooperation is necessary for the proper assessment of the functioning of the institutions. It should be noted that OLAF has repeatedly proposed a new review of the working arrangements in order to reach a mutually satisfactory practical agreement.  During the debate in the Committee on Budgetary Control on the 2014 annual report of olaf's Supervisory Committee, representatives of OLAF and the Supervisory Committee were to be invited to the meeting. In order to resolve the situation, a public debate is needed on OLAF's replies to opinions and other documents. In addition, the Commission must play a crucial role as an intermediary in the negotiations between OLAF and the Supervisory Committee. A review of the agreement on the Rules of Procedure must be carried out as soon as possible. The role of the Supervisory Committee and its scope of action have been clarified.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) is responsible for protecting the EU's financial interests by investigating fraud and illegal activities at European level. In view of the fact that OLAF has not taken account of the recommendations made by the Monitoring Committee and that cooperation between olaf and OLAF is proceeding in a fluid manner, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union needs to ensure high-level supervision of how EU funds are applied in order to avoid fraud or manipulation of any kind. I agree that the Supervisory Committee needs to review previous figures, and the Commission will have to take action to improve current results.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ OLAF's Supervisory Board of Work has informed us that it has no transparent insight into OLAF's work and that the powers and role of the NO are undefined. It continuously underlines its inability to monitor OLAF's independence, its investigative role and the length of investigations due to lack of access to the necessary information.  The Supervisory Board pointed out that with one decision of its Director-General OLAF opened 423 cases in the same day, which is contrary to the legal conditions for opening OLAF investigations, and highlighted a number of other maladministrations. I therefore support no's efforts to seek greater powers and full insight into all OLAF documentation.  On the other hand, OLAF, in its statement regarding the 2014 annual report, presented its record successes, and I certainly commend that. In addition, OLAF is increasingly encouraging global action against fraud and corruption, which often transcend national borders, which I also consider important. It is evident from all that there is no mutual cooperation between olaf leaders and the Supervisory Board.  Therefore, I support the efforts of the European Commission, which wishes to resolve disputes between OLAF and the Supervisory Board, I consider it necessary to clearly redefine the powers, responsibilities and obligations of OLAF and the Supervisory Board, and to ensure the supervision and application of the adopted processes, with a view to protecting and transparency the use of EU citizens' money.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This draft resolution on the 2014 annual report of the OLAF Oversight Committee is in line with the 2014 report of the supervisory committee warning against the agency's practices, particularly in the way it conducts investigations. It has many reservations about the opening and duration of investigations (which tend to be prolonged for no real reason). It strongly recommends that OLAF comply with the legal procedures provided in the event of an investigation, and I must express my concern that such a basic recommendation should be made. Indeed, the anti-fraud agency is sometimes won by a certain subjectivity or hastens in the opening of an investigation, when it has neither the necessary information nor the necessary motives.  The resolution also proposes to allow the supervisory committee to monitor the duration of investigations and to improve the information that OLAF transmits to the supervisory committee. For these reasons, I have decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) has a responsibility to protect the Union's financial interests by investigating fraud, corruption and any other illegal activity that deprives the European Union budget of high amounts, and its Supervisory Board was set up to strengthen and guarantee its independence by regularly monitoring the implementation of OLAF's investigative task. While the European Anti-Fraud Office points out that in 2014 it achieved excellent results in the fight against fraud across Europe, Parliament expresses serious concern with this resolution following reports by OLAF's Supervisory Board pointing to a number of failings and shortcomings as well as the impossibility of implementing the mandate entrusted to it. Given that corruption remains one of the biggest challenges facing the EU, as it detrimentally affects public finances and undermines citizens' trust in democratic processes, I believe that the work of institutions, bodies and all services in this segment must be flawless. Parliament clearly requires the Commission to take concrete measures to improve the Supervisory Board's ability to oversee OLAF and its investigative function, so I support the resolution submitted following a question for an oral response on olaf's supervisory board's 2014 annual report.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to abstain on the resolution because I believe it is incomplete and this provides a partial picture of relations between OLAF and the Supervisory Committee. I do not want to go into the substance of the individual points, but with regard to the opening of 423 cases on the same day, I believe that the protection of the procedural rights of the persons concerned has only been strengthened by the very opening of investigations. It would have been more constructive to give OLAF time to respond to the criticisms made and to have a more complete and up-to-date view of the current situation. Let us remember that OLAF and the Supervisory Committee are two independent bodies, and hasty and incomplete action can unnecessarily sour relations between both of them instead of improving them.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The European Parliament has approved the 2014 annual report of the OLAF Supervisory Committee. I voted in favour of this text. However, if the report was adopted, MEPs wished to remind the European Anti-Fraud Office of the importance of transparent reporting and reliable statistics. This is all the more crucial since this office must lead by example at EU level. This report is a wake-up call for OLAF and Parliament will closely monitor the work and results of this body.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The annual activity report of the OLAF Supervisory Committee notes that, at the time of the reorganisation of OLAF on 1 February 2012, 423 cases were opened on the same day, through a single decision of the Director-General (DG) of the body. The opening of these cases has been in contradiction with the legal requirement to open an investigation, which requires for this purpose that there is a sufficiently serious suspicion of fraud, corruption or other illegal activity likely to affect the financial interests of the Union. Parliament, to this end, emphasises OLAF's responsibility for complying with the legal requirements relating to the opening of an investigation, noting that of the 423 cases opened in February 2012, only 8.4% resulted in recommendations – this signals the insubstantiality of olaf's DG decisions and the lack of transparency of olaf's accountability obligations. Finally, the European Parliament's motion for a resolution calls on OLAF to think about a redistribution of resources and has denounced an imbalance in the distribution of human resources; of these, only 33% are scheduled to monitor 86% of the Union's financial interests. I voted in favour.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. In this time of economic turbulence, it is essential to ensure that European taxpayers' money is used in a relevant manner and in accordance with established rules.  From this perspective, the role of the European Anti-Fraud Office is essential. In order to carry out its investigations, the independence of OLAF is a prerequisite. But if this principle is misused by this institution in order to evade democratic control, it risks breaking the balance of power. However, for the third year in a row, OLAF's supervisory committee has pointed out the difficulties it faces in ensuring its mission of democratic control due to inadequate regulation.  That is why Parliament is asking the Commission to look at the revision of the legal instruments and to find solutions so that OLAF is truly accountable. Better control rules are possible, while respecting the independence of this body. It is not only the credibility of OLAF and the European institutions that is at stake, but also the credibility of our commitment to the fight against fraud involving European funds.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted against this Resolution because it is based on the accusations made by the Monitoring Committee of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) without the Office itself being able to provide its explanations in the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control and without waiting to analyse the content of the annual report submitted by OLAF on 2 June. It is regrettable that, for the first time, the Committee on Budgetary Control did not send a formal invitation to the Director-General of OLAF, despite the importance of the 2014 Activity Report of the Monitoring Committee and despite the intense debate between the two bodies, and that it has not attached the same importance, or the necessary attention, to the presentation of OLAF's annual report. This approach has prevented Parliament from having the possibility of holding a full and substantive debate, with all the information on the table.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the Commission to facilitate negotiations between the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) and its supervisory committee by drawing up an action plan by 31 December to amend the working arrangements to enable the supervisory committee to fulfil its mandate under satisfactory conditions. Parliament calls, in summary, on the European Commission to take steps to improve the capacity of the OLAF oversight committee to monitor the independence of the Office.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This joint resolution is based on the analysis of the 2014 annual report of the Supervisory Committee (CF) of OLAF (European Anti-Fraud Office) and its recommendations.  Among other considerations, the report states that the Director-General of OLAF did not take into account the recommendations of the Supervisory Board (CF), also stating that the latter does not have sufficient information for the performance of its functions and alerting to the difficulty of understanding between the two bodies, which means that the CF has a limited range of action to oversee olaf's action and independence. Furthermore, the text of the report also requires OLAF to comply with the legal requirements for the CF to be able to fulfil one of its essential tasks, in particular as regards the supervision of the duration of OLAF investigations. This CF report was considered appropriate and relevant, so in view of the above and the most recent report, I believe that this resolution deserves my welcome and a vote in favour.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported this resolution which calls on the Commission to take measures to improve the supervisory committee's ability to monitor the independence of OLAF (European Anti-Fraud Office), its investigative functions, the application of procedural safeguards and the duration of investigations, without jeopardising OLAF's independence. Indeed, the 2014 annual report of the OLAF Supervisory Committee raises serious problems, including the lack of an evaluation of the opening of investigations. It is essential that OLAF comply with legal requirements to enable the supervisory committee to fulfil one of its essential functions, which relates to monitoring the duration of OLAF's investigations.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution tabled by the PPE on the 2014 annual report of olaf's Supervisory Committee. My group's proposal, which has been interested in this issue for years, highlights the problems concerning the independence of the Supervisory Committee, which is accused of a lack of transparency and effectiveness, specifically the manipulation of statistics with the aim of making its investigations much shorter than they actually are. I voted in favour because I believe that we must carry out the necessary investigations and check that this institution is working properly.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against this Resolution on the report of OLAF's Monitoring Committee. We understand that there must be verifiable systems in place to ensure an improvement in the performance and tools available to OLAF, but we consider that any supervisory system that arises must be covered by transparent bodies chosen with the most democratic tools available to OLAF, and not by third parties that could be favoured by a supervisory body that was semi-elected and operated by institutions that may also require the research work of OLAF.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Socialist & Democrat MEPs voted against the motion for a resolution on the OLAF Supervisory Committee’s annual report for 2014.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing \ u2012 I voted in favour. I share the demand for greater need for efficiency as well as transparency for OLAF, which will ensure a greater number of cases under investigation. I would like to add that the real solution would be to improve the efficiency of the final stage of the investigation, when olaf's case is taken over by the law enforcement authorities of that country and there we still have a low success rate within the EU.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I accept the annual report of olaf's Supervisory Board, as I believe that OLAF should always and without exception protect the financial interests of the Union.  I also believe that the Commission should answer questions about the incident of opening a case, the compliance with the legal requirements of the OLAF Regulations, the Commission's view of the Commission's methods of conduct and the working relationship between OLAF and its Supervisory Board and how it intends to facilitate a constructive dialogue that is important for the protection of the Union's interests.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution as it takes into account only the views of the Supervisory Committee and not those of OLAF itself. OLAF has yet to make a presentation to the Committee on Budgetary Control and it should be able to do so as per the usual procedure, in order to ensure a fair and balanced resolution. This resolution was one-sided and premature and I voted in favour of the S&D Group’s alternative resolution which makes this clear. We must make certain that investigations into the effectiveness of European bodies are conducted, and reported on, in a thorough manner in order to ensure accurate and useful conclusions.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. OLAF contributes to the efforts of the EU institutions to make the best use of taxpayers' money. The mission of the European Anti-Fraud Office is extremely important as it protects the financial interests of the European Union by investigating fraud, corruption and other illegal activities, investigates issues related to the performance of official duties by members and staff in the European institutions, and supports the EU institutions, in particular the European Commission, in developing and implementing anti-fraud legislation and policies. OLAF receives an increasing amount of information on possible fraud and irregularities through external and internal investigations, from a wide range of sources. The Supervisory Board's annual report for 2014 has attracted a lot of attention in the media and the public. Given the role of the European Anti-Fraud Office, it is extremely important that the work of this office is monitored and analysed. The public must have a quality insight into the work and operations of that body. Olaf's latest work report raised some specific questions about potential illegal phone tapping.  The Supervisory Board has requested that an analysis of the legality of the use of such research funds be carried out. Once a response has been received, the Supervisory Board still considers that OLAF lacks a legal basis for such eavesdropping, although OLAF disagrees. It is important to point out that the role of the Supervisory Board is the general oversight of the institution, not the review of individual procedures in certain cases.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Resolution of the European People's Party and the Greens on the 2014 annual report of olaf's Supervisory Committee. As is clear from olaf's 2014 annual report, OLAF has not produced an adequate assessment of the information received for any of the matters analysed by the Supervisory Committee, the vast majority of cases are not even a trace of any evaluation, and of the 50 recommendations issued by olaf only 8 were fully implemented by OLAF. I therefore join the Commission's call to encourage negotiations between OLAF and the Supervisory Committee by drawing up, by 31 December 2015, an action plan to complement the arrangements for working, thus establishing a working environment in which the Supervisory Committee can fulfil its mandate.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 OLAF must implement the EC regulations and resolutions. Its DG's compliance with the provision of information to the EU and the submission of annual activity reports enhances transparency and effort for sound management.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 By my vote, I did not support the joint motion for a resolution on the 2014 annual report of olaf's supervisory board because, in my opinion, the planned resolution of the Socialists and Democrats Group (S&D) painted a much more accurate picture of the situation. By my vote, I wanted to support this S&D resolution, but this draft was not put to the vote because of the adoption of the joint motion for a resolution. However, I would like to underline that the European Anti-Fraud Office is engaged in a key activity, as it protects the Union's financial interests. Olaf's performance in 2014, which was set out in its annual report, is remarkable and welcome.  At the same time, all disputes with the Audit Committee need to be fully clarified so that internal conflicts do not in the slightest deter the fight against corruption. This requires an unhindered exchange of information between OLAF and the Audit Committee and full transparency.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for the resolution and I share the amazement of my colleagues.  It is OLAF's responsibility to comply with the legal requirements that govern the initiation of an investigation. It is worth recalling that of the 423 files opened in a single day, only 8.4% of those closed resulted in recommendations being made. The supervisory committee must seriously and regularly monitor compliance with legal requirements!

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Combating fraud and actions that are harmful, both to national budgets and the Budget of the European Union, especially in times of fiscal consolidation and economic recovery, is necessary. OLAF therefore plays a responsible role in assisting both the authorities in the Union and the authorities of the Member States in order to recognise the financial fraud, threats and risks that come with them in a timely way.  However, I would like to stress that states must find a compromise between the need to generate monetary revenues and the need not to overload them, as the rates of various taxes such as the VAT rate are an incentive to not report cash flows and therefore I must also take the opportunity here to reiterate the need for tax relief for our citizens and entrepreneurs. I supported the proposal for a resolution, as I believe that the functioning of the Office must be fully complementary to the work of its Supervisory Board in order to ensure the effectiveness of investigations, but also quality cooperation with partners in reporting and detecting irregularities considered fraudulent.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \ i supported OLAF's 2014 annual report. It is necessary to stress strongly olaf's responsibility in complying with the legal requirements for initiating an investigation. I think it is regrettable that the Monitoring Committee was unable to draw up a conclusion on whether the priorities of the investigative policy had been properly defined and if their implementation had positive or negative consequences in the fight against fraud and corruption.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against this Resolution on the report of OLAF's Monitoring Committee. We understand that there must be verifiable systems in place to ensure an improvement in the performance and tools available to OLAF, but we consider that any supervisory system that arises must be covered by transparent bodies chosen with the most democratic tools available to OLAF, and not by third parties that could be favoured by a supervisory body that was semi-elected and operated by institutions that may also require the research work of OLAF.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ Better policymaking means closing the gap between the EU institutions and EU citizens. For this purpose, it is of the utmost importance to have all the relevant information. Recovering our citizens' trust in the EU institutions is an obligation and this resolution is an opportunity to achieve this goal. I have the impression that some citizens feel that the EU institutions are far away from their daily life and are not yet transparent enough. Hence, I welcome any decision that improves the quality of the whole process of EU policymaking. Therefore, a fair debate on both 2014 annual activity reports in order to ensure that Parliament can take into consideration all available relevant information on such an important policy of the European Union is fundamental.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. Of all the motions for a resolution presented, it is the most critical of OLAF. It is in line with the report of the supervisory committee, which in its 2014 report expresses serious concerns about the way OLAF conducts its investigations. The report casts doubt on the opening and duration of investigations. These tend to be extended without valid explanations.  This resolution stresses that it is OLAF's responsibility to comply with the legal requirements governing the initiation of an investigation. It therefore makes it clear that OLAF tends to open investigations without the necessary information or motives. It calls for the supervisory committee to be able to monitor the duration of investigations and to improve the information that OLAF transmits to the Oversight Committee. I vote for this text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted against this Resolution on the report of OLAF's Monitoring Committee. We understand that there must be verifiable systems in place to ensure an improvement in the performance and tools available to OLAF, but we consider that any supervisory system that arises must be covered by transparent bodies chosen with the most democratic tools available to OLAF, and not by third parties that could be favoured by a supervisory body that was semi-elected and operated by institutions that may also require the research work of OLAF.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution as it highlights the concerns we have about the practices carried out within OLAF and its relationship with the OLAF Monitoring Committee.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution as it is a necessary exercise of control by the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) by the European Parliament. This Office is an institution that controls possible fraud contrary to the EU's financial interests. In its field of activity it conducts investigations into fraud, corruption or bad practices in cases affecting the EU budget. This Resolution points to different irregularities in the different disputes between the Surveillance Committee and OLAF itself. Seeking to adopt a political position aimed at improving its functioning, the Resolution also draws attention to the disproportionate allocation of resources and calls for a balanced allocation of resources. It is the commitment to improve the functioning of this very important institution that I have decided to vote in favour of this Resolution.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution as it takes into account only the views of the Supervisory Committee and not those of OLAF itself. OLAF has yet to make a presentation to the Committee on Budgetary Control and it should be able to do so as per the usual procedure, in order to ensure a fair and balanced resolution. This resolution was one-sided and premature and I voted in favour of the S&D Group’s alternative resolution which makes this clear. We must make certain that investigations into the effectiveness of European bodies are conducted, and reported on, in a thorough manner in order to ensure accurate and useful conclusions.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The joint motion for a resolution notes an insufficient position of the Supervisory Committee (SC) and cites unsatisfactory cooperation (OLAF very rarely implements the SC's recommendations) or the SC's lack or unexplained legal means of providing guidance to DG OLAF. In addition, this motion for a resolution recommends that DG OLAF should reconsider its allocation of funds, as around 86% of investigations had to be carried out in the field of agriculture and structural funds. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 The resolution adopted by the European Parliament vis-à-vis OLAF was a necessity. The behaviour of this anti-corruption and fraud office has been considered insufficient for several years. Not only does it not apply the recommendations made to it, but it also shows signs of a lack of transparency in its functioning, problems in relation to the Monitoring Committee, as well as the length of the investigation of individual cases. I supported this resolution and I believe that it will contribute to the reorientation of this body, which monitors the use of funds from the European budget and their possible misappropriation.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this resolution because I believe it would have been right to involve OLAF before drawing any conclusions. Firstly, at the meeting of 4 May at which the Supervisory Committee presented its 2014 annual activity report to the CONT Committee, OLAF was not invited. In addition, OLAF's responses to the opinions and other documents included in the Supervisory Committee's 2014 activity report were not included in the official documentation of the Committee's programme. I also regret the fact that in many cases the Supervisory Committee has made recommendations concerning specific acts of inquiry of the past or suggesting actions relating to the past that cannot be implemented retroactively by OLAF. It has also emerged that for most of the actions for which the Supervisory Committee has indicated that OLAF's follow-up 'cannot be verified', it has not even attempted to carry out an audit by requesting information from OLAF before the report was published. I therefore hope that in future the negotiations will be facilitated in order to clarify the role of the Supervisory Committee and its scope.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: – As far as the so-called situation in Hungary is concerned, I believe that the consternation over a plebiscite held there is totally out of proportion. The Hungarians can agree to any question or reject them, and they can do so freely. Guy Verhofstadt did not impress me at all when he was waving the Hungarian plebiscite in hand.  On the contrary, I had a vicarious sense of shame. What the hell is this European Union interfering in? Verhofstadt and his liberal party in my country have been responsible for the introduction of the right to vote abroad, for the regularisation of hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants, for the introduction of nationality without conditions and for the largest immigration flows since the Second World War, without ever having felt the need, let alone the duty, to consult his own people on this. Hungary has no lessons to receive from this man.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Mr President, on the subject of 'Violation of the rule of law in Hungary', I would like to recommend some more serious reports for a possible serious report. Some: systematic corruption, mutilation and opaqueness in the award and distribution of EU funds and Hungarian public funds. Number two: foreign currency creditors, the misery of hundreds of thousands of families, violations in the field of consumer protection. In this context, a complaint concerning infringements in this connection has been lodged with the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions for three months, so let us finally see the decision. Three, the fact that public sector nurses, social workers and educators have salaries of between EUR 200 and 300 is a gross violation of the fundamental standards of the European Union, but the same income is also paid by manual workers working in assembly plants with full labour law vulnerability. Please investigate this and report if necessary.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – Mr President, the proposal for a resolution on the situation in Hungary condemns Viktor Orban and his government. The European Parliament thus demonstrates that it does not respect its own values, freedom of expression. Because, of course, it is possible to disagree with the questions raised by the Prime Minister or with the related social consultation, but this does not mean a violation of European values that would have justified taking the matter on the agenda. The decision has no specific consequences. In the presentation of the Hungarian media, Viktor Orban can appear as someone who has resolutely defended not only himself and his government, but also Hungary, against this undignified attack. The Prime Minister is happy to appear on the European Union stage for this purpose. More tragically for the Hungarian future, the FIDESZ, a representative of the Hungarian ruling party, together with three others, sent out letters to members campaigning for the adoption of the EU-US Free Trade Agreement.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It is not the discussion in Hungary on immigration that violates European values, because how can we even discuss punishing thoughts, for opinions, for democratic procedures? European values violate Hungary's victory by using Article 7, that is, the deprivation of that state of the rights enjoyed by every country in the European Union. Our societies have the right to discuss immigration, they have the right to decide their future. In fact, today we see entire nations paying for politicians yesterday denying them the right to discuss immigration. We will certainly defend this right of The Hungarians.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: – Mr President, in reference to the situation in Hungary, the EU should not be interfering in the internal affairs of Member States, regardless of political opinions held. Mr Orbán is a democratically-elected prime minister with a two-thirds majority in Hungary’s Parliament. I suspect that there are not many parties or politicians in this Chamber that have had the same support he has in his nation state. The EU should respect the democratic wishes of the Hungarian people and it should keep its nose out where it does not belong.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, this whole debate, at the end of which I voted against, exactly sums up the situation we are in with regard to national sovereignty. If the European Union truly were a family of sovereign states, it would not be interfering in Hungary’s internal political matters. It strikes me as ridiculous that Mr Orbán, who was democratically elected by the Hungarian people, should face such voices from a so-called elected democratic institution like the European Parliament. It is a disgrace, and I think it is a matter for the Hungarian people, rightly or wrongly, to decide their own political destinies.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, I have just voted against a motion condemning Hungary. Why? Because they have dared to suggest that they will have referenda in their own country, freely and democratically held, about issues such as the death penalty. Well, I will tell you something: I envy them. I wish we could have free and fair referenda in the UK and have them on a more regular basis, where they are not being manipulated by the government as one upcoming one on the EU appears to be. If there were a chance of a referendum on the death penalty in the UK, I tell you what, I would enthusiastically campaign for it, and I would like to see the issues out there. So I say to the EU: stop interfering with people’s domestic affairs, stop fighting against democracy. I say to the British people: if you want your voice to be heard, if you want direct democracy on a whole range of subjects where referenda could really make a difference, if you want freedom, then when this referendum does come on our membership of the EU, take note of the example of how they have treated Hungary and let us get out – vote to leave!

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, as we just heard from my colleague Bill Etheridge, if there were a referendum in the UK on the return of the death penalty, he would enthusiastically vote in favour. I as a colleague take a different view. That is democracy: two people sitting next to each other in the same Chamber can have different views, different opinions. We see that in house after house, neighbourhood after neighbourhood across the United Kingdom, and probably as well across the whole of Europe. That is what democracy is about, letting the people take decisions for themselves. I do not necessarily like every single thing that Hungary does, but Hungary is a sovereign, democratic nation – and this place should not interfere.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I do not want to enter into the debate on the death penalty, but it is not a debate about the euro or the euro not. It's a different kind of debate. Europe has always spoken out against the death penalty, because no one has the right to take the life of another man.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because I believe that the death penalty is incompatible with EU values. We Socialists strongly condemn Prime Minister Orbán's continued statements about his possible reinstatement and make it clear that the European Parliament will not tolerate any change in the legal system of any Member State that threatens the most fundamental European values.  We also denounce the public consultation that the Government has launched on migration and its consequent campaign of defamation of immigrants that is taking place throughout the country. For this reason, we call for a European mechanism of democracy, the rule of law and the rule of law. We do not want to stigmatise any particular Member State or Government, but to ensure compliance with a collective obligation of all EU institutions and, in particular, the Commission as guardian of the Treaties, which is to ensure the implementation and observance of the Treaties and charter throughout the EU. Hungary is a key country in the EU and we want to make it clear to its citizens that they have the right to continue to enjoy all their rights freely.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The Joint Resolution on the situation in Hungary sheds light on a recurring problem: that of the risk of freedoms and human rights in some countries. In this case, it is a country governed by a party of authoritarian tinges in which the far right has more and more influence. In practice, this has involved the adoption of racist policies and the proposal to introduce the death penalty into the legal order of the country. I voted in favour of this resolution because, in addition to condemning and censoring the Hungarian Government, it calls on the Council not to have taken any action in advance and introduces the possibility of withdrawing Hungary's right to vote in the Council to persist in its attitude.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights are all values on which the European Union is based. In addition, the abolition of the death penalty is both a prerequisite for eu membership and one of the main objectives of its human rights policy. The recent statements made by the Hungarian Prime Minister, Mr Orban, on the reintroduction of the death penalty and the public consultation on migration initiated by the Hungarian Government are strongly condemned. Against this background, I voted in favour of this resolution as a whole. The introduction of the death penalty is not only incompatible with the values of the EU and its Charter of Fundamental Rights, it would also lead to the opening of criminal proceedings, which could lead to the withdrawal of voting rights in the Council. Furthermore, the immigration survey is highly misleading, prejudiced and unbalanced. I therefore welcome the call for the Commission to immediately launch a comprehensive monitoring process on the state of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary and throughout the EU.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This resolution puts Hungary and its head of government, Viktor Orban, in the position of defendants. However, the coalition led by Viktor Orban won Hungary's last general election by a wide margin. Elected on a clear agenda in elections recognized as democratic by the international community, it merely implements this programme, thus respecting the will of the Hungarian people.  Viktor Orban is accused of consulting his people with a desire to organize referenda on immigration or the death penalty, or a public debate on the fight against terrorism.  Together with my colleagues on the National Front, I am in favour of reinstating the death penalty and stopping immigration. The resolution urges the Commission to take action against Hungary. Consultation with the people would therefore be suspect in the eyes of the European Parliament, which is supposed to be a democratic body. This resolution is a serious interference in the internal affairs of a Member State and violates respect for Hungarian national sovereignty. For all these reasons, I voted against this resolution.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution condemning repeated calls by Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán for a debate on the potential reinstatement of capital punishment, and denouncing other misleading and unbalanced rhetoric linking migration to terrorism and discrediting EU institutions. Such official state rhetoric in Hungary is wrong and must be repudiated. Not only is it in violation of the EU treaties, it is also morally appalling and it therefore raises questions about the current state of the rule of law, democracy and human rights in the country. I am convinced that EU Member States should remain entitled to launch national consultations: however, such consultations should be drafted responsibly and within the framework of the fundamental values of the EU and respect for EU law, not only at legislative but also at administrative level. With regard to these worrying developments in Hungary, I believe the Commission should make sure that relevant monitoring mechanisms are in place to assess the state of democracy in Hungary.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the situation in Hungary. The resolution summarises the mayoral elections in May. plenary session on the situation in Hungary with The Country's Prime Minister Viktor Orbán and European Commission Vice-President Frans Timmermans. The resolution was prompted by Mr Orbán's statements on the possible return of the death penalty in the country and the public consultation of the Hungarian Government on immigration. I believe that the Council should respond more actively to the recent events in Hungary and the Member States should commit themselves to ensuring that the rule of law is respected.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Nothing good in this resolution, which in itself sums up the lack of a case that the Eurocrats of democracy are doing when they are constantly availing themselves of it. "No one is more a slave than one who thinks he is free without being free," Goethe said.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. With this resolution, the European Parliament is expressing its commitment to respect for fundamental rights in Hungary. The resolution stresses that no Member State can flout the values on which the Union is founded. The parliamentarians strongly condemn Viktor Orban's comments on the possibility of a reintroduction of the death penalty and the popular consultation on immigration. Indeed, the European Parliament cannot tolerate actions and words that are in total contradiction with our democratic values.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. 'Our Union is based on fundamental values such as democracy, equality and respect for human rights and human dignity. For all EU Member States, these are the conditions for membership, without exception.  In the light of the recent statements made by the Prime Minister of Hungary on the death penalty in particular, we want to make it clear that it is the responsibility of every government in the EU to strictly adhere to these European values in their legislation.  The content and wording of the recent referendum on immigration and terrorism launched by Hungary is therefore totally unacceptable. The tone is misleading and indiscriminaated and goes against our fundamental European values enshrined in the EU legislative process. We therefore explicitly ask the competent European Commissioner to examine the situation in Hungary and report back to Parliament by September.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. The manifestations of the Prime Minister of Hungary concerning the debate on the death penalty or consultations on immigration, as well as misleading advertising campaigns, are incomprehensible within the framework of values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and human rights. In the face of this behaviour, the lack of reaction and commitment of the Council and the Member States to explain full respect for the union's values is denunciation. It is therefore necessary for the Commission to monitor and assess Hungary's actions with regard to respect for the rule of law and human rights, and to take appropriate measures if there is a risk of infringement within the meaning of Article 7 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This European resolution, led by European technocrats and well-wishers, is actually seeking to condemn Viktor Orban's Hungary. This text is an insult to this sovereign state and flouts democracy by trying to bypass the massive vote of Hungarians for power in power. MEPs seem shocked that Viktor Orban can dare to conduct a public consultation on issues such as the death penalty, terrorism or immigration. It is true that these subjects are automatically "tabous" for European federalists. The resolution encourages the UNION to monitor Hungary, which is thus considered a threat, threatens because the Hungarian government refuses to bow to the dictates of Brussels and single thought. I therefore voted against this resolution because it is committed to the sovereignty of states and democracy.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the positions taken in the resolution analysing the situation in Hungary, particularly with regard to the popular consultations requested by Orban. The text is partisan and aims to exploit the democratic choices of a Member State. For these reasons, I did not intend to support this resolution with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The death penalty is incompatible with EU values, treaties, the Charter of Fundamental Rights, the rule of law and respect for human dignity. In this regard, I condemn the repeated statements made by Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán, which encourage a debate on his possible restoration in Hungary, the institutionalising and thus fuelling a concept which is a violation of the values on which the Union is founded. Its reinstatement would trigger the procedure provided for in Article 7 of the EPU. In addition, I censer the public consultation that is taking place and which establishes a link between immigration and terrorism in a biased, malicious and wrong way, which I request to be annuled immediately. The Commission must initiate a process of monitoring the situation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary. In addition, it would be appropriate for it to submit a legislative proposal for the establishment of common indicators on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights as a tool for the implementation and implementation of the Charter and the Treaties signed by all Member States. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because it expresses Parliament's position on the situation in Hungary. Parliament has decided to adopt this resolution because recent events in Hungary raise concerns about the situation in the country. Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán made a number of statements this year on the need for a public debate on the use of the death penalty in the country, and in a recent interview on national public radio, adding that the decision to reintroduce the death penalty should fall within the exclusive competence of the Member States, thus departing from the provisions of the EU Treaties. The Hungarian Government has also recently launched a public consultation on migration, which is essentially a positive phenomenon in the country, but this consultation has been criticised for their stalled and rhetorical nature, implying a direct link between the phenomenon of migration and the security threat. Parliament has therefore firmly emphasised in its resolution that the death penalty is incompatible with the fundamental values of the Union, such as respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, and recalled that a serious breach of the values set out in the EU Treaty by a Member State would trigger a clear infringement procedure for the EU Treaty.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I did not support in any way the Hungary against the opposition. The joint decision of the Socialists, Liberals, Greens and Communists ignores the facts and is full of slips and factual errors. It recalls the Tavares report adopted from Hungary, a rather weak version of it. It wants to put Hungary under a separate monitoring procedure, and it also foresees the enforcement of Article 7, which involves the suspension of membership rights, completely unfounded. It ignores member states' positions on subsidiarity and immigration. Hysterical decisions like this only benefit extreme EU skeptics.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this statement on the situation in Hungary, as I consider the return of the death penalty to be an inadmissible act that is against the fundamental values of the European Union, the Charter of Fundamental Rights, the rule of law and threatens the right to human dignity.  I also believe that further efforts should be made to convince the Hungarian Prime Minister that the introduction of the death penalty does not solve problems in society and that we must all strive for a better future together, without returning to the bad methods of the past that we once renounced.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that Hungary, if it intends to remain one of the Member States of the European Union, must respect the fundamental principles on which it is based, namely the principles of human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights. It is clear that, if Hungary were to reintroduce the death penalty into its law, all these principles would be violated, if not trampled underfoot.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Recent debates in Hungary on various highly sensitive topics such as freedoms, combating intolerance and discrimination, the rights of migrants, equal treatment of religions, have attracted the attention of the European institutions. Hungary has been and will be one of the countries on the eastern border of the European Union and over time has fully demonstrated its pro-European character and, last but not least, with Romania and Bulgaria has been a factor of stability in the region. However, the recent debates, even if they have raised concern in the European chancellery, we want to believe that they will certainly not lead to measures in which European values and spirit are damaged. Thus, in today's geopolitical context, more than ever, solidarity of all European states is needed to cope with the turmoil in the region and to strengthen the values and principles laid down in international law.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against. It is a classic example of left-wing racism against those who legitimately express ideas that are not homologated to one-off thinking. Orban is accused of holding popular consultations on immigration and the death penalty. This report is an attack on democracy.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because I believe that the death penalty is incompatible with EU values. We Socialists strongly condemn Prime Minister Orbán's continued statements about his possible reinstatement and make it clear that the European Parliament will not tolerate any change in the legal system of any Member State that threatens the most fundamental European values.  We also denounce the public consultation that the Government has launched on migration and its consequent campaign of defamation of immigrants that is taking place throughout the country. For this reason, we call for a European mechanism of democracy, the rule of law and the rule of law. We do not want to stigmatise any particular Member State or Government, but to ensure compliance with a collective obligation of all EU institutions and, in particular, the Commission as guardian of the Treaties, which is to ensure the implementation and observance of the Treaties and charter throughout the EU. Hungary is a key country in the EU and we want to make it clear to its citizens that they have the right to continue to enjoy all their rights freely.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality and respect for human rights. Principles which the European institutions are all called upon to respect. The statements by the Hungarian Prime Minister, Viktor Orbàn, on the possibility of reintroducing the death penalty and on the hunt for immigrants violate the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and the European Convention on Human Rights, which have already been transposed into the Hungarian Constitution. I believe that in Hungary the Commission should therefore initiate a process of monitoring and control, with the aim of assessing the quality of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. The resolution adopted follows this line, and that is why I have decided to support it.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I fully concur that certain recent actions and interventions by the Hungarian Prime Minister and his Government, concerning the possibility of reinstating the death penalty in Hungary, and the wording of the Hungarian Government’s public consultation on migration might be ‘highly misleading, biased and unbalanced’, but I felt more comfortable abstaining as I believe that the Hungarian Government will uphold the EU’s principles of democracy, rule of law and human rights. I believe that this resolution helped to send a message to the Hungarian Government that the EU holds these principles very dear and that they should always be safeguarded, especially within a Member State of the Union.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour as all the most important points for me and my delegation have passed. In particular: the firm stance on the possible reintroduction of the death penalty in an EU country; the condemnation and the request to withdraw the immigration questionnaire proposed by the Orban Government, which stigmatises immigrants and adversely affects public opinion; call on the Commission to introduce a permanent mechanism for monitoring respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law in the EU, including country-by-country monitoring and the imposed of appropriate sanctions if necessary for those states that are guilty of systematic violations.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Hungary.  It is more important than ever to strengthen the application of fundamental rights, the rule of law and democracy as a whole within our common space.  With this in mind, the ALDE had proposed the establishment of a democratic governance pact aimed at respecting the values enshrined in the treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. I welcome the incorporation of this instrument into this resolution, which is greatly needed in light of recent events in Hungary.  Attack on press and media freedoms, totally politicized justice reform that led to the neutralization of the Constitutional Court, national consultation on "immigration and terrorism in Hungary", project to reintroduce the death penalty... There is no shortage of grievances about the violations of our core values against the Orban government. In this context, this resolution, which enshrines the European Parliament's march forward in defence of European values and the accountability of our institutions in the face of violations of fundamental rights, is beneficial.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted against this ignominious resolution on Hungary, which is an insult to any sovereign state and which smears the word "democracy". Parliamentarians appear shocked that Viktor Orban could dare to conduct a public consultation on issues such as the death penalty, dangerously deviating from the Union's views on the subject. Worse, Orban dared to conduct several other public debates, including one in which he sought public opinion on immigration and terrorism. All right, it is not bad to have public debates, as long as they are in line with the Union's visions. On the other hand, daring to make a link between immigration and insecurity is wrong: it is forbidden to tell a truth other than the official truth stamped European Union. Finally, Hungary would be a threat that Big-Brother otherwise known as the European Commission would do well to monitor.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 History has taught us that democracies can self-destruct if the principle of majority voting is not accompanied and restricted by a number of other fundamental principles and rights: those principles and rights referred to in Articles 2 and 6 TEU, which all The European institutions are called upon to defend. The Hungarian Prime Minister's statements on the death penalty and the national consultation against immigration – and against immigrants – that he has promoted are expressive of a long-term anti-democratic trend.  These are alarm bells, but also very serious and damaging events in themselves, because of their immediate effects on the country's cultural, social and political climate and because of their collision with EU and international values and law (including the Geneva Convention on Refugees). I therefore believe that the Council and the Commission must intervene, with a dual task: to use, with regard to the Hungarian situation, all the existing instruments, including its communication of 19 March 2014; and propose a new general control system to be applied systematically to all States in order to protect democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. The joint resolution moves in this direction and I have therefore supported it.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 As an Italian, I grew up with the mentality of our Constitution: "Sovereignty belongs to the people". Today I find it unacceptable that well-thought-out people should be allowed to decide what is right and what is wrong in countries other than their own. The much-vaunted popular sovereignty, of which this Parliament is the only expression in Europe, must be respected, unless there is someone who wants to change the rules of the game. As this is not the case in Hungary, I cannot agree with this resolution, which the Left has strongly wanted and tabled, and I do not agree with their tone. Only a change of text can change my mind.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Recent events in Hungary and the statements of its Prime Minister must be extremely concerned by the other Member States and the European institutions. Echoes of the past, which we thought were outdated, once again plague Europe, contrary to the values and principles on which it is founded. I consider it wrong and reckless, on the path of winning the popular vote, to wave at the reintroduction of the death penalty (the abolition of which, it should be stressed, is a precondition for EU membership, being an act contrary to the values enshrined in Article 2 of the EU Treaty). I cannot fail to condemn, likewise, the discriminatory and xenophobic nature of some of the questions about migration in a popular consultation. The sovereign right of popular consultation of a State loses its meaning and its democratic character when it is not done with responsibility and respect for the dignity of the human person, the principle of equality and fundamental rights. I say that the common sense of the Hungarian people prevails, that the still recent past of their own counterparts is seen and that, by the impulses of circumstantial veleity, the path that Hungary has conquered in democracy, the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights must not be maintained.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The Joint Resolution on the situation in Hungary sheds light on a recurring problem: that of the risk of freedoms and human rights in some countries. In this case, it is a country governed by a party of authoritarian tinges in which the far right has more and more influence. In practice, this has involved the adoption of racist policies and the proposal to introduce the death penalty into the legal order of the country. I voted in favour of this resolution because, in addition to condemning and censoring the Hungarian Government, it calls on the Council not to have taken any action in advance and introduces the possibility of withdrawing Hungary's right to vote in the Council to persist in its attitude.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 Recent developments in Hungary have led to a serious deterioration in the situation in terms of freedom of the press and pluralism, the fight against intolerance and discrimination, human rights for immigrants, asylum seekers and refugees, freedom of assembly and association, the independence of civil society organisations, the rights of persons belonging to minorities and the independence of the judiciary.  Hungary's intention to reintroduce the death penalty to the present day constitutes a serious violation of fundamental human rights. The abolition of the death penalty is a prerequisite for EU membership and remaining in the Community bloc. We strongly condemn the repeated statements made by Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban to initiate a debate on the restoration of the death penalty in Hungary. This concept blatantly violates the values on which the Union is founded. The European Commission must immediately initiate a monitoring process on the state of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary and an assessment of the potential for systematic or serious infringement of the values on which the Union is founded. The Commission will have to report on this subject to the European Parliament and the Council by September 2015.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the Hungary, which is full of slips and factual errors and recalls the Tavares report that was previously adopted from Hungary. The ideas for a monitoring mechanism for the rule of law should not be discussed in the context of such a decision, but rather a much more important subject. The decision ignores the subsidiarity of the Member States and the positions of the Member States on immigration. I do not agree with the proposals of the decision, as it deals with the examination of a single Member State and intends to subject it to a separate monitoring procedure, while ignoring the practices of other EU Member States in violation of the rule of law and fundamental rights. If those principles are to be applied, it must be done objectively, so that Member States whose national minorities are subject to harm and discrimination cannot be excluded from the list of those to be examined.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution follows recent statements by the Hungarian government in favour of a debate on the restoration of the death penalty. It should be firmly reaffirmed that the abolition of the death penalty is a major step in the development of human rights in Europe and that the death penalty is contrary to fundamental values and EU law.  While Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban has finally declared that he does not wish to reintroduce the death penalty in Hungary, the appeal of this resolution to the Commission to activate the first phase of the Article 7 procedure of the Treaty on European Union seems to me to be excessive. Moreover, the request to the European Commission to present a proposal for the creation of a 'European semester' on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights seems inappropriate to me. Such a procedure could replace or compete with the action of the European Court of Justice ensuring compliance and application of the charter and treaties signed by all Member States. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing.
