Although Prime Minister Viktor Orban's recent comments on the reinstatement of the death penalty or the launch of a national consultation on immigration and terrorism containing clear attacks on the European institutions and European Union policy in the questionnaire called for a reaction from the European Parliament, I regret that several political groups have once again used the European Parliament's precincts to transform a fundamental issue that is the situation of the European Parliament. Hungary in pleasing a Member State by calling for its guardianship by the European Commission. It is a questioning of the fundamental principle of the sovereignty of the Member States which will only strengthen the blocking situation and nationalist currents across Europe instead of allowing for the establishment of a necessary dialogue and a real analysis of the situation.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I did not support in any way the Hungary against the opposition. The joint decision of the Socialists, Liberals, Greens and Communists ignores the facts and is full of slips and factual errors. It recalls the Tavares report adopted from Hungary, a rather weak version of it. It wants to put Hungary under a separate monitoring procedure, and it also foresees the enforcement of Article 7, which involves the suspension of membership rights, completely unfounded. It ignores member states' positions on subsidiarity and immigration. Hysterical decisions like this only benefit extreme EU skeptics.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is necessary to tell Viktor Orban that there are limits that a Democrat cannot cross. The need to curb the development of the extreme right does not legitimize the use of its ideas or its methods. I strongly condemn the public consultation on immigration and the poster campaign on the subject launched by the Hungarian government at the national level: the content and wording of the questions are not acceptable in that they convey a perverse analogy between immigration and security threats. Finally, I deplore the Council's lack of reaction to the latest events in Hungary and I denounce the lack of determination of the Member States to ensure respect for the rule of law.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I did not support in any way the Hungary against the opposition. The joint decision of the Socialists, Liberals, Greens and Communists ignores the facts and is full of slips and factual errors. It recalls the Tavares report adopted from Hungary, a rather weak version of it. It wants to put Hungary under a separate monitoring procedure, and it also foresees the enforcement of Article 7, which involves the suspension of membership rights, completely unfounded. It ignores member states' positions on subsidiarity and immigration. Hysterical decisions like this only benefit extreme EU skeptics.

name: Diane DODDS
text: in writing. ‒ I am disappointed that the Hungarian Government has taken such an irrational nationalistic view in relation to a wide range of policy areas and freedoms. These actions have led to companies from outside Hungary who have invested heavily in Hungary, and who have created employment, effectively being restricted from operating in the country. I would urge the Commission to investigate as a matter of urgency any complaints that have been lodged in this regard.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained on the report on the situation in Hungary as I believe that it is incomplete and does not sufficiently reflected prime minister Orban's position. The report calls on the Commission to activate the first stage of the EU rule of law framework and to present a legislative proposal to establish an EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.  I believe that this is not necessary and the rule of law must be upheld by national governments without pressure from various Eurobureaucrats.  I support Prime Minister Orban's view on 1 May 2015 that the decision to reintroduction of the death penalty should be the exclusive competence of the Member States. I believe that it is up to the Member States to lay down their rules at national level.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as the Hungarian Government has the right to hold national consultations on taboo issues, for example the issue of illegal immigration or, in theory, the issue of the death penalty, without any sanction, based on Article 7.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I did not support in any way the Hungary against the opposition. The joint decision of the Socialists, Liberals, Greens and Communists ignores the facts and is full of slips and factual errors. It recalls the Tavares report adopted from Hungary, a rather weak version of it. It wants to put Hungary under a separate monitoring procedure, and it also foresees the enforcement of Article 7, which involves the suspension of membership rights, completely unfounded. It ignores member states' positions on subsidiarity and immigration. Hysterical decisions like this only benefit extreme EU skeptics.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 Growing concerns about political developments, such as the lack of respect for human rights and the desire to introduce the death penalty by 'dictator' Viktor Orban, as defined by Commission President Juncker, are justified. All the campaigns promoted by the far-right government, including the campaign against immigrants and the inclusion in school books of exercises for children, to which it is even required to recognise the 'true' Hungarian among various ethnic groups, are contrary to the most fundamental European values. The European Union, when there are violations of fundamental rights, has a moral obligation to act firmly without risking double standards.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The situation of fundamental rights in Hungary, the recent statements by Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán on a possible reintroduction of the death penalty in the country, a controversial public consultation on immigration and the EU's reaction to these latest developments deserve special attention. The European Commission stated that the reintroduction of the death penalty would be contrary to European values and that, in the event of a serious and persistent breach of EU values, consideration should be given to suspending some of the rights of the Member State concerned, including the right to vote of the representative of the government of that Member State in the Council. I endorse this position of the European Commission

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it is a partisan and totally subjective challenge to a country whose political decisions come from an elected government in a fully democratic process. It is also an attempt to invade an unacceptable country.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. I have already said it, I repeat: we cannot ignore the anti-democratic drift that is taking place in the heart of Europe. The words of hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban leave us dismayed, as do his political initiatives to exhume the death penalty and reject, if not hate, immigrants. We can no longer tolerate this and we must prevent Orban's provocations from turning into a virus that risks infecting the rest of Europe.  The Commission must closely monitor the situation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary and make Parliament aware of any violation of Articles 2 and 7. What is happening in Hungary must also be the starting point for the establishment of an EU mechanism to ensure that respect for the democratic values on which the Union is founded is monitored country by country. I therefore welcome the resolution adopted today by the European Parliament and hope that what is strongly requested in it, starting with the adoption of an own-initiative report on the establishment of this mechanism, will soon be put into practice. The highest democratic institution representing the citizens of the Union cannot afford to lower its guard on respect for fundamental rights.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 Regardless of the considerations made in this resolution on the situation in Hungary, of which we generally do not disagree, this report goes far beyond expressing concern and condemning the intentions expressed to recover the death penalty or discrimination and persecution of emigration. There is a structuring line here that we cannot agree with and which deserves our denunciation. This resolution assumes the assumption that the European Union is founded on a set of values, freedom, democracy, human rights, some formally enshrined in the Treaties, of course, but that, in practice, it is an affront on a daily basis. On the other hand, the resolution is making an unacceptable set of proposals. It is absurd to identify the EU as a paladin of democracy, even more so in the current context, culminating in an unacceptable proposal to create an authentic ranking of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, a Commission tool on the Member States, the consequences of which can only result in greater intervention and interference, contrary to the principle of democracy which it claims to defend.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of paragraph 3, in split vote no 1, as it condemns repeated statements by Orbán on the re-establishment of the death penalty.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ The situation in Hungary has escalated significantly over the last two years, towards abandoning European values on the part of Prime Minister Viktor Orbán and his government. Orbán's repeated statements on the possible reintroduction of the death penalty in Hungary are in absolute contradiction with the values on which the EU is founded, and his subsequent declaration not to proceed with the reintroduction of the death penalty in Hungary only proves that the clearly declared critical attitude of all the competent EU institutions against Orbán's policy brings at least partial successes. The European Union absolutely respects the sovereign right of Member States to open consultations at national level. However, these must reflect governments' readiness to pursue a responsible policy aimed at ensuring democratic and political solutions and respect for fundamental European values.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Report example of left-wing racism against those who legitimately express ideas not homologated to single thought.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The political situation in Hungary is more and more worrisome. I agree with President Junker that Prime Minister Viktor Orbán must reconsider his declarations on the reintroduction of the death penalty, which have nothing to do with the values and principles Europe was built on. It is clear that discussion of capital punishment has been definitively closed by the adoption of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. Moreover, I believe that Orbán’s anti-immigration declarations are not appropriate in a developed country that has been a Member State of the European Union since 2004. Therefore, I support the call for an initiative by the Commission to start a monitoring process on the situation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary, and to present a legislative proposal for the establishment of an EU scoreboard on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I did not support in any way the Hungary against the opposition. The joint decision of the Socialists, Liberals, Greens and Communists ignores the facts and is full of slips and factual errors. It recalls the Tavares report adopted from Hungary, a rather weak version of it. It wants to put Hungary under a separate monitoring procedure, and it also foresees the enforcement of Article 7, which involves the suspension of membership rights, completely unfounded. It ignores member states' positions on subsidiarity and immigration. Hysterical decisions like this only benefit extreme EU skeptics.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I did not support in any way the Hungary against the opposition. The joint decision of the Socialists, Liberals, Greens and Communists ignores the facts and is full of slips and factual errors. It recalls the Tavares report adopted from Hungary, a rather weak version of it. It wants to put Hungary under a separate monitoring procedure, and it also foresees the enforcement of Article 7, which involves the suspension of membership rights, completely unfounded. It ignores member states' positions on subsidiarity and immigration. Hysterical decisions like this only benefit extreme EU skeptics.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because I believe that the death penalty is incompatible with EU values. We Socialists strongly condemn Prime Minister Orbán's continued statements about his possible reinstatement and make it clear that the European Parliament will not tolerate any change in the legal system of any Member State that threatens the most fundamental European values.  We also denounce the public consultation that the Government has launched on migration and its consequent campaign of defamation of immigrants that is taking place throughout the country. For this reason, we call for a European mechanism of democracy, the rule of law and the rule of law. We do not want to stigmatise any particular Member State or Government, but to ensure compliance with a collective obligation of all EU institutions and, in particular, the Commission as guardian of the Treaties, which is to ensure the implementation and observance of the Treaties and charter throughout the EU. Hungary is a key country in the EU and we want to make it clear to its citizens that they have the right to continue to enjoy all their rights freely.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because I believe that the death penalty is incompatible with EU values. We Socialists strongly condemn Prime Minister Orbán's continued statements about his possible reinstatement and make it clear that the European Parliament will not tolerate any change in the legal system of any Member State that threatens the most fundamental European values.  We also denounce the public consultation that the Government has launched on migration and its consequent campaign of defamation of immigrants that is taking place throughout the country. For this reason, we call for a European mechanism of democracy, the rule of law and the rule of law. We do not want to stigmatise any particular Member State or Government, but to ensure compliance with a collective obligation of all EU institutions and, in particular, the Commission as guardian of the Treaties, which is to ensure the implementation and observance of the Treaties and charter throughout the EU. Hungary is a key country in the EU and we want to make it clear to its citizens that they have the right to continue to enjoy all their rights freely.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. It has given cause for concern in recent years about the deteriorating rule of law in Hungary. The European Union is a political project, we cannot afford to have grey areas where respect for fundamental rights is in doubt and where respect for opposition, social minorities and social forces is not guaranteed. I voted with conviction for the report presented today on the Hungarian situation because, without prejudice to the principle of non-interference in the political dialectic within a country, it is the constitutional prerogative of the European Union to ensure that the principles of democracy and institutional balance are respected. I would particularly like to highlight the proposal to establish an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, as an instrument for the respect and application of the Charter and the Treaties, based on common and objective indicators. I think it is really important to move towards an impartial assessment of the situation regarding fundamental rights, democracy and the rule of law in all Member States, indiscriminately and on an equal footing, with an assessment assigned to the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights; This would be an instrument that would allow an automatic and gradual response to violations of the rule of law and fundamental rights at Member State level, which should of course be accompanied by measures of democratic control and subsidiarity.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Hungary because I believe that Prime Minister Orban's political attitude is dangerous for the stability of the country and of the entire European Union. I share the condemnation of Orban's latest statements on the possible reintroduction of the death penalty in Hungary and appeal to the Prime Minister's sense of responsibility to respect the values on which the EU is founded.  Unfortunately, I have to note the gradual mortification of democratic principles, the rule of law and human rights, and I believe that serious action must be taken on the threats and violence against homosexuals, to which an Italian boy living in Hungary recently fell victim. I hope that the Commission will present, as soon as possible, a proposal for the establishment of an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights for the assessment of the situation in all Member States and for correcting any distortions. Finally, I regret the lack of interest shown so far by the Council and the Member States in relation to recent developments in Hungary, which should have taken a more intransigent position on Orban's political choices from the outset.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ We cannot stay silent on the fact that Prime Minister Orbán has indicated his willingness to open the door to reinstating the death penalty, or the fact that he has launched a public ‘consultation’ with the clear intention to frame the debate on migration in the context of terrorism. This is not about political point-scoring for the left, as some conservative MEPs, including from the UK, would have the public believe. This is about engaging in a debate and taking a clear position on statements made by Prime Minister Orbán which run counter to fundamental EU values and could jeopardise the security and wellbeing of citizens far beyond Hungarian borders. That is why I supported the call to the Commission to initiate a monitoring process on the situation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary. What credibility can we have in the world if we do not address concerns within our borders that we require others to address? And what credibility do we have amongst our citizens if we remain silent in the face of policies that threaten to violate the fundamental values for which they have fought so hard?

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. This resolution on Hungary demonstrates the Europeanists' contempt for national sovereignty and democracy. The Europeanists want to stigmatize Viktor Orban's policies, mainly because of his willingness to consult the Hungarian people on important issues such as immigration, terrorism or the death penalty. Even if I do not share all of Mr Orban's political options, I can only agree with his use of the referendum route to involve the Hungarian people in decision-making, on matters that will determine his future. Unlike the Europeanists, I do not think that Hungary is a threat and should be put under surveillance. Unlike them, I am not afraid of the verdict of the ballot box. Their rejection of democracy shows that it is indeed the supporters of European integration who must be closely watched, so that they do not confiscate power at the expense of the peoples of Europe.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Joint Resolution on Hungary, as, since orbán's re-election in 2014, the situation of fundamental rights has worsened. This Resolution has two key points. First, it condemns Orbán's multiple statements on the death penalty, in particular when he says that the reintroduction of the death penalty should be the exclusive competence of the Member States. Secondly, it censors its referendum on migration and terrorism, specifically the anti-immigration campaign launched by the Hungarian Government that undermines human rights. We categorically reaffirm that the abolition of the death penalty is a milestone in the evolution of fundamental rights in Europe and, therefore, our vote is in favour.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it condemns recent statements by the Hungarian Prime Minister on the reintroduction of the death penalty, the public consultation on migration and the increased victimisation of immigrants. The resolution therefore supports the fundamental rights of Hungarians, which are the core values of the European Union.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. Once again, the European Parliament sounded the alarm about the state of law and fundamental rights in Hungary, following the more than ambiguous statements made by Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbon on the reintroduction of the death penalty and its tendentious public consultation linking immigration with terrorism and unemployment.  I gave my full support to the resolution put to a vote. Without borrowing anything from partisan criticism, it allowed us to look back at the latest developments in Hungary and propose constructive solutions so that the EU could have effective mechanisms to ensure not only in Hungary, but in any Member State of the Union that it respects democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. It is regrettable that this resolution has not received wider support, it is not a political joust, but indeed the defence of a common base of European values on which no one should compromise. The credibility of the European project and the defence of the interests of all EU citizens are at stake.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Hungary because I believe that hungary has violated the fundamental principles of democracy, law and human rights that the EU follows. The debate promoted by Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán on the return of the death penalty and the anti-migration advertising initiated by the Hungarian Government do not reflect EU values. We must start monitoring not only Hungary's actions, but also the creation of a universal mechanism to maintain harmony and democracy in the European Union.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because I believe that the death penalty is incompatible with EU values. We Socialists strongly condemn Prime Minister Orbán's continued statements about his possible reinstatement and make it clear that the European Parliament will not tolerate any change in the legal system of any Member State that threatens the most fundamental European values.  We also denounce the public consultation that the Government has launched on migration and its consequent campaign of defamation of immigrants that is taking place throughout the country. For this reason, we call for a European mechanism of democracy, the rule of law and the rule of law. We do not want to stigmatise any particular Member State or Government, but to ensure compliance with a collective obligation of all EU institutions and, in particular, the Commission as guardian of the Treaties, which is to ensure the implementation and observance of the Treaties and charter throughout the EU. Hungary is a key country in the EU and we want to make it clear to its citizens that they have the right to continue to enjoy all their rights freely.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I did not support in any way the Hungary against the opposition. The joint decision of the Socialists, Liberals, Greens and Communists ignores the facts and is full of slips and factual errors. It recalls the Tavares report adopted from Hungary, a rather weak version of it. It wants to put Hungary under a separate monitoring procedure, and it also foresees the enforcement of Article 7, which suspends membership rights, completely unfounded. It ignores member states' positions on subsidiarity and immigration. Hysterical decisions like this only benefit extreme EU skeptics.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution on the situation in Hungary. Hungary, like any other EU Member State, should uphold fundamental rights and the rule of law, and all Member States, Hungary included, need a mechanism/body to monitor and enforce those rights. Furthermore I support the statement that the death penalty is incompatible with the values of respect for human dignity and freedom. By adopting this resolution we in the European Parliament are calling on Commissioner Timmermans to assume his responsibility, in conjunction with all the other Commissioners, and to put in place the mechanism that will permit the role of the Commission as guardian of the Treaties to be exercised.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I did not support in any way the Hungary against the government. The joint decision of the Socialists, Liberals, Greens and Communists ignores the facts and is fraught with slips and factual errors. It recalls the Tavares report adopted from Hungary in 2013, but it is a rather weak version of it. It wants to put Hungary under special surveillance, and it also foresees the enforcement of Article 7, which suspends membership rights, completely unfounded. It ignores member states' subsidiarity and divergent member states' positions on immigration. Hysterical decisions like this only benefit extreme EU skeptics.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I regret that once again the left-wing political groups have used a real subject which is the situation of the rule of law in Hungary to sow confusion and cause division. Prime Minister Viktor Orban's recent reference to the reinstatement of the death penalty, which he will not follow up on, and the launch of a popular consultation on immigration and terrorism, whose vehemence towards the European institutions is questionable and unfair, called for an expression of the European Parliament. However, without being lenient, the text voted was not intended to become a clear condemnation of Hungary. It had even less ambition to turn itself into an indictment against Member States suspected of violating human rights and the rule of law with impunity.  We will not save a dialogue on respect for European values and principles. It's even a healthy exercise. However, the monitoring of Member States by a human rights agency composed of civil servants and the threat of the triggering of Article 7 of the Treaty are certainly not the response desired by our fellow citizens so committed to the sovereignty of their country.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament has today noted its concerns with regard to human rights abuses in Hungary. This House should always be alert to such abuses in Member States – and we must also be alert to the UK Government’s threats to repeal the Human Rights Act.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Joint Resolution on Hungary, as, since orbán's re-election in 2014, the situation of fundamental rights has worsened. This Resolution has two key points. First, it condemns Orbán's multiple statements on the death penalty, in particular when he says that the reintroduction of the death penalty should be the exclusive competence of the Member States. Secondly, it censors its referendum on migration and terrorism, specifically the anti-immigration campaign launched by the Hungarian Government that undermines human rights. We categorically reaffirm that the abolition of the death penalty is a milestone in the evolution of fundamental rights in Europe and, therefore, our vote is in favour.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's resolution on the situation in Hungary, as I share my concerns with most members of this Parliament regarding the social and political processes that have been taking place in Hungary in recent years.  I would like to stress that I oppose the death penalty and I also point out the thesis that such a penalty should be the responsibility of the Member States as initiating the process for its introduction. In addition, creating an atmosphere of uncertainty and security threats on migration opens up opportunities for actions that deviate from the EU's founding principles.  Likewise, I agree that all processes taking place in Hungary may be the beginning of a departure from the rule of law principle. I believe that all Member States must fully respect EU law in their legislative and administrative practices and reflect basic European values through their own legislation.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This resolution slanders Mr Orban and Hungary, even though the political choices of this nation seem to me to be the most sensible among the members of the European Union. The parliamentarians who support this resolution are shocked that Mr Orban is giving the Hungarian people a voice through referendums on immigration, the death penalty and by organising public debates on current issues such as terrorism or immigration, when this practice has only one name: democracy. While this resolution urges the Commission to take action against Hungary, I consider this to be a denial of democracy on the part of the Union and I have therefore voted against this resolution. I also believe that respect for national sovereignty is paramount and that this resolution - by promoting EU interference - violates this fundamental principle of international law. I also consider Hungary's position on immigration, terrorism or the death penalty to be an intelligent position that we must support.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 All Member States undertake to respect the Treaty on European Union and the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union when they join the European Union, so it is difficult to accept that a public person, as Prime Minister, should speak out in favour of breaching those treaties. The reintroduction of the death penalty, even if only in a hypothetical proposal, is contrary to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, and the opening up of this subject is extremely unfortunate. I, too, considered it appropriate to remind the representatives of Hungary.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the situation in Hungary. This motion for a resolution recalls that Victor Orban reaffirmed to the President of the European Parliament his desire not to reintroduce the death penalty in his country, which would have been a violation of European treaties and values. The text also deplores the content of the questionnaire aimed at the Hungarian population, in which the wording tends to make the Union responsible for the influx of migrants into Hungary, the number of which has tripled in the space of a year. This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report is unbalanced and distorts and exaggerates the current situation surrounding Viktor Orban's cabinet. The Orban government was elected by a large majority of the Hungarian people and thus democratically legitimised. External interference is not justified in the current situation, so I reject the report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution, which came after statements by the Hungarian Prime Minister on the reintroduction of the death penalty, and increased victimisation of migrants by his Government. It makes clear that the European Parliament will not accept changes to Hungarian law that threaten core European values.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I did not support in any way the Hungary against the opposition. The joint decision of the Socialists, Liberals, Greens and Communists ignores the facts and is full of slips and factual errors. It recalls the Tavares report adopted from Hungary, a rather weak version of it. It wants to put Hungary under a separate monitoring procedure, and it also foresees the enforcement of Article 7, which involves the suspension of membership rights, completely unfounded. It ignores member states' positions on subsidiarity and immigration. Hysterical decisions like this only benefit extreme EU skeptics.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The ban on the death penalty is a great achievement for fundamental rights in Europe. The statements by the President of Ukraine - Viktor Orban - on the reintroduction of the death penalty deviate from the EU's main objective in the field of human rights. The Member State which joins the EU must respect the acquis communautaire. Ukraine should pay greater attention to the integration of the rule of law, freedom of the media and the prohibition of discrimination on the issue of migration.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. \u2012 Every state in the European Union must respect and promote the values on which it is based. Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbàn's statements aimed at the reintroduction of the death penalty in Hungary are clearly an affront to the values on which the Union is founded. The public consultation on immigration and terrorism is extremely misleading because it creates a link between migratory phenomena and the threat to security. We have therefore loudly called for its cancellation and called on all Member States to participate constructively in the ongoing debate on the European immigration programme.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the resolution because the European Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, equality, the rule of law and human rights. These values are generally valid for each Member State and any attempt to undermine them calls into question the democratic principles on which the Union has stood. The actions of the Hungarian government in recent months should serve as a red light that for freedom and democracy is fought daily. In this regard, I call on the Commission to carry out in-depth monitoring of the state of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary. Finally, within the EU, we need to establish a special mechanism for respect for democracy and human rights.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. This resolution on the situation in Hungary follows a multitude of positions of the European Parliament following the regular violations of fundamental rights, violations of press freedom, and controversies deliberately triggered by its Prime Minister Viktor Orban. Lately, it is on the question of the restoration of the death penalty, on the link between insecurity and migration that the latter has distinguished himself by proclaiming just wanting to open the debate on these serious subjects. This resolution recalls the "values" of the European Union, the rule of law, respect for fundamental rights, the right to asylum. It links them to Article 2 of the Treaty, which can suspend the voting rights of a European Union state if it does not respect these values. A threat that is often agitated, but never used. The resolution also proposes a mechanism to monitor democracy and the rule of law in order to prevent violations of these values by giving the European Union the means to get out of warnings without consistency. I supported this proposal and voted for this resolution to denounce the abuses against journalists, minorities, especially Roma in Hungary and more generally the deleterious atmosphere that the Hungarian government instills in its own country.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it is insulting to Hungary and its President Viktor Orban. Hungary is a sovereign state, Viktor Orban is a democratically elected president, and whatever reproaches they are accused of must be done in a spirit of dialogue and respect. The European Union would do better to sweep at its door, before giving moral lessons to the whole world.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This resolution clarifies that changes to the legal system of a Member State which are incompatible with the values on which the European Union is founded are unacceptable. It is for this reason that we condemn Viktor Orbán's repeated statements calling for a debate on the reintroduction of the death penalty. Hungary is an important part of the European Union and we want Hungarians to be aware that they have inalienable, fundamental rights that cannot be taken away from them.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted against it. This text is an unse nuanced attack on the government led by Mr Orban. It is clearly accused of consulting its people on important subjects that do not support the prevailing ideology in the European Union such as the death penalty. It also has positions on immigration and terrorism which, again, do not go in line with the views that it seems obligatory to defend within the Union. It appears, therefore, that this resolution is a form of trial in heresy, resulting in the threat of sanctions. A quick trial as the findings of the investigation are expected in September. This is unacceptable because it is a real denial of democracy on the part of the European Union.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The Joint Resolution on the situation in Hungary sheds light on a recurring problem: that of the risk of freedoms and human rights in some countries. In this case, it is a country governed by a party of authoritarian tinges in which the far right has more and more influence. In practice, this has involved the adoption of racist policies and the proposal to introduce the death penalty into the legal order of the country. I voted in favour of this resolution because, in addition to condemning and censoring the Hungarian Government, it calls on the Council not to have taken any action in advance and introduces the possibility of withdrawing Hungary's right to vote in the Council to persist in its attitude.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ After the brutal murder of a 21-year-old saleswoman in the town of Kaposvar, Hungarian President Viktor Orbán said they should start discussing the return of the death penalty abolished in 1990 in Hungary.  No Member State of the European Union has the death penalty as it violates the articles of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and members are obliged to comply with all European and international agreements. All Union leaders strongly condemned efforts to initiate such a debate. I am sorry that Hungary faces the problem of a large number of crimes, but this needs to be dealt with in a different way.  I did not support the resolution, although it is undeniable that at a time when the Union faces many challenges we should be more united, not allow extremism and take a common stand by maintaining fundamental European values, democracy and the rule of law.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. The situation in Hungary is very unfavourable to socialists and Democrats. Prime Minister Viktor Orbán's attempts to reinstate capital punishment, limitations on press freedom, persecution of politicians who are not from the prime minister's party: everything brings to mind the insane situation in Latvia. I disapprove of it. I voted in favour of the document because, in voting on the final amendments, our proposals were respected.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ the European Union is founded on principles that must be respected by all its Member States. The principles do not allow the death penalty to exist in EU countries, thereby reinforces the value of human rights, dignity, democracy and the rule of law. This principle was adopted by all countries that joined the EU and their citizens decided to do so in a referendum. The question of the possible introduction of the death penalty contradicts these values and calls them into question. Equally, public consultation as a means of obtaining the opinion of the population must be based on objective and sufficient information; otherwise, it may be misjudged or misused. It is necessary for the Commission to increase its monitoring activities in compliance with the Treaties and conventions by EU Member States and to take appropriate measures in good time if negative phenomena are found.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution. The resolution follows Hungarian President Viktor Orban's bold decisions to consult the public on the subject of the death penalty and to hold a referendum on immigration and terrorism. The Union, which claims to defend democracy, is offended when people express themselves freely. This resolution suggests an audit of the situation in Hungary and even in all Member States, whenever others have the crazy idea of consulting their peoples democratically. This proposal is an attack on the sovereignty of states and an insult to the very notion of democracy!

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the motion for a resolution on the situation in Hungary. Starting from the subject of the death penalty, which does not belong to European values, and then continuing with the important role of public consultations, there are many important issues dealt with in this report. It remains essential to consider that all Member States are required to fully respect EU law in their legislative and administrative practices and that all legislation, including the primary law of each Member State or candidate country, must reflect and be in line with fundamental European values, namely democratic principles, the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on the report on the situation in Hungary. In it, we criticise the recent statements made by Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán, which have sparked a debate on the possibility of reintroducing the death penalty in Hungary, as well as a public consultation on immigration. I agree with the call for all Member States to participate constructively in the current debate on the European Agenda on Migration, which equally affects the internal, external and development policies that need to be pursued in the EU. However, since I deeply believe that it is the sovereign right of each Member State to launch national consultations, which may potentially result in a referendum on a particular issue, I see no reason in this case why we should interfere in such a sovereign right. I abstained in the final vote.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour because we cannot be conniving with the Government of a Member State that systematically calls these figures into question, in particular by announcing the reintroduction of the death penalty, or launched a public consultation which, in addition to actively discriminating against immigrant citizens, incites hatred against them. It is regrettable that the Council has not reacted to these issues, which add to hungary's further systematic violations of the principles of the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights. It is therefore essential to immediately initiate an in-depth monitoring process on the state of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary, analysing the potential serious violation of the values on which the Union is founded. And it is of the utmost importance that the Commission put forward a proposal to establish an EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights as an instrument for the observance and implementation of the Charter and treaties, as well as a proposal to carry out an annual impartial assessment of the situation of fundamental rights, democracy and the rule of law in all Member States , without distinction and on an equal basis.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. From the European Parliament, we have expressed our full condemnation of the comments made by Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán on the death penalty, which is totally incompatible with the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality and human rights on which the EU was founded. Nor can we agree with the public survey launched by that government on immigration. I therefore support the Resolution in which we call on the Commission to follow up to ensure compliance with democratic commitments, the rule of law and human rights in Hungary.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I voted against this resolution because of the fact that Viktor Orban, the elected Prime Minister of Hungary, has been criticised by certain EU politicians since his term of office for purely political conflicts of interest and is even being fought with questionable means in the European Parliament. The Hungarian Government has been democratically elected by the Hungarian people and the EU must finally accept this fact and the Hungarian Government.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution as there is a need for better monitoring of democracy and the rule of law in the European Union. The establishment of an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights would also serve as a tool for ensuring compliance with and enforcement of the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the Treaties as signed by all Member States.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Just a few days after the 70th anniversary of the victory over Nazism, the Hungarian Prime Minister came to defend the death penalty in front of the European Parliament. He also launched a broad campaign against migrants through a national consultation on immigration and terrorism. The European Chamber had already informed him in 2012 of the need to respect the rule of law and fundamental rights. Finally, in this resolution, Parliament proposes to set up a tool to respect these democratic principles as a prerequisite for the hard-to-use "atomic bomb" of Article 7 of the Treaty (it can allow a country's right to vote in the Council to be withdrawn). The Union actually attaches greater importance to respecting budgetary rules and neoliberal doxa. Moreover, it had not failed to condemn Hungary on the independence of its central bank. But it leaves the Hungarian government trampling with impunity on the fundamental rights of workers and migrants. Nevertheless, I vote for this alert resolution, to underline the need for a debate of the Heads of State at the next Council.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. Parliamentarians supporting the resolution are outraged that Prime Minister Orban is giving the Hungarian people a voice through referendums on immigration, the death penalty and public debates on current issues such as terrorism and immigration. This resolution urges the Commission to take action against Hungary, so it is a denial of democracy. Respect for national sovereignty is paramount and this resolution, by promoting the interference of the European Union, violates this fundamental principle of international law. I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. The values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights are not compatible with the restoration of the death penalty. Furthermore, the abolition of the death penalty is a precondition for eu union aspart. I have cast my vote in agreement with the European Parliament's resolution condemning the escalation of events that attack the basic values of the European Union.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ While the situation in Hungary and the rise of populism is of concern, the suggestion in the resolution to create another European oversight body, to somehow ensure Hungary’s compliance with the Charter and Treaties, is not viable or feasible. There is a lack of clarity as to its status under European law and it could infringe the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban is dragging his country into an autocratic drift totally incompatible with our European humanist and democratic values. The arithmetic majority is a necessary condition of democracy but it is not, and never will be, a sufficient condition. In reality, he practises majority tyranny. His comments on the death penalty, his questionnaire that manipulates and suggests complacent answers are all manifestations of methods in total contravention of the spirit and letter of our treaties. Slowly, Mr. Orbon burns our values for authoritarian purposes. It leads a magnificent people backwards from the course of history. Yet Hungarians have already paid dearly for the price of totalitarianism. How many outrages will European humanists still have to endure from a head of government who constantly humiliates our institutions to cynically flatter his vanity and a dubious taste for an increasingly absolute power? This resolution is a strong call from the European Parliament for action. There is an urgent need to equip the European Union with tools to fully fulfil its role as an unwavering guarantor of our values.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing ‒ As a Member who takes the protection of human life as one of the most important duties that representatives of society should defend, I do not like Viktor Orbán's manoeuvring on the reintroduction of the death penalty. The death penalty is against fundamental common European values, and the fact that Orbán is in this way overtaking a right-wing citizen who would otherwise vote for the extremist Jobbik does not justify this. Even the presence of Prime Minister Orbán in the European Parliament and his explanations have not completely removed our doubts. The death penalty has been used in the past in totalitarian regimes, including Hungary, Czechoslovakia and, to this day, China, to silence political opponents following fabricated political processes. Any state that has joined the EU and which has agreed to promote common European values has removed the death penalty clause in its criminal code, and I therefore find it unacceptable to play around with this idea in the submission of the head of an EU Member State.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution on the situation in Hungary since I strongly believe that the European Union is a community based on the rule of law and on fundamental values that are non-negotiable.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: in writing. ‒ The joint resolution tackles a key problem of modern democracy: the rule of law. Without respect for the rule of law no fundamental right can be granted. Hungary is just an example. I urge the Commission to establish a mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights as a tool for compliance with and enforcement of the Charter and the Treaties. The Treaties give us the right tool but unfortunately we lack the political will. I wonder how the Council can decide not to act when confronted with the threat of the introduction of the death penalty in an EU Member State.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament adopted the resolution condemning the Hungarian Government's pro-death penalty policy, as well as the xenophobic national consultation and poster campaign, with a convincing majority, with the support of some members of the People's Party. The EP requested the European Commission to initiate an investigation procedure which could result in the application of Article 7 of the EU Treaty, which could even mean the suspension of the Hungarian Government's right to vote. The decision criticises the hungarian government's policy, not Hungary. Finally, the EP adopted a draft jointly tabled by the left-wing, green and liberal factions, which I supported.  However, the proposal for a resolution of fidesz's own party family, the European People's Party, has drawn at least as strong criticism as the text presented by the other parties. According to the PP proposal, the 'content and language of the national consultation are highly misleading, biased and unbalanced' and that the death penalty is 'contrary to the fundamental values and rights of the Union and therefore the issue is considered closed in the Union'. This is further evidence that there is not a left-wing conspiracy against Hungary, but that the hungarian government's policies are considered unsustainable in Europe regardless of party affiliation.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Prime Minister Viktór Órban recently introduced the discussion on the death penalty in Hungary, as well as on the situation of immigrants. I vote in favour of this resolution, which strongly condemns any kind of reintroduction of the death penalty in Hungary, and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which is an integral part of the Hungarian Constitution, should be respected. I also believe that the primary law of any Member State of the European Union or of any candidate country for membership of the Union must reflect and respect basic European values, in particular democratic principles, the rule of law and fundamental rights. I also strongly condemn the resurgence of nationalism and extremist parties, both left and right, which make simplistic and irresponsible political statements disconnected from European reality.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This resolution on the situation in Hungary, concocted by the European minds of MEPs who are constantly dressed in the costume of single thought, is an insult to the principles of sovereignty and democracy, while Viktor Orban's party enjoys the legitimacy of the ballot boxes and the ever-massive support of its people. The European Union is proving itself in its most detestable way, delivering moral lessons at auction while casting a modest veil over its own many turpitudes. Indeed, these Members are upset that a head of government dares to consult his people on various and varied subjects of societies. What an incongruity for these spirits penetrated by a despotism that wants to be enlightened. This lack of trust in the people, this permanent paternalism masking a certain aristocratic hatred, is absolutely intolerable. There can be no "tabou" that the people could not decide.  But this is obviously a political manoeuvre aimed at systematically criticizing the choices of the Hungarian government refusing to comply with the Brussels diktat. I obviously voted against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted against the resolution on the situation in Hungary tabled by the Socialist, Green, Liberal and GUE groups, which was not supported by the EPP group to which I belong. Certain provisions of this text, which go so far as to provide for the possibility of suspending the right of the Hungarian government representative to vote in the Council, are completely excessive and unacceptable. Moreover, I have refused to condemn the legitimate doubts and questions of the Hungarian people in the face of the unprecedented migration crisis facing our continent. As a reminder, Hungary is the second country after Sweden which receives the highest rate of asylum applications in proportion to the number of inhabitants. The number of migrants entering Hungary has risen from about 2,000 in 2012 to more than 50,000 since January 2015. 95% of them enter the country through the border with Serbia, which is not a member of the Union.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law, respect for human rights and the protection of minorities. The death penalty is incompatible with all these values of ours, and its possible reintroduction by a Member State, in this particular case Hungary, would therefore be a clear violation of the EU Treaties and Charter of Fundamental Rights. We therefore strongly condemn the repeated statements by the Hungarian Prime Minister, Mr Orbán, aimed at pro-eliciting a debate on the possible restoration of the death penalty in Hungary, thereby institutionalising and fuelling a concept that is in clear violation of the values on which the Union is founded. We also deplore the public consultation on immigration initiated by the Hungarian Government, which ends up fuelling xenophobic preconceptions in an instrumental way. We therefore call on the European Commission to immediately activate an in-depth monitoring process concerning the situation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary, assessing any serious or systematic violations of EU values under Article 2 TEU, asking it to present us with an in-depth report on this matter by September 2015.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour, because the values of the European Union are based on dignity, respect for human rights, the legality of rights, freedom, non-discrimination etc. But also because the abolition of the death penalty is a prerogative to join the European Union, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union is an integral part of the Hungarian constitution. Nevertheless, the European Parliament would benefit from adopting a more respectful tone towards a European leader who benefits from the popular anointing of a large part of the Hungarian population.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ MEPs and Commission Vice-President Frans Timmermans held a debate in May regarding the situation in Hungary after Prime Minister Viktor Orbán’s remarks on the possibility of reinstating capital punishment and a public consultation on immigration launched by the Hungarian Government. I voted for this motion for a resolution to reiterate the fact that the European Union is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. The motion for a resolution stresses the need for Hungary to respect that fact.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this text as I believe that Mr Orbán’s actions – and the support that the EPP seems constantly to show him – are very worrying for the future of European democracy. Mr Orbán, a former freedom fighter himself, has unfortunately forgotten his roots in the fight for democratisation. His administration needs to stop taking steps of any kind that could endanger democracy and pluralism in Hungary, and to focus more on the welfare and economic prosperity of the Hungarian people.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This resolution follows the outrageous comments made by Hungarian Prime Minister Victor Orban, calling for a "debate on the death penalty" in his country, and following the launch of a broad public consultation linking the issue of migration to that of security. The resolution mentions the provisions of Article 7 TUE on the obligation of its Member States to respect the eu's values or face sanctions, and calls on the Commission and the Council to pay more attention to the situation in that country. I voted in favour of this joint resolution because I maintain that the death penalty is incompatible with respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy and the rule of law.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution. The death penalty goes against human fundamental rights. The European Union is based, among other things, on value such as respect for human dignity, which includes the abolition of the death penalty. Hungary, by joining the EU, is committed to refraining from imposing the death penalty. This obligation must be respected. Hungary could also stop inciting hostility on migration.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. Europe is a community of values, contrary to what many believe, and in this vote we have shown it. The EU needs instruments to reinforce the values set out in the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Hungary's President Viktor Orbán seems to ignore this fundamental truth, and several of the laws he passes often touch the basic boundaries of a rule of law. With the adoption of this resolution we have taken a step forward in defending these values within the Union, but we must continue: we cannot accept that a state will infringe the most sensitive rights of millions of Europeans. Our current and future actions must be aimed at protecting the values that, as Europeans, un bring us together.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the joint resolution of the Social Democrats - GUE - Liberals and Greens on the situation in Hungary, because it uses as a pretext the reactionary civil government of Hungary and its unacceptable actions targeting migrants and opening the debate on the reintroduction of the death penalty, in order to make the European Union and its "institutions" judges and bodies enforce its "democratic principles" and "values". The resolution goes so far as to require the EU institutions to set up a mechanism that "acts as a tool of compliance and enforcement" in EU Member States for ...."violations of the rule of law", i.e. when it considers that the interests of capital are at stake. They present as a defender of popular freedoms the EU, this transnational imperialist union, which together with civil governments, including Hungary, are tearing up workers' lives and rights for the interests of monopolies.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that Prime Minister Orban's statements to reassure the EU that the death penalty will not be introduced, which runs counter to fundamental values and EU law, have ended the recent controversy over the issue. I believe, however, that there is some concern about the presence of extremist parties questioning the European project.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ I find any talk in Hungary about reintroducing the death penalty regrettable, and I hope the Government will stick to its commitment of not doing so. The abolition of the death penalty constitutes a milestone in the development of fundamental rights in Europe and we should strive to keep fundamental values at the core of the EU.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒Europe as a whole today faces the problem of migration, not just Hungary, so it is important to seek the best solutions through public debate in the communication between decision-makers and citizens to take into account the protection of the human dignity of each person. Consulting citizens on such an important issue, the Hungarian Government shows responsibility.  Therefore, pointing fingers and creating problems, because the Government asks citizens for their opinions, is unacceptable to me just like this resolution and that is why I voted against it. The constructed attacks and presentation of something that has not been said, such as the so-called announcement on the introduction of the death penalty, only shows that those who cannot come to power by elections are ready to use all methods according to that old well-known saying "the end justifies the means". I am absolutely opposed to the introduction of the death penalty as well as the EPP, the political grouping to which I belong.  Fidesz, as an EPP member who shares the same values, can certainly be expected to respect the Charter of Human Rights as always, so the conclusion is that the resolution on Hungary is a political pamphlet that seeks to destabilise a successful Government through shaming and public roll call, simply because it promotes Christian values and protects the interests of its people.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This European resolution, led by European technocrats and well-wishers, is actually seeking to condemn Viktor Orban's Hungary. This text is an insult to a sovereign state and flouts democracy by trying to bypass the massive hungarian vote for power. MEPs seem shocked that Viktor Orban can dare to conduct a public consultation on issues such as the death penalty, terrorism or immigration. It is true that these subjects are fundamentally "tabous" for European federalists. The resolution encourages the European Union to monitor Hungary, which is seen as a threat because the Hungarian government refuses to bow to the dictates of Brussels and single thought.  I obviously voted against this resolution because I defend above all the sovereignty of states and peoples, that is, democracy.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒As well as the EPP Club, I voted against the resolution on the situation in Hungary.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Hungary is urgent. With Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán showing continuing signs of deviation from the fundamental EU values, I am very glad that Parliament is taking a strong position, which is clearly reflected in the resolution we have adopted. The public consultation launched by the Hungarian Government in May is biased and unacceptable. By indicating a link between immigration and terrorism, and by trying to illustrate that people’s livelihoods are incompatible with the arrival of migrants, this questionnaire is misleading public opinion to serve political aims, and calling democracy and the rule of law into question. I therefore strongly support the immediate withdrawal of the questionnaire and the nullification of its findings. The EU is based on its fundamental values, one of which is that no EU citizen shall be executed. Orbán’s repeated efforts to instigate a debate on reintroducing the death penalty must be condemned. Bearing in mind too the deteriorating situation of NGOs and journalistic freedom in Hungary, I insist that the Hungarian people deserve better and I am looking forward to the forthcoming PSE Congress in Budapest for further debates on establishing an EU mechanism to ensure compliance with the Union’s core values.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I have followed closely the recent events on Hungary and the speakers of hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban where he spoke about what happened in his country and the debate on the death penalty. I believe that he made it clear, even during his conversation with the President of the European Parliament, Martin Schulz, that the Hungarian Government does not want to take any measures for its reintroduction. I recognise the lack of need for public consultation on immigration and the questions put to Hungarian citizens, some of whom are tendentious. I do not agree with the accusations against the EU on immigration at a time when we are finally trying to implement an immigration policy based on the principle of solidarity and quotas. I have chosen to abstain on this resolution because we must give the Hungarian Government time to correct the actions it has taken and not isolate a Member State too harshly.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Unlike the PPE Group, I voted in favour of paragraph 12 of the joint resolution on the situation in Hungary. As we did in the last mandate, I support the need to establish a European mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and human rights within the European Union. What is happening now in Romania - a prime minister under criminal investigation for serious corruption and refusing to resign, a parliament that obstructs justice, threats to citizens who dare to freely express their disagreement - fully demonstrates this. However, when we talk about defending democracy, the rule of law and human rights, unfortunately, our socialist Group colleagues refuse to look further east of Hungary. That is why we need such a mechanism at European level, based on common rules and clear procedures. It is about defending values far too important to be left to chance or ad hoc solutions.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 As a result of the statements by the Prime Minister of Hungary, Viktor Orbán, on the death penalty, Parliament recalls that the reintroduction of the death penalty is not the exclusive competence of the Member States. It is supported to this end in the provisions of the Treaties, strongly repudiating any consideration of the reintroduction of the death penalty, as well as the public consultation carried out in Hungary, which establishes a link between migratory phenomena and security threats. The death penalty is incompatible with the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights on which the Union was founded. As such, instigating a debate about its possible re-establishment is clearly in the way of the values that underlie the Union and which aggregate its Members. In order to monitor the state of democracies, Parliament invites the Commission to present a tool for verifying compliance with the Charter and the Treaties, ensuring an annual assessment of the situation of fundamental rights, democracy and the rule of law, based on objective, universal and impartial indicators, assessing the emergence of a systemic threat to EU presuppositions.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. At noon, the European Parliament called on the Hungarian government not to restart the debate on the reintroduction of the death penalty and to abolish its public consultation on immigration.  Controversies with European authorities have been a constant for Prime Minister Viktor Orban since he came to power in 2010. The European Commission and the European Parliament regularly accuse Hungary's reforms of being contrary to EU values.  The European Parliament wanted, through this resolution, to take a position in the wake of recent statements from Budapest.  In declaring his consideration of the restoration of the death penalty in his country, Viktor Orban is in complete contradiction with the spirit and letter of the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the Treaties of the European Union.  Moreover, at a time when the far-right Party, Jobbik, is making steady progress and xenophobia in this country is at its highest level in 14 years, Orban's public consultation on immigration is unacceptable, as the link it establishes between migration phenomena and security problems is tendentious. More broadly, by this vote, it is the policy of Viktor Orban that the deputies have pointed the finger at.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I supported the resolution condemning the repeated statements made by Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban on the possible re-establishment of the death penalty in Hungary. The death penalty is incompatible with the values on which the European Union is based, and to restore it would be tantamount to violating the treaties and the European Charter of Fundamental Rights.  We also denounce the public consultation on immigration launched by the Hungarian government, the content and wording of which establish a direct link between migration phenomena and security problems. We must closely monitor the situation in hungary with regard to democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, because it must be clear to all that we are not messing with these principles, which are at the heart of European commitment.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a resolution which clearly shows that the EU will not accept any changes to the legal system of its Member States that contradict its fundamental principles based on respect for human dignity. The death penalty or xenophobia is incompatible with these principles and Hungary cannot be held hostage by Viktor Orbán's provocations.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The death penalty is incompatible with EU values, treaties, the Charter of Fundamental Rights, the rule of law and respect for human dignity.  In this regard, I condemn the repeated statements made by Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán, which encourage a debate on his possible restoration in Hungary, the institutionalising and thus fuelling a concept which is a violation of the values on which the Union is founded. Its reinstatement would trigger the procedure provided for in Article 7 of the EPU. In addition, I censer the public consultation that is taking place and which establishes a link between immigration and terrorism in a biased, malicious and wrong way, which I request to be annuled immediately. The Commission must initiate a process of monitoring the situation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary. In addition, it would be appropriate for it to submit a legislative proposal for the establishment of common indicators on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights as a tool for the implementation and implementation of the Charter and the Treaties signed by all Member States. That is why I voted in favour of this Resolution

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of a resolution calling on the European Commission to report on the state of democracy in Hungary following the controversial actions and remarks of Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban. I also call for the Commission to establish a mechanism to monitor democracy, the rule of law and human rights every year in the European Union. Shared values in the EU and the application of the Charter of Fundamental Rights as signed by all Member States are more than a prerequisite for membership of the European Union; they are part of its raison d'être. No drift can be allowed!

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of the Resolution on the ground that the death penalty is incompatible with the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and human rights on which the European Union is based, and that any EU Member State that restores the death penalty will incur , consequently, in a violation of the Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. We categorically reaffirm that the abolition of the death penalty is a milestone in the evolution of fundamental rights in Europe.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to qualify my vote on this resolution with two remarks. Firstly, on a general level, I doubt the value of an omnibus resolution which reviews rather indiscriminately all matters of grievance in Hungary’s positioning inside the EU, with little focus on what the priorities should be. Secondly, there may be scope for a new effort to carry out a dialogue with the Orbán administration about some, if not all, of the issues on which there is dissent from the European Parliament and (perhaps) other EU institutions. This could first be attempted informally and confidentially, eschewing the public accusatory tones which have characterised most of the debates and which are counterproductive because they serve to harden and polarise attitudes and positions.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: Writing. – I consider this report to be completely discredited and, on that basis, I voted against it.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ The death penalty is incompatible with the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights on which the Union is founded, and any Member State reintroducing the death penalty would therefore be in violation of the Treaties and of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. The abolition of the death penalty constitutes a milestone in the development of fundamental rights in Europe.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 The prohibition of the death penalty is one of the basic criteria for accession to the EU. EU Member States are bound by a number of international conventions.  I voted against this resolution because the principle of subsidiarity and the sovereignty of the Member States must be respected. Paragraphs 9, but in particular Paragraphs 11 and 12 call for measures that not only undermine that sovereignty, but create an opportunity to systematically undermine freedom of expression and freedom of religion in the future.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 I supported the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Hungary. The EU is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights. The repeated statements by Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán calling for a debate on a possible reinstatation of the death penalty in Hungary are very dangerous. Such a serious subject as the introduction of the death penalty undoubtedly is, it should not be a survey of preferences, or by distracting the population from social and financial problems. I am pleased that we have also criticised the public consultation on migration and the related national billboard campaign initiated by the Hungarian Government, with the fact that the content of this consultation in Hungary on immigration and terrorism and the language used in it are highly misleading, biased and unbalanced, thereby distorting the direct link between migration and security threats.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The European Parliament resolution on the situation in Hungary is the eu-wide response to recent events in the country. Over the last 12 months, the situation, which mainly concerns the violation of basic human rights, has deteriorated significantly. On 24 April 2015, the Hungarian Government launched national consultations on migration. In addition, it issued a questionnaire to be completed by every Hungarian national over the age of 18. The questionnaire contains biased questions on migration and security threats. The answers would thus reveal citizens' personal information and political opinions, which in turn violates the rights of information protection and personal data. Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban's statements on the introduction of the death penalty in the country are also alarming. In a statement to Hungarian radio, he said that member states should decide for themselves to impose the death penalty. This is, of course, immutable, because the death penalty violates human rights and the Treaty and the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. It is regrettable that a Member State is deliberately violating and showing no respect for human dignity. The spread of hateful speech is contrary to the values on which the EU was founded. I believe that Hungary should put an end to such action and the violation of human rights. In view of the limited worrying situation, I voted in favour of the resolution in the European Parliament.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. 'There are growing concerns about political developments and the lack of respect for human rights in Hungary.
