The European Parliament rightly calls Prime Minister Viktor Orban to order. The EU, and especially the Christian Democratic family, is obliged not to look away. Orban wants to reintroduce the death penalty. Orban's campaign against migrants and the death penalty are contrary to the European values his country endorsed upon accession. When are we going to hear a moral appeal from the Christian Democratic People's Party? Why did they not support the joint resolution? Or are they really past the cynicism?  If fundamental rights are violated in a European country, then the EU must intervene. If not, Europe will lose every scrap of credibility: it will bring Greece to its knees for failing to comply with Maastricht criteria, but not dictator Orban for flouting fundamental rights. That is why the EP is today proposing to create a permanent body to monitor and monitor compliance with fundamental rights and democratic standards for each Member State. This body should be able to take measures to ensure that the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the European Convention are respected.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ Freedom, democracy and tolerance are values that make us Europeans. Some of Viktor Orbán's statements and actions are out of step with these values. It is at a time when we are facing serious challenges that attempts to remove the essential elements of democracy are extremely dangerous for the security of our entire space.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it condemns recent statements by the Hungarian Prime Minister on the reintroduction of the death penalty, as well as the public consultation on migration and the increased victimisation of immigrants. The resolution therefore supports the fundamental rights of Hungarians in line with the core values of the European Union.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: I abstained in writing ‒ I abstained. Of course, I fully respect the rules and principles in force in the European Union. In a democratic society, however, the debate on the review of the rules in force is fully legitimate.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the European People's Party resolution on the situation in Hungary because it is balanced, realistic and impartial. The absence of the death penalty is one of the European Union's greatest achievements, and I therefore welcome the decision of The Hungarian Prime Minister Orban, who has pledged not to reintroduce the death penalty in Hungary. I join those who, in relation to the situation in Hungary, call for respect for European Union legislation that reflects democratic principles, the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We are clearly against undemocratic policies and policies that trample on people's rights and dignity. We therefore condemn the anti-democratic political orientations of the Hungarian government, such as the death penalty and anti-immigrant policies.  Nevertheless, for us the constitution of each country, which has emerged through its particular circumstances and has received the approval of its people, excels in relation to the institutions and institutions of the EU which are neither elected nor the peoples approved their policies of direction.  Furthermore, the monitoring mechanism proposed in the report, which will be the European Commission, also lacks popular legitimacy since it is not elected and even its policies are not adopted by the people.  For the above reasons we have decided to abstain.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The Hungarian Government has the right to hold national consultations on taboo issues, for example the issue of illegal immigration or the issue of the death penalty, without any sanction, based on Article 7.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I did not support in any way the Hungary against the opposition. The joint decision of the Socialists, Liberals, Greens and Communists ignores the facts and is full of slips and factual errors. It recalls the Tavares report adopted from Hungary, a rather weak version of it. It wants to put Hungary under a separate monitoring procedure, and it also foresees the enforcement of Article 7, which involves the suspension of membership rights, completely unfounded. It ignores member states' positions on subsidiarity and immigration. Hysterical decisions like this only benefit extreme EU skeptics.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the political conditions in my country, because I believe that it faithfully reflects the critical comments made in the plenary debate and gives a strong and dign fitting response to the provocation of Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban, who has made his own undemocratic policy a European challenge by the thematisation of the death penalty and the treatment of international terrorism and migration as the same threat, and in this connection by the brutal attack on the EU. As a Hungarian Democrat, I am grateful for the political and moral support expressed in this way by the majority of the EP. At the same time, I consider it of particular merit that it is not only an important message for the Hungarian Government, but also that it formulate monitoring and legislative requirements for the EU as a whole, in order to achieve european democratic values more effectively in the Member States, and set a deadline for them. In addition to this decision, I also considered the specific Hungarian experience that Orban is provoking me with controversial topics and measures that he does not actually intend to implement, but which can effectively divert the attention of the European and domestic public from the system of corruption and abuses of power that now completely affect his government. The criticism and condemnation of the decision is also justified because MEPs cannot tolerate the Hungarian leader attacking the EU and its values while using the EP as a public forum for its populist rhetoric.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Hungary because I believe that it takes a comprehensive approach to the threat to the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights in Hungary over the past year. Repeated statements by Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán provoking a debate on the possible reintroduction of the death penalty in Hungary are very dangerous and pose a threat to the EU Treaties and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. I am pleased that the resolution calls on Prime Minister Viktor Orbán, as Head of Government, to promote EU values and lead by example. At the same time, I welcome the hungarian Prime Minister's commitment to refrain from restoring the death penalty in Hungary. It is also good that the resolution also calls on the Commission to come forward with a legislative proposal for the creation of an EU mechanism on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights, which is a tool for respecting and enforcing the Charter and the Treaties signed by all Member States.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The President of the Commission says that the Hungarian President is a dictator. The constitution criminalizes raped women and the homeless. Freedom of expression is violated and Roma discriminated against, etc. There are so many examples of violations of European values that the resolution is still too lenient.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Hungary, which was adopted by Parliament. The resolution condemns in strong terms the repeated statements by Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán, who instigated a debate on the re-establishment of the death penalty in Hungary. Prime Minister Orbán has, for years now, been repeatedly provocative, violating by his statements all EU principles. As I have repeatedly criticised Prime Minister Orbán’s behaviour, I support this resolution and, moreover, I consider it a very important signal and a tool for the enforcement of European values.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. As a civilization, we have progressed to a level where human rights, as well as fundamental democratic values, must be irresponsively respected and we must not tire of raising awareness of them. The events that have recently rocked Hungary are not a sad story only in that country; unfortunately, other countries are also facing them.  Without disputing the fact that The Member States of the Union should respect the acquis of the Union and the basic European values and democratic principles of the rule of law and respect for fundamental human rights, I feel a duty to emphasize and in my opinion the irrefutable right of any democratically elected government in each individual Member State of the Union to sovereign competences in the adoption of its own laws and the maintenance of democratic communication and interaction with voters within its homeland. A right that seems to me to be completely ignored in this debate, accidentally or deliberately.  Therefore, for similar cases that may occur in the future, I emphasise as a crucial, fully independent, balanced and factually sound analysis of any evaluation carried out by the European Commission or the European Parliament on any individual Member State of the Union.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Joint Resolution on Hungary, as, since orbán's re-election in 2014, the situation of fundamental rights has worsened. This Resolution has two key points. First, it condemns Orbán's multiple statements on the death penalty, in particular when he says that the reintroduction of the death penalty should be the exclusive competence of the Member States. Secondly, it censors its referendum on migration and terrorism, specifically the anti-immigration campaign launched by the Hungarian Government that undermines human rights. We categorically reaffirm that the abolition of the death penalty is a milestone in the evolution of fundamental rights in Europe and, therefore, our vote is in favour.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This resolution is detestable to Hungary and an insult to any sovereign state. She blames Viktor Orban for conducting public consultations (referendum) and public debates, especially on immigration and terrorism. I oppose this text because nothing is more precious than the independence and sovereignty of a state.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Joint Resolution on Hungary, as, since orbán's re-election in 2014, the situation of fundamental rights has worsened. This Resolution has two key points. First, it condemns Orbán's multiple statements on the death penalty, in particular when he says that the reintroduction of the death penalty should be the exclusive competence of the Member States. Secondly, it censors its referendum on migration and terrorism, specifically the anti-immigration campaign launched by the Hungarian Government that undermines human rights. We categorically reaffirm that the abolition of the death penalty is a milestone in the evolution of fundamental rights in Europe and, therefore, our vote is in favour.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because it openly expresses its concern and criticises the actions of the Hungarian Government, calls for the withdrawal of the immigration questionnaire and, inter alia, calls on the Commission to activate a new mechanism to end human rights violations in the Member States.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution concerning the situation in Hungary, as I am deeply worried about the xenophobic and racist rhetoric of the Hungarian Government. As a member of the ALDE Group and a promoter of democracy, I believe we should continue our efforts to strengthen mechanisms for the defence of democracy all over our continent, and therefore I believe that this resolution is a good step. However, it is not enough. We should consider the possibility of establishing a European mechanism to monitor the state of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in all Member States. As a Member of the European Parliament, I have been elected to guarantee the observance of fundamental rights in Europe. If democracy is being undermined in one EU country, Hungary in this case, it is as if it was happening in every other European country, and that is why I support this resolution.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because I believe that the death penalty is incompatible with EU values. We Socialists strongly condemn Prime Minister Orbán's continued statements about his possible reinstatement and make it clear that the European Parliament will not tolerate any change in the legal system of any Member State that threatens the most fundamental European values.  We also denounce the public consultation that the Government has launched on migration and its consequent campaign of defamation of immigrants that is taking place throughout the country. For this reason, we call for a European mechanism of democracy, the rule of law and the rule of law. We do not want to stigmatise any particular Member State or Government, but to ensure compliance with a collective obligation of all EU institutions and, in particular, the Commission as guardian of the Treaties, which is to ensure the implementation and observance of the Treaties and charter throughout the EU. Hungary is a key country in the EU and we want to make it clear to its citizens that they have the right to continue to enjoy all their rights freely.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The Joint Resolution on the situation in Hungary sheds light on a recurring problem: that of the risk of freedoms and human rights in some countries. In this case, it is a country governed by a party of authoritarian tinges in which the far right has more and more influence. In practice, this has involved the adoption of racist policies and the proposal to introduce the death penalty into the legal order of the country.  I voted in favour of this resolution because, in addition to condemning and censoring the Hungarian Government, it calls on the Council not to have taken any action in advance and introduces the possibility of withdrawing Hungary's right to vote in the Council to persist in its attitude.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it condemns recent statements by the Hungarian Prime Minister on the reintroduction of the death penalty, as well as the public consultation on migration and the increased victimisation of immigrants. The resolution therefore supports the fundamental rights of Hungarians, which are the core values of the European Union.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I voted against this resolution because of the fact that Viktor Orban, the elected Prime Minister of Hungary, has been criticised by certain EU politicians since his term of office for purely political conflicts of interest and is even being fought with questionable means in the European Parliament. The Hungarian Government has been democratically elected by the Hungarian people and the EU must finally accept this fact and the Hungarian Government.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because the situation in Hungary is no longer bearable. The Orban Government continues to challenge the European Union and the international community with constant gestures of arrogance. At the same time, the internal situation is becoming increasingly untenable, with real intimidation of all minorities. The European Parliament must assume its responsibilities and work to ensure that Hungary becomes once again the great democratic state it was before Orban and his government came to power.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation with regard to fundamental rights: standards and practices in Hungary. The obligations with regard to the values of the European Union – such as human dignity, democracy, the rule of law, the protection of human rights, including freedom of speech, the right to a fair trial, freedom of assembly and the right not to be discriminated against – continue to apply to each and every Member State. I am very concerned about the Hungary’s progressive breaching of the basic common principles that our integration was built on. While democratically elected authorities have the power and the right to review and reshape national law, in doing so they should respect the principles of democracy prevailing in the EU. The continued actions of, and regulations introduced by, the Hungarian political majority have been marked by an absence of adequate consultation with political opposition and civil society, and have resulted in violations of judicial independence and impartiality, private ownership rights and the rights of minorities, and in constraints on the media and press freedom, inter alia. This urgent situation has left us with no choice but to initiate in-depth monitoring, having in mind possible application of the procedure under Article 7 of the EU Treaty.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ the resolution tabled by the European Parliament on the situation in Hungary is not, in my view, an example of good parliamentary work. There was room for an emotional response to the problems being discussed in Hungary, which Prime Minister Orbán explained in the EP at the May plenary session. In my opinion, the issue of migration discussed in Hungary has provoked a disproportionate debate in Parliament, even if it is a serious problem and is the subject of debates between Member States and in the new Member States in particular. The European Parliament should debate calmly, not put the head of one Member State on the ground under an inadequate pretext. This attitude is detrimental and reinforces populism at a time when the European Union needs to regain the trust of its voters. I found it particularly unacceptable in the resolution to call on the EC to come forward with a proposal for the establishment of an EU mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. This mechanism would serve as a tool for controlling Member States and would involve the Agency for Fundamental Rights in Vienna. I think that the European Court of Justice is vigilant about respect for the law and the Treaties, and who has doubts as to whether a state or politician is complying with or is violating it, can appeal to the Court of Justice. The creation of additional bodies only pollutes the legal environment. I did not support the resolution.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against the joint resolution of the Social Democrats - GUE - Liberals and Greens on the situation in Hungary, because it uses as a pretext the reactionary civil government of Hungary and its unacceptable actions targeting migrants and opening the debate on the reintroduction of the death penalty, in order to make the European Union and its "institutions" judges and bodies enforce its "democratic principles" and "values". The resolution goes so far as to require the EU institutions to set up a mechanism that "acts as a tool of compliance and enforcement" in EU Member States for ...."violations of the rule of law", i.e. when it considers that the interests of capital are at stake. They present as a defender of popular freedoms the EU, this transnational imperialist union, which together with civil governments, including Hungary, are tearing up workers' lives and rights for the interests of monopolies.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ I did not support the resolution not because I agreed to introduce the death penalty, but because all Member States have the right to hold discussions with their citizens.  Should Hungary go beyond the debates and take further initiatives, the Commission, as guardian of the EU Treaties, is obliged to intervene, because the absence of the death penalty is one of the basic conditions for membership of the European Union.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – I think it is right that the European Parliament has adopted a resolution expressing its opinion on the situation in Turkey. This report lists the steps turkey should take to get even closer to the EU. Turkey is our strategic partner and our relations often undergo very dynamic developments. On the one hand, we declare both the EU and Turkey willing to develop them, and on the other hand, there are often situations in Turkey that simply challenge respect for the rule of law.  Also, given the current developments in Syria and Iraq and in the fight against terrorism, the importance of Turkey as our partner is growing even further, and it is good that the Union is taking a fair approach to Turkey. It shows that Turkey needs to be motivated to make positive changes, after all, parliamentary elections have shown the will of Turkish society for political pluralism.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: – Mr President, first I would like to congratulate you on chairing this meeting. I guess it is an all-time record – a marathon, hours and hours. Congratulations on your work here. Turning to the report ... I voted in favour of the Turkey report because I very much agree with the analysis of the situation. The only correct response to the human rights situation now, however, would be to break off the accession negotiations. The construction site is not accession at the moment. There are much more important issues that we should negotiate with Turkey, such as improving the customs union to compensate for the TTIP disadvantages with Turkey. It is about the fight against terrorism, it is about refugees, it is about transport infrastructures. Let us finally take advantage of these important issues to make progress and let us instead be the accession negotiations. The resources we are wasting are far too precious. Let us finally deal with the important issues for Turkey, and this is a bilateral partnership between the EU and Turkey.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – Mr President, the report on the progress of Turkey's accession to the EU draws up a balance sheet, takes into account progress and shortcomings. It is natural that, as a condition of accession, it also defines certain expected needs for social conditions. However, in my opinion, this goes beyond acceptable boundaries. When the EU started negotiations with Turkey, a new situation emerged. Until then, the founding countries and the joiners were Christian countries belonging to christian culture. Negotiations have begun with an Islamic country with a large population, where, by the way, religion has a much greater impact on social conditions. I consider that, yes, we must take this into account, we cannot pretend that in everything, in all social conditions, they have the same expectation in an Islamic country as in a Christian country, and this has not been taken into account in any way by this report, which is why I abstained from voting for it.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, I voted against the report because it paves the way for Turkey's future accession to the European Union. I declare, once again, explicitly and categorically that I am opposed to any future accession of Turkey to the European Union.  I would also stress that: firstly, Turkey is in breach of international law towards Greece and Cyprus. Secondly, Turkey illegally maintains the casus beli against Greece, to the extent that my country applies international law of the sea and extends its territorial waters to twelve nautical miles. Thirdly, Turkey is illegally violating Greek airspace and Greek territorial waters. Fourthly, Turkey continues to illegally hold 37% of the territory of Cyprus, a Member State of the European Union, while not recognising the Republic of Cyprus internationally and at the same time carrying out illegal seismographic surveys of hydrocarbons in the EEZ of Cyprus.  Finally, the European Parliament should call on Ankara to immediately withdraw Turkish occupying troops from Cyprus and to respect international law.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: – Mr President, three days ago the Turkish citizens sent us a very clear message and gave us an example of how democracy is built, how it recovers, how one should never give up in this area.  I voted in favour of the report we have presented, which we adopted today. But to some extent, this text, which we have adopted today, is an outdated text, surpassed by the events themselves; it is a text still full of prejudice, precautions and obstacles to the process of agreement itself: it does not deny it, but it calls it into question very directly.  I do not know if we are therefore up to what the Turkish citizens have starred in on this last Sunday: the rejection of the authoritarian regime sought by its President has been achieved; a democratic alternative has been rebuilt – with one foot on the left very remarkable from the Kurdish people's party.  And, in some ways, it is now up to us to send a message of hope, of return, in the same sense: chapters 23 and 24 must be reopened now. That would be our best step in implementing the report we have just adopted.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – I did not support the resolution for the following several reasons. First of all, I believe that the Republic of Turkey is not a European state, neither politically, culturally, nor historically nor civilly. I do not believe at all that the political peak in Turkey intends to become part of the European Union and the European cultural and political tradition. Secondly, I did not see any texts condemning Turkey for refusing to participate in operations against Islamic State, but on the contrary supporting Islamic State. I didn't see any texts stigmatizing Turkey for buying black oil from Islamic State. I also did not see any texts that would raise the issue of "Turkish Stream". More importantly, Turkey benefits from import and export concessions but does not comply with the Union's sanctions policy. This country uses only the benefits of its European partnership, but never fully complies with its obligations. These privileges must be put to an end. Turkey is also supporting the wave of illegal migrants to Bulgaria and Greece. This cannot be done without the consent of an official Ankara. Turkish companies and drivers make social dumping of our companies. That's not in the resolution, either. Therefore, I cannot support such a text. I believe that we are firmly soft on this neighbour of ours, who demonstratively disrespects our interests and, in my view, has no place in the European Union.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, I share some of the concerns that we have heard this afternoon and earlier about human rights in Turkey. I sincerely hope that the new Turkish Government will represent a step in the right direction and not in the wrong one. The reason that I oppose Turkey joining the European Union is that, ultimately, the free movement of workers principle would apply to Turkey. Now that principle, certainly as far as the UK is concerned, is a lopsided principle in two ways. Firstly in terms of other countries where the main language that people learn to speak first is English, so that there is a disproportionate number of people who want to come to the UK. Secondly, and in particular in the case of Turkey, we see that there is there is a disproportionate imbalance in terms of wages and the wages that can be commanded. That kind of freedom works when you have people of broadly similar living standards and where you have broadly similar mentalities and cultures. In the case of Turkey, where we are talking about 90 million people who would have that right to free movement, I think that would certainly be, for me, very much a step too far.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The European Union's enlargement policy has multiple contradictions. All of them emerge strongly when it comes to the case of Turkey, a state that had applied for in 1987, which has been a candidate since 2004 and has closed only one chapter (out of 35) in ten years of negotiations with the EU. At the same time, Turkey perpetuates its occupation over a part of the territory of the Republic of Cyprus, an EU Member State, violates the human rights of the Cypriot population, develops a settlement policy and generates situations of tension in Cypriot territorial waters. The proposed resolution expresses this situation, which is positive. However, I was unable to vote in favour of the Resolution because it contradictoryly encourages the continuation of the negotiations. Such negotiations cannot continue as long as Turkey does not meet the basic requirement to recognize the Republic of Cyprus and to end its occupation. On the other hand, there is a contradiction in assessing positively the possibility of reaching a solution to the situation of the Kurds, but the PKK is not asked to remove the PKK from the list of TERRORIST organisations in the EU. That is why I decided to abstain in the vote.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. I voted against this text because I am opposed in principle to Turkey's accession to the European Union.  If we do not want to jeopardise our functioning and the original idea of Europe, the European Union must not be enlarged indefinitely. A European Union that only measures the admission of new members on the criteria of democratic and economic development will inevitably have to accept those countries that one day actually meet these criteria. Somewhere, however, we have to set limits. However, I do not wish to reject a privileged partnership with Turkey. But even for this, the necessary concessions have so far been lacking. Negotiations have been going on with the candidate country Turkey for ten years now, and during this period there has been more regression than progress. A closer partnership would be in the EU's interest, for example for a more effective fight against terrorist groups such as ISIS in the crisis regions of Syria and Iraq, which border directly on Turkey.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The proposed report on the situation in Turkey clearly supports Turkey's accession to the European Union. This accession is considered in this report to be the most appropriate means for EU-Turkey relations.  Some of the proposed amendments, such as the recognition of the territorial integrity of Cyprus, the regret of Turkey's behaviour against Greece or the condemnation of the Turkish refusal to reopen an Orthodox seminar are rather in the right direction. However, Turkey has an ambiguous policy, being complacent or even complicit in Islamist terrorism, not least by its laxity on its border with Syria towards the Islamic State group. Moreover, geographically, culturally, religiously, historically or civilizationally, Turkey is not part of Europe. So I voted against this report.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text as the majority of my group. Turkey, in my view, is not intended to join the European Union. I would like to remind you that Turkey has been part of the Union's Customs Union since 31 December 1995. As such, it enjoys the same commercial advantages as EU member countries, which has caused many industrial activities to relocate from France to that country (particularly in the television sector).

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on turkey's progress report. The reform process in the negotiations with the EU could be a significant opportunity for Turkey to establish a strong pluralistic democratic system with strong institutions and benefits for all Turkish citizens, as well as for establishing closer relations with the EU. I support the requests to the Commission to reassess how the negotiations have taken place so far and how eu-Turkey relations and cooperation could be improved and intensified. The EU must help Turkey to create strong democratic institutions and effective legislation based on respect for fundamental freedoms, human rights and the rule of law. I agree that concrete progress should be made on visa liberalisation on the basis of the implementation of the requirements set out in the Action Plan on visa-free travel with Turkey.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which still gives Turkey hope that it will one day be able to join the European Union, which the peoples of Europe do not want.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. This is an annual report on the follow-up for 2014 for Turkey.  The report highlights the adoption of a democratisation package in 2013, the implementation of the EU-Turkey agreement on readmission and the opening of a dialogue on visa policy. It acknowledges Turkey's key role in providing humanitarian assistance to Syrian refugees (1.7 million). It also welcomes the progress made in resolving the Kurdish question. The report points, however, to restrictions on freedom of expression, in particular internet law and the banning of social media to prevent them from disclosing corruption. Pressure on the media is also doomed.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution and, above all, in favour of the joint amendment of the ALDE, S&D and PPE Groups which note Turkey's plurality following the results of the elections of ten days ago. I support the opening of negotiations in the various chapters appointed in this Resolution, and not just those which referred to Chapters 23 and 24.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This proposal relates to the 2014 follow-up report on Turkey and details Turkey's multiple developments in terms of its status as a candidate country for EU membership. Although this report includes criticisms of Turkey and the Erdogan administration, in particular on respect for fundamental rights, freedom of expression (including threats from journalists from the ruling authorities), human rights and justice, we cannot deny that the Union and the report remain in favour of Turkey's enlargement and arrival in the Union. Thus, Turkey cannot fundamentally join the Union. Moreover, the recent elections in Turkey, which many organizers believe were partly rigged, attest to this and do not give a majority to the ruling party, the AKP, but they send a signal of will for democratic change in this country whose conservative Islam is increasingly trying to gain a foothold. Finally, Turkey still refuses to recognize the Republic of Cyprus and its relations with Armenia remain more than tense.  For all these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that, over and above the proclamations, this country must begin to respect the human rights and fundamental freedoms that undersoe the very essence of the European Union and, above all, show respect for all EU Member States, starting by stopping all aggression against Cyprus. For all these reasons, I voted against the 2014 progress report on Turkey.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I've abstained. The people of Turkey should decide for themselves whether or not they want to belong to the EU. However, before membership can be considered, the Turkish Government must clearly demonstrate that it respects democracy, human rights and international law. Some of the important issues are the safeguarding of the democratic rights of the Kurds and all other ethnic minorities, the free movement of the political opposition without the risk of reprisals, the development of gender equality policies and the respect of all women's rights, the active fight against widespread corruption and the end of the occupation of parts of Cyprus. Once these fundamental issues are resolved, there is no obstacle to Turkey becoming a member of the EU, but the decision must be made in a democratic referendum in which the people of Turkey decide for themselves. On this basis, I choose to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. This Resolution calls for closer relations between Turkey and the EU, and for the Commission to rethink how it has conducted the negotiations so far and how they can be improved and intensified. Among other issues, Turkey is urged to put the reform process at the heart of its political agenda and European legislative values and principles as markers of this process. And he is also asked to open a process of reform of his Constitution that promotes a more pluralistic, inclusive and tolerant society. The peace process with the Kurdish community, the reunification of Cyprus or collaboration against ISIS are other issues addressed in the report, as well as the prevention of violence against women, anti-discrimination legislation and protection of the LGTBI community, respect for religious freedom or religion-state separation. The EU must help Turkey develop strong democratic institutions and legislation based on respect for fundamental freedoms, human rights and the rule of law, defending and representing all sectors of society.  On these and other issues, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because it expresses Parliament's position on the 2014 Progress reports presented by the Commission to Turkey. In its Communication 'Enlargement Strategy and Key Challenges 2014-2015', the Commission concluded that Turkey is an economic and energy security strategic partner for the EU and that cooperation with Turkey on foreign policy issues is necessary, but in the same Communication the Commission expressed concerns about the protection of fundamental rights, the independence of the judiciary, the rule of law, the right to freedom of assembly and expression. In its resolution, therefore, Parliament recalled that, in order to increase stability and promote good neighbourly relations, Turkey needs to step up its efforts to address the persisting bilateral problems, including outstanding legal obligations and disputes with its immediate neighbours on land and sea borders and airspace, in accordance with the provisions of the UN Charter and international law.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. -u2012 Turkey, with a population of around 77 million, represents a large economy with even greater potential. Although economic growth has cooled slightly in recent years and the employment rate has fallen, Turkey still has a number of prospects for stable growth – assuming a stable political, social and legal framework. The country needs to be recognised as a successful reform policy of recent years, but it still has a lot of work to do to meet the values and standards in force in the EU. On the one hand, we can welcome changes in the legal framework in the area of political parties that open the door to greater political pluralism, but we cannot be satisfied with the rise of corruption in the country and the opacity of investigations into such acts, the low degree of independence, impartiality and efficiency of justice and the violation of a type of human rights. In this context, the restrictions on freedom of speech, media freedom and gender inequality in political, economic, social, cultural and other areas, and the unequal treatment of certain ethnic minorities, are most highlighted. Turkey also has a lot of work to do in foreign policy, particularly in talks with neighbouring countries – Armenia, Greece and Cyprus. The international community is ready to help tackle such difficult issues, but the countries involved must play a key role in this. Without the will to have a sincere dialogue, results cannot be expected.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support this report on Turkey's accession. Negotiations have never stopped and should continue, but Turkey must work to improve and meet the conditions in the areas of justice (rule of law), protection of minority rights, women's rights, fundamental freedoms and fundamental rights. Negotiations on Turkey's accession to the EU must in any case continue. In conclusion, I want to express my satisfaction with the results of the recent parliamentary elections, because they are good for democracy in Turkey.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that Turkey is a strategic partner of the EU, both geopolitically and economically. I therefore believe that we would all benefit enormously from the intensification of EU-Turkey relations.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. I voted against the 2014 progress report on Turkey. This text is nonsense: it always recommends that the country join the European Union. The results of the elections in the Member States show that the Union no longer covers any cultural and civilizational reality. The message of the citizens of the nations of Europe is clear: they do not want this enlargement. No one understands the merits. On the other hand, many of us see the serious disadvantages, particularly migratory and geopolitical, that would result from Turkey's accession to the Union. Moreover, the current climate forces us to reason and the enhanced protection of our citizens. This requires the optimal management of our borders, not their openness, which would only undermine our national economies, our identities and our cultural integrity.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union remains committed to further enlargement, and in this context Turkey is committed to meeting the Copenhagen criteria and to carrying out appropriate and effective reforms so as to gradually align itself with the European Union. The reform process, in the context of negotiations with the EU, could represent a significant opportunity for Turkey to develop a strong pluralistic democratic system with strong institutions for the benefit of all citizens of Turkey and closer relations with the EU, due to its geographical proximity, historical link, the large Turkish community living in the EU and, last but not least, close economic ties and common strategic interests. However, the Commission's report reveals, among other things, that Turkey does not have a free press and the level of corruption has increased worryingly over the past year. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that Turkey is a strategic partner for the EU, and active and credible negotiations are a good framework for exploiting the full potential of EU-Turkey relations.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. Turkey cannot be considered Europe, by values, principles, culture, religion, traditions and not least, for the support it gives to ISIS Islamic terrorism in Syria and Libya. It is regrettable that the EU is still wasting time discussing this issue, and clearly certain things cannot but be approved by this Europe of lobbies and banks.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted in favour of the 2014 follow-up report on Turkey. I voted against this report because it mentioned the opening of chapters of negotiations for Turkey's accession to the European Union. I have always opposed Turkey's entry into the Union. Turkey is not European and has no vocation to be. Let us stop getting wrong, and at the same time stop giving false hopes of membership to the Turkish people.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the Commission's 2014 progress report on Turkey because the time has come for turkey to align itself with the European Union's parameters, which necessarily involves the implementation of appropriate and effective reforms. The efforts that we are sure Turkey will be able to make in strengthening its institutions and in the process of democratisation and modernisation are an indispensable opportunity for the country. Turkey has been a strategic partner for the EU since accession negotiations began in 2005 and a process based on a commitment to reform has been activated. A long way has been taken, but many issues are still on the table. In short, Turkey is called upon to do much more to meet the Copenhagen criteria. Finally, I hope that the results of the recent elections will promote the reforms necessary for Turkey's rapprochement with the European Union.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that Turkey must put its reform process at the centre of its domestic policy choices and commit to democratic rules and principles, which are at the heart of the EU. Turkey also needs to uphold media freedom, freedom of expression and judicial independence. The report also asks the Commission to review the conduct of the EU accession negotiations with Turkey and consider how EU-Turkey relations could be improved and intensified. I would add that I deplore Turkey’s policy of settlement and call on Turkey to refrain from further settlement of Turkish citizens in the occupied areas of Cyprus, which is contrary to the Geneva Convention and the principles of international law. This policy will alter the demographic balance on the island, thus impeding a future solution.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Although I appreciate the basic message communicated in the report, namely that the country must do much more to combat corruption, respect media freedom, freedom of expression and the independence of the judiciary, I preferred to abstain. In particular, I do not agree with the various demands for increased funds to be used in specific sectors in Turkey and the call for new negotiating chapters to be opened. What I think would be desirable is a time for reflection as to whether Turkey's accession is really in the interests of all parties.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I objected to this report, typical of the Europeanist ideology of enlargement at all costs. The report expresses this in a letter, stating that enlargement is an essential means of promoting peace. Is there a geographical limit to the European Union or do parliamentarians intend to extend their anti-democratic organisation to the point of achieving a world government? The question of whether Turkey is European does not even arise in this report, which tends to support turkey's accession to the Union at all costs, in particular by accelerating the easing of the visa regime.  Finally, the rapporteur makes no secret of the fact that integrating Turkey would be aimed at getting rid of Russia's strategic partnership in terms of energy supply.  That is why I am proud to belong to this delegation of seven patriotic Members who, together with Marine Le Pen, have tried to oppose this text by tabling 28 amendments in committee on the subject.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The progress report on Turkey only by name is a progress report, since in fact Turkey is regressing in all areas relating to the principles and values of both the European Union and international law. Turkey, instead of showing goodwill and compliance with EU recommendations, continues to provoke and take actions and actions that run counter to EU policies. assia village. In a resolution, the European Parliament also denounced human rights violations in Turkey and its unacceptable attitude towards the Armenian Genocide. Not only did Turkey not respect the decisions of the European Parliament, but in a particularly contemptuous way towards the European Parliament it reacted in an abusive and cheeky manner. Thus Turkey continues to be in conflict with the European Union and the institutions.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 2014 progress report by Turkey, with which the EU opened accession negotiations in October 2005 and which committed itself to meeting the Copenhagen criteria. The resolution welcomes the Commission's report, shares the view that Turkey remains an important strategic partner and that the negotiations represent an opportunity for both. However, concerns are expressed about the independence of the judicial system and the repeated bans on the media.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 Turkey is a great democratic country, not yet ready to join the EU, but different from the Arab world with which so many of us often confuse it. Other countries that were part of the Ottoman Empire are part of the EU, and we should take unjudicial note of the different developments that Turkey has had in recent years. I believe that the dialogue must not be interrupted, and with it the joint plans for the future. This report seemed to me to be rather balanced and objective in this respect, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Turkey is a strategic partner of the European Union and an important regional actor, which would already justify a detailed monitoring of the country's developments. The starting point, however, of this report is Turkey's commitment to meeting the Copenhagen criteria, undertaking satisfactory and effective reforms, maintaining good neighbourhood relations and progressive harmonisation with the EU. The report correctly identifies many areas that legitimately raise our concern. Even recently, however, the country had legislative elections that resulted in the most diverse parliament in its history. It is therefore expected that the democratisation process, which in recent years has suffered some setbacks, can be resumed.  As the report also points out, the effort that the country has been making to take in the reception of 1.6 million refugees from Iraq and Syria, as well as in strengthening cooperation with the European Union in the fight against trafficking in human beings, should be commendable, as since the beginning of the year, the departure of boats from Turkish ports has been intensifying. For all this, I support this report.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 EU-Turkey relations bring benefits for both sides in economic terms, energy security and foreign policy issues. In the light of Turkey's progress, its efforts to meet the Copenhagen criteria, maintain good neighbourly relations and gradually align with the EU still have many reforms to be carried out. At the expense of the negotiations with the EU, the level of corruption in Turkey is still high, with a strong lack of freedom of the press, respect for human rights and good relations with its neighbourhood. In this context, the EU can seize the opportunity to promote peace, democracy, security and prosperity in Europe by calling on Turkey to put the reform process at the heart of its internal policy in order to establish democratic and effective legislation based on respect for fundamental freedoms. On the basis of these considerations, I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution tabled following various statements by the Council and the Commission on Turkey's progress.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The report calls on Turkey to put its reform process at the centre of domestic policy choices and commit ‘unequivocally’ to democratic rules and principles, which are at the heart of the EU. The report also calls for respect for media freedom, freedom of expression and judicial independence, and welcomes the recent parliamentary elections. It calls on the Commission to review the conduct of the EU accession negotiations with Turkey and consider how EU-Turkey relations could be improved and intensified. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Written. "The Moderates welcome the adoption by the European Parliament by a large majority of its annual report on the progress of the NEGOTIATIONS on EU membership for Turkey. We believe that Turkey is one of the EU's most important partners in a number of important areas, such as energy and trade, counter-terrorism and security, migration and refugee reception. That is why we should do everything we can to speed up the reform process, and the most effective way of doing so is through these negotiations. We therefore particularly welcome parliament's call on the Member States to open Chapters 23 (justice and fundamental rights) and 24 (Freedom, Security and Justice) and thereby increase the pace of reform in these areas. We also look with confidence at this weekend's election results, which show that Turkish democracy is viable.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The European Union's enlargement policy has multiple contradictions. All of them emerge strongly when it comes to the case of Turkey, a state that had applied for in 1987, which has been a candidate since 2004 and has closed only one chapter (out of 35) in ten years of negotiations with the EU. At the same time, Turkey perpetuates its occupation over a part of the territory of the Republic of Cyprus, an EU Member State, violates the human rights of the Cypriot population, develops a settlement policy and generates situations of tension in Cypriot territorial waters. The proposed resolution expresses this situation, which is positive. However, I was unable to vote in favour of the Resolution because it contradictoryly encourages the continuation of the negotiations. Such negotiations cannot continue as long as Turkey does not meet the basic requirement to recognize the Republic of Cyprus and to end its occupation. On the other hand, there is a contradiction in assessing positively the possibility of reaching a solution to the situation of the Kurds, but the PKK is not asked to remove the PKK from the list of TERRORIST organisations in the EU. That is why I decided to abstain in the vote.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution follows the adoption of the 2014 follow-up report on Turkey. While the text echoes the current problems related to press freedom, the independence of the judiciary and the rest of the reforms needed by Turkey, it also calls on the European Commission and the Council to open new negotiating chapters, namely chapters 23 (judicial apparatus and fundamental rights) and 24 (justice, freedom and security) as soon as the established criteria have been met. I was strongly opposed to Turkey's entry into the European Union and therefore to the opening of new chapters, and I voted against this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I abstained on this 2014 follow-up report on Turkey's progress. Of course, it is important to point out flaws and developments in Turkey and to call for more efforts for democratic reforms. However, I am opposed to any initiative to open chapters of negotiations for its accession to the European Union. Turkey is not intended to join the European Union.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. In the current period, the deepening of the European Union, and in particular greater integration of the euro area, is far preferable to any enlargement. That is why we believe that Turkey's accession to the Union should not be on the agenda of the European calendar. On the other hand, we must cooperate with that country, particularly at the trade and customs level and in terms of security. In this area, we need a much deeper partnership, both in terms of managing migration flows and the fight against Daesh.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. In a news marked by the decline in the influence of the AKP, the Muslim-conservative party of Recep Tayyip Erdogan and the arrival of 78 Kurdish MPs in the Turkish Parliament, I voted in favour of the 2014 follow-up report on Turkey.  This report seems to me to be balanced. While emphasizing the place and strategic role that Turkey can and should play in the European partnership, it underlines the gross breaches of fundamental rights, particularly concerning the press and freedom of expression. In 2014, Reporter Without Borders named Turkey as one of the countries where journalists face the most threats and physical attacks. In addition, it urges Turkey and Armenia to normalize relations by ratifying, without preconditions, protocols on the establishment of diplomatic relations, opening the border and striving to improve relations with regard to cross-border cooperation and economic integration. This is a first step, I hope, towards the recognition of the Armenian genocide, which has just been celebrated in its sad centenary.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. In terms of content, I agreed on most of the guidance and requests made in the 2014 follow-up report on Turkey. I believe that a large country such as Turkey, which has relations with the EU (customs union) must step up its efforts to strengthen the rule of law, to the independence of the judiciary, to respect freedom of expression and, more generally, to freedoms. This development is necessary in the interest of Turkish citizens, regardless of Turkey's eventual accession to the Union. Membership which I personally am not in favour of for a set of reasons that I do not have the opportunity to explain here.  That is why, in voting against the report, I wanted to send a clear political signal.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted against the 2014 follow-up report on Turkey. This text is nonsense: it wants to add an additional actor to an already too complex gigantism. The results of the elections in the Member States show that the Union no longer covers any cultural and civilizational reality. The message of the citizens of the nations of Europe is clear: they do not want this enlargement. No one understands its usefulness or coherence. On the other hand, many of us see the serious disadvantages, particularly migratory ones, that would result from Turkey's accession to the Union. Moreover, the current climate forces us to reason and the enhanced protection of our citizens. This requires the optimal management of our borders, not their openness, which would only undermine our national economies, our identities and our cultural integrity.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against this proposal because we fundamentally disagree with Turkey's accession to the EU. Turkey has nothing to do culturally and ethnically with Europe. Its accession to the EU will act as a fifth column.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The reforms carried out in Turkey, the situation of democracy and human rights in the country, corruption, freedom of the press and expression, the Kurdish issue, negotiations with the PKK, the independence of the judiciary and genocide are aspects that have evolved in recent times.  The EU remains committed to pursuing enlargement as a key policy for promoting peace, democracy, security and prosperity in Europe and Turkey has committed itself to meeting the Copenhagen criteria, undertaking satisfactory and effective reforms, maintaining good neighbourly relations and progressive harmonisation with the EU. However, there are still a number of constraints on the separation of powers, the fight against corruption and organised crime, freedom of assembly and peaceful demonstration, freedom of expression and the media, women's rights, religious freedom, the rights of people belonging to (national) minorities and the fight against discrimination against vulnerable groups such as Roma and lesbian people , gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex (LGBTI), that Turkey must continue to take firm steps to overcome.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against this report, because it goes in the exclusive direction of defending Turkey's accession to the European Union.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution carries out an assessment of Turkey's accession process to the EU. While classifying this document, together with similar ones relating to other countries, as an instrument of interference, submission of countries and attack on their sovereignty, we note the more careful and subtle tone with which the matter is addressed, demonstrating the hypocrisy with which one and others are treated according to their geostrategic and political relevance. It is clear that there is a real stalemate about turkey's real intention to join, a game of contradictions between the economic interests that justify this direction and the geopolitical interests that would bring down the weight of the great European powers, in particular Germany.  The pkk's maintenance as a terrorist organisation and Turkey's alignment with NATO policies are other negative examples of the resolution. The resolution, however, points to some guidelines for the need to resolve the conflict in Cyprus, which retains part of its territory occupied by Turkish military forces, a prospect that could contribute to the necessary and expected reunification of Cyprus. Reasons for solidarity with the cause and the Cypriot people are not unrelated to our vote to abstain. In other circumstances we would vote against it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ Turkey is one of the key strategic partners for the European Union and it is therefore important to continue active and credible negotiations that would make it possible to exploit the full potential of EU-Turkey relations. Moreover, the reform process related to the negotiations on Turkey's accession to the EU may represent an opportunity for Turkey to develop a strong pluralistic democratic system for the benefit of all Turkish citizens. I therefore believe that relations and cooperation between the EU and Turkey will be improved and intensified.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 It is right to ask Turkey for more efforts to have more democracy. However, it remains deeply wrong to insist on the Turkish country's accession to Europe.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report since I believe that it strikes a fine balance between the need to continue the accession negotiations and criticisms of Turkey’s performance in a number of crucial areas, such as the rule of law, fundamental freedoms and basic rights, the rights of minorities and women, etc. The report, while being critical of Turkey’s backsliding on democratic reforms, maintains that the EU and Turkey are engaged in accession negotiations.  An acceptable compromise was also achieved on the Cyprus issue. The report also expresses strong support for the Kurdish peace process, which has enormous implications for Turkey’s internal and foreign policies.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. Turkey is a key strategic partner for the EU, most considering it to be a candidate country since 2005. Since then there have been significant changes aimed at strengthening democracy and the rule of law in the country. However, the Turkish Government must continue the pace of negotiations and unequivocally commit itself to respecting the fundamental democratic values and principles of the European Union. For this reason, I voted in favour.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the 2014 progress report by Turkey and share the view that turkey is a political, economic and cultural partner of strategic importance to the European Union.  I believe, in fact, that we need to step up our efforts between the European Union and Turkey towards closer cooperation, and I hope that the Turkish Government will take advantage of the need to intensify the negotiations and commit itself to respect for democratic principles and human rights.  However, I am concerned about the adoption of laws that undermine the freedom of the media and which consequently undermine the principle of freedom of expression and the right to privacy.   In the field of gender equality, too, the situation remains critical, due to high rates of violence against women and poor protections by the authorities. I therefore hope that the government will take responsibility for the gender gap and implement policies aimed at involving women more in civil society.  Finally, I believe that political dialogue with the EU also requires respect for the sovereignty of the Member States and that Turkey refrains from any action that might jeopardise good neighbourly relations.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Turkey has been a candidate for EU membership since 1999 and negotiations have been under way since October 2005. But almost ten years later, further reforms are still needed to open negotiations on Chapters 23 and 24 of justice. The 2014 Progress Report shows in which areas the necessary criteria have not yet been met. Most recently, the Turkish Government has distanced itself from European values through massive restrictions on civil liberties, rather than converging. It is up to the Turkish Government to commit itself to respecting freedom of the press and strengthening judicial independence. In addition, corruption in the country must be combated more strongly. Last Sunday's elections create new opportunities to advance and intensify cooperation. The high turnout in last Monday's parliamentary elections is an indication of the potential of Turkish democracy. The fact that all the major political parties will be represented in the new Parliament is very important. We therefore hope that positive changes will now take place. The lack of the rule of law, tolerance, democracy and freedom of expression means that the opening of new negotiating chapters is therefore off the table for the time being.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report given it sends out a strong, clear and detailed message to Turkey, a key strategic partner of the EU.  The accession process gives us a very effective carrot to encourage significant reform, bringing more democracy, security and stability to Turkey, and therefore Europe and the region. I therefore find it disappointing that parties on the right are willing to forsake the opportunity to move forward on these crucial issues for the benefit of an easy and populist discourse on migration.  By hosting nearly 2 million refugees, Turkey is also instrumental in maintaining stability in our neighbourhood and it is in our interest that we support the country in this effort. But let it be clear that core European values will need to be upheld if Turkey wants to make further progress on accession. We cannot accept a backslide on democratic reforms in fields like the independence of the judiciary, freedom of expression and the media, and the rights of minorities and women. We expect a new government to make progress on these key reforms, including by finding a sustainable solution to the peace process with the Kurdish community and lowering the 10% electoral threshold.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. ‒ I still have reservations about Turkey’s record on civil liberties, including press freedom and gender equality. Women’s rights should be at the core of civil liberties in all EU countries, and the EU should advocate equality between the genders beyond its own borders and particularly in candidate countries. Therefore, until Turkey can demonstrate a strong record in this area, removing all institutionalised inequality towards women, it should not be considered for accession to the EU. However, Turkey still has a strong role as a democratic link between West and East, and because I hope the country will be making progress in the area of civil liberties I decided to withhold my vote instead of voting against or in favour.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. I voted against this annual report on Turkey's progress for the simple reason that Turkey has not made progress. The situation in Turkey has worsened since the so-called "moderate" Islamists came to power in 2002, to the point that the country is now a sanctuary of Islamist terrorism, where jihadists and weapons pass daily to Syria and Iraq. This has not stopped the Europeanists from recently opening the 17th chapter of Turkey's accession negotiations to the European Union. I note, however, that a recital of the proposal refers to a "long process with an uncertain outcome".  I cannot imagine that Turkey could join the European Union when turkey supports Islamist terrorism, discriminates 20s and still does not recognise the Armenian genocide.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the Resolution on the Report on the evolution of relations with Turkey. While we understand that the interest of a general report in this regard may be noticeable, it is necessary at the same time to exercise responsibility to ensure that the issues are properly represented and that no injustice is committed against any of the parties involved. We understand that the accession process of a country of Turkey's size must be followed with greater interest on the part of the Commission and Parliament, which should propose texts that would do justice to Turkey's complex, diverse and, in many cases, difficult to contrast reality in mere reports.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ We welcome the Commission’s 2014 progress report on Turkey, and share its conclusion that Turkey is a key strategic partner for the EU. Active and credible negotiations would provide a suitable framework for exploiting the full potential of EU-Turkey relations.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. In line with my convictions and campaign commitments, I voted against the amendments to this report which suggested that a resumption of the process of negotiating Turkey's accession to the European Union was possible.  I strongly oppose Turkey's entry into the Union and defend a lasting pause in the enlargement process. We must be clear and firm with Turkey; If enhanced cooperation is possible, membership of the European Union is not a desired goal. Geographically, culturally or historically, Turkey does not belong to the European area. However, I abstained in the final vote, as the report included a number of very strong provisions against Turkey, including condemning violations of human rights and freedom of expression in the country, rejecting the settlement policy used in Cyprus, and calling on Turkey to recognise the Armenian genocide.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Commission's submission in 2014. turkey's progress report. This report presented Turkey's achievements in the copenhagen criteria, such as the democratic and rule of law, respect for human rights and the protection of minority rights, the creation of good relations with neighbouring countries, the ability to take over the obligations and objectives of the members of the European Union. This report is essential to consider the appropriateness and possibilities of Turkey's membership.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the 2014 Progress Report on Turkey. I believe we need to take a positive, measured response in our approach to Turkey. In this context I supported the proposal to widen the Customs Union to include agricultural products, services and public procurement and to create favourable conditions for continued growth in trade including the facilitation of visas for business travellers. I supported the removal of the Kurdistan Workers’ Party (PKK) from the EU list of terrorist organisations: this, I believe, is a reasonable and progressive stance. I also supported the vote which referenced the centenary of the Armenian genocide.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that Turkey is a key strategic partner for the EU and that the progress of ongoing negotiations between the two parties will be beneficial to both. However, we have to acknowledge that many human rights violations need to be stamped out in Turkey and that problems still exist in relation to freedom of expression and corruption.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution quite rightly notes that last week’s Turkish election resulted in the most inclusive and representative parliament in that country’s modern history and the success of the Kurdish minority should be noted. Turkey remains an important ally of the EU and I was able to support the resolution.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the Resolution on the Report on the evolution of relations with Turkey. While we understand that the interest of a general report in this regard may be noticeable, it is necessary at the same time to exercise responsibility to ensure that the issues are properly represented and that no injustice is committed against any of the parties involved. We understand that the accession process of a country of Turkey's size must be followed with greater interest on the part of the Commission and Parliament, which should propose texts that would do justice to Turkey's complex, diverse and, in many cases, difficult to contrast reality in mere reports.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament resolution on the Commission's 2014 progress report on Turkey, as it reflects in most thesis and my views.  I would stress the need to continue the dialogue – to create preconditions for an effective and successful EU-Turkey relationship that will benefit us mutually. I agree with the need to continue the Turkish government's efforts to achieve a comprehensive and sustainable result of the peace process with the Kurdish community on the basis of negotiations with the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK). Turkey's EU integration process should continue in line with all necessary criteria. In particular, progress on preventing violations of the European Convention on Human Rights should be emphasised as an important process towards linking the Turkish legal framework to judicial decisions of the European Court of Justice. In the economic aspect, it is necessary to continue strengthening economic cooperation where the effects of the customs union are visible.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Turkey is an unavoidable neighbour of the EU, and we would benefit from clarifying our position, which is that Turkey itself has no more interest than a vocation to join the European Union, a reality that will allow us to build a healthy and unambiguous relationship. This report, on the contrary, clearly supports Turkey's accession to the EU. Indeed, this accession is considered in this report to be the most appropriate means for EU-Turkey relations. So I decided to vote against this report.  Although some of the proposed amendments, such as the recognition of the territorial integrity of Cyprus, the regret of Turkey's behaviour against Greece or the Turkish refusal to reopen an Orthodox seminar were rather in the right direction. Since the primary purpose of this report is to get Turkey to join Europe, it is impossible for me to vote in favour of this report.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I abstained on the resolution on the 2014 follow-up report on Turkey. The motion for a resolution congratulates Turkey on hosting the 1.6 million Syrian and Iraqi refugees. It also points to the efforts to be made with regard to relations with Cyprus but also on certain measures taken by the government against freedom of the press and plurality of opinion. These actions make it impossible for the moment to dialogue on Turkey's possible entry into the EU.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The progress report identifies a number of key points with current relevance, which must in any case be rejected. On the one hand, it calls for the PKK to be removed from the EU list of terrorist groups, which is not justified in view of the past of this movement. It is also concerned about Turkey's cooperation with Russia, which I think is an excessive concern and also an unjustified act of interference. Similarly, Turkey continues to pursue an aggressive settlement policy in northern Cyprus, blocking Kobana for humanitarian aid convoys to build the city and support its population. Nevertheless, the country continues to receive billions in pre-accession aid. I reject this report.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 At the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I supported the motion for a resolution on turkey's 2014 progress report. The report states that as a result of the EU-Turkey Customs Union, bilateral trade has more than increased four-fold, increasing the well-being of the EU and The Turkish people. This suggests that Turkey could be a stable strategic partner for the EU if it continues to implement democratic reforms and moves closer to EU values. I voted in favour because I believe that Turkey has an important role to play as the EU's strategic partner in the EU's energy security and also plays an important role as a member of NATO. It is also important that Turkey and the EU continue their dialogue on counter-terrorism issues in a way that complements each other' external security policies on both sides.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The tone of the report was originally too positive, but with amendments and the vote in the plenary we have achieved a more realistic approach. Turkey is a big European neighbour – for years a candidate country, and one that has reformed significantly. It also plays a crucial role in fighting against Islamic State and other terrorist groupings currently active in Syria and Iraq. Nevertheless, we cannot look away in relation to Turkey’s poor performance when it comes to human rights, democracy and the rule of law. The arbitrary detention, over many years, of journalists critical of the government makes Turkey a leader among countries with the highest number of imprisoned journalists. The most recent case involved the unfounded arrests of journalists who revealed major corruption among high authorities. I call on the Turkish authorities to fulfil the nation’s commitments under the Council of Europe, and the EU accession process, to fully respect human rights and to guarantee freedom of media, thought, belief and gathering. I call on them especially to enable Christians to use their places of worship and practice their religion freely and fully with no discrimination, hate speech or intolerance.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report. The European Parliament has given a clear signal that it wants to remain constructively engaged with a new Turkish government. Despite the serious concerns we have about certain developments in the country, now is not the moment to turn away from Turkey. We have to create a permanent platform for dialogue in order to make progress in the areas of fundamental rights and the rule of law.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Recent polls in Turkey have shown that Turkish citizens are willing to go through a process of internal policy reforms. The disapproval of Tayyip Erdoğan's plans for enhanced powers in the president's executive power highlighted the resilience of Turkish democracy and the democratic spirit. The composition of the new parties in parliament is the "most representative in Turkey's modern history". But alignment with the democratic values and principles of the EU presupposes that Turkey respects media freedom, choice of expression, independence in the judicial system.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
