text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that Turkey is the most important regional partner of the European Union and we must support them in their European way. EU-Turkey cooperation in the field of foreign policy and counter-terrorism is a vivid example of the common values we share, and the high turnout in the last elections reinforces the level of democracy in the country. However, the fall of texts about the Armenian genocide in the report has a destructive effect on our relations, as the self-use of historical facts leads to modern political conflicts.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I believe it is crucial that the EU continues to be the benchmark for reforms in Turkey. This nation has continued to implement the reforms undertaken in recent years, although a new constitution, based on provisions promoting a pluralist, inclusive and tolerant society, would be the foundation of the reform process and would provide a solid basis for fundamental freedoms and the rule of law. I supported this proposal because I consider it to be an important step in the path taken and I also call on the Turkish Government to guarantee media freedom as a matter of priority and to provide an adequate legal framework to guarantee pluralism, in accordance with international standards.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted against the European Parliament's 2014 follow-up report on Turkey.  The report made positive recommendations, for example, calling on Turkey to put its reform process at the centre of domestic policy choices and to make an unequivocal commitment to respect democratic values and principles.  Nevertheless, in calling for the opening of chapters of negotiations with Turkey as part of the enlargement process, this report went against my strong opposition to Turkey's integration into the European Union. That is why I chose to reject this report.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. This annual monitoring report assesses the progress made in Turkey on the "Community acquis", i.e., a set of laws defending fundamental freedoms but also market freedom. This report supports and encourages Turkey's efforts towards minorities, including Kurdish or Roma. He looks back at the events in Taksim Square that claimed the lives of twelve people and the procedural fiasco that followed, as well as the censorship of the press. The mining tragedies in Soma and Ermenek, the metalworkers' strikes are also mentioned, and rightly this report calls for Turkey's compliance with ILO standards. However, this text provides a partial assessment of the situation. No reference to the election period is made despite intimidation, attacks by opposition party activists, and the lack of response from the authorities. However, these pressures must be denounced, especially as we enter a risky post-election period. Nor is there anything about Turkey's role in the Syrian conflict. Finally, the Cyprus question has been completely ignored. That is why I abstained on this report.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution because it confirms the prospect of Turkey joining the Union. An incredible prospect when you consider that Turkey has invaded Cyprus, of which it occupies part of the territory, and that it plays a very ambiguous role with regard to Daesh. Without even remembering that Turkey is not, culturally, a European state!

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted against it. There are some good things in this text, such as the Turkish government's request to ensure the security and respect of Christians in that country, criticism of its poor relations with Greece and its behaviour towards Cyprus, whose territorial integrity must be preserved. It is also recalled that European companies face a number of difficulties in Turkey.  But other demands are unacceptable. Attached to the sovereignty of nations, I am hostile to the European Union's desire to interfere in justice and environmental policy in particular. It is clear that this report is a step towards Turkey's accession to the European Union, which is considered "the most appropriate means for European Union-Turkey relations". I am totally opposed to that.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The Resolution calls for closer relations between the EU and Turkey, and for the Commission to rethink how the negotiations have been conducted so far and how these EU-Turkey relations can be improved and intensified. Turkey is urged to put the reform process at the heart of its political agenda, and European legislative values and principles as markers of that process; the EU must help Turkey develop strong democratic institutions and legislation based on respect for fundamental freedoms, human rights and the rule of law, defending and representing all sectors of society. In accordance with these considerations, I voted in favour of the Resolution.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The European Union's enlargement policy has multiple contradictions. All of them emerge strongly when it comes to the case of Turkey, a state that had applied for in 1987, which has been a candidate since 2004 and has closed only one chapter (out of 35) in ten years of negotiations with the EU. At the same time, Turkey perpetuates its occupation over a part of the territory of the Republic of Cyprus, an EU Member State, violates the human rights of the Cypriot population, develops a settlement policy and generates situations of tension in Cypriot territorial waters. The proposed resolution expresses this situation, which is positive. However, I was unable to vote in favour of the Resolution because it contradictoryly encourages the continuation of the negotiations. Such negotiations cannot continue as long as Turkey does not meet the basic requirement to recognize the Republic of Cyprus and to end its occupation. On the other hand, there is a contradiction in assessing positively the possibility of reaching a solution to the situation of the Kurds, but the PKK is not asked to remove the PKK from the list of TERRORIST organisations in the EU. That is why I decided to abstain in the vote.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The EU presents one of the key policies for promoting peace and democracy and security and prosperity in Europe through its further enlargement. Turkey's progress report recalls that since the customs union began in 1996, the value of bilateral trade between Turkey and the EU has more than quadrupled, both by the significant growth of foreign direct investment from the EU to Turkey and by strong integration between Turkish and European companies for mutual benefit.  It is important to foster dialogue, cooperate and further strengthen significant EU-Turkey economic ties, so I supported this report.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the main issues for the future of European integration is that of Turkey's accession to the European Union. I supported the European Parliament resolution on the Commission's 2014 progress report on Turkey, which clearly set out many of the important elements of this issue. Turkey's accession negotiations represent "a long process with an unknown outcome based on fair and rigorous requirements and a commitment to reform." The Copenhagen criteria are clear, as well as the obligation of good neighbourly relations and successful democratisation of the country. In this context, I welcome active civil society in Turkey and the results of recent parliamentary elections. These elections had at stake a very important process that could lead to the possibility of severe constitutional change and, in practice, turn Turkey into a presidential republic with a strong authoritarian element. Turkish voters did not allow the formation of an all-strong majority, and now Turkey will have to be governed by a coalition. Turkey is a strategic partner of the European Union. I hope that the country will not "tire" of the negotiation process (the start of the formal negotiations was given on 3 October 2005) and will bring to an end the necessary reforms in order to develop the full potential of our relations.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. "U2012 Although I was willing to vote in favour of the Resolution and the Report," I voted against it. I believe that speaking of Turkey it is essential to acknowledge the fact of the Armenian genocide. Of course today's generation could not be blamed for the crimes of the Ottoman Empire. But the idea of forgetting how a million and a half people were taken from life just because they were Armenians leaves me mute. Unfortunately, the rapporteur, Kati Piri, did not reflect this in her report. Nor can the interests of the Republic of Cyprus be ignored when it comes to Northern Cyprus, which is under the control of Turkish troops. I supported my Cypriot colleagues from the Socialist and Democratic Group, Costas Mavrides and Demetris Papadakis. I voted with them.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ the European Union stands by the values of respect for human dignity, the values of democracy, equality, respect for and respect for human rights and freedoms, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities and the values of the rule of law. Pluralism, non-discrimination, tolerance, justice, solidarity and equality between women and men prevail in the Union and its Member States. At the same time, these values are fundamental conditions that must be met and subsequently respected by all states seeking membership of the European Union. Any failure to respect these values and principles, or their lack of implementation, is an obstacle to the journey to the community of EU countries.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report. The overall aim of this report is to work towards Turkey's future accession to the European Union as it would be "the most appropriate means for EU-Turkey relations". Although some good amendments have been tabled, notably in favour of the recognition of the Armenian genocide by the Turks or to remind that any future accession to the Union must be approved by all Member States, the final text remains unacceptable. We strongly oppose Turkey's entry into the European Union and we reject any attempts to encourage this process.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report assessing the progress made by Turkey in 2014. There are a number of positive elements in the report. For example, the EU recognises that Turkey is one of its important strategic partners, points to the growth of mutual trade as well as direct investment from EU countries, and objectively assesses the progress made at different levels in 2014. However, the report also contains some passages with which I cannot identify, such as expressing the EU's concern about closer cooperation between Turkey and Russia in the field of energy, as well as other points which, in my opinion, the EU is only inappropriately meddling in the internal affairs of the state. That is why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the text of the resolution because I believe that it adequately and objectively addresses the progress made in Turkey from a socio-political point of view. Despite the fact that there are still cases of violation of citizens' rights within the country, the European Union can only welcome the positive developments that have taken place. The text of the document, which I believe to be complete and objective, clearly outlines the current situation in the country, defining, in a proactive manner, lines of cooperation between it and the European Union.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report because I do not think that Turkey continues to occupy part of Cypriot territory can be ignored. The GUE/NGL presented a proposal for an amendment for inclusion in the report of mention of a bi-Community and bizonal federation, with one sovereignty, with a single international legal personality and a single citizenship, with political equality between the two communities and equal opportunities for all citizens, on a demilitarised island, which was incomprehensibly rejected by the majority.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. In 2012 My support for the Resolution in which, from the European Parliament, we call for greater efforts in Turkey to implement the necessary reforms if we are to move forward in turkey's accession process to the EU. Turkey must make a clear commitment to the democratic rules and principles governing the EU and, therefore, we call on the EU authorities here to respect freedoms of the press and expression, as well as judicial independence.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. As Turkey is backwardining in terms of democracy and society, I voted against the report.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution acknowledging the efforts made by Turkey so far to implement EU rules and law. However, many concerns still remain in relation to Turkey’s respect for media freedom, freedom of expression and judicial independence.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The Commission and Parliament are pushing to open cooperation with Turkey to more chapters. This is the only power of pressure found by a Union divided between its support for free trade, the security challenges in Syria and Iraq, and the violations of fundamental freedoms in Turkey. Except that Erdogan is not likely to worry as long as his access to the European market is assured, and there is no threat on that side in this resolution.  In any case, I am opposed to any enlargement that Parliament is defending at the cost of permanent structural reforms. Injunctions on political reforms will have no resonance in this context. As for the denunciation, which I support, of the occupation of Northern Cyprus, it unfortunately only adds to many others, alongside the UN resolutions. However, this was not a problem when accession negotiations with Turkey began in 2005. A typical example of the EU's preference for free trade over respect for international rights. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The proposed report on the situation in Turkey clearly supports Turkey's accession to the EU. Indeed, this accession is considered in this report as the most appropriate means for EU-Turkey relations.  Although some of the proposed amendments, such as the recognition of the territorial integrity of Cyprus, the regret of Turkey's behaviour against Greece or the Turkish refusal to reopen an Orthodox seminary, were rather in the right direction. However, it is important to remember that Turkey is allowing Daesh terrorists into Syria and Iraq. Geographically, culturally, religiously, historically or civilizationally, Turkey does not meet any criteria for possible membership of the Union.  Since the primary purpose of this report is to get Turkey to join Europe, I voted against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the report presented by the European Parliament on turkey's progress. The reform process in the context of negotiations with the EU for future accession may represent an opportunity for Turkey to develop a robust democratic system with sound institutions in order to strengthen its relationship with the European Union. However, I stress that the issue of fundamental freedoms and human rights must be carefully assessed and that no disrespect can be tolerated. Still on the issue of building good neighbourly relations, I regret recent developments and stress that this is essential to undertake effective reforms in order to continue with the process of democratisation and modernisation.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it emphasises that reforms to the rule of law, fundamental rights, home affairs and civil society are being given a higher priority and are receiving increased funding under the Instrument for Pre-Accession. The report also commends Turkey’s efforts in assisting and hosting an estimated 1.6 million refugees from Iraq and Syria.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing ‒ although Turkey has implemented several reforms since 2010, this is insufficient to accept the country into the EU. There is a lack of freedom of the press and complete freedom of the Internet, and although Turkey has committed itself to reforms to join the EU, it has still not implemented them for the ninth year. As Turkey is a strategic partner for the EU, the EU should become a fundamental democratic pillar for building democracy in Turkey by promoting universal European values for the reform process, as without democratic values Turkey's accession to the EU will be unacceptable. I am concerned about Turkey's response to the gezi protests in 2013, when brute force was used against the population, and I therefore call for a fair trial instead of politicised court judgments. Media freedom is a priority issue for the EU, as it is closely linked to democracy and the right to information. I do not agree with the Turkish Government's tendencies to prevent freedom of expression, a ban on access to social networks and the punishment of journalists, as was the case with the gezi protests. As in the past, I call once again on Turkey to translate its commitments into concrete legislation and also to implement it gradually. Since democracy is based on the will of the people, reform of the electoral system is essential to reduce the 10% threshold in order to represent more citizens and thus ensure pluralism of the political system in Turkey.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the annual progress report on Turkey which, based on the Commission’s report, assesses the state of play in Turkey’s accession negotiations. The report strikes a fine balance between the need to continue the accession negotiations and criticisms of Turkey’s performance in a number of crucial areas, such as the rule of law, fundamental freedoms and basic rights, the rights of minorities and women, etc. The report, while being critical of Turkey’s backsliding on democratic reforms, maintains that the EU and Turkey are engaged in accession negotiations.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is balanced, realistic, taking into account both turkey's few recent achievements in meeting the Copenhagen criteria and the regrettable number of setbacks in this area in recent years. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the start of accession negotiations in 2005, Turkey has made enormous progress towards establishing a democratic, pluralistic system with sound institutions that benefit social growth and development. This same 2014 report identifies the progress made and underlines that Turkey is a strategic partner for the Union.  There is an urgent need for progress in measures on human rights, freedom of the press and pluralism as a basis for the creation of a true rule of law. We must also underline Turkey's role in neighbourhood issues and its role in welcoming refugees. I believe, however, that the Union must make efforts to resolve the Cyprus issue.   I am in favour of this motion for a resolution and I believe that the Union's relations with Turkey are essential for the creation of a security cordon in our region.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This proposed resolution on the 2014 follow-up report on Turkey recounts the country's developments. Turkey has the status of a candidate country for membership of the European Union. Despite some criticism of the imperfection of democracy in Turkey, notably regarding freedom of expression, respect for fundamental rights and human rights, or the independence of the judiciary, this report remains largely in favour of Turkey's entry into the European Union.  This enlargement is also eagerly wanted by the United States, as evidenced by a recent statement by President Obama, which pushes for Turkey's integration into the Union, because it is a member of NATO and would serve its interests. Opposing Turkey's entry into the Union and finding it scandalous to make Turkey dream of future integration widely rejected by the peoples of Europe, I voted against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I abstained on this report on the follow-up to Turkey's accession negotiations to the European Union. Indeed, I do not share the terms of this text, which encourage the Turkish Government to speed up the pace of accession negotiations. Turkey is intended to be a major partner of the European Union but is not intended to be part of it.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. This report provides an overview of Turkey's progress in 2014. I abstained in the final vote of this report, which included very firm provisions for Turkey. However, until economic and social integration is a reality, the enlargement of the European Union is not an option. There are conditions for joining the European Union that Turkey still does not meet. For the future of cooperation between the EU and Turkey, and for the good of both sides, Turkey must put the reform process at the heart of its national priorities.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Turkey is a key partner for the European Union, by far one of the most important both for its geographical proximity and for its convergent economic and security interests. While maintaining a strong interest in continuing negotiations on Turkey's accession to the European Union, which is nonetheless conditional on the fulfilment of the formal criteria laid down in the Treaty of Lisbon, we cannot deny some concern about some recent events that have undermined Turkey's international image. Specifically, we are rather concerned about the limited independence of the judiciary and the lack of freedom of expression. We also strongly call for the peace process with the Kurdish minority to be speeded up and for a lasting situation to be found for this issue as soon as possible. In any case, we are convinced that the solution to the country's undeniable problems is greater involvement of the international community, and specifically of the European Union. The relaunch of the dialogue with Turkey could lead to important progress both within the country and in the general scenario of a crucial part of the world.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I abstained on this report. While it is important for Turkey to move closer to European standards of governance (political, economic, social, etc.), this cannot be the aim of accession.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that Turkey must put the reform process at the centre of internal policy choices and commit itself more and 'unequivocally' to respecting the EU's democratic values and principles, including freedom of the press, freedom of expression and the independence of the judiciary. In my opinion, the European Commission should review with Turkey the way in which the negotiations for its accession to the EU have been conducted so far, and reflect more on how to improve and intensify its relations with that country.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Turkey is a key strategic partner for the EU, so it is important to provide an appropriate framework for fully exploiting the full potential of EU-Turkey relations. Turkey should be supported in developing a strong, pluralistic, democratic system and sound institutions for the benefit of all Turkish citizens and to strengthen relations with the EU. The use of a critical position should not be missed. The country should be made aware of its clear commitment to respect for the democratic values and principles at the heart of the EU and to amend the restrictions on freedom of the press, freedom of expression and the independence of the courts.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report in order to have a better view of the state of play in EU-Turkey relations and to monitor and asses respect for the rule of law and democracy, human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ As a long-time supporter of Turkey’s bid for a closer relationship with the EU, if not to become a full member, I naturally voted in favour of this document. I did so especially in the light of the recent elections, which have shown a return to plurality and a popular vote which clearly sent a message to Mr Erdogan’s administration. I have great hopes for a return to pluralism and normality in Turkey, and also that the EU can strengthen its relationship with this very important partner and regain its popularity in the hearts of Turkish people.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The 2014 progress report on the accession negotiations with Turkey must be rejected in the current situation. Turkey has still not met the accession criteria on any single point, and has also interfered with fundamental freedoms. To show greater commitment to the fight against corruption, to respect freedom of the press and to strengthen judicial independence: these fundamental freedoms belong to a democratic country that Turkey wants to be. Unfortunately, as this is not the case, I have spoken out against it.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This annual report assesses Turkey's progress, which this year has been very meagre, given the difficulties encountered during the negotiations. The report makes the mistake of pedding on progress that does not exist, such as good relations with the Kurds or the integration of Roma in Turkey even though their respective situation remains deplorable.  Despite this, the resolution presents some constructive criticism of the events in Taksim Square, as well as the Turkish advances on workers' rights. I therefore abstained on this vote.

name: Artis PABRIKS
text: in writing. ‒ While the Progress Report on Turkey could have been more balanced and constructive this year, it is crucial that, despite the many disagreements among Members of the European Parliament, the resolution still refers to the official opening of Chapters 23 (judiciary and fundamental rights) and 24 (justice freedom and security) as important steps to promote truly effective reforms in Turkey. This is something I strongly support. Equally, it is very important that the Progress Report on Turkey states strong support for the reunification of Cyprus. This could be one of the rare opportunities to make history and find a solution on the reunification of Cyprus supported by all parties involved. It is a responsibility of the European Parliament to support this process.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is important that the European Union maintains the EU perspective for Turkey and that Turkey and the EU itself work to promote it. The EU should move towards visa liberalisation for Turkey. It is important for Turkey to continue to implement reforms, including in the areas of the judiciary, constitution and fundamental rights. Freedom of the press must be guaranteed, peaceful demonstrations and public gatherings must be allowed and human rights violations in Gez Park must be taken seriously. Turkey plays an important role in the world– it is a member of NATO and plays a central role in resolving many of the events taking place in neighbouring countries.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Piri's motion for a resolution because I believe that Turkey is an essential partner for the EU in maintaining stability and security in the area. At the same time, in recent years, I have noticed a particular setback in respect for the right to freedom of expression and information in the country, which risks further slowing down the process of EU membership.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ During recent years Turkey has made impressive progress in many areas. For a long time I was a big supporter of Turkish accession to the EU, and I still consider the process as a big opportunity for Turkey to achieve European standards on which to establish the highest level of trust. Unfortunately, I consider that several events – mainly during the past two years – have greatly slowed down the process. Problems including corruption, an unclear separation of powers and a different mutual understanding of political pluralism have hindered the entire process. Turkey will be able to continue its transformation only if it commits to democratic rules and principles, which are at the heart of the EU. In such a spirit, the EU will remain a key partner of Turkey, supporting and helping it in its commitment to achieve genuine change.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. In 1987, Turkey officially applied for membership and was only recognised as a candidate country in 1999. Following the 2004 European Council summit, membership negotiations with Turkey were announced, which began in 2005, the same day as negotiations with Croatia.  They obliged Turkey to fulfil the Copenhasian criteria, establish good-budgetary relations and gradual alignment with the EU, but have so far failed to implement the provisions stemming from the Association Agreement and the Additional Protocol. The shifts in reforms are visible, but they are weak and need to be made a priority of domestic policy. Reforms are urgently needed in the fields of justice, fundamental rights and justice, freedom and security.  Further changes to the constitution, reform of legislation in accordance with European standards and harmonisation of the acquis, involvement of civil society in the decision-making process, and resolution of the Kurdish issue should be worked on. Turkey must ensure and protect the fundamental human rights and freedoms of all its citizens without exception.  The rule of law must reign in Turkey, and all three branches of government must function smoothly and independently. Turkey must recognise the sovereignty of its neighbouring states. I call on Turkey to confront its past and to recognise and condemn the genocide committed by the Ottoman Empire against the Armenian people.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This proposal on the 2014 follow-up report on Turkey details Turkey's multiple developments in terms of its status as a candidate country for EU membership. Although this report includes some criticism of Turkey and the Erdogan administration, notably on respect for fundamental rights, freedom of expression (e.g. threats from journalists from the current government), human rights and justice, it is clear that this text remains in favour of the enlargement of the Union and the arrival of Turkey within it.  Certainly, the recent elections in Turkey, which many organizers believe were partly rigged, did not give the ruling party, the AKP, a majority, but sent a signal of a desire for democratic change in a country where conservative Islam is increasingly trying to take root. But Turkey still refuses to recognize the Republic of Cyprus, its relations with Armenia remain more than tense and its attitude towards the Islamic State poses a serious problem. For all these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ 2014 was declared the YEAR of the EU for Turkey, underlining Ankara's commitment to joining the EU. Nevertheless, the Commission's progress report highlights still unresolved issues. Looking on the positive side, Turkey accepted the 2013 democratisation package, the EU strategy for the resumption of EU accession negotiations, the entry into force of the EU-Turkey readmission treaty and the visa debate.   Turkey's humanitarian role in taking in refugees from Syria (1.7 million of them) as well as progress in resolving the Kurdish issue is important. On the negative side are the highlights: the unrest at the time of the Local Elections in March, as well as the presidential elections in August 2014, the absence of legal consequences as well as legal measures, following a corruption affair in 2013 involving many politicians and their family members, judges and police officers, then the right to media freedom that had been compromised several times until December 2014.  The EU remains there to support Turkey's efforts to build strong, democratic institutions to ensure respect for religious freedom, human rights and the rule of law. In its 2014 conclusion, the Council highlighted and emphasised a key component of the accession process, namely the recognition of all Member States and urged Turkey to take more concrete steps to address the pressing Cyprus problem.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. ‒ Turkey is one of the EU’s most crucial strategic partners, all the more so in the context of the Union’s heated debates on energy security, migration and efforts to find peaceful solutions. With the newly elected government in Turkey, Parliament’s vote approving pre-accession support therefore came at a good time to show the EP’s firm stand on future cooperation. Alongside the reforms we have witnessed, we must not ignore the serious concerns in Turkey about press freedom, effective check-and-balance systems, gender equality and religious freedom, to name just a few. Turkey must step up its efforts on the promotion of human rights and the rule of law, in accordance with the Copenhagen criteria, to bring the accession negotiations forward. It is a pity that the urgent situation of Turkey’s blockade of Kobane is not addressed in the text as adopted. However, I rejoice that our proposal has been approved. With our sister parties, the HDP and CHP, projected to secure 211 seats in the 550-seat Turkish Parliament, we look forward to fresh progress on bringing Turkey closer to the EU, including on the promotion of political pluralism and equal minority rights for Kurds, Alevis, the Roma and other groups.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report and I welcome the progress made by Turkey as highlighted in the Commission's report. Turkey is a major partner for the EU both in the various trade and industrial sectors, as well as for energy security, cooperation in foreign policy, immigration and stability in the region. In the light of this, I believe that it is useful for both sides to establish closer cooperation between the EU and Turkey, with a mutual commitment to intensify negotiations in view of common strategic interests and the certain usefulness that a strengthened dialogue with Turkey on economic issues and greater integration between Turkish and European companies could have in order to benefit growth and employment.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report because I consider Turkey to be an important partner for the EU and its Member States, and I consider the evaluation report to be balanced because it notes both positive and negative elements in Turkish developments. I consider the EU-Turkey partnership to be a key part of our foreign policy, especially now that Turkey is on the cusp of a very complicated region where civil wars are raging and so-called 'war' is raging. The Islamic State is carrying out a number of crimes against humanity here. That is why it is important for Turkey to be our ally.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. As part of the enlargement policy, the Commission publishes an annual follow-up report on the negotiations for each candidate. MEPs have adopted Turkey's follow-up report but the country has yet to continue its reform efforts.  In particular, MEPs call on the Turkish government to be more respectable and to integrate these elements into the government's reform process. MEPs reiterated their call for Turkey to respect media freedom, freedom of expression and judicial independence. I welcome the progress made and encourage the country to continue on this path.  However, I abstained on this text because I oppose Turkey's entry into the European Union.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. The geostrategic importance of Turkey and the need to preserve European influence in an area of instability fix the terms of EU neighbourhood policy, guiding its future course. Since 2005, the EU has begun a lengthy process of accession negotiations with Turkey, which has been emanated by the country's successive setbacks in implementing the reforms drawn up by the EC-Turkey Association Agreement and the Additional Protocol. Failure to comply with the provisions of these Agreements and Protocol undermines the desired harmonisation of Turkey's policies with those of the EU, thus affecting confidence in the negotiation process. In this sense, the European Parliament's motion for a resolution discriminates against points that deserve special attention and particular commitment, such as the separation of powers, the fight against corruption and organised crime, freedom of assembly and peaceful demonstration, freedom of expression and the media, among others. I am voting in favour of the Commission following the exhortation of Parliament and its Members, who in this motion for a resolution invite us to consider how the negotiations have been conducted to date and to consider how they can be improved and intensified in the future.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. To ask whether Turkey has made progress in 2014 on the path to eventual membership of the European Union is to answer it.  And the blame lies with the regime of President Erdogan, which in recent years has multiplied serious acts, both domestically and internationally. Moreover, Turkish voters made no mistake, they refused last Sunday, for the first time in thirteen years, to give the AKP an absolute majority.  To list the facts in stark contradiction with European values would be too long, but some constitute a "sniping" in the pre-accession contract. Turkey remains the world's 14th prison for journalists. And what about the circumvolutions around the Armenian genocide?  Clearly, Turkey is still not at peace with its history and has still not done its duty of remembrance. The brutal reactions of the President and Prime Minister of Turkey following Pope Francis' recognition of the Armenian genocide on Sunday, April 12, are the best proof of this.  It is in this sense that I have objected to the opening of any additional chapter of negotiation.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. The European Union remains committed to pursuing enlargement as a key policy to promote peace, democracy, security and prosperity in Europe. As an EU candidate country, Turkey needs to step up its efforts to resolve bilateral issues that are still open, especially in the areas of fundamental rights and justice, including unfulfilled legal obligations here and disputes involving its land, sea and air borders with its closest neighbours. Turkey must continue to implement a political reform that meets the basic principles of the European Union. It is important that there be close monitoring of the European Union and its support for the development of this country, in particular in the social integration of refugees, respect for human rights, respect for the social role of women and issues related to culture and education. The results of the last elections, going against European values, showed that the Turkish people want a plural society from a political, cultural and religious point of view.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. This Resolution calls for closer relations between Turkey and the EU, and for the Commission to rethink how it has conducted the negotiations so far and how they can be improved and intensified. Among other issues, Turkey is urged to put the reform process at the heart of its political agenda and European legislative values and principles as markers of this process. And he is also asked to open a process of reform of his Constitution, which promotes a more pluralistic, inclusive and tolerant society. The peace process with the Kurdish community, the reunification of Cyprus or collaboration against ISIS are other issues addressed in the report, as well as the prevention of violence against women, anti-discrimination legislation and protection of the LGTBI community, respect for religious freedom or religion-state separation. The EU must help Turkey develop strong democratic institutions and legislation based on respect for fundamental freedoms, human rights and the rule of law, defending and representing all sectors of society.  On these and other issues, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. In the resolution on Turkey's 2014 monitoring report adopted yesterday, the European Parliament welcomed the 7 June general elections in Turkey, while calling on the country to make efforts on the rule of law, in particular to ensure respect for media freedom, freedom of expression and the independence of the judiciary, as well as in the fight against corruption.  Parliament also called on Ankara to put the reform process at the centre of its national priorities. "A new Constitution based on provisions to promote a pluralistic, inclusive and tolerant society would support the reform process and allow for a better anchoring of fundamental freedoms and the rule of law," the resolution states. Parliament also stresses the importance of intensifying dialogue and high-level consultations between the EU and Turkey on foreign and security policy issues so that these policies are complementary. The resolution also calls on Turkey to take the necessary measures to normalize its relations with the Republic of Cyprus and to put an end to repeated violations of Greek airspace and territorial waters.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The complex 2014 progress report on Turkey was discussed at the last plenary session, but ultimately it was decided to postpone the vote, given the sensitivity of the issue and the lack of clarity between the different currents of Parliament. The resolution tabled by the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Human Rights, Common Security and Energy, which I have decided to vote in favour of, shows, on the one hand, the positive results achieved by Turkey during 2014, a country that has become a strategic, economic and energy partner, of increasing importance to Europe, but on the other hand the critical issues remain and these must be absolutely resolved with a view to ever deeper cooperation. It is precisely the negotiations with the EU that represent a significant opportunity for Turkey to develop a strong pluralistic democratic system, with solid institutions, for the benefit of all Turkish citizens and for closer relations with the European Union.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the Resolution on the Report on the evolution of relations with Turkey. While we understand that the interest of a general report in this regard may be noticeable, it is necessary at the same time to exercise responsibility to ensure that the issues are properly represented and that no injustice is committed against any of the parties involved. We understand that the accession process of a country of Turkey's size must be followed with greater interest on the part of the Commission and Parliament, which should propose texts that would do justice to Turkey's complex, diverse and, in many cases, difficult to contrast reality in mere reports.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. ‒ Although I voted for this resolution, I wish to express the following reservations: (1) On a general level, I doubt the value of an omnibus resolution which reviews rather indiscriminately all matters pertaining to the Turkey-EU relationship, with little focus on what the priorities should be; (2) The resolution says much about what Turkey should have done better in its relationship with the EU, and little or nothing about what the EU has done badly or not at all in satisfying its commitments to Turkey; (3) In particular, the resolution could have analysed the ambiguities, fudges and delays in the EU’s approach when dealing with the Turkish request for membership of the EU, which in part provoked Turkey’s later quest for a different geo-strategic posture, not least in order to have a fall-back option should its European quest be blocked; (4) The resolution fails to give sufficient acknowledgement to Turkey’s achievements as a state with Muslim core values, by way of modernisation, economic growth, social development, the stability of its institutions and progress towards an equitable arrangement with its Kurdish community.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ We welcome the Commission’s 2014 Progress Report on Turkey, and share its conclusion that Turkey is a key strategic partner for the EU. Active and credible negotiations would provide a suitable framework for exploiting the full potential of EU-Turkey relations.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: writing \ u2012 My position is based on the belief that every applicant for EU membership should, above all, fulfil the Copenhagen accession criteria.  I consider consistent compliance with the criteria to be the only but at the same time very important condition for assessing a country's readiness to become a member of the EU. Turkey has been promised membership, but at the same time, as a candidate country, it does not meet the criteria in several areas, and this needs to be truthfully named. That is why I abstained in the vote.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the Commission's 2014 progress report on Turkey, which states that Turkey is a strategic partner for the EU in the area of economic and energy security. I also agree that the Commission should reconsider the way in which it has conducted negotiations so far so that EU-Turkey relations and cooperation can be improved. The reform process in Turkey needs to be stepped up. Although there have been changes in the legal sphere and in the area of elections, or in the efforts of the Government of Turkey to achieve a comprehensive and sustainable peace process with the Kurdish community, there is serious concern about the corruption perception index and the prosecution of journalists who have followed corruption cases. Changes to the Law on the High Council of Judges and Prosecutors and the subsequent numerous transfers and dismissals of judges and prosecutors are also of concern. The Commission's report condemns police raids, restrictions on the right to assembly, restrictions on media freedom, but also highlights persistent attitudes about the role of women in Turkish society. For better progress, Turkey must build good neighbourly relations, in particular by intensifying dialogue with Armenia and Cyprus. Turkey has made considerable progress, but there is still much to be done to join the EU in many areas.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. In general, I could say that this year's Progress Report on Turkey is more critical than previous reports, but it is also more constructive. It is important to point out that the Turkish Government's recent events against press freedom and public opinion conflict with the fundamental rights of the European Union. Critical but also constructive compromises have been reached. In particular, as regards visa liberalisation and opportunities for civil society, improvements have been made. The latter are crucial to Turkey's progress as a democratic state. The customs union for trade between Turkey and the EU should also be improved. In the future, it will be necessary to observe consistently corruption in turkey's internal circles of the Turkish Government. On the basis of the elections recently held in Turkey, I welcome the election of the most inclusive and representative parliament in Turkish modern history, which reflects the country's diversity. I would like to commend the resilience of Turkish democracy and the democratic spirit of its citizens, as is reflected in the high participation of citizens in elections. It is important that all political parties work to establish a stable state in the country with a view to reviving the process of democratisation and reform, which will encourage and strengthen the dialogue between Turkey and the European Union. For the reasons set out above, I voted in favour of the adoption of the resolution by the European Parliament.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. I am very pleased with this resolution on the 2014 Progress Report on the situation in Turkey. The EP is right to welcome the election on 7 June 2015 of the most inclusive and representative parliament in Turkey's modern history. It reflects the diversity of the country. We rightly commend the resilience of Turkish democracy and the democratic disposition of turkish citizens. This is reflected in the particularly high turnout and the impressive participation of civil society volunteers on election day.  We rightly urge all political parties to work towards the establishment of a stable and inclusive government in order to reinvigorate the democratisation process in Turkey and the reform dialogue with the EU. The HDP's election result is a strong signal of the need for progress and democracy among the Turkish people and of its support for a peaceful solution to the Kurdish issue.  Finally, I also welcome the reaffirmation of the EP resolution of 15 April 2015 on the centenary of the Armenian genocide. The majority of 550 votes in favour, 47 against with 77 abstentions in this respect speaks for itself.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: writing \ u2012 I appreciate Turkey's reform efforts in previous years. Turkey is a key partner of the European Union, and it is therefore important for the EU to conduct a long-term and inclusive political dialogue, as it can support Turkey in further reforms and lead to better respect for fundamental human rights.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I support this proposal for a 2014 resolution on Turkey's progress. A year, because I believe that Turkey is a partner of the European Union and that negotiations with that country should continue in the best environment due to the positive effects that result from them.  I also believe that Turkey should be encouraged to implement reforms that are essential for future prosperity. While there is a high level of corruption and crime in Turkey, I believe that negotiations and dialogue between the EU and Turkey will implement the necessary reforms that will have a positive impact on addressing these problems as well as the problems of media freedom and the problem of human rights violations and fundamental freedoms.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ I support the draft motion for a resolution. The Commission's conclusion is that Turkey has made significant progress in reforms in the previous 12 months. It also notes the power of transformation negotiated between the Union and Turkey and stresses the importance of close dialogue and cooperation between Turkey and the EU in the reform process, so that negotiations continue to give Turkey clear and credible benchmarks.  That is why it is important to stress the importance of credible negotiations, conducted in good faith and based on a common commitment between Turkey and the Union to effective reforms that strengthen the democratic foundations of Turkish society. Key items, then, are a credible commitment and solid democratic foundations, meeting the Copenhas criteria, building good-budgetary relations, enhancing EU-Turkey cooperation. Turkey remains the EU's sixth largest trading partner, with the EU as Turkey's largest partner with a share of 38% in total Turkish trade and almost 71% in foreign direct investment.  I also support the Commission's ongoing assessment of the EU-Turkey customs union with a view to assessing its impact on both sides and how to improve it, and urges Turkey to remove the remaining restrictions on the free movement of goods.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing \ u2012 I voted against. I welcome all of Turkey's reform actions, as well as all steps to remove trade and other barriers between Turkey and the European Union. However, I do not agree with the efforts to accept Turkey into the European Union, and so I do not think it is right that the amount of funding for pre-accession aid should be increased.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the Commission's 2014 progress report on Turkey. This October will be 10 years since the start of accession negotiations with Turkey, but there is no progress or even a setback in some important areas. Although Turkey is an important trading partner of the European Union and an important partner in the fight against terrorism, we must not forget the EU's core values, such as human rights and fundamental freedoms. It is also of great concern that Journalists Without Borders ranked Turkey among the countries where journalists were the most frequently targeted in threats and physical attacks in 2014.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported today's European Parliament resolution on the Commission's progress report on Turkey for 2014, as I believe that it accentuates sufficiently all the elements of the European Union-Turkey relationship. Turkey is a NATO member, but it is not only a strategic partner for us in the field of security, but also in the field of energy or migration, given its location. However, the interest in close cooperation with Turkey does not preclude the possibility of drawing the country's attention to the need for progress on the independence of the judiciary, the protection of women's rights or religious minorities, freedom of the press, the fight against corruption or the need to maintain standard relations with neighbouring states and to provide equal treatment to all EU Member States.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against this proposal because we fundamentally disagree with Turkey's accession to the EU. Turkey has nothing to do culturally and ethnically with Europe. Its accession to the EU will act as a fifth column.  On the substance, we disagree with the views expressed in the progress report, namely that Turkey is a strategic partner of the EU. We fundamentally and vertically disagree with the undying exhortation mentioned in the proposal for mutual settlement and reunification. We disagree with the characterisation of the attilarch as a 'leader of the Turkish Cypriots'. And we find the proposal to open the port of occupied Famagusta ridiculous, so that the Turks and the settlers of the occupied can trade their illegal products.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the adoption of this report because it faithfully and comprehensively reflects eu-Turkey relations and the current state of the accession process. I also bearing in mind that Turkey's importance as the EU's strategic partner has increased over the past year, above all because of the threat of international terrorism and the dramatic refugee situation. I also think it is important that the report deals with the issues of energy cooperation with sufficient weight. At the same time, I agree with the view reflected in the report that our support and solidarity should not be a reason to turn a blind eye to the fact that the situation of fundamental human and civil rights in the country has not improved substantially or even deteriorated in some areas.  I believe that the decline in the attractiveness of the European alternative and values in Turkish society was also largely down to the EU side: the protracted accession negotiations, the overshadowing of enlargement, had the same effect in the current plans of the Commission and the Council. Progress is urgent because of turkey's extraordinary importance, so I welcomed in the report that it calls for more openness from the EU side, more openness, strengthening the membership perspective and making it more tangible. I hope that a constructive, supportive policy on the part of the EU could also have played a role in the outcome of last week's parliamentary elections in Turkey, which project the chances of a more coloured, tolerant and democratic internal development.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: in writing. ‒ As a vociferous critic of the direction in which President Erdogan has been leading Turkey over the past decade, I speak today with a touch of optimism. With the parliamentary elections of 7 June 2015 depriving Erdogan’s AK party of the majority he has relied on to impose his will, and with the Kurdish party passing the 10% threshold for the first time to take up to 80 seats, this could perhaps mark the horizon of better things to come. A different type of government would do more to honour its role as a NATO ally in the fight against ISIS, truly to honour its commitments as an EU candidate country to align its foreign policy more closely with that of EU Member States, as outlined in Chapter 31 of the acquis, and to refrain from any interference in the Cyprus reunification talks which are taking on an increasingly optimistic tone following the election of Akinci as leader of Turkish-Cypriot community. Turkey has great potential as an emerging major economy, with a talented and diverse population, straddling the divide between East and West. At present I do not foresee such a Government emerging, especially as Erdogan is already talking of fresh elections, but I hope to be proved wrong.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution. Indeed, a relationship that is effective and operational, and is based on dialogue, closer cooperation, reciprocal engagement and negotiations between the Union and Turkey - given their geographical proximity, the historical ties between them, the important Turkish community living in the Union and the close economic ties and common strategic interests - is in the interest of both sides. Turkey is being asked to put the reform process at the heart of its national priorities. The Union must seize this opportunity to become the main vehicle for the continuation of the democratisation process in Turkey by promoting universal values and European regulatory standards, as a reference to the reform process, and by supporting Turkey in establishing robust democratic institutions and effective legislation, based on respect for fundamental freedoms. , human rights and the rule of law, concerned with the representation and defence of the interests of all sections of Turkish society.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this progress report on Turkey. The ALDE Group has introduced clear language into the report, calling on the Commission to reassess the way in which negotiations have been conducted so far. Moreover, the progress report makes clear that the rule of law, press freedom and freedom of expression are core values of the EU, which every country taking the path of accession should respect. By voting in favour of this report, I also wanted to welcome the election of the new Turkish Parliament and to call on the different political forces to work towards the establishment of an inclusive government which should reinvigorate the democratisation process in Turkey and its reform dialogue with the EU.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 The vote in the recent parliamentary elections in Turkey shows that the desire for change has also reached Turkey. President Erdogan's ruling party will be forced to seek allies in order to govern. The country now faces a number of scenarios ranging from the formation of a minority government to a return to the polls. Turkey's strategic position and trade links with Turkey must encourage the European institutions to strengthen already close and effective cooperation. If the European Union is to play a role in the sensitive Middle East scenario, relations with Turkey must be revived. We need frank, prejudice-free discourse on both sides. We must bear in mind that Turkey is a strategic partner for the EU in the fight against terrorism and in the management of migratory flows, which is why assistance to the Tusco Government and to all those involved in the protection of refugees and asylum seekers must be stepped up. Turkey is being asked to renew its commitment to the development of sound democratic institutions and legislation based on respect for human rights, the rule of law and the defence of the interests of all communities.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Turkey is an important ally of the European Union, so any shift for the better in Turkish society can only be welcomed. The president and the government have taken several important steps in the right direction and I hope they will continue to do so. Without entering into the likelihood of Turkish MEMBERSHIP in the EU for the foreseeable future, which is accepted with a certain amount of skepticism on both sides, I find it unacceptable that we call on a sovereign state from this house to adopt a new constitution.  The Constitution is a basic document on which the Turkish state rests and must be tailored to the needs of all Turkish citizens, not to our foreign policy ambitions. I believe that such patronizing behavior on our part, if it has any effect at all, will cause only negative reactions.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \ i supported turkey's 2014 progress report. Turkey is certainly one of the EU's key strategic partners, and through active and credible negotiations, an appropriate framework could be set for exploiting the full potential of EU-Turkey relations. I note that Turkey continues to implement reforms in the area of the rule of law. Progress is being made, but there are still some problems in the fight against corruption, freedom of expression, violence against women, minority rights and judicial independence, and the related separation of powers.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the Resolution on the Report on the evolution of relations with Turkey. While we understand that the interest of a general report in this regard may be noticeable, it is necessary at the same time to exercise responsibility to ensure that the issues are properly represented and that no injustice is committed against any of the parties involved. We understand that the accession process of a country of Turkey's size must be followed with greater interest on the part of the Commission and Parliament, which should propose texts that would do justice to Turkey's complex, diverse and, in many cases, difficult to contrast reality in mere reports.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution, and I would put special emphasis on the importance for Turkey of having more sensible policies regarding human rights and the rights of minorities. In this regard, it is of great importance that Turkey ends its blockade on Kobane and its Kurdish population, and also that it recognises the victims of the Armenian genocide 100 years ago.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This report is once again in line with Turkey's accession to the European Union, a totally unthinkable prospect. Its accession is considered "the most appropriate means for EU-Turkey relations". I therefore vote against this text.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the European Parliament resolution on the 2014 Commission Report on Turkey's progress, given the importance of the EU-Turkey partnership in the current geopolitical context, so tense in the Black Sea and Middle East area. The report voted on today underlines the importance of good cooperation between Turkey and the European Union, but criticises the latest political developments in the country. I subscribe to the concern expressed about the significant increase in corruption in Turkey. At the same time, we note with concern a setback with regard to respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, in particular with regard to media freedom. I strongly condemn the recent police raids and the arrest of several journalists in December. The turkish Government's recent actions against freedom of the press and diversity of opinion are incompatible with the fundamental rights of the European Union, making it difficult to resume the negotiation process. In line with the EU's commitment to respect for the rule of law and fundamental values, I believe that reforms in the area of the judiciary and fundamental rights, namely in the field of justice, freedom and security, are urgently needed in Turkey.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the Resolution on the Report on the evolution of relations with Turkey. While we understand that the interest of a general report in this regard may be noticeable, it is necessary at the same time to exercise responsibility to ensure that the issues are properly represented and that no injustice is committed against any of the parties involved. We understand that the accession process of a country of Turkey's size must be followed with greater interest on the part of the Commission and Parliament, which should propose texts that would do justice to Turkey's complex, diverse and, in many cases, difficult to contrast reality in mere reports.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the Progress Report as it sends a clear message on the need for the EU to be more proactive in promoting human rights in Turkey and on the importance of giving more support to those citizens defending human rights in Turkey, and contemplating Turkey's accession process as a good instrument in promoting democracy and human rights.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The European Union's enlargement policy has multiple contradictions. All of them emerge strongly when it comes to the case of Turkey, a state that had applied for in 1987, which has been a candidate since 2004 and has closed only one chapter (out of 35) in ten years of negotiations with the EU. At the same time, Turkey perpetuates its occupation over a part of the territory of the Republic of Cyprus, an EU Member State, violates the human rights of the Cypriot population, develops a settlement policy and generates situations of tension in Cypriot territorial waters. The proposed resolution expresses this situation, which is positive. However, I was unable to vote in favour of the Resolution because it contradictoryly encourages the continuation of the negotiations. Such negotiations cannot continue as long as Turkey does not meet the basic requirement to recognize the Republic of Cyprus and to end its occupation. On the other hand, there is a contradiction in assessing positively the possibility of reaching a solution to the situation of the Kurds, but the PKK is not asked to remove the PKK from the list of TERRORIST organisations in the EU. That is why I decided to abstain in the vote.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: in writing. – The resolution rightly acknowledges Turkey’s importance as a strategic partner of the EU, with a crucial role in the fight against terrorism and instability in the Middle East. I also welcome the call for Northern Cyprus to be allowed to trade with the EU. The resolution makes some fair criticisms of Turkey. Turkey must respect the rights of religious minorities, take effective action against corruption, and take tougher measures to combat irregular migration. On the other hand, the resolution criticises Turkey’s stance on Cyprus without acknowledging that the EU has yet to honour its commitment to end the isolation of Northern Cyprus. It notes the importance of energy issues but does not call for the opening of Chapter 15 of the acquis, which would help to reduce our reliance on Russian gas. The reference to the April 2015 resolution, urging Turkey to recognise the ‘Armenian genocide’, is deliberately and unnecessarily provocative and could undermine EU-Turkey relations at a time when we need to be encouraging Turkey’s democratic and liberal instincts. Since the resolution combines valid points with some negative ones, as well as gratuitous attacks on Turkey, I abstained.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. As Turkey is backwardining in terms of democracy and society, I voted against the report.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. Progress reports are a means to an end to attest to the EU compatibility of future Member States and thus to advance EU enlargement. Agreeing to progress reports implies supporting the fundamental concern of EU enlargement. However, I am sticking to the AfD's European election programme: 'First consolidation, then enlargement' and 'No EU accession of Turkey'. The accession negotiations with Turkey have been going on for more than 50 years, since the signing of the Association Agreement in 1963. Turkey has been officially a candidate country since 1999, and accession negotiations began in 2005. The governments of all member states – including CDU Chancellor Angela Merkel – are wavering through all stages, even against the opposition of their own people. The Turkish election campaign of the Turkish parties in Germany runs without Turkey's EU membership. However, it is clear to me that Europe has geographical, cultural and historical borders that the EU must not disregard. I therefore reject Turkey's accession and call for an end to the accession negotiations with Turkey. Multilateral cooperation is well maintained within the framework of the United Nations, the Council of Europe, the OECD, NATO and the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), and the EU and Turkey also cooperate economically.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ through this resolution, I wanted to express my concern about events that threaten security in Turkey. The increasing violence, violations of human rights and fundamental freedoms in the country, the repression imposed on journalists and civil society as a whole are a worrying sign for Turkish democracy. As the other parliamentary elections have partly changed the political scene, I call on the Turkish authorities and the authorities to respect the freedoms sought, and I call on them to implement reforms in the area of freedom of faith and religion in a more plausible way. They will also show this by returning land belonging to the Syrian Church and reopening a Greek Orthodox seminary. Finally, I must reject President Erdogan's remarks at a meeting of people commemorating the 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide. I am thinking mainly of his statement when he called Pope Francis' words on the Armenian genocide "delusions." This is unacceptable and, unfortunately, shows the growing authoritarianism of the Turkish President, who has closed himself to his security. All these worrying reasons have led me to abstain at the end.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Mr Ioan Mircea Paşcu, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the strategic military situation in the Black Sea basin following Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea (2015/2036(INI)) (A8-0171/2015).

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, after the Cold War, the Black Sea – which was relatively closed before – became, first, a transport route for Caspian oil and gas towards the West and, second, a source of energy in itself, forcing both its opening up and its consideration in a larger regional perspective, namely the ‘Black Sea Area’. Thus the Black Sea Area has become both economically relevant and politically contested, as witness the geopolitics of the various pipelines crossing it and the efforts by Russia and Turkey to oppose outside penetration. The breaking up of the former Soviet Union and the admission of Romania and Bulgaria to both NATO and the EU have markedly transformed the political landscape, specifically compelling the EU to come up with an integrative instrument, namely the Black Sea Synergy, back in 2007. Contrary to the bureaucratic view, the initiative has had little impact in terms of fostering a regional common identity among the countries in the area, and consequently on strengthening cooperation between them. In part that was so because almost all the countries involved had more important forms of collaboration with the EU, other than the Synergy. However, the relatively reduced efficiency of the initiative is geopolitical. The area was in flux in 2007 and it still is today. After the illegal annexation of Crimea by Russia, the latter’s destabilisation of eastern Ukraine and the practical inclusion of both Abkhazia and South Ossetia in Russia’s military organisation, one could say that the Black Sea Area is moving back to what it looked like two decades ago, with Russia attempting to control its northern shores, as the Soviet Union did 24 years ago. The occupation of Crimea and the current efforts to cut two territorial corridors – one from Russia towards Crimea and another from Crimea towards Transnistria – are undeniable realities. The siege of Mariupol and the destabilisation of Odessa are testimony to that. The fact is that, since the illegal annexation, Crimea has become a launching pad towards Bosnia – and the area around and beyond – due to the transformation of the initially small, defensive Russian force stationed in Sevastopol into a significant strike force equipped with long-range force-projection systems, quite apart from an aggressive programme of modernisation of the Russian Black Sea fleet. In sum, Russia has thus provided itself with a southern Kaliningrad in support of its potential expansion. Consequently, in the last year-and-a-half the Black Sea has acquired important military relevance, in addition to its existing economic relevance, which could not leave the EU uninterested, especially when both the EU security and defence strategies are being revised, making all the Union’s other interests – environment for instance – inevitably mediated by the long—term militarisation process initiated in the area. Therefore, the aim of this report is to increase the EU’s awareness of the complex situation created in the Black Sea, which could not – and should not – be either ignored or left entirely to NATO to deal with. This reality calls for responsible management of the situation in the Black Sea, but a dialogue with Russia – provided it was not misinterpreted by the latter as an encouragement to dare more – should obligatorily be accompanied by the continuation of deterrence as part of a strategic reassurance to the eastern members of both NATO and the EU, who have lost faith in Russia’s real intentions.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I am pleased to have the opportunity today to discuss the issues related to the Black Sea. I will focus on our regional cooperation efforts and perspectives in this area. I welcome the attention that the European Parliament is giving to the Black Sea Basin. The EU has interests and responsibilities in the Black Sea region. We take an active approach to the sea basins that surround us, and the Black Sea is one of them. There are several reasons – environmental, transport, maritime affairs, civil society – for the EU to play an active role in the Black Sea region. We welcome the report by Mr Paşcu, which underlines the significant opportunities and challenges in the Black Sea area that require coordinated action. As we have mentioned on previous occasions, while there are good reasons to call for a comprehensive EU strategy for the Black Sea region, we have to make sure it will be well received both within the EU as a whole and among the non-EU Black Sea states. It must therefore come when the ground has been well prepared. The report before us focuses on the strategic military situation in the Black Sea Basin following the illegal annexation of Crimea and Sevastopol to Russia. The EU stance on this remains clear. We will not recognise the illegal annexation of Crimea and Sevastopol. We continue to condemn it and to fully implement our non-recognition policy, including a trade and investment ban. The EU is assessing the security risks arising from Moscow’s behaviour, for example in the fields of energy security, cyber security, the security of civil aviation and of our banking systems, the stability of our democracies, and ways of countering the Kremlin’s propaganda. We remain prepared for the long haul in the crisis with Russia and are very conscious of the need to preserve EU unity also in the long term. We must be ready to face Moscow’s confrontation as well as its cooperative behaviour. The current EU double-track approach as regards the Ukraine conflict should be applied to EU-Russia interaction as a whole: resilience and firmness, together with dialogue and engagement. On the one hand, the EU remains steadfast in its support for Ukraine’s territorial integrity, sovereignty and independence. It continues to support all diplomatic efforts and in particular those linked to the implementation of the Minsk agreements and those linked to UNSC Resolution 2202. Our current efforts focus on supporting the work of the OSCE Special Monitoring Mission. The EU has also continued its efforts in the trilateral processes with Ukraine and Russia on energy and on the implementation of the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area as part of the EU’s support for the broader comprehensive peace process. There is no doubt that Ukraine faces immense challenges in the security, political and economic areas all at the same time. The EU is committed to bolstering Ukraine’s ability to deal with these challenges and is therefore delivering unprecedented financial support. The implementation of the EUR 11 billion support package is under way and the EU has already committed through loans and grants, including through its banks, the EIB and EBRD, around EUR 6 billion. In parallel, the EU has adopted consecutive packages of restrictive measures, including those aimed at entities in Crimea. The European Council in March explicitly linked the duration of sanctions against Russia to the complete implementation of the Minsk agreements. The EU remains deeply concerned at the continuous military build-up and deterioration of the human rights situation in the Crimean peninsula, including the denial of free speech and the persecution of persons belonging to minorities. The EU continues its cooperation initiatives under the Black Sea Synergy as and where possible. As you already know, the EU’s approach to the region is guided by the Black Sea Synergy. This communication, adopted in 2007, sets out goals and tasks across a range of economic sectors and thematic areas based on the notion of the complementarity of various actors and actions. In January 2015, the EEAS and Commission services reviewed the implementation of the Black Sea Synergy and issued a joint staff working document summarising the lessons learned. This document presents a snapshot of the progress in the main fields of cooperation in the Black Sea region during the last five years. The lessons learned highlighted in the document will inform the future development of the Synergy. Stronger partnerships between the EU institutions and Member States, increasing stakeholders’ participation, and better coordination with other regional and international organisations are among the lessons that we take on board as we move forward.
