The results of the Black Sea Synergy to date reveal the practical utility and the potential of this EU regional policy approach. The Black Sea Synergy should remain a bottom-up initiative geared towards strengthening regional cooperation via concrete projects, making the best possible use of the wide range of tools at the EU’s disposal. An important goal is to bring added value to the citizens of the region, while ensuring environmental sustainability. Also, we have a substantial programme of cross-border cooperation in the Black Sea region. There are projects underway to strengthen monitoring capacities of the Black Sea marine environment as well as in the areas of research, tourism and culture. We do all that while increasingly engaging with the civil society and other regional stakeholders. Last but not least, the EU’s recently-adopted Maritime Security Strategy and its associated action plan looks at maritime security in all the sea basins around us, including the Black Sea, in a cross-sectoral way. As called for by the report, this will help us to address maritime security challenges in an integrated manner, combining civil and military involvement at national and EU level across the numerous policy sectors concerned. The EU needs to remain closely attuned to its interests in the region, including strategic, political and economic interests, and to further discuss how best they can be achieved. On military issues as, very rightly, the report insists upon, we are maintaining and possibly even strengthening close contact with NATO at both political and working level. In its conclusions of 18 May, the Council welcomed ongoing efforts to strengthen strategic and practical cooperation between the EU and NATO, with the overall objective of building a true organisation-to-organisation relationship. In this endeavour, we count on the support of the European Parliament, and we look forward to views and ideas from the Members of this House.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the situation in the Black Sea basin has fundamentally changed due to Russian aggression against Ukraine and the annexation of Crimea by Russia. The military balance has significantly shifted towards entrenchment of Russian military dominance in the Black Sea. There is a country in the region, a neighbour of the EU, which used to benefit from cooperation with European democracies but which, for many years, has been steadily preparing itself for military endeavours instead. We used to close our eyes to this tendency. Experts estimate that since 2009, Putin has increased defence spending in roubles more than 20 times over. We all know the economic and social challenges Russia now faces, but this does not stop Putin spending up to 34% of the national budget on defence and security. Too many European NATO member states do not manage even 2%. There are new realities for the countries of the region, and they are not the reflection of a greater peace. Russia is testing the boundaries of our security. It is up to the EU and NATO to make it clear to Russia that in the current world you cannot send tanks or amass military forces whenever you think things are not going your way. You cannot bully your neighbours or tear independent states apart. The annexation of Crimea will never be recognised, and the Minsk Agreement must be implemented. The EU must stay firm on this principle because, if the trend is not stopped in Ukraine, the limits of our security will be tested further. The military balance in the Black Sea region may be restored by strengthening our transatlantic link and by a bigger NATO presence and increased cooperation under the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) but, in addition, we should help threatened countries to take more responsibility for security in their region. Countries that have the most direct security concerns, due to the changed realities, could combine their efforts by creating a joint military battalion for military exercises, increasing interoperability and furthering modernisation. The issue of the occupation and annexation of Crimea should not be abandoned. There are legal ways to challenge it, including by requesting a legal opinion from the International Court of Justice. It is important to make clear to those responsible for violations of international law and human rights that a crime does not go unpunished. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), blue card question. Mr Landsbergis, you are denouncing Russia for violently changing borders in Europe with the annexation of Crimea. But should the European Union and this Parliament have the right to make such complaints, should they have shown a similar attitude in all the relevant cases?  When European states bombed Serbia to achieve the change of borders and the secession of Kosovo, what were the complaints heard in this Chamber? Or is it that, on the contrary, today the European Union is demanding that Serbia accept Kosovo's secession in order to move the accession process forward? Isn't there inconsistency in that?

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: blue-card answer. – Well, it is very obvious that the United Nations – even the United Nations – called this an illegal act of war. So I do not think it is too much, in this House, to call a spade a spade. Whenever I hear arguments like that put forward, the only resemblance I hear is to words that come from the Kremlin, and I am saddened to hear them in this House. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – Colleague Landsbergis rightly mentioned that the Russian side, with its operations, is testing, testing and pushing the European Community's tolerances, and I obviously agree that there must be some kind of disciplined and common response to this. But what tools do you see in the hands of the European bodies to act more effectively against certain Member States that undermine joint action? For example, the Orban Hungary.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: blue-card answer. – First of all, I understand the situation that our friends in Romania and Bulgaria find themselves in, having lived for so many years in an area that was apparently an area of peace and recreation and now is an area where, supposedly, nuclear armaments might be kept. The situation has changed dramatically. Just a few hours ago this Parliament voted in favour, by a big majority, of the EU—Russia relations report. The report states that there are a lot of things that the EU can do. For one thing, the EU can no longer put new ideas on the table and wait for Russia to change its policies.

name: Ana GOMES
text: On behalf of the S&D Group– Mr President, as Mr Paşcu writes in this report, the European Union and its Member States should not recognise Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea, reiterating its commitment to ukraine's independence and territorial integrity in accordance with the Un Charter and the Budapest Protocol of 1994. Considering the annexation of Crimea and the continued occupation of South Ossesis and Abkhazia in Georgia, Member States need to have a joint security response, prepared for the challenges posed by Russia in the Black Sea basin and consequent changes in the geostrategic context and military situation. This response should be reflected in the review of the European Security Strategy and the European Maritime Security Strategy. Given the potential for instability and, in particular, Europe's dependence on the Black Sea for the transit of energy supplies, the European Union has a strategic interest in deterring regional actors from adopting a reckless political attitude if necessary by mobilising European naucies and aerospace equipment to the Black Sea.  We must also act diplomatically to persuade Russia to put an end to hostilities and respect the Minsk Agreements, but if Putin continues to orchestrate the separatist forces of the Donbass and destabilise Ukraine in Mariupol, Odessa and elsewhere, sanctions against the regime in Moscow need to be strengthened, specifically targeting them against the oligarchy that supports Putin.  It is therefore vital that the Member States of the European Union remain united and refrain from militarily equipping Russia, risking violating international law and the sanctions framework.

name: Marek JUREK
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – In the Russian resolution, we said today that we must be prepared to confront Russia on the basis of our 'soft power'. But in fact, we need to be aware of the true nature of the challenge that Putin is throwing at his neighbors and the West. His policy is contained in this simple doctrine, which he laid out: that for him the greatest geopolitical tragedy of the twentieth century was the disintegration of the Soviet Union. And Putin's policy is simply to rebuild this prison of nations, although of course he wants to change the façade in this prison and repaint its walls. Nevertheless, the objective remains the same. Who does it turn to? In Eastern Europe, first of all, to people who have learned to treat the Soviet Union as a normal reality, and at the same time be guided by an irrational sense of threat from the West, a threat that has never been. If Putin were sure that the response to his annexation of Crimea would be to accept Georgia into the Atlantic alliance, the war in eastern Ukraine would not have happened. And our policy must, above all, be a policy of consistent regional balance. Secondly, we must always bear in mind the geopolitical function of the Black Sea. The Black Sea has always been a bridge and a road between Europe and Central Asia and this function should be regained. That is why, in this report, we are requesting the resumption of work on the construction of the Nabucco gas pipeline, the very connection that will connect Central Asia and Europe energetically. May only these challenges be followed by authentic deeds.

name: Fernando MAURA BARANDIARÁN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, since the beginning of the Ukrainian crisis I have been watching with deep concern the sectarian and bellicose drift undertaken, on some occasions, by many of the members of this House. The numerous reports, resolutions, appeals, vetoes of Russian diplomats, among other measures taken in this Parliament, convey an image which does not favour us at all. There is no doubt that we must maintain a firm and strong stance towards the Russian Government, but it is also crucial to establish a clear dividing line between Russian citizens, which must always be respected, considered and supported, and the leaders at the helm of their Government. Emotional debates, escalation of conflict, propaganda and counter-ownership warfare, resolutions such as those we are discussing today, which are truffled with hypotheses and not facts, harm not only the ultimate objective of resolving the conflict in Ukraine and normalising relations with Russia, but European diplomacy as a whole. If we start on the basis that Russia's annexation of Crimea is illegal and cannot be recognised, the European Parliament is the institution that must channel European interests and values, and use them through diplomacy — what we call 'soft power'— to achieve a peaceful solution to the conflict. Unfortunately, we would say that we are looking to solve the situation in a different way. We must return to the rational field, measure the consequences of our actions and decisions and, above all, rely on facts and realities when making reports and statements.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, this report helps us to understand the geopolitical vision of the grand coalition, which is characterised by the construction of the Russian enemy.  Russia, in this text, is guilty of the situation in eastern Ukraine; he is also guilty of geostrategic changes in the Black Sea; is guilty of the European Union's energy insecurity; and is even guilty of defending himself.  The bad news is that when we build enemies, in the end we seek action against them. And here come NATO's sanctions or strong strategic guarantees to its eastern members. Speaking in silver: troop and weaponry transfer.  And if that were not the case, even the application of Article 5 of the Washington Treaty: war.  All underpinned by genuine manipulations of recent history, such as when it is stated that "the illegal annexation of Crimea offers Russia an outpost located directly on the borders with NATO", as if the 1999 enlargement had not involved an outpost in front of Kaliningrad or the 2004 real watchtower next to the country.  There are too many contradictions. Can the European Union really raise its policy towards Russia based on crimea's incorporation into Russia?  This Parliament recently adopted a resolution which continued to give good independence to the self-proclaimed Republic of Kosovo, the result of the support provided by NATO bombings to terrorist organisations. And we can't forget that the Americans laid the base for Camp Bondsteel, one of the most important facilities that was the CIA detention center, some know a lot about it.  Therefore, groups supporting this text will vote from a cynical and bellicose position in the service of interests outside Europe. The GUE/NGL Group will vote for peace and international cooperation. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – In fact I would like to ask our colleague, Mr Couso Permuy, whether he would speak the same way in this Chamber if a country came and seized a part of his country’s territory. Do you know, Mr Couso Permuy, that nowadays the Russian Black Sea fleet is already greater than the combined fleets of all the other Black Sea coastal states and poses a tremendous threat to European Union security and defence?

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: "blue card" response. – It is precisely my country, regardless of the Government, that is why it does not recognise the illegal annexation or self-proclaiming of Kosovo; because it also affects us deeply in our country. So, don't come to me talking about it. What I want to point out is who started breaking Europe's board. And it wasn't Russia, gentlemen, it was us. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear Mr. Advocate, I must say that I am very sorry that there was a war on the territory of the former Yugoslavia and in my political work of 25 years I have done everything to make peace in this area.  However, I cannot accept your views and I ask you because of this, do you think that the tragedy that Milosevic's bandits made in Srebrenica is something that is reprehensible and do you think that a similar scenario could easily have been repeated in Kosovo and that there would have been mass killings and mass eviction of the population from Kosovo if Milosevic had succeeded in his intentions?

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: "blue card" response. – In no way does support for any massacre come from my words. But that's where you put interest only in one aspect: where it suits you. And I repeat again: the one who broke the agreements that had been taken after the dissolution of the Soviet Union was NATO, and it was not Mr. Milo-evi.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: is the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, if you allow me I will speak in Estonian, because it seems to be the only language that the master of the Kremlin understands. Firstly, I would like to thank Mr Pașic for having been really nice working with him. The man calls things by the right names – Crimea is annexed, nowhere did we start the annexation of Crimea, as a colleague of the GUE/NGL Group recently tried to argue. However, when speaking on behalf of the Green Group, I would like to point out a few of the problems we have had with this report. The first problem is that many of our Members think that too strong language, which is not followed by the use of force, can be counterproductive and rather give Putin bonfire material in the Kremlin again to claim that it is NATO that is now attacking him through the Black Sea. The second problem is that our group thinks that this Parliament's Security Committee is not really a NATO parliamentary assembly, and if the report too strongly emphasises NATO's role in restoring the strategic balance of the Black Sea, then we are perhaps wrong. Perhaps it is up to our Parliament to demand and support the european Union's armed forces, in addition to Turkey and the US and Canada, as the third pillar of NATO, which would realistically be able to ensure our hard rhetoric in resolving security situations. Finally, I would add once again that if Mr Pașcu's country were to be in trouble, our men would always come to the rescue.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, much of the pain, destruction, loss and suffering caused by the recent fighting in Ukraine can be directly attributed to the expansionist policies of the European Union. As a result, the EU is now deeply embroiled in a highly complex and dangerous standoff with Russia which it cannot hope to win. Due to the EU’s previous empire-building ambitions in Ukraine, this organisation now has little moral legitimacy to take any action, either diplomatically or militarily, without the risk of further stoking the fires of conflict in the region. This is why I am today calling for a strategy of intervention and the promotion of peace, to be developed and implemented by a non-state, non-partisan actor such as the UN in order to avoid a potentially catastrophic, multinational, military engagement. While I condemn the EU for its actions in Ukraine, I must also make it clear that I equally condemn Russia's President Putin for his own expansionist ambitions in the Black Sea region. I can only hope that through skilful negotiation and diplomacy, conducted by a competent independent arbiter, a multinational war can be averted. Ukraine needs the opportunity to take control of its own internal affairs to achieve its ambition of becoming a sustainable and united democracy. Given the opportunity, I am convinced Ukraine can develop into a strong, independent, politically free, and defendable nation that can freely trade on both sides of the current divide and with the rest of the world. What Ukraine does not need is an EU or Russian puppet master pulling its strings, moving forward.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Allow me to express my concern. I have listened to the previous speakers and i have noticed how a large number of speakers read their texts from the paper in a very lifeless way, where technical procedure, abstract analyses are discussed and where I completely miss emotions in a Parliament like this. Do not forget that even in these minutes of debate here, people are dying. And it is not a question of focusing on geopolitical interests, whether it is the US, whether it is the Russian stake or the EU or the American interests. It is primarily a question of taking people's interests into account. And this is not happening here in a way that people actually deserve. We must try to find a way to bring about peace in a democratic way, and not, as the report states, to bring even more NATO material into the region and to pour even more oil into the fire. No, we are trying to rediscover this primal democratic path, where people can decide their own future in order to be able to go into a prosperous future. After all, we have the opportunity, in the eastern regions of Ukraine, to try to use international monitoring once again to hear people imagine their future – perhaps at the cost of bringing the western part of Ukraine closer to the European Union. That would be a model suitable for the future. This should be discussed and no longer technical procedure.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: I would point out that Mr Vilimsky spoke as an unregistered person, representing himself and not as a representative of the unregistered as from some cabins translated what I said. I would like to make this clear because, under the regulation, those who belong to the non-attached speak on their behalf and not on behalf of all non-registered persons.

name: Artis PABRIKS
text: – Mr President, I think that this report is very timely and should also give rise to some action in the relevant institutions in the European Union and, I would say, also in NATO. So this is our goal. I see this report as touching on three vital issues as far as the Black Sea is concerned because, after the annexation and occupation (or vice versa: the occupation and annexation) of Crimea, Russia is threatening to turn the international waters of the Black Sea into its internal sea. We should see this problem in the context of all those recent aggressive activities of Russia in the Baltic Sea as well as in the Arctic, and I can see the problem from an economic, political and also humanitarian perspective. Politically and militarily we have not experienced such a challenge for a long time, and it is very interesting for me to see some on the right or far right or far left actually living in an illusion or disinformation about NATO expanding. If the free breath of my nation, the free will of my nation to join the European Union and NATO means aggression towards Russia, should these nations simply die or not breathe? I do not accept such arguments, so from that perspective we are in an extremely difficult situation and we should act. So how can we act? I think that there must be a common approach between the European Union and NATO to safeguard our basic security interests in the Black Sea. Democracy cannot be defended only by speeches if those speeches are just hot air without anything behind them. Secondly, we must also ensure that there is no danger for energy pipelines, as has been seen, for instance, also in the Baltic region. And from a humanitarian perspective, let us remember what we can do for those poor Crimean Tatars in the occupied territories.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Mr President, let me welcome my colleague, Ioan Mircea Paşcu, and his excellent report which radiographs the military and strategic reality in the Black Sea basin. And to point out that if the European Commission does not update its Black Sea Synergy after this report, we will end up with neither security nor energy but just another piece of paper. In this context, I would like to welcome President Poroshenko's decision to denounce the five agreements between Ukraine and the Russian Federation on the transit of Ukrainian territory by Russian military forces in the breakaway region of Transnistria of the Republic of Moldova and to point out that these laws were adopted on 21 May. I would also like to mention that these agreements, although they did not apply in practice, the transports were carried out against the will of the Ukrainian State. As a result of this reality, 1,500 Russian special forces (Spetsnaz) are in Transnistria. Russia is likely to intend to build an air bridge. In the same context of the excellent Paşcu report, I raise the issue of the vulnerability of critical energy infrastructure in the Black Sea basin, now and in the future. Finally, I would like to draw attention to Russia's gradual strategy of implementing the occupation of neighbouring territories, moving from interethnic internal conflicts to frozen conflicts and then to their direct occupation as in the case of South Ossetia, Abkhazia and Crimea. Last but not least, I highlight Russia's massive presence in a large-scale electronic war identified as such by NATO and the partners of the European Union, and I note that Russia has turned Crimea into an impressive military arsenal with the aim of projecting strategic capabilities on the eastern region of NATO and the European Union. This is the reason why NATO and non-NATO states in the Baltic Sea decided to build the defensive pact. Thank you and congratulate the rapporteur once again.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: – Russia's attempts to redraw Europe's eastern borders are taking on worrying proportions. Crimea is further militarized with new war bases, warplanes and hundreds of additional soldiers. Like Kaliningrad in the north, Crimea becomes a massive Russian fortress and there is more.  We see Moscow stepping up the pressure by incorporating the frozen conflicts in the region into confrontation. Moldova, which recently opted for rapprochement with Europe, is subject to a strong Russian embargo and is being torn apart internally as a result of an efficient Russian propaganda machine. In the southern region of Gagauzia, Russian speakers are pushing for an annexation by Russia. There are also Russian troops in Transnistria, officially to keep the peace, but today they are an ideal start for the Kremlin to extend a land corridor from Crimea to Odessa and on to Transnistria. The Russian intervention in Abkhazia and South Ossetia in 2008 was supposedly intended to protect the Russian-speaking minority. Putin wants to use the same pubic patch in the areas around Odessa and Marioepol and the man does not feel much sorry for the minorities. See the list of human rights violations in Crimea against the remaining Crimean Tatars, the Ukrainians, the Jews, and the Greeks.  It is time to stop Russian aggressiveness. Mr Pașcu correctly states that this can only be done by promoting regional cooperation with an important role for NATO. In this context, the EU should consider a single response in the review of the European security strategy. Finally, I support his call for a review of the European energy diversification policy with a view to restarting the Nabucco project.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: – Mr President, according to the most recent forecasts, the Ukrainian economy is set to decline by 9% this year. This negative outlook is the direct result of the continued fighting in the east and the military situation in the Black Sea region. Each day of the conflict costs Ukraine over EUR 5 million, and therefore the achievement of peace in the east is not only vital for security and humanitarian reasons, but also from the economic perspective. In the light of this, we must reiterate that the EU condemns the annexation of Crimea and we must continue to exert pressure on Russia to respect the Minsk peace agreement. Remaining united in our response is imperative to the immediate achievement of peace in the region.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, I have been in this Parliament for eleven months and in that time we have been positioned for Ukraine and Russia as much as on any other issue. I congratulate the rapporteur for having been able to present the coldest text I have ever seen. Reading it I wondered whether this is a report written and prepared by elected Members or is a NATO resolution.  The distortion of reality with vague general considerations, assumptions and aphorisms is reminiscent of the Cold War period. The blind service of the geostrate strategic military and economic interests of NATO, the US and certain circles of the European Union in the region, for the control and routes of energy resources, ladies and gentlemen, by demonizing only one country, without a trace of self-criticism and criticism of the policies of your allies is interpreted by the conclusion.  You are raising the need for military balance in the region and you are calling for NATO's role to be strengthened and for member states to increase military funds, of course at the expense of social spending and social cohesion. My vertical refusal to the resolution is my minimum obligation to voters. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – In the 1980s, the European left, or at least part of the European left, showed solidarity with the peoples of Eastern Europe, who fought for freedom against the Soviet Union, against the communist dictatorship. We remember this time well. What has happened to the left-wing tradition that today you are on the agenda over ukrainians' desires to live in a free world, to live with Europe? What has happened to the left-wing tradition that you are ignoring this commitment today?

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: GUE/NGL), answer to a question with a "blue card". – Mr President, the resolution states that the European Union's attitude to the events in Georgia in 2008 may have encouraged Russia to act in a similar way in Ukraine. In other words, the resolution makes no criticism of European responsibilities, america's and NATO's responsibilities for destabilizing the region and the war in Ukraine; who is ultimately to blame?  Listen, ladies and gentlemen, I told you two hundred percent of a state's budget to boost NATO's budget is a very excessive amount.  Aren't we a little ashamed when in my country at the moment hospitals and schools are closing, trying with this logic to de-escalate the region by strengthening NATO? Is there de-escalation in the region if we continue sanctions on a country and create all these problems that we create? So, you think we're going to solve the problems in an area that's currently on fire? Is this the future of Europe? Is this the future of the region? Is that what we're fighting for?

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, when I read this report, I realised that it is not only the sea that is black, nor is it just the lists that are black, but it is the whole situation that is completely black, both in Eastern Europe, but even more so in this Parliament. Rather than talking about the Cold War, we could talk about very hot war scenarios, or rather a war fever, a propaganda war. This is a militaristic drift which is emphasized with regard to Russia, but which could very well be emphasized to us as well.  The real big problem with this report is that there is no form of self-criticism. There is simply criticism, sometimes well-founded, of Russia, but there is nothing critical of us: yet we should know that on the international stage, geopolitical actors act precisely for geopolitical interests. Russia does its own in ways that are reprehensible, perhaps in some cases, but so much could be said of the American and European methods, which perhaps operate through multinationals, rather than operating precisely through other methods.  I believe that the real great risk – which is never strongly taken into account – is that a completely adrift Russia seeks an ever closer and closer partnership with China, and perhaps also with Iran, creating an Asian bloc that would therefore create a much bigger problem than what we are facing today. Nor do I understand why Turkey is seen as a very reliable side of the West, despite everything we have stressed several times in this Parliament.  Well, I would say that rather than saying that there is no diplomatic route, we must relaunch a diplomatic dialogue with Moscow by any means at all costs, because not only is it unthinkable to engage in a confrontation, but even worse it would be to do so by proxy.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Pasu's report is irresponsible. Let's talk about law and talk about Crimea. You are talking about illegal annexation, but in the name of what? First there was a coup d'etat - illegal, indeed - fomented by the United States, and Ms. Nuland does not hide from it. So there is no rule of law anymore. There is also a people who, in accordance with international law, freely chose their return to the Russian homeland. A homeland he should never have left. The Forbes report and the US media pointed out last week that more than four-fifths of Crimea's population is fully satisfied with this situation. This report concludes that the executive of the United States lies to its people and lies to Europe.  A revanchist and warrior spirit guided the writing of this report. Rather than being the warlike voice of the United States, which wants to break Europe in two and build a new Berlin Wall, this parliament should support peace and ask Kiev to stop bombing civilians. I was in Lugansk when they bombed this town. They're the ones who started it! When I arrived in Brussels, I found that the opposite was being said.  If a new world war comes to this continent, do not think, ladies and gentlemen, that history will forget you. The people will come to judge you severely and you will be condemned co-responsible for the millions of deaths that will result. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, colleague, I do not agree with what you have said. I support the rapporteur's point of view and refer to a fairly clear figure: 6,000 people.  It corresponds to the number of people killed during the conflict in Ukraine. You are talking about a culprit, but how do you know who is guilty?  In my opinion, the incidents that took place and the action of Russia resulted in the death of 6,000 people. What is your message to the families of the 6,000 people who were killed?

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: "blue card" answer. "Dear colleague, first of all, there have been more than 6,000 deaths. I think from the information available that we are closer to 10,000 deaths, which have been mostly reported in the east. Know that it is the so-called rebel party that has suffered the most and that deplores the most deaths.  Also be aware that, coincidentally, people seeking refuge have taken refuge in Russia. Of the one million people who have left Ukraine, 750,000 are currently in Russia. That is the reality. They therefore do not see Russia as the aggressor because, on the contrary, they seek protection from that country.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, the new Russian military doctrine, as of the end of last year, officially considers that NATO and the EU constitute Russia’s main security threat. This is a clear indication that Russia considers us not as partners but as adversaries to be weakened, split and compromised. Following the annexation of Crimea, Russia is creating an offensive strike force in the region. In fact, Crimea is becoming a Kaliningrad of the south, with all the consequences of that. The rapid enhancement of offensive Russian military potential is a real threat and security risk for all the neighbouring countries, not just Ukraine. What is happening, by the way, is not a surprise. After the Russian invasion of Georgia seven years ago, the confrontational military pattern became obvious to all who wanted to see it. In fact, the EU has been lagging behind in its reactions. That is why Mr Paşcu’s report is so important and timely. The Mistral assault helicopter carriers symbolically connect the Georgian invasion with the Ukrainian one because, just after the war against Georgia, Mr Putin ordered these modern French-built warships, and the commander of the Black Sea fleet commented that if they had had these vessels at their disposal, they could have completed the Georgian operation in half a day instead of three days. That is why the message of this report is also to France to abandon, unequivocally and finally, the sale of the ships in question to Russia. They could well be used for enhancing the security of the EU borders. It is time that the Black Sea security risks were addressed as a priority, not only by NATO but also by the EU, which is in need of a revised and modernised security strategy. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: GUE/NGL), question with "blue card". Mr President, Mr President, the report which you have described as excellent makes no reference to the European Union's cooperation with the Agency for Foreign Cooperation. Do you really not think that the European Union should cooperate with the OSE, which is an organisation that seeks peace and cooperation in the region, but instead refers too many times to NATO, which exacerbates confrontation and causes serious problems in the Black Sea?

name: Tunne KELAM
text: blue-card answer. – Mr President, I think there is no question, and you must be well informed, that the EU is working fully with the OSCE. But in addition, bearing in mind also other countries of Eastern Europe which suffered under the Soviet Union’s occupation and terrorism for half a century, our experience shows that the OSCE is not enough. We need real security, and that is established in NATO.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Mr. President, I congratulate my colleague Pasco for his excellent work on this report because its content defines well the guidelines of our common security and defence policy following russia's illegal annexation of Crimea and the changed strategic and security-military situation in the Black Sea basin. Unfortunately, the Minsk agreement remained, for the most part, just a dead letter on paper. That is why it is high time for Russia in particular to take responsibility and help stop hostilities and thus prevent new casualties and destruction. I support the consistent approach of not recognition of Russia's annexation of Crimea, its commitment to the independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine. At the same time, I am committed to continuing to discuss such a necessary peace settlement actively and constructively. The European Union and Russia will become partners again then and when the preconditions for partnership are met – a relationship of proven trust, respect for international principles and signed agreements. The report also covered an extremely important energy dimension and calls for the promotion of energy security as well as the reduction of Member States' energy dependency. In doing so, the Member States of the European Union should also ensure through their measures the necessary security of the exploitation of oil and gas, i.e. their safe transport in the Black Sea area. This was because the Black Sea basin is extremely environmentally sensitive and the increasing militarization of the region further threatens this sensitive ecosystem. Russia's policy of strengthening offensive military forces in the Black Sea and the planned strengthening and modernisation of the Black Sea fleet are the best reminder that the Black Sea basin should be a real priority in european union foreign policy action. This should be added to the possibility of a new escalation of the Transnistria/Transnistria conflict, which would constitute an overflow of war from Ukraine. The existing Black Sea synergy is outdated, which is why I am joining calls on the Commission to develop as soon as possible a new comprehensive European Union strategy for Black Sea space. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question by raising the blue card on the basis of Article 162(8) of the Code of Health. Rules of procedure.)

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), question with "blue card". Thank you, Mr President, for taking my question. I wanted to ask you very briefly and clearly, why when you refer to the referendum that took place in Crimea, you call it illegal, when it was done in accordance with all the principles laid down internationally, there were observers there and, moreover, the difference between yes and no was great?

name: Tonino PICULA
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Behind me is the experience of the Vice-President of the OSCE Parliamentary Assembly and a long-time observer of elections throughout the Eurasian area and always, and I have led five international observation missions in Georgia, Armenia, Russia, Kazakhstan and Moldova, behind me is simply respect for something called the Copenhas Agreement. No essential element of the Copenhagen Agreement, i.e. the Copenhagen rules to recognise elections as legitimate, was met during the so-called referendum in Crimea and therefore cannot be recognised as legal.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In my opinion, the report rightly emphasises that the Union's more than restrained response to Russian aggression and Russia's violation of Georgia's territorial integrity in 2008 may have encouraged Russia to take similar action in Ukraine. Unfortunately, then there was no European determination. If all European leaders had adopted an attitude such as President Lech Kaczynski, who was then accused of anti-Russianism, perhaps the situation in Ukraine would not have been so dramatic today and Russia would have been much more cautious in its expansionist efforts. That is why it is so important today for the Union to take a firm stance – factual, not just verbal, non-appeasing of the annexation of Crimea and a firm response to what is happening in the Black Sea basin. Unfortunately, violations of the ceasefire in Ukraine are becoming more frequent, and incidents in the Black Sea are also multiplying. That is why it is so important to strengthen NATO's presence in the region and it is becoming increasingly indispensable to decide to provide ukraine with defensive weapons and support it to improve its defence capabilities.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, in April 2007, the European Commission launched its initiative for cooperation in the Black Sea region through the Black Sea Synergy project. The region is a growing market with great development potential and an important hub for energy and transport flows. The Black Sea is a major Euro-Atlantic component of strategic importance for the European Union and its Member States, especially when it comes to ensuring their security. The document focuses on economic and trade cooperation, while security and defence cooperation is not sufficiently mentioned Today, the current format seems to be obsolete. The geopolitical equilibrium of the Black Sea basin has been disturbed, and the existing conflicts in the region have been growing since the annexation of Crimea. In this regard, I consider it timely for the European External Action Service and Mrs Mogherini to revise the European Maritime Security Strategy and, in particular, the European Union Strategy for the Black Sea. The new European Union strategy must be developed in full coordination with our EU partners.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the As a former air force officer, I was certainly not a great friend of Russia 30 years ago. But things have changed in international politics. I am very surprised that not even 5% of all Members are present at a debate in this House on war and peace. When we keep talking about Russia's aggression, it is easy to note that former President Gorbachev made it clear that he was lied to in the 1990s when he dissolved the Soviet Union and the Warsaw Pact. When he launched a policy of peace, he was told that NATO would not expand to the east. What about Poland today? What about Bulgaria, Hungary, Romania and the three Baltic states? NATO has increasingly approached Russia, and now Crimea has just come to an end. Since there is always talk of annexation when 95% of the people living there voted in a referendum before in favour of joining and going with Russia is quite reprehensible. When I hear the voices of the Cold War coming from the majority groups in this House, I wonder quite clearly whether the arms industry may be behind this, because in the last 20 years the arms budgets in Europe have fallen extremely. We do not need war. We do not need a war policy. We need dialogue and dialogue! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8))

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: blue-card question. – You mention Bulgaria, the Baltic States and Romania joining the European Union and NATO. Those were legitimate decisions on the part of these countries. So you are against the legitimate decisions of the authorities of these countries to join the Union, which is where they want to be? Or how am I to understand your statement?

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Every sovereign country has the right to do something. Of course, this was their sovereign right. But an EU policy aimed at establishing association agreements while pursuing a policy of association with NATO – as is now happening in Georgia, Azerbaijan, and so on – is, of course, an aggressive expansion. You can do one thing, and you have to leave the other.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – We have a surplus of words and a lack of effective action. I would like to start here because, in my opinion, this report is not only critical of the situation in the Black Sea area, but also critical of us: the institutions, the democratic world, the institutions of the European Parliament, the Nato institutions. What i'm concerned about is that none of the major institutions predicted the situation in Crimea, did not anticipate developments in Ukraine. We are divided in this Parliament, in this House, we are erratic and, unfortunately, we are late to everything that is happening in the area of fighting, in the area of conflict, including in the armed forces. I would also like to draw attention to the inadequate assessment of the situation a few years ago in terms of assessing the situation in Syria, assessing the revolution in Egypt, assessing the situation in the Black Sea area. Unfortunately, all these events show the weakness of the European institutions, the institutions of the democratic world. I call for greater consistency, for dialogue with those countries that may be partners for us, for ukraine to be assisted, for the support of those countries that are counting on Europe – a modern Europe, a democratic Europe. I am also very keen to show one more element: if we are dealing with a hybrid war, we also need a hybrid response, which will consist of numerous actions, not just the ones that are most visible at the moment. I am convinced that the criticism of this report can be a source of good response, but for the time being I regret to say that it is simply not visible.

name: Clare MOODY
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the work on this report and express my sadness and regret that the relationship between the EU and the Russian leadership has had to come to this. Russia’s illegal annexation of Crimea, its deliberate destabilisation of eastern Ukraine and its continued involvement in conflicts across the region, such as Abkhazia and South Ossetia, mean we can no longer trust the Russian leadership. With this in mind, I am glad the report recognises the ongoing work of the EU missions in the Black Sea states and, in particular, the human rights abuses that Crimean citizens have suffered since the annexation. In this context, we must remain unified, continue the sanctions against Russia and continue to cooperate with our eastern partners.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, it is common ground that the sovereignty of national borders and territorial integrity must be respected and therefore the annexation of Crimea should be condemned because it is a violation of international law.  But the report is not just about relations between the European Union and Russia. It is titled "The military situation in the Black Sea after the annexation of Crimea". This report misses something very important – namely the policy of the Republic of Turkey and the events that may result from it. When we so fairly condemn President Putin's policies, we must not forget that the policy of his counterpart President Erdogan is exactly the same and the two faces of the same coin appear.  When we talk about uncertainty in the Black Sea Basin, we should also affect the behavior of the State of Turkey, its support for Islamic State, the possible new refugee wave that can be directed and supported by the Republic of Turkey. Otherwise, by denying and condemning only one manifestation of annexation and aggression, we would have manifested a double standard. I therefore also address my fellow rapporteur – when talking about the Black Sea Basin, attention should also be paid to the anti-European policy of the Republic of Turkey.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: – Mr President, I would also like to welcome Mr Paşcu's report. I consider it a very accurate assessment of the strategic situation and security in the area. I wish that this assessment had a debate in this House a long time ago. Unfortunately, we are very late in assessing the situation, and not only, in the award of a common position. In my opinion, the Minsk agreement is a quasi-failure. There was no talk of Crimea at all; as such, the evolution of security in the area, in Transnistria, the escalation of the conflict with Ukraine, Entitles me to believe that we will soon have Russian troops close to the mouths of the Danube, which will create a very big problem for the security of the European Union. There will be a very long border with Russia and first of all we will have to try to take significant steps, first and foremost diplomatic, to prevent such an escalation of the conflict.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, this report raises concerns over militarisation and the priorities of Russia and the EU in the region. It welcomes efforts by EU Member States to enhance the military capability of the Black Sea states and says that modernisation in enhancing their military capabilities is key to stability. The report also urges the Commission to support EU Member States in increasing their defence budgets. Of course, this does nothing to de-escalate tension in the region. It does, however, expose the hypocrisy of the EU telling Greece to spend money on defence while cutting pensions and raising VAT and forcing austerity on Ireland plus cuts in positive social public spending. The report highlights EU strategic interests in guaranteeing Member States’ energy supply, and the security of oil and gas exploitation in the Black Sea. So the lives and the livelihoods of the people in Crimea are without doubt a mere secondary consideration.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Mr President, many States of the Union are unwittingly involved in geopolitical games of influence between NATO, the European Union and the Eurasian Union. The effort to expand NATO and the Union to the Caucasus, Moldova and Ukraine, the energy hybrid and electronic war in the Baltic region and the countries of the Aimos peninsula, the sanctions against Russia, Crimea, are made in the context of the incessant struggle for power and lead by the powerful players of the above organizations. Let us first point out the fact that the annexation, or better so reunification, of Crimea with Russia is not illegal because that is what the People of Crimea wanted, and it is also proving to be historic. The other Baltic countries, under the pretext of supposedly bad Russia, fell into the trap of Germany's foreign and economic policy, as dictated by the US. Thus, they were forced into a harsh internal devaluation, extremely painful for their citizens, in order to be able to maintain their stable connection with the euro, and without any support whatsoever from the euro area. When Europe's strong economic and more central geopolitical countries such as Sweden, Denmark and the United Kingdom did not adopt the euro, the Baltic countries were quick to submit to German hegemony, granting their national sovereignty through their entrapment in the common currency. Anyone with a common mind understands that additional sanctions on Russia and discussions of military presence and flexible retribution lead to an escalation of the crisis and in no way benefit the European Union. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – You say that a referendum has been held in Crimea and that it is legal, and that there are historical reasons for Crimea to return to Russia, but there are also historical reasons for Crimea to return to Turkey. There are also historical reasons for Constantinople to return to Greece. Sir, if Turkish troops had entered Athens, what would be the outcome of the referendum in Athens?

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), answer a question with a "blue card". – What is your proof that the referendum was not legitimate, as far as the people of Crimea and their will are concerned?

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Yesterday, during discussions on the EU-Russia relationship, I heard the expression soft power several times. I respect the power of the word and the power of the arguments. But soft power against a country attacking neighboring states appears ineffective. For the third year, ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about Russian aggression, the third year. While we exercise soft power, people in Ukraine are dying. For the third year in a row, Vladimir Putin is mocking us. I therefore welcome Mr Paşcu's report, which draws attention to the change in the security situation in the Black Sea and to The fact that Russia is creating a new Kaliningrad from Crimea. I therefore welcome the demonstration of NATO's military force, which has started naval military exercises in the Baltic Sea. I therefore welcome any suggestion of willingness to defend our democracy and Euro-Atlantic values in the Black Sea. Russia honors tough adversaries.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: – Mr President, clearly the Black Sea has turned into a focal point of confrontation, involving strategic national security interests of the highest importance for the countries of the region. In order to overcome this situation, we are offered two approaches: armaments and oneupmanship, which the rapporteur seems to be proposing. This is a road to nowhere. What is needed is to take seriously each side’s security concerns and to examine ways of diplomatically overcoming those concerns. I strongly support urging the Commission to become involved in a new Black Sea strategy building on cooperation.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – The Black Sea region is of strategic importance to the European Union. It is in this area that the most military threats to our security have been born in recent times. Russia's seizure of Crimea is the most spectacular example, but not the only one and not the latest. The occupation of Transnistnist, the 2008 Russo-Georgian War, the seizure of Ossetia and Abkhazia, and the aggressive attitude of the Russian navy in the Black Sea are the image of the last decade. The common denominator of all these problems was and is the policy of the Russian Federation. Therefore, without stopping the Imperialist drive of the Kremlin, we will never be able to stabilise the situation in the region permanently – that is clear.  We have many friends and strategic partners on the Black Sea: Turkey, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. We can also use NATO's military and political capabilities here. By joining forces and the capabilities of all these actors, through a good cooperation strategy, we can stop the progressive Russian aggression. This reduction is a very good start and I would like to believe that it will continue too.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – The security situation in the Black Sea has become increasingly difficult, as all five frozen areas of conflict caused by Russia are in the Black Sea region. Of course, the biggest tension at the moment is the continued Russian aggression in eastern Ukraine and also the annexation of Crimea. The international community must make every decision to stop russia's militarisation of Crimea, including a plan to place nuclear weapons. However, the situation in Crimea and eastern Ukraine is not the only one that is a source of tension in the situation in the Black Sea region. The frozen conflict in Transnistria finally needs a positive solution based on moldova's territorial integrity. Otherwise, this is a possible new crisis, so Russia will have to move its troops out of Transnistria. In addition, Abkhazia and South Ossetia in Georgia have been annexed, which has also increased the possibility of a new conflict and tensions in the region. The European Union and all this part of the international community, which attaches importance to international law, must take very clear steps to reduce tensions in the Black Sea region.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – Mr President, I would like to first congratulate my colleague and Vice-President Pascoe on the good work of the report. The illegal annexation of Crimea and the clustering of military Russian equipment there led to a change in the balance of power in the Black Sea Basin. This poses new risks, especially for countries on NATO's eastern flank. The expansion of the conflict from eastern Ukraine to the south threatens to encompass regions populated by a compact and Bulgarian minority in Zaporozhka and Odessa Oblast, as well as to affect Moldova, where a large Bulgarian community also lives. We also need to keep a closer eye on the rights of other minorities in annexed territories, in particular local Crimean Tatars, who are persecuted for their support for Ukraine's territorial integrity. The same applies to the rest of the population in Crimea, as well as to the population of Luhansk and Donetsk region, which increasingly face a violation of human rights.  We have a duty to work to secure new energy suppliers and reduce our dependence on Russian supplies not only of words, but finally of the share. This is particularly concerned with Eastern Europe, such as Bulgaria. We need a pipeline like Nabucco, so I categorically state that we need to start thawing the project. Nabucco, or pipeline, which also passes through Bulgaria, is a chance for Europe.  Dependencies, however, are not only energy, but also corrupt, dear colleagues. We need to fight corruption inside and outside the European Union. Russian politics and business use this corruption to gain influence and control. It is very important to respond to the aggressive Russian propaganda machine as well as the ongoing repression against political opponents of the regime. In this regard, again from this stand, I call for the immediate release of the kidnapped and held illegally on Russian territory by Nadia Savchenko. Russia should respect international treaties. It is unacceptable in the 21st century to work with Cold War-era practices.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I join Mr Kovatchev's position on Mr Paşcu and thank you very much for a really good report. This is a report prepared in a professional manner, because we have a full diagnosis of the military situation. This is a professionally prepared report because we have an assessment of the political situation and a historical background. Whatever we have said here, historically there is nothing missing in this report – there is both Georgia and the whole region and all sorts of misfortunes that have happened there. What I would particularly like to emphasise in this report is a way forward. We need to go back to the revision of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. This is underlined and Russia must be a party to these talks. And also what is in our interest, and in the interests of the states and residents of the Black Sea basin, namely energy, maritime agriculture, security and, finally, the environment. And that's the call – we need a strategy for the Black Sea. Yes, we need it.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Mr President, one of the central themes of the Paşcu report is the illegal annexation of Crimea by Russia. This act has led to an increased militarisation of the Black Sea, including the increased presence of short- and medium-range nuclear weapons as part of Russia’s ambitious programme to upgrade the Black Sea fleet. It is vital that the Member States of the EU work together, both within our Union and NATO, to meet what is a very real and concerning military threat to our security. At this juncture, I take the opportunity to highlight the difficulties that those in the Crimea are now facing. There are soaring food prices and water shortages, and these are just part of the daily struggle that people are facing under Russian occupation. As feared, the Crimean tatars are being persecuted by the Russians, and ethnic Ukrainians are being expelled from the territory, with an increasing incidence of arrests, raids and police interrogations of their populations being reported. We have also seen incidents of violence against the Jewish population and their property. Indeed, in just the first week of the annexation, a synagogue was vandalised with swastikas. The West, and the European Union in particular, must stand united in condemning Putin’s revanchist doctrine of annexing territory by force.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Mr President, I too congratulate the rapporteur on the excellent report tabled today. The European Union's Black Sea security strategy needs to be redefined and strengthened. This is necessary as a result of the change in the strategic landscape in the area, so that we can talk about an increase in the capacity to respond to developments in the neighbourhood, which seriously affect European security. The illegal annexation of Crimea, the numerous conflicts frozen by Russia in the region, but especially the arming and strengthening of its military capabilities, both strategically and tactically, are likely to prompt a strong reaction from the European Union and the United States of America. The eastern borders of the European Union, including Romania and Poland, as well as the Baltic States, are under increasing pressure. I therefore appreciate that the sanctioning regime applied to the Russian Federation must be continued and strengthened. Member States must remain further united, in one voice, in Russia's hybrid war against Ukraine, and show solidarity and commitment in sanctioning actions that contravene the rules of international law. Energy security is used today by the Russian Federation as a real weapon, but we draw its attention that, however much Member States depend on this dimension, they will never accept the violation of the basic principles of security in Europe. I believe that we should consider, with all responsibility and seriousness, the possibility of providing Ukraine with defensive military means, but not only, so that we can talk about a real strengthening of its defence capacity, as a guarantee for the preservation of peace and security in the region, until it is too late. The US has shown its readiness for this, and high-land states can make an important contribution if they join efforts. Thus, Ukraine, the Republic of Moldova and Georgia must consider the possibility of more sustained cooperation, including in the military field. NATO and the European Union must also continue their efforts so that the Black Sea area remains an open and secure economic zone.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: – Mr President, what has been going on in the Black Sea basin is still the result of the disintegration of the Soviet Union and the traumatic effects it has had on the old Russian nation. The disintegration of the Soviet Union was not only the end of an ideological model, it was certainly, but also historically corresponded to a loss of power and influence from Russia. This, of course, has had traumatic consequences for the Russians and has led them to adopt a series of behaviours which are obviously unacceptable and which have been the subject of due condemnation by vast sectors of the international community, the United Nations, the European Union. And the sanctions policy that has been followed has been the most correct policy.  This does not, however, prevent us from considering that any security policy for the Black Sea must focus mainly on the diplomatic component and that we must never lose sight of the importance of ensuring a long-term relationship with Russia. Russia is our neighbour and we can never lose sight of what is also part of the satisfaction, the safeguarding of our fundamental geopolitical and geoeconomic interests, to safeguard the future relationship with Russia.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: – I rate the report, which is the subject of our discussion today, very highly. This is indeed europe's awakening of Russian imperialism, of Putin's imperialism, because it is not about the people of Russia, it is about this particular power. This awakening comes too late and is not as challenging as the threat posed by Russian imperialism. But it's good that this awakening has occurred. It can be the basis for good policy, consistent policy, continued economic sanctions against Russia, NATO presence in this part of the world, clear assistance to Ukraine and other Eastern Partnership countries. It must also mean that Europe is on its own two feet. European Union countries should be ready to spend 2% of their national product on defence policy in order to be an important part of global security.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Madam President, the illegal annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation and the military conflict in eastern Ukraine has of course completely changed the security balance in the Black Sea region. These two pose new security threats to the European Union and to our eastern neighbours. The European Union is now only some 100 kilometres away from the war in eastern Ukraine and less than 300 kilometres away from Crimea. This of course brings us to the point where we need to build a new comprehensive EU strategy for the Black Sea region which corresponds to the new challenges. The current approach of the European Union in the region is outdated. The fact is that we were able neither to prevent Russia’s invasion of Georgia in 2008, the war in Ukraine or the annexation of Crimea, nor to provide suitable responses, and we have also not been able to provide solutions to the frozen conflicts in the region. I expect the High Representative/Vice-President to come up with a comprehensive strategy addressing the new security challenges in the region in the near future. The fact is that Russia is increasing its military spending and is ready to pursue military actions which we, the European Union, are of course not ready to pursue. We are a project for freedom, and this is one of the fundamental achievements of 70 years of European integration. We should of course never jeopardise this fundamental achievement. Precisely because of this, we should act in a way which prevents escalation in the region and not only addresses it, which would mean an additional level of escalation. We should also take into account the military, reputational and financial risks which the Russian Federation is ready to take to keep the region insecure and, basically, to prevent the Black Sea region from becoming an area governed by the rule of law, a prosperous and a secure region. This is exactly where we step in. My last point is that these countries in the region should be free to make their own foreign policy decisions, to choose whether to engage with Russia or the European Union and how to do so. That should be their option. We are not pressuring them, and the Russian Federation should not pressure them either.

name: Boris ZALA
text: – The European Union has not underestimated the importance of the Black Sea. We see the conflict in Transnistria, South Ossetia, Abkhazia, Nagorno-Karabakh and, most recently, the largest around Crimea. The centre of destabilisation is in this region – somewhere in the Triangle Russia, Turkey, the Balkans. Fortunately, not in the Baltic region at the moment. I welcome my colleague Paşca's report on the grounds that it draws attention to this region as a whole for the first time, but what I particularly welcome is that its point of view is the first time that the European Union as a whole has taken a look. The European Union has not yet considered geopolitical dimensions. What the Commissioner also told us did not touch at all on the geopolitical strategy of the European Union as a whole. I think that this is how both the Commission and the High Representative should start to think, and so should all of us in terms of the strategy of the European Union as a whole.

name: Nikolay BAREKOV
text: – Madam President, the Republic of Bulgaria is the oldest sovereign state to have access to the Black Sea. Bulgarians have been associated with this region historically and economically, for centuries. It is in the interest of Bulgaria and the European Union that the Black Sea Basin be declared a free zone of military presence and military action, in which no provocations take place, is not the subject of speculation from countries in military conflict. I firmly believe that the European Union must act as guarantor of peace in the Black Sea, stimulate social and economic development in border areas and promote their convergence. Any military presence would have a detrimental effect on tourism, fisheries and shipping. I call on you to do what is possible to curb militarism at the expense of active diplomacy. The annexation of Crimea grossly violated international law, but the Nabucco project would be a serious and good response to Russian aggression. I call for an active dialogue without military arguments.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I believe that there is no one in this House who doubts that what is happening in the Black Sea basin is not of increasing importance for the security of the entire European Union. Until Russia annexed Crimea, there was a military balance in this basin. Today, unfortunately, this situation has deteriorated. The question then arises – what can we do? Well, I think two steps need to be taken. Firstly, the European Union should support the countries that lie in the Black Sea basin, always remembering that it has two members there – Bulgaria and Romania. There is also a second problem – I believe that, despite russia's current policy, contacts with this country cannot be broken. In order to avoid various tragic events, direct military communications should be maintained with Russia.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: – Russia is not only fuelling aggressive actions on Ukrainian territory. She is the aggressor – the aggressor who, thanks to deceitful war propaganda, told Europe that Russia's aggression in Crimea and eastern Ukraine was an action closer to unspecified separatists. It should be made clear: Putin's Russia is responsible for the aggression in Ukraine. I have seen the power of Russian propaganda personally, because it has been Putin who, for five years, through disinformation and deceitful propaganda, explains to the world the causes of the Smolensk disaster, in which the Polish elite, led by President Lech Kaczynski, was killed – one of the few leaders of European countries who in August 2008 was able to successfully oppose Putin's actions against Georgia. Anyone who uses the word separatists in the context of what happened in Crimea fits into Putin's deceitful propaganda about the war in Ukraine.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe has made its history on the seas, starting from the Mediterranean, Europeans have given birth to a civilisation that has been forged through confrontation with each other. The Black Sea is one of these scenarios in which we have built our relationship with Russia and the Near East. These seas must continue to be places of peace and not theatres of tragedies and conflicts. Russia's annexation of Crimea violates the UN Charter, giving Moscow a strategic base towards the Balkans and the eastern Mediterranean and making dialogue increasingly difficult. The initiatives taken by the Council towards the Kremlin are a good start, but more needs to be done. The European Union must be energy independent and move forward in the creation of a unified foreign and defence policy, not least because this helps to reduce the expenditure of individual Member States.  Only in this way can we be credible interlocutors, at a time when there is a need for a Europe capable of helping to overcome the unstable global situation that is in danger of deflagrating.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, honourable colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. Perhaps it is worth talking not only about negative things, but about possible and existing cooperation between the countries of the Black Sea.  If countries only spend money on armaments, then there might be a shortage of money to solve many other major problems. Spending money for military purposes is a charge that countries and their societies do not trust strangers.  A logical question and a conclusion emerges: in order to build trust and save money, dialogue must be launched and common objectives must be realised. What could they be? What could these projects be like? For example, the fight against illegal immigration, ecological projects, business and citizen cooperation. If we make an effort, time, money in this direction, then the return will be much higher than the race for who will produce and buy more military equipment or form a larger army. Weapons and armies will not increase security, trust and prosperity. On the contrary, it leads in the opposite direction. As the Russian writer Anton Chekhov said, if a gun hangs on the wall, it will surely shoot at some point. Thank you!

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like warmly to congratulate the rapporteur. The seizure of Crimea by Russia and the start of the war in eastern Ukraine by Russia set up a major geopolitical crisis in the Black Sea area. Crimea offers Russia a strong forward offensive point. It is a thorn in Ukraine’s side and a thorn for the European Union’s eastern border security and defence. Russia, as I mentioned, has tremendously increased – and is increasing – its offensive capability in the Black Sea area. As I also mentioned earlier, the Russian Black Sea fleet is already greater than the combined fleets of all the other Black Sea coastal states. Among those six riparian states, two are Member States of the European Union. Commissioner, I would like to tell you that I was disappointed by what you said and, at the same time, surprised that you talked only about the soft power of the European Union. We need real European Union common security and defence – real common security capabilities. Otherwise we are not going to play any role.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: – I congratulate my colleague, Mr Pașcu, on this very important report. The Black Sea Basin is one of the most important regions in the world. However, it is also of strategic importance to the European Union as an external border for security and defence and for the development of the Eastern Partnership. Following the annexation of Crimea, the change in the balance of forces and russia's illegal control of hundreds of kilometres of the Crimean coast makes the Black Sea basin a largely virtually paramilitary zone. Such changes in the geostrategic situation require an effective response from the European Union. In order to ensure the security and stability of the region, a wide range of measures are needed, including the modernisation and strengthening of the military capabilities of the Member States of the European Union in the Black Sea Basin. I fully agree with the rapporteur that these changes, as well as the increased pressure from Russia on the European Union's eastern border, as noted in the report, the use of disinformation as a weapon must be taken seriously and properly reflected in the European Security Strategy.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Black Sea basin is undoubtedly one of the most strategic regions for the European Union, both for security and defence issues and for the European Neighbourhood Policy.  In 2007, also following accession to the European Union by Bulgaria and Romania, the European Commission presented the Black Sea Synergy, a cooperation initiative for the region that aimed to give new impetus to cooperation processes with Russia, Turkey and other partners. However, the changing geostrategic landscape in the Black Sea basin and Russia's forced annexation of Crimea show that the Black Sea synergy is now obsolete. We are faced with broader and more complex systemic challenges, which require the rapid development of a comprehensive Eu ropean Union strategy. The Commission must therefore work towards greater cooperation on security and defence policy with the partner states bordering the Black Sea and priority must be given to initiatives for the diversification of energy resources in the Black Sea, as part of a strategy for energy independence from Russia.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the immediate proximity and enormous interdependence of the economies of the Member States of the European Union and Russia requires the resolution of disputes through peaceful dialogue, away from cold war logics that further deepen the contradictions between the two sides. Peaceful coexistence, mutual benefit, the resolution of disputes by diplomatic rather than military means, should be the european Union's axis of action in Crimea as well.  Otherwise, the cold war situation between the European Union and Russia will only have negative effects, as has already been the case with the enormous economic damage suffered by Greek farmers as a result of Russian countermeasures to European Union sanctions on Russia.  We are concerned, Madam President, about the fate of the Greek minority of one hundred and fifty thousand souls in Mariupol, which has lived peacefully for centuries in the wider region, in the Donetsk region.  Both sides must therefore exercise restraint, shape their relations with full respect for international law and move forward with understanding, because that is what the interests of the peoples of the European Union and Russia require.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam Chairman, dear Mr. Commissioner, only a few years ago we fantasizeed together with our friends living on the Black Sea that we could help them and that we could map one part of the cooperation we are achieving on the Adriatic and the Ionian Sea, and that this can in some way be a model for cooperation on the Black Sea.  Those are long gone times, it's really past its end time. Today we have on the scene, after environmental disasters on the Black Sea, one total militarization of the Black Sea, especially after the annexation of Crimea, which of course deserves every condemnation. In this context, I would like to call on the European Commission, together with its partners, and especially with Turkey, to think carefully about what strategy to jointly set for the Black Sea, because I think that turkey and, of course, the Member States of the European Union can play an important role in reining in what Russia's ambitions are on the Black Sea.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am surprised that There is no High Commissioner Mogherini on such an important issue.
