We are talking about military matters, we are talking about Russia, we are talking about the Black Sea and with all due respect to those who are in place of Mogherini, the holder is missing. And as if I as a lawyer have to go to an important case in a trial, and instead of going there I maybe send a colleague of mine who is certainly not the owner and therefore my client could theoretically get angry. I'm not a lawyer, I just gave one example. This is to say that, once again, Europe is proving incapable of dealing with the problems with the weapons, in quotation marks, that it has. This is the end result. So we need to talk to Mogherini, we need to talk to the Hungarian Commissioner, we need to talk to whom? I will end by saying that Once again Europe is lashing out at Russia when we have to get along with Russia. In fact, I say to you more: if it were for me, it would be nice if Putin were to invade Europe so we would all be better off.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, High Representative/Vice–President Mogherini at the moment is chairing the EU-Latin America summit. I think the summit has an enormous and strategic importance as well. As you know, the College is a college in which one Commissioner can replace another Commissioner. I think it has been a really fruitful and very helpful debate and exchange. It was very helpful for the EU in forming its policy towards the Black Sea Basin. Let me just make a general remark and then some detailed remarks on the issues you just raised during the debate. Generally, we can say that the illegal annexation of Crimea and Sebastopol by the Russian Federation created a threat, a very dangerous situation, which is a direct challenge to international security, with grave implications for the international legal order that protects the unity and sovereignty of all states. The EU will remain committed to fully implementing its non-recognition policy, including through restrictive measures. On the other hand, if and when a sustainable solution to the Ukraine conflict is found, we will obviously need to adjust and recalibrate our relationship with Russia. We should be ready to engage with that country. We cannot let dividing lines and lasting rifts split our continent. Some honourable Members just raised the issue of energy policy and complained about the lack of action at European level regarding the independence and diversification of resources under energy policy. Let me simply say that the European Commission and the Council have just adopted the communication on the Energy Union. Vice–President Šefčovič is travelling to Central Asia to have negotiations there in order to help diversification for central European and EU countries and the EU Member States generally. We are implementing the Third Energy Package, which aims to bring about independence and diversification in energy policy as well. Others raise the issue of human rights in Crimea. While obviously it is a difficult situation, and we have difficulties and independent NGOs have difficulties in gaining access to Crimea, we can say that High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini is supporting the Council of Europe’s efforts in making the situation more stable and more developed in human rights there. She is supporting Commissioner Muižnieks’s efforts in that area. We have condemned the violation of rights, notably (but not only) of Tatars in Crimea. Some of you raised the issue of the European Security Strategy. Yes, we need a review of the European Security Strategy. It is on its way and we are absolutely relying on your cooperation on that procedure. We look forward to working closely with you and the Member States on the review of the European Security Strategy.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would first like to say that the report is based on facts and realities. Some of it comes directly from Russian open sources, so there is no point in denying it. A second observation I would like to make is that there are no ample references, due to the title and the subject of the report, either to the legal aspects – which have been touched upon by some of my colleagues – or to the human rights situation, as has also been mentioned here. All I would like to say here is that there were no human rights problems before, when Crimea belonged to Ukraine; but now there are, after Crimea was annexed illegally by Russia, with the Tatars. So I think we should bear that in mind. Some of our colleagues have mentioned that the NATO enlargement, which was disrespecting a pledge made to Mr Gorbachev – it was mentioned that he said so – was the cause of what has happened with respect to Ukraine. I would say that even the vision of Mr Gorbachev that there was a pledge that NATO should not enlarge is ignoring the sovereign will of the countries, because we wanted to get into NATO. Probably he meant to say that NATO should not have accepted our decisions, but that is exactly what the Warsaw Pact used to be like. I participated in one of the last meetings of the Warsaw Pact and I participated in NATO, so I know the difference between them. Anyone coming into the Chamber – probably visitors up there – and listening to our debate would believe that we have seen two different movies. We saw a movie in which Russia is occupying foreign territory through force and transforming it into a stronghold. Others have seen a poor, defenceless, peace-loving Russia defending itself against conquest by NATO and the EU. That is not acceptable. Russia has only two sticks – not a carrot and a stick – one bigger stick and one smaller stick – and the favour done by Russia means being beaten with the smaller stick.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday, 11 June 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. Crimea, donated to USSR by Khrushchev in 1954, was a multi-ethnic scene with a good presence of Russians, Tatars, Ukrainians and other nationalities. Unfortunately, this place has now become the site of a show of military power, one of Russia's main military bases. Tatars driven out of Crimea reported that the new power would limit ethnic and national minorities. It is sad that this beautiful landscape, which also holds traces of Persian, Greek, Roman and Turkish cultures, which was not so long ago one of the most visited tourist areas in Ukraine, has become a military base and a dumping point for heavy bombers capable of carrying nuclear weapons.  As Russia has stepped up its military presence in the Black Sea basin, in Crimea, abkhazia, part of Georgia, and South Ossetia, in the occupied regions of the Transnistria, part of Moldova, increased its air and sea defence forces, developing new naval defence missiles and ensuring that Russian fighter jets control three quarters of the airspace of the Black Sea Basin, the European Union must pay attention to this, as its external borders are thus under increased threat. It is important for Russia to implement the Minsk ceasefire agreements, but contrary to point 16 of the report, I believe that the conflict can only be settled peacefully through negotiations. The EU must develop a unified strategy for managing conflicts in the Black Sea basin, taking into account the interests and security of civilians.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – On 18 March 2014, the Russian Federation cynically, through a detailed planned operation involving the military and special services, unlawfully annexed Crimea. Thus, a permanent member of the UNSC violated the principles of territorial integrity, non-interference in the internal affairs of another state and the prohibition of the use of military force against another state. The Kremlin has broken the Budapest Memorandum, an important pillar of its nuclear non-proliferation policy. Russia is perversely trying to use the international principle of the right of nations to self-establish. None of the recognised objective criteria (ethnicity, human rights violations, the best solution to the conflict) have been met. Prior to the annexation, Crimea was not ethnically homogeneous and the Russian minority did not report human rights violations by Ukraine. After the annexation through ethnic cleansing, aimed mainly at the indigenous people of Crimean Tatars and Ukrainians, Russia seeks to make Crimea an ethnically homogeneous militarized zone along the lines of an "unsmelting aircraft carrier", as the Königslish or Dormice Region is often referred to.  Russia has a long tradition of seizing territories in this way – until a century and a half ago, the north-east coast of the Black Sea was inhabited by Caucasian nations. We must not allow the 1944 ethnic cleansing in Crimea to be repeated. We must also oppose the 'creeping' annexation of Abkhazia and South Ossetia. Russia cannot move borders on the map to its liking. Crimea remains an occupied territory from the point of view of international law. He must return to Ukraine. Too rarely do we talk about it.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: in writing. – I would like to congratulate the rapporteur for addressing this most timely international issue. The Black Sea Basin, and notably the situation there, requires our utmost attention: not only due to its strategic importance, in both political and military terms, but in regard to our joint and united approach to Russia’s behaviour in its neighbourhood and on the international scene. With its military manoeuvres, illegal annexations and violations of territorial integrity, the Black Sea Basin is becoming a region where our democratic values are increasingly contested. Also, it is a region where unsettled conflicts and redrawing of borders have taken place. This is completely unacceptable, and must be strongly condemned. We need to speak with one strong voice against such developments, and together with our NATO allies and Easters Partnership countries demonstrate a clear opposition to such behaviour on our Eastern borders.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. – Mr President, I welcome Vice-President Paşcu's report and agree with him that it is very important that the EU continues to communicate consistently with Russia. The violent annexation of Crimea cannot be accepted by the EU. Neither is what is going on in eastern Ukraine today with Russian help. The situation has not only improved in recent months, but only worsened. I urge the EU to act unitedly and decisively to stabilise the situation. This is in our own well-understood interest, because the Black Sea is a strategically key area for us, and we have to face the reality that the balance has been broken, Russia has strengthened its position militarily. This, in turn, has implications for the whole region and requires an even more thoughtful EU eastern policy. Ukraine needs to make serious reforms in order to move towards EU membership. Against this background, the Ukrainians will also judge the EU.  At the same time, if we are truly committed to supporting Ukraine's EU accession process, it is necessary that EU assistance and support be seen by Ukrainian citizens in their own skin as soon as possible.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – The EU must be a source of stability in the Black Sea region. Defending the principles of democracy, independence and sovereignty of the states of the region is paramount to any long-term regional strategy. European solidarity in support of the reform and democratisation objectives of Moldova, Georgia and Ukraine are an integral part of the security strategy that the European Union is promoting in the Black Sea basin to restore stability and prosperity in the region. The illegal annexation of Crimea has produced an unstable and violent climate in eastern Ukraine. Separatists are within the sphere of influence of the Russian Federation and this must be firmly condemned by the entire international community. To this challenge, in my opinion, the EU must respond firmly and wisely by taking the necessary measures to restore peace in the region and to hijack any other attempts at destabilisation in the area. In order to bring the Black Sea region back to prosperity and stability, we need, above all, actions that guarantee the safety of the people and respect for human rights in Eastern Ukraine. Life remains the most important resource we have a duty to protect. The European Union, together with its international partners, through unity around this principle, can overcome the current crisis and restore regional security.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Burundi (2015/2723(RSP)).

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, as you know, there have been a number of emergency debates and resolutions on Burundi in recent months. However, I believe that recent serious events in the country fully justify our addressing this issue once again this afternoon. As Commissioner Mimica said when he addressed this House in April, it is important for Burundians to know that they have champions in the outside world supporting their ambitions to achieve long-term democracy and resilience. That can only be done with consistent and continuous attention to the needs and aspirations of citizens, not least their human rights and fundamental freedoms. Since the last debate in this House there have been a number of developments which unfortunately give rise to considerable concern on the part of the EU. You already know that the decision of the ruling party to nominate President Nkurunziza as a presidential candidate promoted a serious division across society and across politics. The situation deteriorated rapidly with the attempted coup on 13 May. The EU condemned the attempted coup. Indeed, we deplore any act of political violence. This is unequivocally not the way to encourage the openness and transparency which Burundi needs to navigate this crisis in a spirit of consensus and reconciliation. The international community, including the European Union, has obviously been faced with a very challenging situation. As High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini said in her statement following the events of 13 May, our first thoughts must be with the citizens of the country. Their security and safety is paramount, and it is essential the situation does not spin out of control. These concerns also encompass the regional aspect. From a humanitarian point of view, since the political crisis erupted in Burundi, the wave of refugees fleeing Burundi has been ongoing and increasing in intensity over recent weeks. As of today, almost 100 000 people have sought refuge in neighbouring countries: Tanzania, Rwanda, the Democratic Republic of Congo and Uganda. The Commission’s Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection Department is closely monitoring the situation and has already released EUR 1.5 million to meet the immediate needs of Burundian refugees arriving in Rwanda last month. Additional humanitarian aid is being considered to cater for the specific needs of refugees hosted in Tanzania, including health assistance to stop the possible surge of diseases and epidemics, notably cholera. I would like to turn now to the political situation and to our reaction. The EU has been supporting Burundi in its efforts to entrench democracy since the Arusha Agreements put an end to years of civil war and laid the foundations for a new era. This year’s legislative and presidential elections were to be a key step in cementing the long-term democratic development of Burundi. That is why High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini decided to deploy an EU Election Observation Mission, led by the chief observer David Martin MEP. At this point I would like to pay tribute to the dedication and commitment shown by Mr Martin and his team during these difficult weeks. Overall, we remain convinced that respect for the Arusha Peace Agreement is key for the further stability of Burundi. This is the overarching principle we all need to follow. We cannot ignore the fact that the third-term issue is at the origin and the centre of the crisis, and we continue to urge all, including the President, to put the higher interests of the country first. In order to preserve the best chances for the election to succeed, there is a need for a broad consensus on the issue. The idea of the electoral observation mission and of our financial support to the elections was to contribute to an inclusive, transparent, peaceful, credible and fair process that will give confidence to the political actors and electorate and would ensure acceptance of the outcome. This remains our objective, but, to reach that objective, some minimal conditions needed to be met. Unfortunately, our assessment was that these conditions were not in place. In particular, we noted continuing restrictions on independent media and freedom of expression and assembly, excessive use of force against demonstrators, a climate of intimidation for opposition parties and civil society, and a lack of confidence in the election authorities. Developments in the last few days have done nothing to ease our concerns. For this reason we suspended the Electoral Observation Mission and, indeed, our financial support for the elections. We are not alone in questioning the credibility of the elections. Last week, the Catholic Church decided to withdraw from the process and two members of the Election Commission resigned. The African Union (AU) and the East African Community (EAC) are also refraining from sending an electoral observation mission at the moment. But this is not the end of the story. If domestic stakeholders agree on acceptable conditions for holding the elections, then we are ready to redeploy the actual observation mission and support the process. This means we now need to concentrate on getting those conditions in place. All parties should engage in good faith in a dialogue to restore the necessary conditions for democratic elections and, primarily, the government of Burundi should reach out to all domestic stakeholders by restoring confidence through concrete measures. The EU supports all efforts to achieve a peaceful solution to the political crisis in Burundi and especially the work of the East African Community, the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region, and the African Union. As you are aware, the East African Community convened an emergency summit in Dar Es Salam on 31 May. I would like to take up some of the conclusions of that summit, because they are important to our approach in the weeks ahead. We join the East African Community in praising the work of UN Special Envoy, Said Djinnit. In difficult circumstances Mr Djinnit has been facilitating a political dialogue, which is the only way forward. He has our full confidence and it is important that all forces support his efforts. On 5 June the spokesperson of High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini issued a statement calling on all parties in the dialogue to work with Mr Djinnit and with the envoys of the African Union and the East African Community in order to find a consensus on the road ahead. This is the message we are giving out locally, as well as internationally. We have supported the East African Community’s call for a postponement of the elections and we take note that earlier today a presidential decree was signed fixing a new calendar for the elections. But this timetable will not be relevant unless it is accompanied by urgent and serious efforts to build consensus and to take all the steps needed to make the elections credible. It is therefore vital now that the East African Community’s conclusions should be followed up with concrete action. This includes a cessation of violence by all parties and the disarming of youth militias. Conditions proposed by the EAC to ensure safety and respect for fundamental freedoms need to be followed up. It is first and foremost for the government to ensure these conditions are met, and to stop the violence. Obviously the EU will need to review its options in the longer term, but I want to stress the delicacy of the current moment. Delivering successful elections will not be an easy task. All Burundi’s partners need to support African efforts, led by the EAC and the AU, and focus their efforts on calming the political climate. We do this while reminding Burundi and Burundians of the principles which matter to us and to our partnership. The Cotonou Agreement is absolutely clear on the need to respect human rights, democratic principles and the rule of law as essential elements. We must keep this in mind but, at the same time, we need to leave space for Burundians with their regional and African partners to find viable solutions to be current crisis. I want to end by reiterating an important point made by Commissioner Mimica last month. In the current climate, the Commission has to plan for all possible scenarios and, of course, to consider the adoption of possible additional measures, including those related to EU development cooperation with Burundi. But in all these considerations, we need to give attention to the impact which different measures could have on the extremely poor population and thereby the stability of an already fragile country. I look forward very much to hearing the views of the honourable Members. Thank you for your attention.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has It is right and important that, here in the European Parliament, we look at Burundi once again this year. After years of civil war in that country, which has killed 300,000 people, Burundi took a tentative path towards stabilisation and democratization in 2005. With the elections to Parliament and a new President this year, the country, which is still one of the poorest in the world, should take a major step towards greater democracy, the rule of law and greater security for its citizens. The EU was prepared, as the Commissioner said, to support this process and has already allocated EUR 6 million to conduct the elections. An EU and European Parliament election observation mission was ready to accompany the conduct of the elections. The announcement by current President Nkurunziza that he will run for a third term in defiance of Burundi's constitution appears to jeopardise all efforts to hold free and fair elections in Burundi. Civil society demonstrations in the capital Bujumbura are being violently suppressed, more than twenty people have already died, and more than 100 000 Burundian citizens, many of them children, have fled and left the country. And the youth organization of the president's party, Imbonerakure , terrorizes all people suspected of being in opposition to the ruling party. A military coup has already failed, and the compromise between the Hutu and Tutsi ethnic groups found in the Arusha Treaty threatens to be dissolved. Influential institutions, such as the Catholic Church, have withdrawn from the preparation of the electoral process. The summit of the East African Community, also mentioned by the Commissioner, has recommended a postponement of the elections. However, this summit did not take a position on Nkurunziza's desire to run for a third term, which can, of course, now also pose a threat to the whole region, because next year there will be elections in the Democratic Republic of Congo, in Rwanda in 2017. And there, too, presidents could run unconstitutionally for a third term. At the same time, many refugees from Burundi are now becoming a burden on neighbouring Congo, Rwanda and Tanzania. As the European Union, we should act in cooperation with the United Nations and the African Union states and do everything we can to ensure that free elections can be held in Burundi this year. There are possibilities for influence. We could stop the financial contributions to the Government of Burundi so far; we should, however, help the refugees in the refugee camps. And we should maintain our will to support a democratic electoral process in Burundi. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Mr Zeller, I was wondering, listening to that speech, whether you think that EU taxpayers, just recovering from what was probably one of the deepest recessions for many generations, would be universally happy and delighted to hear that we are spending their money and time in places like Burundi when they are still going through some hardship themselves? Do you think that would be greeted with universal joy by the taxpayers of Europe?

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. As you know, it is a noble task of the countries of Europe to help the developing countries – including Burundi – if they want to go down the road to democracy. That was also the intention of development aid. That is why I asked that, until the situation there had been resolved, we should stop everything that has been made so far in terms of payments. Some of the Member States, such as Belgium and the Netherlands, have already done so.

name: David MARTIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, firstly let me say that I welcome the fact that the Commission and the External Action Service have announced EUR 1.5 million to assist the refugees. It is clear that the instability in Burundi is not the fault of its neighbours, and its neighbours should not pay the price of that instability. So any assistance we can give is very welcome. Can I also thank the Commissioner for his kind comments on my role as the Chief Observer and reciprocate by saying that, while in Burundi, I was very impressed by the level of engagement of both the External Action Service and the Commission in trying to find constructive solutions to the very serious problems that Burundi faces. While I was there, Article 8 discussions took place and Article 96 actions were seriously considered, so I welcome the fact that we are fully engaged in the country. As the Commissioner has said, the immediate cause of the unrest in Burundi is the decision of President Nkurunziza to try to seek a third term, and that is clearly – no matter what he has forced his own constitutional court to say – in breach of the Arusha Agreement. And the consequence of his attempt to achieve a third term has been violence on the streets – not by the demonstrators, but by government-backed militias, the Imbonerakure – who have tried to put down these peaceful demonstrations and forced demonstrators off the streets. The first thing that needs to happen in Burundi is that the official security services need to rein in this unofficial militia. The second thing, if we are going to have real elections in Burundi, is there has to be space for the opposition to campaign, and in the short 5-day period I spent there, it was clear to me that government-backed parties were able to hold rallies and encourage supporters, while any attempt by the opposition to get public space was ruthlessly put down. A third thing that needs to happen – and the Commissioner mentioned this – is we need to make sure that the media is reopened. I have to say, I saw a level of cynicism I have rarely seen anywhere when, on the one hand, firstly they banned the radio stations and refused them permission to broadcast, then in the attempted coup, the radio stations were blown up and it was impossible for them to broadcast, and then the government said ‘now you are free to broadcast’ – having destroyed the facilities needed to actually carry out any broadcasting. So the conditions for credible elections do not look good; they need to be restored. I understand today Burundi has announced that the elections will now take place on 29 June and 15 July. If they do restore conditions for credible elections I would recommend we go back to Burundi, but at the present time it is not possible for the European Union to observe these elections.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, Commissioner, we must not, of course, continue to turn a blind eye to the unrest, chaos and massacres in Burundi.  Independent radio and television stations were destroyed by the police to silence the political opposition. Journalists have gone into hiding, others have fled the country, opposition leaders are in exile and no light has been shed on the murder of Zedi Feruzi, leader of the opposition party, who was shot dead by gunmen on 23 May 2015. Moreover, in order to legitimize repression, the authorities said that the demonstrations were now equated with an insurrection against the legal order. Finally, what seems even more serious to me, we are awakening the ethnic fibre, knowing that 21 years ago, this phenomenon had caused real tragedies and a real catastrophe. Secondly, I had the opportunity to participate in the Arusha Agreements in 2001, on behalf of the Presidency of the European Union, and I can say that Mr Nkurunziza's decision to take part in these presidential elections is clearly totally contrary to the Arusha agreements. So in my opinion, he's disqualified. What should the Commission do? I believe that we really have the opportunity to be effective and that the European Union must strongly announce that the government that would be the result of elections held under such illegal conditions would not be recognised by our institutions. We must demand an immediate end to the indiscriminate repression of opponents, the immediate opening of the media space, the return to the country of opposition leaders in exile, the unconditional release of all political prisoners and an immediate end to harassment against civil society. There is also a need to threaten to close bank accounts held abroad by those responsible for cracking down on protesters, and to explicitly raise the threat of international legal action. Mr. Nkurunziza is disqualified, he can no longer be president. You have to say it. You have the real ability to say that and to have an influence on the issue.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, since our last debate, after President Nkurunziza's announcement that he intends to run for a third term, the violence has continued to escalate: several dozen deaths are to be deplored and more than 90,000 Burundians have fled the country, with journalists and opposition leaders being the first victims. Zedi Feruzi, leader of a small opposition party, was murdered on 23 May.  Today, the main opposition leaders are either abroad or in hiding. The elections were postponed in extremis at the beginning of June. The electoral commission has published a new timetable that will not solve anything. This commission is totally disqualified since two of its members are on the run and it has to make its decisions by a majority of four-fifths. The opposition immediately rejected the new timetable and laid down several conditions for the upcoming elections, including the establishment of a new electoral commission and the disarmament of pro-government militias, including imbonerakure. The Burundian authorities are hiding behind institutional shams, claiming that, for constitutional reasons, elections can no longer be postponed.  Has the international community mobilized sufficiently? Of course, the EAC has called for the elections to be postponed. Does the European Union's electoral mission still make sense? Can it still declare itself ready to deploy if the necessary conditions for peaceful, inclusive and credible elections are met? In view of this violence and this timetable, it is impossible.  The UN special envoy is increasingly in dispute and the Burundian authorities remain deaf. Arusha's fragile balance is more threatened than ever and the country is in danger of falling into civil war again. The rise of tensions is indeed accompanied by disturbing ethnicist discourse. The protest movement is presented as a Tutsi cabal, that is to say.  While the country is 50% dependent on international aid, shouldn't the European Union also use financial pressures? Shouldn't the EU's funds - more than 400 million - be redirected to civil society, as the Belgian government has just done? There is an urgent need for concrete action to prevent another massacre.

name: Maria HEUBUCH
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The situation in Burundi is very serious, a great deal has already been said about the situation. It is, once again, the result of an autocrat's rigid adherence to power. The election has now been postponed due to pressure from the regional organisations EAC. This is a success for the EAC. But it does not solve the fundamental problem of the president's bid for a third term. And this adherence to this third term also threatens the peace process in Burundi. After all, under the Arusha Agreement, only one re-election is possible. The question now remains: what can the international community do here? It must monitor more closely the Burundian media, especially the International Criminal Court. And it must pay particular attention to the media, which, as in Rwanda in 1994, is fuelling this ethnic problem, this hatred of peoples, which also exists in Burundi between Tutsi and Hutu. This ethnic tension must not be further fuelled by the media. The International Court of Justice should also launch an investigation into the serious human rights violations in Burundi, especially on the part of the government militias. Simple condemnation by the international community does not help here. Commissioner, you mentioned Cotonou. Through Cotonou, we would now have the opportunity to suspend development aid, as Mr Zeller said. What is your position on this? Does the Commission intend to convert budget aid into direct humanitarian aid, for example? As you have said, we need money for the refugees here, we need money for the fight against cholera. The money could be taken from budget support in order to put pressure on the government in Burundi. If we put extra money in, I hardly believe that this will put pressure on the Burundian Government. What are you going to do beyond election observation, to ensure dialogue between the government, the opposition and civil society (the President is taking the floor out of the speaker's speech.)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, fight for democracy or surrender in the face of yet another dictatorial drift in black Africa. This is the dilemma of the people of Burundi, silenced on radio and television, courageously present in the squares as they launch their cry of protest against an authoritarian man, Pierre Nkurunziza, blinded from the seat of power to the point of breaking constitutional legality, demanding a third presidential term, forcing him with an attempted coup d'état, which is against the law, against the logic of , against common sense and above all against the good of its people. Of course, at least we can say that the police and the army are reacting in an acceptable way, that the more balanced composition between the Tutsis and the Hutu is nullifying Nkurunziza's attempts to foment an ethnic conflict, recalling the spectres of genocide. The Arusha agreements, at least in this one they are holding, but at the collapse of the country tested by galloping inflation, with no more cash in the cash for the attacks and with more than 100,000 refugees and with an army very soon, without pay, it is a collapse that is just around the corner. The report of our mission tells us that in truth no credible dialogue is standing between the current government and the opposition: too weak and fragmented. In Dar es Salaam, African and Eastern leaders have been too ambiguous and hesy, and the real defenders of democracy are only civil society activists. Nkurunziza's arrogant claim is based precisely on this timidity, on this pavidity, them and ours.  Because if Nkurunziza knew that we are all cohesive about not recognizing him in Europe, America and Africa, maybe he would side with it. If there were strict and inflexible conditionality, then credible and democratic elections would be allowed. Sometimes taking time also means wasting time and we don't have this time. We send a coherent message, without ifs and buts. We lack our bricks for peace with consistency and put our faces on it. If you need someone to volunteer for that mission, I'il go. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: David MARTIN
text: blue-card question. – I agree with much of what you said. I just want to make a point. When I was in Burundi the only people trying to turn this into an ethnic conflict were the Government. This is a political dispute. This is about political power, and we should not play their game of turning this into an ethnic conflict. I wonder if you would agree with that?

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Answer to a blue card question. Mr President, thank you for your question. I fully agree with you. In fact, what I said earlier is that the Arusha agreements have worked quite rightly in this respect. It is the government, it is Nkurunziza, which is trying to re-use the ethnic conflict to hide its seat of power, and so we must do everything in our power to keep the bar straight and prevent this game of the President from taking hold and being able to find consensus and, above all, to nail him once and for all to his responsibilities. Thank you.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President – a procedural point under Article 191. Earlier today, my colleague Steven Woolfe stood up to request the closure of the sitting for the rest of the plenary in protest at the disgraceful way in which things were done to close down debate here. We do believe that something should be done, but we would now like to propose a compromise motion on behalf of the EFDD group. We would like to propose that the sitting now be suspended for the rest of the day, simply to give us time to reflect on the undemocratic way that things have been done.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Thank you for my fellow Member's comment. Today, the meeting has already been suspended once, so we cannot do so now, but we have taken your request and will forward this suggestion. I'm going to give congressman Bay the floor from the independents in a minute.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: Madam President, since 1972, the civil war has been raging in Burundi, with too few periods of peace. As in neighbouring Rwanda, the Hutu majority and the Tutsi minority are speaking out on massacres, reminding us that multi-ethnic societies are often multi-conflict societies. The ethnic and political subdivisions of these two camps, which are far from homogeneous, do not help.  However, the situation had calmed down in recent years, thanks in part to the efforts of former President Pierre Buyoya, a Tutsi who had made peace with the Hutus through the Arusha Agreements. Alas, in running for a third presidential term, Pierre Nkurunziza revived old oppositions, unlike the wise Buyoya, who had given up his place. Mr. Nkurunziza seems to want to cling to power, while the Constitution forbids him to run a third time. The fire that smoulders under the ashes is likely to start again, but in addition to the fact that I challenge the European Union's right of interference which it abuses at the expense of the Member States - the Hungarians know something about it - I wonder above all about the ability of the European institutions to act effectively in resolving such complex and distant conflicts.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I see that you would like to make a further orderly comment, obviously I would like to say now that there is an opportunity to interrupt the meeting. I would like to inform you that, according to the article referred to, you are not in a possibility to do so. Is there anything you'd like to add? We are both reading the same article, obviously it would be possible for 40 Members to stand up and ask for the sitting to be postponed, which I doubt you have, or before the debate. Here, Congressman.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, the rule states that: ‘The sitting may be suspended or closed during a debate or a vote if Parliament so decides on a proposal from the President or at the request of a political group or at least 40 Members. Such a proposal or request shall be put to the vote immediately.’ That was done at 12 o’clock today. It is not being done now. Please do it now.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Thank you, Congressman, for your new suggestion. Again, we're reading the same article. I would like to see 40 Members support this idea.  Obviously, you see the same thing that I see that there are not 40 Members. The President does not ask for a political ... (the President y'all y'all the members who interrupted him) ... or on behalf of a political group. Which group would you like to ask on behalf of? And who would you like to ask on behalf of the group? Order me to come forward.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, I said that in my original speech. I made the request on behalf of the EFDD. I am repeating myself now. You are required to put this to the vote immediately, Madam President. You are now playing for time.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: (the President urges Members to calm down and asks for their patience) Who wants to speak out against him?

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: – Madam President, this is disrespectful to this House. If these colleagues are not interested in the situation in Burundi, all they have to do is leave the Chamber. Here we are talking about a very serious situation and they have no capacity to change the agenda. We care about Burundi and what people in burundi are suffering from. And if you're not interested, get them up and leave.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: My question was, would anyone wish to object to the interruption of the meeting or not? Does anyone wish to speak for him? You still have time for a democratic debate, don't you? I won't say a word. I'm going to give the floor to someone who wants to speak for him, another Member. The vote will be made, my dear Congressman, when I open the possibility of voting. When I open it, we'll vote on it. Is there anyone who wants to speak out against him? Would you like to speak for him? Be patient. You are much more patient than you have been, because the Member is right that you do not respect this House, even though I ask you to do so. Congressman, don't yell. Make yourself safe and behave as the integrity of this House requires. Thank you, Congressman, for speaking so loudly that, of course, I can hear you without a microphone.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, are these honourable Members running the show now? Are they giving me the floor? I say this to them: I can understand that you need to utilise every opportunity to draw attention to yourself. You are telling Madam President that she is a disgrace. I must say that I had expected a lot from this group, but the way you are performing here today is really a disgrace. If you look at it, you are like small kids utilising the opportunity when there is a debate. We have got a Commissioner here. We have got a serious debate on a serious issue. You are an absolute disgrace in terms of disrespect to the situation. I have not finished yet, sir. Your absolute disrespect for the situation in Burundi, a situation which is absolutely grave, with people being killed, a situation that is dramatic. You do not even allow the debate on the issue to be finished. Are you serious about that? You do not have a single bit of respect for the situation to finish the debate, to have some kind of conclusion and to be able to vote. Are you not ashamed? Let this debate finish at least, you kids. You are not silent because you admitted that this is disgraceful from your side. You do not have ten minutes for what is happening today in Burundi. It is an absolute disgrace, and if you want to reflect on undemocratic behaviour, then please leave and reflect – and take your time. That would be the best message.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Thank you, Congressman, for your comment. My fellow Members are so loud that I have not heard this, but if you have heard it, of course we should note this. I'm going to give the floor to Congresswoman, and then I'm going to make a decision.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, these are the way in which the European Parliament operates, not the way in which we have chosen them. This morning, too, a debate was postponed which was absolutely important for the lives of some 800 million European and US citizens.  We adapt to the rules that you are carrying out. The rule says you speak a person against a pro person. It seems to me that this has been done, so I would now ask the President to open up for the vote.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Fellow Members, I would like to inform you that a vote will take place. Of course, not now, I will suspend the sitting for half an hour and then we will proceed by vote.  (The debate will be suspended at 17.45 and resumed at 18.15)

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Mr Telička, you have the floor for a point of order.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, I do not mind if people shout at me to shut up, as was the case of one of the honourable UKIP gentlemen who was giving us a lesson on parliamentary democracy. If another gentleman calls me a fascist I think that is well beyond. I am sorry to say I do not know all the gentlemen by name, but I would expect an apology because myself and you and others are considered to be fascists.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Madam President, I am sorry for the offence you have received, I could say that we have received the same offence over and over again, we have been called fascists. I don't know if this isn't an offense either. On a point of order. Madam President, Rule 191 states that, in the event of a suspension of the sitting, at the request of a political group, the vote must be taken immediately and therefore not after a 30-minute suspension, but it does not matter, because our aim was not to suspend the sitting, let alone the one on such an important subject as Burundi, of which we are absolutely convinced of the great importance of burundi. , so much so that there were 5 or at most 6 people present to discuss it, but I am pleased that for something as important as to enforce the Rules of Procedure, only when you wish, you have all arrived. Congratulations!

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Thank you, Congresswoman. I would like to inform my Fellow Members that this was indeed the case, article 191 ... (the President's communication is interrupted) Would the Congresswoman have any further clumsy comments?

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Madam President, excuse me, but I do not intend, like my colleagues, to pass on the serious offence we have received of being called fascists. This insult by a fellow Member cannot be tolerated, this is a serious violation of the Rules of Procedure, of Rule 11, because it is a serious violation of freedom of expression. No one in here can afford to call fascists, especially people who have had grandparents in concentration camps or partisans. No one should be allowed.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Thank you for your comment. I'm going to need a little patience. I think that this is indeed an important issue, I ask my fellow Members to be patient with each other, let us listen to the other, but allow me also to tell what happened in this Chamber to my fellow Members who are interested in the subject: article 191 ... (the President's communication is interrupted) Congressman, do you have a clumsy comment? Give me a call.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: – Madam President, I am going to ask you a very specific question and it is a matter of order for me which is very important, although the subject of the session changes a little bit.  I see Mrs. Aiuto is here in the session with her baby. To me, Mr. Schulz prevented me from entering with my eight-month-old girl. Can you tell why? Because I'm a man, can't I come in with my baby? I'd like to know.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Madam President, (murmurs of dissent) you do not want the vote to happen? Can you hear me Madam President? My microphone does not seem to be working. I am not sure whether it is. Can you hear me? Okay. (Heckling) Do you wish to hear what I want to say or not? Madam President, I can stand here until I know that you can hear me, because you have asked me a question and I want to reply. As you requested, under Rule 191, you are quite right. We made that request in this Chamber when it was empty. I hope everybody enjoyed their drinks, rushing down to get here with the emails and twitters that you had. As part of that rule, a rule that is set down to … (heckling) (to a heckler) Sir, do you wish to speak for me? I am quite happy to stop speaking whilst being interrupted by you. (The President cut off the hecklers) Madam President, we expressed the rule to you absolutely clearly and, for the sake of clarity for the Members in this Chamber, it did actually say that under the rule ‘a sitting may be suspended or closed during a debate’ – we were during a debate – ‘if Parliament so decides on a proposal from the President or a request from a political group’ – we made a request from the political group – ‘such a proposal or request shall be put to the vote immediately.’ We asked for the vote to be put immediately. The vote was suspended for 30 minutes. As a consequence of that our group, as a whole now, are going away to consider for the next couple of hours whether we feel that we should come back and present this motion once again to you. We are considering the legal implications of it. We are going to regard whether there has been a breach of these rules. So I am just letting you know that we may be back sometime later, around nine o'clock. Madam President, we are taking legal advice. We will do so under the rules that this House has set down for this Chamber. At this moment we will withdraw it until we consider the process at nine o'clock tonight. (some applause)

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Go on, Congressman. Before there was a misunderstanding, of course, I suspended the sitting because there was much more chaos in the chamber than there is now, and I exercised this possibility under Article 22 of the procedure. That is why we are going to vote. Those who vote in favour of continuing the debate will vote 'yes' and those who vote in favour of the interruption will vote 'no'. The vote is open. (Parliament rejects the application by electronic vote (29 in favour, 390 against, 17 abstentions))

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: We will now continue to debate the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Burundi.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: – Madam President, the first thing I want to say... Madam President, you must protect the Members of us who are on the floor.  You have not explained the attitude that this group has had, which has tried to block a debate on Burundi without explaining why. Why did they want to suspend a debate about Burundi, when people in Burundi are dying for democracy? They're a disgrace to this House. (Applause) Madam President, we want democratic elections to be held in Burundi, but there have been no conditions for that to happen: it has not been possible. Elections in Burundi are very important for Burundi, but they are also important for the region, for the entire region.  From here I would like to congratulate the work of our representation in Burundi, our Ambassador, the High Representative, our technical observers and also our colleague David Martin, who have been able to assess the real situation in the country: a situation of harassment of the opposition, of absolute blockade of the free media; an impossible situation in which more than forty people have already died and, at the moment, there are one hundred thousand refugees who have gone to neighbouring countries, for fear of repression.  The president is responsible for all this. The President, who has clearly violated the Arusha Agreements; the President, who has decided that his own political career is more important than the life and freedom of his citizens.  The Constitution is down, and the Arusha Agreements are down.  The European Union has to be firm. If we agreed that the President could not be re-introduced, the President cannot re-introduce himself. And it is therefore unacceptable that we continue with this escalation, which we have not managed to stop eer the European Union, the African Union, or the United Nations. We are failing because the Burundians are dying—even though that makes the EFDD Group's colleagues quite laugh, that is what is happening.  We need to act quickly and we need to concentrate our financial assistance on sustaining civil society, all those who are fighting justly to ensure that the Arusha Agreements are respected: European Union money must go to sustain that civil society. And we also need to activate restrictive measures, interrupt visas, intervene on the current accounts of the Burundiese elite that is blocking democratic development. But this afternoon I have to regret that, if the Burundians have seen this session, we are ashamed of the image that the European Union has given this afternoon with regard to Burundi: people playing with the Rules of Procedure to block a debate like this; people who don't believe in the European Union; people who don't believe in democracy; people who have been laughing, screaming to block out a decent debate, which is what this House has to have. I thank you, Madam President, for the patience you have had and I hope that in Burundi today you will know that, in addition to some groups that have come to break the union, there are many others who are here to defend the values of the European Union, which also contemplate solidarity with the countries suffering. (Applause) Madam President, we want democratic elections to be held in Burundi, but there have been no conditions for that to happen: it has not been possible. Elections in Burundi are very important for Burundi, but they are also important for the region, for the entire region.  From here I would like to congratulate the work of our representation in Burundi, our Ambassador, the High Representative, our technical observers and also our colleague David Martin, who have been able to assess the real situation in the country: a situation of harassment of the opposition, of absolute blockade of the free media; an impossible situation in which more than forty people have already died and, at the moment, there are one hundred thousand refugees who have gone to neighbouring countries, for fear of repression.  The president is responsible for all this. The President, who has clearly violated the Arusha Agreements; the President, who has decided that his own political career is more important than the life and freedom of his citizens.  The Constitution is down, and the Arusha Agreements are down.  The European Union has to be firm. If we agreed that the President could not be re-introduced, the President cannot re-introduce himself. And it is therefore unacceptable that we continue with this escalation, which we have not managed to stop eer the European Union, the African Union, or the United Nations. We are failing because burundians are dying—even though that causes them quite a laugh to colleagues in the EFDD Group, that's what's happening.  We need to act quickly and we need to concentrate our financial assistance on sustaining civil society, all those who are fighting justly to ensure that the Arusha Agreements are respected: European Union money must go to sustain that civil society. And we also need to activate restrictive measures, interrupt visas, intervene on the current accounts of the Burundiese elite that is blocking democratic development. But this afternoon I have to regret that, if the Burundians have seen this session, we are ashamed of the image that the European Union has given this afternoon with regard to Burundi: people playing with the Rules of Procedure to block a debate like this; people who don't believe in the European Union; people who don't believe in democracy; people who have been laughing, screaming to block out a decent debate, which is what this House has to have. I thank you, Madam President, for the patience you have had and I hope that in Burundi today you will know that, in addition to some groups that have come to break the union, there are many others who are here to defend the values of the European Union, which also contemplate solidarity with the countries suffering. (Applause)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to apologise to the visitors in the gallery, because they have not seen the best example of political culture today. When I defended the continuation of the debate on Burundi – something as grave and sensitive as that – I was called a fascist, and the person did not even have the manhood to apologise. Commissioner, I have to be very brief. I think that we received a number of relevant items of information from you, and we can see the efforts that the European Union is making. What I missed – and I would appreciate it if you could pass this on to Ms Mogherini – is measures which we could inject into the framework of a common foreign and security policy so as really to exert pressure on the regime, and on the president, so that the situation does not deteriorate. That is something that I missed in your presentation. I understand that you were simply passing on information, but if we are to have genuine common foreign and security policy, and to avoid a deterioration of the situation and a repetition of examples that we have elsewhere on the continent, then this is what we need.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Madam President, the situation in Burundi is very serious and, as is so often the case with the events in Africa, it is unfairly forgotten by the Western media. In just two months, neighbouring countries have taken in more than 100,000 refugees fleeing violence and political instability; a lesson in solidarity for Europe, that strength obsessed with denying asylum to its neighbours. The world bleeds out, all too often because of the interventions and interferences of the European Union. Therefore, putting financial and technical means and supporting the work of agencies and NGOs in the field is necessary, but it is not enough. We cannot continue to accept that commercial or geostrategic interests are imposed on the peaceful coexistence of the peoples of Africa. Too often, the continent's resources have circulated in the opposite direction to European weapons. It is time to break that vicious cycle, seeking a political and sovereign solution to the conflict and facilitating dialogue between the parties and African Union mediation to stabilize the country. We must act for peace.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: – Let us see one bright spot: who would have thought that so many people were interested in a debate on Burundi? And I like that.  Two weeks ago, we were ready to go to Burundi and watch the elections with our chief observer David Martin. It didn't look great, but it still looked reasonable. There were some challenges, but - and that's been reversed in one or two days - the moment the president asked for his third term, the violence began to increase. Then came the coup and now we're standing here. The idea that we could see parliamentary elections on 29 June seems to me to be an idea that we can take this off the table. In any case, we will not be able to see that, because I am actually expecting a very violent election day. You can't legitimize that, and you can't prevent it with a small observation mission.  So we are facing a huge crisis, with 100,000 refugees, with a youth militia putting crosses on the doors of people who would not be loyal to the regime, and the word axe day. The question is, what can we do there. But the question is also what we have not seen in the few years before, that things would now get so screechingly out of control. I think it's sad. I think we should stay involved. But I don't think we're going to see the election.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: – Madam President, firstly I want to join with Ms Valenciano in what she said. I heard colleagues over there talking about what happened to their grandparents 50-70 years ago in Europe. I am afraid that human rights abuses, torture and oppression are realities now in Burundi today. That is what we are here to talk about. I wonder what the people of Burundi must think when they see a debate about a very serious situation in their country being used to make a cheap political point by people over there. Let us go back to this very serious debate. I hope some of you will think hard about that, and maybe think about the people of Burundi, for whom this debate is extremely important because it is about their country and their aspiration to live in the kind of democracy that you and I are lucky enough to live in. Commissioner, I apologise to you as well on behalf this House because you have come here to give us a very good statement, a very clear statement, which covers all the essential aspects of the situation in Burundi. Since we last spoke about it, things are clearly not better.  As chair of the Committee on Development, I have received first-hand information from people on the ground about what is happening – about the human rights abuses, about the youth militias linked to the government which are causing violence, about the intimidation and all the issues that our colleagues have spoken about, and about the real hardship and the suffering that is being caused by the instability in the country, with people fleeing over borders. I am pleased, as the Chair of the committee, that we have stepped up humanitarian aid –unlike UKIP, who do not seem to think that people need that aid – people in Rwanda, in Tanzania, in DRC, where people have fled their country. Last month, Commissioner Mimica reminded us that the EU is a major donor to Burundi, a country which comes 180th out of 187 on the Human Development Index. In the last EDF programme we doubled our aid to Burundi. I know that people here are asking whether we should continue aiding that country in this period. I do not think that poor people should ever pay the price for the folly of their own government. We should remind the Government of Burundi of its responsibilities in respect of human rights under the Cotonou Agreement and remind it that the Council did adopt conclusions on this on 18 May, and the Government should be clear that we are looking at what we can do, because we want the elections to take place. I want to join others who have commended the work of our chief observer, David Martin, in the last few weeks; he has been working with my other colleagues. We want democracy in Burundi. We want the elections to take place under decent conditions. There are a few weeks now to put things right. I hope the Government of Burundi is watching this debate today and is listening to what has been said, and I hope it will act accordingly.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, it is said that Belgian colonial forces used to refer to the territory of Burundi as 'Urundi Rwanda', i.e. 'the other Rwanda'.  The similarities are overcoat: the bloody civil war, which left 300,000 dead in Burundi until 2005, the result of ethnic tensions between Hutus and Tutsis; poverty, impunity and the exodus of hundreds of thousands.  Is Burundi the other Rwanda? The current crisis is marked by an eminently political trait: it is the intention to perpetuate itself in the power of its President, against what is established by the Burundiese Constitution and the Arusha Peace Agreements, which has led to this conflict. And do you have anything to say about it? Do you have anything to do? The Rwandan genocide was not only ethnic in nature, but also political in nature. Kofi Annan bitterly regretted, ten years ago, the international inaction, his inability to stop the genocide, which ended with 800,000 men, women and children.  Ban Ki-moon has urged the Security Council to act and mobilize its instruments to safeguard peace in Burundi: is that enough?  Not acting once is a mistake, a terrible and irreparable mistake, but not acting a second time is simply a crime.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately, this House is once again being forced to deal with the very serious institutional crisis in Burundi. I have already spoken about the situation in the African country at the time of the arrest in January of Bob Rugurika, journalist and director of Radio Publique Africaine. The situation has deteriorated in recent weeks after the announcement of the dismissal of President Nkurunziza and the postponement of the elections that triggered violent and bloody clashes in the country. Since the protests began, some 40 people have died among the population, while a total of more than 100,000 people have fled Burundi. As denounced by many non-governmental associations, the protests were sparked by the decision announced by the President to go to the polls in order to obtain a third term, contrary to the provisions of the country's Constitutional Charter. After the criticisms of a great many African leaders, in addition to those of the United States, we must also bring in the decisive voice of Europe. We must strongly call on the government of the country to stop the repressive spiral and to allow the normal conduct of the elections and respect for the Constitutional Charter.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, again 'in the same play spectators', again for Burundi. We warned that the situation in Burundi would lead to conflict. Outgoing President Nkurunziza's decision to run for a third term, despite decisions to the contrary in the Arunza agreement, overflowed the glass. We condemn the coup attempt and the clashes in Burundi in recent weeks. A new civil war is just around the corner. More than a hundred thousand refugees have fled to neighbouring countries to be rescued.  The restriction of democratic rights and free political action by opposition parties continues. The new elections will now be held without the necessary democratic guarantees. Violence and attacks on dissidents are on the agenda.  The elections of violence and rigging in Burundi must therefore be postponed. That is why the international community and the European Union must take initiatives. At the same time, the European Union must cut off development aid to Burundi and allocate these funds to support Burundian refugees.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: " Madam President, Dear Mr. Commissioner, the real question is only one thing: do we stand before a new civil war? Are we standing before the possibility that the chaos that already exists in Burundi spills over to other states?  These are the right questions to ask ourselves with another key question – what are our mechanisms? What can we do to really prevent a possible new civil war in Burundi and spill over this whole conflict, which is clearly already happening, to other neighbouring countries that will also soon have elections? Of course we should do everything to ensure that the current president no longer runs and thus opens up the possibility of Burundi returning and has a positive impact on relations in other countries, in neighbouring countries of Burundi. I think that's the only way. If we fail to do so, we will, easily possible, not just chaos but a new civil war.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, in Africa, history is repeating itself. Another President, seeing the end of his power, is trying, comme d’habitude, to modify the Constitution to remain Head of State. The result is rebellion by the army, and in some cases also the population: a coup d’état or civil war. This is a time for Burundi. I would like to honour the bravery and resilience of the journalists of the independent newspapers, especially the ones from the weekly magazine Iwacu that declared in their editorial that they must resist – never mind their destroyed newsrooms or their fleeing or murdered colleagues. This political instability in Burundi is not acceptable, either from a geopolitical point of view or from a humanitarian one. Internal disorders are likely to bring a population already devastated by hunger to its knees. Commissioner, you must transmit the message to Ms Mogherini that it is time for the EU to act and to intervene in order to bring this impossible situation to an end.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Madam President, I join in the demonstration of solidarity of all my colleagues with the people of Burundi. The African Union's decision to postpone the elections for a month and a half cannot be considered satisfactory. Indeed, the conditions for the organisation of elections are completely unfulfilled: the CNI does not exist, the media does not exist and political plurality does not exist.  We must also work towards this and the international community has a duty to foster diplomatic contact. But we also have other means: redirect aid to civil society, or even take individual sanctions. The latter could include preventing mobility through visas, but also freezing the assets of the populations and people who are behind the crimes committed and the instability that prevails today in Burundi.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am going to make a speech a little counter-trending to the others, because I do not believe that there are many Europeans who care much about Burundi. I think that Europeans are asking Europe to do the things that are needed for Europeans.  When we talk about people dying in Burundi, very well, I am sorry, as many Europeans will mind, but because they are not starting to talk about all the suicides that are in Europe because there are companies that are not working, because there is an economy that is not good, because there are governments that are not good, because there are a lot of illegal immigrants who come to Europe and we cannot do anything. Because we don't think first of those we can't save in the Mediterranean Sea. We must think of Burundi, as we thought of the Maasai, as we thought of the illegal immigrants in Burma and we do not think of europe's illegal immigrants.  But do not be ashamed to talk about things that make no sense in relation to what Europeans are asking us to do, what young people, the elderly and businesses are asking us to do! But what do we think about Burundi? We are here talking about Burundi and we are not thinking about Europe! What our future is for! But shame on you or not!

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, yes, I think we need to stand by the Burundian people, just because the situation is so complicated and so disastrous there. I fully understand your concerns and I am open to your proposals. I will transmit them to High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini. But precisely because the situation is so fluid, and the outcome at the moment so uncertain, we have to keep all of the scenarios and all the options on the table. That means specifically that, of course, we have to consider the consultations under Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement and a range of appropriate measures which could be taken, including individual measures and, of course, looking at all financial assistance. We have to take into account using CFSP measures, among the various options available, just as proposed by honourable Member Telička. I think we have to give priority now to a peaceful solution and political dialogue. That is why we have to support the regional and African Union efforts to improve the political climate and get consensus on how to make elections work. We have to keep monitoring the situation in every dimension, and I am sure you agree with that approach as well. I look forward to maintaining a dialogue with you and I signal my appreciation of Parliament’s role in keeping this important issue on the international agenda.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place at a later meeting. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. – The decision of the current President to apply for a third term, in the context of the elections on 26 June 2015, provoked the anger of the opposition and numerous continuing demonstrations. Power has for the moment resorted to arrests and repressions resulting in deaths and injuries, instead of opening a constructive dialogue to de-escalate the situation. It is essential that the authorities, political forces and civil society engage in a transparent and inclusive political dialogue. This dialogue must lead to a political process that respects the constitutional provisions and its institutions, as well as the fundamental principles of the 2000 Arusha Peace and Reconciliation Agreement, in order to ensure the continuation of the electoral process, which must be credible, transparent and peaceful. The African Union's decision to send human rights observers to Burundi as quickly as possible is to report abuses and take action to resolve conflicts at local level. The European Union must demand respect for fundamental freedoms and particularly guarantee freedom of opinion, expression and freedom of the press, as well as freedom of peaceful protest.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. History repeats itself, and the case of President Nkurunziza seems too obvious a script. A head of state who amends the Constitution to retain power shortly before the elections, an army that rebels, a civil war. This time it is the people of Burundi who are paying the cost, with violence added to poverty. Given that beyond the plot we also know the ending (just look at the dramatic case of Rwanda), we must intervene immediately. Before the violence grows, before the struggle for power turns into a humanitarian crisis. Europe has a strong negotiating power. If the conflicts continue and the authorities do not reach a peaceful agreement, the violence must be seen as human rights violations and therefore as non-compliance with the Cotonou Agreement. Cooperation must be stopped. The Union has a duty at least to exert strong pressure so that the Burundian people can hold democratic and transparent elections.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the Statement by the Council and the Commission on information on high-level corruption cases in FIFA (2015/2730(RSP)).

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, sport is universal. It is said to be the only truly international language. Sport opens doors, brings people and communities together and bridges divides. For us Europeans, any discussion of sport is first and foremost associated with discussion about football. Albert Camus used to say: ‘What I know about morals, I owe to football.’ For that reason it is all the more unfortunate to hear that sport is being used for criminal purposes. FIFA, born in Europe a little over 100 years ago, has not only gone global, but the events it organises are watched by millions, and sometimes billions, of people. As we speak, the FIFA Women’s World Cup is ongoing in Canada. These events are a source of hope for boys and girls around the world. Such events cannot be undermined by continual suspicions of criminal activities. Illegal betting and match fixing have been making the headlines in recent years. But who could have imagined that the scale of organised crime was so massive. Football is not only a game; it is also an economic activity, creating jobs and attracting investments. As in every economic sector, a sound and transparent basis is needed. For all these reasons, it is important that trust be re—established. The Council and its Presidency have been following the recent developments within football’s governing body, FIFA, with great attention and concern. The context in which we must address this issue is important. The responsibility for good governance and the proper functioning of sporting organisations lies with the international sports bodies themselves and not with governments or EU institutions. However, given the importance of sport to citizens, and of football in particular, it is clear that standards of governance in international sporting organisations are an area of legitimate concern. As far as the EU is concerned, the Lisbon Treaty introduced a new specific competence in the field of sport. It is noteworthy that Article 165 of the Treaty mentions the moral integrity of sport in particular. The Council has paid specific attention to the issue of how sporting organisations are governed and run. In May 2011, the Council adopted a first EU work plan for sport. It established an expert group to address the issue of good governance, which agreed a set of ‘Principles of Good Governance in Sport’. These principles identify the key elements necessary to ensure public and stakeholder confidence in the organisations responsible for sport. Even if the role of the EU is limited to facilitating exchanges of good practice, transfers of knowledge and networking of stakeholders at national and international level, the EU institutions have a role to play in ensuring that good governance principles adopted at EU level are recognised and implemented in all EU Member States. The EU can also facilitate the promotion of principles of good governance in sport beyond its borders, with both the sporting bodies and the public authorities of third countries. Honourable Members, I would like to quote European Council President Tusk. In the context of the recent G7 meeting in Germany, he said: ‘I am really satisfied that some leaders want to use the summit to discuss corruption, including the recent FIFA scandal. We do not need empty declarations against corruption but we have to be ready to fight against those who were corrupted and those who corrupt. We need to fight corruption in all its dimensions, no matter how powerful the authors of these disgraceful practices are.’ I would like to highlight the work done by the EU on corruption in recent months. The Latvian Presidency made this a priority, as early as the Trio Presidency Programme.
