We highlighted, in particular, cooperation with the Group of States against Corruption (GRECO), as well as progress on the Anti-Money Laundering Directive. Indeed, following an agreement between our two institutions, we strengthened rules to prevent money laundering. The Anti-Money Laundering Directive will strengthen EU rules and ensure consistency with the approach followed at international level, based on the recommendations of the Financial Action Task Force. And the Funds Transfer Regulation introduces further requirements regarding the information accompanying transfers of funds. I signed these pieces of legislation with President Schulz at the time of the European Parliament part-session in May. Of course, the global fight against corruption requires much more action and many more steps, as illustrated by the recent revelations on FIFA. But we have made a contribution, at EU level, to the priority that the fight against corruption represents. With regard to the recent developments at FIFA, there is now an opportunity for major reform of that organisation. However, as I said, no matter how many laws we pass, they will not be effective if there is no true will on the part of the organisation to self-regulate and observe these standards. The Council will follow this debate closely and pay due attention to the views that are expressed.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I want to thank the European Parliament for putting this item on today’s agenda. I usually enjoy talking about sport, but today’s subject troubles me deeply. Football often dominates the news and conversations all over the globe. It is the most popular game in the world, and European clubs and our national teams are at its heart. But the last two weeks have revealed an uglier side of the beautiful game. We see an international governance system in football that is broken and has lost all trust and credibility. European fans and our own football associations have shown clearly what they think. FIFA as an organisation in its current form is no longer fit to run international football. Small change will not be enough – but big change may not be enough either. FIFA needs a fresh start, a complete overhaul of the organisation’s culture and institutions. It needs to take responsibility to become a new transparent organisation that meets the highest ethical and moral standards. Fans across Europe and around the world demand nothing less. What role should the European Union play in this process? Clearly this is not an area where we should be legislating or creating new instruments. Our job in the EU is not to organise sport, but we will support and encourage those who are serious about reform. The Commission has already been working for some time with a group of experts on good governance, which developed recommendations looking at transparency and accountability in decision-making, democratic structures and processes, inclusive representation and effective auditing. The expert group is now working on ways to take these recommendations and principles forward. We are looking at how the rights to organise major sporting events are awarded across the single market and taking into account the realities of the digital age. Building on this, I now want to look at how to promote the implementation of principles of good governance by all the sports organisations, including football. Of course, it is not for the European Commission or the European Union to run sports organisations. They have to take responsibility and implement good governance standards themselves. But we can help to develop those standards and encourage federations to put them in place. We can signal to those sport bodies which want to play ball that we are ready to help them. The autonomy of sport, free from government interference, is fundamental; but, like other organisations that play a public role and which fail to respect the highest ethical standards, our sporting federations must face greater scrutiny. Competition in our single market must follow the rules. At the Commission, we work closely with Member States and sports organisations to achieve a real change in sport governance. We will not stand by silently when sports federations fail to do their job. We must be ready to share the thinking we have done in Europe with others who now face the challenge of reform. We owe it to the millions of sports fans in Europe and beyond.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, Madam Minister, the events of recent weeks have been at the highlight of the most important crisis of government in the world of sport. What we are discussing today does not affect only a small number of managers of a sports organization. This issue concerns all of us who love sport and live it day by day. We always talk about the values that sport embodies and, therefore, sport must be especially exemplary. Sport cannot hide its shortcomings and hide behind the sacrosanct principle of sport autonomy. I am thinking in particular of the fight against doping, the fight against violence, the fight against discrimination, the fight against rigged parties and the fight against criminal activities in a broader sense, such as corruption. These matters concern the general interest and, therefore, from the European Parliament we have full legitimacy to discuss and propose solutions. I would like to recall that on 2 February 2012 we adopted a report on the European dimension of sport which I had the honour of being rapporteur. This report proposed that public and sports authorities should act together. I believe that now, more than ever, this must be implemented in order to eradicate corruption and lack of transparency in the world of sport. Autonomy in sport is based on good governance. Good governance is an inexcusable condition for the autonomy and self-regulation of sports organizations, which must be based on the principles of transparency, accountability and democracy and the need for a zero-tolerance policy against corruption. It is urgent that FIFA catches the bull by the horns. FIFA is sick and its illness is due to its current ruling class. His illness is serious and cannot be cured with a touch of magic wand. FIFA must react and take urgent action that includes reforming its statutes, organizational structure, accommodating the different representatives of the sport. It should also limit the number of mandates of its leaders and modify the system of choice of its members, as well as undergo an independent audit of their finances and implement a strict ethical code. Prior to FIFA, other sporting institutions have experienced similar crises and managed to find the right way to overcome them, as UEFA has demonstrated with its reforms. The ball is now in the field of FIFA, its confederations and its national federations. Let them know that Europe is watching them and that Europe will continue to express itself, as many times as necessary, in order to give football the prestige bestowed on it by millions of practitioners and supporters every day, in the four corners of the old continent and beyond. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Miloslav RANSDORF
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Can I ask a question, Mr. Fisas?  600 years ago, Czech reformer Jan Hus characterized corruption in the church as follows: "Dogs fight for bone. Take their bone and they'll stop fighting." Wouldn't it help in this situation, Mr. Fisas, if limits were made, financial limits that meant there was no bone to fight over?

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: "blue card" response. "Well, what I'd say is that UEFA has been through this huge crisis. I honestly believe that Mr Blatter, the president, should not have elected to the election at the time. He did, and I think there's something dark and a little weird about that resignation after four days. Something that should be investigated.

name: Petra KAMMEREVERT
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Joseph Blatter is in FIFA history. But as overdue as his resignation may have been, he was never the only problem. With all its interdependencies, dependencies and dark sides, FIFA is more reminiscent of the multi-headed monster of Greek mythology, the Hydra. With Joseph Blatter, she has lost only one head. But the question remains as to what will happen next. Right now, however, the way is clear for major reforms and a complete realignment of FIFA. There must be no simple move to the agenda. The values of sport, such as fairness, team spirit and equal opportunities, must not be trampled underfoot by corrupt machinations. The consistent action of the US Public Prosecutor's Office clearly shows us the importance of criminal sanctions. Years of self-commitments, half-hearted reforms, and an ethics committee that is not so sure whether it deserves the name at all have not been enough to stop the self-serving mentality of many officials. FIFA must now launch comprehensive reforms. The European member federations, but also UEFA, have a special responsibility here. The questionable European Championship awards in 2018 and 2022 also urgently need to be put on the agenda. Sports federations also have a kind of responsibility for respect for human rights. We need good governance with clear international standards and rules to preserve the integrity of sport. Even if we, as a policy, respect the self-organisation of sport, we must always put our finger in the wound and exert pressure so that in this sport, which we love so much together with millions of fans, it is fair and transparent not only on the pitch, but also in the associations. Together, we must not allow everything that constitutes sport to be trampled underfoot by corrupt and non-transparent federation structures. We owe that to the fans and also to the players. Because they have to be able to rely on everything in their sport in the future.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, are any of us surprised that it has come to this? We have known for years that there is corruption in FIFA, and this has been sapping the soul out of the world’s second most popular sport after cricket. In this House we have long called for reform, particularly after the ludicrous decision to host the World Cup in Qatar, a city of 300 000 people with summer temperatures well into the 40s and no tradition of football. But it is only now that the FBI has acted that we begin to know the full truth. I congratulate the FBI for acting. I think they have done sports fans around the world a favour. Now that the rotting core of the once beautiful game has finally been exposed, the ensuing fallout will undoubtedly expose others, and it is entirely necessary. I welcome the fact that Sepp Blatter has resigned, but much more needs to be done. Blatter needs to go now, not at the end of December. The bids for the 2018 and 2022 World Cups should be investigated and, if there is any evidence of wrongdoing, the entire process should be re-run. But we need root-and-branch reform of FIFA, as others have also suggested. In particular, I do not want any new president to be tarnished by the old regime. We need a completely new field of people coming in here. If FIFA wants inspiration, they should look to the International Olympic Committee (IOC). After they had a similar scandal before the Salt Lake City Olympics in 2002, they put athletes at the core of their executive committees. I think FIFA should be looking at exactly the same thing: trying to put athletes at the core of the decision-making process. They are the people who know the sport. Millions of children play football every day. How do we persuade them to play by the rules, not to cheat and to respect referees, when the guardians of the global game do not play by the same rules themselves?

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, football is attracting ever more popularity and influence, thus attracting power and money. This comes with new challenges, and FIFA clearly has proved unable to address them. FIFA needs action from the outside world to clean up the organisation. It is now time for the public authorities to take the necessary steps to make sure the organisation applies an effective anti-bribery programme and that those in power are held accountable. This time FIFA cannot pretend that the problem is a few corrupt officials. The fact that Sepp Blatter has been re-elected, even after the serious allegations of corruption around him, shows that national federations must take responsibility. They need to be part of the reform process. UEFA has a role to play in paving the way towards more transparency, but the reform must be global. Sepp Blatter should stand down now and an interim president should be appointed. The selection of Russia and Qatar as hosts of the forthcoming World Cups should be subject to re-examination. If there is any proof of misconduct in the Qatar and Russia decisions, these decisions must be immediately reversed. This resolution is a strong political message from all political groups addressed to FIFA and its partners. It is high time for the sport sector, and in particular football, to implement the values it spreads: respect of rules, team spirit and fair play.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, ba chóir fáilte a chur roimh ghabháil oifigigh FIFA. Ní haon ionadh é ar ndóigh. Tá an eagraíocht thar a bheith éillitheach. I mo thír féin, nuair a theip ar Éirinn cáiliú don Chorn Domhanda bhí agóidí ar siúl agus tá sé tagtha chun cinn gur íoc FIFA EUR 5 mhilliún le Cumann Peile na hÉireann chun deireadh a chur leis na hagóidí sin.  Cuireann ár ngrúpa fáilte roimh an gcomhthairiscint i gcomhair rúin a cháineann an chaimiléireacht atá i FIFA. Mar aon leis sin, táimid ag cur leasuithe tábhachtacha chun tosaigh agus iarraim oraibh tacaíocht a thabhairt dóibh siúd. Tá siad bainteach leis an tslí nach bhfuil aird ar bith tugtha ag FIFA ar na treascairtí ar chearta an duine d’oibrithe tógála imirceacha atá ag tógáil na staidiamaí ina mbeidh an Corn Domhanda á imirt i 2022. Deirtear go bhfuair 1 933 oibrí imirceach bás go dtí seo agus tuairiscítear go mbeidh 4 000 duine marbh faoin am a thosnaíonn an comórtas peile. Den chuid is mó is fir óga atá i gceist agus tá siad tar éis taom croí a fháil de bharr an teasa fhíochmhair a théann chomh hard le 50 céim, agus gan aon chosaint acu. Ní féidir leis na hoibrithe fágaint de bharr go bhfuil a gcuid pasanna tógtha ag na fostóirí. Rinne an Eagraíocht Idirnáisiúnta Saothair cur síos ar chóras kafala rialtas Chatar mar ‘obair éigeantais’. Is é seo an praghas tragóideach den chaimiléireacht i FIFA: sclábhaíocht san aois seo. Tuigim anois go bhfuil an próiseas ina roghnaíodh Catar sa chéad dul síos á fhiosrú ag na húdaráis Eilvéiseacha. Ní hamháin go bhfuil FIFA éillitheach, tá siad ag tabhairt tacaíochta don rialtas i gCatar agus don drochúsáid do chearta na n-oibrithe imirceacha. Ní féidir linn ligint dó seo leanúint ar aghaidh. Mar gheall ar an 2 000 duine atá imithe ar shlí na fírinne go dtí seo, níl aon rogha ann do FIFA ach vóta a chaitheamh arís i gcomhair Chorn Domhanda 2022.

name: Helga TRÜPEL
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has FIFA is not a non-profit organisation, but a dangerous one. My colleague Claudia Roth said this a few years ago, and recent events show once again that this is unfortunately the right thing to do. I welcome the resignation of Joseph Blatter, which was overdue. However, as previous speakers have said, it is a bad solution that he is still in office. There must be a new interim President, otherwise there will be no real reappraisal of events. Yes, FIFA must also cooperate with the FBI and the Swiss authorities, and it must support them in their willto for information. And FIFA must clearly work against corruption and introduce clear reforms. I would also like the Commission to take coordinated action against corruption and for the Member States to work with Interpol to send a clear signal against corruption. Most importantly, however, the awarding of the World Cups to Russia and Qatar, that these decisions be reversed. Only countries that really adhere to human rights and workers' rights should be rewarded with world cups. This must become a very clear policy of FIFA. We want a clear code of conduct for sports organisations against corruption, and I also want women to be much better represented in sports organisations, especially on boards, than is the case now. This is a glaring shortcoming. Many women also take part in football, but are not represented there. This urgently needs to change, and that would also be an important sign against corruption. One final word: we have the Erasmus+ programme, and there is a clear statement against doping, against violence, against racism and against game-fixing. That is why this programme must be made more visible to the public.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: Mr President, a resignation at the FIFA summit will not be enough. A vast system of corruption is being uncovered, which sports and the common good lovers cannot tolerate. For years, there have been serious suspicions about the motivations that led FIFA to award Qatar, a gas emirate with no sporting tradition, a competition as important as the World Cup. Everything must be laid to rest by 2022 and the World Cup must be awarded to another country in order to send a clear signal against corruption, but also because it is morally unworthy to endorse the practices of the Islamist dictatorship of Qatar - a small country regularly implicated in the financing of terrorism. This dictatorship leaves no rights to women, it despises them and persecutes homosexuals, doomed to prison and whip. This slave dictatorship is accused by NGOs of allowing thousands of Nepalese and Indian workers to die on World Cup construction sites.  This is a tyrannical country that seeks to intimidate our democracies by prosecuting those who dare to criticize it, including parliamentarians - today politicians, tomorrow journalists and human rights activists. A dictatorship that attacks when it fails to corrupt, an authoritarian theocracy that uses its dollars to buy consciences. Let's refuse this submission. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: "blue card" question. "Dear colleague, Qatar has struck you with a judicial fatwa. Do you have any news of your letter to the President of the French Republic?

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: "blue card" answer. "No, I have not yet heard from this letter, indeed. It is quite surprising that he has not yet responded. I wonder if the letter is not being written in an office of the Qatari Embassy in Paris.

name: Hermann WINKLER
text: Ppe. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Sport, and football in particular, is not, as is often claimed, the most beautiful side thing in the world. No, sport – and football in particular – is the glue, the putty that holds our society together. This is especially true of the many associations, which are mostly run in the voluntary sector. In my own country alone, Germany, there are 26 000 football clubs with almost seven million members who are active in the sport of the disabled with children's and young people, in the field of the elderly. We know that these associations are the best-functioning social stations in our society. Added to this is the great enthusiasm that football, fair competition, generates among spectators. This applies to the Kreisliga as well as to international competitions up to the World Cup. All these people meet regularly, with the proviso of treating each other fairly, respecting values and rules of the game and being a role model. At the lower level, i.e. in the voluntary sector, this works excellently. It is all the worse that where a lot of money flows, where large sums of money are paid as remuneration, nothing works. Confidence in FIFA has been squandered. It is sad to see how greed, the pursuit of power and the lack of moralmorality of individuals discredit the whole of football. All those who are honest about football have a right to expect honesty, transparency, openness and fair play from the football government – FIFA. FIFA needs fundamental changes quickly to restore its credibility. I can only agree with the main demands of the President of the German Football Association today on his ten points. Among other things, it calls for a rapid investigation of corruption allegations, the rapid change at the top of FIFA, the limitation of terms of office, more transparency in World Cup allocations, strict control of cash flows and an adjustment in the voting system. This requires Europe to be united in UEFA – on reforms and also on future personnel decisions. Only in this way is it possible to regain the lost trust and to be a role model again.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Mr President, Madam Minister, Commissioner, the resignation of Joseph Blatter will not bring back the 1,200 workers, mostly Nepalese and Indian, who died on the construction sites of the 2022 World Cup in Qatar, nor will it erase the manipulations and malfeasations on which he will one day have to explain himself to the courts. This decision is good news for ethics and football around the world, but it is obviously far from sufficient: it is a new management team that we must call for. The time has come to clean up and give international football bodies a chance to become credible.  Some of the leaders have filled their pockets with dollars but have their hands full of blood. In any case, this is the detestable image that citizens have today of FIFA. When I proposed at the time, more than two years ago, to withdraw Qatar from its World Cup, many laughed. I note today that this proposal is receiving positive feedback from many of you. I would add, to the evidence that Mrs Riada gave a few minutes ago, the shame that Qatar should feel for preventing Nepalese workers from returning to their country to bury their dead as a result of the earthquake. With this resolution, we wanted to stress that a profound reform of FIFA is needed. Governance above suspicion is needed, as well as a just and healthy framework in which athletes from around the world and football fans can recognize each other again.  It is the responsibility of the European Parliament to use all its influence to punish with a red card the practices of corruption and to tackle the repeated cheating, which allows a diversion of the general interest towards the very particular interest of a minority hungry for power and money, in defiance of all ethics.  We must help put in place mechanisms to stop these criminal practices, because, let us be clear, through the FIFA scandal, it is everyone in sport and all our values that are being flouted. For the millions of children that football still makes dream today, let us urge FIFA to restore a positive image of football. A new transparent governance is an immediate necessity.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – I want to highlight the tremendous strength and importance of international organisations. There is not much talk about the functioning of FIFA, but also about other huge organisations of different orientations, such as the OECD or the World Trade Organisation, the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and many others. But they are organisations with a huge impact on society. Even top officials are elected through diplomatic negotiations for relatively long periods. Their influence is often greater than that of elected representatives in direct elections. They decide fundamental things and they don't have to answer to anyone. They are not under the care of the electorate and the media, as is the case with politicians, and often do not have to comply with the elementary principles of transparency. Scandals like FIFA are opening our eyes. Let us talk about the system of operation of such organisations, let us not be afraid to ventilation them and build on healthy foundations. So that they serve society, not personal interests.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Mr President, it is good that we are having this debate. Earlier on, UKIP tried to create the atmosphere of a football stadium here, including hooligans. Today’s debate is actually fairly modest. We are merely admonishing FIFA here, saying: ‘Now, now boys’ – because it is mostly boys – ‘keep your hands out of the cookie jar’. Ethical codes and admonitions may be necessary, but they are not enough. The Council here expressed surprise at the scale of the corruption, but I think most people in this world were not surprised. It was happening right under our noses, but we have to ask ourselves: why did the US have to come in and clean up our mess? What has Europe done? What have the Member States done? What about the Commission’s famous anti-corruption strategy? Why has that not been used? Commissioner, you rightly talked about the application of the competition rules to international sports federations. There is a complaint against the International Speed Skating Federation which has been sitting on the Commission’s desk for a year now. So I hope that you are going to live up to what you said earlier and give them a response within the next two weeks.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, the events of corruption in FIFA are serious, but not surprising. From mass culture to passive entertainment, the commodization of sport is synonymous with the degradation of its values. The International Olympic Committee has starred in similar scandals and Spanish football is infamous for its outrageous urban requalifications, non-payment to the Treasury or the Social Security of its workers. But behind this scandal, FIFA, in which it must certainly bring order and establish transparent and democratic control mechanisms, hides a greater tragedy: 1,200 construction workers killed during the preparation of the Qatar World Cup, 1,200 victims of a globalized world who care less about their deaths than the profits from their farms. Europe must defend the application of ILO Conventions, in addition to other interests and complicity. Qatar must end the forced labour of migrant workers and ensure their freedom of organization and basic labour rights. What is a scandal is for Europe to look the other way in the face of this situation.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: – Mr President, it is increasingly important to fight corruption in any structures – international or national – but it is even more important for us to send a clear signal to the football authorities that the corrupted decisions should be revisited. Particularly with Qatar, we have some time and proper procedures to follow. With Russia it is too soon, so let us make it a win-win situation and send a message to FIFA saying that it should give the Russian championship to Brazil, which has invested heavily, and let them get some more return on their investment and face Germany in the semi-finals again. Or let us give it to Great Britain, which has all the infrastructure. Perhaps it will be their last event as a member of the European Union.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the recent scandal of corruption at fifa summits adds another dark chapter to the history of football. I, as an Italian, am unfortunately not surprised. We, alas, are sadly used to such scandals and not just in the world of football! Very recent cases of corruption, fraud, rigged matches and illegal betting, often handled by organised crime with the complacency of footballers and managers. To understand us better: an investigation is currently underway by the District Anti-Mafia Directorate of Catanzaro for football betting and a few hours ago the news came out of the launch of an investigation, complete with a search, against the Vice-President of the Italian Football Federation, who is called Claudio Lotito, for attempted extortion, even! However, everyone knew, for example, as it was denounced by Inspector Garcia, that the allocation of the World Cup in Russia in 2018 and those of Qatar in 2022 was tainted by serious corruption. FIFA's ethics committee ignored all the report's conclusions and confirmed the assignments.  Fifa and the whole world of football must be reformed, not only in Italy, but throughout Europe, which seems for too long to follow its own logics that are completely outside the genuine values of sport, such as healthy competition, the development of the person, friendship, discipline and education. Footballers are often role models for the younger generation and therefore play an educational role, but all too often the example given is not up to scratch. Perhaps we should reflect on this fact: our society should ask itself whether it is right to entrust such a fundamental educational role to those who in the vast majority of cases are unable to do so because they have neither the means nor the preparation. In conclusion, I believe that when it comes to transparency, democracy, good governance and financial fair play, these concepts should not remain declamations of principle, but should be applied on a daily basis.  This scandal, albeit in the bitterness of the moment, nevertheless offers us the opportunity for a reform that I believe must be seized. We must be prepared to resist the pressure that will certainly be exerted given the enormous financial interests at stake, but we are ready to play our part!

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr. President, I welcome the investigation into certain FIFA officials about allegations of corruption. The details that have emerged are shocking, but not altogether surprising, as for too long FIFA has been able to dodge allegations of wrongdoing under the guidance of Sepp Blatter. It has emerged that the Football Association in the Republic of Ireland received five million euros in a secret deal to buy its silence following controversy during a 2010 World Cup qualifying playoff match. Hopefully Mr Blatter has now realised that you cannot just throw money at a problem to make it go away.  I would also call upon decision-makers in the Football Association of Ireland to immediately pay back this money. If they have any integrity, they will do this. To fail to do so would be complicit in the corruption that seems to be at the heart of FIFA. What has unfolded is appalling, but FIFA has the opportunity to redeem itself, and this will only happen if it becomes fully transparent. Many lovers of the beautiful game will require clear evidence that change will take place before they can put their trust in FIFA to take that game forward. To sit in silence or to do nothing would be a betrayal of those fans.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The current situation in FIFA needs to be radically changed, which is why the European Parliament is calling for appropriate steps to restore confidence in football, to a sport whose main motto is the principle of fair play. The integrity of sports organisations is very important because sport plays a key role in the global promotion of peace, respect for human rights and solidarity, and brings numerous health and economic benefits to society. Football is one of the most popular sports in the world. It is extremely important that we firmly and unequivocally put an end to all forms of corruption that undermine credibility and damage the reputation of this discipline. In this context, it is crucial to protect athletes and to ban third-party ownership of players in European sport, to eliminate violence, to doping and to combat match-setting. That is why we call on all national football associations to act to implement positive changes in FIFA before the end of 2016. We also expect the same from sponsors and broadcasters. It is only by exerting pressure that we can bring about rapid reforms. We will also closely follow the swiss and US justice investigations into FIFA's decision to award the World Cup to Russia and Qatar. The sports sector is a large and fast-growing branch of the EU economy, contributing to economic growth and job creation. Good governance is a prerequisite for the autonomy of these organisations, which should operate in a transparent, accountable and democratic manner. As the famous footballer Didier Drogba said, "football generates positive emotions and connects people all over the world" – so we should follow the principle of zero tolerance for corruption in sport.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, corruption and money laundering in football and other sports are not limited to the pitch lines and the provision of players and referees. They involve millions associated with sponsorships, player transfers, broadcast rights, applications for sporting events, major construction companies and all sports federations in the world. European clubs and sporting events have been partnering with corrupt and autocratic governments that thus launder money and buy their promotion in the international sphere, ignoring the human rights of workers who build infrastructure and rights inherent in massive expropriations to build them. All this with the complicity, by action and omission, of the financial system and european governments. Go to them, so the FBI and the U.S. Department of Justice have dismantled some of the webs of corruption that are in place at FIFA, a Swiss organization long criticized for its lack of transparency and accountability, exempt from government oversight, scrutiny, and due diligence rules in large companies. The European Union must act and demand reform at FIFA, with the establishment of an independent reform committee composed of personalities not paid by or associated with FIFA so that they can investigate and publish concrete recommendations, including strict implementation of the new anti-money laundering directive. The reform cannot come from FIFA, which is discredited. Part of the reform must include transparency on spending and spending, including codes of conduct and scrutiny and sanctioning mechanisms. If suspicions of corruption are confirmed in the selection of Russia and Qatar for the 2018 and 2022 world championships, we demand that the competitions be reopened. FIFA must also be called on to take responsibility for curbing violations of workers' rights involved in building infrastructure for those competitions.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The typical Saturday afternoon of a father or mother with football-loving children: one stands on the edge of a small football field, cheers at the gate and cries of tears of joy when the little ones proudly jet to the team cabin like Oskar. This is football and the opposite of what Sepp Blatter and his corrupt FIFA comrades are currently showing us. It's no longer about sport, it's about performance, it's about team spirit. It is all about pure money and sheer power. In short, it is a question of destroying the dream for which we fathers and mothers, sons and daughters are feverish Saturday after Saturday on the amateur football pitches of Europe. I would like to see a clear voice from the EU when it comes to bringing football back into the field of idealism, enthusiasm and encounter. As an expert on small and medium-sized enterprises in my group, I often speak of the ideal of the honourable merchant, the honorable merchand. And I would like to see that conviction back in professional sport. Let's do it for the boys, the girls, the volunteers who kick in the small squares of the world. For them, we must ensure that the 2018 and 2022 World Cups are re-allocated. Because of you, the honorable businessman needs his place in professional sports. For your part, we need to re-discuss the idea of fair play for international player transfers.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Mr President, I looked into FIFA’s statute, and it says that the objectives are about unifying, educational, cultural, humanitarian values, promoting integrity, ethics and fair play. But FIFA also has its bodies: it is not just the President; it has a Congress. Our national federations are also a part of that whole institution. It has an audit committee and a committee looking after the observance of regulations. So it is a whole set-up. For me, FIFA is a corrupt organisation. At a time when we see 14 officials, including a vice-president, arrested, and at a time when we have a scandal of major magnitude, still we have the election of Sepp Blatter. For me this is clear evidence that FIFA is a corrupt and unreformable, unaccountable and non-transparent organisation. We need reform, but we do not need FIFA-led reform. We need a new organisation, set up from scratch. I think we also need to address our national institutions and our national federations, because they will be a part of that exercise.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: – Mr President, sport is something that could unite people and it very often does, but it should not be a divisive factor and something that produces scandals. As a colleague has said, how do we expect girls and boys who love to do sport to abide by the rules if the adults in sports organisations do not? It is good that this scandal is finally out in public. But we knew it before. Why did we as a European Union not react before? Why did Member States not act against corrupt structures in their own sports organisations? How could Russia get the FIFA games of 2018 after the Sochi Olympics that were fraught with corruption, environmental destruction and grave human rights violations in the country? Even worse, how could Qatar get the 2022 championships in a country with desert, 40 degrees in the shade and hardly anybody playing football, if at all, and where already more than a thousand people have died in the construction works? Both the Russia 2018 and Qatar 2022 decisions have to be reviewed and withdrawn, and the human rights violations have to be investigated and victims and survivors have to be paid compensation for the pain they have been suffering. As my colleague Helga Trüpel has said, more women need to be in a totally overhauled structure of FIFA, because not only do girls and women play football, we also know how to manage and how to lead organisations, and usually without being corrupt.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: – We are talking about corruption at FIFA tonight. But we also have someone in this House who is demonstrably corrupt and against whom no measure has been taken. I am talking about Mr Bidegain, who, during an undercover operation by the Sunday Times, was only too willing to take bribes from journalists posing as lobbyists. In return, he would then table amendments. This gentleman should, of course, have been cleared immediately, but he could just sit there and that shows once again how hypocritical and hypocritical this Parliament is. Hypocritical, because we want to talk about corruption within FIFA here, but Parliament is not in a way of giving its own member a red card.  But it is getting even crazier, because last year this Parliament gave this corrupt Mr a prize: MEP of the year! How do you make it up? This is political match-fixing that FIFA can suck at.

name: Milan ZVER
text: – Sport is part of the culture and quality of life, especially in Europe, which is the most advanced sport. It is becoming an increasingly important role in our private and public life, so during the Slovenian Presidency we even placed it in European Union documents and later institutionalised accordingly. Sport is represented not only by athletes but also by officials. It is therefore of the utmost importance that all national and global sporting associations act honestly, professionally and transparently in the good development of sport and in accordance with the values associated with it. This is especially true of the world's most important football federation. I support the european parliament resolution tabled because it emphasises that there is no place in the international football union for corruption scandals, because it badly affects the reputation of football played by both top footballers and little boys and girls in Africa, South America, Asia and elsewhere, who love this game and who are so much for them, that their football goals give them the hope that they may one day live life , many beyond poverty. Now Fifa's football officials have smeared not only themselves, but also the sport they represent. More and more illegal acts are known to be committed to sport – from doping, bribery, money laundering, betting, black betting and fake sports outcomes. Crime knows no bounds, and its activities too often cross national borders and successfully evad national law enforcement agencies. The FIFA affair is, in its essence, international, so it requires a comprehensive, common effective response. FIFA, however, needs an organisational overhaul, but also morally – both can only be achieved by new people.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Dear Mr President, I support the resolution on the recent revelations of high-level corruption at FIFA, because above all I believe that this international scandal involving one of the most popular sports on a European and global scale will have detrimental consequences for the reputation of football.  FIFA has been the subject of accusations of corrupt practices for years. However, the arrest of 14 officers on charges of money laundering, racketeering and receiving bribes this time has transcended football's boundaries and entered the political spectrum, even beyond. This is about people's lives and health. More than 1,200 people have died in the construction of qatar's stadiums, a fact that FIFA continues to turn a blind eye to. In Brazil, there have been a number of protests against the holding of the World Cup, and yet we are talking about a country where football is a religion. It is vital that an independent body is set up to monitor compliance with ethical standards. FIFA must once again earn the trust of the people, and this goes through the introduction of the mandate of the members of the executive committee and the transparency of the payments of senior management. First, I call on the Commission, together with the Member States, to make optimal use of the set framework of the European Union Work Plan for Sport, focusing on actions and concrete measures directly affecting good governance.  Secondly, I would like to draw your attention to the fact that to date only nine Member States have signed the Council of Europe Convention on the Manipulation of Sports Competitions. Worst of all, the corruption scandal will inevitably affect not only professional football organizations, but also amateur clubs. It is professional and amateur sport that are important conductors of the message of peace and respect for human rights worldwide. Preserving their integrity is vital.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, this corruption scandal is an encouragement to rethink the functioning of professional sport and football in particular.  The problem begins in school sports, with exalted people who look more like player agents than parents educating their children. It ends in rot that an American investigation – another very relevant symptom on a day like today – has been uncovered in FIFA.  Sport has enormous potential as a promoter of positive values and generator of economic activities. Returning this capability to football requires an exemplary sanction on the culprits of these dismantling, a deep renewal of the organizations that manage the sport and more effective and transparent rules against bribery and money laundering operations, a more demanding media discourse and an end to impunity for the outings of the stars of this sport who are applauded to attitudes favorable to gender-based violence.  Always values: business and sport, only with values.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: – Mr President, the identification between FIFA and corruption is a sign of what happens when we accept that a matter of as obvious public interest as professional sport is dominated and managed from private structures without effective democratic and judicial control. It is a world without external control mechanisms and without proper separation of powers in its inner workings and in its decision-making processes. Any reform that does not include these issues will be doomed to failure, no matter how many references we make to good governance.  By the way, how is it possible that we should have waited for legal proceedings by non-EU countries, such as Switzerland and the United States?  The enormous economic impact of football sets the ideal scenario for the worst vices of individual corruption to grow or, as in the case of FIFA, structural and institutional: the relationship between corrupt and corrupt becomes entirely apparent.  But if you want to go to the roots, let's do so by targeting three fully identified economic sectors: audiovisual media; advertising and sponsorship of athletes and teams; private sports betting, especially in its digital version.  We are talking about the World Cups in France, South Africa, Russia and Qatar, but we do not include any reference to the 2006 World Cups and the recent revelations about Saudi Arabia's vote and the supply of arms to this country from Germany itself.  We should send a message of excuses, starting with the registered vote, for Mr Blatter's incomprehensible re-election as FIFA president just a week ago. Did you know that France and Spain were the only European countries that gave Mr Blatter a favourable vote? Horror and shame.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: Mr President, the revelations about the existence of a system of corruption at the highest level of FIFA seriously damage the image of international football, especially since the sums at stake are colossal. There is talk of a $1.6 million embezzlement for credit card expenses and personal loans involving the former FIFA vice president. There is still talk of Egypt paying $7 million in 2004 in exchange for votes.  The judiciary must conduct the investigation and clean up the Augias football business stables for good in order to restore the sport to its former glory. But it must not be held hostage by geopolitical settlements that would include Russia, the host country for the next World Cup, in 2018.  Finally, if there is to be a suspension of candidacy, as advocated by the chairman of the FIFA compliance committee, the priority must be given to Qatar, a country that funds Islamist terrorism and allows multinationals to practice the modern slavery of thousands of workers on World Cup sites.

name: Ivo BELET
text: – It has been said here many times tonight: sport, and certainly football, has a big social role. I have always argued with great conviction to support this from the political, government- based. Unfortunately, however, with this staggering FIFA cesspool - and I say so - which has now opened up, there is a risk of completely wiping out public support for that political support.  That is why it is our duty to interfere and ensure that these profound reforms at FIFA, which we have been saying for much longer, are now being done quickly and decisively. That is why it is also explicitly appealing to UEFA and the national football associations to take the cow by the horns now. But we also count on you, Commissioner. We are counting on the European Commission and national governments to take the necessary measures, in close cooperation with Interpol, with Europol, with Eurojust, to tackle this corruption and to use the anti-money laundering directive for this purpose, as the President of the Council said earlier.  Football gets a lot of support from all levels of policy, financially as well, and we are absolutely won for that. But that can only be justified if football is governed correctly and transparently. The next few months will have to show whether FIFA can indeed do so through self-regulation. If that is not possible, then the European football federations no longer belong there.  The football supporters - and Commissioner, you yourself said earlier - deserve much better than what they have been through in the last few days and weeks. It is now high time to simply erase the board, to start a white sheet and to give society, and especially the football supporters, a guarantee that football can also be governed properly and correctly on a global level and not as an embarrassing banana republic.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, when is a resignation not a resignation? When it is Sepp Blatter’s. I am disappointed that he will continue to run FIFA until December. For decades we have heard rumours of bribery and corruption at FIFA and yet this man, who has stated that he is more important than many Heads of State, will still be at the helm and will have a major influence in choosing his successor. Therefore I have little confidence that any reform at FIFA will actually happen. The Commission has to take urgent action. FIFA is subject to our regulatory rules. We cannot just abdicate our responsibility and leave it to the US again. The reform that is urgently needed is greater transparency in accounting, an independent audit of the last 10 years, and the adoption of watertight procedures to tackle corruption. We should question why FIFA is established in Switzerland. It cannot just be for tax reasons, can it? If FIFA does not reform, UEFA needs to take action, supported by all the Member States – unlike Blatter’s latest re-election bid: when UEFA called for a vote against him, big Member States like France and Spain refused. I am sure it is nothing to do with the Qatari investments in their country. Is that why they are silent on the 1 200 migrant workers who have lost their lives on the World Cup construction sites in Qatar? For all that we endeavour to raise the profile of the game of football, what we have here is the top body setting the worst possible example, especially for aspiring young footballers.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: – In 1988, the Netherlands became European champion in Germany. I was four years old at the time and I wouldn't really remember that at all. Yet it seems like it was yesterday and as if I was there myself. That's the beauty of football. It gives joy to billions of people, not just in Europe, but around the world. It connects people, it fraternises people. Such a sport, football, deserves to be represented by a transparent, democratic and well-governed football association. The Commissioner has indicated that FIFA does not meet these criteria at all. So a great deal needs to be done and the recent developments and blatter's resignation also provide a unique opportunity to finally come clean.  Several members have already said that we cannot leave this to the Americans and the Swiss, but europe must also show ambition in this. In this respect, I think that both the Council and the Commission are still being a little cautious. I'd expect more of that. We should not reflect once again on the role of the European Union in this case. We need to take action and I have two concrete proposals there.  Commissioner, you yourself have said that FIFA is no longer credible as an international representative of football. As a Parliament, tomorrow we call for the appointed interim President. Would it not be wise for the European Union to suspend its official contacts with FIFA until reforms are carried out, until there is an interim president or a new director?  The second proposal, which has already been mentioned by a number of colleagues: a major investigation in Europe with Eurojust, with Europol, with Interpol, with joint investigation teams, in order to bring out the bottom line in Europe as well.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Minister, there is no doubt that the facts revealed in newspapers all over the world on the management of sport show a very high and widespread level of corruption, especially in which everything and everyone has a price, a price that has an ethical as well as an economic price. In the world, almost 2 billion people are following football, around 400 million European citizens, and it is clear that, if it is confirmed that the last 7 World Cups have been awarded as a result of corruption, it is clear that the confidence of fans and all those who believe in the values of sport will be seriously undermined.  And to this must be added the economic side, a World Cup is a $5 billion business, funded by sponsors, federations, fans, and its conduct must be brought back above all suspicion. It is therefore our duty to be able to impose – I know that there is the independence of the world of football – but we must succeed in imposing greater transparency on FIFA in all its activities, from the election of the president to the mechanism for allocating sporting events, starting with the World Cup. Just as we must demand that the rules of alternation in office, democracy in elections and decisions, transparency and external budgetary control be applied. I call on the Commission to make a serious effort to ensure that these things can happen.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: – Il-futbol huwa sport fuq liema jiddependi l-gťajxien ta' ťafna, speèjalment meta l-ogťla livelli tiegťu żew transformed into global f'komodity. Gťalhekk mhuwiex surprising li l-failures tiegťu jaffettwa third persuni wkoll. L-iskandlu FIFA ma jiddanneżżjax biss lill-FIFA, iżda gťandu ramifikazzjonijiet fuq setturi oťra bťal dik tal-midja, xandir, marketing u jżeffen fin-nofs ukoll is-settur bankarju. Il-futbol gťandu wkoll rwol pubbliku b'valuri soèjali.  L-isports fans, flimkien ma' plejers ekonomici oťra jistťoqqilhom l-ogťla standards ta' integrità fl-isport. Dan konna nafuh qabel ir-revelazzjoni tal-iskandlu FIFA u gťandna nirrikonoxxu li l-Istituzzjonijiet Ewropej diżà varaw diversi miżuri. Iżda l-aťťar revelazzjoni tikxef dejjem aktar l-importanza ta' good governance fl-isport. Hija żaża li ngťidu li hemm bżonn ta' regoli żari fuq l-immaniżjar finanzjarju, transparency u risk management, however hija ťaża oťra li nassiguraw li dawn ir-regoli jiżu infurzati tajjeb sabiex inwarrbu l-korruzzjoni mill-isport.  L-allegazzjonijiet kurrenti jqajmu dubji fuq kemm il-FIFA tista' tiggverna lilha nnifisha, u kemm tista' tibqa' tonqos milli tadotta standards gťoljin ta' good governance. FIFA tidher li hija bbażata fuq self regulation mingťajr checks and balances adegwati. Iżda sports bťall-futbol juri dinamika kummercjali u swieq komparabbli ma' activity ekonomika oťra.  Jekk irridu verament nippreservaw il-kredibilità tal-isport gťall-żenerazzjonijiet future, irridu nieťdu aktar azzjoni. Flimkien gťandna ntennu s-sejťa tagťna gťal aktar transparency u naèèertaw li jkun hemm aktar kontabilità da parti tal-isport.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Mr. President, football is the child of the Industrial Revolution, a sport created by the modern age and planetary promoted by modern communication technologies. The exceptional popularity and mass of football, great marketing and financial value, but also lack of control, made it possible to turn this sport into an interest-level connection between international politics and murky business.  It is sad that such a sport and an inseparable part of our identity becomes synonymous with corruption. Today, the motives of the FIFA investigation should be questioned at least. It's a good thing the investigation is finally even moving. The clues, unfortunately, only confirm any bad assumptions. Corruption disregards activities and national borders. Football is no exception. We also need investigations to continue at national levels, as many have provided legitimacy to FIFA's leadership. I support the initiative to finally clear up the contentious activities in FIFA and UEFA, but also our Croatian Football Federation, because thanks to some of its prominent protagonists it has lost its legitimacy by provoking a boycott and public repulsion. Let's give football back to those who play it and those who enjoy the game!

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, it may be somewhat cynical – but accurate nevertheless – to say that if there was a World Cup for corruption, then FIFA would win it hands down. Certainly, if we are to believe the allegations of USD 150 million in bribes (which may only turn out to be the tip of the iceberg), there is a serious problem with FIFA which, thankfully, now is being investigated. This is terrible, because it is a betrayal of what is called ‘the beautiful game’. For the millions of players, fans, parents, coaches and teachers who give their time at grassroots level on a voluntary basis, the least they can expect is good governance and a good example at the top. They are not getting this now. Hopefully things will change, because they need to change. Two colleagues from Ireland, Diane Dodds and Liadh Ní Riada, have referred to the EUR 5 million given by Mr Blatter to the FAI in a secret deal containing a confidentiality clause which meant that we did not find out about it until recently because of a certain clamour over a World Cup qualifying game. This shows that Mr Blatter saw the vast wealth of FIFA as almost his personal gift to give to subsidiaries when necessary. I was President of the Gaelic Athletic Association in Ireland. It was a great honour and a great responsibility, and it also carries great power. One of the things we do in our organisation is to limit the term of office. I think that is the key here today. If there was a limit, as we have, of 3 years or 5 years, then you would be getting new blood coming through. Corruption, if it occurred, could not be embedded, and certainly what we have seen in FIFA would be averted because, while Mr Blatter has been President for a large number of years, you would have had a change of guard coming forward all the time. I think this is an essential first step for FIFA.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the extension of the Union's competences to sport has also been a success and an advantage for our citizens, European citizens. The educational and social value of sports and the inclusion of sports programmes for the benefit of young people are important and productive facts. The FIFA affair is a serious case of corruption and crime in a discipline, football, which has the largest turnover in the world. What has been tarnished is the very value of sport, as well as the honor of the people involved. Because we're dealing with the scandal here. FIFA, its leaders, have attempted to turn football into a permanent business committee for the benefit of sponsors and marketing. The organisation must now be restructured and external control over activities needs to be rethought. And, please, let's save the value and high meaning of sport! That is the appeal to UEFA and that is also our task now.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Corruption, money laundering, tax evasion: these are the allegations faced by senior FIFA officials. But it is about more than just awarding world cups to Russia or Qatar; it is about marketing rights and possibly purchased votes in the Executive Committee. The question is whether the FIFA leadership has abused the trust of football fans around the world to enrich themselves personally through a system of dependencies and corruption. The investigations by Swiss and US authorities must be supported without reservation. We also need Europol and Interpol and Eurojust. The resignation of Joseph Blatter was overdue, but only a first step towards a radical new beginning for FIFA. An interim president must be prepared to push for deep structural reforms of this second-largest sports federation in the world. Criteria: time limit on the term of office of the members of the Executive Committee and the President, continuous external and independent review of all financial activities and transparent rules for the award of the World Championships. Unfortunately, UEFA, as the European governing body, has only a small share of the vote, but has a special responsibility due to the size of its members. This is especially true for the DFB as the world's largest football association with more than six million members. DFB chief Wolfgang Niersbach presented a 10-point plan today, from respect for human rights in host states to a balanced vote weighting according to the size and relevance of the associations. The sponsors, but also the broadcasters, play an essential role, which must exert their influence in order to speed up the restructuring processes. Special responsibility lies with the public service broadcasters, which co-finance the football system through our fees. Obscure FIFA methods have undermined the integrity of football. We must succeed in refocusing this inspiring sport and its diverse cultural and social dimension.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE). Mr President, what has been revealed in recent times within the F.F.I.A. only causes sadness to all of us who care about the sport.   We must, however, separate any responsibility of the players from football itself. Our message must be clear. Football has nothing to do with corruption. Those who engage with it should be punished by example. It is a social good with a huge influence on the daily lives of millions of people.  As the European Parliament, I believe that we have an obligation not only to demand that the matter be cleared up immediately, but also to press, as far as we are concerned, to proceed with all the necessary reforms for the good of football itself.  But, Mr President, I want to dwell on another point before I close my speech. The recent scandal at the World Football Federation should be an occasion to open up the debate on the significant changes that football needs in general, such as the labour rights of footballers and athletes. It is amazing that, while everyone is talking about football, there is almost no discussion of the real problems of the protagonists. The real protagonists are not only the big stars, they are not just the big teams that we all admire and are glad to see. True protagonists are the millions of children who with a ball in their legs dream at some point to make their dream come true. It is the athletes of smaller teams, but also players of smaller categories, who make football what it really is: the most popular sport on the planet and a global social phenomenon.  What are the rights of these people? What about the thousands of children who, because of a misfortune, will ingloriously end their careers? What do we do about unacceptable practices with regard to players' rights?   Ladies and gentlemen, world football wants change and yes, it needs catharsis at all levels. But it would be unfair if the debate were confined only to the alleged phenomena of corruption. What is important is to see real changes and reforms for the benefit of both the fans and the true protagonists of the sport.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you, Mr Zagorakis, also for your experience.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a woman in charge of FIFA as president would be a wonderful important signal, not least because women are very discriminated against in this area. Finally, unfortunately, in Italy we have also had some very important outrages and insults. So we, at last, are discussing scandals and corruption in the International Football Federation, corruption, bribery for a figure, they say, of about $150 million over 24 years, but it could be many more. There are corruption allegations about the 2018 and 2022 assignments. As far as Russia and Qatar are concerned, however, as you know, with the Treaty of Lisbon in 2009, the European Union acquired specific competence in the field of sport and, above all, specific competence with regard to the integrity of sport, and we must therefore demand maximum transparency, democracy, respect for human rights and legality. Football, because of its popularity and widespread diffusion, has a great social impact and not only. It is a great instrument of integration between citizens and a formidable glue capable of uniting different populations. It is our task to contribute to the defence of the football game and we owe it above all to the young and very young, who with enthusiasm and passion, and often with sacrifices, dedicate their lives to the sport. So defending the honesty of many against the rot of corruption is our moral duty.

name: Herbert REUL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very good one. Football is one of the most wonderful things in the world and it is a disgrace how some officials have dealt with it and what they have done. However, I am at least as annoyed that many – perhaps in all areas too – have intervened far too late. It took a very long time for the American police to take action and then to draw conclusions from it. The dramatic thing for me is that there is an organisation that people have been able to work without the clues, the concerns, the complaints that have also been made public, really having a wide space. In this respect, it is not possible now for Mr Blatter to resign but to remain in office. But an interim chairman really needs to be rebuilt fresh and new. We also need to take a closer look at this. There is no point in replacing one person with another, but structures must be called into question. That is why it is imperative, for example, that the Garcia report should also be made public, so that those who are now looking into reconstruction also know the basics and draw conclusions. I think it is precisely the Europeans who are in demand. How often do we talk about our ambition to stand up for certain values, to stand up for the rule of law, to be against corruption. Have we all carried out our duties to such an extent, including the European Football Association and all its organisations? Or did we not look away from it because it's such a great thing? Have the media actually played their role in the past in terms of enlightenment? Here, too, there are very different things. In part, we have also pushed this forward , and at least we have tolerated it – just now the reference has come – through financial support, even through the media sector. I am grateful that a start has now been made. It just needs to be used resolutely. It is wise for the European Parliament to interfere in this debate with clear demands. But then the football world has to do something. Otherwise, the stakes are greater than the prestige of a single person.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – I support the resolution on the corruption scandal in Fifa, and I think it is right that we in the European Parliament should talk about this problem, because football, which we say is the most important side thing in the world, is much more than one of the sports industries. It is an industry that has now done damage to virtually sport as a whole with this scandal. Football has gained significantly from attractiveness over the past decade, with more and more people monitoring the sport. Today we heard the voice of women that the president of Fifa should be a woman. I, too, was pleased to hear that a very large number of women were watching the Champions League final between Barcelona and Juventus. I think it is right to congratulate these sporting knights on the real demonstration and the feast of football. What has happened among officials, however, casts a bad light and, in its own right, discourages young people who spend much of their time in nature, rather than being locked up in their own rooms, most often by computer, television or some other addiction. These nerd business, which is emerging in football, which is a year after year, has already been mentioned here today, so I firmly believe that it is right to speak out on this and that parliament's voice is also that those who have dealt with these nerd business will be brought where they belong – that is to say, to be convicted and, after all, to pay the price for the damage. they also made football. However, we also see that such a long-term mandate in an area such as being president of Fifa is sometimes similar to some self-reservation in Africa. It is therefore right that something should change in this area, too.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, I fully agree with the Commissioner that FIFA is no longer qualified to run international sport. It needs a complete change. For such a change, first we need to know the full truth. The findings of the Garcia Report should be published in full. Second, the resignation of Mr Blatter was too little, too late, and it is outrageous that he should continue as President for a further six months. An interim leader should immediately be elected to replace him. Third, justice does not arise from injustice. If it is proved that the appointment of Russia and Qatar as hosts of the World Cup has been linked to bribes or any form of corruption, the respective decisions should be annulled without hesitation. It is morally devastating if decisions emerging from corruption are implemented under the pretext of having already been made.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the recent revelations about fifa's top brass report payments and bribes, rampant and systemic corruption, the development of which has been contributed by at least two generations of executives who have abused their positions for more than twenty years by pocketing millions of dollars in bribes. Personally, I hope that the ongoing investigations will succeed in erasing corruption from the world of football and bringing about a review of FIFA's structure, codes and operational practices. If decisive action is not taken, the events we are discussing risk tarnishing the image of the sport as a whole, which I would very much regret, particularly in relation to the hundreds of thousands of amateur clubs and the millions of passionate volunteers.  The Union of European Football Federations and the National Football Federation have an obligation to play their part in intensifying this reform process and I hope that it will introduce mandate limits for members of FIFA's executive committee and lead to improved transparency, both as regards decision-making processes and the way in which Federation officials are remunerated. And the European institutions and the Member States must do everything possible to restore the credibility and attractiveness of this movement.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. President, sport has long since become a big business, which many people have never accepted. Those in the professionalization of sport see the loss of sportsmanship and betrayal of its true purposes. I think professionalization has done a lot of good. For example, it has allowed many talented people to live off their talent, but also others by linking their industry to earning, growing and hiring football. But just by becoming a global business, football has begun to arouse discontent in many who once enjoyed it, especially in these turbulent times when many citizens have a hard time living. That is why football officials have an enormous responsibility to preserve the integrity of the sport and to bring it closer to small people with their behavior.  Unfortunately, FIFA is evidently going in the wrong direction and I believe there will be no end to affairs here. Those participating in them should be severely punished and their decisions based on illegal acts annulled.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: " Mr. President, let's be clear, football is a hotbed of corruption. Black funds, sponsors, everything we know as something that's illegal, it's all about football. It's not just the big leagues: both the second league and the third division and the fourth division and the fifth league, etc. and FIFA is just iceberg, nothing else. We have to be realistic, we have to talk about it because that's the way it is in my country, unfortunately. Croatia is a great football team, we have great players, but unfortunately we have certainly corruption and black funds and all the things I talked about. But, Dear Mr. Commissioner, we also have mechanisms. Member states help our football associations. Cities, municipalities, regions help footballers and football clubs. Let's start cleaning everything from the beginning. FIFA is first in line.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Frankly, I am a little surprised at the amazement of this House. Of FIFA, it seems to me personally the most obvious scandal, a bit the discovery of hot water. The 7 FIFA executives arrested, the two vice-presidents, but really, did we notice that today colleagues? Does anyone really remember that back in 2002, the vice-president of CAF said he had received an offer of $100,000 to vote for Blatter for his second term? So the revelations of Chuck Blazer, of Jack Warner, frankly should come as no surprise to us. And they are people who have no qualms about taking millions of euros away from the reconstruction of Haiti, let alone taking a bribe for a World Cup in Qatar or Russia.  Someone said before that he would like a woman, someone else said a man, I would like to head FIFA especially an honest person, someone who still get emotional about a game in a suburban field, not the usual business committee shark. And I ask you, please, to use our coordinating competence in sport to kick the corruption of football.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The U.S. Department of Justice is investigating FIFA for unbridled systemic and deep-rooted corruption over a period of several decades. The FBI is on. That is a good thing, because without the American authorities, this scandal would never have come to light. But the U.S. investigation is also political needle-sticks against Russia and Qatar, which can now look forward to the 2018 and 2022 World Cups. We should not be naive here. The Frankfurter Allgemeine recently headlined and said that FIFA is corrupt was one of the greatest open secrets in the world. The FIFA scandal makes it clear that money laundering, corruption and bribery must have no place in sport. Effective anti-money laundering rules must also be applied in sport, as provided for in the 2007 White Paper on Sport. Commissioner Navracsics said today that FIFA is no longer fit to lead international football. In other words, in addition to the political dimension we are addressing, there is also a need for reforms at the level of this association. And such reforms must lead to the investigation of the allegations of corruption, to control the flow of money, to transparency in the awarding of world championships and to respect human rights. That is important, and then the values will be restored.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I think we have just sent an unequivocal message from this Chamber tonight, which is about FIFA and FIFA’s integrity. I think FIFA’s integrity needs to be restored and people’s trust in it rebuilt. It is unequivocal and there is a consensus. On the other hand, we have to respect some things as limits for our action. The very first limit is the principle of subsidiarity. We have to take action under the principle of subsidiarity. That means that we have no room for legislation on sport at European level, but we have to support, foster and encourage closer cooperation in sport issues. The other one is the autonomy of the sport. Let me make this clear: FIFA is not a European organisation. It is not only an autonomous organisation but a worldwide organisation. FIFA’s problem is not only Europe’s problem; it is the problem of world sport, of world football. The European Union can play a big role in restoring trust in FIFA, but we are not the only players and we are outsiders. Are we outsiders? Yes and no. We have tools and we have instruments to help restore trust in FIFA. We can help those Member States, those associations and those players that are interested in rebuilding FIFA and FIFA’s role. We are just now working in a working group on good governance and we have strong allies in that work. We have stakeholders with whom we are in close cooperation and I think that we have good results and we can continue along this path in the future as well. You are about to adopt a good resolution. I fully agree with the content of the resolution. It is a powerful message with strong words. I fully support this text and I support all your efforts and I ask you for your support for all my efforts in rebuilding the integrity and trust of sport and sports associations in the future.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I have listened to carefully to the views expressed during the course of the debate. It is clear that the issue at the heart of the debate has left no one indifferent. We all agree that there must be a change and that we have to give a red card to cheating, doping, match-fixing, corruption and other crimes. FIFA is at the centre of a criminal investigation, and this is worrying. We hope that the investigation and trial will be fair and speedy. Many of you have correctly pointed out the principle of autonomy in sport. Indeed, the responsibility for good governance and the proper functioning of sports organisations lies with the international sporting organisations themselves. At the same time, you are right that we should look into the better use of the existing framework. Matters such as good governance principles, auditing rules, combating corruption and the protection and promotion of workers’ rights are important. However, we should not over-regulate. We must remember that only true will and commitment can bring these rules into practice. A key word here is good governance. I hope FIFA will draw conclusions from the current situation. The European Union will follow closely the development of the events, and I am sure the EU sports ministers, meeting informally on 6 and 7 July in Luxembourg, will address this issue.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I have received seven motions for resolutions pursuant to Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 11 June, at 12.00 p.m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: in writing. – The endemic corruption in FIFA is tarnishing the image of the whole sport. We need to send a strong message to FIFA that they cannot continue to get away with dragging the ‘beautiful game’ through the mud. I would like to urge all EU countries to withdraw their national teams from both the 2018 and 2022 World Cup tournaments unless FIFA cleans up its act. Sepp Blatter must go immediately, and whoever replaces him must re-run the Qatar and Russia World Cup bidding process in a fair and transparent way.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
