text: in writing. – The existence of corruption at the highest levels of the football world, with football now being the ‘world’s game’, is a proven fact that must be condemned by all means. This endemic corruption not only compromises the quality of play on the field, but reduces fan support for the sport and tarnishes the beauty of the game. FIFA is still structured in a way that fosters corruption: it is clear that the decision—making system must be revised. It is time to reform FIFA, creating a separate institution that functions with transparency and oversight, and also to deal with the broader problems that the World Cup creates in hosting Nations, such as the increase in public debt, evictions and militarisation of public spaces. These revelations are very discouraging for the millions of football fans who deserve a clean, transparent sport. But they are also an opportunity to really raise the international football authority up to the level of the sport it represents.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Writing. – The corruption scandals, related arrests and resignations that have erupted in recent weeks have shaken FIFA and foreshadow the possibility of the renewal and purification of the organisation. At the same time, we must not forget that in Qatar, which hosted the 2022 World Cup, guest workers working on stadium construction live and work in inhumane conditions, resulting in the deaths of more than 1,000 people. It is common practice to take away passports from workers, not to be paid for months, to get adequate amounts of drinking water while working in desert heat, and to live in overcrowded workers' hostels in conditions unworthy of humans. If no meaningful improvement occurs, some estimates suggest that up to 4,000 people could die by the end of World Cup-related construction. The European Union cannot remain silent, we cannot stand by and watch the rights guaranteed by human rights conventions constantly being violated! We can't leave under the responsibility of the sponsoring companies. How long do these companies give their names and money to modern-day slavery? It is intolerable that in the 21st century, in one of the richest countries in the world, our fellow human beings are practically enslaved and ruthlessly exploited! The Commission and the Member States must act immediately to ensure that human rights are fully respected, and we must set an example. If Qatar refuses to take meaningful and immediate action, I do not consider the boycott of the Qatar World Cup to be unjustified.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Sport is one of the areas of human activity that connects people the most. By defending its true essence, which is honesty in the spirit of sporting rivalry, we defend generally accepted ethical and moral rules. Corruption is a denial of the essence of sport and has an impact not only on the legal and financial area, but also on the social area. It undermines the trust of citizens and makes them witnesses of fraud involuntary. The youngest participants of this show, to whom through sport we want to convey values such as tolerance, teamwork, courage, firmness, perseverance in pursuit of the goal, get lessons that do not count man and his work, but profit and win at all costs. It's not just immoral and dishonest, it's just a crime that's punishable. Today's idea of sport, its social value, is more like an entertainment industry or a millionaire sport than a sport of millions. Therefore, no one doubts that structural reforms in FIFA are a necessity. Work and actions on good governance in the framework of the European Union Work Plan in the field of sport should also be accelerated in cooperation with national associations.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. – FIFA has become a state in state. The various national authorities, international organisations and the EU have let FIFA become an arbitrary monopoly entity that abuses its dominant position on the sports market. Because sport, especially football, has been commercialised. This global football federation has become a commercial monopoly that does billions of euros in business, manages television rights, sponsors, donations, etc. It commissions the organisation of the World Cup in various countries, without transparency, without guarantees, and there are allegations of bribery and corruption.  We call on the Commissioner for Competition as the pre-eminent antitrust regulator under Article 102 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU to initiate control proceedings against FIFA for abuse of a dominant position within the common market. That's the only way to get the knife to the bone. That is why we are going to put a question to the Commission to get a red card for FIFA as well.

name: Julia PITERA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The world's media reported that a former fifa executive committee member, found guilty of corruption, money laundering and tax avoidance in 2013, had cooperated with the US justice system. As a result, more than a dozen FIFA activists accused of taking bribes were detained. Others - among them the former FIFA vice president - are wanted by watch lists. Investigators suspect that over a 24-year period, high-ranking FIFA officials have accepted about $150 million in bribes. The media has long reported on corruption in the football world. However, they were mostly left without the reaction of the FIFA authorities and adequate consequences. It is hardly surprising that international opinion, without accepting this state of affairs, at the same time continued in the belief of the quiet affairs of the outside world. This belief was confirmed by the decisions of the FIFA authorities blocking reforms of national football organisations. For example, in 2008, at the request of the Polish Minister of Sport, the arbitration court of the Polish Olympic Committee introduced a Commissioner to the Polish Football Association. The Commissioner was supposed to heal the situation in PZPN after the disclosure of further cases of corruption in this organization. Two weeks after that decision, FIFA threatened poland with a suspension from international competitions if the Commissioner is not withdrawn from pzpn. This example shows that, in addition to law enforcement investigations, there is a need for steadfast solidarity between states in effectively opposing pathologies in football.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I invite you to vote on this resolution, which I have co-signed, which calls for the immediate replacement of the President of the International Football Association (FIFA), Joseph Blatter, so that the necessary reforms can be carried out urgently within the organisation.  The recent allegations of corruption, coupled with the inhumane working conditions on the Qatar 2022 World Cup, show the world how indispensable it is to look at the functioning of FIFA and shed light on what can be blamed on it.  Football is a sport and I am glad that it can be a unifying celebration for nations, but by no means can it be at the cost of the blood of workers and in defiance of rights and duties. It is not just a question of credibility. It is nothing more or less about dignity. A value that doesn't trade.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is an oral question to the Council on sport and human rights also in the context of the Baku European Games (2015/2720(RSP)) (B8-0556/2015).

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: Author. – Mr President, is there a link between sport and respect for human rights?  The Olympic movement is based on three fundamental values: excellence to give our best, friendship above all difference and respect – respect for one's neighbour, respect for fundamental ethical principles. This oral question to the Council, which I am presenting on behalf of the Subcommittee on Human Rights and the Committee on Foreign Affairs, aims to make us reflect, reflect on the growing discrepancy between the values that inspire sport and what many major sporting events become, in reality: a huge accumulation of interests, both economic and political; a tool for face-washing of regimes that are far from being considered democratic; a missed opportunity to really move towards greater respect for human rights.  Sport, such a powerful tool, cannot live outside the defence of human rights and a commitment to freedom of expression. Sport cannot be blind to what happens where it celebrates its great events, because that blindness makes us all complicit.  These are the first European Games in history, promoted by the European Olympic Committee and, therefore, it is Europe's responsibility not to be complicit in a country, of a regime that systematically violates the values we intend to defend.  We cannot ignore what is happening in Azerbaijan, and these are the 2015 Baku Games. Europe cannot come forward in Baku to applaud, while we are aware of the level of repression in Baku against whom it sees the voice against the Government. It is not just the major human rights organizations that Amnesty International has been prevented from entering Azerbaijan today – the Council of Europe, the United Nations, the OSCE have also told us.  There is a very clear consensus on this situation. Azerbaijan is relentlessly persecuted against human rights defenders and the preparation of these Games has only served to increase this repression. Civil society has been systematically eradicated in that country, annulled, silenced; and the European Union and its Member States say nothing. There are no more organizations working on human rights; the ones in their twenties have been closed.  In Azerbaijan you can safely practice sport freely in large top-notch facilities; but if you criticize the government or defend human rights, you have two options: jail or exile. Because if you criticize electoral processes, such as Anar Mammadli and Elnur Mammadov, you go to jail; if you document the cases of political prisoners, as Intigam Aliyev or Khadija Ismayilova did, you go to jail. If you don't resign yourself to staying silent, just raising your voice, as Leyla Yunus and her husband Arif Yunus did, you're doomed to the worst treatment. You see, President: Leyla Yunus was a finalist for the Sakharov Prize and this Parliament has made a commitment to it. He's about to be in prison for a year. All this time in pre-trial detention, without being tried, in prison, in very poor health. Her husband was also imprisoned: we know nothing about him.  His daughter Dinara, who is here right now, in this House, and who only has them in the world, is wondering why we do nothing. Perhaps the Council can give us some answer today, it can give some answer to Dinara Yunus.  What is the position of the Council and the High Representative in this relationship between sport and respect for human rights and democracy? Shouldn't the Council take advantage of the forthcoming Baku Games as a unique opportunity for the European Union and its Member States to collectively and forcefully defend human rights and universal values? Shouldn't respect for the basics: human rights be indispensable when deciding where major sporting events are held?  These European Games are less than 48 hours away. From here I want to demand the release of all the prisoners of conscience who today suffer from the lack of freedom in Azerbaijan. It is a task in which we can all push -European governments, this Parliament, athletes, fans. What better occasion than when the whole of Europe and the world set their sights on Azerbaijan, we demonstrate our commitment to the universal values we share! What better than to allow all human rights defenders, journalists, imprisoned activists, to enjoy this great occasion for Azerbaijan in freedom!

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the issue of sports and ethics is indeed topical, as we have seen in the previous debate. Now we turn to another sport—related issue: the European games in Baku. As I said during the previous debate, sporting events are an important economic activity, creating jobs and attracting investments. Many sporting events and world championships are being hosted outside the EU and, in particular, in emerging economies. This tendency has only increased since 2008, since when most of the world’s major economies, including the EU, have been obliged to pursue a policy of fiscal restraint. This means that issues such as those raised by the honourable Member will continue to be high on the political agenda. The oral question on which I am now intervening is related to the relationship between sport and human rights, and this relationship should not be underestimated. I would also like to recall that sporting events bring people and communities together and bridge divides. They provide an excellent opportunity to promote democratic values. To this aim, in May 2014, the Council adopted a second EU work plan for sport, under which a set of guiding principles relating to democracy, human rights and labour rights is going to be prepared, in particular in the context of the procedures for awarding major sports events. Work on these principles should be completed later this year. In this context, future Council presidencies will be in a position to decide how best to take forward the role on good governance achieved under the two EU work plans. The aim is to ensure that international sports organisations operate in a way which continues to ensure the support of EU citizens and governments. As regards specifically Azerbaijan, the Eastern Partnership is the main framework within which we set relations with that country. As you know, the most recent Eastern Partnership summit took place last month in Riga. The summit’s joint declaration contains all the participants’ joint commitment to strengthen democracy, the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms, which are the principles at the heart of their partnership. Moreover, the summit’s participants reaffirmed that people-to-people contacts are one of the important modalities of the Eastern Partnership and, in this context, the leaders looked forward to the first ever European Games to be hosted in Azerbaijan in June. It is true that there are concerns about the state of democracy and the human rights situation in Azerbaijan. However, isolation of the country might not be the best response. Dialogue and engagement are important in promoting human rights. I hope the period of the Baku games can be a window of opportunities for progress in this field. Indeed, I am aware of your concerns regarding, in particular, the detention of human rights defenders, activists and journalists, as expressed in this oral question and in a letter that several of you addressed recently to the High Representatives and to ministers. I share these concerns. The EU is raising its concerns on human rights with the Azerbaijani authorities directly and publicly. It has been calling for the fair treatment and release of detained individuals. During their visits in recent months, Commissioner Hahn and EU Special Representative Lambrinidis have raised these issues repeatedly, sometimes publicly. We hope that the Baku games will be an opportunity for the Azerbaijani authorities to show their progressive commitment to democratic values and human rights, and that they will not miss this opportunity. I thank you for your attention and I look forward to your views during this very important debate.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the " Mr. President! Dear colleagues! We all know that major sporting events, as well as sport in general, are not just the focus of sports fans. We know that sport and major sporting events have significant potential, which contributes significantly to the protection and promotion of human rights. The international community must therefore seize this opportunity to make demands to improve the human rights situation in countries that wish to organise prestigious international sporting events. I firmly believe that we must not allow the authoritarian regimes of the world to use major sporting events to consolidate their power and to shine feathers, especially if these sporting events give the name of Europe.  Europe means not only a certain geography, it also means certain values – human rights, civil liberties and the rule of law. It is therefore at least ironic that the first European games take place in a country with almost the lowest level of democratic civil liberties between all the Member States of the Council of Europe, in a country where the Office of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe is forced to close a week before the European Games begin.  I am convinced that European leaders should also ask themselves about their attitude to the world football championship in a country where political opponents are killed and which has illegally been aneced by the territory of another European country.  In the meantime, I would like to use this podium to send a message to politically imprisoned people in Azerbaijan. You know, the fact that European games are taking place in Baku does not mean that Europe has forgotten about you and betrayed you. And I will name the political prisoners to whom I want to send this message: Leyla Yunus, Arif Yunus, Rasul Jafarov, Intigam Aliyev, Khadija Ismayilova, Orkhan Eyybzade, Elvin Karimov, Faraj Karimov, Siraj Karimov, Mammad Azizov, Rashad Hasanov, Rashadat Akhundov, Ilkin Rustamzade, Omar Mammadov, Hilal Mammadov, Abdul Abilov, Rashad Ramazanov, Ilgar Mammadov, Tofig Yagublu, Yadigar Sadigov, Anar Mammadli, Bashir Suleymanli, Emin Huseynov. You are not forgotten, you are in our minds and hearts. Thank!

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for several years now, major sporting events have been moving eastwards, offering authoritarian systems the opportunity to increase their international reputation, no matter if the host towns do not respect human rights. Sports bodies which influence allocation decisions, such as FIFA, seem to be more interested in the economic resources of these countries than in anything else.  The next games are another example of this constant, they will take place in Baku, the capital of Azerbaijan, a country whose economy is travelling at a high rate, thanks to the huge oil and gas fields, but which does not seem to be as advanced in terms of human rights. In recent years, particularly during the last twelve months, expressing dissent has become very risky in this country, due to an increasingly intolerant system of criticism that is putting pressure on a large number of journalists and human rights activists. I would like to mention, for example, the case of Leila Younis, one of the best-known human rights defenders in Azerbaijan and one of the three finalists of the last European Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought. She is currently being held on charges of high treason, fraud, forgery and tax evasion. The wave of repression has also hit foreigners: journalists, members of non-governmental organisations and UN officials have experienced first-hand the intimidation, harassment and obstruction that the Azerbaijani authorities have put in place to stifle criticism.  At present, therefore, there seems to be no room for opposition in Azerbaijan. The international spotlight, which has been on the capital Baku since 12 June, is therefore a unique opportunity that the European Union and its Member States should seize in order to collectively defend human rights and promote universal values. The European Union, through the High Representative, should call for the release of all political prisoners. I believe that athletes must also make a real commitment to the issue of human rights, raising these issues with local organisers and athletes and using their popularity to support those who have been unjustly deprived of their freedom.  Finally, in more general terms, it would be perfectly desirable for the High Representative to push the International Olympic Committee, the European Olympic Committees and the other major sports federations to include respect for human rights in the list of basic requirements to be met for hosting international sporting events and to integrate these requirements into the decision-making processes of sports federations.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Since 1951 there have been the Pan American Games and the Asian Games, since 1965 the Africa Games, and from 2015 there are the European Games. A glorious idea by Patrick Hickey, the head of the European Olympic Committee, together with Asad Rachimov, the Minister of Sport of Azerbaijan. Not coincidentally, the premiere of the 2015 European Games was awarded? Azerbaijan! Not coincidentally, which country bears all the costs of this otherwise more than controversial sporting event? Azerbaijan! We have just discussed FIFA and how we bring real values and the ideal of the honourable businessman back into professional sport. Now we are talking about the new small offshoot of the Olympic Games: all this in one country – and I quote the German weekly Die Zeit – 'where criticism does not have a voice in which human rights are obviously trampled underfoot'. International prestige is important to Azerbaijan, not only since the Eurovision Song Contest was held. Baku will also use the Olympic flame to put the country in a good light. Baku promises us magical games. Let us ensure that, in the end, there are three victors in particular on the podium: freedom, democracy and justice.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the European Games in Baku raise the human rights situation in Azerbaijan. This also happened when Baku had Eurovision in 2012. There is much to improve on the human rights situation in Azerbaijan. I believe and hope that the organisation of the Games in Baku will promote the country's openness and, sooner or later, human rights.  Sporting competitions and cultural events are held continuously in countries where human rights violations occur. I do not believe in isolation policy, but in cooperation, and human rights are best promoted through dialogue. It is appropriate for the European Parliament to debate human rights, such as the suspicions of corruption in FIFA just now, and sport. It is difficult to come up with a better forum than Parliament for such a debate. Citizens of 28 countries are represented in this House. I understand very well that the International Olympic Committee and other sporting organisations avoid taking a position on policy. Sporting events are supposed to unite, not tear.  I am opposed to the death penalty, but if the death penalty were an obstacle to the organisation of international sporting events, we would not be able to allow sporting games to take hold, even in the United States. I'm not going to Baku to watch these games, but I want to wish the organizers and athletes well. I also hope that this will strengthen human rights in Baku. Society is strong when it is fair to its citizens and respects everyone's human rights.  (The speaker promised to answer the blue card question under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Blue card question. Thank you, Mr President, thank you, My colleague, for accepting this question. The question I wanted to ask you is this: you said in your speech earlier that this can be a great opportunity for Azerbaijan, precisely to improve its respect for human rights. You do not agree with me, if I tell you that it would have been much more appropriate, to give it to you if anything once you had respected human rights. So, if anything, once it has taken really concrete steps in this direction or, as is often the case and is also the case in certain latitudes of this Parliament, are the principles always applied in a convenient way?

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: answer to the blue card question. – Parliament has not given these games, that is what other parties have decided. But I hope that the fact that human rights will be discussed will contribute, in the long term and hopefully also in the short term, to respect for human rights.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, in a few hours the opening ceremony of the first European Games will be held. They will take place in Baku, Azerbaijan - what a symbol! Ilham Aliyev has ruled the country with an iron fist since 2003 and intends to make it a showcase to restore the coat of arms of his regime. Almost half of the state budget would have been devoted to it. But human rights defenders, who denounce this situation, come to disrupt its beautiful scenario. The bank accounts of NGOs have been frozen, their lawyers harassed, their leaders imprisoned. One of the most well-known cases is that of Leyla Yunus, a vehement critic of the government, who was arrested in July 2014, days after calling for a boycott of the games. She was, indeed, one of the finalists for the Sakharov Prize. His pre-trial detention must officially end after the games; funny coincidence. Her condition is of concern, she does not have access to the medicines she needs, she has lost 16 kg since her arrest. We promised to monitor his situation. We can also mention the lawyer Intigam Aliyev, Anar Mammadli, the journalist Khadija Ismailova, Emin Huseynov, a refugee at the Swiss embassy, and many others. Madam Minister, you are telling us that you hope that dialogue with the Azeri authorities will improve the human rights situation. Negotiations on the Association Agreement have stalled for three years. What miracle do you expect in the coming hours? You are announcing a framework for the next presidency. That is not the answer we are waiting for. You're telling us that you hope the prisoners will be treated well. They are rights defenders, journalists, NGO representatives who are in prison. They must be demanded for their immediate release. Your answer, Madam Minister, who puts the question of sport first on the economic front, is vague and cannot satisfy me. I am in favour of an institutional boycott of these games, as many NGOs are calling for. This is the best way not to endorse the plan.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. The first European Games take place in a country with an authoritarian regime that is locking up the critics. Sport should actually unite and not divide people, it should be fun, even in its own country. This is not the case in Azerbaijan. This is not the case for dozens of human rights activists; they are in prison simply because they have called for freedom of the press and freedom of assembly and for criticising this regime. Two of them are Leyla and Arif Yunus, the parents of Dinara Yunus, who is here with us today and whom I would like to welcome here. Because she wants to see her parents alive again and embrace them. Or Rasul Jafarov, who organized "Sing for Democracy" before the 2012 Song Contest and is now in prison for it, among other things. Members from seven political groups have joined forces to call for the unconditional release of all these human rights activists. And we have demanded that no one from the Commission, the Council or the governments of the Member States or other high-ranking representatives attend the opening alongside President Aliyev. And do you know what we are experiencing now? People from Amnesty International, activists and activists are not even allowed to enter Baku. They will be returned to the airport. And what does the Austrian Second President of the National Council do? There are no ministers going there. But the Second President of the National Council, Kopf, I have learned today, goes with an economic delegation to be there. And he will award the Austrian Cross of Honour for Science and The Arts to a Deputy Minister of the Regime. This is scandalous! And it is a knee-jerk fall in front of a regime that tramples on human rights and on which we are dependent because we need the gas. I call on the Austrian Second President of the National Council to make the journey on one condition: the immediate release of the political prisoners, so that Dinara Yunus can also support her parents alive again! And if that doesn't happen, cancel this trip. As Europeans, we owe this to the human rights activists in Baku and Azerbaijan.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, as we sit here debating Azerbaijan’s human rights record, stating that they should meet similar standards to those set in western EU Member States, it is easy to forget that they provide a judge who sits at the European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) just across the river from us here in Strasbourg. In fact, he has done so for the last 12 years and, so far as I am aware, no one has called for his removal nor had any reason to do so. Although I do not regard ECHR membership as a defining characteristic in identifying adherence to human rights, would it not be hypocritical of the European Union to, on the one hand, accept into EU law judgments of the ECHR that have been handed down by Azerbaijan’s representative whilst, on the other, refusing to acknowledge that Azerbaijan seeks to fulfil its obligations towards the international community? I do understand the serious concerns being raised in this Chamber during this debate. However, sporting events such as the forthcoming Baku Games in Azerbaijan, as pointed out by the Council, are a great way to bring countries closer together. Indeed, what better and more peaceful way to continue to encourage Azerbaijan in its engagement with the rest of the world? Azerbaijan, to my mind, should be commended for the manner in which its Muslim, Jewish and Christian citizens have built a largely peaceful society. There are few places in that region with such a record. By some standards, one could argue that Azerbaijan is a success on this issue alone. Sport is a means by which to communicate with those with whom we do not share a language. I well remember, as a youngster, sporting tournaments which opened my mind to the names and flags of other countries, helping me to expand my knowledge of our world and the people in it. Why deny today’s youngsters the opportunity to learn about Baku and Azerbaijan?

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – The first European Games under the auspices of the European Olympic Committee will take place in Baku, Azerbaijan. The Olympic Charter contains the principles of the International Olympic Movement, which consist in understanding sport as an instrument of harmonious human development with a vision of promoting peace in societies and respect for human dignity. The rules apply both to the sports competition itself and to the entire organizational side of each sporting event. There are fears that the Azerbaijani authorities will try to use the Olympic sporting event to strengthen the international image of their policies without solving human rights violations. The detentions of social activists, journalists and human rights defenders and NGOs signal the progressive shrinking of civil liberties in the public sphere. The Azerbaijani authorities have forced many activists to suspend their activities and to leave the country.  These authorities must stop persecuting and intimidating civil society organisations, opposition politicians and independent journalists, and to refrain from disrupting and undermining their valuable work for the development of democracy in this country. With such a large sporting holiday as the European Games, the eyes of the whole world will be on Azerbaijan. This is therefore an excellent opportunity for the country's government to reform human rights. Sport plays an important role in European society. This is an area that can make a significant contribution to improving respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. Sport regulates social behaviour and creates a sense of belonging within the community, which in turn leads to the strengthening of democracy.  Upcoming international sporting events will be an important and sensitive choice for the European Union. It is important that sports federations, with their principle of autonomy, take into account human rights issues when it comes to choosing the host of major sporting events. The Games should take place in a sporting spirit, but also in a spirit of democracy and of all values.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the With the european Olympic Games, Azerbaijan wants to highlight its European identity. Aliyev can cost a lot: six billion dollars, free tickets for the athletes. However, when it comes to human rights, this European identity is of little value, and the European Convention on Human Rights is being trampled underfoot in that country. Human rights campaigners are hindered, persecuted, end up in prison, including Leyla and Aris Yunus, who we have proposed for the Sakharov Prize. Leyla is in danger of death and we all want the release of all political prisoners. I would also hope that these Olympic Games will not be opened until Leyla and her husband are released on humanitarian grounds.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – At the moment, The Vice-President of this Parliament, Mr Czarnecki, should be speaking, but unfortunately he has landed in hospital, so let me replace him. The European Games, which start in Azerbaijan in two days' time, are an opportunity that all parties to the dispute around this event can and should seize. Sport should unite, not divide, and we have seen many times how this simple principle allows us to tame the greatest conflicts. Of course, problems cannot be ignored, but we must remember that Azerbaijani democracy is young and needs time to mature. Let us observe, advise, share our experiences, but let us not condemn and deny anyone the opportunity to experience sporting emotions because of the political differences that they are.  For the European Union, Azerbaijan is an important partner in troubled times, including through the Eastern Partnership. We discussed today a report on the situation in the Black Sea basin. It shows that we need friends in the region to defend our common security. Without Azerbaijan, this will not work. I wish all participants, supporters, that the European Games in Baku will bring a lot of sporting excitement and allow Azerbaijan to open up to what Europe has the best to offer: democracy and human rights.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, Azerbaijan is a country with a rich history and a specific national culture. For many years it was part of the Soviet Union, and today it is looking for its identity and its own political presence. Azerbaijan's ambitions to play a serious and visible role in Europe are not only confirmed by Baku's drive for partnership with the European Union and even a deepening of integration processes, but are also illustrated by their vivid bid to host the first summer European Olympics. For this initiative, Azerbaijan has invested €10 billion in the more than 10,000 volunteers have joined the organization.  Of course, Europe has its principles, rules and criteria, and we must not turn a blind eye to any deviation from the principles of democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights. However, this should not make us irreconcilable adversaries and we should not be treated stigmatly or as a factor of last resort, Mr President, but, on the contrary, in partnership to solve democratic tasks.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá sé an-náireach cad atá ag titim amach san Asarbaiseáin agus tá sé thar a bheith tábhachtach go gcáintear é.  Le tacaíocht chorparáideach ón dtionscal ola agus gan mórán baol pionóis, tá an réimeas san Asarbaiseáin ag leanúint ar aghaidh lena ionsaithe ar chearta an duine. Tá siad ag cur gníomhaígh pholaitiúla agus gníomhaígh ar son chearta an duine, iriseoirí agus acadóirí ina measc, sa phríosún. Tá sé soiléir go bhfuilid ag déanamh iarracht ar shaoirse cainte a ghiorrú agus an freasúra a scriosadh. I súile an réimis, tabharfaidh na cluichí dlisteanacht dá gcuid gníomhaíochtaí agus tuairimí frith-dhaonlathacha. Tá sé scannalach nár bhris an Coiste Oilimpeach Eorpach an ciúnas go dtí seo. Ní féidir linn glacadh leis seo, agus tá sé práinneach go dtabharfaimis tosaíocht don mhéid atá ag titim amach san Asarbaiseáin. Ba mhaith liom an deis seo a thógaint inniu chun rialtas na hAsarbaiseáine a cháineadh go láidir de dheascaibh an chinnidh a ghlacadar chun cosc a chur ar Amnesty International cuairt a thabhairt ar an Asarbaiseáin roimh na cluichí. Ba chóir dóibh náire a bheith orthu leo féin.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the When it comes to sport and human rights, it is crucial to ask the question of the responsibility of major sports federations. Whether it is FIFA, the Olympic Committee or other federations, their power of action, their influence on governments is far too great for them to be allowed to see themselves as apolitical actors. It is clearly their human rights responsibility to think about what they can do within their means and then act accordingly. The timing of the award is decisive. The procurement process needs to be fundamentally reformed. In addition to technical and economic elements, human rights aspects must also be included in the assessment of the candidate countries. The grading of a candidate country must incorporate measurable social and human rights standards, such as press freedom indexes or quantifiable assessments by international human rights bodies. It is also necessary to assess the impact of organising a major sporting event on the human rights situation. In Azerbaijan, free reporting before and during the Baku Games was restricted. Azerbaijan is already ranked 162nd out of 180 in the press freedom rankings. And there is no sign that the politically non-violent prisoners will be released. That is why I also appeal to the high-level political representatives of the EU institutions and the Member States to stay away from the opening ceremonies as a visible protest against the serious human rights violations in Azerbaijan.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is the second time today that we have spoken about sport, unfortunately in order to deplore the violation of precisely those values that it should defend. The first European games are made in Baku: those who start well are halfway through the work. There is no shortage of money, of course: 6 400 athletes, 20 sports, 18 facilities; who knows, if among these disciplines, there will also be the launch of the barrel of oil or the thousand cubic meters of gas. Because I think they are the only ones that interest many and too many in this Parliament and also outside. It is a pity that so many people forget that Azerbaijan has also acceded to the ECHR, but it does not respect the provisions of that convention in the slightest. Too bad they also forgot about Rasul Jafarov, who forgot about Giorgi Gogia, left at the airport without even being able to enter, thus leaving Human Rights Watch out. It is a pity that many others also forget about Leyla Yunus, who in April 2014 was arrested and detained in conditions absolutely incompatible with the very serious pathology, the diabetes from which she suffers, among other finalists of the Sakharov Prize.  Un democratic elections, journalists arrested, torture and those who have more. Sport and human rights, ladies and gentlemen, I do not think we can sell off for 2 barrels of oil, let alone 4 cubic metres of gas. Europe has done nothing, or rather has done absolutely not do enough to demand a reaction from Azerbaijan and then to allow it to play these games in a serious way. If we shut up today, we are feeding the idea of impunity, we are feeding in their conviction the fact that so much our dignity, our values can be bought so much per kilo. Sport has the power to change the world, to unite people, it speaks a language that everyone understands. Sport can create hope where there was only despair before, Nelson Mandela.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I will be good, when you preside over the President, I will always be good, I promise you. But hearing these comments, I have to say, but when they did the Olympics in China, who stood up and said they shouldn't do the Olympics in China? Is there Communism – you talked about fascism, racism, Putin, now Azerbaijan – and Communism? Dear gentlemen, what is communism, what does China do? Isn't there the death penalty in China? Children don't work, they kill them! Nothing, you forget! Instead of Azerbaijan, we need to tell everything and more. I am a friend of Azerbaijan, I am happy to be, it is a moderate Islamic state that is to be taken as an example and so I think it is right to play the games there, it is right to open up to Azerbaijan. That is right, because there are certainly important energy potentials too, but if we always continue to use malice to say that everyone else is scary, they suck, why? We may not live in a dictatorship, where there may not be the dead, where there may not be things, so to speak in the open, but they destroy people, they destroy society, they destroy businesses, and that is called Europe in some respects. So let us stop being hypocrites and giving lessons to the world when we are not even able to govern Europe and its constituent countries well.

name: Milan ZVER
text: – The first pan-European games are being organised in Baku, where more than 6 000 young people will want to achieve their best results. Like any game, these have another remarkable added value – that is, to connect Europeans with the universal language of peace represented by sport. That's how I've always imagined the mission of sport. Even as a young man, I was hit hard by the boycott of the two Olympic Games in the 1980s, and some less young people will remember that. When, as the competent sport of the Ministerial Council of the European Union in 2008, I was surprised by the question of whether the European Union would boycott the Beijing Olympic Games because of China's violation of human rights and freedoms in Tibet, I immediately rejected this possibility, as a boycott would do more harm to the Chinese people, including the Tibetan people, than to the authorities. A boycott would miss the overall cultural effects that such an event brings in the environment where the games take place. Interestingly, the same view was later defended by the Tibetan religious leader Dalai Lama. Today, we have once again linked this sporting event in Baku to the violation of human rights and freedoms. This is a legitimate, while a legitimate debate on the human rights situation in Azerbaijan is certainly always welcome, as is in other countries, including within the European Union. This must remain our common concern and one of our priorities. However, perhaps the Games will have a positive impact on the development of a democratic culture, and our enduring task is to monitor Azerbaijan regularly in terms of respect for human rights and freedoms, not just when the Games are there.

name: Soraya POST
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Major sporting events should of course be a neutral place where the sport and sporting performance are at the center. Unfortunately, this is at risk when the competitions are being held in countries with dubious democracies, where the Games are turning into a political tool for the regime to legitimise human rights violations.  The Council and the High Representative for Foreign Affairs should clearly call on the European Olympic Committee to make demands on host countries to ensure respect for human rights. When the European Olympic Committee fails to assume its responsibility for this in the run-up to the Games in Baku, it is all the more important that the EUROPEAN Union now sends a clear signal about this – not least in support of the forces fighting for human rights within the country.  One problem that has occurred at all major sporting events regardless of the host country is the sharp increase in demand for sexual services. Major organisers of sporting events need to clearly condemn prostitution and take greater responsibility for countering an increase as a result of such events. To combat the exploitation of people, in several different areas, from social clean-ups to workers' conditions. These are key criteria for the sustainability and future development of these sporting events.  I believe that europe has a great opportunity to put pressure on this. This also applies to the case mentioned, with Leyla Yunus, for example, and several with her. They had Leyla Yunus as a finalist for our Sakharov Prize simply because of her work for human rights and the values she stood for. Those values and the work that we valued in even being able to honour her, that is what she has been imprisoned for.  I believe that the European Union as an institution must put pressure on and use the expert group set up in May 2011. There are ethical and moral rules that we can push for, this is not worthy of the European Union, not to act.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the so-called interest in Human Rights in Azerbaijan is preliminary, and this is demonstrated first of all by the title of the question which refers generally and insorally to sport and human rights. The reference to human rights issues in Azerbaijan in the question is limited to two of the six paragraphs. Question, which is also vague, since it does not mention specific human rights incidents in Azerbaijan. The aim of the question, as shown by the debate, is the politicisation of sports competitions starting in two days, on Friday, in Baku. Furthermore, a fortnight ago in Brussels, at the mini-session of the European Parliament, we discussed partnership. Because colleagues did not rais these issues at the time. On the contrary in Riga, the leaders of the European Union not only did not address the issues of human rights protection in Azerbaijan, but instead co-signed a joint declaration on democracy and human rights. Responsible for monitoring human rights incidents is the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe, which has a monitoring committee, which will rule on this matter in a fortnight. Do not try, ladies and gentlemen, to pre-understand the decisions of the Council of Europe.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Mr Marias, you heard my comments about Azerbaijan’s judge sitting over the road at the ECHR. What organisation do you think is best placed to most effectively address human rights issues directly with Azerbaijan? Is it Parliament? Is it another European Union institution, or maybe the Council of Europe?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), answer to a question with a "blue card". Mr President, I referred to the fact that the most competent body that monitors human rights issues is the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe, which meets here in Strasbourg, next to us.  And this Convention has a monitoring committee, it has a rapporteur on the issue of Azerbaijan, it goes on the ground and investigates, so it is this competent committee that will recommend to the Council of Europe on this issue, with evidence and concrete decisions. We must take this seriously.  And I explained that in 20 days this committee will meet. This debate is therefore pre-formal in order to create a prerequisite decision, if any, on the decision to be taken in the Council of Europe. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Laura AGEA
text: Blue card question. I wanted to ask Mr Marias whether he is aware of further developments in Azerbaijan, where the osce, Council of Europe and UN offices no longer have interlocutors, why they have all been arrested and where, above all, the OSCE office has been closed and the representatives of these institutions are considered uninvited guests.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), answer to a question with a "blue card". – I wanted to inform my colleague that because, before I was elected as a Member of the European Parliament and a member of the Council of Europe, I know that these procedures exist. If it is the way it says it, which it is not, the rapporteur responsible for these matters will be able to present them there in a fortnight' s time, there will be a special debate, not half an hour into the debate here, but several hours, to take a decision.  Let me just point out, Mr President, that who is going to benefit from the situation that is currently being created, or will it be created in Azerbaijan when Azerbaijan is isolated, when it is the organisation that supports Europe's energy security with the TDP? Who will benefit from the dissolution of the Eastern Partnership? These questions must be able to be answered, politically, by colleagues.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Mr President, the Azerbaijani authorities are eager to host high-level, high-visibility international events. They bring status, visitors and media attention. But the limelight of the European Games cannot and will not overshadow the very troubling human rights situation in Azerbaijan, where an unprecedented number of people are imprisoned. Opposition leaders, journalists, human rights defenders – and really anyone who is critical – risk intimidation and imprisonment, and some of the brightest minds have now fled the country. It is not appropriate to have EU officials participating in ceremonies starting in a couple of days, so long as political prisoners are not released. After all, the label ‘European’ should mean something. When rights are respected, we can build a much more powerful and meaningful partnership between the EU and Azerbaijan. In the meantime we will not forget the political prisoners, and we urge the Azerbaijani authorities to release them as soon as possible and to allow human rights NGOs, such as Amnesty International, access to the country.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – In just a few days, the first Ever European Games will be launched, with 6,000 athletes from 50 countries competing for valuable metals and participating in the Rio Olympics. The decision to play this sporting event in Baku, Azerbaijan, was made in December 2012. Of the 48 representatives of the individual Olympic committees, 38 voted in favour of hosting these Games in Baku. I therefore believe that Azerbaijan's mandate to host this event is strong enough and should not be questioned here. The European Parliament has the right to express its opinion on the human rights situation in the country, but it should realise that this upcoming event is primarily sporting in nature. Therefore, I could not support any resolution, especially before the Council of Europe, which I think is much more competent on this, will sit on this. Finally, let me wish the Czech sports team good luck in Baku. I hope that the European Games will be a feast of sport and will not be politicised in any way.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, we have just talked about corruption and human rights violations of FIFA, but what a signal do other European sports leaders when selecting Azerbaijan to host the European games, turning a blind eye to censorship and repression and giving President Aliyev what he wants: favourable publicity and respectability, to which oil money can buy.  As preparations for the games in Baku are finalised, azerbaijani authorities are trying to prosecute and detain journalists and human rights defenders, prohibiting them from traveling and also freezing their assets. I would like to break down the cases of Intigam Aliyev and Khadija Ismail for documenting cases of political prisoners and corruption in power; Anar Mammadli, Bashir Suleymanli and Elnur Mammadov for monitoring the 2013 presidential elections; Leyla Yunus and her husband, Arif, for criticizing the government, and Rasul Jafarov for creating the "Sports for Rights" organization. Just yesterday, ominosamente, was ordered the closure of the OSCE office in Baku and today Amnesty International was prevented from entering the country. The EU is a key partner for Azerbaijan in energy, trade and political dialogue, but it is precisely with our partners that we must further promote our values. European Union leaders should not participate in the opening ceremonies of the European Games in Baku.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: – Mr President, I would like to start by wishing all of the individual participants in the European Games well. The oral question we have put to the Council quite rightly points out that sporting events have a transcending potential and can contribute to nobler causes such as human rights and, indeed, peace itself. We therefore trust that the point has been made to the European External Action Service and the Council by the special representative, Mr Lambrinidis, who was in Azerbaijan as recently as February. Yet we have seen, particularly in the run-up to the Games, that there is a confirmed pattern of systematic deficiencies, especially as far as freedom of expression is concerned. The Council of Europe Commissioner for Human Rights has said on the record, ‘All of my partners in Azerbaijan are in jail.’ The list includes Leyla Yunus, Hilal Mammadov, Intigam Aliyev, Rasul Jafarov – and it goes on. This is a very long list indeed. To our friends in Azerbaijan our message is simple:  you are absolutely right in seeing the Baku European Games as a spotlight on Azerbaijan. It is now up to you to use or not to use this unique opportunity to demonstrate that Azerbaijan truly adheres to the international commitments on human rights that it has signed up to. It is up to you to demonstrate whether there is a community of values that binds us, or not.

name: Boris ZALA
text: – Mr President, there is a fine line between major sports events and politics. There is no doubt that Azerbaijani President Aliyev is using the organisation of the European games as a way to promote his country’s international prestige, as did Putin with the Sochi Winter Olympics, Lukashenko with the ice hockey world championship and as other countries have done as well. However, I have a problem with mixing politics and sport too much – for instance, denying countries the right to host such events or boycotting them. It is counter-productive. Isolation is generally not a good policy when it comes to promoting human rights. We must raise our voice for human rights. But the notion that the Olympic Games, or other sporting events, are only for fully-fledged liberal democracies is wrong, because it means denying them to the majority of sports fans around the world.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: – A large part of the critical opinions expressed today must be accepted, but they are right, but above all very, very late. Just this event will take place. By condemning all sorts of aspects, we should not address these words so often to Azerbaijan, but to the European Olympic Committee, because it is the European Olympic Committee that has decided, and we have just heard, what a predominance of votes. Financial considerations were certainly at stake, of course. Meanwhile, I think it's a sporting event. But let us not condemn the event, let us not politicise sport, let us not take away the satisfaction of the athletes: let them be convinced – the medal won there has value. However, it is an opportunity to get in touch, an opportunity to also point out to Azerbaijan all sorts of irregularities in the way the state is run. But bypassing and ignoring Azerbaijan, we make the dictator only stronger.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – I listened very carefully to the whole debate. I must say that I am disappointed by the speech of the Representative of the Council. I would expect harsher and clearer words, Minister, to address Azerbaijan, especially if you are from a country that has its experiences with the communist regime. I say this as a person and a Member of the Czech Republic who has also experienced her own. I think that we must use these games to harshly condemn Azerbaijan and how the regime there violates human rights. A few weeks ago, I interpelling the Commission on the fate of a journalist in Azerbaijan, Chadiji Ismail, who, only because she was examining the property situation of the president there in the Czech Republic, was unlawfully accused and arrested. These are dozens of cases where miscarriages of justice or deliberate attempts are made to use the judiciary to suppress political opponents, suppress journalists and suppress human rights defenders.  Let us de-azerbaijan, let us use the Games to make it clear that it is not possible to tolerate the suppression of human rights.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, hosting the Olympic Games is an honour and a very prestigious reason for each country. It means having the spotlight on you, becoming a destination for athletes, fans but also institutional representatives. It means, in short, becoming accredited and credible interlocutors. It seems a well-established trend now that countries rich in natural resources but poor in respect for fundamental freedoms use sporting events to promote their national brand through the ball. Azerbaijan is certainly not a champion of rights, yet it will host the first European Olympic Games. In the palaces the party, in the prisons the political dissidents. Now the boycott of the games would only be to the detriment of the many athletes who train with constancy, seriousness and commitment for these competitions. But political action in the political forums is appropriate, rather than appropriate. International rights and consideration are not bought, either by gas or by oil.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: – Mr President, let us look at the question posed: sport and politics. The Azerbaijani authorities are being questioned precisely because they want to gain political credit – but is it also right to invite what is really a propaganda attack against the Azerbaijani Government on the subject of human rights precisely at the time of these games? These are Olympic Games. Historically, when Olympic Games took place, hostilities were ceased. It was an occasion to try to come together, and I venture to say that if there were not this preparation for such an onslaught, there would not have been this harsh regime, which we cannot accept, of course. But we have to question what brought it about in this particular case.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, (you can't hear) the games. I wish success to all athletes. As a member of the Croatian Olympic Committee, I can say that I really hope that the first European Games will be a great manifestation of sports, the success of European sport which, as we know, has fantastic athletes and athletes.  But what needs to be said definitively here: Azerbaijan is certainly a country where human rights and media freedom and all that are our European values continue to be violated. That is why this debate is necessary here in Parliament. But also as a country that plays an important role in its region, I agree with the Council's position that Azerbaijan should not experience our isolation because it certainly would not be good in the short or long term.  We know what kind of things have happened. It is our obligation to warn about human rights violations, to insist on it in every conversation, but at the same time to try to use these games as a guideline on how to solve the state of relations and the Eastern Partnership that we so strongly advocate.

name: Laura AGEA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, while the spotlight will be on baku tomorrow for the opening of the first European Olympic Games, the cells of Azerbaijani prisons, where almost a hundred Azerbaijani political prisoners are locked up, will be dark. The twentieth century was generous in passing on to us a trail of global sporting events that were worn out and abused by dictators. The first, in alphabetical order, was the Berlin Olympics of 1936; back then, Hitler emerged as an enlightened dictator. Today, however, Aliyev is using sport to legitimise his dictatorship. In Azerbaijan, the OSCE, the Council of Europe and the UN no longer have interlocutors because they are systematically arrested by the regime. Ladies and gentlemen, Leyla Yunus, who was accused of high treason with her husband for promoting initiatives aimed at dialogue between Azerbaijani and Armenian civil societies. Having said that, we call on the Commission to express a clear position of boycott of the opening ceremony by the Heads of State or Government of the Member States. The European Union's inaction towards Azerbaijan is an application of double standards that corrodes our credibility. Our indifference would make us complicit. The day after tomorrow, the spotlight must be on the cells of Azerbaijani prisoners.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, Minister, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The European Olympic Committee awarded Azerbaijan the first European Games in December 2012. These games will open on Friday of this week. 6 000 athletes from 50 countries will take part and compete in 20 sports. Even a team from Armenia is there, despite the conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh. The European Games are a kind of European Olympic Games, and Azerbaijan has made enormous efforts – especially financial efforts – to meet the strict requirements of the European Olympic Committee. Eur 820 million alone went into the operational budget for equipping the Games, and billions of euros in infrastructure, especially in construction, totalling around six billion euros. From a political point of view, Azerbaijan has been involved in the European Neighbourhood Policy since 2004 and has been a member of the European Eastern Partnership since May 2009. Azerbaijan and Europe are important strategic partners. For the period 2014-2015, the EU has allocated €3 million to support civil society in Azerbaijan. Human rights are important, there is no question about that. Human rights are also in line with the Olympic idea. The Olympic Committee's Agenda 2020 therefore provides for respect for human rights, respect for freedom of the press and safeguarding the protection of minorities in a candidate country. Let us not politicise sport, ladies and gentlemen. I would agree with the Council's assessment – as you said today, Minister: the European Games should be a window of progress between Europe and Azerbaijan in strengthening relations between Europe and Azerbaijan. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Kappel, you have just found that sport and politics should not be mixed up, and you first spoke of Azerbaijan's signing of various human rights conventions, etc. But you have not said a word about this country flouting human rights, especially now that these sporting events are beginning. None of us, at least not those I have heard talking about here, have said that the athletes should not go. But do you think it is okay for the Austrian Second President of the National Council, Mr Kopf, to go now with an economic delegation, to present a minister with a prize and to pretend that nothing is happening there and not people who are fighting for the freedoms that we have here are in prison?

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: As I said, human rights must be upheld, there is no question about that, and human rights are also in line with the Olympic idea. It has been mentioned several times today, as Professor Marias has also said: there are institutions in Europe, in particular the Council of Europe, which can devote themselves to this issue in a competent and comprehensive manner. A half-hour discussion here is certainly not enough to deal with this problem. Please let us have the discussion where it belongs, in this case in the Council of Europe.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I share your concerns regarding the situation of human rights in Azerbaijan and particularly the detention of human rights defenders. The European partnership is a space in which respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms must be guaranteed. I will inform Commissioner Hahn and the High Representative of this discussion and will also convey your concerns to them. I would like to recall that respect for human rights and democracy is a core value of the EU, and we do not hesitate to promote it. The EU, through the European External Action Service, is raising its concerns with the Azerbaijani authorities directly and publicly, irrespective of the European Games. The EU Special Representative for Human Rights, Stavros Lambrinidis, and Commissioner Hahn also raised the EU’s concerns on human rights issues during their recent visits to Baku in February and April respectively. In particular, they called for the fair treatment and release of detained individuals. The EU delegation in Baku, working closely with the embassies of EU Member States, is supporting local human rights defenders, including by applying the EU Guidelines on Human Rights Defenders. Together with like-minded partners, the EU is carefully monitoring the cases – including the court cases – of those in detention. We are also working with the Council of Europe and are hopeful that the joint committee drawn from Azerbaijan’s government and civil society, mediated by the Council of Europe, will deliver positive results. We continue to look actively for other ways in which we can support civil society in Azerbaijan, including those activists and independent journalists currently in detention. As I said at the beginning of the debate, the Baku Games are an excellent opportunity for the Azerbaijani authorities to demonstrate their progressive commitment to democratic values and human rights. We hope this opportunity will not be missed.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – Large sporting events take on a dimension that goes far beyond the sporting realm. The purpose of this oral question is to highlight the importance and potential that these events can and should have in contributing substantially to the defence of human rights. The European Games in Baku, Azerbaijan, the first of its kind, are held between 12 and 28 June. The United Nations warns of the relentless persecution of opponents, human rights defenders and journalists in the country, whose civil society has been eradicated, silenced. This crackdown has increased as the date of the Games approached. Sport cannot live oblivious to the defence of human rights, and Europe cannot come forward in Baku to applaud while we are aware of the suffering of the Aliyev government, especially those who have the voice against it. We call for the release of all prisoners of conscience in Azerbaijan and hope that, with the collaboration of governments and sports federations, respect for human rights will finally become a key element in deciding the venues of the great sporting events of the future.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The European Games in Baku have at first sight only the name European. Indeed, this year, Azerbaijan will host the European Games and invest more than one billion euros even as many evils affect this country. As a result, many wastes and corruption are reported, 50% of students have too low an educational level, living conditions are sometimes difficult and the price of medicines (often fakes) is far too high for a population that is in dire need of it. As with the awarding of the 2022 World Cup to Qatar or the Summer Olympics to China, this award allows an autocratic regime such as Azerbaijan to redeem itself from conduct and legitimize itself. Refusing to interfere, however, I can see a degraded situation regarding freedom of expression (ranked 162/180 states according to RSF) and endemic corruption (noted 29/100 according to Transparency International). Until recently, the country called on the OSCE to close its office in Baku, banned several European journalists from the Games, or imprisoned journalist Khadija Ismailova, author of several books on state corruption.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. "This text seems to me quite out of place and to tell the truth, smoky. Indeed, major sporting events are not intended to "advance the protection and promotion of human rights", at a time when these generous principles are being abused in their own countries of origin.  There are other points that catch my eye. On the one hand, the mass corruption that is observed for the designation of host cities or countries, the clearest example being the 2022 Football World Cup in Doha, Qatar. This week's fifa debate should keep us on alert.  On the other hand, our Parliament could question the place of sport in our society. These are games, like the games that entertained the Roman plebe in the Lower Empire, a consumption of spectacle far more than the practice of effort by the citizens themselves. Let Azerbaijan give the sense it wants to its European Games and let us care about the practice rather than the consumption of sport in our societies.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. – Large sporting events take on a dimension that goes far beyond the sporting realm. The purpose of this oral question is to highlight the importance and potential that these events can and should have in contributing substantially to the defence of human rights. The European Games in Baku, Azerbaijan, the first of its kind, are held between 12 and 28 June. This crackdown has increased as the date of the Games approached. We call for the release of all prisoners of conscience in Azerbaijan and hope that, with the collaboration of governments and sports federations, respect for human rights will finally become a key element in deciding the venues of the great sporting events of the future.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing – Every major sporting event at international level, which in addition is mediated by television and radio broadcasts, attracts a great deal of attention from athletes, sports fans, but also citizens who are only passive observers. They bring great attention and popularity to the country where sporting events and games are organized. Participants in the games, as well as viewers, will also learn a lot about the country, its history, its present, but also the politicians who run the country. I therefore believe that it is also necessary to use the European Games in Baku to draw the world's attention to human rights violations in Azerbaijan and the closure of journalists who point to non-compliance with the law. Visitors to the Games, athletes can also use the space to discuss with the people of Baku how human rights are being violated in their state. Isolation of Azerbaijan would harm its people who want to live in a democratic society.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. – The world of sport is globally dominated by money, aggressive commercialisation, corruption and politicisation – instead of being an activity aimed at boosting the positive achievements of young people and their ambitions to reach new horizons of their physical and mental capacities. That is why every important sports event in countries which are outside of the mainstream political power and strategy games in the world becomes a matter of lively political controversy. Azerbaijan is certainly not a country with the highest standard of respect for democratic values, such as human rights, the rule of law and freedom of expression, but it is nevertheless a country which can proudly display its commitment to secular values, religious tolerance and gender equality. Instead of continually exposing Azerbaijan to criticism which barely takes account of its complex geopolitical situation and the fact that a large part of its national territory is occupied by neighbouring Armenia – with the assistance of Russian troops stationed on its territory – the EU should do much more to boost dialogue with Baku and contribute to a just solution to the Nagorno-Karabakh dispute. The Games in Baku should be left to the athletes!
